hom.sense: The second letter of the alphabet: called baMCN and baA; (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np;) the latter of which forms is used in spelling; like as are its analogues, as tA [and vA] and HA [and xA and rA] and TA [and ZA and fA and hA] and yA; because in this case they are not generally regarded as nouns, but as mere sounds: (Sb, M:) [these are generally pronounced with imáleh, i. e. bé, té, &c., with the exception of HA, xA, TA, and ZA; and when they are regarded as nouns, their duals are bayaAni, tayaAni, &c.:] the pl. of baMCN is baMCaAtN; and that of baA is OabowaMCN (TA ubi suprà.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrah [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; and of those termed Xafahiy-ap [or labial]; and of those termed culoq [or pronounced with the extremity of the tongue or the lips]: Kh says that the letters of the second and third classes above mentioned [the latter of which comprises the former] are those composing the words rub-a mano laf-a; and on account of their easiness of utterance, they abound in the composition of words, so that no perfect quinqueliteral-radical word is without one or more of them, unless it is of the class termed muwal-ad, not of the classical language of the Arabs. (TA at the commencement of bAb AlbMC.)
In the dial. of Mázin, it is changed into m; (TA ubi suprà;) as in bak-apu, which thus becomes mak-apu [the town of Mekkeh]. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)

bi is a preposition, or particle governing the gen. case; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) having kesr for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a letter after which one makes a pause; (Ṣ;) or, correctly speaking, having a vowel for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a quiescent letter; and having kesr, not fet-ḥ, to make it accord with its government [of the gen. case], and to distinguish between it and that which is both a noun and a particle. (IB.) It is used to denote adhesion (Sb, T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ) of the verb to its objective complement, (Ṣ,) or of a noun or verb to that to which it is itself prefixed; (TA;) and adjunction, or association: (Sb, T:) and some say that its meaning of denoting adhesion is inseparable from it; and therefore Sb restricted himself to the mention of this meaning: (Mughnee:) or Sb says that its primary meaning is that of denoting adhesion and mixture. (Ibn-Es-Sáïgh, quoted in a marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) It denotes adhesion [&c.] in the proper sense; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in Oamosakotu bizayodK, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) meaning I laid hold upon, or seized, [Zeyd, or] somewhat of the body of Zeyd, or what might detain him, as an arm or a hand, or a garment, and the like; whereas Oamosakotuhu may mean I withheld him, or restrained him, from acting according to his own free will: (Mughnee:) and it denotes the same in a tropical sense; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd]; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) as though meaning I made my passing to adhere to Zeyd; (Ṣ;) or I made my passing to adhere to a place near to Zeyd: accord. to Akh, it is for mararotu EalaIi zayodK; but mararotu bihi is more common than mararotu Ealayohi, and is therefore more properly regarded as the original form of expression: (Mughnee:) accord. to F, the vowel of this preposition is kesr [when it is prefixed to a noun or a pronoun]; or, as some say, it is fet-ḥ when it is with a noun properly so called; as in mar-a bazayodK: so in the Ḳ; this being the reverse of what they have prescribed in the case of [the preposition] l: but in the case of b, no vowel but kesr is known. (MF.) It denotes the same in the saying bihi daMCN [In him is a disease; i. e. a disease is cleaving to him]: and so [accord. to some] in Oaqosamotu bQll-ehi [I swore, or, emphatically, I swear, by God; and similar phrases, respecting which see a later division of this paragraph]. (L.) So, too, in OaXoraka bQll-ehi, because meaning He associated another with God: and in wak-alotu bifulaAnK, meaning I associated a wakiyl [or factor, &c.] with such a one. (T.) [And so in other phrases here following.] Ealayoka bizayodK Keep thou to Zeyd: or take thou Zeyd. (TA voce EalaI.) Ealayoka bikacaA Keep thou to such a thing: (El-Munáwee:) or take thou such a thing. (Ḥam p. 216.) fabahaA wanaEomato Keep thou to it, fbhA meaning faEalayoka bihaA, (Mgh in art. nEm,) [or let him keep to it, i. e. faEalayohi bihaA,] or thou hast taken to, or adopted and followed, or adhered to, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, i. e. fabiQls-un-api Oaxacata, (Mgh,) or he hath taken to,, &c., i. e. fabiQls-un-api Oaxaca, (IAth, TA in art. nEm,) or by this practice, or action, is excellence attained, or he will attain excellence, i. e. fabihecihi AlxaSolapi Oawi AlfaEolapi yunaAlu AlfaDolu, or yanaAlu AlfaDola; (IAth ubi suprà;) and excellent is the practise, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, wnEmt meaning waniEomati AlxaSolapu Als-un-apu, (Mgh,) or and excellent is the practice, or the action, i. e. waniEomati AlxaSolapu, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. nEm,) or waniEomati AlxaSolapu Ouwi AlfaEolapu: (IAth ubi suprà:) and it also occurs in a trad., where the meaning is [He who hath done such a thing hath adhered to the ordinance of indulgence; and excellent is the practice, or action,, &c.: for here fbhA is meant to imply] fabiQlr-axoSapi Oaxaca. (TA in the present art. See also art. nEm.)

It is also used to render a verb transitive; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) having the same effect as hemzeh [prefixed], in causing [what would otherwise be] the agent to become an objective complement; as in cahabotu bizayodK syn. with Oacohabotuhu [I made Zeyd to go away; or I took him away]; (Mughnee;) and hence, [in the Ḳur ii. 16,] cahaba Qll-ehu binuwrihimo [God taketh away their light]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) which refutes the assertion of Mbr and Suh, that cahabotu bizayodK means [I went away with Zeyd; i. e.] I accompanied Zeyd in going away. (Mughnee.) J says that any verb that is not trans. you may render so by means of bi and A [prefixed] and reduplication [of the medial radical letter]: you say, TaAra bihi and OaTaArahu and Tay-arahu [as meaning He made him to fly, or to fly away]: but IB says that this is not correct as of common application; for some verbs are rendered trans. by means of hemzeh, but not by reduplication; and some by reduplication, but not by hemzeh; and some by b, but not by hemzeh nor by reduplication: you say, dafaEotu zayodFA biEamorKw [as meaning I made ʼAmr to repel Zeyd, lit. I repelled Zeyd by ʼAmr], but not OadofaEotuhu nor daf-aEotuhu. (TA.)

It also denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument; (Ṣ, M,* Mughnee, Ḳ;*) as in katabotu biAlqalami [I wrote with the reed-pen]; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) and najarotu biAlqaduwmi [I worked as a carpenter with the adz]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and Darabotu bAls-ayofi [I struck with the sword]. (M.) And hence the bi in bisomi Qll-ehi, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to some, because the action [before which it is pronounced] is not practicable in the most perfect manner but by means of it: (Mughnee:) but others disallow this, because the name of God should not be regarded as an instrument: (MF, TA:) and some say that the b here is to denote beginning, as though one said, OabotadaOu bisomi Qll-ehi [I begin with the name of God]. (TA.)

It also denotes a cause; as in Uin-akumo Zalamotumo Oanofusakumo biQt-ixaAcikumu QloEijola [Verily ye have wronged yourselves by, i. e. because of, your taking to yourselves the calf as a god (Ḳur ii. 51)]; and in fakul-FA OaxaconaA bicanobihi [And every one of these we have punished for, i. e. because of, his sin (Ḳur xxix. 39)]; (Mughnee, Ḳ) and in lano yadoxula OaHadakumu Aljan-apa biEamalihi [Not any of you shall enter Paradise by, or for, or because of, his works]. (TA from a trad.) And so in laqaytu bizayodK AlOasada I met, or found, by reason of my meeting, or finding, Zeyd, the lion: (Mughnee:) or the b in this instance denotes comparison; [i. e. I met, or found, in Zeyd the like of the lion;] as also in raOayotu bifulaAnK Alqamara [I saw in such a one the like of the moon]. (TA.)
Another ex. of the same usage is the saying [of a poet],
qado suqiyato MbaAluhumo biAln-aAri
waAln-aAru qado taXofiI mina AlOuwaAri
[Their camels had been watered because of the brand that they bore: for fire, or the brand, sometimes cures of the heat of thirst]; i. e., because of their being branded with the names [or marks] of their owners, they had free access left them to the water. (Mughnee. See also another reading of this verse voce naArN.) [In like manner] it is used in the sense of mino Oajoli [which means bisababi (Mṣb in art. Ajl)] in the saying of Lebeed,
gulobN taXac-ara biAlc-uHuwli kaOan-ahaA
jin-u AlbadiI-i rawaAsiyAF OaqodaAmuhaA
(Ṣ) Thick-necked men, like lions, who threatened one another because of rancorous feelings, as though they were the Jinn of the valley El-Bedee, [or of the desert, (TA in art. bdw,)] their feet standing firm in contention and obstinate altercation. (EM pp. 174 and 175.) It is also used to denote a cause when prefixed to Oan-a and to maA as in celika biOan-ahumo kaAnuwA yakofuruwna biMyaAti Qll-ehi [That was because they used to disbelieve in the signs of God]; and in celika bimaA EaSawoA [That was because they disobeyed]: both instances in the Ḳur ii. 58. (Bḍ.)

It is also used to denote concomitance, as syn. with maEa; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in AiXotarayotu Alfarasa bilijaAmihi wasarojihi [I bought the horse with his bit and bridle and his saddle]; (TA;) and in lam-aA raMniI biAls-alaAHi haraba, i. e. When he saw me advancing with the weapon, [he fled;] or when he saw me possessor of a weapon; (Sh, T;) and in AihobiTo bisalaAmK [Descend thou with security, or with greeting (Ḳur xi. 50)]; and in waqado daxaluwA biQlokufori [They having entered with unbelief (Ḳur v. 66)]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) bAlkfr being a denotative of state. (Bḍ.) Authors differ respecting the b in the saying, fasab-iHo biHamodi rab-ika, in the Ḳur [xv. 98 and ex. 3]; some saying that it denotes concomitance, and that Hmd is prefixed to the objective complement, so that the meaning is, sab-iHohN HaAmidFA lahu [Declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory, praising Him], i. e. declare thou his freedom from that which is not suitable to Him, and ascribe to Him that which is suitable to Him; but others say that it denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and that Hmd is prefixed to the agent, so that the meaning is, sab-iHohu bimaA Hamida bihi nafosahu [declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory by means of ascribing to Him that wherewith He hath praised himself]: and so, too, respecting the saying, suboHaAnaka Qll-ehum-a wabiHamodika; some asserting that it is one proposition, the, being redundant; but others saying, it is two propositions, the w being a conjunction, and the verb upon which the b is dependent being suppressed, so that the meaning is, [I declare thy freedom from everything derogatory from thy glory, 0 God,] wabiHamodika sab-aHotuka [and with the praising of Thee, or by means of the praise that belongeth to Thee, I declare thy freedom, &c.]. (Mughnee. [Other explanations of these two phrases have been proposed; but those given above are the most approved.]) You also say, EalaI-a bihi, meaning Bring thou him, [i. e.] come with him, to me. (Ḥar p. 109.) DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu bimaA raHubato, in the Ḳur ix. 119, means biruHobihaA [i. e. The earth became strait to them, with, meaning notwithstanding, its amplitude, or spaciousness]. (Bḍ.) Sometimes the negative lA intervenes between bi [denoting concomitance] and the noun governed by it in the gen. case; [so that bilaA signifies Without;] as in jiYotu bilaA zaAdK [I came without travelling-provision]. (Mughnee and Ḳ in art. lA.)

It is also syn. with fiI before a noun signifying a place or a time; (Mughnee,* Ḳ,* TA;) as in jalasotu biAlmasojidi [I sat in the mosque]; (TA;) and walaqado naSarakumu Qll-ehu bibadorK [And verily God aided you against your enemies at Bedr (Ḳur iii. 119)]; and naj-ayonaAhumo bisaHarK [We saved them a little before daybreak (Ḳur liv. 34)]: (Mughnee, Ḳ, TA:) and so in biOay-ikumu Qlomafotuwnu (T, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [lxviii. 6], (TA,) accord. to some, (T, Mughnee,) i. e. In which of you is madness; or in which of the two parties of you is the mad: (Bḍ:) or the b is here redundant; (Sb, Bḍ, Mughnee;) the meaning being which of you is he who is afflicted with madness. (Bḍ. [See also a later division of this paragraph.])

It also denotes substitution; [meaning Instead of, or in place of;] as in the saying [of the Hamásee (Mughnee)],
falayota liI bihimu qawomFA UicaA rakibuwA
Xan-awA AlUigaArapa furosaAnFA warukobaAnaA
[Then would that I had, instead of them, a people who, when they mounted their beasts, poured the sudden attack, they being horsemen and camel-riders]; (Ḥam p. 8, Mughnee, Ḳ;) i. e., badalFA bihimo (TA:) but some read Xad-uwA AlUigaArapa, [and so it is in some, app., the most correct, of the copies of the Mughnee,] for Xad-uwA liloUigaAripi [hastened for the making a sudden attack]. (Ḥam, Mughnee.) So, too, in the saying, AiEotaDotu biheciA Alv-awobi xayorFA minohu [I received, in the place of this garment, or piece of cloth, one better than it]; and laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]; and hecaA bicaAki [This is instead, or in the place, of that; but see another explanation of this last phrase in what follows]. (The Lubáb, TA.)

It also denotes requital; or the giving, or doing, in return; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and in this case is prefixed to the word signifying the substitute, or thing given or done in exchange [or return; or to the word signifying that for which a substitute is given, or for which a thing is given or done in exchange or return]; (Mughnee;) as in the saying, AiXotarayotuhu biOalofi dirohamK [I purchased it for a thousand dirhems]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) [and in the saying in the Ḳur ix. 112, Uin-a Qll-eha QXotarI mina QlomuWominiyna Oanofusahumo waOamowaAlahumo biOan-a lahumu Qlojan-apa Verily God hath purchased of the believers their souls and their possessions for the price of their having Paradise;] and kaAfaOotu UiHosaAnahu biDiEofK [I requited his beneficence with a like beneficence, or with double, or more], (Mughnee,) or kaAfOotuhu biDiEofi UiHosaAnihi [I requited him with the like, or with double the amount, or with more than double the amount, of his beneficence], (Ḳ,) but the former is preferable; (TA;) [and xadama biTaEaAmi biTonihi (Ṣ and A, &c. in art. wgd) He served for, meaning in return for, the food of his belly;] and
hecaA bicaAka walaA EatobN EalaI Alz-amani
[This is in return for that, (an explanation somewhat differing from one in the next preceding division of this paragraph,) and no blame is imputable to fortune]: and hence, AudoxuluwA Qljan-apa bimaA kunotumo taEomaluwna [Enter ye Paradise in return for that which ye wrought (Ḳur xvi. 34)]; for the b here is not that which denotes a cause, as the Moatezileh assert it to be, and as all [of the Sunnees] hold it to be in the saying of the Prophet, lano yadoxula OaHadukumu Aljan-apa biEamalihi [before cited and explained]; because what is given instead of something is sometimes given gratuitously; and it is evident that there is no mutual opposition between the trad. and the verse of the Ḳur-án. (Mughnee.)

It is also syn. with Eano; and is said to be peculiar to interrogation; as in faQsoOalo bihi xabiyrFA [And ask thou respecting Him, or it, one possessing knowledge (Ḳur xxv. 60)]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and accord. to IAạr in the Ḳur lxx. 1; (T;) and in the saying of 'Alkameh,
faUino tasoOaluwniI biAln-isaMCi faUin-aniI
baSiyrN biOadowaMCi Aln-isaMCi xabiyru
[And if ye ask me respecting the diseases of women, verily I am knowing in the diseases of women, skilful]: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or it is not peculiar to interrogation; as in wayawoma taXaq-aqu Qls-amaMCu biQlogamaAmi [And the day when the heavens shall be rent asunder from the clouds (Ḳur xxv. 27)]; (Mughnee, Ḳ) and maA gar-aka birab-ika (Ḳ) i. e. What hath beguiled thee from thy Lord, and from believing in him? in the Ḳur lxxxii. 6; and so in the same, lvii. 13: (TA: [but see art. gr:]) or, accord. to Z, the b in bAlgmAm means by, as by an instrument; (Mughnee;) or it means because of, or by means of, the rising of the clouds therefrom: (Bḍ:) and in like manner the Basrees explain it as occurring in faQsoOalo bihi xabiyrFA, as denoting the cause; and they assert that it is never syn. with Eano; but their explanation is improbable. (Mughnee.)

It is also syn. with EalaIi; as in Uino tiOomanohu biqinoTaArK (Mughnee, Ḳ *) or bidiynaArK (Ṣ) [If thou give him charge over a hundredweight or over a deenár (Ḳur iii. 68)]; like as EalaI is sometimes put in the place of bi as after the verb raDiIa: (Ṣ, TA:) and so in lawo tusaw-aI bihimu QloOaroDu [That the ground were made even over them], in the Ḳur [iv. 45], (TA,) i. e. that they were buried; (Bḍ)
and in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd], accord. to Akh, as before mentioned; (Mughnee, in the first division of the art. on this preposition;) and in zayodN biAls-aToHi [Zeyd is on the roof]; (TA;) and in a verse cited in this Lex. voce vaEolabN. (Mughnee.)

It also denotes part of a whole; (Mṣb in art. bED Mughnee, Ḳ;) so accord. to Aṣ and AAF and others; (Mṣb, Mughnee;) as syn. with mino (Mṣb, TA:) IḲt says; the Arabs say, Xaribotu bimaMCi kacaA, meaning minohu [I drank of such a water]; and AZ mentions, as a saying of the Arabs, saqaAka Qll-ehu mino maMCi kacaA, meaning bihi [May God give thee to drink of such a water], thus making the two prepositions syn.: (Mṣb: [in which five similar instances are cited from poets; and two of these are cited also in the Mughnee:]) and thus it signifies in EayonFA yaXorabu bihaA EibaAdu Qll-ehi [A fountain from which the servants of God shall drink, in the Ḳur lxxvi. 6; and the like occurs in lxxxiii. 28]; (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ;) accord. to the authorities mentioned above; (Mughnee;) or the meaning is, with which the servants of God shall satisfy their thirst (yarowaI bihaA); (T, Mughnee;) or, accord. to Z, with which the servants of God shall drink wine: (Mughnee:) if the b were redundant, [as some assert it to be, (Bḍ,)] the meaning would be, that they shall drink the whole of it; which is not right: (Mṣb:) thus, also, it is used in waQmosaHuwA biruWuLsikumo [in the Ḳur v. 8], (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to some; (Mughnee;) i. e. [And wipe ye] a part of your heads; and this explanation has been given as on the authority of EshSháfi'ee; but he is said to have disapproved it, and to have held that the b here denotes adhesion: (TA:) this latter is its apparent meaning in this and the other instances: or, as some say, in this last instance it is used to denote the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and there is an ellipsis in the phrase, and an inversion; the meaning being, AimosaHuwA ruWuLsakumo biAlmaMCi [wipe ye your heads with water]. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to denote swearing; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and is the primary one of the particles used for this purpose; therefore it is peculiarly distinguished by its being allowable to mention the verb with it, (Mughnee,) as Ouqosimu biQll-ehi laOafoEalan-a [I swear by God I will assuredly do such a thing]; (Mughnee, Ḳ) and by its being prefixed to a pronoun, as in bika laOafoEalan-a [By thee I will assuredly do such a thing]; and by its being used in adjuring, or conjuring, for the purpose of inducing one to incline to that which is desired of him, as in bQll-ehi halo qaAma zayodN, meaning I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by God, to tell me, did Zeyd stand? (Mughnee.) [See also the first explanation of this particle, where it is said, on the authority of the L, that, when thus used, it denotes adhesion.]

It is also syn. with UilaI as denoting the end of an extent or interval; as in OaHosana biI, meaning He did good, or acted well, to me: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) but some say that the verb here imports the meaning of laTafa [which is trans. by means of b, i. e. he acted graciously, or courteously, with me]. (Mughnee.)

It is also redundant, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) to denote corroboration: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and is prefixed to the agent: (Mughnee:) first, necessarily; as in OaHosino bizayodK; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) accord. to general opinion (Mughnee) originally OaHosana zayodN, i. e. SaAra caA HusonK [Zeyd became possessed of goodness, or goodliness, or beauty]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) or the correct meaning is Hasuna zayodN [Good, or goodly, or beautiful, or very good, &c., is Zeyd! or how good, or goodly, or beautiful, is Zeyd!], as in the B: (TA:) secondly, in most instances; and this is in the case of the agent of kafaI; as in kafaI biQll-ehi XahiydFA [God sufficeth, being witness, or as a witness (Ḳur xiii., last verse;, &c.)]; (Mughnee, Ḳ [and a similar ex. is given in the Ṣ, from the Ḳur xxv. 33;]) the b here denoting emphatic praise; but you may drop it, saying, kafaI Qll-ehu XahiydFA: (Fr, TA:) thirdly, in a case of necessity, by poetic licence; as in the saying,
Oalamo yaOotiyka waAlOanobaMCu tanomiI
bimaA laAqato labuwnu baniI ziyaAdi
[Did not what the milch camel of the sons of Ziyád experienced come to thee (yaOotiyka being in like manner put for yaOotika) when the tidings were increasing?]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the objective complement of a verb; as in walaA tuloquwA biOayodykumo UilaI Qlt-aholukapi [And cast ye not yourselves (bOydykm meaning biOanofusikumo) to perdition (Ḳur ii. 191)]; and in wahuz-iI Uilayoki bijicoEi Aln-axolapi [And shake thou towards thee the trunk of the palm-tree (Ḳur xix. 25)]: but some say that the former means and cast ye not yourselves (Oanofusakumo being understood) with your hands to perdition; or that the meaning is, by means, or because, of your hands: (Mughnee:) and ISd says that huz-iI, in the latter, is made trans. by means of b because it is used in the sense of juz-iI: (TA in art hz:) so, too, in the saying,
naDoribu biAls-ayofi wanarjuw biAlfarajo
[We smite with the sword, and we hope for the removal of grief]: (Ṣ, Mughnee:) and in the trad., kafaI biAlmaroCi kacibFA Oano yuHad-iva bikul-i maA samiEa [It suffices the man in respect of lying that he relate all that he has heard]. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the inchoative; as in biHasobika [when you say, biHasobika dirohamN, meaning A thing sufficing thee is a dirhem; a phrase which may be used in two ways; as predicating of what is sufficient, that it is a dirhem; and as predicating of a dirhem, that it is sufficient; in which latter case, bHsbk is an enunciative put before its inchoative, so that the meaning is, a dirhem is a thing sufficing thee, i. e. a dirhem is sufficient for thee; as is shown in a marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee: in the latter way is used the saying, mentioned in the Ṣ, biHasobika qawolu Als-awoCi A thing sufficing thee is the saying what is evil: and so, app., each of the following sayings, mentioned in the TA on the authority of Fr; Hasobuka biSadiyqinaA A person sufficing thee is our friend; and naAhiyka biOaxiynaA A person sufficing thee is our brother: the b is added, as Fr says, to denote emphatic praise]: so too in xarajotu faUiciA bizayodK [I went forth, and lo, there, or then, was Zeyd]; and in kayofa bika UicaA kaAna kacaA [How art thou, or how wilt thou be, when it is thus, or when such a thing is the case?]; and so, accord. to Sb, in biOy-ikumu Qlomafotuwnu [mentioned before, in explanation of bi as syn. with fiI]; but Abu-l-Ḥasan says that bOy-km is dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, denoting the predicate of Aalmftwn; and some say that this is an inf. n. in the sense of finonapN; [so that the meaning may be, bOay-ikumu Almafotuwnu musotaqir-N In which of you is madness residing?]; or, as some say, bi is here syn. with fiI [as I have before mentioned], (Mughnee.) A strange case is that of its being added before that which is originally an inchoative, namely, the noun, or subject, of layosa, on the condition of its being transferred to the later place which is properly that of the enunciative; as in the reading of some, [wujuwhakumo layosa Qlbir-a biOano tuwal-uwA qabala QlomaXoriqi waQlomagoribi] [Your turning your faces towards the east and the west is not obedience (Ḳur ii. 172)]; with Albr- in the accus. case. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the enunciative; and this is in two kinds of cases: first, when the phrase is not affirmative; and cases of this kind may be followed as exs.; as layosa zayodN biqaAYimK [Zeyd is not standing]; and wamaA Qll-ehu bigaAfilK Eam-aA taEomaluwna [And God is not heedless of that which ye do (Ḳur ii. 69, &c.)]: secondly, when the phrase is affirmative; and in cases of this kind, one limits himself to what has been heard [from the Arabs]: so say Akh and his followers; and they hold to be an instance of this kind the phrase, jazaMCu say-iYapK bimivolihaA [The recompense of an evil action is the like thereof (Ḳur x. 28)]; and the saying of the Hamásee,
wamanoEukahaA biXaIoCK yusotaTaAEu
[And the preventing thee from having her (referring to a mare) is a thing that is possible]: but it is more proper to make bmvlhA dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, as the enunciative; [the meaning being, jazaMCu say-aYapK musotaqir-N bimivolihaA, or yasotaqir-u bimivolihaA, i. e. the recompense of an evil action is a thing consisting in the like thereof]; and to make bXIC dependent upon mnEkhA; the meaning being, wamanoEukahaA biXaIoCK m-aA yusotaTaAEu [i. e. and the preventing thee from having her, by something, is possible: see Ḥam p. 102]: Ibn-Málik also [holds, like Akh and his followers, that bi may be redundant when prefixed to the enunciative in an affirmative proposition; for he] says, respecting biHasobika zayodN, that zyd is an inchoative placed after its enunciative, [so that the meaning is, Zeyd is a person sufficing thee,] because zayodN is determinate and Hasobuka is indeterminate. (Mughnee. [See also what has been said above respecting the phrase biHasobika dirohamN, in treating of bi as added before the inchoative.])
It is also redundantly prefixed to the denotative of state of which the governing word is made negative; as in
famaA rajaEato bixaAYibapK rikaAbN
Hakiymu bonu Almusay-abi munotahaAhaA
[And travelling-camels (meaning their riders) returned not disappointed, whose goal, or ultimate object, was Hakeem the son of El-Museiyab]; and in
famaA QnobaEavota bimazoWudK walaA wakali
[And thou didst not, being sent, or roused, go away frightened, nor impotent, committing thine affair to another]: so says Ibn-Málik: but AḤei disagrees with him, explaining these two exs. as elliptical; the meaning implied in the former being, biHaAjapK xaAYibapK [with an object of want disappointed, or frustrated]; and in the second, biXaxoSK mazoWuwdK, i. e. macoEuwrK [with a person frightened]; the poet meaning, by the mzWwd, himself, after the manner of the saying, raOayotu minohu OasadFA; and this is plain with respect to the former ex., but not with respect to the second; for the negation of attributes of dispraise denoted as intensive in degree does not involve the negation of what is simply essential in those attributes; and one does not say, laqiytu minohu OasadFA, or baHorFA, [or raOayotu minohu OasadFA, as above, or baHorFA,] but when meaning to express an intensive degree of boldness, or of generosity. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the corroborative nafosN and EayonN: and some hold it to be so in yatarab-ana biOanofusihin-a [as meaning Shall themselves wait (Ḳur ii. 228 and 234)]: but this presents matter for consideration; because the affixed pronoun in the nom. case, [whether expressed, as in this instance, in which it is the final syllable na, or implied in the verb,] when corroborated by nafos, should properly be corroborated first by the separate [pronoun], as in qumotumo Oanotumo Oanofusukumo [Ye stood, ye, yourselves]; and because the corroboration in this instance is lost, since it cannot be imagined that any others are here meant than those who are commanded to wait: [the preferable rendering is, shall wait to see what may take place with themselves:] bOnfshn- is added only for rousing them the more to wait, by making known that their minds should not be directed towards the men. (Mughnee.) Accord. to some, it is also redundantly prefixed to a noun governed in the gen. case [by another preposition]; as in
fOaSobaHona laA yasoOalonahu Eano biOabihi
[And they became in a condition in which they asked him not respecting his father; which may perhaps be regarded by some as similar to the saying,
yaDoHakona Eano kaAlbaradi Almunoham-i
but in this instance, ka is generally held to be a noun, syn. with mivol]. (The Lubáb, TA.)

Sometimes it is understood; as in Qll-eh lAfEln- [i. e. Qll-ehi laOafoEalan-a and Qll-eha laOafoEalan-a By God, I will assuredly do such a thing; in the latter as well as the former, for a noun is often put in the accus. case because of a preposition understood; or, accord. to Bḍ, in ii. 1, a verb significant of swearing is understood]: and in xayorK [for bixayorK In a good state], addressed to him who says, kayofa OaSobaHota [How hast thou entered upon the time of morning? or How hast thou become?]. (TA.)

[It occurs also in several elliptical phrases; one of which (fabihaA waniEomato) has been mentioned among the exs. of its primary meaning: some are mentioned in other arts.; as biOabiI and binafosiI, in arts. Abw and nfs: and there are many others, of which exs. here follow.] Moḥammad is related, in a trad., to have said, after hitting a butt with an arrow, OanaA bhaA OanaA bhaA, meaning OanaA SaAHibuhaA [I am the doer of it! I am the doer of it!]. (Sh, T.) And in another trad., Moḥammad is related to have said to one who told him of a man's having committed an unlawful action, laEal-aka biceliki, meaning laEal-aka SaAHibu AlOamori [May-be thou art the doer of that thing]. (T.) And in another, he is related to have said to a woman brought to him for having committed adultery or fornication, mano biki, meaning mano SaAHibuki [Who was thine accomplice?]: (T:) or mani AlfaAEilu biki [Who was the agent with thee?]. (TA.) OanaA bika walaka, occurring in a form of prayer, means I seek, or take, refuge in Thee; or by thy right disposal and facilitation I worship; and to Thee, not to any other, I humble myself. (Mgh in art. bwA.) One says also, mano liI bikacaA, meaning Who will be responsible, answerable, amenable, or surety, to me for such a thing? (Ḥar p. 126: and the like is said in p. 191.) And similar to this is the saying, kaOan-iI bika, meaning kaOan-iI OaboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be to-morrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition. (Idem p. 126.) [You also say, kaOan-aka bihi, meaning Thou art so near to him that it is as though thou sawest him: or it is as though thou wert with him: i. e. thou art almost in his presence.]

The Basrees hold that prepositions do not supply the places of other prepositions regularly; but are imagined to do so when they admit of being differently rendered; or it is because a word is sometimes used in the sense of another word, as in Xaribona bimaMCi AlbaHori meaning rawiyna, and in OaHosana biI meaning laTafa; or else because they do so anomalously. (Mughnee.)
[As a numeral, b denotes Two.]

entry.sense: baA and baMCN: see the letter b, and arts. bwO and bI

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. baOobaOahu, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and bObO bihi, (Fr, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. baOobaMapu (Lth, T, M) and baYobaMCN; (Fr, M;) [as also bOabiI; see art. biOabiI Oanota;] He said to him, biOabiI, (Fr, M,) or bOabaA, (M,) or biOabiI Oanota, (Lth, T, Ḳ,) [all meaning With my father mayest thou be ransomed! or] meaning Oafodiyka biOabiI [I will ransom thee with my father]; (Lth, T;) or he said to him, biOabiI Oanota waOum-iI [With my father mayest thou be ransomed, and with my mother! or I will ransom thee, &c.; see art. Abw]; (Ṣ;) the current phrase of the Arabs being that which includes both parents: (TA:) i. e., a man said so to another man, (Lth, T, M,) or to a child; (Fr, Ṣ, M;) and in like manner to his horse, for having saved him from some accident: (IAạr, T:) the verb is derived from biOabiI. (Lth, T, M.) Hence AlbiOabo, in an ex. cited voce OabN, in art. Abw, q. v.; (M;) or AlbiYabo; (TA in art. Abw;) or Albiyabo. (Ṣ in that art.)
And [hence,] baObaWuwhu They made a show of treating him with graciousness, courtesy, or blandishment; as also tabaOobaWuwA↓ Ealayohi. (M.)
[Hence also,] baOobaMCN↓, with medd, [used as an inf. n.,] A woman's dandling, or dancing, of her child. (AA, T.)

baOobaOa also signifies He (a child) said baOobaOo↓ (M, Ḳ) [in some copies of the Ḳ written baAbaA, both meaning Papa, or Father,] to his father. (M.) [Accord. to the TA, the verb is trans. in this sense, as in the senses before explained; but I think that baOobaOahu has been there erroneously put for baOobaOa.]
And He (a stallion [meaning a stallion-camel]) reiterated the sound of the letter b [or b] in his braying. (M.)

[And hence, perhaps,] baOobaON↓ [or, more probably, baOobaMCN↓, with medd, agreeably with analogy, used as an inf. n.,] The chiding of the cat, or act of chiding the cat; (AA, T, Ṣgh;) also termed gas-N. (AA, T.)
Also He hastened, made haste, or sped: and tabaOobaOonaA↓ we hastened,, &c.: (marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ:) or tabaOobaOa↓ signifies he ran. (El-Umawee, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2: see above, in three places.
baOobOo and baOobaON: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

buWobuWN The source, origin, race, root, or stock, syn. OaSolN, (AA, Sh, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of a man, (Sh, T,) whether noble or base. (AA, T.) You say, huwa kariymu AlbuWobuWi He is of generous, or noble, origin; lit., generous, or noble, of origin. (TḲ.) And fulaAnN fiIbuWobuWi Alkarami Such a one is of [a race] the source (OaSol) of generosity, or nobleness. (Ṣ. [In the PṢ, mn is here put in the place of fI: but fI is often used in phrases of the same kind and meaning as that above, in the sense of mino.]) IKh cites from Jereer,
fiI yuWobuWi Almajodi wabuHobuwHi Alkaramo
[Of a race the source of glory, and the very heart of generosity, or nobleness]: but Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee quotes the words thus;
fiI DiYoDiYi Almajodi wabuWobuwoCi Alkaramo [which may be rendered, of a race the source of glory, and the very root of generosity]; whence it appears that buWobuwCN is a dial. var. of buWobuWN in the sense here given. (TA.)
The middle of a thing; (Ḳ;) [and app. the heart, or very heart, thereof; the middle as being the best part of a thing;] like buHobuwHN. (TA.)

[Hence, perhaps,]The pupil, or apple, or the image that is seen reflected in the black, (Eayor AA, T, or UinosaAn Ḳ,) of the eye. (AA, T, Ḳ.) Whence the saying, huwa OaEaz-u EalaI-i mino buWobuWi EayoniI [He is dearer to me than the apple of my eye; a saying common in the present day, with the substitution of UinosaAn for buWobuW]. (TA.)

A generous, or noble, (ISk, T,) or a clever, an ingenious, or an accomplished, or a well-bred, or an elegant, (M, Ḳ,) and a light, an active, or a sprightly, (M,) lord, master, chief, or personage: (ISk, T, M, Ḳ:) fem. with p {buWobuWapN}. (IKh, TA.)

Also, (AA, T, Ṣ,* [but I find it only in one of three copies of the Ṣ,]) or buWobuWoCN↓, and baOobaMCN↓, (Ḳ,) the last from the M, (TA, [but it is not in the M as transcribed in the TT,]) A learned man (AA, T, Ṣ, Ḳ) who teaches; (AA, T;) but the teaching of others is not a condition required in the application of the epithet; (TA;) like sarosuwrN. (Ṣ [in which this last word is evidently given as a syn.: but in the Ḳ it is given to show the form, only, of buWobuwoCN].)
Also The body of a locust, (Ḳ,) without the head and legs. (TA.)

And, accord. to the Ḳ, The head, or uppermost part, of a vessel in which [the collyrium called] kuHol is kept: but it will appear, in art. yO, that this is [perhaps] a mistranscription for yuWoyuWN. (TA.)

hom.sense: baOobaMCN: see R. Q. 1, in two places:
and see buWobuWN.

entry.sense: buWobuwCN: see buWobuWN, in two places.
AlbiYabo: see OabN, in art. Abw.

baAbiliI-N Of, or belonging to, or relating to, baAbil [i. e. Babel], a place [well known] in El-'Irák: it is an epithet applied to enchantment, [which is said to have been there taught by two fallen angels, Hároot and Mároot, (see the Ḳur ii. 96,)] and to wine. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And hence, (TA,) Poison: [and, accord to the CK, wine;] as also baAbiliy-apN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
In the original language of the place above mentioned, AlbaAbiliI-u is a name of AlmuXotariI [The planet Jupiter]. (TA.)
baAbily-apN: see above.

baAbuwnajN [from the Persian baAbuwnaho Chamomile; or chamomile-flowers: both called by these names in the present day]: a certain herb, of several different colours; yellow-flowered, and whiteflowered, and purple-flowered: (Avicenna [Ibn-Seenà] i. 139:) i. q. OuqoHuwaAnN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, all in art qHw:) i. e. the AqHwAn is the bAbwnj with the Persians: (Mṣb in that art.:) or the flower of the AqHwAn: (Ṣ in art. qrS:) or of the yellow AqHwAn, (TA in art. qrS,) when it has become dry: (Ṣ, TA, both in art. qrS:) a well-known flower, of great utility, (Ḳ, TA,) or of which the oil is of great utility: (CK:) commonly known in El-Yemen by the name of mwns [app. muWonisN, because of its pleasant odour, or its medical properties]. (TA.)

baOojN, also pronounced baAjN, without C, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the former alone is mentioned by Th in the Fṣ, and is the chaste word, (TA,) arabicized, from the Persian baAhaA, (Ṣ,) A sort, or species, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of food, or viands. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying, AijoEali AlbaOojaAt baUojAF waAHidFA [Make thou the sorts, or species, of food, or viands, to be one sort, or species]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) occurring in a trad., in which it is without C in each case, accord. to IDrst: several different sorts of food being brought to ʼOmar, he asked respecting them, and it was said, [They are] sikobaAj and zirobaAj and UisofiydobaAj; whereupon he ordered that the bowls should be brought, and their contents were emptied into one; he saying the words above. (Marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ.) IKh says that a man would bring various sorts [of food], and one would say, AijoEalohaA bOojAF waAHdiA [Make thou them to be one sort]. (TA.) The pl. is [baOojaAtN, as shown above, as though the sing. were baOojapN, and] OabowaAjN. (Mṣb, TA.) laOajoEalan-a Aln-aAsa kul-ahumo baOojFA waAHidFA is [likewise] a saying of ʼOmar, (Mṣb, TA,) meaning [I will assuredly make the people, all of them, to be] one body or assemblage; baOojN signifying a state of assembling, or collecting together: (Ḳz, TA:) or [of] one uniform way or mode or manner, (Mṣb, TA,) as El-Fihree says in the Expos. of the Fṣ, on the authority of ISd in the book entitled El-'Awees; (TA;) i. e., in respect of gifts, or allowances: (Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, it is from baOojN or baAjN signifying a uniform line of road. (TA.) You say also, Aln-aAsu baOojN waAHidN The people are [as] one thing. (TA.) And humo fiI OamorK baOojK They are [in one and the same, or] in an equal, or a uniform, case. (Ḳ.) And jaEala AlkalaAma baOojAF waAxidFA He made the speech, or language, to be [uniform, or] of one mode, or manner. (TA.) And AijoEalo hecA AlX-aIoCa baOojFA waAHidFA Make thou this thing to be [uniform, or] of one way, or mode, or manner. (ISk.) And AijoEali AlOamora baOojFA waAHidFA Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr.)

baAcanojaAnN, [or baAcinojaAnN, commonly pronounced in the present day baAdnojaAn and bayodinojaAn and biydinojaAn, from the Persian baAdinokaAno,] a word of well-known meaning, often mentioned by the author of the Ḳ, [in explaining the words OanabN and HadaqN and magodN and wagodN,] but not in its proper place in the lexicon. (TA.) [It signifies The solanum melongena, mad-apple, or egg-plant; both the black, distinguished by the epithet Oasowadu, and the white, distinguished by the epithet OaboyaDu. And the solanum lycopersicum, or solanum Aethiopicum; also called love-apple, and so by the Arabs, tuf-aAHN AlHub-i; and golden apple, tuf-aAHN cahabiI-N; and tomato; and distinguished from the former species by the epithet OaHomaru, and by the appellation bAcnjAn quwTap.]
[baAcanojaAnN tiroyaAqiI-N Xanthium.]
1. baOara, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboOaru}, (M, Ḳ,) He sunk, or dug, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a well; (Ṣ, M;) as also AbtOr↓. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, aor. as above, inf. n. baOorN, He dug a [hollow such as is termed] buWorap, (AZ, Ṣ, M,) in which to cook. (AZ, Ṣ.)

Also, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n.; (M;) and AbtOr↓; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) He hid, or concealed, a thing: (T, M, Ḳ:) and he stored it, or laid it up, for a time of need. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence a hollow dug in the ground is termed buWorapN. (T.)

You say also, AbtOr↓ xayorFA, (T, M, Ḳ,) and baOarahu, (M, Ḳ,) He did good beforehand: (T, M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, he, as it were, did good beforehand for himself, having laid it up, or concealed it, for himself: (T, TA:) so says El-Umawee: or he laid up for himself in store concealed good: (TA:) or he did good concealedly: (M, Ḳ:) and AYtbr signifies the same. (T, TA.)
4. AbOr fulaAnFA He made, or he assigned, or appointed, (jaEala,) for such a one, a well. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1, in three places.

biYorN (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) and biyrN, (Mṣb,) of the fem. gender, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and biYorapN↓, (M,) A well: (M, TA:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ, Mṣb) OaboWurN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (by transposition, Fr, Mṣb) MburN (Fr, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaboMrN and (by transposition, Yaạḳoob, T, Ṣ, M) MbaArN and (of mult., Ṣ, Mṣb) biYaArN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and pl. of pauc. [of biyrN] OaboyaArN. (Mṣb.) The dim. is buWayorapN↓. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: buWorapN A hollow, or hole, dug in the ground, (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which to cook; also called UirapN: (AZ, Ṣ:) or (M) a place in which fire is lighted. (M, Ḳ.) [See 1.]
See also baYiyrapN.
biYorpN: see bYorN:
and see baYiyrapN.

entry.sense: buWayorapN: see biYorN.
baYiyrapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and biYorapN↓ and buWorapN↓ (M, Ḳ) A thing stored, or laid up, for a time of need. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

baO-LrN, (T, TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or Oab-aArN, (as in other copies of the Ḳ and so in the CK,) the latter formed by transposition, and the former [said to have been] not heard, (M,) A well-sinker, or well-digger. (T, M, Ḳ.)

baOozN i. q. baAzK [which see in art. bzw; and baAzN]: pl. [of pauc.] OaboWuzN, and [of mult.] buWuwzN and biYozaAnN. (Ḳ.)
IJ holds that the O is substituted for A, and that it remains in AbWz and bYzAn like as is the case in OaEoyaAdN [in which the I is substituted for w and remains in the pl. because it is substituted for w in the sing. EiydN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baWusa, aor. yaboWusu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baOosN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or baOosapN; (M; [so I find in a copy of the M, but perhaps it is a mistranscription for baMsapN;]) and baYisa, [aor. yaboOasu,] inf. n. baOosN; (M;) He was, or became, mighty, or strong, in war or fight; (Ḳ;) courageous, or valiant: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or very mighty or strong in war or fight. (AZ, Ṣ.)

baYosu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaboOasu (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and yaboYisu, the latter extr., like yanoEimu aor. of naEima, (M,) [and some other instances, (see Hasiba,)] inf. n. buWosN (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and buWuwsN and buWosaI (Ḳ) and baOosN (TA) and baYysN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [in measure] like OamiyrN, (TA,) [accord. to the CK biYosN, which is a mistake,] and baYiysaI, (TṢ, TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the Ḳ biYosaI; (TA;) or baWusa; (A;) or both these forms; (M;) He was, or became, in a state of distress; straitened in his means of subsistence, or in the conveniences of life; (M, Mṣb;) in a state of poverty: (M, A, Mṣb,* TA:) or in a state of pressing want: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and baWusa, inf. n. baMsapN and baYiysN, whence the subst. baWosaI, he was, or became, in a state of trial, or affliction: (M:) and [in like manner,] OaboOasa↓, (inf. n. UiboMsN,S,) distress, or poverty, or misfortune, or calamity, (AlbaOosaMCu,) befell him. (IAạr, Ṣ,* M, TA.)

biYosa, also written baYisa and biYisa and baOosa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) is a word of dispraise or blame, (Ṣ,) implying all kinds of dispraise or blame, (TA,) [or superlative dispraise or blame; signifying, Very evil or bad is he, or it: or superlatively evil or bad is he, or it:] contr. of niEma: (Ṣ, M, TA:) a pret. verb, imperfectly inflected, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like niEoma, (Ṣ,) [having only one variation of form, namely, the fem. biYosato, though the masc. is more commonly used even when the agent is fem. or pl.,] because it is translated from its original application, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. from baYisa fulaAnN signifying OaSaAba buWosFA [he found, met with, or experienced, distress, &c.], to signify dispraise or blame. (Ṣ, TA.) When it is accompanied by a gen. n. without the article Al, this is always in the accus. case: but when the n. has the article Al, it is always in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, biYosa rajulFA zayodF [Very evil or bad, or superlatively evil or bad, as a man, is Zeyd; rjlA being a specificative]: (Ḳ:) and biYosa Alr-ajulu zayodN [Very evil,, &c., is the man, Zeyd]; and biYosati AlmaroOapu hinodN [or more commonly biYosa AlEayoru in this case also, Very evil,, &c., is the woman, Hind]. (Ṣ.) Some argue that it is a noun, from the saying, niEoma Als-ayoru EalaI biYosa AlEayoru, because it has a prep.; but this is explained as elliptical, and meaning, niEama Als-ayoru EalaI EayorK maquwlK fiyhi biYosa AlEyoru [Excellent is the journeying upon an ass of which it is said Very evil,, &c., is the ass]. (I’Aḳ p. 232.) Zj says that when it is followed by maA, then maA, with it, is regarded as occupying the place of an indeterminate noun; [namely, XayoYFA, as a specificative; as in the Ḳur ii. 84,biYosa maA QXotarawA bihi Oanofusahumo, or biYosamaA, &c., Very evil,, &c., as a thing, is that for which they have sold, or exchanged, themselves:] (TA:) but some say that it is the agent, and is a determinate noun; and this is the opinion of Ibn-Kharoof, which he ascribes to Sb. (I’Aḳ ubi suprà.) [For further illustration, see niEoma.]

entry.sense: 4: see baYisa
5: see 6.

8. AbtOs bihi, (M, A,) and minohu, (Ṣ, TA,) He was distressed by it, or at it; it does not signify dislike: (IB, TA:) or he grieved at it, (Ṣ, M, A,) and humbled and abased himself: so in the Ḳur xi. 38 and xii. 69. (M, A, TA.) It is said of a man when a thing that he dislikes becomes known to him. (AZ, TA.)
baOosN Might, or strength, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in war or fight: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) courage; valour, or valiantness; prowess. (M, Ḳ.)
War, or fight; (M, Mṣb;) as also baYiyosN↓ (M) and baOosaMCu↓: (TA:) pl. of the first,OaboWasN. (Mṣb.)

Hence, (M,) † Fear, (M, TA,) in the saying, laA bOosa Ealayoka, (M, TA,*) and bika, (M,) [† There is no fear for thee: lit., there is no war against thee, or with thee]: the saying of which to an enemy implies the granting him security, or protection: and in the same sense it is used in a trad., in the phrase AiXotad-a AlbaOosu [† Fear became vehement]. (TA.)

I. q. DararN † [Harm, injury,, &c.]: so in the phrase laA baOosa [There is, or will be, no harm,, &c.; and laA baOosa bikacaA, and fiI kacaA, † There is, or will be, no harm in such a thing]. (Ḥar p. 311.) It is said in a trad., laA baOosa biQloginaI limani Qt-aqaI [There is no harm in wealth to him who is pious]. (El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer of Es-Suyootee.) baAs also occurs for baOos; the being suppressed, agreeably with analogy; not altered by permutation. (M, TA.)
Punishment: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or severe punishment; (TA;) as also baYisN↓, in measure like katifN. (IAạr, TA.)
See also buWosN, in two places.

buWosN (also written buwsN, with the suppressed, Mṣb) Distress; straitness of the means of subsistence, or of the conveniences of life; poverty: (M, Mṣb,* TA:*) or a state of pressing want: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or misfortune; calamity: (A:) and buWuwsN↓ and buWosaI↓ (Ḳ, TA) and baOosaMCu↓ (M, A) and baOosN↓ (TA) and baYiysN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baYiysaI↓ (TA) and maboOasapN↓ (M, TA) [all of which, except baOosaMCu↓ and maboOasapN↓, are said to be inf. ns. (see baYisa)] signify the same as buWosN: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA:) buWosaI↓ and baOosaMCu↓ are both from buWosN [with which they are syn. accord. to authorities indicated above]; (Zj, IDrd, TA;) the former is contr. of nuEomaI, (Ṣ, TA,) and in like manner the latter is contr. of naEomaMCu: (TA:) the latter is of the measure faEolaMCu without any OafoEalu, because it is a subst.; like as OafoEalu occurs among substs. without any faEalaMCu, as in the instance of OaHomadu: (Akh, Ṣ:) or buWosaI↓ signifies a state of trial or affliction, and is a subst.; and baYiysN↓ and baMsapN↓ signify the same, but are inf. ns.: (M:) and baOosaMCu↓ is syn. with Xid-apN [like buWosN in the first of the senses explained above]; (Ṣ, TA;) and maXaq-apN [meaning distress, or difficulty]: (TA:) or it signifies misfortune, or calamity, (A, Ḳ,) like buWosN; (A;) and so OaboWusN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or rather this last signifies misfortunes, or calamities; for it is pl. of baOosN↓, i. e., a pl. of pauc.; not of buWosN, as J asserts it to be; for the pl. of pauc. of buWosN is OaboMsN: (IB, TA:) but OaboWusN may be used as pl. of baOosaMCu↓. (Fr, in Ṣ, voce Dar-aMCu, q. v.) [See exs. of these two pls. in what follows.] You say yawomu buWosK wayawomu nuEomK [A day of distress, or poverty,, &c., and a day of ease and plenty]. (Ṣ, TA.) And buWosFA lahu [May distress, or poverty,, &c., befall him]: a form of imprecation. (Sb, M, TA.) And buWosa Qboni sumay-apa, app. an expression of pity [meaning Alas for the distress,, &c., of Ibn-Sumeiyeh!]. (TA, from a trad.) And EasaIa Alguwayoru OaboWusFA Perhaps the little cave [may be attended with] calamities; not calamity, as in the Ṣ [and Ḳ]: (IB:) a prov.; (Ṣ;) originating from a cave's having collapsed upon some men in it; or from an enemy's having come to some men in a cave, and slain them; wherefore it is applied to anything whence evil is feared: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. gwr:) or it is applied to him who is suspected of a thing: (IAạr, TA:) or Alguwayoru was the name of a certain water, which belonged to the tribe of Kelb, and the words of this prov. were said by Ez-Zebbà, when Kaseer turned aside from the plain road, and took the way to Alguwayoru: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. gwr:)AbWsA is in the accus. case by reason of yakuwnu understood. (Mughnee.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94.] ElKumeyt also says,
qaAluwA OasaMCa banuw kurozK faqulotu lahumo
EasaI Alguwayoru biOaboMsK waOgowaAri
[They said, Benoo-Kurz have done evil: and I said to them, Perhaps the little cave may be attended with calamities and connected with other caves]: OaboMs is here pl. of buWos. (IB, TA.) [In the Ṣ, the last words are written biUiboMsK waUiEowaArK, in one copy: in another, wUigowaAri: both of which are app. wrong.]
See also baAYisN.
biYosN and biyosN and bayosN and bay-isN: see baYiysN.
banaAtu biYosK Calamities; misfortunes. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baYisN: see baOosN, last signification:
and see baYiysN.

entry.sense: buWosaI: see buWosN, in three places.
baOosaMCu: see baOosN: and buWosN: the latter, in five places.
Zj explains it as signifying, in the Ḳur vi. 42, Hunger. (M, TA.*)
Also The act of beating, or striking. (Lth, TA.)
baWuwsN One in whom buWos [i. e. distress, &c.] is apparent, or manifest. (M, TA.)
buWuwsN: see buWosN

hom.sense: baYysN: see baOosN: and buWosN: the latter, in two places.
Mighty, or strong, in war or fight; (A;) courageous, or valiant. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

EacaAbN bYiysN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and biYiysN↓, agreeably with a general rule applying to words of this description, (M,) and biYosN↓, (M, Ḳ,) and baYisN↓, (M,) and bayoYasN↓, (M, Ḳ,) and baYoYasN↓, (M,) and bay-isN↓, and bayosN↓, which last, however, is of no authority, (M,) or biysN↓, and bayiysN, with the changed into I, (TA,) A vehement punishment: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur vii. 165. (TA.)

entry.sense: biYiysN: see baYysN.
baMsapN: see buWosN.
baYiysaI: see buWosN.

baAYisN Distressed; straitened in his means of subsistence, or in the conveniences of life; (Mṣb;) or poor: (A, Mṣb:*) or one who is in want, and an object of pity for what he suffers: (TA:) or in a state of pressing want: (Ṣ:) or in a state of trial, or affliction: (M, TA:) or one who is crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by disease, or who suffers from a protracted disease, and is in need: (Mgh:) an epithet denoting pity, (Sb, M, TA,) or grief: (Mgh:) buWosN↓ occurs as its pl.; (M, TA;) or is for cawuwbuWosK. (M.)
bayoYasN and bayoYisN: see baYiysN.
The former also signifies Strong. (Ḳ, TA.)
And hence, (TA,) AlbayoYasu The lion. (Ḳ, TA.)
AlOaboOasu The most vehement refusal. (Th, M.)
maboOasapN: see buWosN, in two places.

mubotaYisN Disliking, or hating: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and grieving: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or rather, distressed, by, or at, a thing; not disliking, or hating: (IB, TA:) or grieving, and humbling and abasing himself. (Zj, M, TA.)
maA baOahotu lahu: see bahaOa.

baborN A certain beast of prey, (M, Ḳ,) well known; (Ḳ;) a certain animal, (Mṣb,) namely, the furaAniq [or lion's provider], (Ṣ,) that emulates, or vies with, the lion in running, or that is hostile to the lion: [so may be rendered the words yuEaAdiI AlOasada; and in the uncertainty that exists respecting the animal in question, the meaning of this expression is doubtful: an animal may be called (as the jackal is) the lion's provider merely because the lion follows it and deprives it of its prey:] (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a certain Indian animal, stronger than the lion, between which and the lion and leopard, or panther, (namir,) exists hostility (muEaAdaApN); when it attacks the leopard, or panther, (nmr,), the lion aids the latter; but the scorpion is on friendly terms with it, and sometimes makes its abode in its hair: (Ḳzw:) the word is foreign, or Persian, (OaEojamiI-N,) [app. the Persian babaro, which is said to be applied to the tiger, leopard, and lion,] arabicized: (M, Ḳ:) Az thinks it to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language: (Mṣb:) pl. bubuwrN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

babogaMCu (Mṣb, Ḳ) and bab-agaMCu (Ḳ, Ḳzw) [in modern vulgar Arabic babagaAn, The parrot;] a certain well-known bird; (Mṣb;) a certain green bird, (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA,) well known; (TA;) the bird called in Persian TuwTiy, beautiful in colour and form, mostly green, but in some instances red, and yellow, and white; having a thick bill and tongue: it hears the speech of men and repeats it, without knowing its meaning; and utters letters rightly: when they desire to teach it, they put a mirror in its cage, so that it sees therein its own form, and they speak to it from behind the mirror, and when it hears, it repeats, desiring to do as its like; and thus it learns quickly: one of the wonders relating to it is [said to be this], that it never drinks water; for if it drank, it would die: (Ḳzw:) the affix renders fem. the word, but not the thing named thereby, like the p in HamaAmapN and naEaAmapN; for the word applies to the male and the female, so that one says, babogaMCu cakarN [a male parrot] and babogaMCu OunovaI [a female parrot]: and the pl. is babogaAwaAtN [or bab-agaAwaAtN], like as SaHoraAwatN is pl. of SaHoraMCu. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. bat-ahu, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yabotutu} and _i {yabotitu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) the latter anomalous, because a reduplicative verb [of this kind] having the aor. with kesr is not trans., except in certain instances, of which this is one; the other instances being Eal-ahu, in relation to drinking,, aor. _u {yaEolulu} and _i {yaEolilu}, and nam-a AlHadiyva, aor. _u {yanomumu} and _i {yanomimu}, and Xad-ahu, aor. _u {yaXodudu} and _i {yaXodidu}, and Hab-ahu, aor. _i {yaHobibu}; the last having but one form [of aor.]; (Ṣ;) inf. n. bat-N: (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, A, &c.:) and Abt-hu↓, (M,) inf. n. UibotaAtN: (Mgh, Ḳ:) He cut it off, severed it, separated it, or disunited it, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, A,* Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) entirely, or utterly; (Lth, T, M;) namely, a thing; (M;) a rope, or cord; (Lth, T;) and a tie, or bond, of union between two persons. (M.)

[bat-ahu and Abt-hu↓, accord. to the TA, app. signify also He, or it, caused him (a man) to become unable to proceed in his journey, his camel that bore him breaking down, or stopping from fatigue, or perishing: for Anbt- as signifying “he became so” is there said to be quasi-pass. of those two verbs when it has this sense. Hence,] bat-ahu Als-afaru [The journey caused him to become cut off,, &c.]. (A.) And saAqa daAb-atahu Hat-aI bat-ahaA [He urged on his beast so that, or until, he caused it to become cut off,, &c.]: (A:) and Oabat-a↓ baEiyrahu He caused his camel to become cut off,, &c., (qaTaEapu,) by travel: (M, TA:) this is not said but of a man who has forced on his camel at a hard pace, or by laborious journeying. (TA.)

bat-a TalaAqa QmoraOatihi, (T, Mṣb, TA,) or TalaAqa AlmaroOapi, (Mgh,) and Oabat-ahu↓, (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb,) He made the divorce of his wife, or of the woman, to be absolutely separating, (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) so as to cut her off from return. (Mṣb.) Lth, with whom AZ agrees, has erred in asserting that bat-a is intrans. and Oabat-↓ trans.: (T, TA:) both are trans. and intrans., (T, Mṣb, TA,) as En-Nawawee asserts in the Tahdheeb el-Asmà wa-1-Loghát. (TA.) You say, AlT-aloqapu AlwaAHidapu tabut-u, and tubit-u↓, i. e. The single divorce cuts the matrimonial tie, or bond, of the woman, (taqoTaEu EiSomapa Aln-ikaAHi, T, Mgh,*) when the period during which she must wait before contracting a new marriage has ended. (T.) [See also bat-N.]
bat-a Ealayohi AlqaDaMCa, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) inf. n. bat-N; (M;) and Oabat-ahu↓; (T, Ṣ, M;) He (the judge, T) decided the judgment, or sentence, against him. (T, Ṣ,* M.)
bat-a Ealayohi AlX-ahaAdapa, and Oabat-ahaA↓, He decided against him by the testimony, [or pronounced the testimony decisive against him,] and compelled, or constrained, him to admit it. (M.)
bat-a XahaAdatahu, and Oabat-ahaA↓, He gave his testimony decisively. (Mṣb.)
Oabut-u Oan-ahu qaAla I know, or declare, decidedly, not [merely] thinking it, that he said thus. (Saheeh of Muslim.)

bat-a Aln-iy-apa He made the intention decided; or fixed it decidedly. (A.) It is said in a trad., laA SiyaAma limano lamo yubit-a↓ AlS-yaAmi mina All-ayoli, (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) or lamo yabut-a, accord. to different recitals, (Mgh,) i. e. There is no fasting to him [meaning his fasting is null] who does not decisively impose it upon himself, by intention, from the night: (Ṣ,* Mgh:) or, who does not form the intention of fasting before daybreak, and thus cut it off from the time in which there is no fasting, namely, the night: the intention is termed bat-N [and UibotaAtN] because it makes a division between non-fasting and fasting: (T, TA:) lamo yubit, from AlUibaAtapu, is a mistake; but lm yubay-it, from Alt-aboyiytu, [see bay-ata,] is correct. (Mgh.) And it is said in another trad., Oabit-uwA↓ nikaAHa hecihi Aln-isaMCi, i. e. Decide ye the affair respecting the marriage of these women, and confirm it by its [proper] conditions: an oblique prohibition of the kind of marriage termed nikaAHu AlmutoEapi, because it is a marriage not [absolutely or lawfully] decided, [being] made definite as to duration. (TA.)

bat-a also signifies He made to have, or take, effect; he executed, or performed; (Ḥar p. 210;) and so Abt-↓, as in the phrase, Abt- yamiynahu He made his oath to have, or take, effect; he executed, or performed, it. (M.)

sakoriAnu maA yabut-u kalaAmFA, (Ks, T, M,) and mA yabit-u, (M,) and mA yubit-u↓, (Ks, T, M,) One who is drunk, who does not speak plainly, or distinctly; lit., who does not make speech plain, or distinct; (Ks, T;) or who does not articulate speech; syn. maA yaqoTaEuhu: (M:)
or, as Aṣ says, (T,) sakoraAnu maA yabut-u, (T, A,) or laA yabut-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and lA yabit-u, and lA yubat-u↓, (Ḳ,) which last form of the verb is disallowed by Aṣ, but both are correct accord. to Fr, (T, Ṣ,) meaning one who is drunk, who does not, or will not, [i. e. cannot,] decide an affair. (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also baAt-N.]
See also 7.

[Hence,] bat-to yamiynuhu, (M, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yabotitu} only, inf. n. butuwtN, (Mṣb,) His oath bad, or took, effect; was executed, or performed; syn. wajabato: (M:) it was, or proved, true: (Mṣb:) a phrase mentioned by AZ, and, if correct, not needing any explanation. (M.) [See Abt- yamiynahu, above.]
bat-a, aor. _i {yabotitu}, inf. n. butuwtN, He was, or became, lean, or meagre. (M, Ḳ.) [See baAt-N.]
bat-N [inf. n. of bat-a] also signifies The selling, and the weaving, a [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn [or bat-, q. v.]. (KL.)
2. bt-thu, inf. n. tabotiytN, He cut it off, or severed it, [entirely, or utterly, and] much, or with extraordinary energy or effectiveness; the teshdeed denoting intensiveness of signification. (Ṣ.)
bat-atuwhu They furnished him with [bataAt, or] travel-ling-provisions. (M, Ḳ.)
bat-itohumo Give thou to them [garments called] butuwt [pl. of bat-u, q. v.]. (TA, from a trad.)
4: see 1, passim:
and see 7.

entry.sense: 5. tbt-t He became furnished with [bataAt, or] travelling provisions: and he became provided with [bataAt, or] utensils and furniture of the house or tent; or household goods. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

7. Anbt- It was, or became, cut off, severed, separated, or disunited, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) entirely, or utterly; (Lth, T, M;) namely, a thing; (M;) a rope, or cord; (Lth, T;) and a tie, or bond, of union between two persons: (T, M:*) as also bat-a↓, (Lth, AZ, T, M, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yabotitu} and _u {yabotutu} (M, [so accord. to a copy of that work, but it seems to be indicated in the Mṣb (see 1, near the close of the paragraph,) that it is _i only, in this case,]) inf. n. bat-N; (Lth, AZ, T, M, Ḳ;) and Abt-↓, (T, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. UibotaAtN; (T, TA;) the last said by Lth and AZ to be trans. only; (T, TA;) but it is both trans. and intrans., like the second: (T, Mṣb, TA:) so says En-Nawawee, as mentioned above: see 1. (TA.) You say, AinoqaTaEa fulaAnK faQnobat-a Haboluhu Eanohu [Such a one broke off, or disunited himself, from such a one, and his tie, or bond, of union became severed from him]. (T, TA, [but in a copy of the former, for En flAn, is put Eano maAlihi from his property.])

He became unable to proceed in his journey, his camel that bore him breaking down, or stopping from fatigue, or perishing: (A,* Mgh,* TA:) quasi-pass. of bat-ahu and Oabat-ahu. (TA.) You say, saAra Hat-aI Qnobat-a He journeyed until he was unable to proceed, &c. (A, Mgh, TA.) [See also munobat-N.]
His maMC, (A,) the mMC of his back, (Ks, T, Ḳ,) [i. e. his seminal fluid,] became cut off, or stopped, or ceased, (Ks, T, A, Ḳ,) by reason of age: (A:) said of a man. (Ks, T, A.)

hom.sense: bat-N inf. n. of 1, q. v. (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, &c.) [It is sometimes used as an inf. n.; as also bat-pN↓ and bataAtN↓, explained in the M as syn. with qaToEN: and sometimes, as is often the case with inf. ns., in the sense of the act. part. n. of its verb, namely baAt-N↓, trans. and intrans.; as also bataAtN↓; both of which are masc. and fem., because originally inf. ns.; but bat-N has also bat-apN for its fem. The following are exs.]

OaEoTayotuhu hecihi AlEaTiy-apa bat-aA batolFA [I gave him this gift, cutting it off from my property so as to make it irrevocable; or, it being cut off, &c.]. (Lth, T.) And taSad-aqafulaAnN SadaqapF bataAtFA↓, and SadaqapF bat-apF batolapu, (T, Ṣ,) Such a one bestowed an alms, or a gift for the sake of God, cut off from his property; (T, TA;) and therefore, (TA,) parted from himself. (Ṣ, TA.) Such a gift is termed SadaqapN bat-apN, (A,* Nh,) and Sdqp bat-apN batolapN. (M.)

Tal-aqahaA, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and bataAtFA↓, (Ḳ,) and Albat-apa, (T,) and TaloqapF bat-apF, (Mṣb,) and TalaAqFA baAt-aA↓, (Lth, T, Mṣb,* TA, [in one copy of the T simply baAt-aA,]) He divorced her by a separating divorce; (Ḳ;) by a divorce cutting her off from returning: and such a divorce is also termed TlAq mubit-N↓: (Mṣb:) or the first of these phrases signifies he divorced her by a divorce either cut off, [meaning decided and irrevocable,] or cutting off. (Mgh.) And Tal-aqahaA valaAvFA bat-apF, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and bataAtFA↓, (M,) He divorced her by three divorces so as to cut her off from returning: (M, Mṣb:) or by three divorces cut off from himself [so as to be irrevocable]: (Ṣ:) or by three divorces cutting off [from returning]. (TA.)

Halafa bat-aA, and bat-apF, and bataAtFA↓, [may mean He swore decidedly, or decisively; or irrevocably: or] he swore with effect, or execution, or performance; [see 1, near the end of the paragraph;] from the signification of “cutting,” or “cutting off,”, &c.: (M:) [or, as also] Halafa yamiynFA bat-FA, and bat-apF, (Mṣb, TA,) and baAt-apF↓, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) and bataAtFA↓, (TA,) he swore an oath that was, or proved, true. (Mṣb.)

TaHana biAlr-aHaI bat-FA He ground with the mill, turning it, (AZ, T,) or beginning the turning, (Ṣ,) from his left: (AZ, T, Ṣ:) [i. e., making it to turn in the contrary way of the hands of a watch: the last word is app. an inf. n.; as though meaning effectually; for this is the general and easier or more powerful way of turning the handmill:] the contrary way is termed XazorFA: (AZ, T, Ṣ:*) or TaHana bat-aA signifies he began in the turning [of the mill] with the left [hand]. (Ḳ: [but biAlyasaAri is here evidently put by mistake for Eani AlyasaAri.])

A kind of TayolasaAn [q. v.] called saAj, (Lth, T,) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (M, Mgh,) square, or four-sided, (Lth, T, M,) thick, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) loose, or uncompact, in texture, (M,) and green [or rather of a dingy ash-colour, or dark dust-colour, for such is the general meaning of OaxoDaru, the term here used, when applied to a garment of this kind]; (Lth, T, M;) or, as some say, (M,) of [the soft hair termed] wabar, and of wool; (M, Mgh;) and thus described in the Kifáyet el-Mutaḥaffiḍh: (TA:) or a TylsAn of [the material termed] xaz-, (Ṣ Mgh, Ḳ,) and the like: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. butuwtN, (Lth, T, Ṣ, Mgh,) or bitaAtN, (M,) but the former occurs in trads. [&c.], (TA,) and [pl. of pauc.] Oabut-N. (M.)

entry.sense: bat-apN: see bat-N.

laA OafoEaluhu Qlobat-apa, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) as also bat-apF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by IF, (Mṣb,) but IB says that Sb and his companions allow only the former, and that only Fr allows the latter, (TA,) and some say that the former has been heard pronounced with the disjunctive. [Aalobat-apa], (MF,) and thus it is written in a copy of the Ḳ, (TA,) but others greatly disapprove of this, (MF,) [meaning I will not do it, decidedly, or absolutely,] is said of anything in respect of which there is no returning, or revoking; (Ṣ, IF, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) Alabt-apa being said of a thing to be done, or performed, irrevocably, and from which there is no abstaining by reason of sluggishness; (T;) as though the speaker cut off the doing of the thing: (M:) the last word is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: (Ṣ:) Sb says, it is a corroborative inf. n., and is not used without Al. (M.) It is said in a trad., OaHosibuhu qaAla juwayoriyap Oawi Qlobapa qaAla [I think he said Juweyriyeh, or decidedly he said so]; as though the speaker doubted of the female's name, and said, “I think it was Juweyriyeh;” then corrected, and said, “or I know,” or “declare,” “decidedly, (Oabut-u, i. e. OaqoTaEu,) that he said Juweyriyeh: I do not [merely] think.” (Saheeh of Muslim.)

hom.sense: bataAtN: see bat-N, in seven places.

A man is said to be EalaI bataAti OamorK, meaning On the point of [accomplishing, or deciding,] an affair. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) A rájiz says,
waHaAjapK kunotu EalaI bataAtihaA
[Many a needful affair I was on the point of accomplishing]. (Ṣ.)

Travelling provisions: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) and requisites, equipments, or furniture; syn. jahaAzN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. Oabit-apN. (Ṣ.) A verse of Tarafeh cited voce baAEa exhibits an ex. of the former signification. (TA.)

Also The utensils and furniture of the house or tent; or household goods: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., laA yuWoxacu minokumo EuXoru AlbataAti [The tithe of the utensils, &c. of the house or tent shall not be taken from you]: (Ṣ:) i. e., no poor-rate shall be levied upon such utensils, &c. that are not for traffic. (AʼObeyd.)

entry.sense: bat-aI-N: see what next follows.
bat-aAtN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and bat-iI-N↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A maker, (Ṣ,) or seller, of the kind of garment called bat-. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)
baAt-N: see bat-N, in three places.

Cut off from [the possession of] reason, or intellect, by drunkenness: (AḤn, M:) or drunken: (Ḳ:) and stupid, or foolish: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and OaHomaqu baAt-N signifies very stupid or foolish, (T, M,) accord. to Lth; but [Az adds,] what we remember to have heard from those deserving of confidence is taAb-N, from Alt-abaAbu, meaning AlxasaAru;
like as one says, OaHomaqu xaAsirN daAbirN daAmirN [explained in art. xsr]. (T.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]
Also Lean, or meagre, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and unable to rise, or stand. (TA.)
TalaAqN mubit-N: see bat-N.
mabotuwtapN A woman absolutely separated by divorce, so as to be cut off from return: originally mabotuwtN TalaAquhaA. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

munobat-N A man unable to proceed in his journey, his camel that bore him having broken down, or stopped from fatigue, or perished; (T, M,* TA;) syn. munoqaTaEN bihi: (Ṣ, Mgh, TA:) or who remains on his road unable to attain the place to which he is directing his course, the beast or camel that bore him (Zahoruhu) having broken down, or stopped from fatigue, or perished. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. batara, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor _u, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. batorN; (T, Ṣ, M, &c.;) and Abtr↓; (T;) He cut, or cut off, a thing before it was complete: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb:) or he cut, or cut off, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in any manner: (M:) or he cut off (a tail or the like, T) entirely, or utterly. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, M, Ḳ.)
batarahu, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) or Abtrhu↓; (M, L;) He cut off his tail: (Ḳ:) or he cut, or amputated, his tail in any place. (M, L.)
batara raHimahu, (M,) aor. as above, (M, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (M,) † He cut, or severed, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; he disunited himself from his relations. (M, Ḳ.*)

batira, aor. _a {yabotaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. batarN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He (any beast, M) had his tail cut off: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or [had either the whole or a part of his tail cut off;] had his tail cut, or amputated, in any place. (M.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
[Hence,] Abtrhu said of God, He made him to be. or become, Oabotar, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., without offspring, or progeny. (TA.)
5: see 7.
7. Anbtr It (a tail or the like, T) became cut, or cut off, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) in any place, (M,) or entirely; (T, M;) and tbt-r↓ signifies the same. (TA.)
butaArN: see baAtirN
batuwrN: see baAtirN
butayoraMCu: see Oabotaru.
bat-aArN: see baAtirN

baAtirN A cutting, or sharp, sword; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also bat-aArN↓ (T, M, Ḳ) and batuwrN↓ (M) and bataArN↓. (Ḳ.) [But all of these except the first are app. intensive epithets, signifying very sharp.]
See also OubaAtirN.
Oabotaru A tail cut off entirely. (T, L.)

Any beast (M) having the tail cut off: (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or [having either the whole or a part of the tail cut off;] having the tail cut, or amputated, in any place: (M:) fem. batoraMCu; with which mabotuwrapN↓ is syn.: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. butorN. (A, Mṣb.)

† A certain malignant, or noxious, serpent: (Ḳ:) or a short-tailed serpent: (Mgh; and Ed-Durr en-Netheer, an abridgment of the Nh of IAth, by El-Jelál:) or a certain species of blue serpent, having its tail [as it were] cut off, which none in a state of pregnancy sees without casting her burden: (ISh:) or the kind of serpent called XayoTaAn, having a short tail: no one sees it without fleeing from it, and no one in a state of pregnancy beholds it without casting her young: it is thus called only because of the shortness of its tail, as thought its tail were cut off. (M.)
† A leathern water-bag, and a bucket, having no loop. (M, Ḳ.)
† Defective, deficient, incomplete, or imperfect. (Mgh.)
† In want, or poor. (M, Ḳ.)
† Suffering loss; syn. xaAsirN. (M, Ḳ.)
† One from whom all good, or prosperity, is cut off. (M.)

† Having no offspring, or progeny; (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, Ṣ, M, IAth, Ḳ;) as also OubaAtirN↓ (M, Ḳ) and munobatirN↓. (IAth.) [The dim., Oubayotiru↓, occurs in a trad., in this sense, or in some other sense implying contempt.]
† Anything cut off, (Ḳ,) or anything of which the effect is cut off, (Ṣ,) from good, or prosperity. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a trad. cited voce baAlN.]
xuTobapN batoraMCu † A xTbp [q. v.] in which the speaker does not praise God nor bless the Prophet: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) particularly applied to a certain xTbp of Ziyád. (Ṣ, A.)

rakoEapN batoraMCu, (TA,) and [its dim.] butayoraMCu↓, (Ṣ, TA,) † A single rkEp [q. v.] performed instead of the complete performance of the prayer called Alwitor: or a rkEp cut short, or cut off, after the completion of one rkEp, when both were to have been performed. (TA.)
AlOabotaraAni † The ass (AlEayoru) and the slave: (ISK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) so called because of the little good that is in them: (ISk, Ṣ:) each is called AlOabotaru. (Ḳ.)
OubaAtirN † Short; (M, Ḳ;) as though cut off from completion. (M.)
See also Oabotaru.

Also † A man who cuts, or severs, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; who disunites himself from his relations; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also baAtirN↓; (A:) or quick to cut, or sever, the ties, or bonds, between him and his friend. (IAạr.)
Oubayotiru: see Oabotaru.
mabotuwrapN: see Oabotaru.
munobatirN: see Oabotaru.

hom.sense: 1. batiEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabotaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bataEN, (ISh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a horse, Ḳ) was, or became, long in the neck, and at the same time strong in its base: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or thick and fleshy in the neck: or strong in the neck. (ISh.)
It, (the body,) and he, (a man,) was, or became, strong in the joints. (Ḳ, TA.)
bataEa, aor. _i {yabotiEu}, He prepared, and made, the beverage called nabiyc. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) [See bitoEN.]

entry.sense: batoEN, with fet-ḥ, [perhaps a mistake for bataEN, (see 1,)] Strength. (TA.)

hom.sense: bitoEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and bitoEN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) [Hydromel, or] nabiyc of honey, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that has become strong; (Ḳ;) nbyc made of honey, as though it were wine in strength, the drinking of which is disapproved; (El-ʼEyn;) an intoxicating beverage made of honey, in El-Y emen: (Mgh:) or wine made of fresh dates: (Ibn-El-Beytár, cited by Golius:) or the pure juice of grapes; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) said by some to be so called by reason of the strength therein, from bataEN, [inf. n. of batiEa,] meaning “strength of the neck:” (TA:) or the former signifies wine: (Ḳ:) or wine made of honey: (AḤn:) a word of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) the wine of El-Medeeneh is from unripe dates, and from ripe dates; that of the Persians, from grapes; that of the people of El-Yemen is bitoE, and is from honey; and that of the Abyssinians is sukurokap. (Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree.) [See mizorN.]
See also batEN.

entry.sense: batiEN A horse long in the neck, and at the same time strong in its base: fem. with p {batiEapN}: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or long in the neck. (IAạr.) You say also EunuqN batiEN (ISh, TA) and batiEapN (TA) A strong neck: or an excessively long neck: (TA:) or a thick and fleshy neck: (ISh:) and OabotaEu↓ [in like manner] signifies full, applied to a rusog, [app. here meaning a pastern], (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, who cites, from Ru-beh, the phrase rusogFA OabotaEa: but IB thinks that the right reading is jiydFA OabotaEa [a full neck]. (TA.)
Also A tall man: (L, TA:) in this sense, accord. to the Ḳ, bitoEN↓, which is a mistake: (TA:) fem. with p {batiEapN}. (L, TA.)

And Strong in the joints, applied to a body, (Lth, Ḳ,) and to a man; as also OabotaEu↓: (Ḳ:) fem. of the former with p {batiEapN}: (TA:) and of ↓ the latter, batoEaMCu: and pl. of the latter, butoEN. (Ḳ.)
butaEu pl. of batoEaMCu, fem. of OabotaEu, q. v.
bitaEN: see bitoEN.
A vintner, in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) [See bitEN.]
baAtiEN: Strong. (TA.)

hom.sense: OabotaEu: see batiEN, in three places.

It is also a word used as a corroborative: you say, jaAWuwA OajomaEuwna OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: (Ṣ:) and jaMCa Alqawomu OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna OaboSaEuwna [the people, or company of men, came, all of them, or all together]: (AHeyth:) and jaAWuwA kul-uhumo OajomaEuwna OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna [they came, all of them, all together]: these words which follow AjmEwn being imitative sequents to it, not occurring save after it [in the order above]: (O, Ḳ:) or one may begin with whichsoever of them he will, after it. (Ibn-Keysán, Ḳ.) And [the fem. is batoEaMCu:] you say Alqabiylapu kul-uhaA jamoEaMCu katoEaMCu baSoEaMCu batoEaMCu [The tribe, all of it, all together: in the CK, erroneously, kuvoEMCu (with damm and v) and buSoEACu and butoEACu]. (Ḳ.) And [the pl. of batoEaMCu is butaEu↓, originally batoEaAwaAtN:]
you say Aln-isaMCu kul-uhun-a jumaEu kutaEu buSaEu butaEu [The women, all of them, all together: in the CK, erroneously, jumaEN kutaEN buSaEN butaEN, though it is well known that each of these is determinate, and imperfectly declinable]. (Ḳ.) It is only necessary that he who mentions all these words should mention first kul-, and follow it with the word formed from j m E, then add the rest in whatsoever order he will; but the more approved way is to put the word formed from k t E before the rest. (TA.) Fr mentions the phrases OaEojabniI AlqaSoru OajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether], and Ald-aAru jamoEaMCa [the house, all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow OajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows OajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSal-uwA juluwsFA OajomaEiyna and OajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, OaEoniykumo OajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]. (Ḳ.) [But see OajomEu.]

entry.sense: 1. batakahu, aor. _i {yabotiku} and _u {yabotuku}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. batokN, (Ṣ,) He cut it; or severed it, or cut it off, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) entirely, or from its root; (TA;) and in like manner, bt-khu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tabotiykN; (TA;) but btak is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, of the action, or its application to many objects. (Ṣ, TA.) McaAna AlOanoEaAmi, in the Ḳur [iv. 118], accord. to Abu-l-ʼAbbás, (TA,) means And they shall assuredly cut, or cut off, the ears of the cattle: (Ṣ,* TA:) or, as Az thinks, slit the ears of the cattle, as they did in the time of ignorance. (TA.)
Also He plucked it out; he laid hold upon it and pulled it towards him so that it became severed from its root and plucked out; (Lth, Ṣ,* TA;) namely, a hair, or feather, or the like. (Lth, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
5: see 7.
7. Anbtk It became cut; or became severed, or cut off, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) entirely, or from its root; (TA;) and in like manner, tbt-k↓. (Ḳ.)
Also It became plucked out. (Lth, TA.)

bitokapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and batokapN (Ḳ) A piece, or portion, of a thing, cut off, or severed: pl. bitakN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of the poet, (Ṣ,) namely, Zuheyr, (TA,)
Hat-aI UicaA maA hawatE kaf-u AlgulaAmi lahaA
TaArato wafiI kaf-ihi mino riyXihaA bitaku
[Until, when the hand of the boy descends to her, she flies, while portions of her feathers, plucked out, are in his hand]. (Ṣ, TA.)

And [hence,] i. q. juhomapN mina All-ayoli [i. e.
