A portion at the commencement of the latter parts of the night, accord. to the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. jhm; or a remaining portion of darkness in the latter part of the night, accord. to the Ḳ in that art.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as though it were a division [or portion cut off] of the night. (TA.)
batuwkN: see what next follows.

baAtikN (applied to a sword, Ṣ) Sharp, or cutting; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also batuwkN↓: (Ḳ:) [but the latter is an intensive epithet, signifying very sharp; or cutting much, or keenly]: the pl. [of the former] is bawaAtiku. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. batalahu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _i {yabotilu}, (Ṣ,) or _u, (Mṣb,) or both, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. batolN, (Lth, T, Ṣ, &c.,) He cut it off, or severed it; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also bt-lhu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabotiylN: (TA:) he separated it (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) from another thing. (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] batala AlEumorapa He made the performance of the Emrp [or minor pilgrimage] to be obligatory, by itself. (A, TA.) And bt-l↓ AlEumoraI He made the EmrI to be obligatory [upon himself]; i. e., the saying, I have assigned to thee my house that thou mayest inhabit it to the end of my life. (TA.)
batila, aor. _a {yabotalu}, inf. n. batolN, [but accord. to analogy, this should rather be batlN,] He (a man) was, or became, wide between the shoulders. (T.)
2: see 1, in two places:
and see also 5:
and mubat-alN.

entry.sense: 5. tbt-lA: see 7, in two places.
[Hence,] He was, or became, alone. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ,) or tbt-lA UilaI Qll-ehi, (M, Ḳ,) and bt-l↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. tabotiylN, (Ṣ,) He detached himself from worldly things, and devoted himself to God: (Ṣ:) or he devoted himself to God exclusively, and was sincere, or without hypocrisy, towards Him: (M, Ḳ:) he forsook every other thing, and applied himself to the service of God: (Fr, T:) he devoted himself exclusively to the service of God: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T:) or he abstained from sexual intercourse: (Ḳ:) or tbt-l [alone] has this signification; (M, TA;) or he separated himself from women, and abstained from sexual intercourse: and hence, is metaphorically employed to denote exclusive devotion to God. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [lxxiii. 8], watabat-alo Uilayopi tabotiylFA, (T, Ṣ, M,) for tbt-l Alyh tabat-ulFA. (T.) You say also, tbt-lA UilaI AlEibaAdapi He applied himself exclusively to the service of God. (Mṣb.)
tabat-lato, said of a woman, She adorned and beautified herself. (TA.)

7. Anbtl It was, or became, cut off, or severed; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also tbt-l↓. (M, Ḳ.) You say, Anbtlt Alfsiylapu, (Ḳ, [in a copy of the M Abttlt↓, probably a mistranscription,]) The shoot, or offset, of the palm-tree was cut off, or severed, mino Oum-ihaA [from its mother-tree]; as also tbt-lt↓ and Astbtlt↓. (M, Ḳ.)
Anbtl fiI sayorihi He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and made much progress, in his journeying, or pace. (TA.)
8: see 7.

EaTaMCN batolN A gift that is [as it were] cut off; i. e., of which there is not the like; or after which another is not given. (M, Ḳ.) And SadaqapN batolapN, (M, Ḳ,) and Sdqp bat-apN batolapN, (TA,) An alms, or a gift for the sake of God, cut off from its giver: (M, Ḳ:) or cut off from all the property [irrevocably], to be devoted to the cause of God. (O, TA. [See also art. bt.]) You say also, OaEoTayotuhu hecihi AlEaTiy-apa bat-aA batolFA: see art. bt. And Tal-aqahaA bat-apF batolapF; (Ṣ;) or Tl-qhA TaloqapF bat-apF batolapF; (Mṣb;) [He divorced her by a separating divorce; or by a decided and irrevocable divorce; (see art. bt;)] the last word being a corroborative of that next preceding it. (TA.) And Halafa yamiynFA batolapF He swore a decided [or an irrevocable] oath. (M, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce bat-u.])
Also Truth; or true: whence batolFA in truth; or truly. (TA.)
batuwlN A shoot, or an offset, of a palm-tree, cut off from its mother-tree, and independent thereof; as also batiylapN↓, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and batiylN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

A virgin, that is cut off from husbands: (Ṣ:) a woman that withholds herself from men, (T,) or that is cut off from men, (M, Ḳ,) having no desire for them, (T, M, TA,) nor need of them; (T;) and, with the art. Al, applied to the Virgin Mary; (M, Ḳ;) as also batiylN↓: (M, Ḳ:) with the art. Al, it is applied also to Fátimeh, the daughter of Moḥammad, because she was separated from the [other] women of her age and nation by chasteness and excel-lence and religion and [other] grounds of pretension to respect: (Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, T, Ḳ:*) or it signifies, (Ṣ,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) a woman detached from worldly things, and devoted to God; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also batiylN↓ and batiylapN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
batiylN: see batuwlN, in three places.
Also Slender; (Ḥam p. 589;) applied to a waist; (Ḥam, TA;) as also mubat-alN↓. (TA.)
A tree having its racemes pendulous. (Ḳ. [See also mubotilN.])
A watercourse (Ibn-ʼAbbád, M, Ḳ) in the lower part of a valley: pl. butulN. (M, Ḳ.)
batiylapN: see batuwlN, in two places.
Also Any limb, or member, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with its flesh, (Lth, T, Ṣ,) separate from others, (M, Ḳ,) or by itself: (Lth, T:) pl. bataAYilu. (Lth, T, Ṣ, &c.)
In one dial., (M,) The posteriors; (M, Ḳ;) because divided [or distinct] from the back. (M.)
mar-a EalaI batiylapK mino raOoyihi, and batolaMCi↓ mn rOyh, [He proceeded according to] an irrevocable determination or resolution. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Oabotalu; fem. batolaMCu: for the latter, see what next precedes.
EumorapN batolaMCu [A minor pilgrimage] not conjoined with another. (Ḳ.)
And Oabotalu, applied to a man, Wide between the shoulders. (T.)

mubotilN, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ,) or mubotilapN, (M, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, mubotalap,]) the first being [in the opinion of ISd] pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the second, like as tamorN is of tamrapN, (M,) A palmtree (naxolapN) having a shoot, or an offset, cut off from it and independent of it; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and used in like manner as a pl.;
i. e., the first is also used as a pl.: (Ṣ:) or the first signifies solitary, or isolated: (Ibn-Ḥabeeb, TA:) or of which the racemes are pendulous. (TA. [See also batiyylN.])
mubat-alN: see batyilN.

mubat-alapN, applied to a woman, Beautiful, elegant, or pretty; (Ḳ;) as though her beauty were divided into portions (but-ila↓, i. e. quT-iEa,) [and distributed in due proportions] upon her limbs: (M,* Ḳ:) or perfect in make, (Ṣ,) whose flesh is not accumulated, one portion upon another, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) but distinctly disposed; this latter being said by some to be the meaning: (M:) or, accord. to Lḥ, (M, TA,) having a lankness, or looseness, in her limbs; (M, Ḳ, TA;) not having them compressed, one upon another; (M:) or as though the flesh were cut off from them: (TA:) and in like manner, mubat-alN applied to a camel: (M, Ḳ:) not applied as an epithet to a man: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or mubat-alapu Alxaloqi signifies distinct in make from the generality of women; excelling them [therein]: (Aboo-Saʼeed, T, TA:) or perfect in make: or having every part beautiful in itself; not dependent [for its beauty] upon another part: (T:) or beautiful in make; not with one part falling short of another [in beauty]; not being beautiful in the eye and ugly in the nose, nor beautiful in the nose and ugly in the eye; but perfect. (IAạr, TA.)
munobatilN Cut off, or severed. (Ṣ.)
[And hence,] EaziymapN munobatilapN An irrevocable determination or resolution. (TA.)

1. bav-ahu, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabovuvu} (Lth, T, M, L, Ḳ) and _i {yabovivu}, (M, L, Ḳ,) the latter [anomalous, and therefore] thought by MF to be a mistake, arising from confounding bav-a with bat-a, he not knowing any authority for it except the Ḳ, (TA,) inf. n. bavN; (Lth, T, M, L;) and Abv-hu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UibovaAvN; (TA;) and bv-vhu↓, (Ḳ,) or this has an intensive signification; (Ṣ;) and bavobavahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. bavobavapN; (Ṣ;) He spread it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) he dispersed it, scattered it, or disseminated it; (Lth, T, Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (Lth, T, M, A,* L;) or ‡ news, tidings, or information. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) You say, bav-uwA Alxayola fiI AlgaArapi They spread, or dispersed, the horses, or horseme in the hostile incursion. (T, M,* A, L.) And bav-a Aljunoda fiI AlbilaAdi He (the Sultán) spread, or dispersed, the army in the provinces. (Mṣb.) And bav-a kilaAbahu He (the hunter, A, L) spread, or dispersed, his dogs (T, A, L) Eala AlS-ayodi [against the chase, or game]. (A.) And bav-a Qll-ehu Alxaloqa,, (aor. _u {yabovuvu}, inf. n. bav-N, Mṣb,) God spread, or dispersed, mankind, or the beings whom He created, fiI AlOaroDi [in the earth]: (T, A:) or God created them. (Mṣb.) wabav-N minohumaA riHaAlFA kvyrFA wanisaMCN, in the Ḳur [iv. 1.], means And spread, or dispersed, and multiplied, from them two, many men, and women. (T.) You say also, buv-ati AlbusuTu The carpets were spread. (T.) And bav-a AlmataAEa binawaAHiI Albayoti He spread out the furniture, or utensils, in the sides of the tent, or house, or chamber. (A.) And bav-a AlgubaAra, (Ḳ,) and bavobavahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He, or it, raised the dust. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And bavobava↓ Alt-uraAba He, or it, raised the dust, or earth, and removed it from that which was beneath it. (M.) And bavobavuwhu↓ They uncovered him. (Hr, M, L, from a trad. respecting a dying Jew.) And bav-a AlHadiyva † He spread, published, or revealed, the discourse, narration, or information. (Mṣb.) And, accord. to IF, bav-a Als-ir-a and Abv-hu↓ † [He spread, published, or revealed, the secret]. (Mṣb.) And bavavotuhu maA fiI nafosiI, aor. _u {yabovuvu}; and Oabovavatuhu↓ Uiy-aAhu; ‡ I revealed, or showed, to him what was in my mind. (A.) And Oabovavotuka↓ siriI-, (Ṣ,) or Als-ir-a; (Ḳ;) and bavavotuka Als-ir-a, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bav-N; (TA;) † I revealed, or showed, to him my secret, or the secret: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or Oabovavotuhu↓ sir-iI (T) and baAvavotuhu↓ sir-iI (A) ‡ I acquainted him with my secret: (T, A:) and Abv-hu↓ AlHadiyva † he acquainted him with the discourse, narration, or information. (M.) And bav-ahu Xuquwrahu † He complained to him of his state, or condition. (M, in art. Xqr.)
2. bv-v Alxabara He spread, or disseminated, the news, tidings, or information, much: (Ṣ:) or i. q. bav-ahu, q. v. (Ḳ.)
3. baAvavatuhu sir-iI: see 1; last sentence but one.
bayonahumaA mubaAv-apN ‡ [Between them two is a mutual revealing of secrets: see 6]. (A.)
4: see 1, in six places.

Oabovavotuka [without a second objective complement,] † I revealed, or showed, or have revealed or shown, to thee my bav-, (Ṣ, TA,) whence the verb in this sense is derived; (TA;) i. e., my state, (Ṣ,) or my grief, or sorrow. (Ṣ, TA.)
6. tabaAv-uwA † [They revealed secrets, one to another: see 3]. (Ḳ, in art. njv.)

7. Anbv- It spread; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) it became dispersed, scattered, or disseminated; (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (M, L;) or ‡ news, tidings, or information. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) You say, Anbv-t Alxayolu The horses, or horsemen, spread, or became dispersed, or dispersed themselves, (M, L,) in a hostile incursion. (L.) And Anbv- AljaraAdu fiI AlOaroDi The locusts spread, or became dispersed, or dispersed themselves, in the land. (M, A, L.)
10. Astbv-hu Uiy-aAhu † He asked him, or petitioned him, to reveal it to him. (M, L, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. bavobava, inf. n. bavobavapN: see 1, in four places.
bavobava AlOamora † He inquired respecting the affair or event, scrutinized it, and sought information respecting it. (T, L.)

hom.sense: bavN (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and munobav-N↓, (A, TA,) both applied to dates, (tamorN, Aṣ, Ṣ, &c.,) Scattered, strewn, dispersed, and separate, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) one from another: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or separate, or disunited, not being packed, or not campact: (A:) or not well packed, (Ṣ, M,) so that they are separated, or disunited: (M:) or scattered; not in the bag or other receptacle; like fav-N: (M:) tamorN bavN being a phrase [in which the latter word is an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.,] like maMCN gaworN. (Ṣ.)
A state, or condition. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Grief, or sorrow, (T, Ṣ, M,) which one makes known to his companion or friend: (T:) or violent, or intense, grief or sorrow; and violent, or severe, disease or sickness; as though, in consequence of its violence, one made it known to his companion or friend: (T, TA:) or the most violent or intense grief or sorrow. (Ḳ.) HaDaraniI bav-iI, occurring in a trad., means My grief, or sorrow, became violent, or intense. (TA.)

entry.sense: zariAbiI-u mabovuwvapN [in the Ḳur lxxxviii. 16] means Goodly carpets, or the like, (Bḍ,) spread: (A, Bḍ:) or, accord. to Fr, many in number. (T.)
munobav-N: see bavN.
Scattered dust: so in the Ḳur [lvi. 6]. (T.)
† Swooning (Ḳ) from grief, or sorrow. (TA.)

1. bavira, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabovaru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. buvuwrN; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and bavura, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabovuru}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. bavorN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buvuwrN; (M, Ḳ;) and bavurN, aor. _u {yabovuru}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) It (a man's face, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, or the skin, M, A, Mṣb) broke out with pimples, or small pustules; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tbv-r↓: (M, A, and some copies of the Ḳ:) or this last signifies it (a man's skin) became blistered, or vesicated. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
2. bv-r It (tar) [made a camel to break out with small pustules; or] excoriated a camel, and made him to bleed. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA in art. HrX.)
5: see 1.

bavorN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bavarN↓, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) coll. gen. ns., (Mṣb,* MF,) originally inf. ns., (Mṣb,) Pimples, or small pustules; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to some, specially upon the face; (M, TA;) as also buvuwrN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) which is the pl. of bavorF: (Mṣb:) ns. un. bavaraAtN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and bavarapN: (M, Mṣb:) and pl. of this last bavaraAtN: (Mṣb:) or buvuwrN, pl. of bavorN, signifies purulent pustules like the small-pox, upon the face and other parts of the person of a man. (T.) You say, xarajato bihi bavorapN faEaSarahaA [A pimple, or small pustule, or purulent pustule, came forth on him, and he squeezed it]. (A.) And bijilodihi bavorN Xat-aI [In his skin are scattered, or sundry, pimples,, &c.]. (A.)
bavarN: see bavorN.

hom.sense:
1. bavaqa AlmaMCa, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaboviqu} and _u {yabovuqu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bavoqN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He made an opening for the water by breaking through the bank, or the dam that confined it. (Mgh, Mṣb.*) And bavaqa Aln-ahora, inf. n. bavoqN (Lth, Ḳ) and bivoqN, (Ḳ, TA,) in some of the copies of the Ṣ [and in the CK] bavaqN, but this is wrong, though Ru-beh has used it by poetic license, (TA,) and tabovaAqN, (Ḳ,) He broke [through] the bank of the river, or rivulet, in order that the water might pour out, or flow forth; (Lth, Ḳ, TA;)
as also bvuq↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboviyqN; the latter not commonly mentioned. (TA.) And bavaqa Als-ayolu mawoDiEa kacaA, aor. _u {yabovuqu}, inf. n. bavoqN and bivoqN, on the authority of Yaạḳoob, The torrent broke through, and clave, such a place. (Ṣ.)
See also 7.
bavaqat AlEayonu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabovuqu}, inf. n. bavoqN and tabovaAqN, (TA,) The eye shed tears quickly. (AA, Ḳ.)
bavaqati Alr-akiy-apu, (AZ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabovuqu}, (AZ, TA,) inf. n. buvuwqN The well became full, and abundant in water. (AZ, Ḳ.)
baviqa, aor. _a {yabovaqu}, [inf. n., by rule, bavaqN,] It (seed-produce) became affected with the disease termed bavoqN. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

7. Anbvq It (water) had vent; or it poured out, or flowed forth: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or it ran, or flowed, of itself, without the breaking through of a dam or the like. (Mgh.) [For Ainofajara, in the Ṣ, Golius appears to have found Ainofaraja, which is a mistake.]
[The Christians, as Golius has observed, use this verb to denote the procession of the Holy Spirit.]
Anbvq Als-ayolu Ealayohimo ‡ The torrent came upon them without their expecting it, or thinking it. (Ḳ,* TA.) And bavaqa↓ AlmaMCu Ealayohimo † The water came upon them. (TA.)
Anbvq Ealayohimo biAlkilaAmi ‡ He came upon them with speech without their expecting it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Anbvqt AlOaroDu ‡ The land became abundant in herbage, or fruitful. (TA.)

hom.sense: bavoqN and bivoqN↓ An opening made for water by breaking through the bank, or the dam that confined it: (Mgh, Mṣb:*) or the place where the bank of a river, or rivulet, is broken [through] in order that the water may pour out, or flow forth: a place where water has vent, or pours out, or flows forth: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies a place furrowed, or hollowed out, by water: (JK:) pl. buvuwqN. (JK, Ḳ.)
Also the former, A disease that affects seed-produce, occasioned by rain. (TA.)

entry.sense: bivoqN: see bavoqN.
baAviqN [act. part. n. of 1].
rakiy-apN baAviqapN A well full, and abundant in water. (Ḳ.) And miyaAhN buv-aqN [pl. of baAviqN], like ruk-aEN [pl. of raAkiEN, app. Waters flowing forth abundantly]. (TA.)
[Hence,] huwa baAviqu Alkarami † He is abundant in generosity. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. yajiHa, [aor. and inf. n. as below,] He rejoiced; or was joyful, glad, or happy; (Ṣ, A;) as also tbj-H↓: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) and ↓the latter signifies also he magnified himself; and gloried, or boasted: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Lḥ, this verb signifies he gloried, or boasted; and vied with others, or contended with them for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness, in respect of something; as also tmjiH: or, as some say, he magnified himself: and bajiEa is said to signify he was, or became, great in his own estimation. (TA.) You say also, bajiEa bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabojaHu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bajaHN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and bajaHa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabojaHu}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) but the latter is of weak authority; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He rejoiced in it, or at it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ;) as also tbj-H↓ and AbtjH↓: (TA:) or he gloried in it, or boasted of it; and so tbj-H↓. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN yatabaj-aHu↓ EalayonaA, and yatamaj-aHu ElynA, Such a one talks foolishly, or irrationally, [to us, assuming superiority over us,] by reason of self-conceitedness: and so one says in speaking of a person in jest. (TA.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. bj-Huh It (a thing, or an affair, TA) rejoiced him; made him joyful, glad, or happy; (A, TA;) as also AbjH-Hu↓. (TA.) And baj-aHotuhu, (inf. n. tabojiyEN, Ṣ, Ḳ,) I rejoiced him; made him joyful,, &c.: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or, as some say, magnified him: (TA:) and bajaHotuhu↓, aor. _i {yabojiHu}, I magnified it; namely, a thing. (Mṣb.)
4: see 2.
5: see 1, in five places.
6. Aln-isaMCu yatabaAjaHona Women, or the women, vie, or contend for superiority, one with another, in beauty, or goodliness, and in glorying, or boasting. (A, TA.)
8: see 1.
Joyful; [an intensive epithet] applied to a man. (TA.)
baAjiHN Great in estimation; applied to a man: pl. buj-aEN and bujoHN. (TA.)

mabaAjiHu [a pl. of which the sing. is app. mabojaHapN, meaning, accord. to analogy, A cause of joy or gladness or happiness]. You say, laqiytu minohu AlmanaAjiHa wAlmabaAjiHa [app. I experienced from it, or him, the causes of success, and the causes of joy, &c.]. (A, TA.)
mutabaj-iHN: see bajiEN.

1. bajada biAlmakaAni, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yabojudu}, (L,) inf. n. bujuwdN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and tabojiydN; (Kr;) and bj-d↓, inf. n. tabojiydN; (L, Ḳ;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) in the place; (Ṣ, A, L;) settled, or remained fixed, in it; not quitting it. (A.)
bajadati AlUibalu, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. bujuwdN; and bj-dt↓; (L;) The camels kept to the place of pasturing. (L, Ḳ.)
2: see 1, in two places.
bajadN A company, or an assembly, of men: and a hundred, and more, of horses: (L, Ḳ:) on the authority of El-Hejeree: (TA:) pl. bujuwdN. (L.)
bajodapN i. q. OaSolN [The root, basis, or foundation; or the origin, or source; or the most essential part, or very essence; of a thing]. (Ḳ.)

And [hence, app.,] The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of a case or an affair; as also bujodapN↓ and bujudapN↓: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or the true, or real, state or circumstances thereof; the positive, or established, truth thereof; from bajada baAlmakaAni. (A.) You say, huwa EaAlimN bibajodapi Oamorika, (Ṣ, A, L,) and bibujodatihi↓, and bibujudatihi↓, (Ṣ, L,) He is acquainted with the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of thy case or affair: (Ṣ, L:) or, with the true, or real, state or circumstances thereof; with the positive, or established, truth thereof. (A.) And Einodihu bajodapu celika, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) He possesses the knowledge of that. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hence, (Ṣ,) hawa Qbonu bajodatihaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) contr. of hw Abn njodatihaA, (A in art, njd,) or, as in the books of proverbs, OanaA Qbonu bajodatihaA, the [affixed] pronoun referring to AlOaroD [understood], as is said by Meyd and Z, (TA,) applied to [signify He is, or I am,] the person acquainted with the thing; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) possessing, or exercising, the skill requisite for it; (Ṣ, L;) the discriminator, or discerner, thereof; (L;) and one says likewise, huwa Qbonu madiynatihaA waQbonu bajodatihaA: (TA:) it is also applied to [signify he is, or I am,] the skilful guide of the way [thereof]: (L, Ḳ:) and hence, [accord. to some,] it is proverbially applied to any one acquainted with an affair; skilful therein: (TA:) and to [signify he is, or I am,] the person who will not quit, or depart from, his place; from the saying bajada baAlmakaAni: (L:) or the person who will not depart from his saying: (Ḳ: [there explained by the words limano laA yaboraHu mino qawolihi: but the TA supplies some apparent omissions in this explanation, making it to agree with that which here immediately precedes it, taken from the L; and adds that, in some copies of the Ḳ, En qwlh is erroneously put for mn qwlh: also, that he who remains in a place knows that place:]) or, accord. to some, bajodapN signifies dust, or earth; so that OanaA Qbonu bajodatahaA is as though it meant I am created of its dust, or earth. (TA.)

Also A [desert, such as is termed] SaHoriMC. (Ḳ.) Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr uses the phrase Aibonu bajodatahaA as meaning Its male chameleon; the pronoun referring to a desert (falaAp) which he is describing. (TA.) And you say of a land covered with black locusts, OaSobaHati AlOaroDu bajodahF waAHidapF [The land became, or has become, one desert, destitute of vegetable produce]. (L.)
bujodahN and bujudapN: see bajodapN; each in two places.

bijaAdN A striped garment of the kind called kisaMC, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) being one of the kinds of kasMC worn by the Arabs of the desert: (Ṣ, L:) or, of which the wool has been spun, or twisted, in the manner termed yasorapF [app. a mistranscription for yasorFA (see fatolN yasorN in art. ysr)], and woven with the instrument called SiySap: pl. bujudN: a single oblong piece thereof is called faliyjN, of which the pl. is fulujN. (L, TA.)
Also A kind of tent, of [the soft hair called] wabar. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, TA voce bayotN, q. v.)
baAjidN Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, in a place; (L;) settled, or remaining fixed, in a land. (A.)

1. yajira, aor. _a {yabojaru}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. bajarN, (Ṣ, M,) He (a man, Ṣ) had his navel, or the part remaining of the navel-string after it had been cut, protruding, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) elevated, and hard, (TA,) and thick at the base, (Ṣ, M,) and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part. (M.)
He was, or became, large in the belly. (Ḳ.)

His (a man's, TA) belly became full of milk, (Ḳ,) or pure milk, (TA,) and of water, and he was not satiated; (Ḳ;) as also majira: (TA:) or he drank much milk, or water, and was hardly, or not at all, satiated. (Lḥ, TA.)
bajorN: see bujorN, in three places.

hom.sense: Evil; mischief: a great, terrible, or momentous, thing or case; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bajorN↓ and bujoriI-N↓: (TA:) a wonderful thing: (Ḳ:) a calamity, or misfortune; (Ṣ;) as also bajorN↓ (TA) and bujoriI-N↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bujoriy-apN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of bujorN [or pl. pl., being app. pl. of the pl. of pauc. OabojurN,] OabaAjiru; and pl. pl. (as though pl. of the pl. OabojaArN, T) OabaAjiyru: (Ḳ:) and pl. of bujoriI-N↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and of bujoriy-apN↓ (Ḳ) bajaAriI-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say OamorN bujorN A great, terrible, or momentous, thing or case. (TA.) And qaAla hujorFA wabujorFA [He said a foul and] a wonderful thing. (TA.) And Uin-ahu layajiIoCu biAlOabaAjiri Verily he brings to pass calamities, or misfortunes. (A.) And laqiytu minohu AlbajaAriI-a I experienced from him calamities, or misfortunes. (AZ, Ṣ.) And Uin-amaA huwa Alfajoru Oawi Albajoru↓ or Albujoru [It is only the daybreak or misfortune]: a saying of Aboo-Bekr; meaning, if thou wait until the daybreak shine, thou wilt see the way; but if thou journey without a guide in the darkness, it will lead thee to evil: but the saying is recited differently; with AlbHr in the place of Albjr. (L. [See baHorN.])
[See also bujolN.]

entry.sense: bajarN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (M.)
See also bujorN.

bajarN A man (TA) having his belly full of milk, (Ḳ,) or pure milk, (TA,) and of water, without being satiated: (Ḳ:) or drinking much milk, or water, and being hardly, or not at all, satiated. (Lḥ, TA.)
bajorahN Prominence, or protrusion, in the navel: (Mgh:) or largeness of the belly: pl. bajaraAtN. (Yákoot, TA.) [See what next follows.]

bujorapN A tumour, or swelling, or an inflation, in the navel; the like of which in the back is termed EujorahN: (IAạr, IAth:) or the part of the navel-string which remains after it has been cut, when it is thick at the base, and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part; as also bajarapN↓: (ISd, L:) or the navel, (L, Ḳ,) of a man and of a camel, (L,) whether large or not: (L, Ḳ:) and a knot in the belly: (L, Ḳ:) or a knotted vein in the belly; the like of which in the back is termed EujorapF: (L:) and (as some say, L) a knot in the face, and in the neck: (L, Ḳ:) pl. bujarN. (L.) [See also EujorapN.]

[Hence,] cakara Eujarahu wabujarahu ‡ He mentioned his vices, or faults, and his whole state or case: (Ḳ:) or all his affairs; those which were apparent and those which were hidden: or his secrets: or his vices, or faults. (TA.) And OafaDayotu Uilayoka biEujariI wabujariI ‡ I have revealed to thee my vices, or faults; meaning, my whole state or case. (Ṣ.) And Oaxobarotuhu biEujariI wabujariI ‡ I acquainted him with my vices, or faults, which I conceal from others, by reason of my confidence in him. (Aṣ.) And OaXokuw UilaI Qll-ehi EujariI wabujariI, said by ʼAlee, ‡ I complain unto God of my sorrows and my griefs; (IAạr, IAth;) meaning, all my affairs or circumstances; those which are apparent and those which are hidden. (IAth.) [See, again, EujorapN.]

It is said in a prov., Eay-ara bujayorN↓ bujaraho nasiIa bujayorN xabaraho, meaning † [Bujeyr cast reproach upon] his vices, or faults: [Bujeyr forgot his own state or condition:] or, as some say, they were two men: [so that the meaning is, Bujeyr reproached Bujarah:, &c.:] (Ṣ:) accord. to El-Mufaddal, Bujeyr and Bujarah were two brothers, in an ancient age: but accord. to the lexicologists, the meaning is, that one affected with what is termed a bujorap in his navel reproached another for that which was in him. (Az, TA.)
bajarapN: see bujorapN.
bujoriI-N: see bujorN, in three places.
bujoriy-apN: see bujorN, in two places.

bajiyrN is an imitative sequent to kaviyrN. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to AA, it signifies Abundant, or much, wealth: [or rather this seems to be the meaning of the phrase maAlN bajiyrN: for it is added,] and in like manner [it is used in the phrase], makaAnN EamiyrN bajiyrN [A place inhabited, peopled, well stocked with people and the like, or in a flourishing state, and large, or ample]. (TA.)
bujayorN: see bujorapN.
baAjirN: see what follows.

Oabojaru A man (Ṣ) having his navel, or the part remaining of the navel-string after its having been cut, protruding, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and elevated, and hard, (TA,) and thick at the base, (Ṣ, M,) and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part: (M:) fem. bajoraMCu: (Ṣ:) pl. bujorN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bujoraAnN. (Ḳ.)

Large in the belly: pl. as above: and baAjirN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) or this latter, having a swollen, or an inflated, belly: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or having a large belly and a protruding navel: and its pl. is bajarapN, occurring in a trad., in which the tribe of Kureysh are described as OaXiH-apN bajarapN: or bjrp may here mean ‡ hoarders and acquirers of wealth. (L.)

One says also HaqiybapN bajoraMCu † A full [receptacle of the kind called] Hqybp; and SurarN bujorN † full purses; and kiysN OaEojazu [or OaEojaru?]: but they did not say, HaqiybapN EajozaMCu [or EajoraMCu?]; nor kiysN Oabojaru; though analogy does not disagree to it: it is from bujorN signifying “prominence in the belly.” (Ḥar p. 639.)
And OaroDN bajoraMCu † Ground, or land, that is elevated, (Ḳ,* TA,) and hard. (TA.)
Oabojaru also signifies † The rope of a ship; (Ḳ;) because of its greatness in relation to ropes in general. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. bajasa AlmaMCa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabojusu} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yabojisu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. bajosN, (Mṣb, TA,) He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; gave vent to it; made it to flow; syn. fajarahu, (Ṣ,) or fataHahu, (Mṣb,) or Xaq-ahu: (A, Ḳ:) [all of which, in this case, signify the same:] and in like manner one says of a wound; (A, Ḳ;) but in this case, the phrase is tropical: (TA:) and bj-s↓ AlamMCi, inf. n. tabojiysN, He (namely, God, TA) made the water to flow forth, or to flow forth copiously, syn. faj-arahu, (Ḳ, TA,) from the cloud or clouds, and from the spring. (TA.)
See also 7, in two places.

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5: see 7, in three places.

7. Anbjs It (water) had a way, passage, vent, or channel, opened for it to flow forth; it had vent; it poured forth; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [it burst forth;] from a cloud or clouds, and from a spring; (A;) and from a rock; (Ḳur vii. 160;) as also bajasa↓, aor. _u {yabojusu}; (Ṣ, TA;) and tbj-s↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) syn. of the first, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,* TA,) and last, (Ṣ,) Ainofajara: (Ṣ, A, TA:) or of the last, tafaj-ara [properly signifying it poured forth copiously]: (A, TA:) AinobijaAsN signifies particularly the welling forth [of water] from a spring: or it has a general application: (Ḳ:) and bajosN↓ signifies cracking in a water-skin, or stone, or earth, so that water issues from it. (TA.) You say, Als-aHaAbu yanobajisu biAlmaTari [The clouds pour with rain]. (TA.) And OataAnaA bivariydK yatabaj-asu↓, (A,) or yatabaj-asu↓ OudomFA, (TA,) [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth, which streamed with seasoning,] meaning, by reason of the abundance of grease [in it]. (A, TA.)

maMCN bajosN Water having a way, passage, vent, or channel, opened for it to flow forth; having a vent; or pouring forth: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, saHaAbN bajosN [clouds pouring forth rain]; (TA;) and [so] saHaAYibu buj-asN [pl. of baAjisN↓ and baAjisapN]: (Ṣ:) and maMCN bajiysN↓ flowing water: (Kr, TA:) and EayonN bajiysN↓ a copious spring. (Ḳ,* TA.)
bajysN: see bajosN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. bajula, aor. _u {yabojulu}, inf. n. bajaAlapN and bujuwlN, He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed bajaAl and bajiyl [i. e. magnified, honoured,, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

bajala, aor. _a {yabojalu}; and bajala, aor. _u {yabojulu}, inf. n. bajolN and bujuwlN; He was, or became, in a good state or condition; having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (Ḳ.)
And He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (Ḳ.)

[bajalahu He bled him (namely, a horse, or a camel,) by opening the vein called AlOabojal: so accord. to analogy; like wadajahu, meaning “he bled him by opening the vein called Alwadaj,”, &c.] lamo yubojalo means He had not been bled in the Oabojal. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. bj-lhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabojiylN, He magnified, honoured, revered, venerated, or respected, him: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he said to him bajalN, meaning Sufficient for thee (jasobuka) is the place [or condition or rank] which thou hast attained. (Ḳ.)
4. Abjlhu It sufficed, or contented, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It rejoiced him. (TA.)
bujolN: see bajalN.

hom.sense:
bajalo is a noun (Mughnee) syn. with Hasobu: (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ:*) and is also a verbal noun syn. with yakofiI. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*) You say bajaliI (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ) and bajoliI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning HasobiI [My sufficiency, or a thing sufficing me, i. e. sufficient for me, is such a thing]: (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ:) [it is said in the Ḥam, p. 145, as on the authority of Akh, that they do not say bajolI; but this is a mistranscription for bajaloniI, as will be seen from what follows:] and, using it as a verbal noun, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) but this is rare, (Mughnee,) you say bajaloniI, meaning yakofiyniI [It suffices me, or will suffice me]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and bajaloka, meaning yakofiyka [It suffices thee, or will suffice thee]: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Akh, they say bajaloka, like as they say, qaToka; but not bajaloniI, like qaToniI: (Ṣ:) or the n in bajaloniI is absolutely necessary accord. to him who says that bajalN is a verbal noun; and accord. to him who says that this word is syn. with Hasobu, the n is allowable. (MF.) [See, under the words qado and qaTo, what is said respecting qadoniI and qaToniI.] In the saying of Jábir Ibn-Ra-lán Es-Simbisee,
lam-aA raOato maEoXarFA qal-ato Hamuwlatuhumo
qaAlato suEaAdu OahecaA maAlukumo bajalaA
[When she saw a company whose beasts of burden were few, So'ád said, Is this your property, sufficing you?] meaning, when she saw the fewness of our camels: the last word occupies the place of a denotative of state, and is made to end thus by poetic license: Abu-l-ʼAlà says that this word may be put in the accus. case as meaning not exceeding what I see; or it may be for bajaliI, after the manner of some of the Arabs who are related, by Akh and others, to have said gulaAmaA for gulaAmiI. (Ḥam pp. 299 and 300.) [See also 2: and see bajalN.]
It is also a particle, (Mughnee,) meaning naEamo [Yes; yea; or even so]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: bajalN Calumny, slander, or false accusation: or this is with damm; (Ḳ;) i. e. bujolN↓; (T, TA;) meaning a great calumny, &c.; (Ḳ,* TA;) and Az thinks that this may be a dial. var. of bujorN, with which it is syn.; because l and r are interchanged in many instances. (TA.)
A wonderful thing; syn. EajabN. (Ḳ.)

cuw AlbaHali denotes dispraise; meaning Content with mean things; not desirous of the means of acquiring eminence: (Ḳ:) or content that another should manage affairs in his stead, and that he should be a burden upon others, saying, Sufficient for me (HasobiI [or bajaliI]) is that [state or condition] wherein I am: (O, TA:) from a saying of Luk- mán Ibn-'Ád; (O, Ḳ;) as is also cuw Albajolapi, which denotes praise. (O, TA.)

bajolapN A goodly, or beautiful, from or appearance, figure, person, mien, or external state or condition: (Sh, Ḳ:) a pleasing aspect; goodliness, or beauty; grounds of pretension to respect; and excellence; or sharpness, or quickness, of intellect. (TA.) You say, Uin-ahu lacuw bajolapK [Verily he has a goodly, or beautiful, form, &c.]. (Sh, TA.) [See the end of the next preceding paragraph.]
A small tree: pl. bajalaAtN. (Ḳ.)

bajaAlN and bajiylN↓, applied to a man, i. q. mubaj-alN↓ [Magnified, honoured, revered, venerated, or respected]: (Sh, Ḳ:) or bulky, or corpulent; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) applied to a man; (Aṣ, TA;) or to an old man: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies an old, or aged, lord or chief: (AA, Ṣ:) or a bulky, or corpulent, old man: or, as some say, one beyond the middle age, in whom one sees goodliness of form or appearance, and advancement in years: (Mgh:) or both signify an old man, who is a great lord or chief, endowed with goodliness, and with excel-lence, or sharpness of intellect: (Ḳ:) not applied to a woman; (TA;) i. e., a woman is not termed bajaAlapN. (Mgh.)
bajiylN: see bajaAlN.
Also Gross, big, thick, coarse, or rough; applied to anything. (Ḳ.)
OamorN bajiylN An affair, an event, or a case, deemed strange, or evil, and great, or formidable. (TA.) xayorN bajiylN Ample, abundant, good or wealth or prosperity. (TA.)

baAjilN Being in a good state or condition; having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life; (Ḳ;) applied to a man and to a camel: (TA:) or, as Yaạḳoob says, on the authority of Abu-l-Ghamr El-'Okeylee, having much fat; applied to a man and a she-camel and a he-camel. (Ṣ.)
Also Joyful, glad, or happy. (Ḳ.)

Oabojalu A certain vein, (Ṣ,) a thick vein, (Ḳ, Ḥam p. 417,) of the horse and of the camel, (Ṣ, TA,) in the thigh and the shank, (Ḥam ubi suprà,) or in the kind leg or the fore leg, (TA,) corresponding to the Oakomal (Ṣ, Ḳ) of man: (Ṣ:) pl. OabaAjilu. (Ḥam ubi suprà, TA.) You say, faSada Oabojalahu [He opened his Abjl]; i. e., the horse's or the camel's. (TA.) And one says of a swift horse, huwa waAhiI AlOabaAjili [He is lax in the AbAjl]. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)
mub-j-alN: see bajaAlN.

1. baH-a, (L,) first pers. baHiHotu, aor. yabaH-u, (ISk, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and ISd says, I see, or think, that Lḥ has mentioned yaboHaHu, which is extr. with respect to rule, (TA,) inf. n. baHaHN; (ISk, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and first pers. baHaHotu, (AO, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but the former is the more chaste, (T, TA,) aor. yabaE-u (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ) and yabiE-u and yabuE-u, [which last is contr. to analogy,] (L,) inf. n. baE-u (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ) and baHaHN and baHaAHN and buHuwHN and baHaAHapN and buHuwHapN; (Ḳ;) He had a hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, voice; (L;) he was taken with a hoarseness, harshness, roughness, or gruffness, of the voice. (Ḳ.)
It is tropically used in speaking of inanimate things; as in baE-a AlEuwdu, meaning ‡ [The lute] was rough [in sound: see OabaE-u]. (A.)
4. AbH-hu It (crying out, or vociferating,) rendered him hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, in voice. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
8. humo fiI QbotiHaAHK They are in a state of amplitude, and of plenty, or of abundance of herbage or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. baHobaEa: see R. Q. 2, in two places.

R. Q. 2. tabaHobaEa Ald-aAra, (Ḳ,) and baHobaEahaA↓, (TA,) † He was, or became, [established] in the middle, or midst, [which is the best part,] of the dAr [i. e. abode, or district, or country,, &c.], (Ḳ, TA,) and became possessed of mastery, dominion, or authority, and power, over it. (TA.) Fr, however, makes tabaHobuHN to be from eAlbaAHapu [q. v.], not from a reduplicative root. (TA.)

tbHbH also signifies † He was, or became, settled, or established, in authority and power, (syn. tamak-ana,) in alighting, and taking up his abode, or sojourning; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and was, or became, [established] in the middle, or midst, [or best part,] of the place of abode; (TA;) and so bHbH↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also ‡ He took a wide, an ample, or a large, range. (A.)
[Hence,] tbHbH AlHayaA † The rain became of wide extent, and had influence upon the land. (TA, from a trad.)
And tabaHobaHati AlEarabu fiI lugaAtihaA ‡ The Arabs were copious, or took a wide range, in their dialects. (A.)
And tbHbH fiI Almajodi † He became in an ample state of glory, honour, or dignity. (TA.)
An Arab of the desert said, of a woman in labour, tarakotuhaA tabaHobaHu EalaI OayodiI AlqawaAbili [app. † I left her obtaining delivery by the hands of the midwives]. (AZ, TA.)
buH-apN: see OabaH-u.

buH-apN (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and buHaAHN↓ (L) Hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, of the voice; (E, Ḳ;) which is sometimes natural: or the former is applied absolutely, and the latter to that which arises from disease. (L.)
You say, fiI Sawotihi buH-apN [In his voice is hoarseness,, &c.]. (Ṣ, A.)
buHaAHN: see buH-apN.
baHobaHiI-N † Ample in expenditure: and having an ample place of abode. (Fr, Ḳ.)
buHobuwHN: see what next follows.

buHobuwHapN † The middle, or midst, [or best part,] syn. wasaTN, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of an abode, or a district, or country, (Ṣ, A,) or a place, (Ḳ,) and of a place where one alights and abides, (TA,) and of Paradise, and of anything, and the best part thereof; (AʼObeyd, TA;) [like wasaTN, by which it is explained; because what is between the two extremes is generally the best: it may be well rendered the heart, or very heart, of a thing;] and buHobuwHN↓, also, has the former of these significations [and by implication the other likewise]. (TA, voce buWobuWN, where see an ex.) Jereer says,
qawomiI tamiymN humu Alqawomu Alc-ayna humu
yanofuwna tagoliba Eano buHobuwHapi Ald-aAri
[My people are Temeem: they are the people who drive away Teghlib from the middle, or best part, of the country]. (Ṣ.) [It is said in the A, that this word, as syn. with wasaTN, in relation to an abode or the like (dAr), is tropical; but I see no reason for this, unless by wsT be meant the “best part.”]

hom.sense: OabaH-N, applied to a man, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or OabaH-N AlS-awoti, (A,) Having a hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, voice: (L, Ḳ:) fem. baH-aMCu; with which baH-apN↓ is syn.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. buH-N. (Ṣ.) baAH-N is not allowable. (Ṣ.)
And OabaH-u applied to a lute (EuwdN), ‡ Rough (Ḳ, TA) in sound. (TA.)
Also ‡ The base, or thick, chord of a lute; syn. bam-u; because of its rough sound. (TA.)
‡ A [gold coin of the kind called] diynaAr; (Ḳ, TA;) because of its harsh sound [when one rings it]. (TA.)

‡ A qidoH [or gaming-arrow] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) by means of which lots, or portions, are divided: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. buH-N: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or such an arrow that has no sound. (TA.) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh says,
qarawoA OaDoyaAfahumo rabaHFA bibuH-K
yaEiyXu bifaDolihin-a AlHaI-u sumori
[They entertained their guests with young weaned she-camels, on the superabundant remains of which the tribe lived, by means of tawny-coloured gaming-arrows whereby the lots that determined who should afford the entertainment were divided: or, accord. to the TA, rbHA here signifies fat, as a subst.; but this is inconsistent with the affixed pronoun relating to it]. (Ṣ.)
† Fat, as an epithet, not a subst. (Ḳ.)
kisorN OabaH-u † [A portion of a limb,, &c.,] having much fat. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. baHuta, aor. _u {yaboHutu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. buHuwtapN, (Ḳ,) or baHotN, (Mṣb,) It (a thing) was, or became, unmixed, free from admixture, or pure: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and] he was unmixed, or pure, in race, lineage, or parentage. (Mṣb.)

3. bAHt AlmaMCa, (A,) inf. n. mubaAHatapN, (TA,) He drank water, or the water, not upon vufol [i. e. without having eaten anything such as flesh-meat or bread or dates or grain]: (A:) or he drank water, or the water, not mixed with honey or any other thing. (TA.) And bAHt AlX-araAba He drank the wine, or beverage, pure, without any mixture. (A.) And bAHt Alr-imova [He (a camel) ate of the shrub called rmv without any other pasture]. (T in art. TlH.) And bAHt daAb-atahu biAlD-ariyEi He fed his beast with DryE, (i. e. dry herbage, TA,) and the like, unmixed [with other pasture]. (Ḳ.)

bAHthu Alwud-a He regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he was pure, or sincere, to him in love, or affection. (M.) And bAHt AlqitaAla He fought with earnestness and energy, unmixed with lenity. (A,* TA.) And bAHt fulaAnFA (inf. n. as above, TA) He acted openly, or undisguisedly, with, or towards, such a one. (Ḳ, TA.)

baHotN Unmixed, free from admixture, or pure; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) applied to anything: (A, Ḳ:) anything that is eaten alone, without seasoning or condiment or any savoury food: and in like manner, seasoning, or condiment, or any savoury food, without bread: (Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà:) unmixed, or pure, in race, lineage, or parentage; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) applied [for instance] to an Arab, (Ṣ, A,) and to an Arab of the desert: (TA:) originally an inf. n.; (Mṣb;) [and therefore] the same as masc. and fem. and dual and pl.: but if you will, you may use baHotapN as a fem. epithet, applied [for instance] to an Arab woman; and may use the dual and pl. forms: (Ṣ:) or the fem. is [properly] with p {baHotapN}; or, as some say, the word has no dual nor pl. nor dim. form. (Ḳ.) You say XaraAbN baHotN Unmixed wine or beverage: (Ṣ:) and xamorN baHotN and baHotapN and xumuwrN baHotapN [unmixed wine and wines]. (TA.) And xubozN baHotN Bread without anything else [to season it]. (Ṣ.) And Oakala Alxuboza baHotFA, and All-aHoma baHotFA, He ate the bread without any seasoning or condiment or savoury food, and the flesh-meat without bread. (TA.) And qad-ama Uilayohi qafaArFA baHotFA He presented to him food without any seasoning or condiment. (A.) And Ad-ahana biduhonK baHotN He anointed himself with ointment unmixed with any perfume. (Mgh.) And misokN baHonN (A, Mṣb) [Unmixed, or unadulterated, and therefore] strong [-scented,] musk. (Mṣb.) And barodN baHotN laHotN Vehement, or intense, cold; (TA;) [as though unmixed with any degree of warmth;] syn. SaAdiqN: (Ḳ in art. lHt:) the last word is an imitative sequent. (TA in that art.)

1. baHavahu, aor. _a {yaboHavu}, inf. n. baHovN, He scraped it up; [as one who seeks to find a thing therein;] namely, the dust, or earth: (L:) and he searched, or sought, for it, or after it, (namely, a thing,) in the dust, or earth; as also AbtHvhu↓: (L, TA:) thus each is made trans. by itself: and authors often say, baHava fiyhi [meaning he searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it]: (TA:) one says, baHava fiI AlOaroDi he dug up the earth; and thus it is used in the Ḳur v. 34: (Mṣb:) but accord. to the usage commonly known and obtaining, (TA,) you say, baHava Eanohu, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n.; (L, Mṣb;) as well as baHavahu; (L;) and AbtHv↓ Enh; (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) [in some copies of the Ḳ AnbHv, which is said in the TA to be a mistake; and AbtHvhu↓; (see above;)] and tbH-v↓ Enh; (T, L, Ḳ;) and AstbHv↓ Enh; (L, Ḳ;) and AstbHvhu↓; (L;) [he scraped up the dust, or earth, from over it: and hence,] he searched, or sought, for it, after it, or respecting it; he inquired, and sought for information, respecting it; he searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; he inquired respecting it, and searched to the utmost after it; (Ṣ,* A,* L, Mṣb,* Ḳ;*) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, L,) or an affair, or event. (Mṣb.) You say also, AstbHv↓ OaxaAhu Eano sirih-i He examined his brother respecting his secret. (A in art. nbv.)

3. [bAHvhu Eano OamorK, inf. n. mubaAHavapN, He searched, or inquired, with him into a thing; or investigated, scrutinized, or examined, with him a thing, or an affair: and particularly, in the way of disputation.]
EaAdatuhu Oano yubaAHiva wayubaAhita [His custom is to engage with another in mutual scrutiny of secrets, or faults, or the like, and in mutual calumniation,, &c.: see 6]. (A in art. bht.)
5: see 1.
6. tabaAHavuwA Eani AlOasoraAri They searched, or inquired, into each other's secrets. (A in art. nbv.)
8. UibotaHava see 1, in three places.
AbtHv also signifies He played with the dust, or earth, termed bHAvp; or at the game called AlbHvp. (Ḳ.) In a copy of the Ḳ, the verb is here incorrectly written AnbHv. (TA.)
10: see 1, in three places.

hom.sense: baHovN, (so in the Ḳ,) or bHiyvN↓, (so in the L,) accord. to Sh, (L,) A mine (L, Ḳ) in which one searches for gold and silver. (L.)
Also the former, A great serpent; (Ḳ;) because it scrapes up the dust or earth. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlbuHovapu, (as written in the L,) or AlbaHovapu, (as in the Ḳ,) accord. to Sh, (L,) and AlbuH-y-vaI↓, (L, Ḳ,) accord. to ISh, (L,) A certain game with buHaAvap↓, i. e, dust, or earth. (L, Ḳ.) You say, laEiba AlbuHovapa He played the game thus called. (L.)
UibilN baHuwvN Camels that scrape up the dust, or earth, with their fore feet, backwards, (AA, T, L, Ḳ,) in going; i. e., throwing it behind them; or, as some say, with their feet. (TA.)

AlbaHuwvu, (Ḳ,) or suwarpu AlbaHuwvi, (L,) thus written in the Fáïk, and if so, baHuwvN is an intensive epithet, applying alike to a masc. and a fem. noun, like SabuwrN; (TA;)
or, accord. to some, suwrapu AlbuHuwvi, (L,) pl. of baHovi; (TA;) a name of The chapter of the Ḳur-án called suwrapu Alt-awobapi, (L, Ḳ,) and AlbaraMCapi; (L;) [chap. ix.;] given to it because it inquires respecting the hypocrites and their secrets. (L.)
baHiyvN: see baHovN.

A secret: whence the prov., badaA baHiyvuhumo [Their secret became apparent, or revealed]. (TA. [But in the Ṣ, in art. njv, q. v., we find badaA najiyvu Alqawomi; and so in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 159.])
buHaAvapN Dust, or earth, (Az, Ḳ,) which is scraped up from what is searched for therein. (Az, TA.) See AlbuHovapu.
AlbuHayovaI: see AlbuHovapu.

baAHivN [act. part. n. of 1; Scraping up dust or earth:, &c.]. kaAlbaAHivi Eani AlX-aforapi [Like him who is scraping up the dust, or earth, from over the great knife with which he is to be slaughtered,] is a prov.: (Ṣ, L:) and so kabaAHivapK Eano HatofihaA biZilofihaA [Like one searching for her death with her hoof]: originating from the fact of a ewe's digging up a knife in the dust, or earth, and then being slaughtered with it. (L.)
baAHivaMCu Dust, or earth, (L, Ḳ,) of the burrow of the Jerboa, (L,) resembling the [hole termed] qaASiEaMC; (L, Ḳ;) but it is not this: pl. baAHivaAwaAtN. (L.)

maboHavN A place, and a time, of scraping up or digging; of searching, inquiring, investigating, scrutinizing, or examining: pl. mabaAHivu. (KL.) You say, tarakotuhu bimabaAHivi Albaqari (Ṣ, Ḳ*) [I left him in the places where the wild oxen scrape up the ground]; meaning, in a desert place, destitute of herbage, or of human beings; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in an unknown place; (Ḳ;) i. e., so that it was not known where he was. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. baHovara, [inf. n. baHovarapN,] He took, drew, or pulled, a thing out, or forth; and uncovered it, laid it open, or exposed it; (Abu-l-Jarráh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also baEovara. (Abu-l-Jarráh, Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [c. 9], accord. to one reading, buEovira buHovira maA fiI Alqubuwri, [instead of buEovira,] meaning [When that which is in the graves is taken forth and uncovered; i. e.,] when the dead are raised to life; syn. buEiva; and it is not improbable that baHovara may be composed of baHava and Oavara [app. a mistranscription for OavaAra], accord. to the opinion of those who hold that quadriliteral and quinqueliteral words are composed of two. (TA.)
He searched, or sought, for, or after, a thing in the dust or earth, or the like; syn. baHava [which IbrD thinks may be a mistake for baEava: but see baEovara]. (L, Ḳ, and Bḍ in c. 9.)

He separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing. (Ṣ.) He scattered, or dispersed, his household goods, or his commodities, and turned them over, one upon another; as also baEovara. (Fr, Ṣ.)
It (milk) curdled, or coagulated, and formed little clots of curd; syn. taqaT-aEa wataHab-aba. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. 2. tabaHovara It (a thing, Ṣ) became separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
labanN mubaHovirN Milk curdling, or coagulating, and forming little clots of curd. (Ḳ. [See Q. 1.]) When the upper portion is thick and the lower thin, it is termed haAdirN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baHara, (TA,) [aor. _a {yaboHaru},] inf. n. baHorN, (Ḳ,) He slit; cut, or divided, lengthwise; split; or clave; (Ḳ, TA;) and enlarged, or made wide. (TA.) Hence the term baHorN [as meaning “a sea” or “great river”] is said to be derived, because what is so called is cleft, or trenched, in the earth, and the trench is made the bed of its water. (TA.)

baHarahaA, (M,) or baHara OucunahaA, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaboHaru}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. baHorN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He slit her (a camel's, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, and a sheep's or goat's, M) ear, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in halves, or in halves lengthwise, (M, TA,) widely; (B;) and in like manner, baHarahu he slit his (a camel's) ear widely: (B:) and bH-r↓ McaAna AlOanoEaAmi, inf. n. taboHiyrN, He slit [&c.] the ears of the cattle. (Az, TA in art. btk.)
[baHura, aor. _u {yaboHuru}, inf. n. baHaArapN, It was, or became, wide, or spacious. The inf. n. is mentioned in the A: see baHorN: and see also 10.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. AbHr He embarked [or voyaged] upon the sea or a great river. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [Opposed to Oabar-a.]
‡ It (water, Ḳ, sweet water Ṣ, A) was, or became, salt. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.)
OaboHarati AlOaroDu The land abounded with places where water stagnated. (T, Ḳ.* [In the latter, manaAfiEuhaA is put by mistake for manaAqiEuhaA. See baHorapN.])
† He found water to be salt; not easy, or pleasant, to be drunk. (Ḳ, TA. [In some copies of the Ḳ, for lamo yasugo, we find lamo yamotaniEo, which is evidently a mistake.])
He met, or met with, a man unintentionally: (M, Ḳ:) from the phrase, laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tbH-r: see 10.
Also † He (a pastor) took a wide range in abundant pasturage. (TA.)
tbH-r fiI AlmaAli ‡ He enlarged himself, or he became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in wealth, or camels, or the like; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AstbHr↓ fyh. (TA.)

tbH-r fiI AlEilomi ‡ He went deep into science, or knowledge, and enlarged himself, or took a wide range, therein, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) wide as the sea; (TA;) and in like manner one says with respect to other things: (Ṣ:) and so AstbHr↓ fyh. (A, TA.)
10. AstbHr ‡ It (a place) became wide, or spacious, like the sea: (A:) it spread wide; became expanded; (Ḳ;) as also tbH-r↓. (TA.) [See also baHura.]
‡ He (a poet, A, Ḳ, and a xaTiyb, [i. e. a speaker, an orator, or the like,] A) expatiated in speech; was, or became, diffuse therein. (M, A, Ḳ.)
See also 5, in two places.

baHorN [A sea: and a great river:] a spacious place comprising a large quantity of water; (B;) a large quantity of water, (Ḳ, TA,) whether salt or sweet; (TA;) contr. of bar-N; (Ṣ, A;) so called because of its depth (Ṣ, TA) and large extent; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) from AlbaHaArapu; (A;) or because its bed is trenched in the earth; see 1: (TA:) or a large quantity of salt water, only; (Ḳ;) and so called because of its saltness: (El-Umawee, TA: [but accord. to the A, this word as an epithet meaning “salt” is tropical:]) or rather this is its general meaning: (TA:) for it signifies also any great river; (Ṣ, M, TA;) any river of which the water does not cease to flow; (Zj, T, TA;) such as the Euphrates, for instance; (Ṣ;) or such as the Tigris, and the Nile, and other similar great rivers of sweet water; of which the great salt baHor is the place of confluence; so called because trenched in the earth: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboHurN and [of mult.] biHaArN and buHuwrN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The dim. is OubayoHirN↓, (Ḳ,) which is anomalous; and buHayorN↓, which is the regular form: accord. to the Ḳ, the latter is not used; but this is untrue; for it is sometimes used, though rare. (MF.)

Hence its application in the saying of the Arabs, yaA haAdiIa All-ayoli jurota Uin-amaA huwa AlbaHoru Oawi Alfajoru, which Th explains by saying that the meaning is, ‡ [O guide of the night, thou hast deviated from the right way:] it is only destruction or thou wilt see the daybreak: the night is here likened to the sea [and with the night is associated the idea of destruction]: but accord. to one recital, it is Albajoru, instead of AlbaHoru. (TA. [See art. bjr.])
Also ‡ Salt; as an epithet, applied to water. (Ṣ, A.)

‡ A fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) that runs much; (Aṣ, TA;) that takes a wide range in his running; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, B;) that runs like the sea, or a great river; or like the sea, or a great river, when it rolls wave over wave. (Nifṭaweyh;, TA.)

‡ A generous man; (Ḳ, TA;) one who takes a wide range in his beneficence, bounty, or kindness; who abounds therein. (TA.) You say, laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA ‡ [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]: b here denoting substitution. (The Lubáb cited in the TA voce bi.) And laqiytu minohu baHorFA ‡ [I found him to be a man of exceeding generosity]; a phrase expressing an intensive degree of generosity: and raOayotu minohu baHorFA [signifies the same]. (Mughnee in art. bi.)
‡ A man of extensive knowledge or science; one who takes a wide range in his knowledge or science. (B.)
‡ Any person, or thing, that takes a wide range in a thing. (B.)

† Land of seed-produce and fruitfulness; or a tract, or region, in which are green herbs or leguminous plants, and waters; or the part of a country near to water; syn. riyfN: (Aboo-ʼAlee, Ḳ:) and the dim. buHayorN↓ is used in the same sense; or, by poetic licence, for buHayorapN↓. (TA.) So in the Ḳur [xxx. 40], Zahara AlfasaAdu fiI Albar-i waAlbaHori † [Corruption hath appeared in the desert, or deserts, and in the land of seed-produce and fruitfulness;, &c.]: (Aboo-ʼAlee, TA:)
or the meaning here is, [in the desert, or deserts, and in the towns, or villages, in which is water: (see bar-N:) or in the open country and] in the cities [or towns] upon the rivers; by sterility in the former, and scarcity in the latter: (Zj, TA, and T in art. br:) or in the land and the sea; i. e., the land has become sterile, or unfruitful, and the supply of the sea has become cut off. (Az, TA.) See also baHorapN.

Also, AlbaHoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or baHoru Alr-aHimi, (A, Mgh,) † The bottom (Eumoq, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ, or qaEor, IAth, TA) of the womb; fundus uteri: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) whence blood of a pure red colour, (Ṣ,) or intensely red, (Mgh,) is termed baHoraAniI-N (Ṣ, Mgh) and baAHirN. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: baHorapN A wide tract of land: so accord. to Aboo-Naṣr: but in one place he says, a small valley in rugged land: pl. biHaArN. (TA.)

A land, country, or territory, belonging to, or inhabited by, a people; syn. balodapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, hecihi baHoratunaA This is our land,, &c.; syn. OaroDunaA. (Ṣ.) It occurs also in the dim. form [buHayorapN↓], as in the Towsheeh of El-Jelál. (TA.)

Any town, or village, that has a running river and wholesome water: (Ḳ:) and [absolutely] any town, or village: of such the Arabs say, hecihi baHoratunaA This is our town, or village: and the pl. biHaArN they apply to cities, as well as towns, or villages. (TA.)
Low, or depressed, land: (IAạr, Ḳ:) occurring also in the dim. form [buHayorapN↓]. (TA.)
A meadow; or a garden; syn. rawoDapN: (T, TA:) or one that is large, (Ḳ,) and wide. (TA.)
A place where water stagnates. (Sh, Ḳ.)

The pl. is baHorN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ, [or this is a coll. gen. n. of which baHorapN is the n. un.,]) or biHarN, (as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) or buHorN, (as in the CK,) and biHaArN. (Ḳ.)

laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and SuHorapa buHorapa↓, as in the Expositions of the Tesheel, &c., (MF,) and SaHorapF baHorapF, (Ḳ,) and SuHorapF buHorapF↓, (MF,) I met him out, with nothing intervening between me and him; (Ṣ, L;) both of us being exposed to open view; (TA;) without anything concealing, or intervening. (Ḳ, TA.) SHrpa bHrpa, without tenween, is a compound denotative of state; not, as some say, consisting of two inf. ns.: and sometimes naHorapF is added; in which case each of the three words is with tenween, decl.; and they do not form a compound. (MF. [But see SaHorap.)]

entry.sense: SuHorapa buHorapa and SuHorapF buHorapF: see baHorapN.
A seaman; a sailor; (TA;) as also baH-aArN↓: (Ḳ:) and [baHoriy-apN↓ and] baH-aArapN↓ seamen; sailors. (Ḳ, TA.)
[In the dial. of Egypt, North; northern; because the Mediterranean Sea lies on the north of that country: like as, in Hebrew, יָם signifies “west;” because that sea lies on the west of Palestine.]
baHoriy-apN: see baHoriI-N.

buHoraAnN, a post-classical word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) used by the physicians, signifying The crisis of a disease; the sudden change which happens to a sick person, (Ṣ, TA,) and the commencement of convalescence, (TA,) in acute diseases; (Ṣ, TA;) at a time fixed by some motion in the heavenly bodies, mostly by a motion of the moon; being a change to health or to the contrary: a word [said to be] of Greek origin. (The Nuzheh of the sheykh Dáwood El-Antákee, cited in the TA.) [Pl. baHaAriynu.] They say, hecaA yawomu buHoraAnK and yawomN baAHuwriI-N↓ [This is the day of a crisis of a disease]: bAHwrI- being anomalous: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [perhaps from AlbaAHuwru signifying “the moon,” because the crisis of a disease is thought to be mostly fixed by a motion of the moon: or] as though it were a rel. n. of baAHuwrN and baAHuwraMCu meaning the “vehemence of heat in [the month of] tam-uwz.” (Ṣ.)

damN baHoraAniI-N † Blood of the menses; accord. to El-Ḳutabee: or † intensely red blood: (Mgh:) or † intensely red, and thick, and abundant, menstrual blood: (IAth:) or ‡ black blood: (A:) or, as also damN baAHirN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) † blood of the womb: (Ḳ:) or † blood of a pure red colour: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or † such blood from the belly: (M:) or † pure blood of an intensely red colour: (Mṣb:) both from AlbaHoru signifying “the bottom of the womb:”: (Ṣ:) the former is a rel. n. therefrom, (A, IAth, Mṣb,) in which the A and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification, (IAth,) or to distinguish it from the rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense]: (Mṣb:) or it is a rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense], because of its abundance. (IAth.)
OaHomaru baHoraAniI-N, and baAHirN↓, (TA,) and baAHiriI-N↓, (IAạr, TA,) † Intense red. (TA.)
buHayorN dim. of baHorN, which see, in two places

baHiyrapN A she-camel having her ear slit: (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ *:) [and, as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] a she-camel of which the mother was a saAYibap; (Fr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., of which the mother had brought forth ten females consecutively before her, and of which the ear was slit; (Mgh;) or of which the mother had brought forth five, of which five the last, if a male, was slaughtered and eaten, but if a female, her ear was slit and she was left with her mother; (Mgh,* Mṣb;) the predicament of which was the same as that of her mother; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., what was unlawful with respect to her mother was unlawful with respect to herself: (TA:) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, that had brought forth five young ones, and of which the fifth, if a male, was slaughtered, and its flesh was eaten by the men and women; but if a female, her ear was slit, and it was unlawful to the Arabs to eat her flesh and to drink her milk and to ride her; but when she died, her flesh was lawful to the women: (Ḳ:) so says Az, on the authority of Ibn-ʼArafeh: (TA: [but it appears from the explanation in the Mṣb, quoted above, that it was the slit-eared young she-camel here mentioned, not the mother, that was thus termed:]) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, which, having brought forth ten young ones, had her ear slit, (Ḳ,) and no use was made of her milk nor of her back, (TA,) and she was left at liberty to pasture, (Ḳ,) and to go to water, (TA,) and her flesh, when she died, was made unlawful to the women of the Arabs, but was eaten by the men: (Ḳ:) or one that was left at liberty, without a pastor: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, syn. with saAYibapN; i. e., say they, a she-camel which, having brought forth seven young ones, had her ear slit, and was not ridden, nor used for carrying: (Mṣb:) or a she-camel that had brought forth five young ones, the last of which was a male, in which case her ear was slit, and she was exempted from being ridden and from carrying and from being slaughtered, and not prevented from taking of any water to which she came, nor from any pasturage, nor even ridden by a weary man who, having become unable to proceed in his journey, his means having failed him, or his camel that bore him stopping with him from fatigue or breaking down or perishing, might chance to find her: (Aboo-Ishák the Grammarian, TA: [and the like, but less fully, is said in the Mgh:]) or, applied specially to a ewe, or she-goat, one that, having brought forth five young ones, had her ear slit: (L, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, for buHirat is put nuHirat:]) it also signifies a she-camel (L) abounding in milk: (L, Ḳ:) the pl. is baHaAYiru and buHurN; (L, Ḳ;) the latter a strange form of pl. of a fem. sing. such as bHyrp; and said to be the only instance of the kind except SurumN pl. of SariymapN, meaning “having her ear cut off.” (TA.) It is said in a trad., that the person who instituted the practices relative to the bHyrp and the HaAmiI, and the first who altered the religion of Ishmael, was ʼAmr the son of Loheí the son of Kama'ah the son of Jundab; and these practices are forbidden in the Ḳur v. 102. (TA.)
buHayorapN A small sea; a lake: as though they imagined the word baHorapN [as syn. with baHorN]: otherwise there is no reason for the p. (M, TA.)
See also baHorN: and see baHorapN, in two places.
baH-aArN: see baHoriI-N.
baH-aArapN: see baHoriI-N.
baAHirN: see baHoraAniI-N, in three places.
baAHiriI-N: see baHoraAniI-N, in three places.

hom.sense: baAHuwrN and baAHuwraMCu↓ The vehemence of heat in [the Syrian month of] tam-uwz or tamuwz [corresponding to July, O. Ṣ.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [pl. of the former bawaAHiyru:] both are [said to be] post-classical words: (Ṣ:) but they are [classical words,] arabicized; for they occur in verses of the kind called rajaz of some of the [early] Arabs. (MF.)
AlbaAHuwru The moon. (Aboo-ʼAlee, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: baAHuwraMCu: see baAHuwrN.
baAHuwriI-N: see buHoraAnN.
OubayoHirN: dim. of baHorN, q. v. (Ḳ.)

R. Q. 1. baxobaxa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. baxobaxapN and bixobaAxN, (TA,) [a verb imitative of the sound which it signifies,]
He (a camel [in a state of excitement]) brayed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so that his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag] filled his mouth: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, began to bray. (TA.)
[Hence, perhaps,] He (a man) said [baxo] or baxo baxo [&c.]. (TA, and Ḥar p. 556.)
And [hence,] baxobaxa biSuHobatiI He rejoiced in my company. (Ḥar ubi suprà.)
And baxobaxa Alr-ajula He said baxo or baxo baxo, &c. to the man. (Ṣ.)

baxo, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) [in some copies of the Ḳ written bax-a, which is wrong, for it is] like balo, (A,) [i. e.] like qado, (TA,) [perhaps, as I have suggested above, from the sound made by a he-camel in a state of excitement,] a word used on the occasion of praising; (Ṣ, A;) on praising one from whom has proceeded a good and wonderful action; (Ḥar p. 142;) on approving a thing; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) on being pleased with it, or having one's admiration excited by it; (A, Ḳ;) or on the occasion of glorying and of praising; (Ḳ;) in pronouncing a thing great in estimation, (IAmb,) or excellent; (AHeyth;) in deeming a thing great in estimation, (AḤei,) or good; (Mgh;) or it means wonder, or admiration; (R;) and sometimes it is used [ironically] to denote disapproval; also, as an exhortation to gentleness with a thing, and to taking extraordinary pains; (TA;) and in a case of expertness, or skilfulness: (AḤei:) it means niEoma Alr-ajulu and niEoma AlfiEolu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the man! and, the deed!]; (Ḥar p. 142;) [or simply, excellent! or most excellent! how good! how goodly! well done! bravo! and the like;] or EaZuma AlOamoru and faxuma [great in estimation is the thing, or affair, or event, or case!]: (Ḳ:) MF observes, [probably from finding bax-a in the place of baxo in his copy or copies of the Ḳ,] that this explanation is like an express assertion that it is a verb in the pret. tense, which requires consideration. (TA.) It is used alone; and in this case you say, baxo, (Ḳ,) and baxi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) with kesr for its invariable termination, (Mṣb,) and baxK, and baxN; (Ḳ, TA; [but in the CK, in the place of baxK and baxN, we find buxN;]) without teshdeed, (T, Mṣb,) in most cases; (Mṣb;) but also with teshdeed, (T, Ṣ, A,) like a noun; so that one says, baxK laka and bax-K [&c., meaning I say excel-lent!, &c., to thee]: (Ṣ:). and one repeats it, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) for the sake of emphasis; (Ṣ, A;) saying, baxo baxo, (IAmb, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) with the x quiescent like the l in halo and balo, (IAmb,) and baxK baxK, (Ṣ, A, R, Ḳ,) pronounced in the latter manner, with tenween, when in connexion with a following word, [and in this case only, whereas it is pronounced in the former manner in any case,] (Ṣ, A,) and bax-K bax-K, (Ṣ,* A,* R, Ḳ,) and baxK baxo, (Ḳ,) and bax-i bax-i. (R.)
jamalN baxobaAxu Alhadiyri A camel that fills his mouth with his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag] when he brays. (Ṣ.)

UibilN mubaxobaxapN Camels to which one says baxo baxo; being pleased with them: (ISd, TA:) or largebellied camels; (Ḳ;) as also muxaboxabapN, which is formed from the former by transposition; from baxo baxo, or baxK baxo, which is said by the Arabs in praising a thing; as though, by reason of their greatness, the people, seeing them, said, How goodly are they! (TA.)
1. baxatahu He beat, struck, or smote, him; (JK, Ḳ;) namely, a man. (JK.) [See also bakatahu.]

2. taboxiytN [inf. n. of bax-atahu] The overcoming another with an argument or the like; or reducing him to silence, through inability to reply; i. q. tabokiytN: and the addressing an adversary in a dispute or litigation with speech so as to put a stop to his plea, or allegation: from the author of the Tekmileh. (Mgh.)

Also, as a term of the theologians, The believing at first view, without consideration of a thing: so in Sal-aI EalaI Alt-aboxiyti [he prayed according to the belief which he formed at first view, without consideration]; said of a person when the kibleh is doubtful, and he cannot work out a solution of the difficulty. (Mgh.)
Q. Q. 2. tabaxotaI: see tabaxotara.

baxotN Fortune; or particularly good fortune; syn. jad-N, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and HaZ-N: (Mṣb, TA:) a foreign, or Persian, word, (Mṣb,) arabicized: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or post-classical: accord. to the 'Ináyeh, not a chaste Arabic word: but in the Shifá el-Ghaleel said to have been used by the Arabs in ancient times; and the like is said in the L: Az says, “I know not if it be Arabic or not.” (TA.)

buxotu [a coll. gen. n.] A species of camels; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) the Khurásánee [or Bactrian] camels; (Ḳ;) begot between an Arabian she-camel and a faAlij [which is a large two-humped camel brought from Es-Sind for the purpose of covering]; (TA;) long-necked; (Nh;) [large and strong, accord. to Ibn-Maạroof; and two-humped, accord. to Leo Africanus: the Mauritanian Arabs call thus all camels promiscuously; but accord. to the more common use of the word are to be understood hairy camels, fit for winter-work; generally of Turhumán or Bactrian breed; distinct from the Arabian, which are accustomed to bear bardens in winter and summer: (Golius:)] they are also called buxotiy-apN↓: (Ḳ:) n. un. buxotiI-N↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) fem. buxotiy-apN↓: (Ṣ:) pl. baxaAtiI-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) imperfectly decl., (Ṣ,) and baxaAtaI (Ḳ, TA [in the CK baxaAtiI]) and baxaAtK, (Ḳ,) and you may say [with the article] AlbaxaAtiI, without tenween: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) it is a foreign, or Persian, word, (TA,) arabicized: but some say, it is Arabic: (Ṣ, TA:) some hesitate as to its being Arabic because baxotN, meaning xaZ-N, is not. (Mṣb.)
buxotiI-N and buxotiy-apN: see buxotN; for the latter, in two places.
baxiytN, not thought by IDrd to be a chaste word, (TA,) Fortunate; possessed of good fortune; (A, Ḳ, TA;) as also maboxuwtN↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
bax-aAtN One who acquires, as his permanent property, camels such as are termed buxot: (Ḳ:) and one who makes use of such camels. (TA.)
maboxuwtN: see baxiytN.
Q. 1. baxotara: see what next follows.

Q. 2. tabaxotara, (L,) inf. n. tabaxoturN; (JK, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and baxotara↓, (L,) inf. n. baxotarapN; (L, Ḳ;) He walked in a certain manner; (Ṣ;) with an elegant gait; (JK, Ḳ;) with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, (L, TA, TḲ,) with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (TḲ;) or with a twisting of the back, (Fr, in TA, voce tamaT-aTa, and Bḍ in lxxv. 33,) and with extended steps. (Bḍ ibid.) You say also, fulaAnN yatabaxotaru fiI miXoyatihi and yatabaxotaI [Such a one carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, in his gait; or with a twisting of his back, and with extended steps]. (L.)

baxotariI-N and bixotiyrN↓ Elegant, or beautiful, in gait and in body; (L, Ḳ: in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, instead of waAljisomi, is erroneously put waAljasiymu: TA:) applied to a man: (L:) or (so accord. to the L and TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) proud and self-conceited: (L, Ḳ:) or who walks in the manner termed tabaxoturN [see Q. 2.]: (JK, L:) the former epithet is also applied to a camel: (L:) the fem. of the former is with p {baxotariy-apN}. (JK, L.)

buxoturiI-N a subst. signifying The gait denoted by Alt-abaxoturu [inf. n. of Q. 2]: (JK:) [and so baxotariy-apN↓: whence the phrase] fulaAnN yamoXiI Albaxotariy-apN Such a one walks in the manner termed tabaxoturN. (Ṣ, L.)
baxotariy-apN: see what next precedes.
bixotiyrN: see baxotariI-N.

hom.sense: 1. baxarati Alqidoru, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboxuru}, (Mṣb,) or _a, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baxorN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and buxaArN, (TA,) The cooking-pot sent up fume, vapour, steam, or an exhalation. (Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

baxira, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboxaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baxarN, (TA,) He had a stinking mouth [or breath; he exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour from his mouth]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) You say, baxiratN EalayonaA She exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour upon us from her mouth. (A. [But in my copy of that work, and in the TA, it is erroneously written baxarato.]) And baxira Alfamu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The mouth stank; exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour. (Mṣb.) [See baxarN, below.]

entry.sense: 2. bx-rt She perfumed [or rather fumigated her own or another's person or clothes, &c. with baxuwr]. (A.)
4. Abxrhu It (a thing) caused him to have a stinking mouth [or breath]. (Ḳ,* TA.)

5. tbx-r (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) He fumigated himself with perfume or the like; (TA;) with baxuwr. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
One says, fulaAnN yatabax-aru wayabaxotaru [Such a one fumigates himself with perfume, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side]. (A.)

buxaArN [Fume, vapour, steam, or exhalation;] what rises from water, like smoke; (Ṣ;) any fume (Ḳ, TA) that rises and diffuses itself (TA) from what is hot, (Ḳ, TA,) or from hot water; (TA;) anything that rises and diffuses itself from hot water or from damp earth: pl. OaboxirapN and buxaAraAtN. (Mṣb.)
Also The stench of a noiseless emission of wind from the anus. (TA.)
See also baxarN.
baxuwrN Incense, or a substance for fumigation; syn. duxonapN; (Mṣb;) that with which one fumigates himself: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) aloes-wood used for that purpose. (TA in art. qtr.)

baxuwru maroyama [Arthanita, or sow-bread; the common cyclamen; also called Alwalofu; the latter name, accord. to Golius, on the authority of Zeyn El-'Attár, given to it by the Syrians;] a certain plant, (Ḳ,) originally called EaroTaniyvaA; hot; dry; (TA;) having the property of clearing the complexion, or skin; aperient; diuretic; (Ḳ;) laxative; (TA;) and very useful: (Ḳ:) it is a laxative when used in the form of a suppository, or applied as a liniment below the navel. (TA.)
Oaboxaru Having a stinking mouth [or breath]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. baxoraMCu: and pl. buxorN. (Mṣb.)

maboxarapN A thing that occasions one's knowing, or inferring, or suspecting, stench, or fetor, of the mouth [or breath; a cause of stench, or fetor, of the mouth or breath]: such is said to be the sleeping between daybreak and sunrise, or in the first part of the day. (TA.)
miboxarapN A vessel for fumigation; a censer; syn. mijomarapN [q. v.: pl. mabaAxiru]. (Mṣb in art. jmr.)
mubax-arN A garment perfumed [or rather fumigated with perfume]. (A.)
maboxuwrN [Affected by the fumes of wine, &c.; or] affected with pain and headache occasioned by wine, or with the remains of intoxication. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. baxasahu, aor. _a {yaboxasu}, inf. n. baxosN, He diminished it; lessened it; made it deficient, or defective: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he made it faulty. (Mṣb.) You say, baxasa Alkay-aAlu [for baxasa Alkay-aAlu Alkayola The measurer made defective measure]. (A.) And of a just sale, laA baxosa fiyhi walaA XaTaTa, (Ṣ,) or walaA XuTuwTa, (T, TA,) [There is no deficiency in it nor excess.] And it is said in the Ḳur [lxxii. 13], falaA yaxaAfu baxosFA walaA rahaqFA He shall not fear diminution of the reward of his actions, nor wrong, or injustice. (TA.) And in this sense, [as also in the next,] the verb is doubly trans. (Mṣb.) You say, baxasahu Haq-ahu He diminished to him his right, or due; deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part of it. (Ṣ, A.) And it is said in the Ḳur [vii. 83 and xi. 86 and xxvi. 183], walaA taboxasuwA Aln-aAsa OaXoyaMCahumo [And ye shall not diminish unto men their things]: (Mṣb:) or the verb in this instance has the signification next following. (TA.)
He wronged him; acted wrongfully, or unjustly, towards him. (A, Ḳ.)
baxasa Eayonahu: see baxaSa.

entry.sense: 6. tbAxswA They defrauded one another in a sale. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baxosN Deficient; defective. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xii. 20], waXarawohu bivamanK baxosK And they sold him for a deficient, or defective, price: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) or for a price less than was incumbent: or for an insufficient price: or for an unjust price; accord. to Zj; because the sale of a man that has been found is unlawful. (TA.)
Land that produces herbage without being [artificially] watered: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or land which is watered by the rain; because it has deficient watering: (Mgh:) pl. buxuwsN. (JK, TA.)

Also, (TA, as from Ibn-Málik,) or baxosiI-N↓, [which is more probably the correct form,] a rel. n. from baxosN in the sense immediately preceding, explained in the T as signifying, (Mgh,) Seed-produce that is not irrigated with water from a spring or well or the like, but only by the rain. (Mgh, and TA from Ibn-Málik.)

entry.sense: baxosiI-N: see baxosN.

baAxisN Any one who acts wrongfully, or unjustly. (TA.) It is said in a prov., taHosibuhaA HamoqaMCa wahiIa baAxisN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) so runs the prov.; but accord. to Th, (Ṣ,) you may also say baAxisapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., [Thou thinkest her stupid,] but she is wrongful, or unjust: applied to him who feigns himself to be of weak understanding when he is crafty and cunning. (Ḳ, TA.) The origin of the prov. was this: a man of the Benu-l-'Ambar, of Temeem, mixed his property with that of a woman, coveting the possession of it, and thinking that she was stupid, and that she did not take care of her property nor know it: then he made a division with her, after he had mixed; but she was not content with the division until she took her property: she complained of him to those in authority, so that he released himself from her by giving her what she desired of the property: and the man was reproved for his conduct; it being said to him, “Thou cheatest a woman: is not this wrongful conduct (baxos)?” whereupon he replied in the words above, which became a proverb. (Th, Ḳ,* TA.)

1. baxaSa Eayonahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaboxaSu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. baxoSN, (Ṣ, Mgh,) He put out his eye; syn. faqaOahaA, (Mgh,) and Eaw-arahaA: (A, Mgh:) or he pulled out his eye [altogether, i. e.,] with its bulb: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [in the former, maED XaHomatihaA: in the latter, not so well, biXaHomihaA:]) or he put his finger into his eye: (Mṣb:) Yaạḳoob says that you should not say baxasa; (Ṣ;) and so says ISk: (TA in art. bxs:) but accord. to Aṣ, as related by Aboo-Turáb, you say baxaSa Eayonahu and baxazahaA and baxasahaA, all as meaning he put out his eye; syn. faqaOahaA: (TA:) and IAạr says that baxasahaA and baxaSahaA signify alike: (Mṣb:) the former of these two is a dial. var. of the latter; (TA in art. bxs;) and signifies he put it out (faqaOahaA) with his finger or some other thing: (Lth, Aṣ, and Ḳ in art. bxs:) but baxaSa is the better word. (Lḥ, IAạr, Mṣb.)

1. baxaEa Alc-abiyHapa, (Z, in the Fáïk,) or AlX-aApa, (Z, in the A,) or biAlX-aApi, (O, Ḳ,) [aor. _a {yaboxaEu}, inf. n. baxoEN,] He slaughtered the beast for slaughter, or the sheep or goat, with much, or extraordinary, effectiveness, or energy, (Z, Ḳ,) so that he reached the back of the neck, (Z, in the A,) or so that he reached the bixaAE, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK nuxaAE,]) cutting the bone of the neck. (TA.) This is the primary signification; and hence the verb is used to denote the doing anything to a great extent, in a great degree, egregiously, or with much or extraordinary effectiveness or energy or the like. (Z, Ḳ.)

[Hence you say,] baxaEa nafosahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboxaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baxoEN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and buxuwEN, (TA,) ‡ He killed himself with grief, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or with wrath, or rage. (Mṣb, TA.)
