And baAlaguwA fiI baxoEi Oanofusihimo ‡ They exceeded the ordinary bounds in subduing and abasing themselves by obedience. (TA.)

And baxaEotu laka nafosiI wanuSoHiI, aor. _a {yaboxaEu}, inf. n. buxuwEN, ‡ I exerted for thee myself and my good advice, or counsel, laboriously, earnestly, or with energy: (TA:) and baxaEa lahu nuSoHahu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. baxoEN, (TA,) ‡ He acted sincerely towards him, and took extraordinary pains, in giving him good advice, or counsel. (Ḳ, TA.)

And baxaEa lahu biAlHaq-i, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. buxuwEN; and baxiEa, inf. n. buxuwEN and baxaAEapN; ‡ He confessed, or acknowledged, to him the right, or due, and humbled himself to him: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or you say, baxaEaniI biAlHaq-i, inf. n. buxuwEN, meaning † he submitted himself to me, and gave the right, or due, freely: (Mṣb:) and baxaEotu lahu † I became submissive and obedient, and made confession, or acknowledgment, to him: or, accord. to the A, baxaEa signifies ‡ he made confession, or acknowledgment, with the utmost submissiveness. (TA.)
And baxaEa fulaAnFA xabarahu ‡ He related his information, or news, truly to such a one. (Ḳ.)
Also, baxaEa Alr-akiy-apa, aor. _a {yaboxaEu}, inf. n. baxoEN, † He dug the well until its water appeared. (Ks, Ḳ.)

And hence the saying of ʼÁïsheh, speaking of ʼOmar, baxaEa AlOaroDa faqaMCato OukolahaA, meaning † He subdued and abased the people of the earth, [so that it disclosed] and he drew forth the treasures that it contained, and the possessions of the kings. (TA.) And baxaEa AlOaroDa biAlz-iraAEapi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baxoEN, (TA,) ‡ He exhausted the strength of the land by sowing, tilling it continuously, and not giving it rest for a year. (Ḳ, TA.)

AlbixaAEu A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the Sulob [or back-bone], (Z in the Fáïk and Ksh, and Ḳ,) lying within the qafaA [or back of the neck]; (Z in the Ksh, and TA;) Bḍ says, lying within the faqaAr [or vertebræ]; but it is said that this is a mistranscription, and that the right reading is the qfA, as in the Ksh; and it is said in the Ḳ to be running into the bone [or, as in the CK, bones,] of the neck; but this is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to an assertion of Z, (Ḳ,) in his Fáïk and Ksh, (TA,) it is different from the nuxaAE, with n, which is the white cord in the interior of the bone of the neck, extending to the back-bone: but IA th says, I have searched long in lexicons, and in books of medicine and anatomy, but have not found AlbxAE, with b, mentioned in any of them. (TA.)

falaEal-aka baAxiEN nafosaka, in the Ḳur [xviii. 5], (Ṣ,) means ‡ And may-be thou wilt hill thyself (Ṣ, Ḳ) with grief, (Ṣ,) being beyond measure eager for their becoming Muslims. (Ḳ, TA.) These words imply an incitement to abstain from regret. (B.)
OaboxaEu [More, and most, effectual to kill, and destroy]. (Ḳ voce OaxonaEu, q. v.)

humo OaboxaEu TaAEapF ‡ They are more sincere and more energetic in obedience than others; as though they exceeded the ordinary bounds in subduing and abasing themselves by obedience. (TA, from a trad.)

hom.sense: 1. baxiqa, aor. _a {yaboxaqu}; and baxaqa, aor. _u {yaboxuqu}; He had that affection of an eye which is termed baxaqu, explained below. (Ḳ.) [And,] accord. to ISd, baxaqato Eayonuhu, and baxiqato, His eye went away; or perished: and i. q. EaArato [his eye became blind; or became wanting; or sank in its socket]: the more approved form is [baxaqato,] with fet-ḥ [to the medial radical]: and it is also explained as meaning fuqiYato [it was put out; or was blinded;, &c.]: (TA:) or, accord. to the Mj, baxiqati AlEayonu signifies the flesh [app. meaning the bulb, which is also termed the XaHomap,] of the eye disappeared: and the epithet applied to the eye in this case is baxoqaMCu↓. (Mgh.)

baxaqa Eayonahu, aor. _a {yaboxaqu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. baxoqN, (Ṣ,) i. q. Eaw-arahaA [He put out his eye; or made it to sink in its socket]; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OaboxaqahaA↓: (TA:) or the former, (Mgh,) and ↓the latter, (AA, Ḳ, TA,) i. q. faqaOahaA [he put it out; or blinded it;, &c.]. (AA, Mgh, Ḳ.)
4: see 1, in two places:
and see also 7.

entry.sense: 7. Ainobaxaqati AlEayonu, so in the Moḥeeṭ; accord. to the Ḳ, Oaboxaqat↓, but this is wrong; i. q. nadarat [The eye fell out from its place; or became displaced]; as in the Ḳ. (TA.)

baxaqN [app. inf. n. of baxiqa: and, as a simple subst.,] The worst, or most unseemly, kind of Eawar [or blindness of one eye, or loss thereof,, &c.], and that in which there is most [of the foul matter termed] gamaS: [in the CK, for Oakovaruhu gamaSFA, is erroneously put Aakovaruhu gamoDFA; and so I find in the JK:] or the state in which the edge of one's eyelid (Xuforu Eayonihi [in the CK Xuforu Eayonayohi]) will not meet the black, or part surrounded by the white: (Lth, Ḳ:) or blindness of one eye (EawarN) by the disappearance, in the head, of the black, or part surrounded by the white: (Ṣ:) or the disappearance of that part of the eye, in the head, after blindness of the eye: (Sh, TA:) or the having the sight gone, but the eye remaining open, blind, or white and blind, but still whole. (IAạr, TA.)
baxiyqN, and with p {baxiyqapN}: see Oaboxaqu, in three places.
baAxiqu AlEayonu and EayonN baAxiqapN: see Oaboxaqu, in two places.

rajulN Oaboxaqu, and baxiyqN↓ and baAxiqu↓ AlEayoni and maboxuwqu↓ AlEayoni all signify the same; (Ḳ;) i. e. A man blind of one eye; or wanting one eye; or having one of his eyes sunk in its socket; or having one of his eyes dried up; syn. OaEowaru: (TA:) [or having that affection of an eye which is termed baxaqN:] and in like manner baxoqaMCu applied to a sheep or goat for sacrifice on the occasion of the pilgrimage signifies EaworaMCu [blind of one eye;, &c.]; (Mgh, TA;) or, as some say, having an eye of which the black, or part surrounded by the white, has disappeared in the head. (Mgh.) And EayonN baxoqaMCu and baAxiqapN↓ and baxiyqN↓ and baxiyqapN↓ i. q. EaworaMCu [An eye that is blind;, &c.]: (Ḳ:) see also 1.
maboxuwqu AlEayoni: see Oaboxaqu.

1. baxila, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboxalu}, inf. n. baxalN; (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and baxula, aor. _u {yaboxulu}, inf. n. buxolN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: see buxolN, below. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, baxila bikacaA, (Ṣ, TA,) and baxula bihi, He was, or became, niggardly,, &c., of such a thing. (TA.) And baxila Eanohu [He withheld, with niggardliness, from him]: and baxila Ealayohi [he was niggardly to him]. (Bḍ and Jel in xlvii. last verse.)
2. bx-lhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboxiylN, (Ḳ,) He attributed, or imputed, to him buxol [or niggardliness,, &c.]: (Ṣ:) or he accused him thereof: (Ḳ:) or he called him baxiyl [or niggardly,, &c.]. (TA.)
4. Abxlhu He found him to be baxiyl [or niggardly,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
baxolN: see what next follows.

buxolN and baxalN↓, [both of which are properly inf. ns.,] (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and baxolN↓, (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and buxulN↓ (Ḳ) and baxilN↓ and bixolN↓ (TA) and buxuwlN↓, (Ḳ,) of all which, the first is that which commonly obtains, (TA,) are syn., (JK, Ṣ,) signifying Niggardliness, tenaciousness, stinginess, penuriousness, or avarice; contr. of karamN (Ḳ, TA) and juwdN; and its definition is the withholding of acquired articles of property from that wherefrom it is not lawful to withhold them: (TA:) or the debarring the asker, or beggar, from what one has that is superabundant: (Mṣb:) and in the law, the refusal of what is incumbent, or obligatory. (Mṣb, TA.)
bixolN: see what next precedes.
baxalN: see buxolN:
and see also baxiylN.
baxilN: see buxolN.
buxulN: see buxolN.
baxolapN A single act, or instance, of buxol [or niggardliness, &c.]. (JK, TA.)
baxaAlN: see what next follows.

baxiylN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAxilN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; (Ḳ;) i. e. cuw buxolK; (Mṣb;) epithets from 1: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) or one from whom niggardliness is experienced much or often: (TA: [appin explanation of the former:]) and so baxalN↓, in inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore implying more than the possession of the simple attribute of niggardliness, &c., being a kind of personification]; (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil El-Aạrábee, Ḳ;) and bax-aAlN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baxaAlN↓ (Ḳ) and mubax-alN↓ (JK, Ḳ) i. e. Xadiydu Albuxoli [very, or vehemently, niggardly, &c.]: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. of the first, buxalaMCu; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of the second, bux-alN (Ḳ) and bux-aAlN. (TA.)
buxuwlN: see buxolN.
bax-aAlN: see baxiylN.
baAxilN: see baxiylN.

maboxalapN A cause of, or a thing that incites to, buxol [or niggardliness, &c.]: (Ḳ:) a word of the same class as majobanapN and maholakapN and maEoTaXapN and mafaAzapN, &c. (TA.) So explained as occurring in the trad., (TA,) Alwaladu maboxalapN majobanapN [Children are a cause of niggardliness and a cause of cowardice]; (Ṣ, TA;) because on account of them one loves property, and continuance of life. (Ṣ in art. jbn.)
mubax-alN: see baxiylN.

hom.sense: 1. bad-a, aor. _u {yabodudu}, inf. n. bad-N: see 2.
bad-a rijolayohi He parted his legs, or straddled, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in the stocks, or otherwise. (M.)
bad-ahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He removed with it, withdrew with it, drew away with it, [or drew it away, from its place,] (M, Ḳ,) namely, a thing. (M.)
He made him (namely, his companion, M) to retire, or withdraw, far away; and to refrain, forbear, or abstain; (M, Ḳ;) Eani AlX-aIoCi from the thing. (M.)
OanaA Oabud-u bika Eano celika AlOamori I will defend thee from that thing, or event, by repelling it, or averting it, from thee. (M, L.)
bud-a Eano dabari Ald-aAb-api It (a felt cloth) was cut, or slit, so as to be clear of the galls, or sores, on the back of the beast. (M, TA.)

bad-a, (M,) second pers. badidota, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yabad-u, (M,) inf. n. badadN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,)
He (a man) was, or became, wide between the thighs, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by reason of abundance of flesh: (ISk, Ṣ, M:) or wide between the arms; (Ḳ;) having the arms far from the sides: (M:) or wide between the shoulder-joints: (M:) or large in make, having one part far from another. (M, Ḳ.)

Also He (a quadruped, ISk, T, Ṣ, or a horse, M) had his fore legs far apart: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M:) or he (a horse) had his fore legs far from his sides: (Lth, T:) and he (a camel) had his elbows far from his sides. (T.)
bad-a qatabahu,, aor. _u {yabodudu}, He furnished his camel's saddle with what are called bidaAdaAni and badiydaAni (Ṣ.) [See bidaAdN]

2. bd-d, inf. n. tabodiydN, He separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated; (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ;) as also bad-a↓, aor. _u {yabodudu}, inf. n. bad-N: (Ṣ, L:) or the latter has this meaning, and the former signifies he separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated, much. (Mṣb.)
He (a man) gave his equal share of the expenses for a journey. (IAạr, T.) [See also 3.]
He (a man) was, or became, weary, tired, or fatigued: (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ:) or he drowsed, or slumbered, while sitting, without sleeping. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. bAd- Alqawomu, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAd-apN (M, Ḳ) and bidaAdN, (T, M, Ḳ,) with which the subst. badaAdN↓ is syn., (M, and mentioned also in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and in the CK, and in the TA, but not as from the Ḳ,) as also bidaAdapN↓, (TA, as from the Ḳ, but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) The people, or company of men, contributed what was necessary to be expended (in a journey, T, M, L), each man giving something, and then collected the sum, and expended it among themselves. (T, M, L, Ḳ.) In a copy of the Ḳ, for yunofiquwnahu, is erroneously put yuboquwnahu. (TA. [In the CK, yaboquwnahu.]) Accord. to IAạr, bidaAdN signifies The contributing equally for the purchasing of corn, or food, to eat: and also a people's having money, or property, divided into lots, or portions, and distributed in shares among them: (L:) [and] accord. to the same, the dividing property among a people in shares. (T. [See also 4.])

Also, bAd-hu, (M, A, Ḳ,) or bAd-hu fI AlbayoEi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. mubaAd-apN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or mubaAdadap, (TA,) and bidaAdN; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and so baAyaEahu badadFA↓, (Ṣ M, Ḳ,) or mubaAd-apF; (A;) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him; syn. EaAraDahu biAlbayoEi, (M, A,* L,) and baAEahu muEaAraDahF: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from the saying, ehecaA bic-uhu, and bid-uhu, “this is the like of it:” (L:) from IAạr. (M.)
[See also bud-N.]

4. Abd- fiyhimu AlEaTaMC, (Aṣ, T,) and Abd- bayonahumo AlEaTaMCa, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) and Oabad-ahumo AlEaTaMCa, (M, A, Mgh,) He divided among them the gift, giving to each of them his lot, or share, or portion, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) singly, not giving a portion to be shared by two: (Aṣ, T, M,* Mgh, L:) said with respect to food and property and any other thing. (M.) You say, Oabodadotuhumo AlmaAla waAlT-aEaAma I divided among them, in shares, the property and the food. (IAạr, T.) [Hence,] Oabid-iyhimo tamorapF tamorapF (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, from a trad.) [Give thou to each of them a date; or] distribute thou among them to each a date: (T:) said by Umm-Selemeh, (T, A, Mgh,) to a slave-girl, when beggars had become numerous. (A.) UibodaAdN in relation to a gift signifies The giving [persons] one by one; and qiraAnN, the “giving two by two.” (AʼObeyd, T.) [See also 3.]

yubid-uhumo is used by a poet, referring to a saying, and is explained by IAạr as meaning It (the saying) shall be distributed among them (yuf-arqu fiyhimo); opposed to yajomaEu [i. e. yajomaEuhumo; which shows that the former means it shall be addressed to them one by one, or separately]. (M, TA. [The author of the former adds, “I know not, in discourse, Oabodadotuhu as meaning far-aqotuhu:” but this is not what IAạr means.])
Oabid-ahumaA naEojatayona Allot thou to them (namely, two lambs,) two ewes, to each lamb a ewe, to suckle it: said when one ewe is not sufficient for both the lambs. (T,* Ṣ.)
Abd- DaboEayohi He extended his upper arms, separating them from his sides, in prostrating himself in prayer. (T, A, Mgh, L.)
Abd- yadahu UilaI AlOaroDi He extended his arm, or hand, to the ground, or earth, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, L,) as one does when he takes up something from it. (L.)
Abd- naZarahu He prolonged his look. (T, L.) And Abd-hu baSarahu (T, A, L) He prolonged his look at him, or it; as one does when he sees a thing that he dislikes. (T, L.)

hom.sense: 5. tbd-d It (a thing, Ṣ, M, L, and a people, or company of men, T, L) became separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated; (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) [as also badobada↓, for its inf. n.] badobadapN likewise signifies the being separated, disunited,, &c. (AA, T.)
tbd-dwA XayoYFA They divided a thing among themselves in lots, shares, or portions, (Ḳ,) equally. (TA.)
tbd-d Sadora AljaAriyapi It (an ornament) occupied the two sides, (A,) or the whole, (Ḳ,) of the bosom of the girl. (A, Ḳ.) [See an ex. voce jaliyfF.]

entry.sense: 6. tbAd-wA They removed to a distance, one from another. (Ḥam p. 823.)
They went, or passed, two by two, each one of a pair removing, or withdrawing, with the other, or making the other to retire, or withdraw, far away. (M.)

They went forth into the field [of battle], one to another: (A:) or they took their adversaries, or opponents, [with whom to fight,] (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) each man his man; as also laquwA badaAdahumo↓: (Ḳ:) or this latter signifies they met their numbers, to each man a man. (T, Ṣ.)
8. Abtd-Ahu biAAlD-arobi They two took him on both sides of him, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or came to him on both sides of him, (Ḳ,) with beating. (T, Ṣ.)
Als-abuEaAni yabotad-aAni Alr-ajula The two wild beasts come upon both sides of the man. (Ṣ, A.)

Alr-aDiyEaAni yabotad-aAni Oum-ahumaA (T, Ṣ, A *) The two sucklings suck their mother on either side, one from one breast and the other from the other breast. (T, A,* TA.) You do not say, yabotad-uhaA QbonuhaA, but yabotad-uhaA QbonaAhaA. (T, Ṣ.)

10. Astbd- He was, or became, alone; independent of others; (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ; in the first and last expl. by tafar-ada; and in the others, by Ainofarada;) exclusively of others; (L;) without any to share, or participate, with him; or he had none to share, or participate, with him: (Mṣb:) bihi [in it; i. e. he had it, or kept it, to himself, exclusively, with none to share with him in it]: (Ḳ:) and bikacaA [in such a thing]: (Ṣ, L:) and biraOoyihi [in his opinion; i. e. he followed his own opinion only, with none to agree with him; or he was singular in his opinion]: (M, L:) and biOamorK [in a thing, or an affair]: (L, Mṣb:) and biOamorihi [in his affair]; meaning he obtained [absolute] predominance, or control, over his affair, so that people would not hear [or obey] any other. (A.) It is said in a trad., kun-aA naraI Oan-a lanaAfiIi hecaA AlOamori Haq-aA faQsotabadotumo EalayonaA [We used to opine that we had a right to act in this affair, and ye have been alone the actors, predominant over us]. (L.) And you say, Astbd- AlOamoru bifulaAnK, meaning ‡ The thing, or affair, overcame such a one, so that he could not manage it well, or thoroughly. (A.)
R. Q. 1. badobada, inf. n. badobadapN: see 5.

hom.sense: budN as signifying A separating oneself, or an artifice whereby one may avoid a thing or escape from it, (MF,) or an avoiding a thing, (Mṣb,) is not used but in negative phrases, (Mṣb, MF,) except by post-classical writers. (MF.) You say, laA bud-a mino kacaA (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) There is no separating oneself from such a thing: (AA, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or there is no artifice whereby one may avoid it, or escape from it: (M, Ḳ:) or there is no avoiding it: (Mṣb:) it is absolutely necessary: it is not possible to separate oneself from it, nor is there anything that can serve in its stead. (TA.) And maA laka minohu bud-N [Thou hast not any means, or way, of separating thyself from it, or avoiding it]. (M, L.) And layosa lihecaA AlOamori bud-N There is no artifice for this affair. (T.) [It is also said, with reference to the first of these phrases, that] bud-N signifies Amplitude; from Oabad-u meaning “wide between the legs.” (Ḥam p. 348.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) and bid-N↓ (M) and bidaAdN↓ (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ) and budaAdN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or badaAdN↓, (CK,) and bud-apN↓, (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,) or bid-apN↓, (Ṣ, A, IAth, and mentioned also in a copy of the Ḳ,) but J has been charged with error in writing it thus, (Ḳ,) by Ṣgh, (TA,) A lot, share, portion, or set portion; (T, Ṣ, M, A, IAth, Ḳ;) of anything: (M, Ḳ:) [or] the last signifies a piece, or portion, separated, disunited, or dispersed: (Ḥam p. 823:) the pl. of bidaAdN is bududN; and of budadN bud-apN; (IAạr, T, M;) and of bidadN bid-apN. (IAth, and Ḥam p. 823.)

Also the first, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in the place of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. EiwaDN: (Ṣ, L, TA:) it is said to have this signification. (Ṣ.) [In the copies of the Ḳ, AlbaEuwDu is put in the place of AlEiwaDu: but this is said in the TA to be a mistake.]

bud-N is also an arabicized word, from buto, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in a copy of the M, but-,]) which is Persian; (T, Ṣ;) meaning An idol; (IDrd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) pl. badadapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OabodaAdN: (Ḳ:)
and (or accord. to some, TA) the house of an idol: (Ḳ:) or a house in which are idols and images or pictures. (M.)

entry.sense: bid-N: see bud-N.

Also, and badiydN↓ (T, Ḳ) and badiydapN↓, (Ḳ,) A like; a fellow; an equal. (T, Ḳ.) You say, huwa bid-uhu and badiyduhu↓ He, or it, is the like, &c., of him, or it. (T.) And huma bid-aAni They two are likes, or fellows, or equals. (TA.) And maA Oanota liI bibadiydK↓ fatukal-imaniI Thou art not my like, or fellow, or equal, that thou shouldst speak to me. (TA.)
bad-apN: see badadN.

hom.sense: bud-apN: see bud-N.

Also A distance; a space; an interval; an extent, or an extreme extent; a long space, or any space, of time. (M, Ḳ,* TA.) So in the saying, bayoniI wabayonaka bud-apN [Between me and thee is a distance,, &c.]. (M, TA.)
bid-apN: see bud-N, and bidaAdi:
and see also badadN.
badada and badadFA: see badaAdi, in three places:
and see also 3.
maA laka bihi badadN and bad-apN↓ and bid-apN↓ Thou hast not power, or ability, to do it, or to bear it, or to cope with him. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

jaMCati Alxayolu badaAdi; (T, Ṣ;) in which bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination because it deviates from its original form, i. e., the inf. n. badadN; and it is indecl. because it deviates from its original form and is of the fem. gender and has the quality of an epithet; for two of these causes render it imperfectly decl., and the three render it indecl.; (Ṣ;) or badaAdi badaAdi, and badaAda badaAda, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) the last indecl. with fet-ḥ for its termination, (TA,) and badada badada↓, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) also indecl., with fet-ḥ, (TA,) and composed in the same manner as xamosapa EaXara, (Lḥ, M, TA,) and badadFA badadFA↓; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) all of these indecl. except the last, and each virtually in the accus. case as a denotative of state, except the last, (MF,) which is literally in the accus. case, as an inf. n.; (M, MF;) The horses, or horsemen, came in a state of dispersion: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) And taf-r-aqa Alqawomu badaAd The people, or company of men, became separated, in a state of dispersion. (Ṣ.) And cahaba Alqawomu badaAdi badAdi The people, or company of men, went away [in a state of dispersion; or] one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) [See also OabaAdiyd.] It is said in a form of prayer, Aallehum-a Qqotulohumo badadFA↓ waOaHoSihimo EadadFA [O God, slay them one by one, and reckon them by number]: (M:) or OaHoSihimo EadadFA waQloEanohumo bidadFA, or, accord. to one recital, waQqotulohumo bidadFA, pl. of bid-apN↓, the meaning being [reckon them by number, and] curse them, or slay them, with a cursing, or slaughter, distributed among them by shares. (Mgh.)

yaA qawomi badaAdi badaAdi means O my people, take each one of you his adversary, or opponent [with whom to fight]. (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.*) Here bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is an imperative verbal noun, and the imperative is alike uninfluenced with respect to its termination by any governing word; and it is said to be with kesr because two quiescent letters would otherwise occur together, [and] because it occupies the place of an imperative verb [which in like manner is terminated with kesr when it is necessary to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together]. (Ṣ.)

With the article, you say, AlbadaAdu, (Aṣ, T,) which signifies The going forth to encounter another in fight, or to single combat; as in the saying, lawo kaAna AlbadaAdu lamaA OaTaAquwnaA Had we gone forth to encounter them in fight, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) man to man, [they had not been able to cope with us;] (Aṣ, T;) or man by man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, laquwA badaAdahumo, explained above: see 6.
See also bud-N.
And see 3.

entry.sense: budaAdN: see bud-N.

hom.sense: bidaAdN: see bud-N.

Also A stuffed lining put beneath a [camel's saddle of the kind called] qatab, to defend the animal's back from being hurt thereby: there is one such on each side: (T:) or, of a horse's saddle, and of a qatab, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the stuffed thing, or pad, that is placed beneath, in order that it may not gall the animal's back; (M, Ḳ;) as also badiydN↓: (Ḳ:) or the bidaAdaAni and badiydaAni↓ are two bags (xariyTataAni), which are stuffed, and placed under the curved pieces of wood, in order that the wood may not gall the animal's back; derived from bad-a rijolayohi “he parted his legs:” (Ṣ:) [see also badiydN:] or the bidaAdaAni of a qatab are two things like provender-bags, 'which are stuffed, and bound with strings, or cords, to the pieces of wood called the ZalifaAt and OaHonaMC: (T:) or they are, to the qatab, like the kar- to the raHol, except that they do not appear before the Zalifap, being only within [it]: (M:) [see also HidojN:] pl. [of pauc.] Oabid-apN (T, Ṣ) and [of mult.] badaAYidu. (Ṣ.)
Also A piece of felt cloth, that is bound upon a beast which has a galled, or sore, back, (L, Ḳ,) cut, or slit, so as to be clear of the galls, or sores. (L.)
badiydN: see bid-N, in three places.
Also A saddlebag; syn. xurojN: (Ḳ:) [and] badiydaAni a pair of saddle-bags; syn. xurojaAni. (Ṣ.)
See also bidaAdN, in two places.
Also A wide [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or falaApN badiydN [a desert, or waterless desert,] in which is no one. (T, L. [In a copy of the former written bado badN.])

entry.sense: bidaAdapN: see 3.
badiydapN: see bid-N.

baAd-N The inner side of the thigh: (M, A, Ḳ:) or the part of the horseman's thigh that is next the saddle: (T, M, A, L:) or the part between the legs: (M, L:) the inner sides of the two thighs are called the baAd-aAni, (Ṣ,) because the saddle separates them; (IAạr, M;) and if so, baAd-N is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be a possessive epithet [meaning cuw bad-K]. (M, L.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlbaAd-i EalaI Als-arji, meaning He is a good rider upon the saddle. (A.)
Also the part of a horse's back upon which the thigh of the rider presses. (Ḳṭ, T, L.)

Oabad-N A man wide between the thighs, (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by reason of abundance of flesh: (ISk, Ṣ, M:) or wide between the arms; (Ḳ;) having the arms far from the sides: (M:) or wide between the shoulder-joints: (M:) or (so in the Ḳ; but accord. to the Ṣ, “and”) large in make, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) having one part far from another: (M, Ḳ:) and wide in the breast: (Aboo-Málik, T:) fem. bad-aMCu: (Ṣ:) which also signifies a woman (M, L) large in the UisokataAni [or labia majora of the vulva], (M, L, Ḳ,) having their edges far apart: (M, L:) or having much flesh in the thighs. (T, L.) AlOabad-N is used to signify The weaver, (T, M, Ḳ,) because of the distance between his thighs. (M.) The following saying, (Ḳ,) quoted by J, from the rájiz Aboo-Nukheyleh Es-Saadee,
Oalad-u yamoXiI miXayapa AlOabad-i
is incorrect, and should be thus,
bad-aMCu tamoXiI miXoyapa AlOabad-i
[A woman of large make, walking in the manner of the man of large make; or a woman wide between the thighs,, &c.]; (Ḳ;) for it is descriptive of a woman, as IB and Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee have observed before the author of the Ḳ. (TA.)

Also A horse [or any quadruped (see bad-a)] having the fore legs far apart: (M, Ḳ:) or having the fore legs far from the sides: (TA:) or wide between the legs: (Ḥam p. 348:) and a camel having the elbows far from the sides: (TA:) and the fem. bad-aMCu, a cow having her fore legs far apart. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] AlOabad-u Alz-aniymu [in the CK Alr-aviymu] The lion; (M, Ḳ;) the former epithet being applied to him because his fore legs are far apart, and the latter because he is [often] alone. (M.)
katifN bad-aMCu A broad shoulder-blade, the sides of which are distant, one from another. (M, L.)

TayorN OabaAdiydu, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tabaAdiydu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) [in the CK nabAdiydu,] erroneously written by J yabaAdiydu↓, (Ḳ,) [but see what follows; like OanaAdiydu and yanaAdiydu;] Birds in a state of dispersion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In the following verse of 'Otárid Ibn-Kurrán, quoted by J,
kaOan-amaA Oahulu HajorK yanoZuruwna mataI
yarawonaniI xaArijFA TayorN yabaAdiydu
[As though the people of Hajr, watching when they should see me going forth, were birds in a state of dispersion], (Ḳ,) thus related also by Yaạḳoob, and thus in the handwriting of Az, (TA,) the last two words should be Tayoru AlyanaAdiydi, the latter with n, and governed by the former in the gen. case, the rhyme being with kesr: (Ḳ:) so says Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee. (TA.)

cahabuwA OabaAdiydu, (M, Ḳ,) and tabaAdiydu↓, (Ḳ,) or yabaAdiydu↓, (as in the T, from Fr, and in the M and L, and in some copies of the Ḳ, [but see above,]) [as also OanaAdiydu, and yanaAdiydu, or tanaAdiydu,] They went away in a state of dispersion. (M, L, Ḳ.)
tabaAdiydu: see OabaAdiydu, in two places.

mubid-N [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. The following words of ʼOmar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah,
Oamubid-N suWaAlaka AlEaAlamiyna
are said to signify Dost thou distribute thy petition among mankind one by one, so as to include them universally?
or dost thou constrain them by thy petition? from the saying, maA laka minohu bud-N [“thou hast no means,” or “way,” “of separating thyself from it,” or “avoiding it”]. (M, L.)
XamolN mubad-adN [A united state of affairs]. become disunited [or discomposed or disorganized]. (Ṣ, L.)
AimoraOapN mutabad-idapN An emaciated woman, [as though] having one part far from another. (M, L.)
yabaAdiydu: see OabaAdiydu, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. badaOa bihi, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _a {yabodaOu}, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. badoCN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) i. q. AbtdO↓ bh; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [He began with it;] he made it to have precedence, or to be first; gave precedence to it; syn. qad-amahu: (Mgh, Mṣb:) in the dial. of the Ansár, badiYa bh is used in this sense of qd-mh; (M;) or badiIa bh [without C]; (IḲṭṭ, TA; [see badpCN;]) [and badaI bh; see art. bdI;] and AbdO↓ bh signifies the same. (Mṣb.) [So in the Ḳur xii. 76, fabadaOa biOawoEiyatihimo qabola wiEaMCi Oaxiyhi And he began with their bags, before the bags of his brother. And badaOahu is sometimes used in the sense of badaOa bihi; whence, in the Ḳur ix. 13, wahumo badaWuwkumo Oaw-ala mar-apK And they, it was, began with you the first time; i. e., as Bḍ says, by acting with hostility, and fighting.] You say also, bad-aA vum-a EaAda He began, or did a first time, or the first time: then repeated, or did a second time. (Az, TA in art. Ewd.) And badaOa fiIi AlOamori [He began, or made a beginning, in the affair.] (M.)
badaOa also signifies It (a thing) began; began to be; originated; or came into existence. (Mṣb.) [See also 5.]

badaOa AlX-ayoCa, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He began the thing; commenced it; set about it; as also AbtdOhu↓: accord. to the Mgh, the latter has this meaning, or, agreeably with the authority of the M and Ḳ, the meaning which here next follows:] he did the thing first, for the first time, by way of beginning, or originally; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also AbdOhu↓ and AbtdOhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) i. e., not after the example of anything preceding. (TA. [But this addition seems rather to belong to another explanation to be mentioned below.]) One does not say, AbtdO↓ zayodFA nor badaOahu, because these two verbs [signifying as last explained above] do not have for their objects corporeal things. (Mgh.) [El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee uses the phrase saOaboduWuhumo bimaXomaEipK I will begin with them (meaning his guests) by sporting and jesting; like the phrase in the Ḳur ix. 13 cited above: but different from these is the saying in the Ḳur xxxii. 6, wabadaOa xaloqi QloUinosaAni mino TiynK And He began the creation of man from clay.] The saying, faUino kaAna Als-abuEu QbotadaOahu↓ means AbtdO Oaxocahu Oawo EaD-ahu [But if the beast, or bird, of prey has begun the seizing of him, or the biting of him]; the noun that is prefixed [to the pronoun] being suppressed. (Mgh.) You say also, kaAna celika fiI QbotidaMCi↓ AlOamori That was in the beginning, or first, of the affair. (Mṣb.) [See also badoCN, below.]

He originated the thing; brought it into being or existence; made it, or produced it, for the first time, it not having been before; (Mgh;) [and] so AbdOhu↓, said [of God, and] of a man, as the agent; (Mṣb;) and AbtdOhu↓. (Mgh in art. bdE.) [Hence,] badaOa Qll-ehu Alxaloqa, and OabodaOahumo↓, God created, or brought into existence, mankind, or the created beings: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) both signify the same. (Ṣ.) maA yubodiYu↓ AlbaATilu wamaA yuEiydu [in the Ḳur xxxiv. 48, means What doth that which is false, or the Devil, originate, or produce in the first instance? and what doth it, or he, reproduce after it hath perished?]: Zj says that maA, here, is in the place of an accus., meaning in each Instance OaI-a XaIoCK: or it may be a negative; and AlbATl here is Iblees; i. e., Iblees createth not, nor raiseth to life after death. (M.) You say also, maA yubodiYu↓ wamaA yuEiydu, meaning maA yatakal-amu bibaAdiYapK↓ walaA EaAYidapK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. He does not say anything for the first time, nor anything for the second time; or anything original, nor anything in the way of repetition; baAdiYapu↓ AlkalaAmi signifying what is said for the first time; and EaAYidapu AlkalaAmi, what is said for the second time, afterwards: (TA:) or he says not anything: (A in art. Ewd:) and he has no art, artifice, or cunning. (IAạr, TA in art. Ewd; and A in the present art.)
badaOa AlbiYora He dug the well [for the first time: see badiIoCN]. (Mṣb.)
badaOa mino OaroDK UilaI OaroDK, (T,) or mino OaroDihi, (Ḳ,) He went forth from a land to a land, or from his land; as also AbdO↓. (T, Ḳ.)

budiYa, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ, M) had the small-pox: (AZ, Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or the HaSobap [i. e. measles, or spotted fever]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or, as AZ says, and the HSbp: (T:) or, as Lḥ says, there came forth upon him pustules resembling the small-pox: but he adds, some say, the small-pox itself: (M:) the epithet applied to a person affected therewith is maboduwoCN↓. (AZ, Aṣ, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M.)

Also He fell sick. (IAth, TA.) In a trad. of ' Áïsheh occur the words, fiI Alyawomi Al-aciI budiYa fiyhi rasuwli Qll-ehi [meaning In the day in which the Apostle of God fell sick]: and IAth says, mataI budiYa fulaAnN meaning When did such a one fall sick? is a phrase used in inquiring respecting the living [who has been attacked by illness] and respecting the dead. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AbdO: see 1, in seven places.
Also He did a new thing; a thing unknown before; or a strange, or wonderful, thing. (Ṣ,* TA.)
And He voided excrement, or ordure; or broke wind; syn. najaA; [as also OabodaI;] said of a man. (M.)
And He put forth his second teeth; said of a child; (M;) and of a colt. (TA voce OaHofara, q. v.)

5. tbd-O He, or it, began, or made a beginning. (KL.) [See also 1. Golius mentions, but without giving the authority, and without the vowel-signs, the saying, haAti AlqiS-apa mino ciI tubud-iYato; but writing the last word tbdyt, stating only that it is in the passive form; as meaning Relate thou the story, or history, from the beginning.]
8: see 1, in seven places.
AbtdOhu biwaEodK He made him a promise in anticipation; without his asking it of him. (M in art. Anf.)

badCN inf.n. of 1; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) [The act of beginning;] or the doing a thing first. (M.) You say, laka AlbadoCu, (M, Ḳ,) and AlbudoCu↓, (Aṣ, TA,) and AlbadoOapu↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AlbudoOapu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and AlbidoOapu↓, (L,) and AlbadaMCapu↓, (M, Ḳ,) and AlbudaMCapu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and AlbudaAhapu, with h substituted for C, (M, Mṭr,) and AlbidaMCapu↓, (Mṭr, TA,) and, accord. to IḲṭṭ, AlbidaAyapu, but see what follows, (TA,) and AlbadiYapu↓, (M, Ḳ,) and Albud-aMCapu↓, (AZ, TA,) It is for thee to begin, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) before any other, in shooting or casting, &c.: (Ṣ:) as to AlbidaAyapu, mentioned above, accord. to Mṭr [and Fei], (TA,) it is a vulgar word, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) as IB and several others have stated, (Mṣb, TA,*) a corruption of AlbidaMCapu↓, (Mgh, Mṣb,) signifying the first; as also AlbudaMCapu↓; and AlbadoOapu↓: (Mṣb:) but IḲṭṭ says that it is a word of the dial. of the Ansár; badaOotu biAlX-aIoCi and badiytu bihi signifying qad-amotuhu: [see 1:] and he cites the following verse of Ibn-Rawáhah:
biQsomi QloUilaAhi wabihi badiynaA
walawo EabadonaA gayorahu XaqiynaA
[In the name of God, and with it we begin; and if we worshipped any other than Him, we should be miserable]: see art. bdI. (TA. [This verse is also cited in the Ṣ in art. bdw, where, in one copy I find it as above; in another, with badayonaA instead of badiyonaA.]) And you say, faEalahu EawocaA wabadoCFA, (T, Ṣ,) and Eawodahu EalaI badoYihi, (M,) and fiI Eawodihi wabadoYihi, and fiI Eawodatihi wabadoOatihi↓, (Ṣ, M,) [He did it returning and beginning again; or returning to his beginning; i. e. he did it again from the beginning; he recommenced it: or you say this] meaning like as is meant by the saying next following. (TA.) rajaEa Eawodahu EalaI badoYihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and EawodFA EalaI badoCK, in both of which [and in the last following] the verb may be trans., and the noun following therefore in the accus. case, (TA,) and fiI Eawodihi wabadoYihi, and fiI Eawodatihi wabadoOatihi↓, [in both of which, if correct, the verb must be intrans.,] and EawodFA wabadoCFA, [as though meaning EaAYidFA wabaAdiYFA, used as a phrase denotative of state,] (Ḳ,) [but in this last, and the two next preceding, accord. to the TA, the verb should be faEalahu, as in the next preceding sentence, instead of rajaEa, and this is confirmed by what is said in the Ḳ in art. Ewd,] He returned in the way whence he had come: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [accord. to the TA, the literal meaning of the first and second may be he made his returning to revert to his beginning, and he made a returning to revert to a beginning:] or the meaning of the first, (Sb, TA in art. Ewd, and Ḳ in that art.,) and of the second, (Ḳ in that art.,) is, he returned without stopping after he had gone away: (Sb, Ḳ:) and sometimes it signifies the stopping in one's coming and then returning: (Sb:) [and it returned to its first state; it recommenced:] and you say, rajaEotu EawodiI EalaI badoYiI, meaning I returned like as I had come. (Sb ubi suprà.)

Also First, or former; preceding all others, or preceding another; as also AlbadoCu badiIoCN↓; and AlbadiYu being syn. with AlOaw-alu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, AifoEalohu baAdiI badoCK, and baAdiI badiIoCK↓, meaning Do thou it the first thing, or the first of everything; [accord. to different copies of the Ṣ;] the I in bAdI being quiescent, in the place of the accus. case, accord. to usage; and sometimes they omit the [altogether], on account of frequent use [of the phrase], as will be stated in art. bdw, (Ṣ in the present art.,) saying baAdiI badK, and baAdiIbadiI (Ṣ in art. bdw.) You say also, AifoEalohu badoCFA, and Oaw-ala badoCK, (Th, M, Ḳ,) and badoCa badoCK, (CK,) and badaA badoCK, (M, Ḳ,) and baAdiYa↓ badoCK, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and baAdiIa badK, (Ḳ,) and baAdiIo badFA, (M, Ḳ, [in the CK baAdiIo badK,]) and baAdiIo badFA, (M,) and baAdiYa↓ badaA, (Ḳ,) and baAdiIo badaA, (M, Ḳ,) and baAdiYa↓ badiIoCK↓, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, CK,) and baAdiYa↓ badiI-K, which is anomalous, (M,) or baAdiIa bad-iIi, (Ḳ,) and baAdiIo badiy-K, (Fr, AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M,) and baAdiYa↓ badiYK↓, (Ṣ, CK,) or baAdiIa badiYK↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and baAdiIo badoOapa↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) the former word being the act. part. n. of badiIa, which is of the dial. of the Ansár, as mentioned above, and the latter being indecl., with fet-ḥ for its termination, (TA, [in the CK the latter word is written badoCap,]) and badoOapa↓ badoCK, (CK,) and badoOapa badoOapa↓, (M, Ḳ,) and badoOapa↓ badiIoCK↓, (Ṣ,) and badiIoCa↓ badoCK, (Ṣ, CK,) and badoCa ciI badoCK, (Fr, T,) and badoOapa↓ ciI badoCK, (Fr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and badoOapa ciI badoOapK↓, and badoOapa↓ ciI badiIoCK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and badaOapa↓ ciI badaMCapa↓, (Ḳ, TA,) not bdACp [as in the CK], (TA,) and badiIoCa ciI badiIoCK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK the last word is written badoCK,]) and badaMCapi↓ ciI badiIoCK↓, (Ḳ,) meaning Do thou it the first thing; (Fr, T, Ḳ;) so in a correct copy [of the Ḳ, and so I find in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK]: accord. to another copy, the first of everything: (TA:) or the first of first; (Ṣ;) thus in the L: (TA:) the words here put in the accus. case [literally or virtually] are so put [in some instances] as adverbial nouns; or, accord. to MF, they may be [in some instances] denotatives of state, with respect to the agent; the meaning being AifoEalohu HaAlapa kawonika baAdiYFA, i. e. mubotadiYaA bihi [lit. do thou it in the state of thy being beginning it]. (TA.) [In like manner,] you also say, badoCa Alr-aOoIi, and [more commonly] baAdiYa↓ Alr-aOoIi, At first thought; or on the first opinion: (Lḥ, M:) [badoCu Alr-aOoIi and] baAdiYu↓ Alr-aOoIi signifying the first, and beginning, of the idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; or what is perceived before considering well or thoroughly: (M:) [and badoCN alone signifying a first idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; as is implied in the A, voce Say-uwrN, q. v.:] hence, faEalahu fiI baAdiYi↓ Alr-aOoyi [He did it at first thought,, &c.]: (M:) and Oanota baAdiYa↓ Alr-aOoIi turiydu ZulomanaA, and mubotadaOa↓ AlrOI, i.e. Thou at first thought,, &c., desirest to wrong us: and one says also, baAdiIa AlrOI, without; meaning on the occasion of what appeared of opinion; i. e. at the first of what appeared thereof; [or at the first opinion's presenting itself;;] in which case, the phrase does not belong to this art. [but to art. bdw]: it occurs in the Ḳur xi. 29: (M:) AA alone there read baAdiYa, with; all the other readers pronounced it without C (TA.)

Also A chief, or lord, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) who occupies the first place in chieftainship or lordship: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, a youth, or young man, whose judgment, or opinion, is deemed good, and who is consulted: (M:) or it signifies also an intelligent youth or young man: (Ḳ:) pl. buduwoCN. (M.) A poet (namely, Ows Ibn-Maghrà Es-Saadee, TA) says,
vunoyaAnunaA Uino OataAhumo kaAna badoOahumu
wabadoWuhumo Uino OataAnaA kiAna vunoyaAnaA
[Our second chief, if he came to them, would be their first chief; and their first chief, if he came to us, would be a second chief]. (Ṣ.)

Also, and badoOapN↓, A share, or portion, of a slaughtered camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the best share or portion thereof: (T:) or the former word has the latter signification; and the latter word, the former signification: and the former signifies also a bone with the meat, or flesh, that is on it: (M:) and a joint; syn. mafoSilN; (AA, T, M;) and so badFA q.v.: (AA, T:) the pl. [of pauc.] of badoCN is OabodaMCN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] buduwoCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the former of which is the more common: (TA:) or this is pl. of badFA. (AA, T.) The shares abovementioned [as commonly divided for the game called Almayosir q. v.] are ten; namely, the two haunches, the two thighs properly so called, the two thighs commonly so called (i. e. the tibiæ), the two shoulders, and the two arms; which last are the worst, because of the many veins [therein]. (TA.)
See also badiIoCN.
budCN: see badoCN; second sentence.
badiYN: see baAdiYa badiYK, or baAdiIa badiYK, voce badCN.

hom.sense: badoOapN: see badoCN, in thirteen places.

Also The beginning, or outward course, of a military expedition; opposed to rajoEapN, meaning the returning, or homeward course, thereof: occurring in a trad., in which it is said that the Prophet gave, in the case of the former, a fourth [of the spoil], and in the case of the latter, a third; i.e., when a troop went forth from the main body of the army and attacked a party of the enemy, they were to have a fourth of the spoil that they took, and the rest of the army was to share with them the remaining three fourths; and if a troop did so in returning, they were to have a third of all the spoil that they took, because of the greater difficulty and danger attending this case. (T, Mgh.)

kaAna celika fiI badoOatinaA, and budoOatinaA↓, and bidoOatinaA↓, (Ḳ,) and badaMCatinaA↓, (Lḥ, M, TA,) and budaMCatinaA↓, and bidaMCatinaA↓, (TA,) and badaOatinaA↓, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) but [ISd says,] I know not how that is, (M,) and mubodaYinaA↓, and mubodaYinaA↓, (Ḳ,) and mabodaOatinaA↓, (Lḥ, M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or mabodaAtinaA, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) thus in the baAhir of Ibn-ʼOdeys [in the CK Ibn-'Adebbes], (Ḳ,) which is said to indicate that we should hesitate respecting them [before admitting them to be of classical authority], are phrases meaning That was in the first of our state, and in our adolescence. (TA.)
Also, (so in a copy of the M, there written badoOap,) or budoOapN↓, with damm, (Ḳ,) A certain plant; (M;) a black thing, resembling a truffle (kamoC), of which no use is made: so says AḤn. (M.)

entry.sense: budoOapN: see badoCN; second sentence: and see badoOapN, in two places.
bidoOapN: see badoCN; second sentence: and see badoOapN
badaOapN: see badoOapN.
badaMCN, with medd; [Excrement from the anus; as also bad-aA;] a subst. from OabodaOa, as meaning najaA. (M.)
badiIoCN: see badoCN, as signifying First, or former; in eight places.

Also, applied to a thing, or an affair, i. q badiyEN, (Ṣ, and so in a copy of the Ḳ,) or mubodaEN: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) [thus it signifies] Originated; brought into being or existence; made, or produced, for the first time, not having been before, or not after the similitude of any former thing: (TA:) and created: (M, Ḳ:) and wonderful: (M, Mṣb, TA:) and strange, or extraordinary, as not being after the similitude of any former thing. (TA.)

[Hence, as is implied in the Mgh,] biYorN badiIoCN A well newly dug; (T, Mgh, Mṣb;) i. q. badiyEN; (M;) or dug since the era of El-Islám (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not ancient; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also badoCN↓: (Ṣ:) the former epithet [in this sense] is generally pronounced [badiI-N] without C: (T:) the well thus called is one dug in a waste land that has no owner: (TA:) AO says, (TA,) this epithet, and badiyE, are applied to a well when thou hast dug it; but if thou findest it to have been dug before thee, it is termed xafiy-ap; and thus the well of Zemzem is termed xfy-p, because it was Ismá'eel's, and was filled up or covered over [after his time]: (T, TA:) the term qaliyb is [said to be] applied to an ancient well of which neither the owner nor the digger is known: (TA:) it is said in a trad., that the Hariym of a well such as is termed bdIC [i. e. the space surrounding it and belonging to it] is five-and-twenty cubits: (T, Ṣ: [but see HariymN:]) the pl. is buduwoCN: (M:) and AO says that buwdaAnN is pl. of badiIoCN applied to a well, and is syn. with qulobaAnN [a pl. of qaliybN which I have not found elsewhere] and rakaAyaA, being formed by transposition of letters from budoyaAnN [which is for budoMnN, as badiI-N is for badiIoCN; the d and I being transposed, the word becomes buyodaAnN, and this, by a rule of permutation, becomes buwdaAnN]. (TA.)
badaMCapN: see badoCN, in three places: and see badoOapN: and badiYapN, in two places.
budaMCapN: see badoCN, in two places: and see badoOapN: and see also badiyoYapN.
bidaMCapN: see badoCN, in two places: and see badoOapN.
badiyoYapN: see badoCN; second sentence.

Also, (M, Ḳ,) and badaMCapN↓, (Ḳ,) or budaMCapN↓, (M,) i. q. badiyhapN, (Ḳ,) and badaAhapN, (TA,) or budaAhapN, i. e. The first occurrence of a thing, that happens to one unexpectedly: (M:) [or the first of anything: and an occurrence thereof by which one is taken unawares: accord. to explanations in the Ḳ in art. bdh:] pl. of the first, badaAyaA. (TA.)

[And all app. signify The faculty of extemporizing; like badiyhapN (q. v.), &c.] You say, fulaAnN cuw badaMCapK↓ jay-idapK, i. e. badiyhapK HasanapK, [meaning] Such a one has a good faculty of extemporizing; or of uttering, or relating, things by means of the promptness of his intelligence. (TA.)
bud-aMCapN: see badoCN; second sentence.
baAdiYN [act. part. n. of 1]: see badoCN, in nine places.
baAdiYapN: see 1, in two places.
mabodaON [originally noun of place and of time from 1; A place, and a time, of beginning,, &c.]
See badoOapN.
[Also A principle, or first rule, of a science, &c.: pl. mabaAdiYu.]
[And The primary import of a word; opposed in this sense to gaAyapN.]
mubodaON: see badoOapN.

AlmubodiYu, applied to God, The Creator, or Originator, of the things [that exist], who hath produced them at the beginning, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (Nh.) And AlmubodiYu AlmuEiydu, so applied, He who createth mankind, and who returneth them after life to death in the present world and after death to life on the day of resurrection. (TA in art. Ewd.)

mubodiYu muEiydN A man who has gone on warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions, time after time, and is experienced in affairs: (AʼObeyd, and Ḳ in art. Ewd:) and a horse upon which the owner has gone time after time on warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions; (TA in that art.;) or well trained and exercised, (Ḳ and TA in that art.) so as to be obedient to his rider. (TA in that art.)
[For other significations of mubodiYN, see its verb (4); and see OaHofara.]
mabodaOapN: see badoOapN

hom.sense: maboduwoCN [pass. part. n. of 1; Begun,, &c.]
See budiYa.

entry.sense: mubotadaON: see badoCN.
[In grammar, as correlative of xabarN, An inchoative.]

hom.sense: 1. badara, aor. _u {yaboduru}, inf. n. badorN, It (the moon) became full. (Mṣb.)
‡ He (a boy) became full-grown and round; implying comparison to the full moon. (TA.)
† It (fruit) attained to maturity. (TA, from a trad.) [See also 4.]
It rose like the full moon. (Er Rághib.)
See also 3, in six places.
badarato minohu bawaAdiru gDabK and badarat bawaAdiru Alxayoli: see baAdirapN.
badarati AlUibila She (a camel) brought forth at an earlier period of the year than the other camels. (TA.) [See badoriy-apN, voce badoriI-N.]
xarajotu Oaboduru ‡ I went forth to make water. (A.)

entry.sense: 3. bAdrhu, inf. n. mubaAdarapN and bidaArN; and Abtdrhu↓; He hastened, or made haste, or strove to be first or beforehand, in doing [or attaining or obtaining] it; (M, Ḳ, TA, TḲ;) namely, a thing: (M:) and badara↓ gayoruhu Uilayohi, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboduru}; and bAdrhu Alyh; (M;) He hastened with another, or vied or strove with him in hastening, to it [or to do or attain or obtain it]: syn. EaAjalahu, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and OasoraEa Uilayohi. (TA.) bAdr [as well as badara↓ and Abtdr↓] denotes mutual effort only when it is immediately trans.: when it is trans. by means of UilaI [or bi (the former in the TA written by mistake ElI)], there is nothing to show that it denotes this. (MF.) [But it is often immediately trans. without its denoting such effort.] One says, bAdrhu He hastened to do it [&c., as explained above]; meaning, a thing that he desired, or wished for: (TA:) [and bAdrbihi signifies the same; or he hastened with it: and the former signifies also he betook himself early to him or it:] and bAdr Uilayohi he hastened to it; (Ṣ, A;) as also badara↓ Alyh, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaboduru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. buduwrN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, accord. to Zj, agreeably with its derivation, [see badorN,] he employed the fulness of his power, or force, to hasten [to it]: (TA:) and badarahu↓ AlOamoru, and badara↓ Uilayohi, (aor. _u {yaboduru}, inf. n. badorN, TA, [or buduwrN, as above,]) the thing, or event, came to him, or happened to him, hastily, quickly, or speedily; and, beforehand [or before he expected it]; syn. Eajila, (M, Ḳ,) and sabaqa, (M,) or Aisotabaqa: (Ḳ:) [and badara↓ minohu qawolN, and fiEolN, a saying, and an action, proceeded from him hastily, without premeditation: see baAdirapN.] It is said in a trad., baAdiruwA biAloOaEomaAli haramFA [Strive ye to be before decrepitude with good works; i. e., to perform them before decrepitude]. (El-Jámiʼ es- Sagheer.) And in another, baAdiruwA AlS-uboHa biAlowitori [Strive ye to be before daybreak with the prayers termed wtr; i. e., to perform them before daybreak]. (Idem.) And in another, baAdiruwA biSalAapi Almagoribi qabola TuluwEi Aln-ajomi [Hasten ye with, or to perform, the prayer of sunset before the rising of the star]. (Idem.) You say also, fulaAnN yubaAdiru fiI Oakoli maAli Alyatiymi [Such a one hastens in consuming the property of the orphan before the latter is of full age]. (A.) And baAdara kibara Alyatiymi [He hastened to be before the orphan's attaining to full age in expending his property]; said of a guardian; i. q. Oabodara↓ fiI maAli Alyatiymi: (Ḳ:) and thus, bidaArFAOano yakobaruwA, in the Ḳur [iv. 5], means hastening to be before their attaining to full age in expending their property. (Bḍ,* Jel.) And bAdrhu AlgaAyapa and UilaI AlgaAyapi [He strove with him in hastening, or strove to get before him, to the goal]. (A.) And Abtdr↓ AlgaAyapa and UilaI AlgaAyapi [He strove in hastening, or strove to get first, to the goal]. (Ḥam p. 46.) And baAdara baEoDuhumo baEoDFA UilaI OamorK, and AbtdrwA↓ OamorFA, and tbAdrwhu↓, They vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening to a thing, or an affair, trying which of them would be first. (T.)

hom.sense: 4. Abdr He had the full moon rising to him, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or upon him: (A:) a verb similar to Oaqomara and OaXoraqa: (A:) or he journeyed during a night of full moon. (T, Ḳ.)
It (an unripe date) became red. (TA.) [See also 1.]
Abdr fiI AlmaAli Alyatiymi: see 3.

entry.sense: 6. tbAdrwA They hastened together; vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening; made haste to be, or get, before one another; strove, one with another, to be first, or beforehand. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, tbAdrwA UilaI Oaxoci Als-ilaAHi, (TA,) and AbtdrwA↓ Als-ilaAHa, (Ṣ, TA,) They hastened together,, &c., to take the weapons. (Ṣ.) And tbAdrwA AlbaAEa [They hastened together; or vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening; to attain power, or eminence, or nobility]; as also Abtdrwhu↓. (A.) nd tbAdrwA OamorFM: see 3, last sentence.
hecaA maA yatabaAdaru minohu † [This meaning is what appears from it (namely, the phrase, or sentence,) at first sight]. (A phrase of frequent occurrence in the TA, &c.)
8: see 3, in four places; and see 6, in two places.
Aibotadarato EayonaAIa My eyes flowed with tears. (TA, from a trad.)
Q. Q. 1. bayodara He heaped up wheat. (Ḳ.)

badorN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally an inf. n., (Mṣb,) The full moon; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also baAdirN↓; (L, Ḳ;) the moon in its fourteenth night: (Ṣ:) or the latter signifies [simply] the moon: (IAạr, T:) the moon in its fourteenth night is called bdr because it hastens to rise before the sun sets; (Ṣ, M;) and to set before the sun rises: (TA:) or because of its fulness; (Ṣ, TA;) as being likened to a badorap: or, as Er-Rághib thinks to be most probable, it is itself a primitive word: (TA:) pl. buduwrN. (M, A.) Hence, layolapu Albadori [The night of the full moon; which is] the fourteenth night [of the lunar month]. (Ṣ.)
‡ A lord, master, or chief, (M, Ḳ,) of a people: so called as being likened to the full moon. (M.)

Applied to a boy, (Zj, M, Ḳ,) ‡ Full of youthful vigour and of flesh: (Zj:) or full, or plump: (M:) or i. q. mubaAdirN↓ [precocious]. (T, Ḳ.) [In this sense, an epithet; and so its fem. badorapN (q. v.), applied to an eye.]
‡ A cover; or a dish or plate; syn. TabaqN: (Ibn-Wahb, Ḳ:) because resembling the full moon, being round: so Az thinks. (TA.)
See also badorapN, in two places.

hom.sense: badorapN, applied to an eye (EayonN), Quick-sighted; or that sees before others: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or that sees before [the eyes of] other horses; applied to a horse's eye: (IAạr, T, M:) or sharp-sighted: or round and large: (M:) or full like the full moon: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but the correct meaning is [said to be] that [mentioned above as] given by IAạr: (M:) or, accord. to IAạr, full; not defective. (T.)

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and badorN↓, (Ḳ,) The skin of a lamb or kid (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) when it has been weaned, (AZ, Ṣ, M,) used for milk: for [when it is killed] while it continues sucking, its skin, if used for milk, is called XakowapN;
and for clarified butter, Euk-ap: when it has been weaned, its skin for milk is called badorap; and for clarified butter, misoOad: and when it is in its second year, its skin for milk is called waTob; and for clarified butter, niHoI: (AZ, Ṣ:) pl. (of the former, M) bidarN and buduwrN: (M, Ḳ:) the former said by El-Fárisee to be the only instance of the kind except hiDabN pl. of haDobapN, and biDaEN pl. of baDoEapN [or this may be pl. of biDoEapN]. (M. [But the assertion of El-Fárisee is incorrect (see HayoDapN), unless it be meant to apply only to sound words; and in this case, at least one addition should be made, namely qiSaEN pl. of qaSoEapN.])

Hence, (M,) the former word, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, &c.,) and ↓the latter also, (Ḳ,) The sum of ten thousand dirhems: (Ṣ, A:) or a purse containing a thousand, (T, M, Ḳ,) or ten thousand, dirhems, (T, M,* A, Ḳ,) or seven thousand deenárs: (Ḳ:) pl. buduwrN, (TA,) and pl. of pauc. bidaraAtN. (T.)

entry.sense: AisotabaqonaA AlbadaraI We strove to outrun one another, vying, one with another, in haste. (M, Ḳ.)
badoriI-N Rain that is before (qabola), or a little before (qubayola), or in the first part of (qubula), winter. (Ḳ, accord. to different copies: the second reading is that followed in the TA.)

badoriy-apu A she-camel whose mother has brought her forth at an earlier period of the year than that when the others brought forth, and therefore more abundant in milk than others, and of a more generous quality. (M.)
And the former, A fat young camel weaned from its mother. (Ḳ.)
badaAriI-N A lamb brought forth a little before winter. (TA.)
baAdirN: see badorN.
bayodarN a word of the dial. of El-'Irák, (AʼObeyd in art. rbd in the TA,) A place in which wheat, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or grain, (Mṣb,) is trodden out. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

It may also mean, tropically, ‡ The wheat and straw therein: (Mgh:) or rather, as Az says, on the authority of IAạr, it signifies [also] (Mgh) reaped grain collected together; or wheat collected together in the place in which it is trodden out; syn. kudosN, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and EaramapN: (Mgh:) Kr restricts it to wheat. (M.)
Accord. to the Towsheeh, it is [A place] for [drying] dates. (TA in art. jrn.)

baAdirapN Hastiness of temper; passionateness: (Ṣ:) or a hasty saying, or action, that suddenly proceeds (yaboduru, in the CK yaboduw,) from one in anger: (M, A,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and a slip; a mistake; an error; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) on an occasion of one's being angry: (Ṣ:) or a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word or saying: and a quick fit of anger: (IAạr, T:) pl. bawaAdiru, (Ṣ, A.) You say, OaxoXaI Ealayoka baAdiratahu I fear for thee his hastiness of temper, or passionateness: (Ṣ:) or what may hastily proceed from him in his anger. (A.) And badarato↓ minohu yawaAdiru gaDabK Slips, mistakes, or errors, on an occasion of his being angry, hastily proceeded from him. (Ṣ.) And baAdirapu AlX-ar-i signifies What hastily, or suddenly, befalls one, of evil, or mischief. (M.)

An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; or a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; or a faculty of extemporizing; syn. badiyhahN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, fulaAnu Hasanu AlbaAdirapi Such a one has a good intuitive knowledge,, &c. (TA.)
The point of a sword. (M, Ḳ.)
The extremity of an arrow, next the head. (A.)
The head of a plant; (M;) the first part thereof from which the earth cleaves asunder. (M, Ḳ.*)
The first that appears of the [plant called] Hin-aMC. (M.)
The leaves of the [herb called] Huw-aMCap. (Ḳ.)
The best, and freshest in growth, of the [plant called] waros. (M, Ḳ.*)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) or bawaAdiru, (Ṣ, A,) which is the pl., (Ḳ,) of a man, &c., (Ṣ, M,) The portion of flesh, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or the portions thereof, (A,) between the shoulder-joint and the neck, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or between the necks and the shoulderjoints: (A:) or the former, (Ḳ,) or its dual, (M,) of a man, the two portions of flesh that are above the rugavaAwaAni and below the vanoduwap: (M, Ḳ:) or the dual, [relating to a camel, signifies] the two sides of the kirokirap [or callous lump on the breast]: or two veins on either side thereof. (M.)
badarato↓ bawaAdiru Alxayoli The first, or fore parts, (OawaAYil,) of the horses appeared [or suddenly came in view]. (Mṣb.)

badorapN mubad-arapN [A sum such as is termed bdrp aggregated, made up, or completed]: the latter word is a corroborative; like the latter in qanaATiyru muqanoTarapN, (Ksh and Bḍ in iii. 12,) and in OalofN muWal-afapN. (Ksh ibid.)
mubaAdirN applied to a boy: see badorN.

hom.sense: 1. badaEahu: see 4, in two places.
baduEa, aor. _u {yaboduEu}, inf. n. badaAEapN and buduwEN, He became superlative in his kind; or it became so in its kind; (Ks, Ḳ;) in good or in evil. (Ks.)
badiEa, aor. _a {yabodaEu}, He was, or became, fat. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. bd-Ehu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabodiyEN, (Ḳ,) He attributed to him, imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, innovation, or what is termed bidoEap; expl. by nasabahu UilaI AlbidoEapi [which means nasaba Uilayohi AlbidoEapa]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. AbdEhu He originated it; invented it; devised it; excogitated it; innovated it; made it, did it, produced it, caused it to be or exist, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing; syn. AixotaraEahu laA EalaI mivaAlK, (Ṣ,) and Asotaxorajahu, and OaHodavahu, (Mṣb,) and OabodaOahu; (Ḳ, TA; but in both without the pronoun;) as also AbtdEh↓; (Mṣb;) syn. AibotadaOahu, and OaHodavahu, (Mgh,) and OanoXaOahu, (Ḳ,) and badaOahu; (TA;) and so badaEahu↓, aor. _a {yabodaEu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. badoEN; (TA;) but OabodaEa is more commonly used than badaEa. (TA.) You say, AbdE Qll-ehu Alxaloqa God created the creation, not after any similitude. (Mṣb.) And in the Ḳur [lvii. 27], we find, warahobaAniy-apF QbotadaEuwhaA↓ And monkery which they originated, or innovated. (TA.) And you say, badaEa↓ Alr-akiy-apa, (IDrd, Ḳ,) inf. n. badoEN, (IDrd,) He produced, or fetched out, by his labour in digging, the water of the well; (IDrd, Ḳ;) and originated it; or made it to be for the first time, it not having been before. (IDrd.) And AbdE Alr-ajulu The man introduced an innovation, or what is termed a bidoEap; [the object being understood;] as also AbtdE↓. (TA.) And AbdE AlX-aAEiru The poet produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)

AbdEt Alr-aAHilapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Alr-ikaAbu, (Ks, Mgh,) The ridden camel, or travelling camel, became fatigued, or jaded, and broke down, or perished; (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) as though doing a new thing: (Ks, Mgh:) or the former phrase, (Ḳ,) followed by bihi, (TA,) she limped [with him], halted, or was slightly lame: (Ḳ, TA:) or she lay down upon her breast in the road, by reason of emaciation or disease: or she ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue, or of limping, or halting, or slight lameness; as though she did a new and unaccustomed thing: (TA:) or AbdAE is not without limping, or halting, or slight lameness, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to certain of the Arabs of the desert; but, says AO, this is not at variance with the explanations given. (TA.) And OubodiEa biAlr-ajuli The man's camel which he rode became fatigued, or jaded: (Ṣ:) or OubodiEa bifulaAnK (Mgh, Ḳ) such a one's camel which he rode ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue or lameness: (Mgh:) or broke down, or perished, (Ḳ, TA,) or became fatigued, or jaded, (TA,) and he became unable to prosecute his journey; (Ḳ, TA;) and his beast became so fatigued that it was left to remain where it was; or stood still with him. (TA.) [See also OuEobida bihi.] It is said in a proverb, UicaA Talabota AlbaATila OubodiEa bika [When thou seekest what is vain, or false, thou wilt be prevented from attaining thine object]. (TA.)

OabodaEa fulaAnN bifulaAnK ‡ Such a one prevented such a one from attaining his wish, (qaTaEa bihi,) and abstained from aiding, or assisting, him, and did not undertake the accomplishment of his want, (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA,) and was not [at hand] when he thought he would be. (TA.)

OabodaEato Huj-atuhu ‡ His argument, or plea, or the like, was, or became, vain, or false, or ineffectual: (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ:) or was, or became, weak. (A, TA.) And OubodiEato Huj-atuhu ‡ His argument, or plea,, &c., was rendered vain, or ineffectual. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ,* TA.) OabodaEa bir-uhu biXukoriI wafaDoluhu waUyjaAbuhu biwaSofiI † [His kindness has crippled my power of thanking, and his bounty, and the obligation which he has imposed, my power of description]: so in the L; but in the O and Ḳ, qaSoduhu [his intention] is put in the place of fDlh; and in the Ḳ, wAyjAbh is omitted: (TA:) said when one thanks another for his beneficence, acknowledging that his thanks are inadequate to his beneficence. (Ḳ.)
AbdE biAlHaj-i, and biAls-afari, He determined, resolved, or decided, upon pilgrimage, and upon journeying. (TA.)
AbdE yamiynFA He rendered an both binding, or obligatory. (IAạr.)
AbdEwA bihi They beat him, or struck him. (TA.)

entry.sense:
5. tbd-E He turned innovator. (O, Ḳ.) Ru-beh says,
Oino kunota lilehi Alt-aqiI-a AlOaTowaEaA
falayosa wajoha AlHaq-i Oano tabad-aEaA
[If thou be, towards God, the pious, the very obedient, it is not the right way that thou shouldst turn innovator]. (TA.)
8: see 4, in three places.
10. AstbdEhu He reckoned it badiyE [i. e. new, wonderful, unknown before]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

bidoEN i. q. badiyEN↓, q. v., and mubotadaEN↓; (Ṣ;) [but generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; signifying] A novelty; or thing existing for the first time: (Ḳ:) and i. q. badiyEN↓ and mubotadiEN↓, a first doer; as though meaning one who has none among his fellows to share, or participate, with him in a thing, or an affair: (Mṣb:) pl. OabodaAEN. (Akh, Ṣ.) You say, fulaAnN bidoEN fiI hecA AlOamori, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. badiyEN↓, (Ṣ,) meaning Such a one is the first doer in this affair; the first who has done it. (Mṣb.) And hence the saying in the Ḳur [xlvi. 8], qulo maA kunotu bidoEFA mina Alr-usuli (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) Say thou, I am not the first who has been sent of the apostles: (Mṣb, TA:) or the meaning is, I am not an innovator among the apostles; inviting you to that to which they do not invite you; or able to do that which they were not able to do: and accord. to one reading, it is bidaEFA↓; as being [a sing. epithet] like qiyamN; or for caA bidaEK [in which the latter word is pl. of bidoEapN]. (Bḍ.)

Applied to a man, (TA,) Superlative (Ks, Ḳ) in his kind (Ks) in anything; (Ḳ;) in good and in evil; (Ks;) or in knowledge, or courage, or nobility: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {bidoEapN}: pl. of the masc. OabodaAEN [a pl. of pauc., which is also, as is said in the L, applied to women,] and buduEN [a pl. of mult.]; and pl. of the fem. bidaEN. (Ḳ.) ↓{bidoEN} A man liberal in disposition; syn. gamorN. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A full body. (Ḳ.)
bidaEN: see bidoEN.
It is also pl. of bidoEapN, [both as a subst. and] as fem. of bidoEN. (Ḳ.)

bidoEapN An innovation; a novelty; anything originated, invented, or innovated; anything made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (ISK:) a dissentient state or condition: (Mṣb:) a subst. from AibotidaAEN, like rifoEapN from AirotifaAEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and xilofapN from AixotilaAfN: (Mgh:) subsequently and generally applied to an addition, or an impairment, in religion: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a novelty, or an innovation, in religion, after the completion [thereof]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an opinion declining, or swerving, from the right way, and an action, innovated after [the time of] the Prophet: (Lth, Ḳ:) or an action at variance with the Sunneh: (KT:) [generally a heretical innovation; or a new heresy: but] there is a bdEp not disapproved, termed bidoEapN mubaAHapN [an allowed, or allowable, innovation]; which is that whereof the goodness is attested by some principle in the law, or which is required to prevent some cause of evil; such as the Khaleefeh's seclusion of himself from the promiscuous classes of the people: (Mṣb:) there are two kinds of bdEp; namely bidoEapN hudFI [an innovation of a right kind], and bidoEapN DalaAlK [an innovation of an erroneous kind]. (IAth.)

hom.sense: badiyEN i. q. bidoEN, which see in three places, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and mubotadaEN↓; [i. e. Originated; invented; innovated; made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) new; wonderful; unknown before. (TA.) You say, jiYota biOamorK badiyEK Thou hast done a new thing; a wonderful thing; a thing unknown before: and OamorN baAdiEN↓ signifies the same as OamorN badiyEN. (TA.) And jaMCa biA lbadiyEi, (Ṣ,) or OataI biAlbadayEi, (Ḳ,) said of a poet, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA.) And HabolN badXyEN A new rope: (AḤn:) or a rope begun to be twisted, not being yet a rope, but undone, then spun, then twisted again. (Ḳ.) And zimaAmN badiyEN A new nose-rein of a camel. (TA.) And rakiy-apN badiyEN A newly-dug well. (TA.) [See also badiIoCN.] And badiyEN alone, A skin for wine, &c.: (Ṣ:) or a new skin for wine, &c.: (Ḳ:) and a new skin for water or milk: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) Hence the trad., Uin-a tihaAmapa kabadiyEi AlEasali HulowN Oaw-aluhu HulowN Mxiruhu [Verily Tihámeh is like the skin, or new skin, of honey: the first part thereof is sweet: the last part thereof is sweet]: (Ṣ, Ḳ *:) because honey does not change in flavour, whereas milk does change. (Ṣ.)
Fat; as an epithet: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) pl. budoEN. (Ḳ.)

Also i. q. mubotadiEN↓ [An originator, inventor, or innovator; one who makes, does, produces, causes to be or exist, or brings into existence, newly, for the first time, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, like qadiyrN in the sense of qaAdirN; from badaEa. (TA.) [See also bidoEN.] You say, Aall-ehu badiyEN Als-amewaAti waAlOaroDi God is the Creator of the heavens and the earth, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, Ṣ.*) And hence AlbadiyEu is a name of God, meaning The Originator of the creation, according to his own will, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (TA.)

entry.sense: [badiyEapN A new, and an admirable, or a wonderful, thing; and especially such in speech, or language, in poetry, and in answering, or replying: pl. badaAYiEu: see an ex. voce badiyhapN.]
baAdiEN: see badiyEN.
mubotadaEN: see bidoEN and badiyEN, in two places.
mubotadiEN: see bidoEN and badiyEN, in two places.
1. badala, inf. n. badaAlN: see 2, in three places.

2. tabodiylN properly signifies [The changing, or altering, a thing; or] the changing, or altering, the form, or fashion, or semblance, or the quality, or condition, [of a thing,] to another form,, &c., while the substance remains the same; (Th, T, TA;) or the changing a thing from its state, or condition; (Ibn-ʼArafeh, TA;) or the changing a thing without substitution: (Ṣ:) but the Arabs have used it also in the sense of UibodaAlN↓, (Mbr, T, TA,) which signifies [the changing a thing by substitution; exchanging it; replacing it with another thing; or] the removing, or displacing, the substance [of a thing], and introducing anew another substance. (Th, T, TA.) You say, bad-alotuhu, inf. n. tabodiylN, (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning I changed it, or altered it; (M, Ḳ) or I changed, or altered, the form, or fashion, or semblance, or the quality, or condition, of it; (Mṣb;) as in the phrase, bad-alotu AlxaAtama biAlHaloqapi [I changed, or altered, the signet-ring into the simple ring], said when one has melted the former and made of it a simple ring; (Fr, T, TA;) and bad-ala Qll-ehu Als-ayiY-aAti HasanaAtK [God changed the evil deeds into good deeds]; the verb being doubly trans. by itself because it has the meaning of jaEala and Say-ara. (Mṣb. [But see what follows.]) Oabodalotuhu↓ bikacaA, [in the Ṣ, Oabodalotu AlX-aIoCa bigayorihi, without explanation,] inf. n. UibodaAlN, [I changed it by substituting for it such a thing, or exchanged it for such a thing, or replaced it with such a thing,] is said when one has removed the first, and put the second in its place; (Mṣb;) as in the phrase, Oabodalotu AlxaAtama biAlHaloqapi [I changed the signet-ring by substituting for it the simple ring; exchanged the signet-ring for the simple ring; or replaced the signet-ring with the simple ring]; said when one removes the one, and puts the other in its place: (Fr, T, TA:) and this verb is also made doubly trans. by itself, like bad-alotu, (Mṣb,) which is used in the sense of Oabodalotu [as shown above]; (Mbr, T, TA;) for instance, where it is said, [in the Ḳur lxvi. 5,] EasaI rab-uhu Uino Tal-aqakun-a Oano yubodilahu OazowajFA xayorFA minokun-a [May-be, his Lord, if he divorce you, will give him in exchange wives better than you]; accord to one reading, yubad-ilahu (Mṣb.) An ex. of the latter of these two verbs in the sense of the former is the saying in the Ḳur [xxv. 70], yubad-ilu Qll-ehu say-iMtihimo HasanaAtK [God will change their evil deeds by substituting for them good deeds]; i. e. will cancel the evil deeds and put in their place good deeds: but in the saying in the Ḳur [iv. 59], kul-amaA naDijato juluwduhumo bad-alonaAhumo juluwdFA gayorahaA [Whenever their skins are thoroughly burned, we will change the condition thereof to them into the condition of other skins], the meaning is, that the first condition of their skins shall be restored; so that the substance is one, but the condition is different. (Mbr, T, TA.)
You say also, bad-alahu Qll-ehu mana Alxawofi OamonFA [God gave him in exchange for fear, or in lieu of fear, security]. (Ṣ.) [And bad-alahu bihi kacaA He gave him in exchange for it, or in lieu of it, such a thing: see Ḳur xxxiv. 15. And bd-l makaAnahu kacaA He gave in exchange for it, or in lieu of it, such a thing: see Ḳur vii. 93 and xvi. 103.] bad-ala HusonFA baEoda suwoCK, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 11], means He hath done good [by way of exchange after evil]; i. e., repented; (Jel;) or bad-ala canobuhu biAltawobapi [hath exchanged his sin for repentance]. (Bḍ.) tabodiylN and UibodaAlN↓ both signify The act of exchanging [a thing for another thing]; or making [a thing] to be a substitute [for another thing]; (KL, PṢ;) and so does badaAlN↓. (KL.) You say, bd-l AlX-aIoCa mina AlXaIoCi, (M, Ḳ,*) and Abdlhu↓ minohu, i. e. Ait-axacahu minohu badlFA [here meaning He exchanged the thing for the thing; or, more literally, he made the thing a substitute for the thing]. (M, Ḳ. [In the text of the former of these, as given in the TT, instead of Ait-axacahu, I find taxica ( a dial. var. of Ait-axaca) without the affixed pronoun, which is meant to be understood or is omitted inadvertently by the transcriber: and here it should be observed, that the explanation which I have rendered as above admits of another meaning, namely, Oaxacahu minohu badalFA “he took it as a substitute for it:” in the M, immediately before, Oaxacahu minohu badalFA is given as the explanation of the phrases tbd-l AlX-aIoCa and biAlX-aIoCi, and Astbdlhu and bihi: see 10.]) You say also, badalotu↓ Alv-awoba bigayorihi, aor. _u {yabodulu} [inf. n. badaAlN, mentioned and explained above, I exchanged the garment, or piece of cloth, for another; or made it to be a substitute for another;] and Aisotabodalotuhu↓ bigayorihi signifies the same. (Mṣb. [But the latter phrase has more frequently another meaning, explained below: see 10.]) [Abdlhu↓ in the phrases Abdlhu kacaA as meaning He changed it into, or substituted for it, such a thing, and Abdlhu mino kacaA as meaning he changed it from, or substituted it for, such a thing, is more common than bd-lh, which is used in the same sense; as badalahu↓ is also; for] AO applies the term maboduwlN↓ [in lieu of the more common term mubodalN↓] to a letter that is changed from another letter, as in madahotuhu for madaHotuhu; and this shows that badalotu is trans. [and signifies I changed,, &c.]. (Az, TA.)

3. mubaAdalapN and tabaAdalN↓ signify the same, (Ṣ,) namely, The act of exchanging with another or others. (PṢ.) You say, bAdlhu, inf. n. mubaAdalapN and bidaAlN [in the CK erroneously written with fet-ḥ to the b, He exchanged, or made an exchange, with him; or] he gave him the like of that which he took, or received, from him; (IDrd,* M, Ḳ;) for instance, a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place of another; (Lth, T, Mṣb,* in explanation of the former inf. n.;) and a brother in the place of a brother. (Lth, T.) And tabaAdalaA↓ They exchanged, or made an exchange, each with the other; or each gave to the other the like of that which he took, or received, from him. (TA.) nubaAdiluho, ending a verse of El-Kulákh, means for whom we would take a substitute: El-Marzookee says, it is for nubaAdilu bihi Aln-aAsa [for whom we would make an exchange with the people]; the preposition being suppressed. (Ḥam p. 465.)
4. Abdlhu, inf. n. UibodaAlN: see 2, in five places.

hom.sense: 5. tbd-l It (a thing, M) became changed, or altered. (M, Ḳ.)

In the saying of the rájiz,
fabud-ilato waAld-ahoru cuw tabad-uli
the meaning is, cw tabodiyl [i. e. the meaning of the whole is, And, or but, she was changed, or altered; for time has the property of changing, or altering]. (M.)
See also 10, in three places.

entry.sense: 6: see 3, in two places.

10. Astbdl AlX-aIoCa and biAlX-aIoCi, and tbd-lhu↓ and bihi, (M, Ḳ,*) He took a substitute, or a thing in exchange, for the thing. (M.) You say, Astbdl AlX-aIoCa bigayorihi, and tbd-lhu↓ bihi, He took the thing [as a substitute, or in exchange, for another; or] in the place of another. (Ṣ.) And Astbdl vawobFA makaAna vawobK [He took a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place, or in lieu, of a garment,, &c.]; and OaxFA makaAna OaxK [a brother in the place, or in lieu, of a brother]. (Lth, T.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 58], Oatasotabodiluwna Ql-aciI huwa OadonaI biAl-aciI huwa xayorN Will ye take in exchange that which is worse for that which is better? (Jel. [See also other exs. in the Ḳur ix. 39 and xlvii. last verse.]) And mano yatabad-ali↓ Alkufora biAloUiymaAni [Whoso adopteth infidelity in lieu of faith]. (Ḳur ii. 102. [See also other exs. in the Ḳur iv. 2 and xxxiii. 52.])
See also 2, last sentence but one.
bidolN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

badalN and bidolN↓, (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like mavalN and mivolN, and XabahN and XibohN, (Fr, T, Ṣ,) and nakalN and nikalN, the only other instances of the kind, i. e. of words of both these measures, that have been heard, accord. to AO, (Ṣ, TA, [but in one copy of the Ṣ, I find AʼObeyd,]) and badiylN↓ (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) all signify the same; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. xalafN, (M, Ḳ,) and EiwaDN: (Kull:) badalu AlX-aIoCi [and Albadalu mina AlX-aIoCi] and bidoluhu↓ and badiyluhu↓ meaning Alxalafu minohu [the substitute for the thing;, &c.]; (M, Ḳ;) i. e., another thing: (Ṣ:) pl. OabodaAlN, (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which, as pl. of badiylN↓, has few parallels. (IDrd, TA.) Sb says, [making a distinction between badalN and badiylN↓,] you say, Uin-a badalaka zayodN, i. e. Verily Zeyd is in thy place: but if you put badal in the place of badiyli, you say, Uin-a badalaka zayodN, i. e. Uin-a bidaylaka↓ zayodN [Verily thy substitute is Zeyd]: and a man says to another, Go thou with such a one; and he replies, maEiIa rajulN badaluhu, i. e. With me is a man who stands in his stead, and is in his place, or who will stand, &c. (M.) You say also, bala kacaA [and badalFA mino kacaA], meaning Instead of, in the place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, such a thing. (Kull.) [And badala Oano tafoEala kacaA Instead of thy doing thus.]
