AlOabodaAlu (IDrd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and AlbudalaMCu (TA) [The Substitutes, or Lieutenants;] certain righteous persons, of whom the world is never destitute; when one dies, God substituting another in his place: (Ṣ:) certain persons by means of whom God rules the earth; (M, Ḳ;) consisting of seventy men, (IDrd, M, Ḳ,) according to their assertion, of whom the earth is never destitute; (IDrd, TA;) forty of whom are in Syria, and thirty in the other countries; (IDrd, M, Ḳ;) none of them dying without another's supplying his place, (M, Ḳ,) from the rest of mankind; (Ḳ;) and therefore they are named AbdAl: (M:) accord. to Abu-lBakà, as stated by El-Munáwee, it seems that they meant [by this appellation] the substitutes and successors of the prophets; and accord. to some, they were seven, neither more nor fewer, by means of whom God takes care of the seven climates; one being successor of Abraham (El-Khaleel), and to him pertains the first climate; the second, of Moses (El-Keleem); the third, of Aaron; the fourth, of Idrees; the fifth, of Joseph; the sixth, of Jesus; and the seventh, of Adam: (TA: [in which is also mentioned a treatise denying their existence, and disapproving of the assertion that by means of them God takes care of the earth:]) the sing. is badalN and bidolN↓, (T,) or badiylN↓. (IDrd, Ṣ.)

Huruwfu Albadali (M, Ḳ) The letters of substitution; those which are substituted for other letters; not those which are substituted in consequence of idghám. (M.) [The letters included under this appellation differ accord. to different authors: see De Sacy's Gram. Ar. 2nd ed. i. 33.]

bidolN↓ (Kr, M, Ḳ) and badalN (M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, also signify Generous, and noble: (Kr,* M, Ḳ:) and used in these senses, [says ISd,] they are, in my opinion, not devoid of implication of the meaning of a substitute: (M:) the pl. is OabodaAlN (M, Ḳ.)
badiylN: see badalN, in six places

bad-aAlN A seller of eatables (AHeyth, T, Ḳ) of every kind: thus he is called by the Arabs; (AHeyth, T;) because he changes one sale for another; selling one thing to-day and another to-morrow: (AḤát, TA:) the vulgar say, baq-aAlN. (AHeyth, T, Ḳ.)

Also One who has no more property than is sufficient for his purchasing one thing, and who, when he sells this, buys another thing in exchange for it. (TA in art. jdl.) [Hence,] hecaA raOoIu Aljad-aAliyna waAlbad-aAliyna is a phrase used as meaning This is flimsy opinion. (TA in the present art. and in art. jdl, [but in the latter without the w,] on the authority of AHeyth.)
mubodalN: see 2.
mabodalN: see 2.

1. baduna, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabodunu}; (T, Ṣ;) and badana, aor. _u {yabodunu}; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;)
inf. n. badaAnapN (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) of the former, (ISk, T, Ṣ, &c.,) and budonN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) also of the former, (ISk, T,) or of the latter, (Ṣ,) and badonN, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to AZ, (T,) and badaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) or buduwnN is the inf. n. of the latter verb; (Mṣb;) said of a man, (ISk, T, Ṣ,) and of a camel; (Mṣb;) and badunato and badanato, said of a woman, (AZ, T, M, Ḳ,) and of a badanap, q. v.; (Zj, T, &c.;) He, and she, was, or became, big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) abounding in flesh; (T;) fat: (Zj, T, M:) or the former verb has this last signification, that of fatness; and the latter verb is syn. with bad-ana q. v. (Ḥam p. 158.) [See also budonN, below.]

hom.sense: He clad a man with a badan, i. e. a diroE [or coat of mail]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And Fat; i. e. the substance termed XaHomN. (M, TA.)
It is also a pl. of badanapN: (T, Ṣ, &c.:)
and of baAdinN. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: badanN The body, without the head and arms and legs; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so says Az: (Mṣb:) or the body without the arms and legs: (Mgh:) or [the part] from the shoulder-joint to the posteriors [inclusive]: (TA [as from the Mgh, in my copy of which it is not found]:) or the jasada [generally meaning the body together with the members] of a man; (Ṣ;) often applied. to the whole of the jasad; (Az, TA;) and in the Ḳur x. 92 it is said to mean the body without soul: (Ṣ:) pl. OabodaAnN; (M, Mṣb;) whence the phrase, mentioned by Lḥ, Uin-ahaA laHasanapu AlOabodaAni [meaning Verily she is beautiful in respect of the body], as though the term badanN were applied to every portion of her. (M.) Xirokapu AlOabodaAni is originally XirokapN biAlOabodaAni, meaning Copartnership in bodily labours for the acquirement of gains. (Mṣb.)

And hence, ‡ The part of a shirt, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and of a [garment of the kind called] jub-ap, (Mgh,) that lies against the back and the belly, [i. e. the body thereof,] without the sleeves and the daxaAriyS [or gores with which it is widened]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. as above. (Mṣb.)

Also † A short diroE [or coat of mail], (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of the measure of the body: (M:) or it is [a coat of mail] like a diroE, except that it is short, only such as covers the body, with short sleeves: (T:) or, as some say, any diroE: (M:) and so it is said to mean in the Ḳur x. 92 by IAạr (T) and by Th; (M;) but Akh says that this assertion is of no account: (Ṣ:) pl. as above. (M, Ḳ.)
And † A small [garment of the kind called] jub-ap; as being likened to a coat of mail. (TA.)

Accord. to Kr, (M,) A limb, or member: or, specially, the limbs, or members, of a slaughtered camel: (M, Ḳ: [in the latter of which, the former of these two explanations is improperly connected with the first in this paragraph by the conjunction Aw:]) to these he specially applies it in one instance: pl. as above. (M.)

Also An old, or aged, man: (Ḳ:) or so rajulN badanN. (T, Ṣ, M.) [In like manner, baAdinN↓ and badinN↓ are said by Golius, as on the authority of the Ṣ, to signify annosus et senior, applied to a man, and also to a woman; but this explanation is wrong; and the latter word I do not find in any lexicon.]

And An old mountain-goat: (M, Ḳ:) or so waEilN badanN: (Ṣ:) [in the present day, badan is applied to the wild goat of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; the capra jaela of Hamilton Smith; called by some an ibex; as is also tayotal, properly vayotalN:] pl. [of pauc.] Oabodunu (M, Ḳ [in the CK, erroneously, OabodanN]) and [of mult.] buduwnN, which is extr. [with respect to rule], on the authority of IAạr. (M, TA.) The rájiz says, describing a bitch (Ṣ, M) and a mountain-goat, (M, TA,)
qado qulotu lam-aA badati AlEuqaAbu
waDam-ahaA waAlbadana AlHiqaAbN
jid-iI likul-i EaAmilK vawaAbu
Aalr-aOosu waAlOakoruEu waAlUihaAbu , (Ṣ,* M,* TA,) [I had said, when El-'Ikáb appeared, and El-Hikáb comprised her and the old mountain-goat, “Exert thyself: for every worker there is a recompense: the head and the shanks and the hide shall be thine”]: AlEqAb is the name of a bitch, and AlHqAb is a certain mountain: he says, “Catch thou this goat, and I will make thy recompense to be the head and the shanks and the hide.” (TA.) [Hence Golius has been led to mistake AlHiqaAb for a signification of Albadanu.]
† The lineage, or parentage, of a man, and his grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (M, Ḳ.)
badinN: see badanN

hom.sense: budunN: see budonN.
It is also a pl. of badanapN. (M, Ḳ, &c.)

entry.sense: badanapN A she-camel, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a male camel, (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and a cow, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a bull, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to some, (Mṣb,) or properly the first of these, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and the second, (Mgh,) but made by the Sunneh to apply to a cow also, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) that is slaughtered at Mekkeh, (Ṣ,) or that is, (M, Ḳ,) or may be, (T,) brought thither for sacrifice; (T, M, Ḳ;) so called because they used to fatten them, (Ṣ,) or because of their greatness, or bulkiness: (T, Mgh, Mṣb:) not applied to a sheep or goat: (T, Mṣb, TA:) En-Nawawee erroneously cites the T as asserting that it is thus applied; misled, it is said, by an omission in his copy: (MF, TA:) pl. badanaAtN, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) a pl. of pauc., (Mgh,) and budonN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) or budunN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or both, (M, Mṣb, TA,) the former being a contraction of the latter, which seems to be pl. of badiynN: (Mṣb:) one should not use badanN as a pl. of badanapN; though they used to say xaXabN and OajamN, &c. (M, TA.)
[badaniI-N Of, or relating to, the badan, or body; corporeal.]
[See also baAdinN.]
badiynN: see baAdinN, in four places.

baAdinN, applied to a man, Big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also badiynN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and mubad-anN↓ (M, Ḳ) [and badaniI-N↓]: and fat; as also mubad-anN↓: (T, M:) or heavy in body; heavy by reason of age: and badiynN↓ signifies fat: (Ḥam p. 158:) baAdinN is likewise applied to a woman, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as are also baAdinapN (M, Mgh, Ḳ) and badiynN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mubad-anapN↓: (T, M:) the pl. is bud-anN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and budonN (M, TA) and budunN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) the first of these being pl. of baAdinN, (M, Mṣb,) and so the second; (M;) and the third being pl. of badiynN↓. (Mṣb.) See also badanN.
mubad-anN, and with p {mubad-anapN}: see baAdinN, in three places.
mibodaAnN That becomes fat quickly, with little fodder [or food]. (M, Ḳ.)

1. badahahu, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabodahu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. badoCN, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) He, or it, came upon him, or happened to him, suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (JK, Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also bAdhhu↓, inf. n. mubaAdahapN: (JK, Mṣb:) the former verb has this signification said of an affair, or event. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And badahahu biOamorK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (JK, TA,) signifies Aisotaqobalahu bihi, (JK, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. He met him, or encountered him, with a thing, or an affair, or an action, (TḲ,) suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it: (T, TA:) or he began with him by it, or with it; syn. badaOahu bihi; (Ḳ;) the h being a substitute for the A (TA:) and bAdhhu↓ bihi, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAdahapN and bidaAhN, (Ḳ,) he came upon him suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) with it. (Ḳ.)
See also 2.
2. bd-h, inf. n. tabodiyhN, He answered, or replied, quickly: (IAạr, TA:) and badaha↓ he answered, or replied, or he spoke, extempore; without premeditation. (Ḥar p. 64.)
3: see 1, in two places.
6. huma yatabaAdahaAni biA lX-iEori (Ṣ, TA) They two dispute, or contend together [extemporaneously, or extemporizing, with verses or poetry]. (TA.)
See also 8.

8. Abtdh AlxuTobapa (Ḳ, TA) He extemporized the discourse, or sermon, or oration; spoke it, or composed it, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation. (TA.) And humo yatabaAdahuwna↓ AlxuTaba (Ḳ, TA) They extemporize discourses,, &c.: here the measure tafaAEulN has not its proper quality [of denoting participation in the manner of contention, though it has in a phrase mentioned before]. (TA.)
badohN and budohN: see budaAhapN.
EalaI badiypK, and badiyhFA: see badiyhapN
badaAhapN: see budaAhapN, in two places.

budaAhapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and badaAhapN↓ (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and badiyhapN↓ (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and badohN↓ and budohN↓ (Ḳ) substs. from badahahu biOamorK, (JK, Ṣ,) meaning The first of anything; and an occurrence thereof by which one is taken unawares: (Ḳ:) or the first occurrence of a thing, that happens to one unexpectedly. (M, in explanation of the first word, in art. bdO.)

Also the first (Ṣ, TA) and ↓second (JK) and ↓third (TA) The first part of the running of a horse; (JK, Ṣ, TA;) opposed to EulaAlapN, signifying [the “remaining part of the running,” or “an afterrunning,” or] “a running after a running.” (TA.) You say, huwa cuw badiyhapK↓ waEulaAlapK, and budaAhapK, [He has a first running and an after-running, differing, the one from the other]. (Az, TA.) And laHiqahu fiI budaAhapi jaroyihi [He overtook him in the first part of his running]. (Z, TA.) ISd thinks that in all these cases the h is a substitute for C. (TA.) [Hence,] gamoru Albadiyohapi↓ [properly Fleet in the first part of his running; meaning] ‡ a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA, in art. gmr.)
See also the next paragraph. in three places.

badiyhapN: see budaAhapN, in four places. You say, laka Albadiyhapu, (Ḳ,) in which ISd thinks the h to be a substitute for C, (TA,) It is for thee to begin; (Ḳ;) and so lk AlbudaAhapu↓, with h substituted for C. (M, Mbr, TA art. bdO.) And OajaAba EalaI Albadyhapi (Ḳ) He answered, or replied, on the first of his being taken unawares. (TA.) [EalaI badiyhK↓ is mentioned by Freytag, but on what authority he does not say, as meaning Unpreparedly, suddenly, or unexpectedly; and so badiyhFA↓ by Golius, as on the authority of J, but I do not find it in the Ṣ in the present article.] And raMhu badiyhapF, signifies He saw him suddenly, or unexpectedly. (TA.) And badiyhapu Alr-aOoIi, Suddenly formed, unpremeditated, judgment or opinion. (Mṣb.)
badiyhapN and budaAhapN↓ both signify The coming, of speech, without premeditation: and the coming suddenly, unexpectedly, or unawares. (KL.)

And ↓the latter, [and more commonly the former,] An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; such as that one is the half of two; being, with respect to knowledge, like badiyEN with respect to intellect: (Kull:) [or] the former signifies the faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence: [intuition, or intuitive perception:] accord. to ʼAlee-Ibn-Dháfir El-Haddád, it signifies primarily AirotijaAlN fiI AlkalaAmi [i. e. the faculty of extemporizing: or speaking, or composing, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation]: and predominantly, the poetizing, or versifying, impromptu, without premeditation or consideration: except that ArtjAl is quicker than bdyhp. (TA.) You say, huwa cuw badiyhapK (Ḳ) He has a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence. (TA.) And fulaAnN cuw badiyhapK HasanapK Such a one has a good faculty of extemporizing; or of uttering, or relating, things by means of the promptness of his intelligence. (TA, in art. bdO: see badiyoYapN.) And hecaA maEoluwmN fiI badaAYihi AlEuquwli [This is known among the intuitive notions of intellects; i. e., intuitively]. (Ḳ,* TA.) badaAYihu seems to be pl. of badiyhapN, as in the phrase, (TA,) lahu badaAYihu, i. e. badaAYiEu [He has new, or admirable, things that he utters], (Ḳ, TA,) in speech, or language, and poetry, and in answering, or replying: but here it is not improbable that the h may be a substitute for the E. (TA.)

badiyhiI-N [Intuitive knowledge;] such that its origination does not rest upon speculation, and acquisition by study, whether it do, or do not, require some other thing, as conjecture or experience, &c.; (KT, Kull;) so that it is [sometimes] syn. with DaruwriI-N [and opposed to naZariI-N]: and sometimes it means such as does not require anything whatever after the intellect has directed itself; so that it is more particular than DaruwriI-N: (KT:) as the conception of heat and cold, and the assent of the mind to the position that negation and affirmation cannot be co-existent, nor be simultaneously non-existent, in the same instance. (KT, Kull.)
[And hence,] A mere simpleton or fool: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

rajulN mibodahN (Ṣ) A man possessing in a large degree the faculty of extemporizing, or of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; firm, or steady, in speech or discourse, or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions, when he is taken unawares. (Ḥar p. 64.)

hom.sense: 1. badaA, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yaboduw, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. buduw-N (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and badowN and badaMCN (M, Ḳ) and badaMCapN (Ḳ) and badFA, (M, on the authority of Sb,) for which last we find, in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, buduw-N, a repetition, (TA,) or buduwoCN, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) It appeared; it became apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and tbd-I↓ [signifies the same; or he showed himself, or it showed itself; (see an ex. in art. jyX, voce jaAXa, last sentence;) or] he, or it, came in sight, or within sight. (KL.)

badaA lahu fiI AlOamori, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 665,) inf. n. badowN (M, Ḳ) and badFA (M, and so in a copy of the Ḳ) and badaMCN, (T, M, and so in the CK,) or badaMCapN and badaApN; (as in some copies of the Ḳ;) or badaA lahu fiI AlOamori badaMCN↓, (Ṣ, IB,) the last word being in the nom. case because it is the agent; (IB, TA;) An opinion presented itself, or occurred, to him, or arose in his mind, syn. naXaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥar ubi suprà,) or appeared to him, (M,) [respecting the affair, or case,] different from his first opinion, so that it turned him therefrom: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) or there appeared to him, respecting the affair, or case, what did not appear at first: (Mṣb:) accord. to Fr, badaA liI badaMCN↓ means another opinion appeared to me: accord. to Az, badaA liI badFA means my opinion changed from what it was. (TA.) Esh-Shemmàkh says,
laEal-aka waAlmawoEuwdu Haq-N wafaAWuhu
badaA laka fiI tiloka AlqaluwSi badaMCu
[May-be (but it is right that the promise be fulfilled) an opinion different from thy first opinion hath arisen in thy mind respecting that youthful she-camel]. (M, TA.) vum-a badaA lahumo mino baEodi maA raOawuA QloMyaAti layasojunan-ahu, in the Ḳur [xii.35], means badaA lahumo badaMCN↓ waqaAluwA layasojunun-ahu, [i.e. Then an opinion arose in their minds, after they had seen the signs of his innocence, and they said that they should certainly imprison him,] because lysjnn-h, being a proposition, cannot be the agent: so says Sb. (M.) badaA lil-hi Oano yaqotulahumo, occurring in a trad., means ‡ God determined that He would slay them: for, as IAth says, badaMCN signifies the deeming to be right a thing that is known after its having been not known; and this may not be attributed to God: but as is said by Suh, in the R, one may say, [of God,] badaA lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA, [properly signifying It occurred to him, or appeared to him, that he should do such a thing,] as meaning ‡ He desired to do such a thing; [as also badaA lahu fiI fiEoli kacaA;] and thus the phrase in the trad., here mentioned, has been explained. (TA.) [One says also, AifoEalo kacaA maA badaA laka Do thou thus as long as it seems fit to thee: see, a verse of El-Aḥmar cited voce jal-a.]

badaA Alqawomu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. badowN, (Ṣ,) or badaMCN; (M, Ḳ;) [the latter of which is said in the TA to be the right;] or badaA UilaI AlbaAdiyapi, inf. n. badaAwapN and bidaAwapN; (Mṣb;) The people, or company of men, went forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, the former, went forth to their baAdiyap: (Ṣ:) or went forth from the region, or district, of towns or villages or of cultivated land, to the pasturingplaces in the deserts: (T:) [ISd says,] badowN may be used as meaning bidaAwapN, which is the contr. of HiDaArapN: (M:) [J says,] badaAwapN and bidaAwapN signify the dwelling, or abiding, in the baAdiyap [or desert]; the contr. of HiDaArapN: but Th says, I know not badaAwapN, with fet-ḥ, except on the authority of AZ alone: (Ṣ:) Aṣ says that bdAwp and HDArp are with kesr to the b and fet-ḥ to the H; but AZ says the reverse, i. e. with fet-ḥ to the b and kesr to the H: (T:) both are also explained as signifying the going forth to the baAdiyap: and some mention budaAwapN, with damm; but this is not known: (TA:) tbd-I↓ like wise signifies he went forth from the constant sources of water to the places where herbage was to be sought [in the desert]; (T;) or he dwelt, or abode, in the baAdiyap. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. He who abides in the desert becomes rude, rough, coarse, or uncivil, like the desert-Arabs. (Ṣ.) And in another, kaAna yaboduw UilaI hecihi Alt-ilaAEi [He used to go forth to these water-courses in the desert, or these high grounds, or low grounds,, &c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] badaA He voided his excrement, or ordure; (M, Ḳ;) as also AbdI↓ (T, Ḳ) [and AbdO]: because he who does so goes forth from the tents or houses into the open country. (T.)
badaAniI bikacaA, aor. yaboduw, is like badaOaniI [i. e. He began with me by doing such a thing]. (M, TA.)
badiyati AlOaroDu The land produced, or abounded with, badaAp, i. e. truffles: (Ḳ,* TA:) or had in it truffles. (TḲ.)
And The land had in it badaAp, meaning dust, or earth. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)

entry.sense: 2. bd-I, inf. n. tabodiyapN, He showed, or made apparent, a want that occurred, or presented itself, to him. (TA.) [See bdaMCapN.]
He sent forth a horse [or beast] to the place of pasture [app. in the baAdiyap, or desert]. (TA, from a trad.)
3. mubaAdaApN The going, or coming, out, or forth, in the field, to encounter another in battle, or war. (TA.)

And [more commonly] The showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: (KL, TA:) [a meaning more fully expressed by the phrase mubaAdaApN biAlEadaAwapi: for you say,] baAdaI biAlEadaAwapi He showed open enmity, or hostility, [with another;] syn. jaAhara bihaA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) as also tbAdI↓: (Ḳ:) or you say, tbAdwA↓ bAlEdwAp they showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tajaAharuwA bihaA. (Ṣ.) You say also, bAdI Aln-aAsa biOamorihi He showed, or revealed, to the people, or to men, his affair, or case. (TA.) [Thus, bAdAhu biAlOamori and AbdI↓ lahu AlOamora signify the same; i. e. He showed, or revealed, to him the affair, or case.]
And bAdI bayonahumaA He measured, or compared, them both together, each with the other. (A, TA.)

4. AbdAhu He made it apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, exhibited, manifested, evinced, discovered, or revealed, it; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and it has been said [correctly, as will be seen below,] that AbdI Eanohu signifies the same. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yubodi lanaA SafoHatahu naqama Ealayohi kitaAbu Qll-ehi, i. e. ‡ Whoso showeth, or revealeth, to us his deed [or crime] which he was concealing, [the book of God shall execute vengeance upon him, meaning] we will inflict upon him the punishment ordained by the book of God. (TA.) AbdI lahu SafoHatahu also means ‡ He showed open enmity, or hostility, with him. (A and TA in art. SfH.) And AbdI Eano qaEorihi, said of water, means It showed its bottom, by reason of its clearness. (L in art. mkd.) See also 3.
Oabodayota fiI manoTiqika Thou deviatedst, or hast deviated, from the right way in thy speech. (Ṣ.)
See also 1.

hom.sense: 5. tbd-I: see 1, in two places.
In the common dial. of the people of El-Yemen, it signifies He ate the morning-meal; syn. tagad-aI. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tbAdI: see 3, in two places.
Also He affected to be like, or imitated, the people of the baAdiyap [or desert]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
badK: see badowN, in two places.

hom.sense: badFA The excrement from the anus (M, Ḳ *) of a man. (M.) [And badaMCN, from OabodaOa, signifies the same.]
A joint (mafoSil) of a man; (AA, M, Ḳ;) as also badoCN: (AA, M:) pl. OabodaMCN. (AA, M, Ḳ.)
badaA for badFA: see badowN, in two places.
badowN: see baAdiyapN:
and see also baAdK.

Also The first of a thing; originally [badoCN,] with hemzeh: (Ḥar p. 583:) and badiI-N↓, also, [originally badiIoCN,] signifies the first: (TA:) [and badK↓ and badaA↓, the latter for badFA, are used for badoCK. Hence,] one says, AifoEalo celika baAdiI badK↓, (Ṣ,) or baAdiIa badK, (M, Ḳ,) and baAdiI badiI↓, (Fr, Ṣ, M,) or baAdiIa badiI, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or bAdI badiIK↓, (as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and baAdaIa badFA↓, (M, Ḳ,) mentioned by Sb, who says that it is without tenween, though analogy does not forbid its being with tenween, (M,) meaning Do thou that first; (Ṣ, TA;) or, the first thing: (Fr, TA:) originally [baAdiYa badoCK, &c.,] with hemz. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See badoCN.]) Hence also the phrase, AlHamodulilehi badiy-FA↓ [Praise be to God in the first place]. (TA.)
badaApN: see badaMCN:
and see also baAdiyapN.
Also, (Ḳ, TA,) like qaTaApN, (TA, [but in the CK badoOap, q. v.,]) Truffles; syn. kamoOapN. (Ḳ.)
And Dust, or earth. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: badowapN Either side of a valley. (AḤn, M, Ḳ.)

badawiI-N [Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the badow, or desert: and, used as a subst., a man, and particularly an Arab, of the desert:] a rel. n. from badowN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) extr. [with respect to rule], (M, Ḳ,) for by rule it should be badowiI-N; (El-Tebreezee, TA;) or it is an irregular rel. n. from baAdiyapN: (Mṣb:) and badaAwiI-N↓ and bidaAwiI-N↓ are similar rel. ns., (M, Ḳ,) from badaAwapN and bidaAwapN, as syn. with badowN and baAdiyapN, agreeably with rule; or the former of these two may be a rel. n. from badowN and baAdiyapN, and therefore extr. [with respect to rule]; but it is said that when a rel. n. may be regarded as regular or irregular, it is more proper to regard it as regular; (M;) or the former is a rel. n. signifying of, or belonging to, or relating to, AlbadaAwap as meaning the dwelling, or abiding, in the desert, (Ṣ, TA,) accord. to the opinion of AZ; and the latter is a rel. n. from AlbidaAwap accord. to the opinion of Aṣ and others; and is held by Th to be the chaste form: (TA:) but badawiI-N is the only one of these rel. ns. that is known to the common people: (M:) it is opposed to a townsman or villager. (TA.) [The pl. is badaAwaI, and vulg. bidowaAnN. See also baAdK, often applied to a man as syn. with badawiI-N.]
badawaAtN: see badaMCN, in three places.

badaMCN [An opinion that occurs to one, or arises in the mind; and particularly one that is different from a former opinion;] a subst. from badaA in the phrase badaA lahu fiI AlOamori. (Mṣb.) See 1, in four places. One says also, huwa cuw badawaAtK↓ He is one who has various opinions occurring to him, or arising in his mind, (IDrd, Ṣ,* Ḳ,* and Ḥar p. 665,) of which he chooses some and rejects others: (IDrd, TA:) it is said in praise, (IDrd, TA, and Kzz in Ḥar ubi suprà,) and sometimes in dispraise: (Kzz in Ḥar ubi suprà:) badawaAtN is pl. of badApN↓, [which is therefore syn. with badaMCN,] like as qaTawaAtN is pl. of qaTaApN. (IDrd, TA, and Ḥar ubi supra.) One says likewise Oabuw AlbadawaAti↓, meaning The father [i. e. originator] of opinions that present themselves to him. (IDrd, TA.) And Als-uloTaAnu cuw EadawaAtK wacuw badawaAtK↓ (Ṣ, [in which the context indicates it to mean The Sultán is characterized by deviations from the right way:] but accord. to SM, it is) a trad., meaning the Sultán ceases not to have some new opinion presenting itself to him. (TA.)
bidaMCN, in the common dial. of the people of El-Yemen, signifies The morning-meal; syn. gadaMCN. (TA.)
badiIN: see baAdiyapN:
and see badowN, in three places.
Also, [or biYorN badiI-N,] originally badiIoCN, q. v. in art. bdO, (TA,) A well: (T:) or a well that is not ancient: (TA:) pl. buwdaAnN, formed by transposition from budoyaAnN. (T.)

badaMCapN What appears, or becomes apparent, of wants, or needful things: pl. badaAMtN; for which one may also say, badaAwaAtN. (T.) These two pls. also signify Wants that appear, or become apparent, to one. (TA.) [The latter of them is likewise pl. of what next follows.]
badaAwapN and bidaAwapN: see baAdiyapN.
The former also signifies The first that appears, or becomes apparent, of a thing. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.) [See badaMCapN.]
badaAwiI-N and bidaAwiI-N: see badawiI-N.

baAdK Appearing, or apparent; or becoming, or being, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] baAdiIa Alr-aOoIi At the [first] appearance of opinion; (Fr, Lḥ, M;) or according to the appearance of opinion; (Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ;*) which may mean either insincerely or inconsiderately: (Zj, TA:) so in the Ḳur xi. 29; (Zj, Ṣ;) where only AA read it with hemz: (TA:) if with hemz, it is from badaOotu, and means at first thought, or on the first opinion. (Ṣ; and Lḥ in M, art. bdO: see badoCN.) For baAdiI badK, or baAdiIa badK, and baAdiI badiI, &c., see badowN, in four places.
baAdiI badiI is sometimes used as a name for Calamity, or misfortune: it consists of two nouns made one, like maEodiIo kariba. (Ṣ.)

baAdK also signifies A man going forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) or one who is in the baAdiyap, dwelling in the tents, and not remaining in his place: (TA:) pl. baAduwna and bud-FA [in the TA erroneously said to be budFI like hudFI] and bud-aMCN: (M, Ḳ:) and badowN↓ is a quasi-pl. n. of baAdK; (M, TA;) or is for Oaholu badowK, meaning people who go forth to the desert; (M;) or it means dwellers in the desert, or people of the desert: (MF:) baAdiyapN↓ also signifies the same as baAduwna, i. e. people migrating from the constant sources of water, and going forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; contr. of HaADirapN; and bawaAdiI [or bawaAdK] is pl. of baAdiyapN. (T.)
baAdaApN: see what next follows.

baAdiyapN (T, Ṣ, &c.) A desert; so called because of its being open, or uncovered; (TA;) contr. of HaDarN; (M, Ḳ;) as also badowN↓, (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and baAdaApN↓, (M, Ḳ,) or badaApN↓, (TA, [thought by SM to be the correct form because found by him in the M, in which I find bAdAp,]) and badiI-N↓, said to be used as syn. with baAdiyapN in a verse of Lebeed cited among the exs. of the preposition bi, p. 142, (TA,) and bdaAwapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and bidaAwapN↓; (M;) [of which the last two and the second (namely, badowN,) seem to be originally inf. ns.; see 1:] or a land in which are no towns or villages or cultivated soil: (Lth, T:) or the places to which people migrate from the constant sources of water, when they go forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; also termed mabaAdK, which is syn. with manaAjiEu, contr. of maHaADiru, and pl. of mabodFI↓, (T,) this last signifying the contr. of maHoDarN: (Ṣ:) the pl. of baAdiyapN is bawaAdK. (T, Mṣb.)
See also baAdK.
mabodFI: pl. mabaAdK: see baAdiyapN.
rakiI-N mubodK Wells showing their water; having it uncovered by dust or earth; contr. of rakiIN gaAmidN. (A in art. gmd.)

1. badiytu biAlX-aIoCi and badayotu bihi i. q. [badaOotu and] AibotadaOotu [I began with the thing; or made it to have precedence, or to be first]; (M, Ḳ;) of the dial. of the Ansár: (M:) the people of El-Medeeneh say, badayonaA, or badiynaA, [accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,] in the sense of badaOonaA: (Ṣ:) [the right reading seems to be badayonaA; for] IKh says, none says badayotu in the sense of badaOotu, except the Ansár: all others say, badiytu and badaOotu; when the hemzeh is suppressed, the d is pronounced with kesr, and therefore the hemzeh is changed into I. (IB, TA.) [See a verse of Ibn-Rawáhah cited voce badoCN.]
bidaAyapN, said by Mṭr to be a vulgar word, and by IB to be erroneous, but by IḲṭṭ to be of the dial. of the Ansár: see art. bdO [voce badoCN, second sentence, in two places]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. bac-a, (M,) sec. pers. bacicota, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. yabac-u, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. bacaAcapN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and bucuwcapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and bacacN (M, Mgh, Ḳ) and bacaAcN, (Ḳ,) or bicaAcN, with kesr, (TA,) [of all which, the third is the regular form,] He (a man) was, or became, threadbare, and shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel, (Ks, Ṣ, M, Mgh, L,) and in an evil condition; (M, L, Ḳ;) slovenly with respect to his person: (Ks, M, L:) or he neglected the constant adornment of himself: or he adorned himself one day, and another day left his hair in a shaggy or dishevelled, or matted and dusty, state: (T, L:) or he was humble in his apparel, not taking pleasure therein. (IAth, L.) bacaAcap is said in a trad. to be a part of religion; (Ks, T, M, Mgh, L;) meaning, in this instance, The being humble in dress, and wearing that which is not conducive to self-conceit and pride. (Mgh.)

bac-ahu, aor. yabuc-u, (T, Ṣ, M, L,) inf. n. bac-N (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and baciycapN↓, (Ḳ,) [or this may be a simple subst.,] He overcame him; (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) he surpassed him in goodliness or beauty, or in any deed: (T, L:) he outstripped him. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., bac-a AlqaAYiliyna He outstripped, or surpassed, and overcame, the speakers. (L.)

entry.sense: 3. bAc-hu He hastened with him; made haste, or strove, to be, or get, before him: (Ḳ,* TA:) he vied with him in glory or excellence. (TA.)
8. Abtc- Haq-ahu He took his (i. e. his own) right, or due. (Ḳ.)
10. Astbc- biAlOamori He was alone, with none to share, or participate, with him, in the affair; (Ḳ,* TA;) i. q. Astbd- (Ḳ) and Astql-. (TA.)

bac-N [perhaps from the Persian bado] A man slovenly with respect to his person, and poor. (IAạr, T, L.) And bac-u AlhayoYapi, and baAc-u↓ AlhayoYapi, A man threadbare, and shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel; (Ks, T,* Ṣ, Mgh, L;) and in an evil condition with respect to it; (L, Ḳ;) slovenly with respect to his person: (Ks, L:) or one who neglects the constant adornment of his person: or who adorns himself one day, and another day leaves his hair in a shaggy or dishevelled, or matted and dusty, state: (T, L:) or humble in his apparel, not taking pleasure therein. (IAth, L.)
bac-u Albaxoti A man having evil fortune. (Kr, M, L.)
hayoYapN bac-apN A threadbare, and shabby, or mean, state of apparel. (M.)
HaAlN bac-apN, (Ṣ,) and HaAlapN bac-apN, (TA,) An evil state or condition. (Ṣ, TA.)
tamorN bac-N Dates that are separate, each one from another, not sticking together; like fac-N: (IAạr, M:) or that are scattered. (Ḳ.)
fac-N bac-N Single; sole; that is alone, or apart from others: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and so Oabac-u↓ OaHac-u. (Ḳ.)

fiI hayoYatihi bac-apN, and bacaAcapN, [the latter an inf. n. (of bac-a) used as a simple subst.,] In his state of apparel is slovenliness, and threadbareness, and shabbiness, or meanness. (T.) baciycapN↓, also, (sometimes written bacobacapN↓, TA, and so in the TT but without vowel-signs,) signifies Slovenliness with respect to one's person; or neglect of cleanliness. (T, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baciycapN, or bacobacapN: see bac-apN.
And for the former, see also bac-ahu.
baAc-N: see bac-N.
Also Any one overcoming, or surpassing. (M, L.)

entry.sense: Oabac-N: see bac-N.

hom.sense: 1. bacuWa, (T, M, Ḳ,) with and without C, (Mgh,) aor. _u {yabocuOu}, (T,) inf. n. bacaMCN and bacaMCapN, (M, Ḳ,) the former written in one copy of the Ḳ bacaON, and the latter in some copies written bacoOapN; (TA;) and bacaOa, and baciYa, (Ḳ,) aor. of both _a; (TA;) and some say baciIa, aor. yabocaI, inf. n. bacaMCN; (T;) or, accord. to the Mṣb, only bacaOa is with C, and the others are properly written baciIa and bacuwa; (TA;) He (a man) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or obscene, (T, M, Ḳ, TA,) in tongue; (TA;) evil in speech. (T.) And bacaOa EalaI Alqawomi, aor. _a {yabocaOu}, inf. n. bacoCN and bacaMCN, He behaved in a lightwitted, weak, stupid, or foolish, manner, or ignorantly, towards the people, or company of men; and uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against them; and so though with truth. (Mṣb.)
bacaOa also signifies He was, or became, evil in disposition. (Fr, T.)
And, said of a place, It became devoid of pasture, barren, or unfruitful. (TA.)
baAcaOahu fabacaOahu: see 3.

bacaOahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabocaOu}, (T,) inf. n. bacoCN, (T, Ṣ,) also signifies He dispraised it; discommended it; (T, M, Ḳ;) namely, a thing: (M:) and be despised him: (T, Ḳ:) and he saw in him (a man, Ṣ) a state, or condition, that he disliked, or hated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he did not approve him; and was not pleased with his aspect. (TA.) And bacaOatohu EayoniI, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,*) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, M,) My eye did not approve him, or it; (T, Ṣ;) I was not pleased with his, or its, aspect; (Ṣ;) and I saw in him, or it, a state, or condition, that I disliked. or hated: (T:) or my eye despised, or regarded as of light estimation, him, or it: (M, Mṣb:) accord. to AZ, this is said when a thing has been praised, or greatly praised, to thee, and in thy presence, and then thou dost not see it to be as it has been described: but when thou seest it to be as it has been described, thou sayest, maA tabocaWuhu AlEayoni. (T.) One says also, bacaOa AlOaroDa He dispraised, or discommended, the pasture of the land. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And in like manner, bacaOa AlmawoDiEa (Ṣ) He did not praise the place. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. bAcOhu, (T,) inf. n. mubaAcaOapN, (T, Ḳ,) in some copies of the Ḳ without C, (TA,) and bicaMCN, (T, Ḳ,) [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language: and he held such discourse with him: these significations being indicated by the following exs., and by the saying that] the inf. ns. are syn. with mufaAHaXapN. (T, Ḳ.) You say, baAcaOahu fabacaOahu↓ [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language, and he surpassed him therein: in this case, the aor. of the latter verb is _u, notwithstanding the final faucial letter]. (TA.) And Esh-Shaabee says, Uica EaZumati AlHaloqapu faUin-amaA huwa bicaMCN wanijaMCN [i. e. When the ring of people becomes large, it is only an occasion of holding foul, unseemly, or obscene, and secret, discourse]: it is said that bcMC here signifies mfAHXp: (T:) the meaning is, that there is much bcAC and njAC, i. e. munaAjaAp, therein. (TA in art. njw. [But there, in the place of faUin-amaA huwa, I find fahiIa; and in the TA in the present art., faUin-amaA bihi.])
Also He contended with him in an altercation. (T.)
4. AbcO He uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (TA.)
baciIoCN A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, (T, M, Ḳ, TA,) in tongue; (TA;) evil in speech. (T.) [See also art. bcw.]
A place in which is no pasture: (Ḳ:) and OaroDN baciyoYapN a land in which is no pasture. (Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: 1. bacixa, aor. _a {yabocaxu}, inf. n. bacaxN; (Mṣb;) and bacaxa, [aor. _a {yabocaxu} and _u {yabocuxu}, (see what follows,)] inf. n. bucuwxN; (L;) It (a mountain) was high, or lofty. (L, Mṣb.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) bacixa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabocaxu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bacxN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and bacaxa, aor. _a {yabocaxu} and _u {yabocuxu}, but the former is the more approved, inf. n. bacoxN and bucuwxN; (L;) † He was, or became, proud, and lofty, or haughty; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also tbc-x↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) ‡ he exalted himself above others, (L, TA,) as also tbc-x↓, (A,) by his speech, and his glorying, or boasting. (L, TA.)
And bacaxa, aor. _a {yabocaxu}, inf. n. bacaxaAnN, ‡ He (a camel) brayed in the most vehement manner, (L, TA,) and put forth his XiqXiqap [or faucial bag]. (TA.)
bacaxa, aor. _a {yabocaxu}, inf. n. bacoxN, He split, clave, rifted, slit, or rent, a thing. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 3. bAcxhu † He vied, or competed, or contended, with him in glorying or boasting, or in glory or excellence, or for superiority in nobleness. (L, TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
bicoxN: see baAcixN.
bicixo and bacaxo [for the latter of which, in the CK, we find bacixo,] i. q. baxo [Excellent!, &c.]; (JK, T, Ḳ, TA;) and wonderful! (T, TA.)
bicixo bicixo is also said in chiding a camel that brays in the most vehement manner, (see bacaxa,) or in imitating his braying. (L.)
bacixN: see baAcixN.
bucaAxiy-N Great; syn. EaZiymN. (Ḳ.)
bac-aAxN: see what next follows, in four places.

baAcixN High, or lofty; (JK, A, Mṣb;) applied to a mountain: (JK, Mṣb:) [and] a high, or lofty, mountain; an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (L, TA:) pl. bawaAcixu (JK, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) and baAcixaAtN [both fem. forms]: (JK:) and the former pl. applied as an epithet to mountains. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] rajulN baAcixN, (JK, L,) and bac-aAxN↓, (JK, A, L,) [the latter an intensive epithet,] ‡ A proud, and lofty, or haughty, man, who exalts himself above others, (JK, A, L,) by his speech, and his glorying, or boasting: (JK, L:) pl. of the former bucaxaMCu, like as EulamaMCu is pl. of EaAlimN, and buc-axN. (L.) You say, In speech, he is bac-aAxN↓; and in poetry, baAcixN. (L.)
And XarafN baAcixN ‡ High, or exalted, nobility. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

baEiyrN baAcixN, (L,) and bac-aAxN↓, (L, Ḳ,) or bac-aAxu↓ Alhadiyri, (A,) and bicoxN↓, and bacixN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ A camel that brays much, (Ḳ,) or in the most vehement manner, (L,) and puts forth his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag]. (Ḳ.)
bayocaxN A large-bodied, or corpulent, woman; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bayodaxN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. bacara, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yabocuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bacorN, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He sowed seed; (Ṣ, TA;) he cast grain upon the ground to sow it; (Mṣb;) he cast grain upon the ground, scattering it; (A;) he scattered seed (T, MF) upon the ground; as also bc-r↓, [but app. in an intensive sense,] (MF,) inf. n. tabociyrN (T, MF) and tabocirapN: (T:) this is the primary signification. (MF.)
Also, (M,) inf. n. as above, (M, Ḳ,) He sowed land; (M, L, Ḳ;) and so bc-r↓, (M, L,) inf. n. tabociyrN. (L, Ḳ.)
Also, (M,) inf. n. as above, (M, Ḳ,) He scattered, or dispersed, (M, Ḳ,) a thing; (M;) and so bc-r↓, [or rather he scattered, or dispersed, much,] inf. n. tabociyrN. (Ḳ.)
bacara Qll-ehu Alxaloqi, (M, A,) inf. n. as above, (M,) God scattered, or dispersed, mankind (M, A) in the earth. (A.)

bacara AlkalaAma ‡ He disseminated, scattered, or diffused, talk, or speech, (Mṣb, TA,) bayona Aln-aAsi among the people, or mankind, like as seed is scattered: (TA:) and bc-rhu↓ he did so much. (Mṣb.)
bacarati AlOaroDu, (M, A,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (M, Ḳ,) ‡ The land put forth its plants, or herbage, (Aṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) in a scattered state: (Aṣ, M, A:) or put forth its bacor. (M.)
bacura, aor. _u {yabocuru}, inf. n. bacaArapN, ‡ He divulged what was secret; he revealed what he had heard. (T, L.)
bacira, [aor. _a {yabocaru},] inf. n. bacarN, He talked much; was loquacious. (M.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in four places.

bc-r, inf. n. tabociyrN, also signifies He was extravagant in expenditure; and so bAcr↓, inf. n. mubaAcarapN: (TA:) or the former, he dissipated, or squandered, (his wealth, or property, Ṣ, M, and any other thing, M, TA,) by extravagant expenditure, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and destroyed, consumed, wasted, or ruined, it: (M, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, jar-abahu is here put for xar-abahu: in the M it is Oafosadahu:]) or he expended his wealth, or property, so largely as not to leave of it that whereby he might subsist: or he expended it in acts of disobedience: (TA:) or he dissipated, or squandered, his wealth, or property, in a way that was not right: (Mṣb:) or in a way that did not behoove: it includes the meaning of Oasorafa in common, or conventional, acceptation, and is used in the proper sense of this latter verb: or, as some say, tabociyrN denotes excess in respect of the right objects of expenditure, which is ignorance of the [right] manner, and of things that should prevent it; and UisoraAfN denotes excess with respect to quantity, and is ignorance of the values of the right objects. (MF.) [See also bacaAr-apN.]
3: see 2.
5. tbc-r It became scattered or dispersed; or much scattered or dispersed. (A.)
‡ It (talk, or speech,) became much disseminated or scattered or diffused. (Mṣb.)

bacorN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and bucorN↓, (M,) the former either an inf. n. used as a proper subst. or of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Mṣb,) Grain that is set apart for sowing; (Lth, M, Ḳ;) any seed, or grain that is sown; as also bizorN or bazorN: (Kh, Mṣb:) or grain such as wheat, that is sown; distinguished from bzr, which is applied to the seed of sweet-smelling plants and of leguminous herbs: and this distinction commonly obtains: (Mṣb:) or [so accord. to the M, but in the Ḳ “and,”] the first that comes forth, of seed-produce and of leguminous and other plants, (M, Ḳ,*) as long as it has but two leaves: (M:) or bacorN signifies any plant, or herbage, when just come forth from the earth: (M:) or such as has assumed a colour, (M, Ḳ,) or shown its kind or species: (M:) pl. bucuwrN and bicaArN. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] bacorN signifies also ‡ Progeny; (T, M, Ḳ;) and so bucaArapN↓. (M, Ḳ.) One says, Oin-a heWulaMCi labacoru sawoCK ‡ Verily these are a progeny of evil, or an evil progeny. (T, A.*)
bucorN: see bacorN.

tafar-aquwA Xacara bacara and Xicara bicara↓ They dispersed, or became dispersed, in every direction: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [namely, men: and] the like is said of a man's camels: (Ṣ:) bcr is an imitative sequent to Xcr: (Ṣ:) some say that the b in the former is a substitute for m [in macara or micara]; but others hold that in each case the word is an original. (TA.)
bacirN: see tibocaArapN.

Also, (M, Ḳ,) and bayocaArN↓ and bayocaArap↓ and tibocaArN↓ and bayocaAraAniy-N↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ A man who talks much; loquacious; (M, Ḳ;) and so hucarapN bucarapN↓ (IDrd, M) and hayocaArapN bayocaArapN↓: (M:) irrationally, or vainly, or frivolously, loquacious; a great babbler. (TA.)
See also bacuwrN.
TaEaAmN bacirN [Wheat, or food,] in which is bucaArap, i. e. increase, redundance, exuberance, plenty, or abundance. (T,* M, L, Ḳ.*)
Xicara bicara: see Xacara bacara, above.
hucarapN bucarapN: see bacirN.
Albucur-aI What is false, vain, or ineffectual; syn. AlbaATilu: (Seer, M, L, Ḳ:) [like AlHucur-aI:] the radical idea denoted by it is that of dispersion. (M, L.)

bacuwrN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and baciyrN↓ (M, Ḳ) ‡ A man who divulges secrets; (Ṣ, M, A;) as also bacirN↓, of which the fem. is with p {bacirapN}: (L:) or one who cannot keep his secret: (T, Ḳ:) pl. of the first bucurN. (T, Ṣ, M.)
Also, both the first and second, ‡ A calumniator; a slanderer: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the former as above. (TA.)

hom.sense: baciyrN is [said to be] an imitative sequent to kaviyrN; (M, Ḳ;) like baviyrN, of which it is [held to be] a dial. var., or a corruption occasioned by mispronunciation. (Fr, Ṣ.) [But I think it is more probably syn. with mabocuwrN↓, as signifying Scattered, or dispersed, like naviyrN in the sense of manovuwrN, &c.; and that for this reason it is used as a corroborative of kvyr.]
See also bacuwrN.

entry.sense: bacaArapN: see bacaAr-apN.
bucaArapN Increase, redundance, exuberance, plenty, or abundance, in wheat, or food. (Lḥ,* T,* M, L, Ḳ.*) You say, TaEaAmN kaviyru AlbucaArapi Wheat, or food, in which is much increase,, &c. (T, TA.)
See also bacorN.

bacaAr-apN, and sometimes bacaArapN↓, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) and yabocarapN↓, (AA,) and nabocarapN↓, with n, (T, Ḳ,) i. q. tabociyrN, (M, Ḳ,) The dissipating, or squandering, of wealth, or property, in a way that is not right. (T, TA.)
bayocarapN: see what next precedes.
bayocaraAniI-N: see bacirN.
baycaArN: see bacirN.
bayocaArapN: see tibocaArapN:
and see also bacirN, in two places.
tibocaArN: see bacirN.

tibocaArapN A man who dissipates, or squanders, his wealth, or property, by extravagant expenditure, and consumes, destroys, wastes, or ruins, it; (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also mubac-irN↓ and mubaAcirN↓ and bcirN↓ and bayocaArapN↓. (TA.)
mubac-irN: see what next precedes.
OaroDN mibocaArN Aln-abaAti [or more probably mibocaArN liln-abaAti] ‡ Land that yields increase. (A.)
mabocuwrN: see baciyrN.
‡ Many; much; abundant: (Ḳ, TA:) water that is abundant; or blessed with abundance, plenty, or increase. (A.)
mubaAcirN: see tibocArapN.
nabocarapN: see bacaAr-apN.
bacoqN: see bayocaqN, in two places.

baAcaqN (Mgh, Ḳ) and baAciqN↓ (Ḳ) [in my copy of the Mṣb erroneously written bAcyq] a Persian word, arabicized; originally baAdaho, which signifies Wine: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or juice of grapes cooked in the least degree, so as to be strong (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and intoxicating; an arabicized word; (Mṣb;) said to have been introduced by the Benoo-Umeiyeh, (TA,) and to have been unknown to the Prophet; (Mgh;) but there is a trad. of I’Ab which is understood to mean that the Prophet forbade what is thus called: (Mgh, TA:) some assert it to mean that it existed not in his time; (TA;) but this latter assertion is weak. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: baAciqN: see above.
It is also an imitative sequent to HaAciqN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: bayocaqN [meaning A pawn] in the game of chess is from bayaAcaqapN↓; (TA;) which latter signifies footmen, as opposed to horsemen, (AO, Ḳ, TA,) and is an arabicized word, from the Persian, (AO, TA,) originally PiyaAdaho: (TA:) the pl. of bycq is bayaAciqu; for which a poet uses bucuwqN, as though he suppressed the I [in the sing.], making bycq to become bacoqN↓: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) or, accord. to El-Khárzenjee, (JK, TA,) bacoqN↓ signifies a guide in a journey; as also bayocaqN: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) or [in the CK “and”] small and light or active: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as in the Tekmileh, (TA,) short and light or active: (JK, TA:) and its pl. is bucuwqo. (JK, Ḳ.)
bayaAciqapN: see bayocaqN.

1. bacalahu, aor. _u {yaboculu} (Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yabocilu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. bacolN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He gave it, and was liberal, or bountiful, with it; he gave it liberally, bountifully, unsparingly, or freely; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) he gave it willingly, of his own free will or good pleasure: (TA:) and he made it allowable, or lawful, to be taken or possessed or done, willingly, or of his own free will or good pleasure: (Mṣb:) bacolN is the contr. of manoEN. (M.) [Hence,] saOalotuhu faOaEoTaAniI bacola yamiynihi I asked him, and he gave me what he was able to give. (TA.) [And bacala lahu nafosahu. † He gave up himself to, or spent himself for, him or it; he gave, or applied, himself, or his mind, unsparingly to it, namely, an undertaking, &c.: a phrase of frequent occurrence. And bacala jahodahu, and majohuwdahu, † He exerted, or put forth, or expended, unsparingly, or freely, his power, or ability, or his utmost power or ability or endeavour: also of frequent occurrence.] And farasN lahu SawonN wabacolN ‡ A horse that reserves a portion of his run, and is unsparing with a portion thereof; not putting forth the whole at once: (TA:) or that has a run which he reserves [for the time of need], and a run which he performs unsparingly: (A in art. Xhd: see XaAhidN:) and farasN cuw SawonK waQboticaAlK↓ a horse that has a running pace (HuDorN) which he has reserved for the time of need, and a run (EadowN) less quick which he has performed freely, or without reservation (qadi Qbotacalahu). (T.) [In the Ḳ these phrases are given in a mutilated state, and with a mutilated explanation.] And Sawonuhu xayorN mino bacolihi ‡ His interior state, or disposition of mind, is better than his apparent state, &c. (TA.)
See also 8.

5. tbc-l He neglected the preserving of himself or his honour or reputation [from disgrace]; i. q. taraka Alt-aSaAwuna (Ṣ) or Alt-aSaw-una; (TA;) he was careless of himself or his honour or reputation; contr. of taSaAwana; (Mṣb in the present art,;) as also Abtcl↓. (Mṣb in art. Swn.) You say, karuma walamo yatabac-alo [He was generous, and was not careless of his honour or reputation]. (M and L in art. wfr.)
tbc-l fiI Eamali kacaA, and Abtcl↓ nafosahu fiyhi and bihi, He employed his own self in the doing of such a thing. (T.)

8. AiboticaAlN is the contr. of SiyaAnapN; (M, Ḳ;) [i. e.] Abtclhu signifies He held it in mean estimation; namely, a garment or other thing; (TA;) [he was careless of it; he used it, or employed it, on, or for, ordinary, mean, or vile, occasions, or purposes;] he used it for service and work; namely, a garment, &c.; syn. Aimotahanahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) he wore it (a garment) in times of service and work; as also bacalahu↓; (Mṣb, TA;) or, as IḲooṭ says, bacalahu, [aor. _u {yaboculu} and _i {yabocilu},] inf. n. bacolapN and bicolapN, signifies he did not preserve it, lay it up, take care of it, or reserve it; namely, a garment. (Mṣb.) See also 5, in two places. You say also, Abtcl Eadowahu † [He (a horse) performed his run freely, or without reservation; opposed to SaAnahu]. (T.) See 1.

10. Astbclhu He sought, or demanded, of him a liberal, free, or willing, gift. (TA.) And Aisotabocalotu fulaAnFA XayoYFA I asked of such a one that he would liberally, freely, or willingly, give me a thing. (T.)
bacolN A thing that is given liberally, freely, or willingly: and inf. n. [or 1, q. v.], used as a proper subst.: pl. bucuwlN. (Ḥar p. 206.)
bacolapN: see what next follows, in two places.

bicolapN A garment that is worn (T, Ṣ, Mṣb) in service, or work; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) that is not preserved, laid up, taken care of, or reserved; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also bacolapN↓ (Mṣb) and mbocalN↓, (T,) or mibocalapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the pl. of which is mabaAcilN: (Ṣ:) and an old and worn-out garment; (TA;) as also mibocalN↓ and mibocalapN↓; (M, Ḳ;) the last of which is mentioned on the authority of AZ, but is disapproved by ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh, who asserts it to be without p: (IB, TA:) bicolapN sometimes has bicalN as pl. (TA.) You say, jaMCa naA fulaAnN fiI mabaAcilih↓, i. e. fiI viyaAbi bicolatihi or bacolatihi↓ [Such a one came to us in his garments that he wore in service, or work]. (Ṣ, accord. to different copies. [I have shown that bicolapN and bacolapN are dial. vars., both as inf. ns. (see 8) and as proper substs.]) The word badolapN, with fet-ḥ, and with the unpointed d, applied by the vulgar to [a suit of] new clothes, is a mistake for bicolapN, and this is correctly a name for old and worn-out clothes. (TA. [But this is doubtful; for badolapN commonly signifies, in modern Arabic, a change of clothes; and hence, a suit of clothes, whether new or old.])

IJ uses it metaphorically, in relation to poetry; saying, Alr-ajazu Uin-amaA yusotaEaAnu bihi fiI Albicolapi waEinoda AlAiEotimaAli waAlHudaMCi waAlmihonapi ‡ [The metre termed rejez is only used as an aid in the ordinary, or meaner, business of life, and on the occasion of doing one's work, and singing to camels for the purpose of urging them on, and performing service of any kind: but in this case it may be regarded as an inf. n.: see 8]. (M.)
bacuwlN: see bac-aAlN.
bacaAlapN i. q. bacolN [inf. n. of 1, The act of giving liberally,, &c.]. (TA.)

bac-aAlN A man wont to give property liberally, freely, or willingly; or who so gives it much, or frequently; as also bacuwlN↓ (T, TA) [and app. mibocaAlN↓, (like misomaAHN, &c.,) of which the pl. occurs in the following saying]. humo mabaAciylu↓ lilomaEoruwfi [They are very liberally disposed to the exercise of beneficence, or bounty]. (TA.)
baAcilN Any one who gives [liberally,] freely, or willingly. (M.)
mibocilN: see bicolapN, in two places.

mubotacalN Held in mean estimation: as in the saying, maAluhu maSuwnN waEiroDuhu mubotacalN [His wealth is preserved, or taken care of, and his honour, or reputation, is held in mean estimation]. (TA.)
† Language, and a proverb, which one is wont to speak or mention, or which one is fond of speaking or mentioning. (TA.)

fulaAnN Sadoqu Almubotacali Such a one is strong, or sturdy, in the work in which he employs himself: (T:) or sharp, vigorous, or effective, in nature, or disposition; one who, when employed in a work, is found to be strong, or sturdy. (TA.) And sayofN Sadoqu Almubotacali ‡ A sword sharp, or penetrating, in the part with which one strikes. (Ḳ, TA.)

mubotacilN, (Ḳ,) or mutabac-ilN↓, (M, [so in a copy of that work, accord. to the TT, but this is probably a mistranscription,]) Wearing a mibocal, i. e. [a garment used in service or work, or] an old and worn-out garment: (M, Ḳ:) and the latter, [if not a mistranscription for the former,] neglecting the adorning of himself, by way of humility. (TA, from a trad.)
See also what follows.
mutabac-ilN (T, M, Ḳ) and mubotacilN↓ (M, Ḳ) A man who employs his own self in doing a thing; (T;) a man who performs his own work. (M, Ḳ.)
See also what next precedes.

1. bacuwa, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yabocuw, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. bacaMCN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bacaMCapN, (Ḳ,) or the latter is the original form, but the p is elided, as in jamaAlN, inf. n. of jamula, (Ṣ,) or bacaMCapN is an inf. n. of the verb with C, but that of bcw is bacaMCN; (IB;) and some say, baciIa, (T,) which is a dial. var. of the former, (Mṣb,) aor. yabocaI, inf. n. bacaMCN; (T in art. bcO;) He (a man) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or obscene [in tongue]; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) evil in speech; (T in art. bcO;) as also bacuWa, (T, M, Ḳ, in that art.,) and bacaOa, (Mṣb and Ḳ in art. bcO,) and baciYa: (Ḳ in that art.:) and AbcI↓ he uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (TA.) And bacawotu EalaI Alqawomi, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabocuwu}, inf. n. bacaMCN; (Mṣb;) and Oabocayotu↓ Ealayohimo, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) or Oabocayotuhumo, (M, IB, Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) I uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against the people, or company of men: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) or behaved in a lightwitted, weak, stupid, or foolish, manner, or ignorantly, towards them; and uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against them; and so though with truth. (Mṣb.) And bacaA also signifies He (a man) was, or became, evil in disposition. (TA.)

3. bAcI, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. mubaAcaApN, (TA,) [He vied with another, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language: or he held such discourse with another:] the inf. n. is syn. with mufaAHaXapN. (TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
bacaMCN [inf. n. of 1, used as a subst,] Foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

baciIN, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or baciIN All-isaAni, (Ṣ,) A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue: (T, Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) or lightwitted, weak, stupid, or ignorant, in behaviour; and foul, unseemly, or obscene, in speech; and so though speaking truth: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {baciIapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and pl. OabociyaMCu. (T.)

hom.sense: 1. bar-a, [first pers. barirotu,] aor. yabar-u, (T, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. bir-N, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He was pious [towards his father or parents, and ‡ towards God; (see the explanations of the verb as used transitively;) and was kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and kind, or good, in his dealings with strangers]: (Mṣb:) he was good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (T, Mṣb:) [or he was amply, largely, or extensively, good or beneficent:] and he was true, or veracious. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Authorities differ as to the primary signification of this verb, and as to the subordinate meanings: see bir-N below.] You say also, bar-a fiI qawolihi, (Mṣb, TA,) and fiI yamiynihi, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. barirotu (T, A, Mgh, Ḳ) and bararotu, (Ḳ,) aor. yabar-u (M, Mṣb) and yabir-N, (M,) inf. n. bir-N (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and bar-N, (Ḳ,) or buruwrN, (Mṣb,) He was true, or veracious, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in his saying, (Mṣb, TA,) and in his oath. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

bar-a Eamalahu, and bur-a, inf. n. bir-N and buruwrN; and Oabar-a↓; [His deed, or work, was, or proved, good; or was well, or sinlessly, performed;] all signify the same. (M.) And bur-a AlEamalu, i. e. AlHaj-u, a form of benediction, said to a person come from pilgrimage, May the deed, or work, i. e. the pilgrimage, have been sinlessly performed. (TA.) And bar-a Haj-uhu, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yabar-u, (T,) inf. n. bir-N (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or buruwrN; (T;) and bur-a Haj-uhu, (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yubar-u, inf. n. bir-N; (T;) His pilgrimage was sinlessly performed: (Sh, T:) or was characterized by the giving of food, and by sweetness of speech; as explained by Moḥammad himself: was accepted: was rewarded. (TA.)

bar-a, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yabar-u (T, M, Ḳ) and yabir-u, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. bir-N (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bar-N and buruwrN, (M, Ḳ,) It (a saying, Mṣb, and an oath, T, A, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) was, or proved, true. (M, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA.) [See an ex. voce Oaliy-apN, in art. Alw.]

bar-ato biI siloEatuhu, inf. n. bir-N, ‡ His commodity, or article of merchandise, was easy of sale to me, (Aboo-Saʼeed, T, A,*) and procured me gain: (A:) originally meaning it recompensed me, by its high price, for my care of it. (T.) [See also bar-ahu, below.]

bar-a waAlidahu, (M,) [and app. biwaAlidihi, (see bar-N,)] first pers. barirotu (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bararotu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yabar-u (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and yabir-u, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. bir-N (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mabar-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb *) and buruwrN, (Mṣb,) He treated, or behaved towards, his father with filial piety, duty, or obedience; (TA;) or with ample obedience; (B;) the inf. ns. signifying the contr. of EuquwqN: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) he treated, or behaved towards, his father with good obedience, and with gentleness, or courtesy, striving to do the things that were pleasing to him, and to avoid what were displeasing to him. (Mṣb.) And [hence, app., for accord. to the A it is tropical.] bar-a xaAliqahu, (Ṣ,) or rab-ahu, (A,) aor. yabar-u, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. bir-N; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and tbr-rhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) ‡ He obeyed his Creator, or his Lord; (Ṣ, M,* A, Ḳ;*) [was pious towards Him;] served Him; rendered religious service to Him: (TA:) or rendered Him ample obedience: the obedience here meant is of two kinds; namely, that of belief and that of works; and both these kinds are meant by Albir- in the Ḳur ii. 172. (B.) [And app. bar-ato waladahaA, or biwaladihaA, She behaved with maternal affection towards her child, or offspring. (See bar-N.)] And bar-ahu, (M,) and bar-a raHimahu, (T,) first pers. barirotu, (T, M,) inf. n. bir-N, (T, M, Ḳ,) He behaved towards him, and towards his kindred, or relations, with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his, or their, circumstances; syn. waSalahu [and waSalahumo]: (T, M, Ḳ:) such is said to be the signification of the verb as use in the Ḳur lx. 8. (M, B, TA. [See also 3.]) And Aall-ehu yabar-u EibaAdahu † God is merciful to his servants: (M, TA:) or bar-ahu, inf. n. bir-N, said of God, means He recompensed him, or rewarded him, for his obedience. (B, TA.) [bar-ahu bikacaA (occurring in the Ṣ and Ḳ in explanation of OaloTafahu bikacaA) may be rendered He showed kindness,, &c., to him by such a thing, or such an action,, &c.: and also he presented him with such a thing; like waSalahu bikacaA.]

bar-a Qll-ehu Haj-ahu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yabar-u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bir-N, (Ṣ,) or buruwrN, (Mṣb,) God accepted his pilgrimage; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also Abr-hu↓: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) the latter alone is allowed by Fr: (M, TA:) [though bur-a Haj-uhu and Eamaluhu, mentioned above, are well known; as is the pass. part. n. maboruwrN, which see below:] and one says, [in like manner,] Abr-↓ Qll-ehu Eamaluhu [God accepted his deed, or work, as good; approved it]. (M.)
See also 4, in three places.
bar-a, (TḲ,) inf. n. bir-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He drove sheep or goats: (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he called them. (Yoo.) [See also bir-N below.]

entry.sense: 3. bAr-hu, inf. n. mubaAr-apN, He behaved towards him with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances; or he did so, experiencing from him the same behaviour; syn. of the inf. n. mulaATafapN. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. lTf: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned. [See also 1.])

hom.sense: 4. Abr- Eamaluhu: see 1.
Abr- Haj-ahu, and Eamalahu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

Abr- Alqawola, (Mṣb,) and Alyamiyna, (T, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He executed, or performed, the saying, and the oath, truly. (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Accord. to El-Aḥmar, one also says, barirotu↓ qasamiI; but none other asserts this. (T, TA.)
Abr- fulaAnN qasama fulaAnK Such a one assented, or consented, to the conjurement of such a one: OaHonavuhu signifies “he assented not,” or “consented not, thereto.” (T, TA.)

Abr- Ealayohimo, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (T, TA,) He overcame them: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) he subdued them, or overcame them, by good or other actions; (TA;) by actions or sayings; (TA;) as also bar-ahumo↓, aor. yabur-u: (T, Ḳ, TA:) he was refractory, or stubborn, and overcame them. (TA, from a trad.) You say, Abr- EalaI xaSomihi [He overcame his adversary]. (A.) And Abr- Ealayohimo Xar-FA [He overcame them in evil]: and hence Abr- is used in the sense of fajara [he transgressed,, &c.]; as in the saying of a poet,
falasotu OubaAliI mano Oabar-a wamano fajaro
[Then I care not who acts wickedly and who transgresses]. (IAạr, M.)
Abr- [from bar-N] He rode, or journeyed, upon the land. (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Opposed to OaboHara. (A.)
5. tbr-r [He affected, or endeavoured to characterize himself by, bir-, i. e. filial piety,, &c.].
qado tabar-arota fiI OamorinaA Thou hast abstained from crime, or sin, or the like, in our affair, or business, or case. (T, TA.)
tbr-r xaAliqahu: see 1.

entry.sense: 6. tbAr-wA They practised mutual bir- [meaning kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for each other's circumstances]. (Ṣ.)

R. Q. 1. barobara, inf. n. barobarapN, He talked much, and raised a clamour, or confused noise, (M, Ḳ,) with his tongue: (M:) he cried, or cried out, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and talked in anger, (Ṣ,) or talked confusedly, with anger and aversion. (TA.) And barobara fiI kalaAmihi He was profuse and unprofitable in his talk. (Fr.)
Also, inf. n. as above, He (a goat) uttered a cry or cries, [or rattled,] (M, Ḳ,) being excited by desire of the female. (M.)

hom.sense: bar-N [originally barirN] (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAr-N↓ (Mṣb) Pious [towards his father or parents, and ‡ towards God; ‡ obedient to God, serving God, or rendering religious service to God; (see 1;) and kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and good in his dealings with strangers]; good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (Mṣb:) true, or veracious: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and both signify also abounding in bir- [or filial piety,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) the former is [said to be] a stronger epithet than the latter, like as EadolN is stronger than EaAdilN: (B:) [but its pl. shows that it is not, like EadolN, originally an inf. n.: it is a regular contraction of barirN, like as baAr-N is of baArirN:] the fem. of each is with p: (Lḥ, M:) the pl. (of the former, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, or of the latter, B) is OaboraAN; and (of the latter, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, or of the former, B) bararapN: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the former pl. is often specially applied to saints, those who abstain from worldly pleasures, and devotees; and the latter, to the recording angels. (B.) You say, OanaA bar-N biwaAlidiI, and baAr-N↓, I am characterized by filial piety, dutifulness, or obedience, to my father: (Ṣ, M, A:*) the latter is mentioned on the authority of Kr; but some disallow it. (M, TA.) And AlOum-u bar-apN biwaladihaA [The mother is maternally affectionate to her child, or offspring]. (Ṣ.) And rajulN bar-N biciI qaraAbatihi, and baAr-N↓, A man who behaves towards his kindred with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for their circumstances. (T.) And rajulN bar-N sar-N A man who treats with goodness and affection and gentleness, and rejoices, or gladdens, his brethren: pl. bar-uwna sar-uwna. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA, in art. sr.) And bar-N fiI qawolK, and fiI yamiynK, and baAr-N↓, True, or veracious, in a saying, and in an oath. (Mṣb.) And yamiynN bar-apN and baAr-apN↓ [A true oath; or an oath that proves true]. (Ḥam p. 811.) Albar-u is also a name of God; (M, Ḳ;) meaning † The Merciful, or Compassionate: (M:) or the Very Benign to his servants; (IAth;) the Ample in goodness or beneficence: (B:) AlbaAr-u is not so used. (IAth.) It is said in a trad., tamas-aHuwA biAlOaroDi faUin-ahaA bar-apN bikumo † Wipe yourselves with the dust, or earth, [in performing the ceremony termed Alt-ayam-umu,] for it is benignant towards you, like as the mother is to her children; meaning, ye are created from it, and in it are your means of subsistence, and to it ye return after death: (IAth:) or the meaning is, that your tents, or houses, are upon it, and ye are buried in it. (M.)

bar-N Land; opposed to baHorN [as meaning “sea” and the like]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) from bir-N signifying “ampleness,” “largeness,” or “extensiveness;” (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF;) or the former word is the original of the latter. (B, TA. [See the latter word.]) [Hence, bar-FA wabaHorFA By land and by sea.]

A desert, or deserts; a waste, or wastes. (T, TA. [See also bar-iy-apN, voce bar-iy-N.]) So, accord. to Mujáhid [and the Jel] in words of the Ḳur [vi. 59], wayaEolamu maA fiI Albar-i waAlbaHori And He knoweth what is in the desert, or deserts, and the towns, or villages, in which is water, (T, TA,) or which are upon the rivers. (Jel.) [So too in the phrase nabaAtu Albar-i The plants, or herbage, of the desert or waste; the wild plants or herbage. And Easalu Albar-i Honey of the desert; wild honey. And HayawaAnu Albar-i The animal, or animals, of the desert; the wild animal or animals.]
A wide tract of land. (Bḍ in ii. 41.)
[The open country; opposed to baHorN as meaning the “cities,” or “towns,” “upon the rivers:” see the latter word.]
Elevated ground, open to view. (T.)

The tract, or part, out of doors, or where one is exposed to view; contr. of kin-N: used by the Arabs indeterminately; [without the article Al;] as in the phrase, jalasotu bar-FA (Lth, T) meaning I sat outside the house; (A;) and xarajotu bar-FA (Lth, T) meaning I went forth outside the [house or] town, (A,) or into the desert: (TA:) but [Az says,] these are post-classical phrases, which I have not heard from the chaste-speaking Arabs of the desert. (T.)
You say also, Oariydu jaw-FA wayuriydu bar-FA I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A.)

entry.sense: bur-N Wheat; and the grain of wheat; syn. qamoHN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) or HinoTapN; (M, Ḳ;) but it is a more chaste word than qamoHN and HinoTapN: (M:) pl. of bur-apN; (Ṣ, M;) or [rather] bur-apN is the n. un. [signifying a grain of wheat, like qamoHapN]: (IDrd, Mṣb:) the pl. of bur-N is OaboraArN; (Ḳ;) or this pl. is allowable on the ground of analogy, accord. to Mbr, but is disallowed by Sb. (Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., (TA,) huwa OaqoSaru mino br-apK [He, or it, is shorter than a grain of wheat]. (A, TA.) And you say, OaToEmanaA Qbona bur-apK He fed us with bread. (A.)
bir-N inf. n. of 1: (T, Ṣ, M, &c.:) it is said by some to signify primarily Ampleness, largeness, or extensiveness; whence bar-N as opposed to baHorN: then,

Benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct [to parents and others; i. e. piety to parents; and ‡ towards God]: and goodness, or beneficence: and kindness, or good and affectionate and gentle behaviour, and regard for the circumstances of another: (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF:) or bar-N, as opposed to baHorN, [or as signifying “a wide tract of land,” (Bḍ in ii. 41,)] is the original of bir-N, (Bḍ in ii. 41, B, TA,) which signifies ample, large, or extensive, goodness or beneficence, (Z, in the Ksh, ii. 41, [but he regards it as the original of bar-N,] and Bḍ on the same passage, and B, Ḳ, TA,) to men; (TA;) or comprehending every kind of goodness: (Ksh and Bḍ ubi suprà:) and hence it is said to be in three things: in the service of God: in paying regard to relations; acting well to them: and in dealing with strangers: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) or every deed that is approved: (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 172:) and [particularly] obedience to God: (T, Ṣ, M, &c.: [see also bar-apu:]) [and every incumbent duty: and hence,] the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (Ḳ:) and fidelity to an engagement: (TA:) also a gratuitous gift, or favour; and a bounty, or benefit; syn. faDolN; (Mṣb;) and UiHosaAnN; as also mabar-apN↓ [an inf. n., but when used as a simple subst. its pl. is mabaArN and mabar-aAtN]. (Ḥar p. 94.) In the Ḳur [ii. 172], where it is said, lukin-a Albir-a mano Mmana biQll-ehi, by Albr- is meant caA Albir-i [i. e. But the pious, or obedient to God, is he who believeth in God]; (T, M, Ksh, Bḍ, Jel;) and some read AlbaAr-a: (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel:) or the meaning is, lkn- Albir-a bir-u mn Mmn bAll-eh i. e. but the obedience of which it behooveth one to be mindful is the obedience of him who believeth in God: (Sb, T, IJ, M, Ksh, Bḍ:) and this explanation is preferable to the former. (Bḍ.)
It is said in a prov., (T, Ṣ,) laA yaEorifu hir-FA mino birK, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, but in the T and M maA is put in the place of lA,) meaning He knows not him who dislikes him, or hates him, from him who behaves towards him with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,* TA:) or undutiful conduct to a parent from gentleness, or courtesy: (El-Fezáree, T, Ḳ:) or altercation, (T,) or dislike, or hatred, (Ḳ,) from honourable treatment: (T, Ḳ:) or the calling of sheep, or goats, from the driving of them: (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the driving of sheep, or goats, from the calling of them: (Yoo, T:) or the calling of them to water from the calling of them to fodder; (Ḳ;) which last rendering is agreeable with an explanation of bir-N by IAạr [mentioned in the T]; (TA;) and birobirN↓, also, has the signification here assigned to bir-N: (Ḳ,* TA:) or Alharoharap from Albarobarap; (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ;) i. e. the crying of sheep from the crying of goats: (AʼObeyd, T:) or the cat from the rat, or mouse: (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ:) and bir-N also signifies the [species of rat called] jurac: (Aboo-Tálib, T, Ḳ:) or a small animal resembling the rat or mouse: (M:) and the young of the fox. (Ḳ.)

Also Good, as a subst., not an adj.; syn. xayorN; (Sh, T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which comprises all that has been said in explanation of bir-N (Sh, T, Mgh) as used in the saying of Moḥammad, Ealyokumo biAlS-idoqi faUin-ahu yahodiI UilaI Albir-i [Keep ye to truth; for it guides to good, or to a good, or right, state]: some render it in this instance by Alxayor; and some, by AlS-alaAH. (Sh, T.) It signifies also The good of the present life, consisting in spiritual and worldly blessings, and of that which is to come, consisting in everlasting enjoyment in Paradise: so in the Ḳur iii. 86: (T:) or [simply] Paradise. (Ḳ.)
Also The heart; or the mind. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, huwa muTomaYin-u Albir-i [He is quiet, or at rest, in heart, or mind]. (TA.)

[bariyrN a coll. gen. n.] The fruit of the OaraAk [q. v.], (Ṣ, M,) in a general sense: (M:) or the first thereof; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] the first that appears, or when it first appears, and is sweet: (M:) or when it has become hard: (Mṣb:) or when it is larger in its berries (Hab-) than such as is termed kabaAv, and smaller in its clusters; having a round, small, hard stone, a little larger than the Him-aS; its cluster filling the hand: (AḤn, M:) n. un. with p {bariyrapN}. (AḤn, Ṣ, M, Mṣb.)
bur-aI A good, sweet, or pleasant, word or expression or saying: (Ḳ:) from bir-N signifying “benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct.” (TA.)
[bar-iI-N Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the land as opposed to the sea or a great river.]
[And Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the desert or waste; growing, or living, or produced, in the desert or waste; wild, or in an uncultivated state.]

[And hence,] OaroDN bar-iy-apN Uncultivated land; without seed-produce, and unfruitful; without green herbs or leguminous plants and without waters; contr. of riyfiy-apN. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.*) And, simply, bar-ay-apN↓, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bar-iytN↓, (AʼObeyd, IAạr, Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter a variation of the former, the I being made quiescent, and the p therefore being changed into t, as in EiforiytN, originally EiforiyapN, (Ṣ,) a rel. n. from bar-N, (Sh, T, Mṣb,) A desert; a waste; a spacious tract of ground without herbage; syn. SaHoraMCu: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see also bar-N:] or a tract nearer to the desert (Albar-) than it is to water: (Sh, T:) [but some write the latter word bir-iytN↓; and it is said that] bir-iytu, (T and Ḳ in art. brt,) of the same measure as sik-iytN, (Ḳ in that art.,) signifies flat, even, or level, land: (T, Ḳ:) or a barren, flat, even, or level, land: a poet says,
bir-iytu OaroDK baEodahaA bir-iytu
[A barren, flat land, after which is a second barren, flat land]: (T:) ISd says that bir-iytN, in a poem of Ru-beh, [from which the ex. given above is probably taken,] is of the measure fiEoliytN from Albar-u; and that art. brt is not the place in which it should be mentioned: (TA:) Lth says, Albar-iytu is a noun derived from Albar-iy-apu; the I becoming quiescent, and the p becoming an inseparable t, as though it were a radical letter, as in the case of EiforiyapN, which thus becomes EiforiytN: (T, TA:) the pl. of br-y-p is baraAriI-u; and that of br-yt is baraAriytu. (Ṣ.)
bar-iy-apN and bar-iytN and bir-iytN: see bar-iI-N.
bar-aArN as signifying A possessor of bur-, i. e. wheat, though agreeable with prevailing analogy, is not allowable, not being sanctioned by usage. (Sb, M.)

bar-aAniI-N External; or outward: apparent; public. (T.) Hence the saying of Selmán, (T,) mano OaSolaHa jaw-aAniy-ahu OaSolaHa Qll-ehu bar-aAniy-ahu (T, A, Ḳ) Whoso maketh his inner man (sariyratahu) to be good, God will make his outward man (EalaAniyatahu) to be good. (T.) bar-aAniI-N is a rel. n., irregularly formed, (Ḳ,) from bar-N signifying “elevated ground, open to view;” and jaw-aAniI-N, from jaw-N signifying “any low, or depressed, part of the ground.” (T.) You say, AfotataHa AlbaAba Albar-aAniI-a He opened the outer door. (A.)

barobaru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Albarobaru, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [a coll. gen. proper name, of which the n. un., or rel. n., is barobariI-N↓,] a foreign word, (Ṣ,) [probably of African origin, the primary form of which is the source of Βάρβαρος, &c.,] arabicized; (Mṣb;) or, as some say, from barobarapN in speech; (TA; [see R. Q. 1;]) and AlbaraAbirapu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the pl. of barobaru, (Ḳ,) or of Albarobaru, (Mṣb,) [or of barobariI-N, agreeably with what follows and with analogy,] the p being added because the sing. is a foreign word, or [so in the M and TA, but in the Ṣ “and,”] a rel. n., (Ṣ, M,) but it may be elided; [so that one may say AlbaraAbiru;] (Ṣ;) A certain people, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the inhabitants of El-Maghrib [or Northern Africa west of Egypt], (Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) like the Arabs of the desert in hardness, and coarseness, or rudeness, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) and in slightness of religion, and littleness of knowledge: (Mgh:) and another people, [the Colobi mentioned by Diodorus Siculus and Strabo,] between the Abyssinians and the Zinj, who amputate [the glans of] the penis, and make it a dowry for a wife. (Ḳ.) [There are various opinions of the origins of these races. The appellation of AlbaraAbirapu, sing. barobariI-N↓, is also applied by late historians, and in the present day, to The races inhabiting the portion of the valley of the Nile which we commonly call Nubia.]
buroburN: see barobaArN.
birobirN: see bir-N.
barobariI-N: see barobaArN:
and see also barobaru, in two places.

barobaArN One who talks much, and raises a clamour, or confused noise, (M, Ḳ,) with his tongue: (M:) who cries, or cries out, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and talks in anger, (Ṣ,) or talks confusedly, with anger and aversion: (TA:) who vociferates much; (TA;) as also buroburN↓: (Ḳ:) and barobariI-N↓ signifies one who talks much and unprofitably. (Fr.)
AlbarobaAru The lion; as also Almubarobiru↓: (Ḳ:) because of the confused noise that he makes, and his aversion and anger. (TA.)
dalowN barobaArN A bucket that makes a noise (M, Ḳ) in the water. (M.)
burobuwrN What is termed jaXiyX [i. e. coarselyground flour,, &c.], (M, CK, [in MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, and of the Ṣ also, HaXiyX, which is evidently a mistranscription,]) of wheat. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
baAr-N and its fem. with p {baAr-apN}: see bar-N, in five places.

hom.sense: Oabar-N [accord. to analogy signifies More, and most, pious, &c.: see bar-N. But the only meaning that I find assigned to it in any of the lexicons is that here following.]

More, and most, distant in the desert, (T, Ḳ,) as to habitation. (T.) So in the saying, OafoSaHu AlEarabi Oabar-uhumo The most chaste in speech of the Arabs are the most distant of them in the desert, as to habitation. (T, Ḳ.* [In the latter, instead of AfSH, we find OaSolaHu.])

entry.sense: mubir-N One who overcomes. (TA.) [See 4.]
Uin-ahu lamubir-N bicelika means Verily he is a prudent, or sound, manager of that; syn. DaAbiTN lahu. (M, Ḳ.*)
mabar-apN: see bir-N.

maboruwrN, applied to a pilgrimage, Sinlessly performed: (Sh, T, Mgh:) or characterized by the giving of food and by sweetness of speech; as explained by Moḥammad himself: accepted: rewarded. (TA.) maboruwrN maOojuwrN [Thou art accepted, or approved, and rewarded] and maboruwrFA maOojuwrFA [Go thou accepted, or approved, and rewarded] are forms of benediction:
the former, of the dial. of Temeem; Oanota being understood: the latter, of the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz; Aicohabo being understood. (M.)
Applied to a sale, Truly and honestly executed. (Sh, T, Mgh.)
Almubarobiru: see barobaArN.

hom.sense: 1. bariYa, [aor. _a {yaboraOu}, inf. n. generally buroCN or baraMCapN,] He was, or became, clear, or free, of, or from, a thing; in the manners which will be explained below: (Bḍ ii. 51:) he was, or became, in a state of freedom or immunity, secure, or safe. (T.)
