[Hence,] bariYa mina AlmaraDi, and baraOa, (T, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaboraOu} and baruWa, aor. _u {yaboruOu}; (Mṣb;) inf. n. buroCN: (T, Mṣb:) or bariYa mn AlmrD, inf. n. buroCN, with damm; and the people of El-Ḥijáz say baraOa, inf. n. baroCN, with fet-ḥ: (Ṣ:) accord. to Aṣ, bariIa mn AlmrD is of the dial. of Temeem; and baraOa of the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz: or, accord. to AZ, the people of El-Ḥijáz say baraOa; and the rest of the Arabs say bariYa: (T:) or baraOa [alone], said of a sick man, aor. _u {yaboruOu} and _a {yaboraOu}; and bariYa; and baruWa; inf. n. baroCN [probably a mistranscription for buroCN] and buruWN: or, accord. to Lḥ, the people of El-Ḥijáz say baraOa, aor. _u {yaboruOu}, inf. n. buroCN and buruWN [i. e. buruwoCN]; and the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, [baraOa,] aor. _a {yaboraOu}, inf. n. buroCN and buruWu; and Temeem, bariYa, [aor. _a {yaboraOu},] inf. n. buroCN and buruWN: (M:) or baraOa, (Ḳ,) said by IḲṭṭ to be the most chaste form, (TA,) aor. _a {yaboraOu}, (Ḳ,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and _u, (Ḳ,) said by Zj to be the only instance of a verb of the measure faEala with C for its last radical letter having its aor. of the measure yafoEulu, [though others mention also qaraOa, aor. yaqoruWu, and hanaOa, aor. yahonuWu,] and asserted to be a bad form, (TA,) inf. n. buroCN and buruwoCN; and baruWa, (Ḳ,) not a chaste form, (TA,) aor. _u {yaboruOu}; and bariYa, (Ḳ,) a chaste form, (TA,) [and the most common of all,] aor. _a {yaboraOu}, inf. n. baroCN and buruWN, (Ḳ, TA,) or buroCN, (CK,) and buruwoCN; (Ḳ, TA;) He became free from the disease, sickness, or malady: (T:) or [he recovered from it:] he became convalescent; or sound, or healthy, at the close of disease, but was yet weak; or he recovered, but not completely, his health and strength; syn. niqaha; (M, Ḳ;) i. e., he acquired that slight degree of soundness, or health, which comes at the close of disease, but with disease remaining in him. (TA.) [And bariYa Aljuroju, or baraOa, The wound healed; or became in a healing state: of frequent occurrence.] And bariYa mina AlOamori, [the only form of the verb used in this case, and in the other cases in which it is mentioned below,] aor. _a {yaboraOu} and _u {yaboruOu}, the latter extr., (M, Ḳ,) or rather it is very strange, for IḲooṭ says that naEima, aor. yanoEumu, and faDila, aor. yafoDulu, are the only instances of this kind, (TA,) inf. n. baraMCapN (M, Ḳ) and baraMCN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and buruWN, (M,) or buroCN, (Ḳ, TA,) or buruwoCN; (CK;) and tbr-O↓; (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ, Mgh;*) [He was, or became, free from the thing, or affair; or clear, or quit, thereof; clear of having or taking, or of having had or taken, any part therein; guiltless of it: and also, irresponsible for it; as in an ex. q. v. voce EiDaADN:] said in relation to [a fault or the like, and] a debt, and a claim, and religion [&c.]. (Lḥ, M.) You say, bariYa mina AlEayobi, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or AlEuyuwbi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. baraMCapN, (Mgh,) He was, or became, free (Mṣb) [from the fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice], (Mgh, Mṣb,) [or faults,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) And bariYa mina Ald-ayoni, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) or Ald-uyuwni, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaboraOu}, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. baraMCapN, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) He was, or became, clear, or quit, of the debt; (or debts; Ṣ;) irresponsible for it [or them]: or in a state of immunity with respect to it [or them]; i. e., exempt from the demand thereof. (Mṣb.) And barYa Uilayoka mino Haq-ika, inf. n. baraMCapN and baraMCN (Lḥ, M) and buruWN, [He was, or became, clear, or quit, to thee, of thy claim, or due, or right; or exempt from the demand thereof;] as also tbr-O↓. (M.) And bariYotu Uilayoka mino fulaAnK, inf. n. baraMCpN, [I was, or became, or have become, clear, to thee, of having or taking, or of having had or taken, any part with such a one; or, irresponsible to thee for such a one:] (AZ, T, Ṣ:* [in one copy of the Ṣ, I find the phrase bariYotu minoka, commencing the art.; but not in other copies:]) this is the only form of the verb used in this case, and in relation to debt [and the like]. (AZ, T.)

He removed himself, or kept, far, or aloof, [from unclean things, or things occasioning blame; followed by mino, with which it may be rendered he shunned, or avoided;] syn. tanaz-ahu and tabaAEada. (T.) [You say, bariYa mina AlOaqocaAri He removed himself, or kept, far, or aloof, from unclean things.]

He manifested an excuse, [or asserted himself to be clear or quit or irresponsible, like tbr-O↓,] and gave warning; syn. OaEocara and Oanocara. (T.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ix. 1], baraMCapN mina Qll-ehi warasuwlihi A manifestation of excuse, and a warning, from God and his apostle. (T.)

baraOa Qll-ehu Alxaloqa, (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or Alxaliyaqapa, (Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaboraOu}, (T, M, &c.,) inf. n. baroCN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and buruwoCN, (AZ, Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) God created mankind, or the beings, or things, that are created, syn. xalaqa, (Fr, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) after no similitude, or model, (TA,) [but, properly, though not always meaning so, out of pre-existing matter; for] Bḍ says [in ii. 51] that the primary meaning of the root brC is to denote a thing's becoming clear, or free, of, or from, another thing; either by being released [therefrom], as in bariYa AlmariyDu mino maraDihi and Almadoyuwnu mino daynihi [both sufficiently explained above]; or by production [therefrom], as in baraOa Qll-ehu Mdama mina AlT-iyni [God produced, or created, Adam, from, or out of, clay]. (TA.) This verb relates to substances [as in the exs. given above] and to accidents; and hence, [in the Ḳur lvii. 22,] mino qboli Oano naboraOahaA [Before our creating it, if hA refer to muSiybap, preceding it; but, as Bḍ says, it may refer to this, or to AlOaroD, or to Oanofus]: (M:) but AlbaroCu has a more particular application than Alxaloqu; the former being particularly applied to the creation of animate beings, with few exceptions: you say, baraOa Qll-ehu Aln-asamapa waxalaqa Als-amewaAti waAlOaroDa [God created, or produced, man, or the soul, and He created the heavens and the earth]. (TA.) [To this verb, or perhaps to baraI, or to both, בָרָא is the Hebrew equivalent, properly (though not necessarily always) signifying “he created out of pre-existing matter,” or “he fashioned.”]

entry.sense: 2. br-Ohu, inf. n. taborYapN: see 4, in four places. [Hence,] laA Alt-aboriYapi The lA that denies in a general manner, absolutely, or to the uttermost; i. e. the lA that is a universal negative. (Mughnee, &c.)
Also He verified his being free [from a thing], clear, or quit, [of it,] guiltless [of it], or irresponsible [for it]. (Mgh, TA.)

3. bArOhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAraOapN (T, M, Mgh) and biraMCN, (M,) He made him (his copartner) free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, the latter doing to him the same: (Mgh:) he compounded, or made a compromise, with him (his hired man, T, M) for their mutual separation: (M:) he separated himself from him (his copartner, Ṣ, O), the latter doing the same. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And baAraOotu Alr-ajula I became free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, to the man, he becoming so to me. (M.) And bArO AlmaroOapa, (T, M, Ḳ,) or QmoraOatahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He compounded, or made a compromise, with the woman (or his wife, Ṣ) for their mutual separation; (M, Ḳ;) i. e. he divorced her for a compensation [which she was to make him, such as her giving up a portion of her dowry remaining due to her, in order that they might be clear, each of the other]: it occurs also [without C] in art. brI. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AbrOhu He (God, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [recovered him, or] restored him to convalescence, (M, Ḳ,) mina AlmaraDi [from the disease, sickness, or malady]. (Ṣ.)

OaboraOaka mina AlOamori and bar-aOaka↓ (M, Ḳ *) He (i. e. God, TA) made thee, pronounced thee, or held thee, or hath made thee,, &c., or may He make thee,, &c., to be free from the thing or affair, or clear or quit thereof, or guiltless thereof, or irresponsible for it; (TA;) [or He acquitted thee, or hath acquitted thee, or may He acquit thee, thereof; or He showed thee, or hath showed thee, or may He show thee, to be free from it,, &c.: see also 2, above:] said in relation to [a fault or the like, and] a debt, and a claim, and religion [&c.]. (M.) You say, bar-aOotuhu↓ mina AlEayobi I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be free from the fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 69], fabar-aOohu↓ Qll-ehu mimaA qaAluwA (M) But God showed him to be clear of that which they said. (Bḍ.) You say also, OaboraOotuhu mina Ald-ayoni I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of the debt; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e., exempt from the demand thereof: (Mṣb:) and OaboraOotuhu mim-aA liI Ealayohi; and bar-aOotuhu↓, inf. n. taboriYapN; [I acquitted him of that which he owed me:] (Ṣ:) and OaboraOotuhu [alone] I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of a claim that I had upon him, or a due or right that he owed me. (Mgh.)
AbrO [in the T (as on the authority of Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee) OaboraI] He entered upon [the night, or day, called] AlbaraMC, q. v. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in three places. tbr-O minohu also signifies He asserted himself to be free from it; or clear, or quit, of it; namely, a fault, or the like. (Mgh.) [And He declared himself to be clear of him; to be not connected, or implicated, with him; he renounced him: see Ḳur ii. 161 and 162, &c.:]
6. tabaAraOonaA We separated ourselves, each from the other. (TA.) [See 3.]

10. AstbrO, (T,) or AstbrO mina Albawoli, (Mṣb,) He took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the orifice of his penis from the remains of urine, by shaking it and pulling it and the like, until he knew that nothing remained in it: (T:) or he purified, or cleansed, himself from urine; syn. tanaz-ahu Eanohu: (Mṣb:) or AstbrO, (M,) or AstbrO Alc-akara, (Ḳ, TA,) signifies he took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the penis from urine; or he cleansed it entirely from urine; (M,* Ḳ,* TA;) and so AstbrO Alfaroja: and in like manner, AstbrOti Alfaroja said of a woman: (El-Munáwee, TA:) but the lawyers make a distinction between AsotiboraMCN and AisotinoqaMCN [which are made syn. in the M and Ḳ]: see the latter word. (TA.)

And AstbrO AljaAriyapa, (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) or AlmaroOapa, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He abstained from sexual intercourse (T, M, Ḳ) with the girl whom he had purchased or whom he had taken captive, (T,) or with the woman, (M, Ḳ,) until she had menstruated (T, M, Ḳ) at his abode, once, and then become purified: (T:) the meaning is, (T,) he sought to find her free from pregnancy. (T, Mgh, Mṣb.)

Hence, (Mgh,) AstbrO AlX-ayoCi, (Z, Mgh, Mṣb,) or AlOamora, (TA,) He searched, searched out, or sought to find or discover, the uttermost of the thing, or affair, (Z, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) in order that he might know it, (Mgh,) to put an end to his doubt. (Z, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) You say, AisotaboraOotu maA Einodaka [I searched, or sought to find or discover, or I have searched,, &c., the uttermost of what thou hast, of knowledge, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.) And AstbrO OroDa kacaA famaA wajada DaAl-atahu [He searched the uttermost of such a land and found not his stray beast]. (TA.) It is said in the Expos. of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer that AisotiboraMCN is an expression denoting The seeking, or seeking leisurely and repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of a thing, until one knows it; considering it with the endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of it; taking, in doing so, the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or good judgment. (Mgh.)

buruOapN A hunter's lurking-place or covert: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. buraON. (T, Ṣ, M.) El-Aạshà says,
bihaA buraON mivolu Alfasiyli Almukam-ami
[At it (a source of water mentioned in the context) were hunters' lurking-places, like young palmtrees covered over: for tender young palm-trees are often covered over with a kind of coarse matting]. (T, Ṣ, M.)
baraMCN: see bariIoCN, in six places.

AlbaraMCN The first night of the [lunar] month; (El-Mázinee, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) called thus, (Ṣ,) or layolapu AlbaraMCi, (M,) because the moon has then become clear of the sun: (Ṣ, M:) or the first day of the month: (AA, T, Ḳ:) or the last night thereof: (Aṣ, T, Ḳ:) or the last day thereof; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) a fortunate day; every event happening therein being regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing; (IAạr, T;) but most hold that the last day of the month is termed Aln-aHiyrapN; (TA;) as also Aibonu AlbaraMCi: (Ḳ:) or this is the first day of the month: (IAạr, T, TA:) pl. OaboriYapN. (Th, M.)
buraMCu: see bariIoCN, in two places.

bariIoCN Free, (Mṣb,) minohu from it; namely a fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and, also followed by minohu, clear, or quit, of it; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e. exempt from the demand thereof; namely a debt, (Mṣb,) or a claim, or due, or right; (Mgh;) as also baAriIN↓ and baraMCN↓. (Mṣb.) You say, OanaA bariIoCN minohu [I am free from it,, &c.]; (T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ;*) and baraMCN↓, used alike as sing. and dual and pl. (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and masc. and fem., (Fr, T, M, Ḳ,) because it is originally an inf. n.; (Fr, T, Ṣ;) and buraMCN↓: (Ṣ, M:) the pl. of bariIoCN is bariyWuwna (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and buraOCu (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and buraMCN, (T, M, Ḳ,) of the measure fuEaAlN, (T,) like ruxaAlN, (M, Ḳ,) of an extr. measure, disapproved by Suh, who says, in the R, that it is a contraction of buraOCu, and has tenween because it resembles [words originally of the measure] fuEaAlN, and that the rel. n. formed from it is buraAwiI-N↓, (TA,) but it is mentioned by AAF as a pl. of bariIoCN, and as being like ruxaAlN, and Fr mentions buraMCu as a pl. of the same, imperfectly decl., with one of the two hemzehs suppressed, (M,) and biraMCN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OaboraMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaboriYaMCu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last two anomalous: (TA:) the fem. of bariyoCN is bariyoYapN; pl. bariyoMtN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and bariy-aAtN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and baraAyaA. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) You say, OanaA bariIoCN minohu and xaliI-N minohu [I am free from it; or, more commonly, I am clear, or quit, of it, or him]; and OnaA baraMCN↓ minohu and xalaMCN minohu; (Ṣ;) and OanaA AlbaraMCu↓ minohu: (M:) and naHonu minoka AlbaraMCu↓ and AlxalaMCu [We are clear, or quit, of you]; (Fr, T;) i. e., cawuw AlbaraMCi: so says Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ; and Aṣ says the like of what Fr says. (T.) It is said in the Ḳur [xliii. 25], Uin-aniI baraMCN↓ mim-aA taEobuduwna [Verily I am clear of that which ye worship]; (T, M;) or bariIoCN, or buraMCN↓; accord. to different readers. (Bḍ.) bariIoCN occurs in several places in the Ḳur. (M.) Accord. to IAạr, it signifies Clear of evil qualities or dispositions; shunning what is vain and false; remote from actions that occasion suspicion; pure in heart from associating any with God: and it signifies sound in body and intellect. (T.) See also baAriYN, in two places.

baraMCapN A writing of [i. e. conferring] immunity or exemption: from bariYa mina Ald-ayoni and AlEayob, of which it is the inf. n.: pl. baraAMtN, with medd: baraAwaAtN is [pl. of baraApN, and both of these are] vulgar. (Mgh.)
buraAwiI-N: see bariIoCN.

Albariy-apu The creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created; or, particularly, mankind; syn. Alxaloqu: (T, Ṣ, M:) pronounced without C; (T, Ṣ;) originally with C, like nabiI-N and cur-iyapN; (M;) and the people of Mekkeh differ from the other Arabs in pronouncing these three words with C: (Yoo, T, M:) Lḥ says that the Arabs agree in omitting the C in these three instances; and he does not except the people of Mekkeh: (M:) it is of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of mafoEuwlapN, (Mṣb,) from baraOa Qll-ehu Alxaloqa, meaning xalaqahumo: (Fr, T:) or, if derived from AlbaraI [“earth” or “dust”], it is originally without C: (Fr, T, Ṣ:) pl. baraAyaA and bariy-aAtN. (Ṣ in art. brw and brI.)

hom.sense: baAriYN, (Ḳ,) or baAriYN mino maraDihi, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M,) [Recovering from his disease, sickness, or malady: or] convalescent; or becoming sound, or healthy, at the close of his disease, but being yet weak; or recovering, but not completely, his health and strength: [see 1:] (M, Ḳ:) as also bariYoCN↓: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ:) but whether the latter be properly used in this sense is disputed; while the former is said to be the act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses: (TA:) pl. biraMCN, (M, Ḳ,) like as SiHaAHN is pl. of SaHiyHN, accord. to Lḥ, so that he holds it to be pl. of bariIoCN; or it may be pl. of baAriYN, like as jiyaAEN is pl. of jaAYiEN, and SiHaAbN of SaAHibN. (M.) bariIoCN↓ is sometimes written and pronounced bariI-N [in all its senses]. (Ḳz.)
See also bariyoCN.

AlbaAriYu, applied to God, The Creator; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) He who hath created the things that are created, not after any similitude, or model; (Nh;) or He who hath created those things free from any incongruity, or faultiness, (Mgh, and Bḍ in ii. 51,) and distinguished, one from another, by various forms and outward appearances: (Bḍ:) or the Former, or Fashioner; syn. AlmuSaw-iru [q. v.]. (M.)

entry.sense: barobaxN The passage, or conduit, of water, called Uirodab-ap and baAluwEap [q. v.], made of baked clay: (Ḳ:) or baraAbixu [the pl.] signifies the baked-clay conduits of privies, which convey [the water, &c.] from the house-top to the ground. (Ṣ, but omitted in some copies.)
brobaxu Albawoli The canal of the urine [from the kidney to the bladder; i. e. the ureter]: (L, KL, TA:) of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

burovunN, of the lion, (AZ, T,) and of any animal of prey, (AZ, Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of birds, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) [The toe; i. e.] what corresponds to the UiSobaE of a man; (AZ, Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) [in the Lex. of Golius, as on the authority of the Ṣ, and in that of Freytag, idem quod Anmlp in homine; but this is a mistake, app. occasioned by a mistranscription in a copy of the Ṣ;] and the mixolab is its claw, i. e., nail: (AZ, Aṣ, T, Ṣ:) or the paw (kaf-), (M, Ḳ,) altogether, (M,) with the OaSaAbiE [or toes]: (M, Ḳ:) or the claw, i. e. nail, of the lion, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) likened to the instrument for perforating leather; (Lth, T;) and of [all] animals of prey, and of birds that do not prey, corresponding to the Zufor of man: Th says, of man, it is [termed] the Zufor; of animals having the kind of foot called xuf-, the manosimo; of solidhoofed animals, the HaAfir; of cloven-hoofed animals, the Zilof; of beasts and birds of prey, the mixolab; and of birds that do not prey, and of dogs and the like, the burovun; though it may be also used [in like manner] of all animals of prey: (Mṣb:) [but properly] it is of birds that do not prey, as the crow-kind, and the pigeon; (M;) and sometimes, of the [lizard called] Dab-, (Ṣ, M,) and of the rat, or mouse, and of the jerboa: (M:) and is, in the pl. form, (M, TA,) which is baraAvinu, (T, Ṣ, M, TA,) metaphorically applied, by Sá'ideh Ibn-Jueiyeh, to the fingers of a man gathering honey [deposited by wild bees in a hollow of a rock]. (M,* TA.)
burovunu AlOasadi also signifies † A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels, (Ḳ, TA,) in the form of the claw of the lion. (TA.)
This, also, is the name of a sword of Marthad Ibn-'Alas. (Ḳ.)

[burovunapN seems to signify the same as burovunN or baraAvinu: for] Temeem are termed in a trad. the burovumap and burojumap of the tribes of Mudar; and El-Khaṭṭábee says that it should be the burovunap, i. e. † [The claw, or] the claws; meaning thereby their impetuous valour, and strength: but brvmp may be a dial. var. of brvnp, or the m may be substituted for the n for the purpose of assimilation [to brjmp]. (TA.)

1. barija [written in the TA without the vowel-signs, but the context seems to show that it is thus, and that the inf. n. is barajN] It (anything) was, or became, apparent, manifest, or conspicuous, and high, or elevated: whence burojN, applied to a certain kind of structure. (TA.)
barija, [aor. _a {yaboraju},] inf. n. barajN, [also signifies] He had that quality of the eye which is termed barajN, explained below. (M, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or barija Oamoruhu, (TA,) aor. _a {yaboraju}, His state, condition, or case, became ample in respect of eating and drinking. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 4.
4. Abrj He (a man, TA) built a buroj [or tower,, &c.]; as also br-j↓, inf. n. taboriyjN. (Ḳ.)

5. tabar-ajato She (a woman) showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and beauties of person or form or countenance, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) to men, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to strangers, or men distantly related to her; (Mṣb;) to do which is culpable; but to do so to the husband is not: (TA:) or she showed her face: or she showed the beauties of her neck and face: or she did so exhibiting a pretty look: (TA:) or she showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and what excites a man's lust. (A boo-Is-ḥáḳ, TA.) Fr, referring to verse 33 of ch. xxxiii. of the Ḳur, says that in the time when Abraham was born, the women used to wear a shirt of pearls, not sewed at the two sides; or, as some say, they used to wear garments which did not conceal their persons. (TA.)

burojN [Gr. πύργος, (Golius,) A tower;] an angle, syn. rukon, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a fortress, (Ṣ,) or of a city: (TA:) and sometimes a fortress itself: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called from its conspicuousness and construction and height: (TA: [see 1:]) or the primary signification of brj is strength; whence Oaboraju in a sense explained below: (Ḥar p. 286:) pl. [of mult.] buruwjN and [of pauc.] OaboraAjN: (Ṣ:) the buruwjN of the wall of a city or fortress are chambers (buyuwt [meaning towers]) built upon the wall: and such chambers (bywt) built upon the sides of the angles of a qaSor [i. e. pavilion or palace, &c.] are sometimes thus called. (Lth.) [Hence,] buroju HamaAmK [A pigeon-turret; a pigeon-house; being generally constructed in the form of a turret, or of a sugar-loaf;] a lodging-place of pigeons: pl. as above. (Mṣb.)

Also † [A sign of the Zodiac;] one of the buruwj of the heaven; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which are twelve in number; every one having a distinct name: (TA:) the Arabs in ancient times did not know them: (Ḥam p. 560:) pl. OaboraAjN as well as buruwjN: (Mṣb, TA:) these are meant by the buruwj mentioned in the Ḳur xv. 16 and xxv. 62 and lxxxv. 1: (Bḍ, Jel:) or in the last of these instances, (Bḍ,) by the brwj in the heaven are meant the Mansions of the Moon: (Bḍ, Mṣb:) or the stars or asterisms or constellations: (TA:) or the great stars or asterisms or constellations; (Bḍ, Mṣb;) and so, accord. to Zj, in the second of the said passages of the Ḳur: (TA:) or the gates of heaven: (Bḍ, Mṣb:) or, as some say, i. q. quSuwr [i. e. pavilions, &c.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: barajN Such a constitution of the eye that the white entirely surrounds the black, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) no part of the black being concealed: (Ṣ, M:) or width of the eye: or width of the white of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball, and beauty of the black part: or clearness of the white and black parts theeeof: (M, TA:) or width of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball: (Ḥam p. 560:) or width of the eye with intense whiteness of the person: (TA:) and distance between the eyebrows. (L, TA.) [See also balajN.]
Goodly, elegant, or pretty; beautiful of face: or [so in copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, but in the CK “and”] shining, or splendid; conspicuous; and well known. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xuluqN baArijN A large, or liberal, disposition; syn. waAsiEN. (Ḥam p. 560.)

hom.sense: OaboraAjN A man having that quality of the eye which is termed barajN: (M, TA:) fem. barojaMCu; applied to a woman; (Ṣ) and also to an eye (EayonN) having the quality termed barajN: (M, TA:) pl. burojN. (Ḥam p. 560.)
hecaA Oaboraju mino hecaA This is stronger than this. (Ḥar p. 286.)

entry.sense: UiboriyjN The vessel, or receptacle, [generally a skin,] in which milk is churned, or beaten and agitated, or in which the butter of the milk is extracted, or fetched out, by putting water in it, and agitating it; syn. mimoxaDapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

vawobN mubar-ajN A garment whereon are figures of buruwj [or towers]: (Zj, TA:) or whereon are depicted figures resembling the buruwj [or towers] of the wall of a city or the like: (T, A, TA:) or figured with eyes, of the garments termed HulalN; from Albaraju (Ṣ.)

burojumapN (in the Ḥam p. 352 burojumN) is the sing. of baraAjimu (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and burojumaAtN; (T, TA;) and signifies [A knuckle, or finger-joint;] the outer, or the inner, joint, or place of division, of the fingers: and (as some say, TA) the middle toe of any bird: (Ḳ:) or baraAjimu signifies all the finger-joints; (AʼObeyd, Ḳ;) as also rawaAjimu [a mistranscription for rawaAjib]: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or the parts of the fingers that are protuberant when one clinches his hand: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) or the backs of the finger-bones: (Ḳ:) or the finger-joints (Ṣ, Mgh) that are between the OaXaAjiE and the rawaAjib; (Ṣ;) i. e. (Ṣ, Mgh) [the middle knuckles; (see OaXojaEu and raAjibapN;)] the heads of the sulaAmayaAt, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) on the back, or outer side, of the hand, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which become protuberant when one clinches his hand: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, as in the Kf, the heads of the slAmyAt; and their inner and outer sides are termed the rawaAjib: (Mṣb:) accord. to the T, the wrinkled parts at the joints of the fingers; the smooth portion between which is called raAjibapN: or, as in another place, in the backs of the fingers; the parts between them being called the rawaAjib: in every finger are three burojumaAt, except the thumb: or, as in another place, in every finger are two of what are thus termed: it is also explained as signifying the joints in the backs of the fingers, upon which the dirt collects. (TA.)
The phrase AlOaxocu biAlbaraAjimi, meaning The seizing with the hand, is one requiring consideration [as of doubtful character]. (Mgh.) [See also burovunN.]

hom.sense:
1. bariHa is syn. with zaAla [in two senses; i. e. as an attributive verb, and also as a non-attributive verb; as will be shown by what follows]. (Ṣ, A, Mgh.) [Using it as an attributive verb,] you say, laA OaboraHu Hat-aI taqoDiIa HaAjatiI I will not go away, or depart, or withdraw, (laA OazuwlN, and laA OatanaH-aIi,) until thou accomplish my want: from bariHa AlmakaAnu, inf. n. baraAHN, he went away, or departed, from the place; syn. zaAla minohu: and to be distinguished from the phrase in the Ḳur [xviii. 59, similar as to words,] mentioned below. (Mgh.) You say, bariHa makaAnahu, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboraHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baraAHN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and buruwHN (L, TA, and Ḥam p. 250) and baraHN, (L,) or baroHN, (as in a copy of the TA,) He went away, or departed, from his place; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà;) and he became in the baraAH [or wide, uncultivated, or uninhabited, tract]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) And maA bariHa makaAnahu He did not quit his place. (Mṣb.) And bariHa [alone], aor. _a {yaboraHu}, inf. n. baraAHN, It (a thing) went away, or departed, (zaAla,) from its place; (Mṣb;) as also tbr-H↓. (L.) In the phrase laA baraAHa [There is, or shall be, no quitting of place, or going away, or departing], the noun is in the accus. case, as in laA rayoba: but it is allowable to put it in the nom. case, so that lA is used in the manner of layosa; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the following saying of Saạd Ibn-Málik, [in the TA, in one place, Ibn-Náshib,] in a poem of which the rhyme is with refa, (Ṣ, IAth,) alluding to El-Hárith Ibn-ʼAbbád, who had withdrawn himself from the war of Teghlib and Bekr the sons of Wáïl: (IAth, TA:)
mano far-aEano niyraAnihaA
faOanaA Qbonu qayosK laA baraAHu
[Whoso fleeth from its fires, (i. e. niyraAni AlHarobi the fires of the war,) let him do so: but as for me, I am the son of Keys: to me there is not, or shall not be, any quitting of place]. (Ṣ, IAth. [See also Ḥam p. 250, where, for man far-a, we find mano Sad-a whoso turneth away.]) [Hence,] bariHati Alr-iyHu biAlt-uraAbi The wind carried up, raised, or swept up and scattered, [lit. went away with,] the dust. (Mṣb.) [Hence also, accord. to some,] bariHa AlxafaMCu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) and baraHa, (Ibn-El-Lihyánee, Z, and TA, [thus written in a copy of the A,]) ‡ The state of concealment departed, or ceased: or ‡ what was in a state of concealment became apparent; from baraAHN meaning “what is open and apparent” of land: or ‡ what I was concealing became apparent: (T, TA:) or ‡ the affair, or case, became manifest, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and its concealment ceased, (A,) [or] as though the secret departed, and ceased: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, † the secret became apparent: (TA in art. xfI:) or, lit., the low ground became high and apparent; meaning † what was concealed became revealed: (Ḥar pp. 133-4:) the first who said it was Shikk the Diviner. (IDrd, TA.)

[Using it as a non-attributive verb,] you say, laA OaboraHu OafoEalu celika I will not cease, or I will continue, (laA OazaAlu,) to do that: (Ṣ, A:*) and maA bariHa yafoEalu kacaA [he ceased not to do thus; or] he persevered in, or kept to, doing thus: (Mṣb:) and maA bariHa zayodN qaAYimFA [Zeyd ceased not to be, or he kept, or continued, standing]: in this case, the verb is of the category of kaAna; (Mgh;) relates to time; and requires a predicate: and its inf. n. is baraAHN. (Ḥam p. 250.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [xviii. 59], laA OaboraAHu Hat-aI Oaboluga majomaEa AlbaHorayoni, but the predicate is suppressed: it may be maA naHonu fiyhi kacelika [i. e. I will not cease in that wherein we are thus engaged until I reach the place of meeting of the two seas]: (Mgh:) or it means laA OazaAlu Oasiyru [I will not cease journeying]: (Bḍ, Jel:) or lA AbrH here may mean I will not depart (laA Oazuwlu) from that upon which I am intent, namely journeying and seeking; and I will not relinquish it; so that it does not require the predicate. (Bḍ. [He gives a third explanation, paraphrastic and strained, which I omit.])

baraHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboraHu} (L, TA, [but it is implied in the Ḳ that it is _u, which is contr. to rule,]) inf. n. buruwHN, It (a gazelle, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a bird, and any wild animal, that is hunted or shot, TA) turned its left side towards the spectator, passing by (Ṣ, Ḳ *) from the direction of his right hand towards that of his left hand: (Ṣ:) or passed by from the direction of the spectator's left hand towards that of his right hand: (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, L, Mṣb, in art. snH:) [the former appears to be accord. to the usage of the Hijázees; and the latter, accord. to that of the Nejdees, in general: see baAriHN:] contr. of sanaHa. (Ṣ.)

baraHa, aor. _u {yaboruHu}, [contr. to rule,] (Ḳ,) inf. n. baroHN, (TA,) He was angry. (Ḳ.) When a man has been angry with his companion, one says, maA OaXad-a maA baraHa Ealayohi [How violently angry was he with him!]. (L.)
2. bar-aHato biya AlHum-aI The fever affected me with its severity, violence, or sharpness, termed buraHaMCu. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) from buraHaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) br-H bihi, inf. n. taboriyHN, It (an affair, an event, or a case,) affected him severely; afflicted, distressed, or harassed, him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said also of anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind: (A:) and of a beating, meaning it hurt him severely, or greatly. (Mṣb.) Also said of a man, meaning He importuned him, or pressed him, with annoyance, or molestation: (A, TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by importuning or pressing; as also AbrH↓: (TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by distressing importunity or pressing: (T, TA:) and he punished, tormented, or tortured, him. (TA.) taboriyHN signifies The act of annoying, molesting, or hurting: (Mgh:) and in a trad., (in which it is forbidden, TA,) the killing, or putting to death, in an evil [or a cruel] manner; such as throwing live fish, and lice, into the fire. (Mgh, TA.)
bar-aHa Qll-ehu Eanoka May God remove from thee AlbaroH [i. e. difficulty, distress, affliction, &c., or the difficulty,, &c.]. (A, TA.)
4. AbrHhu He made him, or caused him, to go away from, depart from, or quit, his place. (A,* L.)

He, or it, pleased, or rejoiced, him; excited his admiration and approval; induced in him wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says also, maA OaboraHa hecaA AlOamora How greatly does this affair, or event, please, or rejoice! how greatly does it excite admiration and approval! or how greatly does it induce wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy! (Ṣ.)
He treated him with honour, or honoured him, and magnified him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, he found him to be generous, or noble. (TA.)
He judged him, or it, i. e. a man, (A, TA,) and a horse, (A,) or anything, (TA,) to be excellent, or to excel, (A, TA,) and wondered at, or admired, him, or it. (A.)

AbrH also signifies He exceeded the usual bounds, degree, or mode. (Aṣ, Ṣ,* TA.) You say, OaboraHota karamFA, and luWomFA, (A, TA,) Thou hast done a thing exceeding the usual bounds [in generosity, or nobleness, and in meanness, or ignobleness]; or extravagant; or excessive. (TA.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

baroHN Difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; evil, or mischief; (Ḳ, TA;) annoyance, molestation, or hurt; severe punishment; trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue; (TA;) a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing or event: (Ḥam p. 135:) and annoyance, or molestation, by distressing importunity or pressing; a subst. from 2: (T, TA:) and binotu baroHK, [and app. Aibonu baroHK also,] a calamity, misfortune, or disaster; or a great, or terrible, thing, affair, or case; (TA;) as also binotu baAriHK↓, and Aibonu bariyHK↓; (Ḳ;) pl. banaAtu baroHK and banuw baroHK. (TA.) [See also taboriyHN.] You say, laqiytu minohu baroHFA baAriHFA↓ I experienced from him, or it, [great] difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; [great] annoyance, molestation, or hurt; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;*) a phrase having an intensive signification, (Ḳ, TA,) like layolN Oaloyalu [and layolN laAYilN]; and so baroHFA mubar-iHFA↓. (TA.) When used as an imprecation, the more approved way is to put the two words in the accus. case: but sometimes they are put in the nom. case; as in the saying of a poet, baroHN laEyonaka baAriHN↓ [May great difficulty,, &c., befall thy two eyes!]. (TA.) You say also, laqiytu minohu banaAti baroHK, (Ṣ, A,) and baniI baroHK, (Ṣ,) I experienced from him, or it, difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adverse events; and calamities, misfortunes, or disasters: (Ṣ:) and, in the same sense, lqyt mnh AlbiraHiyna↓, and AlburaHiyna↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlbaraHiyna↓; (Ḳ;) or, accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, AlbiroHayni↓, and AlburoHayoni↓, and AlbaroHayoni↓, as duals; but the former reading is the more correct: (TA:) [MF disapproves of the form baraHiyna, and it is not mentioned in the L; but the dual form baroHayoni is there mentioned:]
it seems as though the sing. of bariHiyna [or buraHiyna] were biraHapN [or buraHapN], and that the pl. is formed by the termination wn to compensate for the rejection of the p, as is virtually the case in OaraDuwna; [or because the signification is regarded as that of a personification;] and that the pl. only is used. (L.) It is said in a prov., binotu baroHK XarakN EalaI raOosika [Calamity is, or be, a snare upon thy head]. (TA.)
bariHN: see mubar-iHN.
SaroHapa baroHapa, or SaroHapF baroHapF, &c.: see art. SrH.

buroHapN The best of anything: (TA:) and [particularly] one of the best of she-camels: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, of he-camels: (T:) pl. buraHN. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, hecihi buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or huwa buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (T,) This is a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or he is a camel, (T,) of the best of camels. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
baroHaI a word that is said when one misses the mark in shooting or casting; like as maroHaI is said when one hits the mark. (Ṣ, ISd, A, Ḳ.)

buraHaMCu Severity, violence, or sharpness, (Aṣ, A, TA,) or vehement molestation, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a fever (Aṣ, A, Ṣ, Ḳ), &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [a paroxysm; used in this sense by modern physicians:] and vehement distress of mind arising from the oppression caused by inspiration or revelation; such as is said to have affected the Prophet; [but most probably a paroxysm of that species of catalepsy which physicians term ecstasy;] occurring in a trad. (TA.) You say of one suffering from fever, when it is intense, OaSaAbatohu AlburaHaMCu [The paroxysm, or severe fit, has befallen him]. (TA.)
AlbiraHiyna and AlburaHiyna, &c.: see baroHN.

hom.sense: A wide, or spacious, tract of land, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) kaving in it no seed-produce nor trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or land having in it no building nor habitation: (Ḥam p. 237:) and applied as an epithet to land, signifying wide, or spacious, open, or conspicuous, and having in it no herbage nor habitation: and what is open, uncovered, and wholly apparent, of land: (TA:) or a place having no trees nor other things to cover or conceal it; as though such things had departed; (Mgh;) a place free from trees, &c.: (Mṣb:) or an elevated and open tract of land. (Ḥar p. 134.)
Habiylu baraAHK is an appellation given to ‡ A lion: and † a courageous man: as though each of them were bound with ropes, (Ḳ, TA,) and did not quit his place. (TA.)

An affair, a thing, or a case, that is plain, evident, or manifest; (Ḳ, TA;) or open, or public. (TA.) You say, jaMCanaA biAlOamori baraAHFA [He told us, or did to us, the thing] plainly [or openly]. (Ṣ.) And jaMCa biAlkufori baraAHFA wabiAlX-ar-i SuraAHFA [He uttered, or committed an act of, infidelity plainly, or openly, and evil, or mischief, unmixedly]. (A, TA.)
Counsel, or an opinion, that is disapproved, or deemed evil. (Ḳ.)

baraAHi, (El-Mufaddal, Ṣ, A, &c.,) and baraAHu, with damm and without tenween, (AZ, El-Mufaddal,) a name of The sun: (Ṣ, A, &c.:) determinate [and the former indecl.]: the sun is so called because of the spreading of its light, and its conspicuousness; or, being applied to the sun when it sets, brAH means baAriHapN; like as kasaAbi, a name applied to a hunting-bitch, means kaAsibapN. (TA.) You say, dalakato baraAHi The sun set [or declined from the meridian]. (A, TA.) For this phrase, occurring at the end of a verse cited by Ḳṭr, Fr reads dalakato biraAHi; rAH being pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of raAHapN, meaning the “hand” [or “palm of the hand”]: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to which reading, the poet means The sun had set, or had declined from the meridian, while they put their hands, or the palms of their hands, over their eyes, looking to see if it had set, or had declined from the meridian: or he who says, dalakati AlX-amosu biraAHi means the sun had almost set: the two readings barAH and birAH are mentioned by AʼObeyd and Az and Hr and Z and others: AZ says, dlkt biraAHK, with tenween, and baraAHN, without tenween. (TA.) [See also raAHapN, in art. rwH.]

entry.sense: baruwHN: see baAriHN.

hom.sense: bariyHN: see baAriHN.
Also The croaking of the guraAb [or crow, of whatever species, as raven, carrion-crow, &c.]. (L.)

[Hence,] Aibonu bariyHK: so in the Ḳ: in the Ṣ, Oum-u bariyHK; but IB and Aboo-Zekereeyà say that only the former is right: (TA:) [in one copy of the Ṣ, however, I find both of these:] The guraAb [or crow, as a generic term, applying to the raven, carrion-crow, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) so called because of its cry: a determinate appellation: for the pl., the expression used is banaAtu bariyHK. (TA.)
See also baroHN.
qawolN bariyHN A saying by which one pronounces a person to have said, or done, right. (L.)

entry.sense: baAriHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) as also baruwHN↓ and bariyHN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a gazelle, (Ṣ,) or what is hunted or shot, (Ḳ, TA,) of gazelles and birds and wild animals [in general], (TA,) Turning his left side towards the spectator, (Ṣ,) passing from the direction of the right hand of the latter towards the direction of his left hand: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or turning his right side towards the spectator, passing from the direction of the latter's left hand towards that of his right: (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, A,* L, Mṣb,* in art. snH:) contr. of saAniHN: (Ṣ,* TA:) pl. bawaAriHu. (L in art. snH.) The Arabs [who apply the epithet in the latter sense] regard the bArH as an evil omen, and the sAnH as a good omen; because one cannot shoot at the former without turning himself: (Ṣ:) but some of them hold the reverse: (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee and L in art. snH:) the people of Nejd hold the sAnH to be a good omen; but sometimes a Nejdee adopts the opinion of the Hijázee [which is the contrary]. (IB in that art.) The first of these epithets is also applied to a bird as meaning Inauspicious; ill-omened. (A.) It is said in a prov., mano liI biA ls-aAniHi baEoda AlbaAriHi (TA) i. e. [Who will be responsible to me] for a fortunate, or lucky, event, after an unfortunate, or unlucky? (Ḳ in art. snH:) applied in the case of a man's doing evil, and its being said, “He will at a future time do good to thee:” originally said by a man on the occasion of gazelles' passing before him in the manner of such as are termed baAriHap, and its being said to him, “They will present themselves to thee in the manner of such as are termed saAnHap.” (TA.) And in another prov. it is said, Uin-amaA huwa kabaAriHi AlOarowaI [It, or he, is only like the mountain-goat passing in the manner of such as is termed bArH]: for it dwells on the tops of the mountains, and men scarcely ever see it passing with the right or left side towards them save once in the course of ages: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied in the case of an extraordinary occurrence: (Ḳ:) [or in the case of a benefit conferred by a man who very rarely confers benefits on others: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 35:)] or when a man has delayed, or been tardy in, visiting [but has come at last]. (TA.)
Hence, fitolapN baAriHapN i. q. XazorapN [i. e. ‡ A manner of twisting contrary to that which is usual: see Xazara]. (A.)
And hecihi faEolpN baAriHapN ‡ This is an action that has not happened rightly. (A.)
[Hence,] binotu baAriHN: and [perhaps] laqiytu minohu baroHFA baAriHFA: and baroHN liEayonaka baAriHN: see baroHN.

[And hence, perhaps, because of its evil effect; or because it comes, accord. to some, from the left, i. e. northerly direction, or, accord. to others, from the right, i. e. southerly direction; or] from baroHN as signifying “a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing, or event;” (Ḥam p. 135;) baAriHN signifies also A hot wind: (Ṣ:) or a hot wind in the SayofN [i. e. summer or spring]: (Ḳ:) or a hot wind coming from the direction of El-Yemen: (Ḥam p. 135:) or a wind that carries up, raises, or sweeps up and scatters, the dust: (Mṣb:) pl. bawAriHu: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) or the bwArH are hot north, or northerly, winds in the Sayof: (AZ, Az, Ṣ:) this Az found to be the sense in which the term was used by the Arabs in his time: (TA:) or violent winds that carry with them the dust by reason of their violence: (TA:) or this name (the pl.) was given by the Arabs to all winds in the time of the stars of the qayoZ [or summer]: they mostly blow in the time of the stars of Libra; [app. meaning when Libra is on, or near, the meridian at nightfall, agreeably with a statement in modern Arabic almanacs, that the periods of the beginning and end of the winds thus called are the 30th of May and the 9th of July;] and these winds are what are termed the samaAYim [pl. of samuwmN]. (Ibn-Kunáseh, TA.)
AlbawaAriHu is also said by some to signify AlOanowaMCu [pl. of nawoCN, q. v.]; as mentioned by AḤn; but he repels their assertion. (TA.)

AlbaAriHapu The next, or nearest, past, or preceding, night; yesternight: (Ṣ, A, Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) from bariHa signifying zaAla [“he, or it, went away”, &c.]. (Ṣ, A.)
[In modern Arabic, Yesterday; as also AlbaAriH.] It has no dim. formed from it. (Sb, in Ṣ, in art. Oms; and TA.) You say, laqiytuhu AlbaAriHap [I met, or met with, him, or it, last night, or yesternight]: and laqiytuhu AlbaAriHapa AlOuwlaI [I met, or met with, him, or it, the night before last; this being the sense in which the phrase is now used by the learned: but the vulgar expression is Oaw-al AlbaAriHap, generally pronounced Oaw-al AamobaAriHaho or Oaw-al AamobaAriHo, agreeably with a peculiarity of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, or of Teiyi and Himyer, by the substitution of Aamo for Aalo: see art. Am]. (Ṣ) From daybreak to the time when the sun declines from the meridian, one says, raOayotu All-ayolapa fiI manaAmiI [I saw to-night in my sleep (such a thing)]; but when the sun has declined, one says, raOayotu AlbaAriHapa [I saw last night, or yesternight]: (AZ, Th: [and the like is said in the Mgh and Mṣb:]) or one says, kaAna kacaA wakacaA All-ayolapa [Such and such things happened to-night] until the sun is somewhat high and the day has become bright; but after this, one says, kaAna AlbaAriHapa [It happened last night, or yesternight]. (Yoo, Seer.) The Arabs say,
maA OaXobaha All-ayolapa biA lbaAriHapi
How like is this night wherein we are to the former night that has departed! (TA:) [or, this night to yesternight!]: originally occurring in a poem of Tarafeh: used as meaning “how like is the child to the father!” and applied to [any] two things resembling each other. (Ḥar p. 667.)

OaboraHu is formed [from baraHa for bar-aHa] by the rejection of the added letter: [for a word of this kind is regularly formed only from an unaugmented triliteral-radical verb:] or it is like OaHonaku, having no proper verb. (L.) You say, hecaA OaboraHu EalaI-a mino caAka (A,* L, Mṣb *) This is more difficult, distressing, or afflicting, to me than that. (L, Mṣb.*) And hecaM AlOamoru OaboraHu mino hecaA This affair, event, or case, is more difficult, or distressing, than this. (Ṣ.) And qataluwhumo OaboraHa qatolK [They slew them with a most severe slaughter]. (Ṣ.)

taboriyHN [inf. n. of 2, used as a simple subst.,] is said by some to be sing. of tabaAriyHu, and has been used as such by post-classical authors, but is not of established authority: accord. to others, the latter has no sing.: (MF:) the pl. signifies Difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adversities: [see also baroHN:] or the difficulties, or obligations, incurred by troublesome, or inconvenient, means of obtaining subsistence: (TA:) and tabaAriyHu AlX-awoqi the burning, or fierce burning, [or the burnings,, &c.,] of the yearning, or longing, of the soul, or of longing desire. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OnaA mubar-aHN biI I am importuned, or pressed, with annoyance, or molestation. (A, TA.) [See the verb {2}.]

mubar-iHN and bariHN↓, applied to an affair, an event, or a case, signify the same; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. Severe, afflicting, distressing, or harassing: (TA:) and the former, to a beating, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, TA,) meaning the same; (TA;) or hurting (Ṣ, Mgh) severely: (Ṣ:) and to a man, meaning annoying, or molesting, by importuning, or pressing. (TA.) [See 2.] laqiytu minohu baroHFA mubar-iHFA: see baroHN.

yaboruwHN, (Ḳ,) thus correctly written, with the I before the b; [not byrwH, as in the CK; in Chald. יַבְרוּחַ, the word corresponding to the sing. of the Hebr. דּוּדָאִים in Gen. xxx. 14 and 16, accord. to the paraphrase of Onkelos;] or yaboruwHN SanamiI-N [the idol-like ybrwH]; (TA;) The root, or lower part, of the wild luf-aAH [or mandrake, not to be confounded with another plant to which the name of luf-aAH, q. v., is also applied], (Ḳ,) which is known by the names of faAwaAniyaA and Euwdu AlS-aliybi [names now given to the peony], and called by MF tuf-aAHu Albar-i, [or the wild apple, but perhaps this is a mistranscription for luf-aAHu Albar-i,] said by him to be an appellation used by the vulgar; (TA;) resembling the form of a man; (Ḳ;) and of two sorts, male and female; called by the people of Greece Eabodu Als-alaAmi: (TA:) it torpifies, (Ḳ,) and strengthens the two appetites [namely that of the stomach and that of the generative organ]: (TA:) if ivory is cooked with it for six hours, it renders it soft; and if a part affected by [the disease termed] baraX is rubbed with its leaves for a week, (Ḳ,) without interruption, (TA,) it removes it without causing ulcers, or sores: (Ḳ:) the root of the wild luf-aAH is the yaborwH: it has the form of a human being; the male like the male, and the female like the female; and they pretend that he who pulls it up dies; wherefore, when they desire to do so, they tie a dog or some other animal to it. (Ḳzw, voce luf-aAH.)

hom.sense: 1. baruda, aor. _u {yaborudu}, inf. n. buruwdapN; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and barada, aor. _u {yaborudu}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. barodN; (M, Mṣb;) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb, and the latter said of water, Mṣb) was, or became, cold, chill, or cool; [see barodN below;] (Ṣ, M;) its heat became allayed. (Mṣb.) The latter verb is also used transitively, as will be shown below. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] baruda maDojaEahu [lit. His bed, or place of sleep, became cold; meaning] ‡ he went on a journey. (A.)

barada also signifies ‡ He died; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) because death is the non-existence of the heat of the soul; (L;) or it is allusive to the extinction of the natural heat; or to the cessation of motion. (MF.) For

barada, (MF,) aor. _u {yaborudu}, (Mgh,) inf. n. barodN, (MF,) likewise signifies † It was, or became, still, quiet, or motionless; (Mgh, MF;) for instance, a slaughtered sheep or goat [&c.]. (Mgh.) And † It (beverage of the kind called nabiyc) became still, and without briskness. (TA, from a trad.) You say, ruEiba fabarada makaAnahu [† He became frightened, and remained motionless in his place; makaAnahu meaning fiI makaAnahu: and hence,] ‡ he became amazed, or stupified. (A.) And baradato Eayonuhu † The pain in his eye became allayed, or stilled. (L.) And barada OamorunaA † Our affair, or case, became easy. (TA, from a trad. [See also baAridN.])
Also, inf. n. barod, [which see below,] † He slept. (T.)

And hence, ‡ It remained, or became permanent, or fixed, or settled. (T.) So in the saying, lamo yaborudo biyadiI minohu XayoCN ‡ There did not remain, or become permanent or fixed or settled, in my hand, thereof, anything. (T, L.*) You say also, barada OasiyrFA fiI Oayodiyohimo ‡ He remained safely a captive in their hands. (A.) And barada fiI Oayodiyhmo salomFA ‡ He became a permanent captive, remaining in their hands, not to be ransomed nor liberated nor demanded. (L.) And barada Almawoti EalaImuSoTalaAhu ‡ Death fixed, or settled, [upon his face and extremities, or] upon his limbs, or upon his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire. (AHeyth, L.) And barada Almawoti Ealayohi [‡ Death became impressed upon him;] the marks, or signs, of death became apparent upon him. (A.)

[And hence, app.,] ‡ It (a right, or due,) became incumbent, or obligatory, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and established. (TA.) You say, barada liI Haq-iI EalaI fulaAnK ‡ My right, or due, became incumbent, or obligatory, on such a one, and established against him. (M,* A,* TA.) And maA barada laka EalaI fulaAnK ‡ What hath become incumbent, or obligatory, to thee, on such a one, and established against him? or what hath become owed, or due, to thee, by, or from, such a one? as also maA caAba laka Ealayohi. (Ṣ.) And barada liI Ealayohi kacaA mina AlmaAli ‡ Such an amount of the property, or of property, became incumbent, or obligatory, to me, on him, and established against him; or became owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (Ṣ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaborudu}, inf. n. barodN, (TA, [but see the next sentence,]) † He (a man) was, or became, weak; and so burida, a verb like EuniIa. (Ḳ.) And, inf. n. buraAdN and buruwdN, (M, Ḳ,) † He was, or became, languid, (Ḳ,) or weak and languid, from leanness or disease: (M:) or weak in the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) And barada mux-uhu, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaborudu}, inf. n. barodN, (TA,) ‡ He was, or became, lean, or emaciated; (A, Ḳ;) and so baradato EiZaAmuhu. (A, TA.)
† It (a sword [or the like]) was, or became, blunt. (M, Ḳ.)

baradahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaborudu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. barodN; (Ḳ;) and br-dhu↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboriydN; (Ṣ;) He made it, or rendered it, (for ex., water, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) cold, chill, or cool: (Ṣ, &c.:) but the latter has an intensive signification [he made it, or rendered it, very cold, or very cool]: (Mṣb:) or both signify, (Ḳ,) or the former signifies, (M, TA,) he mixed it with snow: (M, Ḳ:) one does not say Abrdhu↓, except in a bad dialect. (Ṣ.) bar-idiyhi, being used by a poet for balo ridiyhi, has been erroneously supposed to mean “Make thou it hot.” (M.) You say, baradanaA All-ayolu, (aor. and inf. n. as above, M,) and barada EalayonaA, The night affected us with its cold. (M, Ḳ.) And saqayotuhu XarobapF baradato fuWaAdahu, (Ṣ, M,*) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) I gave him to drink a draught that cooled his heart: (Ṣ, M:)
or baradotu bihaA fuWaAdahu [with which I cooled his heart]. (So in the T.) And bar-ido↓ fuWaAdaka biXarobapK Cool thy heart by a draught. (A.) And AisoqiniI sawiyqFA Oaborudo bihi kabidiI [Give thou me to drink swyq with which I may cool my liver]. (T.) And barada Eayonuhu biAlokuHoli, (AʼObeyd, T, M,) or biAlobaruwdi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He cooled his eye with the collyrium, or] he applied the cooling collyrium to his eye, (T,* Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and allayed its pain. (M.) The following words, cited by IAạr,
baraduwA gawaAriba OayonuqK Hudobi [lit. They cooled the fore parts of the humps, or the backs, of humped she-camels], mean ‡ they put off from them their saddles, that their backs might become cool. (M.) You say also, bar-ido↓ Zahora farasika saAEapF ‡ Relieve thy horse from riding [lit. cool his back] awhile. (A.) And laA tubar-ido↓ Eano fulaAnK ‡ Do not thou alleviate the punishment [in the world to come] due to the offence of such a one by thy reviling him, or cursing him, when he has acted injuriously to thee. (T, Ṣ,* M,* A,* L.) And barada Alxuboza, (T, L, Ḳ,) biAlomaMCi, (T,) He poured [cold] water upon the bread, (T, L, Ḳ,) and moistened it [therewith: see baruwdN]. (T, L.)
burida (a verb like EuniIa, Ḳ) It (a company of men) was hailed upon. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And buridati. AlOaruDu The land, or ground, was hailed upon. (Ṣ.)
barada, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor _u, (TA,) inf. n. barodN, (Mgh, TA,) also signifies He filed (M, Mgh, Ḳ) iron, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) and the like, (M,) with a miborad.(Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

baradahu and Abrdhu↓ He sent him as a bariyd [or messenger on a postmule or post-horse]. (Ḳ.) And barada barydFA, (M,) and Abrdhu↓, (A,) He sent a bryd. (M, A.) And Abrd↓ Uiloyahi, (Ṣ,) or Abrd↓ Alyh bariydFA, (T, TA.) He sent to him a bryd. (T, Ṣ.)
2: see baradahu, in four places.
br-dhu Ealayohi ‡ He made it incumbent, or obligatory, on him. (M, A.)

And br-dhu, (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK,) inf. n. taboriydN; (TA;) and Abrdhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) ‡ It (a thing, M) made him, or rendered him, weak; weakened him; (Ḳ;) or made him, or rendered him, weak and languid. (M.)
[br-d also signifies, as is indicated in the TA voce HubaAHibN, It (a locust) spread forth its wings; which are termed its burodaAni: see burodN.]

4. Abrd He entered upon a cold, or cool, time: (Mgh, Mṣb:) he entered upon the last part of the day: (M, Ḳ:) he entered upon the time when the sun had declined: (Moḥammad Ibn-Kaab, T:) and he entered upon the cool season, at the end of the summer. (Lth, T.) [Hence,] OaboriduwA biAlT-aEaAmi Delay ye to eat food until it is cool: occurring in a trad. (El-Munáwee.) And OaboriduwA biAlZ-uhori (T, A, Mgh, Mṣb) Defer ye the noon-prayers until the cooler time of the day, when the vehemence of the heat shall have become allayed. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And Oaborido Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyripa Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (M, and L in art. fyH.)
Abrdlahu He gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (M, Ḳ.) You say also, saqayotuhu faOaboradotu lahu, meaning I gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)
Abrdhu He brought it cold, or cool. (M, Ḳ.)
See baradahu, first sentence.
And see 2.
See also 1, in four places; last three sentences.

entry.sense: 5. tbr-d fiyhi He descended into it, (i. e., into water, TA,) and washed himself in it, to refresh himself by its coolness. (M, Ḳ.) See also 8.
tbr-d also signifies † He became weakened. (TA.)

8. Abtrd He washed himself with cold water: (Ṣ:) and likewise, (Ṣ,) or AbtrdAlmaMCa, (Ḳ,) he drank water to cool his liver: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he poured the water cold upon himself, (M, Ḳ,) meaning, upon his head: (M:) and tbr-d↓ biAlomaACi, (T, A,) and Abtrd, (A,) he washed himself with water, or with the water. (T.)
10. Astbrd Ealayohi lisaAnahu ‡ He let loose his tongue and used it like a file against him. (A.)
barodN and buruwdapN↓ [originally inf. ns.] Cold; coldness; chill; chilness; cool, as a subst.; coolness; the former, contr. of Har-N; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb;) and the latter, of HaraArapN. (Ṣ.)
And [hence] the former, ‡ Pleasantness; enjoyment; ease; comfort: as in the saying, nasoOaluka Aljan-apa wabarodahaA ‡ We ask of Thee Paradise and its pleasantness,, &c. (L.)

Also † Sleep: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) [an inf. n. used as a subst.:] so in the Ḳur lxxviii. 24: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) for sleep cools a man: (TA:) or, accord. to I’Ab, it there means the coldness, or coolness, of beverage. (T.) You say, manaEa Albaradu Albaroda † The hail prevented sleep. (A.)

And † Saliva: (Th, T, M, Ḳ:) so, accord. to Th, in the saying of El-'Arjee,
waUino XiYoti lamo OaToEamu nuqaAxFA walaA barodaA
And if thou desire, I will not taste sweet water, nor saliva [from any lips but thine]. (T, M,* TA. [But this is cited in the Ṣ as an ex. of barod signifying sleep.])
See also baAridN.
[Hence,] AlbarodaAni: see AlOaboradaAni, voce Oaboradu.

burodN A kind of garment; (Ṣ;) a kind of striped garment: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to some, of the description termed waXoIN [or variegated]: (M:) or particular kinds thereof are distinguished by such terms as burodu EaSobK and burodu waXoIK: (Mṣb:) also, (as a coll. gen. n., TA,) garments of the kind called OakosiyapN, [pl. of kisaMCN,] which are wrapped round the body; (Ḳ;) one of which is called burodapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or, as Lth says, the burod is [a] well-known [garment], of the kind called buruwdu AlEaSobi and buruwdu AlwaXoIi; (T;) but the burodapN↓ is a garment of the kind called kisaMCN, four-sided, black, and somewhat small, worn by the Arabs of the desert: (T, Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb,* TA:) or this latter (the brdp) is a striped garment of the kind called XamolapN: (T:) or it is an oblong piece of woollen cloth, fringed: (M:) Sh says, I saw an Arab of the desert wearing a piece of woollen cloth resembling a napkin, wrapped round the body like an apron; and on my saying to him, What dost thou call it? he answered, burodap: (T:) [the modern brdp, in every case in which I have seen it, I have observed to be an oblong piece of thick woollen cloth, generally brown or of a dark or ashy dust-colour, and either plain, or having stripes so narrow and near together as to appear, at a little distance, of one colour; used both to envelop the person by day and as a night-covering: the brdp of Moḥammad is described as about seven feet and a half in length, and four and a half in width, and in colour either OaxoDar or OaHomar, i. e. of a dark or ashy dust-colour or brown; for such are the significations of these two epithets when applied to a garment of this kind, and in some other cases:] the pl. of burodN is OaborudN (M, Ḳ) and OaboraAdN [both pls. of pauc.] and buruwdN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and buradN, (IAạr, T,) or this last is pl. of burodapN, (Ṣ, M,) and biraAdN, like as qiraATN is pl. of quroTN, or this, also, is pl. of burodapN, like as biraAmN is pl. of buromapN. (M.)
cuwburodK, as opposed to cuw kisaMCi, means † A rich man. (Ṣ in art. Ej.)

waqaEa bayonuhumaA qad-u buruwdK yumonapK, (so in copies of the Ḳ, in the TA yumanapK,) or buruwdK vamiynapK, (so in a copy of the A,) ‡ [There happened between them two the rending of buruwd of the fabric of El-Yemen, accord. to the reading in the Ḳ, or of costly buruwd, accord. to the reading in the A,] means they arrived at a great, or severe, state of affairs; (Ḳ;) or is said of two men who have contended together in vehement altercation so that they have rent each other's garments; (A;) [accord. to the reading in the Ḳ,] because yumanN, [in the CK yumon,] which are buruwd of El-Yemen, are not rent save on account of some great, or severe, thing, or affair. (Ḳ.)

humaA fiI burodapi↓ OaxomaAsK means † They two do one deed; or act alike; (IAạr, M, Ḳ;) and resemble each other, as though they were in one burodap: (IAạr, M:) or they two have become near together, and in a state of agreement. (Ḳ in art. xms, q. v.)
And salaba AlS-ahobaMCa burodatahaA↓ ‡ He, or it, deprived the wine of its colour. (A.)
And burodaA AljaraAdi, (T,) or Aljunodabi, (Ṣ,) † The two wings [of the locust, or of the species called jndb]. (T, Ṣ.)
And burodapu↓ AlD-aOoni † A certain sort of milk. (Ḳ.)

baradN Hail; what descends from the clouds, resembing pebbles; (M, Mṣb;) frozen rain; (Lth, T;) what is called Hab-u AlgamaAmi (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Hab-u Almuzoni (Mṣb) [i. e. the grains, or berries, of the clouds: a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p {baradapN}, signifying a hailstone].
baridN Possessing coldness or coolness: an epithet applied to the [plant called] Sil-iyaAn. (Ṣ.)

saHaAbN baridN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and Oaboradu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Clouds containing hail (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ *) and cold. (T.) You say also saHaAbapN baridapN A cloud containing hail (T, Ṣ, M, A *) and cold; (T;) but not sHAbp barodaMCu. (M.)

hom.sense: barodapN: see baAridN:
and see also baradapN.
hiIa laka barodapa nafosahaA She is purely thine; (Fr, AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M;) syn. xaAliSapF: (M:) AʼObeyd explains it by xaAliSFA, (T, Ṣ, M,) not in the fem. form, (TA,) on the authority of Fr. (T.)
huwa liI barodapa yamiyniI, (AʼObeyd, M,) or huwa libarodapi yamiyniI, (Ṣ,) He, or it, is known to me. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M.)
barodapu a proper name applied to The ewe. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: burodapN: see burodN, in five places.

hom.sense: baradapN (T, Ṣ, M, A, &c.) and barodapN↓ (T, M, Ḳ) Indigestion; a malady arising from unwholesome food: (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or heaviness of food to the stomach: (IAạr, T, L:) so termed because it makes the stomach cold. (T, L, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., OaSolu kul-i daMCK Albaradapu [The origin of every disease is indigestion]. (T, Ṣ, M,* A.)
Also, the former, The middle of the eye. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: buradaMCu An ague; i. e. a fever attended by a cold fit, (Ḳ,) or by shivering. (TA.)

barodiy-N A well-known kind of plant, (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) of which the kind of paper termed qiroTaAs is made; (TA in art. qrTs, q. v.;) [namely, papyrus; and] of which mats are made; (Mṣb;) [app. meaning rushes in general: but the former is generally meant by it in the present day, and is probably the proper signification: anciently, mats, as well as ropes and sails, &c., were made of the rind of the papyrus; and even small boats were constructed of its stalks bound together; and of such, probably, was the ark in which the infant Moses was exposed: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. barodiy-apN. (M, TA.) Hence, qaTonu AlbarodiI- The cotton of the papyrus, which, resembling wool, is gathered from the stalk, and, mixed with lime, composes a very tenacious kind of cement. (Golius, from Ibn-Maạroof.)
[Also, a rel. n. from the same, meaning Of, or belonging to, or resembling, the plant so called. Hence the saying,] lahaA saAqN barodiy-apN [She has a shank like a papyrus-stalk]. (A.)
burodiI-N One of the most excellent sorts of dates: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) an excellent sort of dates, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) resembling the baroniI-: (AḤn, M:) or a sort of dates of El-Ḥijáz. (TA.)
[barodaAnN Feeling cold or chilly or cool: fem. with p {barodaAnapN}: perhaps post-classical; for I have not found it mentioned in any of the lexicons.]

hom.sense: buraAdN: see baAridN.
Also Weakness of the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) [See also 1.]

entry.sense: baruwdN: see baAridN.
Beverage that cools the heat of thirst. (T.)

Also, (T, L, Ḳ,) and maboruwdN↓, (T, M, A, L, Ḳ,) Bread upon which water is poured; (T, L, Ḳ;) which is moistened with cold water: (A:) eaten by women to make them fat. (M, A, L.) The subst. applied to such bread is bariydN↓ (A.)
baruwdN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] also signifies Cold water which one pours upon his head. (M.)
Anything with which a thing is rendered cold, or cooled. (Ṣ, M.)
A collyrium which cools the eye; (Lth, T, M, Mṣb;) also termed baruwdu AlEayoni. (T, Ṣ.)
baruwdu AlZ-il-i † Pleasant in social intercourse: applied alike to the male and the female. (TA, from a trad.)
vawobN baruwdN A garment without nap: (Ḳ:) and a garment that is not warm nor soft. (TA.)

hom.sense: bariydN: see baruwdN.

Also A mule appointed [for the conveyance of messengers] in a ribaAT [or public building for the accommodation of travellers and their beasts, or in a sik-ap, which is a house or the like specially appropriated to messengers and the beasts that carry them: thus it signifies a postmule: afterwards, it was applied also to a posthorse, and any beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers]: (Mgh:) [this is what is meant by the words in the Ṣ and Ḳ, Albariydu Almurat-abu:] it is a word of Persian origin, (Z in the Fáïk,) arabicized, from buriydaho dumo, (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh,) i. e. “docked,” or “having the tail cut off;” for the post-mules (bigaAlu Albariydi) had their tails cut off in order that they might be known: (Z in the Fáïk:) [or perhaps it is from the Hebrew פֶּרֶד “a mule:”] or it is applied to the beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers (daAb-apu Albariydi) because he traverses the space called bariyd [defined below: but the reason before given for this appellation is more probable: it is like the Lat. “veredus”]: (T, Mṣb:) pl. burudN (Z, Mgh, Mṣb) and burodN, which is a contraction of the former, like as rusolN is of rusulN. (Z.) You say, Humila fulaAnN EalaI Albariyid [Such a one was borne on the postmule or post-horse]. (Ṣ.) Imra-el-Ḳeys speaks of a bryd of the horses of Barbar. (Ṣ.)

Having been originally used in the sense first explained above, it was afterwards applied to A messenger borne on a post-mule [or post-horse]: (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh:) or messengers on beasts of the post: (M, Ḳ:) or a messenger that journeys with haste: (A:) or [simply] a messenger: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (M,* Z.) Hence the saying, AlHum-aI bariydu Almawoti Fever is the messenger of death: (T, Mṣb:) because it gives warning thereof. (T.) Hence also Albariydu applied to The animal called AlfuraAniqu, (said to be the jackal, but some say otherwise, TA,) because he gives warning before [the approach of] the lion. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And SaAHibu Albariyid [The master of the messengers that journey on post-mules or post-horses]. (Ṣ.) [And xayolN Albariyid, occurring in many histories, &c., The post-horses, that carry messengers and others.]

Also, having been applied to a messenger on a post-mule [or post-horse], it then became applied to The space, or distance, traversed by the messenger thus called; (Mgh, Mṣb;*) the space, or distance, between each sik-ap and the sik-ap next to it; the sk-p being a structure of either of the kinds called bayot and qub-ap, or a ribaAT [explained above], in which the appointed messengers lodge; (Z in the Fáïk;) the space, or distance, between two stations, or places of alighting; or two parasangs, or leagues; (M, Ḳ;) [six miles;] each parasang, or league, being three miles, and each mile being four thousand cubits: (TA:) or twelve miles; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. four parasangs, or leagues: (Mgh, TA:) [for] the space, or distance, between each station termed sik-ap and the next to it is either two parasangs or four: (Z in the Fáïk:) the distance of twelve miles is [also] termed sik-apu Albariyid: (T:) the pl. is as above. (T, Z.) A journey of four burud, or forty-eight miles, renders it allowable to shorten prayers; which miles are of the Háshimee measure, such as are measured on the road to Mekkeh. (T.)

Also The course, or pace, of a camel along the space thus called: so in the following verse of Muzarrid, in praise of 'Arábeh El-Owsee:
fadatoka EaraAba Alyawoma Oum-iI waxaAlatiI
wanaAqatiIa Aln-aAjiI Uilayoka bariyduhaA
[May my mother, and my maternal aunt, and my she-camel that is swift in her course to thee from one station to another, be ransoms for thee, O 'Arábeh, (the name being contracted,) this day!]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: buraAdapN Filings; (M, Mgh, Ḳ;) what falls from iron [&c.] when filed. (Ṣ.)
buruwdapN: see barodN.

bar-aAdapN A vessel which cools water: (M, Ḳ:) or a kaw-aAzap [app. meaning either a stand, or a shelf, upon which mugs (kiyzaAn, pl. of kuwz,) are placed; erroneously in the Ḳ, kuw-aArapN, and kuwaArapN, as I find it in different copies;] upon which water is cooled: (Lth, T, Ḳ:*) but [Az says,] I know not whether it be a classical or a post-classical word. (T.) Hence the saying, baAtato kiyzaAnuhumo EalaI Albar-aAdapi Their mugs passed the night upon the br-Adp. (A, TA.)

baAridN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) Cold; chill; cool; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) applied to water [&c.]; (M, Ḳ;) as also barodN↓, [originally an inf. n., like EadolN, used as an epithet,] (M, Ḳ,) and baruwdN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and buraAdN↓; (M, Ḳ;) but the last two are intensive forms [signifying very cold or chill or cool]. (TA.)

‡ Anything loved, beloved, liked, or approved. (TA.) [Hence,] EayoXN baArdN ‡ An easy and a pleasant life, or state of life. (ISk,* T,* M, A, L, Ḳ.) And layolapN baAridapN AlEayoXi, and barodapu↓ AlEayoXi, [the latter written in the TT baradapu AlEyX,] ‡ A night of easy and pleasant life. (M, L.) And ganymapN baAridapN: see the latter word.
samuwmN baAridN ‡ A hot wind that is constant, continual, permanent, settled, or incessant. (Ṣ, L.)
liI Ealayohi OalofN baAridN ‡ A thousand [pieces of money, &c.] are incumbent, or obligatory, on him, to me, and established against him; or are owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (Ṣ, M.*)
jaMCa fulaAnN baAridFA mux-uhu, and baArida AlEiZaAma, ‡ Such a one came in a lean, or an emaciated, state: in the contr. case, one says, HaAr-aA mux-uhu, and HaAr-a AlEiZaAmi. (A, TA.)
[baAridN also signifies † Blunt; applied to a sword and the like: see 1.]
[And, contr., † Sharp: for you say,] murohafaAtN bawaAridu [pl. of baAridapN, meaning] † Sharp, or cutting, swords: (TA:) or slaying swords. (Ṣ.)

baAridapN † Spoil acquired without fatigue; (IAạr, T;) also termed ganiymapN baAridapN; and to this is likened, by the Prophet, fasting in winter. (T.) Also † Gain made by merchandise at the time of one's buying it. (IAạr, T.)
Oaboradu [More, and most, cold, or chill, or cool].

[Hence,] AlOaboradaAni and AlbarodaAni↓ The morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;)
also called AlEaSoraAni (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AlS-aroEaAni and Alr-idofaAni: (T:) or (as in the Ṣ, but in the M and Ḳ “and”) the morning-shade and evening-shade: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so called because of their coldness, or coolness. (TA.)
See also baridN.
vaworN Oaboradu A bull upon which are spots, or patches, of white and black: (Ṣ, M:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.)
And AlOaboradu The leopard: fem. with p {AlOaboradapu}: (T, Ḳ: [but in the TT, the fem. is written like the masc.:]) pl. AlOabaAridu. (T, Ḳ.) The female is also called Alxayovamapu. (T.)

Uiboradapu, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) with kesr (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) to the C and the r (Mgh, TA,) [in the CK Aiboradap,] Cold in the belly, or inside; (M, Ḳ;) a well-known malady, arising from the prevalence of cold and humidity, and preventing one, by languor, from performing the act of coition: (Ṣ, Mgh:) and a dripping of the urine, which prevents a man's taking pleasure in women. (T, L.)

Also Coldness of the damp earth, and of rain. (M, L.) An Arab says, Uin-ahaA labaAridapN Alyawoma [Verily it (the morning, AlgadaApu, L) is cold to-day]; and another says to him, layosato bibaAridapK Uin-amaA hiIa Uiboridapu Alv-araI [It is not cold: it is only the coldness of the damp earth]. (Ṣ, L.)
muboradN [pass. part. n. of 4]. You say, OaroDN muboradapN: see maboruwdN.

hom.sense: muboridN [act. part. n. of 4]. You say, jiYonaAka muboridiyna We came to thee when the heat had become allayed. (T.)
Also One sending, or who sends, a bariyd [or burud, i. e., a messenger on a post-mule or posthorse, or messengers on post-mules or post-horses]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: miboradN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) A file; (M;) syn. suwhaAnN; (M, Ḳ;) which is a Persian word: (M:) pl. mabaAridu. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] jaEala lisaAnihi Ealayohi muboridFA ‡ [He made his tongue like a file upon him; i. e.] he annoyed him, or hurt him, with his tongue, and vituperated him. (A.) [See a saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir voce jin-N.]

maboradapN [A cause of coldness or coolness]. You say, hecaA AlX-aIoCu maboradapN lilobadani [This thing is a cause of coldness, or coolness, to the body]: and Aṣ relates that he said to an Arab of the desert, “What induceth thee to take a sleep in the morning while the sun is yet low?” and he answered, Uin-ahaA maboradapN fiI AlS-ayofi masoxanapN fiI AlX-itaMCi [Verily it is a cause of coolness in the summer, and a cause of warmth in the winter]. (Ṣ, A.)
mubar-adN: see what follows.
maboruwdN Made, or rendered, cold or chill or cool: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [and mubar-adN↓ signifies the same in an intensive manner:] applied to water [&c.: or signifying mixed with snow: see baradahu]. (Ḳ.)
XajarapN maboruwdapN A tree deprived of its leaves by the cold. (AḤn, M.)
OaroDN maboruwdapN (M, A, Ḳ) and muboradapN↓ (Ḳ) Land, or ground, hailed upon: (M, Ḳ:) or snowed upon. (A, TA.)
See also baruwdN.
barodaEapN: see barocaEapN.
barocaEN: see what next follows.

hom.sense:
barocaEapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and barodaEapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) A [cloth of the kind called] Hilos which is put beneath the [saddle called] raHol (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the camel: (Mgh:) pl. baraAciEu (Mgh, Mṣb) and baraAdiEu (Mṣb.) Ru-beh says, [using the sing. without the p as a coll. gen. n.,]
wataHota OaHonaMCi Alr-iHaAli AlbarocaEu↓
[And beneath the curved pieces of wood of the camels' saddles are the bardha'ahs]. (TA.)

This is the primary signification: but in the conventional language of our time, it is applied to An ass's saddle; the thing upon which one rides on an ass, like the saroj to the horse; (Mṣb;) [i. e. a pad, or stuffed saddle; generally stuffed with straw; and used for a mule as well as for an ass;] or an ass's brcEp is a saddle like the raHol and qatab. (TA voce UikaAfN, q. v.)
barocaEapN also signifies Land which is neither hard nor soft: (Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)

entry.sense: baraAciEiI-N A maker of baraAciEu, pl. of barocaEapN: a rel. n. similar to OanomaATiI-N. (TA.)
Q. 1. barocana, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. barocanapN, (T,) He (a horse) went in the manner of the birocawon, q. v. (T, M, Ḳ.)
He (a man) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish: whence IDrd thinks birocawonN to be derived: (M, Mṣb:*) but this opinion is of no account. (M.)
He was unable to reply, (T, Ḳ,) when asked respecting a thing. (T.)
He subdued, overpowered, or overcame: (Ḳ: [expl. by qahara and galaba; but I think that the right reading may be quhira and guliba, meaning he was, or became, subdued,, &c.:]) said of a man. (TA.)

birocawonN [A horse of mean breed, or of coarse make; a jade: but commonly applied to a hack, or hackney; a horse for ordinary use, and for journeying:] a daAb-ap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not in an absolute sense, but of a particular sort, namely, (MF,) a horse that is not of Arabian breed: (T, MF:) or a heavy, or sluggish, dAb-p: (so in a copy of the Ṣ:) or a coarse horse: (Towsheeh, TA:) or a horse of coarse make, hardy so as to endure travel upon the mountain-roads and rugged ground, not of Arabian breed, mostly brought from Er-Room [meaning Asia Minor or Greece]: (TA, from the Expos. of the 'Irákeeyeh of Es-Sakháwee:) or a horse of large and coarse make, with thick limbs; whereas those of Arabian breed are light of flesh, lank in the belly, and more slender in the limbs: (El-Bájee, TA:) or a Turkish horse; opposed to Arabian: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a pacinghorse; syn. rahawaAnN: (TA voce himolaAjN:) fem. with p {birocawonapN}; (Ks, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) sometimes; but without p it is applied to the female as well as the male: (IAmb, Mṣb:) pl. baraAciynN (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)
mubarocinN An owner of a birocawon: (Ḳ:) or a rider thereon. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baraza, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboruzu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. buruwzN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) He (a man, Ṣ) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth; he issued. (Ṣ, A.) He (a man, TA) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (Ḳ:) or did so to satisfy a want of nature: (TṢ, TA:) as also, in the former sense, (Ḳ,) or in the latter, (Ṣ,) tbr-z↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and bariza; (Ṣgh, TA;) and so, in the former sense, br-z↓ inf. n. taboriyzN; (Ḥar p. 510;) [and in the latter sense, bArz↓ accord. to an explanation of its part. n. mubaArizN in Ḥar p. 566:] or tbr-z↓ signifies he voided his excrement, or ordure. (Mgh, Mṣb.) You say, barazaUilaI Alqironi fiI AlHarobi He went, or came, out, or forth, into the field to his adversary in battle or war. (TA.)
He, or it, (a man, TA, or thing, Mṣb, or anything, Fr,) appeared, or became apparent, (Fr, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) after concealment, (Fr, Ḳ,) or after obscurity; (Ṣgh;) as also bariza (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
[It was, or became, prominent, or projecting: often used in this sense.]

baruza, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baraAzapN, (Mṣb,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed barozN q. v.: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner, baruzato, inf. n. as above, she (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed barozapN (A.)

2. br-zhu, (inf. n. taboriyzN, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made it apparent, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, or manifested, it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) namely, a writing, or book, (A,) or other thing; (Ṣ, A;) as also Abrzhu↓: (A, Mṣb:) or Abrz↓ AlkitaAba signifies he put forth, or produced, the writing, or book; syn. Oaxorajahu: (TA:) and [as it often signifies in the present day,] published, it; syn. naXarahu. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also 4 below.] It is said in the Ḳur [xxvi. 91 and lxxix. 36], wabur-izati AljaHiymu, meaning And Hell shall be uncovered. (A.)
br-z raAkibahu He (a horse) saved his rider. (Ḳ.)
See also 1.

[Hence,] br-z Alfarasu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or br-z EalaI Alxayoli, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboriyzN, (Mṣb,) The horse outstripped (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) the [other] horses (Mṣb, Ḳ) in the race-ground: (Mṣb:) it is said of a horse that outstrips in a race: and, accord. to some, the like is said of whatever outstrips: (TA:) and br-z EalaI AlgaAyapi [He (a horse) passed beyond the goal]. (A.)

Hence, br-z fiI AlEilomi, inf. n. as above, He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows in knowledge. (Mṣb.) And [simply] br-z He surpassed his companions (Ṣ, Ḳ) in excellence, or in courage. (Ḳ.) And br-z EalaI OaqoraAnihi [He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows, or his opponents]. (A.)
See also 4, last signification.

3. bArzhu fiI AlHarobi, (A, Mṣb,* Ḳ*) inf. n. mubaArazapN and biraAzN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He went, or came, out, or forth, in the field, to [encounter] him (i. e. his adversary) in battle, or war. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 1.

4. Abrzhu He made, or caused, him (a man) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth: (Ṣ:) [or to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (see 1:)] and he made, or caused, it (a thing) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth; or he put it, or took it, or drew it, out, or forth; syn. Oaxorajahu; as also Astbrzhu↓. (Ḳ.) See also 2, in two places.
Abrz He determined, resolved, or decided, upon journeying: (IAạr, Ḳ:) the vulgar say br-z↓ (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
6. humaA yatabaArazaAni They two (meaning two adversaries) go, or come, out, or forth, into the field, each to [encounter] the other, in battle or war. (Ḳ,* TA.)
tbArzA They both separated themselves, each from his company, and betook themselves each to the other. (Ḳ.)
