barozN A man characterized by pleasing or goodly aspect, and by intelligence: fem. with p {barozapN}: (Ṣ, TA:) or a man of open condition or state: (TA:) or pure in disposition; (TA;) abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) of great dignity or estimation: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {barozapN}: (A, Mṣb:) pl. fem. barozaAtN: (A:) or, as also baroziI-N↓ a man who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and in whose intelligence, (Ḳ,) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, in whose excellence, bifaDolihi, but this is app. a mistranscription, or, as some say, in whose abstinence from what is unlawful and indecorous, (TA,) and his judgment, confidence is placed: (Ḳ:) and barozapN a woman whose good qualities or actions, or whose beauties, are apparent: (Ḳ:) or open in her converse; syn. mutaAjirapN: or, as in some correct lexicons, disdainful of mean things; syn. mutajaAl-apN: or of middle age, (kaholapN,) who is not veiled or concealed like young women: (TA:) or of great dignity or estimation: (AO, TA:) or who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit, and of whom they talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and is intelligent: (TA:) or who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and goes or comes forth to men, and talks with them, and is advanced in age beyond those women who are kept concealed: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or open in her converse, (mutajaAhirapN,) of middle age, (kaholapN,) of great dignity or estimation, who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit and talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous: (Ḳ:) or in whose judgment, and her abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous, confidence is placed: (TA:) or who does not veil her face from a man and bend her head down towards the ground. (IAạr, on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr.)
baroziI-N: see barozN

baraAzN A field, plain, or wide expanse of land, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) without trees; (Mṣb;) as also biraAzN↓; but this latter form is rare: (Mṣb:) or an open tract of land destitute of herbage and trees and without hills or mountains: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, Ṣ:) an open place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, Ṣ:) an open place in which is no covert. (TA.)

[Hence,] xaraja UilaI AlbaraAzi ‡ He went forth to satisfy a want of nature. (A.) And UicaA OaraAda AlbaraAza OaboEada ‡ [When he desired to satisfy a want of nature, he went far off]: a trad.; respecting which El-Khaṭṭábee says that the relaters of traditions err respecting the word, pronouncing it with kesr, for biraAzN↓ is an inf. n.: but (SM says that) authorities differ as to this point. (TA.)
[It is further said,] baraAzN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or biraAzN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) is metonymically applied to ‡ Excrement; human ordure; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the feces of food. (Ṣ.)
biraAzN: see baraAzN, in three places.
baArizN act. part. n. of baraza [q. v.].
Wholly, or entirely, apparent or manifest. (TA.)
OaroDN baArizapN Land that is apparent, open, or uncovered, (Bḍ and Jel in xviii. 45, and TA,) upon which is no mountain nor any other thing, (Jel,) or that has no hill nor mountain nor sand. (TA.)
UiboriziI-N: see what next follows.

UiboriyzN (Sh, IAạr, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UiboriziI-N↓, (Sh, IAạr, Ḳ,) the latter of which is incorrectly written in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ UiboriyziI-N, (TA,) Pure gold: (Sh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or an ornament of pure gold: (IAạr:) the former an arabicized word [app. from the Greek ὄβρυζον, as also the latter]: (Mṣb:) of the measure UifoEiylN; the C and I being augmentative. (IJ.)

maborazN [lit. A place to which one goes forth in the field, or plain, or open tract or country;] a privy, or place where one performs ablution; syn. mutawaD-aOo; (Ṣ;) [as also mutabar-azN↓, occurring in the TA in art. jwz.]

kitaAbN muborazN, (Ḳ,) and maboruwzN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) A writing, or book, put forth, or published; syn. manoXuwrN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or made apparent, shown, or manifested: (Mṣb:) ↓the latter anomalous; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) being from Oaboraza; (Mṣb;) and AḤát disapproved it; and thought that it might be a mistake for mazobuwrN, meaning “written;” but it [is said that it] occurs in two poems of Lebeed: (Ṣ:) in one of these instances, however, for Almaboruwzu, some read Almuborazu; and Ṣgh says that he found not the other instance in the poems of Lebeed: IJ says that AlmaboruwzN↓ is for AlmaboruwzN bihi. (TA.) You say, qado OaEoTawohu kitaAbFA maboruwzFA↓ They had given him a writing, or book, published; i. e., manoXuwrFA. (TA.)
maboruwzN: see muborazN, throughout.
mutabar-azN: see maborazN.
barozaxN A thing that intervenes between any two things: (L:) or a bar, an obstruction, or a thing that makes a separation, between two things: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur lv. 20: pl. baraAzixu. (L.)

The interval between the present life and that which is to come, (Ṣ, A,) from the period of death to the resurrection, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) upon which he who dies enters; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the period, or state, from the day of death to the day of resurrection: so in the Ḳur xxiii. 102. (Fr.)

baraAzixu AlUiymaAni What is between the beginning of faith, (L, Ḳ,) which is the acknowledgment, or confession, of God, (L,) and the end thereof, (L, Ḳ,) which is the removal of what is hurtful from the road: (L:) or what is between doubt and certainty. (L, Ḳ.)
Q. 1. burosima He (a man) was affected with the disease termed birosaAm; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also bulosima. (TA.)

birosaAmN, (in the T with fet-ḥ, [barosaAmN,] Mgh,) A certain malady, or disease, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) attended by delirium: (Ḳ:) [in the present day, this term is applied to the pleurisy, as also caAtu Aljanobi; and so it is explained by Golius and Freytag; or, as the latter adds, accord. to Avicenna, pleurodyne: but] in some of the books of medicine, it is said to be a tumour, (Mṣb,) or a hot tumour, (TA,) that is incident to the septum which is between the liver and the bowels, [app. meaning the upper parts of the greater and lesser omentum,] and then reaches to the brain: (Mṣb, TA:) also pronounced bilosaAmN: (ISk, Mṣb:) i. q. muwmN: (M, TA:) it is an arabicized word; (IDrd, Mgh, Mṣb;) or seems to be so; composed of baro and saAmo; the former of these, in Persian, signifying the “breast,” or “chest;” and the latter, “death” [and “fire” and “a swelling;” of which three meanings, the second and third are agreeable with the two explanations of brsAm given above]: so says Az. (TA.)

birosiymN, with kesr, (Ḳ,) vulgarly pronounced with fet-ḥ to the b, [barosiym,] (TA,) [Alexandrian trefoil or clover; trifolium Alexandrinum; described by Forskål in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 139; the most common and the best kind of succulent food for cattle grown in Egypt: it is sown when the waters of the inundation are leaving the fields; and yields three crops; the second of which is termed rib-apN; and so is the third; but this is generally left for seed: when dry, it is termed dariysN: if his words have not been perverted by copyists, F explains it as] the grain of the quroT, (Hab-u AlquroT) [but I think it probable that this is a mistranscription, for xayoru AlquroTi, i. e., the best of the (species of trefoil, or clover, called) quroT,] resembling the ruTobap [or raTobap], or superior to this latter in size, or quality (Oajal-u minohaA): (Ḳ:) the quroT resembles the ruTobap, [written in the TA without the vowel signs,] but is superior to this latter in size, or quality (Ajl- mnhA), and larger in the leaves, and is what is called in Persian Xabocar [or Xabodar]: (AḤn, TA:) it is one of the best kinds of herbage for horses and the like, which fatten upon it. (TA.)

UiboriysamN, (M, [and thus written in copies of the Ḳ,]) with kesr to the r [as well as the C], accord. to IAạr, (M,) [and] with fet-ḥ to the s; (Ḳ;) or UiborayosamN; (M;) and [app. UiboriysumN,] with damm to the s; (Ḳ;) or it has three dial. forms; accord. to ISk, it is Abrysim [app. UiboriysimN]; others say that it is Abrysam [app. OaborayosamN], with fet-ḥ; IAạr says that it is UiboriysamN, with kesr to the C and the r and with fet-ḥ to the s, and he says that there is not in the language an instance of UifoEiylilN, with kesr, but there are instances of UifoEiylalN, as UiholiylajN [q. v.] and UiboriysamN; (Ṣ; [but I find that in two copies of that work, and in the L, this passage is mutilated; for it runs thus; “ISk says that it is UiboriysamN, with kesr to the C and r, and with fet-ḥ to the s,”, &c.;]) or one of its dial. forms is UiboriysimN, with kesr to the C and the r and the s; but ISk disallows this, [or, probably, as appears from what has been said above, we should read here, “accord. to ISk, but others disallow this,”] saying that there is not in the language an instance of AfElyl with kesr to the [former] l, but with fet-ḥ, as UiholiylajN and UToriyfalN; and the second form is OaborayosamN, with fet-ḥ to those three letters; and the third is UiborayosamN, with kesr to the C, and fet-ḥ to the r and the s; (Mṣb;) and IB [appears to indicate the second and third of these forms, for he] says that some pronounce Abrysm with fet-ḥ to the C and the r, and some pronounce it with kesr to the C, and with fet-ḥ to the s; (TA;) Silk; syn. HariyrN: (M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, specially, raw silk: (TA:) [it is said that] Hryr is the same as Abrysm: (Mṣb in art. Hr:) or dressed silk; syn. Abrysm maTobuwx: (Mgh and Mṣb in that art.:) or stuff wholly composed of silk: or of which the woof is silk: (Mgh in that art., from the Jema et-Tefáreek:) [and it is also said that] qaz-a is the same as Abrysm: (Ḳ in art. qz:) or a kind thereof: (Ṣ in that art.:) or that whereof Abrysm is made: (Lth, Az, Mṣb, TA, all in that art.:) [medicinal properties are ascribed to it: it is said that] it is exhilarating, warming to the body, moderate in temperament, and strengthening to the sight when used as a collyrium: (Ḳ:) the word is arabicized, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [but in the last it is said, after the explanation of the meaning, “or it is arabicized,”]) from [the Persian] AbryXm [i. e. OaboriyXamo]: (TA:) and is perfectly decl., even if used as a proper name, in the manner of a surname, because it was arabicized in its indeterminate state, not like UisoHaAqu, &c., which were arabicized in their determinate state, and are not used by the Arabs indeterminately. (Ṣ.)
UiborisamiI-N or UiborayosamiI-N [&c.] A manufacturer [or seller] of Abrysm. (TA.)
mubarosamN A man affected with the disease termed birosaAm; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also mubalosamN. (Mṣb, TA.)
1. bariXa, aor. _a {yaboraXu}, inf. n. baraXN, i. q. bariSa, aor. _a {yaboraXu}, inf. n. baraSN: (Mṣb:) [or rather, used allusively for the latter verb: see OaboraXu. See also baraXN, below.]
9. AbrX-, inf. n. UiborXaAXN, He (a horse) was, or became, marked with small specks, called baraX, differing from the rest of his colour. (Ṣ.)

baraXN, in the hair of a horse, Small specks, differing from the rest of the colour; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also buroXapN↓: (Ḳ:) or both signify a colour in which one speck is red and another black or dustcoloured or the like. (TA.)
And hence, (T-A,) the former, (A, TA,) or ↓both (Ḳ,) A whiteness that appears upon the nails. (Ibráheem El-Ḥarbee, A, Ḳ.)
And the former, White specks in the skin. (A.)
[See also 1.]
buroXapN: see baraXN, in two places.
bariyXN: see OaboraXu.

OaboraXu, applied to a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to one of the sort termed birocawn, (Lḥ,) Marked with the small speaks termed baraX; (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bariyXN↓. (Ḳ.) Also, XaApN baroXaMCu A ewe, or she-goat, marked with specks of various colours. (TA.) And Hay-apN baroXaMCu A serpent black speckled with white, or white speckled with black. (TA.)

[Hence,] i. q. OaboraSu: fem. baroXaMCu: pl. buroXN: (Mṣb:) [or rather, used allusively for OaboraSu; for] Jedheemeh (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) Ibn-Málik (Ṣ, TA) Ibn-Fahm, (TA,) the king [of El-Heereh], (Ḳ,) was surnamed AlOaboraXu in allusion to his being OaboraS; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the Arabs fearing to apply to him this latter epithet: (Ḳ:) or he was thus called because he was marked with black or red specks caused by a burn. (Kh.)

makaAnN OaboraXu A place of various colours, abounding in plants or herbage: (Ḳ:) and OaroDN baroXaMCN, and sanapN baroXaMCu, land, and a year, in which is abundance of herbage (Ks, Ḳ) of various colours; (Ks;) as also raboXaMCu and ramoXaMCu. (TA.)

1. bariSa, (Ṣ, [so in two copies, in one mentioned by Freytag buriSa, which is a mistake,] M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboraSu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baraSN, (M, Mṣb,) He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, affected with baraS [or leprosy (see baraSN below)]. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also bariXa.]
2. br-S raOosahu, (A,) inf. n. taboriySN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He shaved his head. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
br-S AlmaTaru AlOaroDa, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) † The rain fell upon the land before it was ploughed, or tilled. (Ibn'-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. AbrS He begot a child that was OaboraS [or leprous]. (Ḳ.)
AbrShu Qll-ehu God rendered him, or caused him to be or become, OaboraS [or leprous]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tbr-S AlOaroDa ‡ He (a camel, A, TA) found no pasture in the land without depasturing it; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) left no pasture in the land. (A.)

baroSN, with fet-ḥ, A certain small reptile (duwayob-apN) that is in the well. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ. [In the CK, fI AlbaEiyri is put by mistake for fiI AlbiYori.]) [Perhaps it is the same as is called buroS, (see this word below,) which may be a vulgar pronunciation; and if so, this may be the reason why the author of the Ḳ has added, contr. to his usual rule, “with fet-ḥ.”]

buroSN i. q. wazagapN [A lizard of the species called gecko, of a leprous hue, as its name brS indicates; so applied in the present day]; (TA;) and Oabuw bariySK↓, (M,) or Oabuw burayoSK↓, (TA,) is a surname of the same. (M, TA.) [See also baroSN; and see saAm-u OaboraSa, voce OaboraSu; and bariySapF.]

baraSN [Leprosy; particularly the malignant species thereof termed “leuce;”] a certain disease, (Ṣ, TA,) well known, (TA,) which is a whiteness; (Ṣ;) a whiteness incident in the skin; (M;) a whiteness which appears upon the exterior of the body, by reason of a corrupt state of constitution. (A, Ḳ.)
‡ What has become white, in a beast, in consequence of his being bitten. (Ḳ, TA.)
buroSapN † i. q. bal-uwqapN; (ISh;) pl. biraASN, (ISh, Ḳ,) which signifies White places, (ISh,) or portions distinct from the rest, (Ḳ,) in sand, which give growth to nothing. (ISh, Ḳ.)
The pl. also signifies † The alighting-places of the jinn, or genii: (Ḳ:) [reminding us of our fairy-rings:] in which sense, also, it is pl. of buroSapN. (TA.)
Also, the sing., † An aperture in clouds, or mist, through which the face of the sky is seen. (M, TA.)
biraSapN: see saAm-u OaboraSa, voce OaboraSu.

hom.sense: bariySN A shining, or glistening; syn. baSiySN (A, Ḳ) and bariyqN. (A.)
Also A certain plant, resembling the suEod [or cyperus], (AA, Ḳ,) growing in channels of running water. (AA.)
Oabuw bariySK: see buroSN.
Oabuw burayoSN: see buroSN.
Oabuw burayS is also the name of A certain bird, otherwise called blEp, [so written in the TA, without any syll. signs,] accord. to IKh, and mentioned in the Ḳ in art. blS. (TA.)

entry.sense: bariySapN A certain small reptile (daAb-apN SagiyrapN), smaller than the wazagap; when it bites a thing, the latter is not cured. (M, TA.) [See also buroSN; and see saAm-u OaboraSa, voce OaboraSu.]
OaboraSu [Leprous;] having the disease called baraSN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) fem. baroSaMCu: (M, Mṣb:) pl. buroSN (Mṣb, TA) and buroSaAnN. (TA.)

saAm-u OaboraSa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former word being decl., prefixed to the latter as governing it in the gen. case; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and saAm-u OaboraSa, as one word, the former being indecl. with fet-ḥ for its termination, and the latter being imperfectly decl., (Ṣ, Mṣb;) in this and in the former instance; (Mṣb;) and sam-u OaboraSa; (as in some copies of the Ḳ in art. sm;) i. q. Alwazagapu [The species of lizard described above, voce buroSN]: (M, and so in the JK and Ḳ in art. wzg:)
or such as are large, of the wazag [whereof wazagapN is the n. un.]: (A, Mṣb:) or [one] of the large [sorts] of the wazag: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) determinate, as a generic appellation: (Ṣ, TA:) Aṣ says, I know not why it is so called: (TA:) [the reason seems to be its leprous hue: see buroSN:] its blood and its urine have a wonderful effect when put into the orifice of the penis of a child suffering from difficulty in voiding his urine, (Ḳ, TA,) relieving him immediately; (TA;) and its head, pounded, when put upon a member, causes to come forth a thing that has entered into it and become concealed therein, such as a thorn and the like: (Ḳ:) the dual is saAm-aA OaboraSa: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the pl. is sawaAm-u OaboraSa, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) AbrS having no dual form nor pl.; (M;) or, (Ḳ,) or sometimes, (Mṣb,) or if you will you may say, (Ṣ,) Als-awaAm-u, without mentioning AbrS; and AlbiraSapu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AlOabaAriSu; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) without mentioning saAm-; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the last of these pls. being as though formed from a rel. n., [namely, OaboraSiI-N,] although without [the termination] p, like as they said AlmahaAlibu [for AlmahaAlibapu]. (M.)
AlOaboraSu The moon. (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [So called because of its mottled hue.] You say, bit-u laA muWonisiI Uil-aA AlOaboraSu [I passed the night, none but the moon cheering me by its presence]. (A, TA.)
Hay-apN baroSaMCu A serpent having in it, (Ḳ,) i. e., in its skin, (M, TA,) white places, distinct from the general colour. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
OaroDN baroSaMCu ‡ Land bare of herbage; (A;) of which the herbage has been depastured (Ḳ, TA) in some places, so that it has become bare thereof. (TA.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. baroTala, (inf. n. baroTalapN, TḲ,) He placed a long stone (biroTiylN) in the fore part (UizaMC, q. v.,) of his watering-trough. (Lth, Ḳ.)
[He gave him a biroTiyl, or bribe;] he bribed him. (Ḳ.) And buroTila He was bribed. (TA.)

entry.sense: Q. 2. tabaroTala He received a [biroTiyl, or] bribe. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: biroTiylN A long stone: pl. baraATiylN: (Ṣ:) or a broad stone: (TA in art. brm:) or a stone (Seer, A, Ḳ) of an oblong form (A, TA) a cubit in length, (Seer, TA,) or an iron, long, broad, and hard by nature, (Ḳ,) not such as is made long, or sharpened or made sharp-pointed, by men, (TA,) with which the millstone is pecked (tunoqaru [i. e., wrought into shape, and roughened in its surface, by pecking]): so says Lth: (TA:) to this is sometimes likened the muzzle, or fore part of the nose and mouth, of a she-camel of high breed: (Lth, TA:) [and hence,] it signifies also † the muzzle, or fore part of the nose and mouth, of an old bear: (TA:) some say that the dual signifies two elongated stones, of the hardest kind, slender, and sharp-pointed, with which the millstone is pecked (tunoqaru [explained above]). (TA.) Also, (Ḳ,) accord. to Sh, (TA,) A pickaxe, or stonecutter's pick; syn. miEowalN: (Sh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. as above: accord. to IAạr, what is called in Persian Asknh [app. a mistranscription, or a dial. var., of Uisokank]. (TA.)

A bribe; syn. riXowapN: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) app. mentioned in the Ḳ as an Arabic word; and if so, the pronunciation with fet-ḥ to the b is a vulgarism, since there is no such measure as faEoliylN: Abu-l-ʼAlà El-Ma'arree says that it is not known in this sense in the [classical] language of the Arabs; and it seems as though it were taken from the same word signifying “an oblong stone;” as though the bribe were likened to a stone that is thrown: (TA:) or it seems as though it were taken from the same word signifying a miEowal; because therewith a thing is got out; (Mṣb;) and so El-Munáwee asserts it to be: (TA:) pl. as above. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the phrase, Oaloqamahu AlbiroTiyla [He tipt him the bribe; conveyed it to him in like manner as one puts a morsel into another's mouth; somewhat like our phrase he greased his fist]. (TA.) And the saying, AlbaraATiylu tanoSuru AlOabaATiyli [Bribes render victorious false allegations]: (Mṣb, TA:) a prov. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: mubaroTilu Alr-aOosi A man having a long head. (A in art. kwz.)

hom.sense: 1. baraEa Aljabala He ascended, or ascended upon, the mountain. (TA.)
And baraEa SaAHibahu He was, or became, superior to his companion; he excelled him; (IAạr;) he overcame him. (Ḳ.)

baraEa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboraEu}; (Mṣb, MṢ, PṢ, [accord. to the TA, which is followed in the TḲ, _u, which is evidently a mistake,]) and baruEa, aor. _u {yaboruEu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and bariEa, aor. _a {yaboraEu}; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) inf. n. buruwEN, (M, Ḳ,) which is of baraEa, (TA,) and baraAEapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of baruEa [and is the more common]; (Mṣb, TA;) He excelled in knowledge, or courage, or other qualities: (Mṣb:) or he excelled his companions in knowledge, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he was, or became, accomplished, perfect, or complete, in every excellence, and in goodliness. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tbr-E biAlEaTaMCi He gave what was not incumbent, or obligatory, on him; he gave supererogatorily: (Ḳ:) or he gave gratuitously, unasked, or unbidden: (TA:) as though he affected baraAEap [or excellence] therein, and generosity. (Z, TA.) And tbr-E biAlOamori He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, disinterestedly; not seeking, or desiring, a compensation. (Mṣb.) And tbr-E biAljihaAdi [He engaged unbidden, or disinterestedly, in war against unbelievers]. (Mṣb in art. TwE.)
bariyEapN: see baAriEN.
baAriEN Anything overtopping. (IAạr.)

Excelling in knowledge, or courage, or other qualities: (Mṣb:) or excelling his companions in knowledge, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or accomplished, perfect, or complete, in every excellence, and in goodliness: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {baAriEapN}. (Ḳ.) And bariyEapN↓, applied to a woman, (IAạr,) Excelling in goodliness, or beauty, and in intelligence. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And baAriEapN, applied to a girl, Goodly, or beautiful. (TA.)
OamorN baAriEN A case, a state, or condition, or an affair, exalted, or of high estimation; (TA;) goodly, or comely. (Ḳ, TA.)

saEodN AlbaArEi A certain najom [or asterism]. (TA, [in which it is here said to be “of the Mansions,” i. e., of the Mansions of the Moon; but it seems that layosa, or the like, has been omitted by a copyist; for it is said in art. sEd, (q. v.,) on several authorities, to be not of the Mansions of the Moon.])
OaboraEu This is larger, bigger, or more bulky, than he, or it. (Ḳ, TA.)

faEalahu mutabar-iEFA He did it without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; supererogatorily: or gratuitously, unasked, or unbidden: or disinterestedly; not seeking, or desiring, a compensation: syn. mutaTaw-iEFA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Q. 1. baroEamati AlX-ajarapu The tree put forth its baraAEiym [pl. of buroEuwmN], (Ṣ,) or its buroEumap. (M, Ḳ.)
buroEumN: see what next follows.
buroEumapN: see what next follows.

buroEuwmN and buroEumN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and buroEuwmapN↓ and buroEumapN↓ (Ḳ) The calyx of the fruit, or produce, of a tree: (Ḳ:) and blossoms, or white blossoms, syn. naworN, (Ḳ TA,) before they open: (TA:) or flowers, (Ṣ, and Mṣb in explanation of the first word in art. zhr,) or the flower of a tree, (Ḳ,) before the opening thereof: (Ṣ, Mṣb ubi suprà, Ḳ:) pl. baraAEiymu. (Ṣ, TA.)
baraAEiymu also signifies The heads, or tops; or round, high, slender tops; or peaks; (XamaAriyx;) of mountains: (AZ, Ḳ:) sing. buroEuwmapN↓. (AZ, TA.)
buroEuwmapN: see buroEuwmN, in two places.

buroguwvN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also, accord. to Es-Suyootee, with fet-ḥ and with kesr to the first letter, and Dmr says the like; [so that it is app. written also baroguwvN, as it is commonly pronounced by the vulgar, though it is generally said that there is no word of this measure except SaEofuwq; and birogawovN, like birocawonN, for there is no word of the measure fiEoluwlN;] but each of these two forms requires proof; (MF;) [like the Hebr. בַּרְעש, which, accord. to Gesenius, is undoubtedly from an Æthiopic root signifying “to spring,” “to dance;” The flea;] a certain insect (duwayob-ap), resembling the HuroquwS; (TA;) well known: (Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {buroguwvapN}:] pl. baraAgiyvu. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense:
1. baraqa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboruqu}, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. buruwqN, (Ṣ,) or bariyqN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Ṣ,) and baroqN and baraqaAnN (Ḳ, TA, but in the CK buruwqN, as in the Ṣ,)
It (a thing, Mgh, Ḳ, a sword, &c., Ṣ and the dawn, Ḳ, TA) shone, gleamed, or glistened. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.)

Also said of a cloud, aor. as above, inf. n. bariyqN and baroqF and baraqaAnN, It gleamed or shone [with lightning]; and so Abrq↓, (JK,) and tbr-q↓. (Ḳ in art. Hlj.) And baraqati Als-amaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. baraqaAnN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baroqN (Mṣb, TA) and buruwqN, (Ḳ,) The sky lightened; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Abrqt↓: (AO, AA, Ḳ:) or gleamed or shone [with lightning]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or lightened much before rain; as also Abrqt↓. (TA in art. rEd.) And baraqa Albaroqu The lightning appeared. (Ḳ.)

And [hence] said of a man, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or raEada wabaraqa, (Ṣ,) ‡ He threatened; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or he threatened with evil; (Mṣb;) [or he threatened and menaced;] or he frightened (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. rEd) and threatened; (Ṣ in that art.;) and Abrq↓ signifies the same; (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so OaroEada waOaboraqa: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aṣ, ArEd and Abrq are not allowable. (TA, and Ṣ in art. rEd, q. v.) But baraqato, inf. n. baroqN, said of a woman, (Ḳ,) or raEadato wabaraqato, (Ṣ,) means ‡ She beautified (Ṣ and A in art. rEd, and Ḳ) and adorned herself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [as also tbr-qt↓, (occurring in the Ḳ in art. Alq, coupled with its syn. tazay-anat,)] and showed, or presented, herself, (A in art. rEd, and TA,) liI to me: (A in art. rEd:) or she exhibited her beauty intentionally: (TA:) and br-qt↓ means the same, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboriyqN; (TA;) and so Abrqt↓: (Ḳ:) you say, Abrqt↓ biwajohihaA wasaAYiri jisomihaA ‡ She beautified herself in her face and the rest of her person: (Lḥ, TA:) and Abrqt↓ Eano wajohihaA ‡ She showed her face. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

Also, said of a star, or an asterism, It rose. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) One says, laA OafoEaluhu maA baraqa Aln-ajomu fiI Als-amaMCi I will not do it as long as the star, or asterism, [by which may be meant the asterism of the Pleiades,] rises in the sky. (Lḥ, TA.)

baraqa AlbaSaru, (Ṣ,) or baSaruhu, (Ḳ,) The eye or eyes, or his eye or eyes, glistened, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) being raised, or fixedly open: (Ṣ:) or became raised, or fixedly open: occurring in the Ḳur [lxxv. 7], accord. to one reading: (Fr, TA:) or the eye, or his eye, became open by reason of fright. (TA.) bariqa has a different meaning, which see below. (Ṣ.)

baraqato, said of a she-camel, She put her tail between her thighs, making it to cleave to her belly, without being pregnant: (IAạr, TA:) or she raised her tail, and feigned herself pregnant, not being so; as also Abrqt↓, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Abrqt bicanbihaA: (TA:) or Abrqt signifies she smote with her tail at one time upon her vulva and another time upon her buttocks; and also, she feigned herself pregnant, not being so. (JK.)

bariqa He feared, so that he was astonished or amazed or stupified, at seeing the gleam of lightning: (TA voce baHira:) or his (a man's) sight became confused in consequence of his looking at lightning. (Bḍ in lxxv. 7.) And hence, (Bḍ ibid.,) bariqa AlbaSaru, (Ṣ, Bḍ,) or baSaruhu, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboraqu}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and baraqa, aor. _u {yaboruqu}; (Ḳ;) or the latter has [only] a meaning explained above; (Ṣ;) inf. n. baraqN, which is of the former verb; (Ṣ;) accord. to the Ḳ, baroqN; but this is wrong; (TA;) and [of the latter verb,] buruwqN; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) The eye or eyes, or his eye or eyes, became dazzled, so as not to close, or move, the lid, or lids: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or became confused, so as not to see. (Ḳ.) bariqa baSaruhu signifies also His eye or eyes, or his sight, became weak: whence bariqato qadamaAhu His two feet became weak. (TA.) Also bariqa alone, (TA,) inf. n. baraqN, (Fr, Ḳ, TA,) He (a man, TA) was frightened; or he feared, or was afraid: (Fr, Ḳ, TA:) and he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ḳ.)

bariqa said of a skin, aor. _a {yaboraqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. baraqN, (JK,) so in the O, in which, as in the Ḳ, the part. n., being bariqN, indicates that the verb is like fariHa; (TA;) and baraqa, (Ḳ,) so in the L, (TA,) aor. _u {yaboruqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baroqN and buruwqN; thus in the L, which indicates that the verb is like naSara; (TA;) It became affected by the heat so that its butter melted and became decomposed, (Aṣ, JK, Ḳ,) and did not become compact. (Ḳ.)

baraqa TaEaAmFA, (JK,) or baraqahu bizayotK Oawo samonK (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboruqu}, (JK,) inf. n. baroqN (JK, Ṣ) and buruwqN, (L,) He poured upon the food, (JK,) or put into it, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) somewhat, (JK,) or a small quantity, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of olive-oil (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) or of clarified butter. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And baraqotu lahu I made his food [somewhat] greasy for him with clarified butter. (TA.) And OuboruquwA AlmaMCi bizayotK Pour ye upon the water a little olive-oil. (Ṣ.)

bariqati Alganamu, aor. _a {yaboraqu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. baraqN, (Ṣ,) The sheep, or goats, had a complaint in their bellies from eating the barowaq: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, AlUibilu the camels. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. br-q biEayonayohi, (JK,) or br-q baSarahu, (TA,) He glistened with his eyes by reason of looking hard, or intently. (JK, TA.*) And br-q Eayonayohi, inf. n. taboriyqN, He opened his eyes wide, and looked sharply, or intently. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
br-qt, said of a woman: see 1.
And br-q He decorated, or adorned, his place of abode. (El-Muärrij, Ḳ.)
bar-aqota waEar-aqota Thou madest a sign with a thing, that had nothing to verify it, [app. meaning thou madest a false display, or a vain promise,] and didst little (IAạr.)
Also br-q, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He (a man) journeyed far. (El-Muärrij Ḳ.)
br-q fiI AlmaEaASiI He persisted, or persevered, in acts of disobedience. (El-Muärrij, Ḳ.)
br-q biIa AlOamoru The affair was unattainable, or impracticable, to me. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in eight places.
Abrq, (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Abrq bisayofihi, (JK,) said of a man, (Aboo-Naṣr, JK, Ṣ,) He made a sign with his sword [by waving it about so as to make it glisten]. (Aboo-Naṣr, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Abrq He betook himself, or directed his course, towards the lightning. (TA.)
He entered into [a tract wherein was] lightning. (TA.)
He saw lightning. (TA.) Tufeyl uses the phrase Oaboraqona Alxariyfa as meaning They (women borne in vehicles upon camels) saw the lightning of [the season, or the rain, called] the xryf. (AAF, TA.)
He was smitten, or assailed, or affected, by lightning. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Abrqhu AlfazaEu [app. Fright, or fear, made him to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right way: see bariqa]. (TA.)
[And hence, perhaps,] Abrq AlS-ayoda He roused the game, or chase. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
10. Astbrq It (a place, and the horizon,) shone, or gleamed, with lightning. (TA.)

baroqN [Lightning;] what gleams in the clouds, (TA,) or, from the clouds; from baraqa [in the first of the senses explained above], said of a thing, inf. n. [baroqN and] bariyqN: (Bḍ in ii. 18:) or an angel's smiting the clouds, and putting them in motion, in order that they may become propelled, so that thou seest the fires [issue from them]: (Mujáhid, Ḳ:) or a whip of light with which the angel drives the clouds: (I’Ab, TA:) sing. of buruwqN, i. e., of the brwq of the clouds: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it has no pl., being originally an inf. n. (Bḍ ubi suprà.) baroqu Alxul-abi and baroqu xul-abK and baroqN xul-abN signify That [lightning] which is without rain. (Ṣ. [See also art. xlb])

hom.sense: buroqN [Lizards of the species called] DibaAb, pl. of Dab-N. (IAạr, Ḳ.) It is app. pl. of baruwqN or of Oaboraqu: [more probably, I think, of the former; from the raising of the tail, which is a habit of those lizards.]
See also buroqapN.

entry.sense: baraqN A lamb; syn. HamalN [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a Persian word, (Ṣ,) arabicized; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) originally baraho: (Ḳ:) pl. [of mult.] buroqaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and biroqaAnN and [of pauc.] OaboraAqN. (Ḳ.)
bariqN [part. n. of bariqa: and particularly explained as meaning] A skin affected by the heat so that its butter melts and becomes decomposed, (JK, O, Ḳ,) and does not become compact. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baroqapN [app. an inf. n. of un., signifying A flash of lightning]. (M, TA in art. wbS.)
A fit of confusion, or perplexity, affecting one in such a manner that he is unable to see his right course. (Ḳ,* TA.)

buroqapN A quantity of lightning: (Bḍ in xxiv. 43, TA:) pl. buroqN↓; (TA;) or [this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.; or, probably, it is a mistranscription, and] the pl. is buraqN, also pronounced buruqN. (Bḍ ubi suprà.)

Rugged ground in which are stones and sand and earth mixed together, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) the stones thereof mostly white, but some being red, and black, and the earth white and of a whitish dust-colour, and sometimes by its side are meadows (rawoD); (TA;) as also Oaboraqu↓ and baroqaMCu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a portion of such land (OaroD) as is termed baroqaMCu↓, which consists of tracts containing black stones mixed with white sand, and which, when spacious, is termed Oaboraqu↓: (JK:) [and] a mountain mixed with sand; as also Oaboraqu↓: (IAạr, TA:) the pl. of buroqapN is buraqN (Ḳ, TA) and biraAqN; (JK, Ṣ;) and that of Abrq↓ is OabaAriqu, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) after the manner of a subst., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it; (TA;) and that of brqMC↓ is baroqaAwaAtN. (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The buraq of the country of the Arabs are more than a hundred; and are distinguished by particular adjuncts, as buroqapN AlOavomaAdi and buroqapu AlOajaAwili, &c. (Ḳ.) One says qunofucu buroqapK [A hedge-hog of a brqp], like as one says Dab-u kudoyapi (Ṣ)
[The colour denoted by the epithet Oaboraqu: in a mountain, a mixture of blackness and whiteness: see HaqobaMCu, voce OaHoqabu.]
Paucity of grease or gravy (JK, TA) in food. (TA.)
buroqaAnN Shining much in the body: (JK, Ḳ:) applied to man. (JK.)
Locusts when they become yellow, and have variegated stripes or streaks: (JK:) or locusts that are variegated (Ḳ TA) with white and black: (TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {buroqaAnapN}. (Ḳ.)
[See also baraqN of which it is a pl.]

entry.sense: buroquwqN, (Ḳ,) with damm, (TA,) [vulg. baroquwq, The plum; or] small Uij-aAS [or plums]; (Ḳ;) known in Syria by the name of jAbzk: (TA:) and (as some say, TA) the miXomiX [or apricot]: a post-classical word [probably arabicized from the Persian baroquwqo, which is applied to both the fruits above mentioned]. (Ḳ.)

AlburaAqu A certain beast which Moḥammad rode on the night of the ascension [to heaven]; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) or which the apostles ride in ascending to heaven; resembling a mule; (Mṣb;;) or less than the mule, but greater than the ass: (Ḳ:) so called because of the intense whiteness of his hue, and his great brightness; or because of the quickness of his motion; in respect of both of which he is likened to lightning. (TA.)

baruwqN a she-camel raising her tail, and feigning herself pregnant, not being so; as also muboriqu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and baAriqN↓ a she-camel Putting her tail between her thighs, making it to cleave to her belly, not being pregnant: (IAạr, TA:) pl. of the first buroqN (TA;) and of the second mabaAriyqu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The Arabs say, daEoniI mino takocaAbika wataOovaAmika XawalaAna Albaruwqi [Let me alone and cease from they lying and thy sin like the she-camel's raising of her tail and feigning herself pregnant when she is not so]: XwlAn being in the accus. case as an inf. n.: i. e., thou art in the predicament of the she-camel that raises her tail so as to make one imagine her to be pregnant when she is not so. (TA.) The pl. buroqN is also applied to scorpions, as meaning Raising their tails like the she-camel termed brwq (TA.)
Also, applied to a man, Fearful, or timid; (JK;) or cowardly. (TA.)

barwaqN A certain kind of plant (JK, Ṣ) which camels do not feed upon except in cases of necessity; (JK;) a small, feeble tree, which, when the sky becomes clouded, grows green: (Ḳ:) n. un. witIh p: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it was described by an Arab of the desert to AḤn as follows: a feeble, juicy plant, having slender branches, at the heads of which are small envelopes (qamaAEiylu SigaArN) like chick-peas, in which is a kind of black grain: its feebleness is such that it withers on the spot when the sun becomes hot upon it: and nothing feeds upon it; but men, when they are afflicted with dearth, or drought, express from it a bitter juice, then work it together, or knead it, with habiyd [or colocynths, or the pulp, or seeds, thereof], or some other thing, and eat it; but it is not eaten alone, because it occasions excitement: it is one of the plants that are plentiful in time of drought and scarce in time of fruitfulness; when copious rain falls upon it, it dies; and when we see it to have become abundant, and coarse, or rough, we fear drought: accord. to another of the Arabs of the desert, the barowaqap is a bad kind of herb, or leguminous plant, that grows among the first of the herbs, or leguminous plants: it has a reed like the sbAT [so I render lhA qSbp mvl AlsbAT, but I thing that the right reading is, lahaA quDubN mivolu Als-iyaATi it has twigs like whips, agreeably with the description next preceding, in which it is said to have slender branches,] and a black fruit, or produce. (TA.) Hence, OaXokaru mino barowaqapK [More grateful than a barwakah]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because it grows green when it sees the clouds, (Ṣ,) or by means of the least moisture falling from the sky: (TA:) a prove. (Ṣ.) And OaDoEafu mino barowaqapK [Weaker than a barwakah]. (TA.)
bariyqN [accord. to the Mgh and Ḳ an inf. n. of baraqa, but accord. to the Ṣ a simple subst.,] A shining, gleaming, glistening, glitter, lustre, brilliancy, or splendour. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

bariyqapN Milk upon which is poured a little grease or clarified butter: (ISK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or food in which is milk: and such as has a little clarified butter, and grease, put into it: (TA:) or food that has a little olive-oil poured upon it: (JK:) or condiment in which is put a little olive-oil or grease: (L:) pl. baraAYiqu; (JK, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) with which tabaAriyqu↓ [pl. of taborwqN↓] is syn., (L, TA,) applied to food (Ṣ, TA) in which is put a little olive-oil or clarified butter: (Ṣ:) or taborwqN↓ signifies the grease in a cooking-pot: and water with a little olive-oil poured upon it: and tabaAriyqu↓ is its pl. (JK.)
bar-aAqN Shining, gleaming, or glistening, much, or intensely. (TA.) See also UiboriyqN, and baAriqN
fatFI bar-aAqu Alv-anaAyaA A young man whose middle pairs of teeth are beautiful and bright, glistening, when he smiles, like lightning: meant to imply cheerfulness of countenance. (TA.)
bar-aAqapN A woman characterized by beauty and splendour or brilliancy [of complexion or skin]: (Ḳ * TA:) or, as some say, who shows her beauty intentionally. (TA.) [See UiboriyqN.]

barowaAqN A certain plant also called xunovaI [i. e. the asphodel, called by both these names in the present day]: the eating of its fresh, juicy stalk, boiled with olive-oil and vinegar, counteracts jaundice; and the smearing with its root, or lower part, removes the two kinds of bahaq [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
baAriqN Shining, gleaming, or glistening. (Mgh.)

Clouds (saHaAbN) having, or containing, [or emitting,] lightning. (Ṣ.) You say also saHaAbapN baAriqapN [A cloud having, or emitting, lightning]: (Ṣ, TA:) and sHAbp bar-aAqapN↓ signifies the same [but in an intensive manner: see bar-aAqN]. (TA.)

baAriqapN ‡ Swords: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) so called because of their shining, or glistening: (TA:) pl. bawaAriqu; (JK, Ḥam p. 306;) applied to swords and other weapons. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) Hence the trad. of 'Ammàr, Aljan-apu taHota AlbaAriqapi [Paradise is beneath the swords]; (JK, TA;) meaning, in warring in the cause of God. (JK.) You also say, raOayotu AlbaAriqapa meaning I saw the shining, or glistening, of the weapons. (Lḥ, TA.)
See also baruwqN.

hom.sense: baworaqN, (JK, Mgh,) with fet-ḥ to the b (Mgh,) or buwraqN., with damm, (Ḳ,) A certain, thing, or substance, that is put into dough, (JK, Mgh, TA,) and causes it to become inflated; (Mgh;) or into flour; (TA voce buwrakN;) [or this is a particular kind thereof, as appears from what follows: accord. to Golius, nitrum and aphronitrum: but] it is of four kinds; maAYiI-N [or the water-kind], and jabaliI-N [or the mountain-kind], and OaromaniI-N [or Armenian], and miSoriI-N [or Egyptian], which is the naToruwn [q. v., i. e. natron]: (Ḳ:) the best thereof is the ArmnI; and this is said to be meant by the term when it is used absolutely: this is called also bwrqu AlS-aAgapi [a term now applied to borax, as is bwrq alone, and miloHu AlS-aAgapi], because it polishes silver well [or because of its use in soldering]: the dust-coloured kind thereof is called bwrqu Alxab-aAziyna [the bwrq of the bakers, or makers of bread]: the nTrwn is the red kind thereof: and there is a kind thereof having an oily quality: and a kind consisting of thin butyraceous fragments; and this, if light and hard, is the UiforiyqiI: and the best thereof is that which is produced in Egypt: (TA:) bruised, or powdered, the belly is smeared with it, near to a fire, and it expels worms: and moistened with honey or with oil of jasmine, the male organs of generation are anointed with it, for it is excellent for the venereal faculty. (Ḳ.)
Also A man in whom one does not trust, or confide: pl. bawaAriqu. (JK.)

entry.sense: buwriqiI-N [or baworaqiI-N] A seller of buwraq [or baworaq]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Oaboraqu A rope (Habol) having two colours; (Ṣ, O;) twisted with a black strand and a white strand: (JK:) and in like manner, (JK,) a mountain (jabal, JK, Ḳ) in which are two colours, (Ḳ, TA,) black and white: (TA:) and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or,”) anything having blackness and whiteness together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say tayosN OaboraqN and EanozN baroqaMCu [A black and white he-goat and she-goat]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and XaApN baroqaMCu a ewe whose white wool is cleft, or divided, by black flocks [or streaks]: (Ḳ:) Oaboraqu and baroqaMCu applied to sheep or goats are like Oabolaqu and baloqaMCu applied to beasts of the equine kind, and OaboqaEu and baqoEaMCu to dogs. (Lḥ, TA.)

baroqaMCu is also a name given to An eye; (Ṣ, M;) because it has blackness and whiteness mingled in it: (M, TA:) dual baroqaAwaAni. (TA.) And EayonN baroqaMCu signifies An eye black in the iris, with whiteness [of the rest] of the bulb. (TA.)
rawoDapN baroqMCu A meadorc, or garden, in which are two colours. (TA.)
See also buroqapN. in seven places.
Oaboraqu also signifies A certain bird. (Tekmileh, Ḳ.)
And [the pl.] buroqN is used as a name for The [locusts, or crickets, termed] janaAdib. (IB, TA.)
Also A certain Persian medicine, good for the memory. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

UiboriyqN a Persian word, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) arabicized, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally Mbo riyzo (CK [in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the TA, incorrectly, Mb riI]) [A ewer, such as is used for wine, and also such as is used for water to be poured on the hands; each having a long and slender spout, and a handle;] a well-known vessel; (TA;) a vessel having a spout (Mgh, and Bḍ and Jel in lvi. 18) and a handle: (Bḍ and Jel ibid:) accord. to Kr, a kuwz; and so says AḤn in one place; but in another he says that it is like a kwz: (TA:) [it is somewhat like a kwz with the addition of a spout:] pl. OabaAriyqu (Ṣ, Mṣb) [and sometimes OabaAriqapN].

A sword such as is termed bar-aAq↓; (Ḳ;) i. e. (TA) a sword that shines, gleams, or glistens, much, or intensely: (Ṣ, Kr:) or simply a sword: or, as some say, a bow: (JK:) or it signifies also a bow in which are talaAmiyE [or places differing in colour from the rest, and, app., glistening]: (Ḳ:) thus, accord. to Az, in a verse of ʼAmr Ibn-Aḥmar: but correctly, accord. to Ṣgh, it has there the first of the significations explained in this sentence: and it is said, also, that sayofN UiboriyqN signifies a sword having much lustre, and much diversified with wavy marks or streaks, or in its grain. (TA.)

A woman who is beautiful, and splendid, or brilliant, (Lḥ, JK, Ḳ, TA,) in colour [or complexion]: (Lḥ, TA:) or, as some say, who shows her beauty intentionally. (TA.) [See also bar-aAqapN (voce bar-aAqN).]

entry.sense: OubayoriqN dim. of UisotaboraqN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

UisotaboraqN, (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) sometimes with the conjunctive A, (TA,) Thick diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (Ed-Dahhak, Ṣ, Ḳ, and so Bḍ and Jel in xviii. 30, &c.:) or dybAj made [or interwoven] with gold: (Ḳ:) or closely-woven, thick, beautiful dybAj made [or interwoven] with gold: (TA:) or closely- woven cloths, or garments, of silk, like dybAj: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or thick silk: (IAth, TA:) or a red thong cut from an untanned skin (qid-apN HamoraMCu), as though it were [composed of] pieces of bow-strings, or chords: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) it is an arabicized word, (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) form UisotarowahN, (IDrd, Ḳ,) which is Syriac; (IDrd, TA;) or from the Persian, (Ṣ, TA,) in which sitabor and Uisotabor signify “thick,” absolutely, whence sitaboraho and Uisotaboraho are particularly applied to signify “thick dybAj, and then the latter is arabicized by substituting q for the h: so says Esh-Shiháb El-Khafájee: or the A and s and t are augmentative, and it is mentioned in the present art. in the Ṣ and Ḳ as though this were the case, agreeably with the form of its dim., which is said by J and in the Ḳ to be OubayoriqN↓; for in forming the dim., a word is reduced to its root. (TA.)

maboraqN [A shining, gleaming, or glistening: or a time thereof]. You say, jaACa Einoda maboraqi AlS-uboHi [He came at the shining,, &c., or at the time of the shining, &c., of the dawn; or] when the dawn shone, or gleamed, or glistened. (Ḳ, TA. [In the latter, mbrq is said to be here a meemee inf. n.])
muboriqN: see baruwqN.

Q. 1. broqaXahu, (Ṣ, A, TA,) inf. n. baroqaXapN, (TA,) He variegated it with divers, or different, colours; (Ṣ, TA;) from Oabuw baraAqiXa, the bird so called: (Ṣ:) or he adorned him, or it. (A.) [See also baroqaXapN, below.]
Hence, baroqaXa qawolahu † He embellished his saying. (Ḥar p. 235.)

Q. 2. tabaroqaXa He adorned himself (A, Ḳ) with various colours. (Ḳ.) You say, tabaroqaXa lanaA He adorned himself with various colours for us: (Ḳ:) or with various colours of every kind. (TA.) And tabaroqaXato She assumed various colours: or she varied in dispositions: syn. talaw-anato. (A.) And tbrqX Albayotu The house, or chamber, or tent, became variegated. (TA.) And tbrqXt AlbilaAdu The countries became adorned with various colours; from Oabuw baraAqiXa. (TA.)

biroqiXN A certain bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) different from that called Oabuw baraAqiXa, (Ḳ, accord. to the TA, [for we there read TaAYirN Mxaru; the bird called Abw brAqX having been mentioned before; but in the CK, in the place of Mxaru, we find OaxoDaru, i. e., green;]) of small size, (Ṣ, TA,) that assumes various colours, of the kind called Hum-ar, (TA,) like the sparrow, (Ṣ, TA,) and called XuroXuwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) by the people of El-Ḥijáz: (Ṣ, TA:) but Az states his having heard certain of the Arabs of the desert call it Abw brAqX. (TA.)
baroqaXapN The diversity of colour of that which is termed OaroqaXu. (Ḳ.) [See also 1.]

Oabuw baraAqiXa A certain bird that assumes various colours; (Ṣ;) a small wild bird, like the qanofuc [or hedge-hog, but qunofuc is probably a mistranscription for qunobur, or lark], the upper part of whose feathers is dust-coloured (Oagobaru, as in the Ḳ, accord. to the TA), or white (Oagar-u, as in some copies of the Ḳ), and the middle red, and the lower part black, so that when it is roused, or provoked, it ruffles its feathers and becomes variously changed in colour: (Lth, Ḳ:) or a certain bird that is found in the trees called EiDaAh, and the colour of which is between blackness and whiteness, having six qawaAdim [or primary feathers], three on each side, heavy in the rump, that makes a noise with its wings when it flies, and assumes various colours: (IKh:) a certain variegated bird. (TA in art. Abw.)
[Hence,] huwa Oabuw baraAqiXa † He is varying, or variable, in dispositions. (A, TA.)
AljaAru AlbaraAqiXiy-u The neighbour that is variable in his actions; like AljaAru AlyarobuwEiII-u. (IAạr, TA in art. jwr.)
Q. 1. baroqaEahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. baroqaEapN, (TA,) He attired him with a buroquE: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and baroqaEa AlmaroOapa he attired the woman with a buroquE (Mṣb.)

baroqaEa liHoyatahu [He veiled his beard with a buroquE;] He assumed the guise of such as wear the buroquE; (TA;) i. e. SaAra maOobuwnFA [he became effeminate, or a catamite]. (Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
Oalamo tara qayosFA qayosa EayolaAna baroqaEato
liHaAhaA wabaAEato nabolahaA biAlmagaAzili
[Dost thou no see that Keys, Keys-'Eylan, have veiled their beards, and sold their arrows for spindles?]. (TA.)
baroqaEa fulaAnFA biAlEaSaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He struck such a one with the staff, or stick, between his ears, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it became like the buroquE upon his head. (TA.)
Q. 2. tabaroqaEa He attired himself with a buroquE (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and tabaroqaEato she (a women) attired herself with a buroquE. (Mṣb.)
buroqaEN: see what next follows.

buroquEN (IAạr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buroqaEN↓ (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but some disallow this latter, (Mṣb,) and buroquwEN↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but AḤát disallows this, as well as the second, (TA,) A thing pertaining to women and to horses or similar beasts, (Ḳ,) or to horses or similar beasts and to the women of the Arabs of the desert; (Ṣ;) a thing with which a woman veils her face; (Mṣb;) having in it two holes for the eyes: (Lth:) a small piece of cloth, or rag, pierced for the eyes, worn by horses or similar beasts and by the women of the Arabs of the desert: (Mgh:) [or, accord. to the general fashion of the present time, a long strip of cotton or other cloth, black, blue, or of some other colour, or white, concealing the whole of the face of the woman wearing it, except the eyes, and reaching nearly to the feet, suspended at the top by a narrow band, or other fastening, which passes up the middle of the forehead, and which is sewed, as are also the two upper corners, to a band which is tied round the head, beneath the head-veil: (see my “Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians,” ch. i.:)] buroqaEapN↓, if correct, is a more particular term: (Mgh:) the pl. is baraAqiEu. (Lth, Mṣb.) [See niqaAbN.]
[AlburoquEu The curtain of the door of the Kaabeh.]
See also biroqiEu.
biroqaEu: see what next follows.

biroqaEu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) imperfectly decl., (Ṣ, TA,) and biroqaEu↓, (Fr, Az, Ibn-ʼAbbád,) of a rare form, like hijoraE, (Fr, Az,*) or AlbiroqiEu and AlburoquEu↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) but perhaps this last is a mistranscription, for biroqaEu, (TA,) a name of The heaven, or sky: (Fr:) or the seventh heaven: (AAF, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the fourth heaven: (Lth, Az, Ḳ:) or the first heaven; (Ḳ;) i. e. the lowest heaven: IDrd says, so they assert; and in like manner says IF;
and he says, the b is augmentative, the radical letters being r q E, for every heaven is termed raqiyEN, and the heavens [together] are termed OaroqiEapN: (TA:) or the lowest heaven is termed Alr-aqiyEu. (Ṣ, TA.) [See an ex. voce sadirN.]
buroqaEapN: see buroquEN.
buroquwEN: see buroquEN.

farasN mubaroqaEN, (TA,) or farasN Oagar-N mubaroqaEN, (Mgh,) A horse having what is termed gur-apN mubaroqiEapN: (TA:) or a horse having the whole of his face white. (Mgh.) And XaApN mubaroqaEapN A sheep, or ewe, having the head white. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

gur-apN mubaroqiEapN A blaze, or whiteness, on the face of a horse, occupying the whole of his face, except that he looks (yanoZuru [for which yunoZaru is erroneously substituted in the CK]) in blackness; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) [i. e.] this whiteness passing downwards to the cheeks without reaching to the eyes. (L, TA.)

1. baraka, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboruku}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. buruwkN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and taboraAkN, (Ḳ,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) i. q. AisotanaAxa [i. e. He lay down, or kneeled and lay down, upon his breast, with his legs folded]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he made his breast to cleave to the ground; (Mgh;) he fell upon his barok, i. e. breast; (Mṣb;) he threw his brk, i. e. breast, upon the ground; (TA;) and in like manner, br-k↓, (TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) inf. n. taboriykN. (TA.) And barakati Aln-aEaAmapu The ostrich lay upon its breast. (TA.) And baraka is also said of a lion, and of a man. (Ḳ voce rbD.) [Of the latter, one also says, baraka EalaI rukobatayohi He fell, or set himself, upon his knees; he kneeled.] The buruwk of a man praying, which is forbidden, is The putting down the hands before the knees, after the manner of the camel [when he lies down; for the latter falls first upon his knees, and then upon his stiflejoints]. (Mgh.)

Hence, i. e., from the verb said of a camel, inf. n. buruwkN, (TA,) He, or it, (i. e. anything, Ṣ,) was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, or fixed; continued, remained, or stayed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in a place: (TḲ:) [and so, app., with _i for its aor.; for] you say, baraka liloqitaAli, aor. _i {yaboriku}, [He was, or became, firm,, &c., for the purpose of fighting,] and in like manner barika, aor. _a {yaboraku}. (TA. [See also a similar signification of 8.])
† It (the night) was, or became, long, or protracted; as though it did not quit its place. (A and TA in art. qEs.)
See also 8, in two places.

hom.sense: 2: see 1.

taboriykN also signifies The praying for barakap, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) for a man, &c. (TA.) You say, bar-akotu Ealayohi, inf. n. taboriykN, I said to him, baAraka Qll-eha Ealayoka [or fiyka, &c., God bless thee!, &c.]. (TA.) And br-k ElI AlT-aEaAmi He prayed for, or invoked, a blessing on the food. (TḲ.)
3. bArk Ealayohi He kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) namely, an affair, (TA in art. HfZ,) or commerce, or traffic, &c. (Lḥ, TA.)

bArk Qll-ehu fiyka, (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and laka, and Ealayoka, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and baArakaka, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaArakapN, (TḲ,) [God bless, beatify, felicitate, or prosper, thee;] God put in thee, (TA,) give thee, make thee to possess, (T, Ḳ,) barakap [i. e. a blessing, good of any kind, prosperity or good fortune, increase,, &c.]. (TA, TḲ.) baAriko EalaI muHam-idK waEalaI Mli muHam-adK (in a trad., TA,) means Continue Thou, or perpetuate Thou, (O God,) to Moḥammad and to the family of Moḥammad the eminence and honour which Thou hast given them: (Ḳ, TA:) [or still bless or beatify, or continue to bless or beatify, Moḥammad, &c.: though it may well be rendered simply bless or beatify, &c.:] Az says that it is from baraka said of a camel, meaning “he lay down upon his breast in a place and clave thereto.” (TA.) And Aall-ehuma baAriko lanaA fiI Almawoti, in another trad., means [O God, bless us] in the state to which death will bring us. (TA.) The Arabs say to the beggar, buwrika fiyka [Mayest thou be blest; and, in the present day, Aall-eh yubaArik fiyk God bless thee]; meaning thereby to repel him; not to pray for him: and by reason of frequency of usage of this phrase, they have made buwrik↓ a noun: a poet [in Ḥar XryX AlEdwI (app. Sherees, not Shereesh, El-'Adawee), in the TA Aboo-Fir'own,] says,
taZun-u Oan-a buwrikFA yakofiyniI
UicaA xarajotu baAsiTFA yamiyniI
[She imagines that the saying “Mayest thou be blest” will suffice me when I go forth stretching out my right hand for an alms]. (Ḥar p. 378. [This verse is differently cited in the TA; for there, instead of tZn- and xrjt, we find tuHib-u and gadawotu.])
[You also say of a man, bArk fiyhi, and lahu, &c., meaning He blessed him; i. e. he prayed God to bless him.]
See also 6.

4. Abrkhu He made him (namely, a camel,) to lie down [or kneel and lie down] upon his breast. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Oaborakotuhu fabaraka I made him to lie down upon his breast, and he lay down upon his breast: but this is rare: the more common phrase is Oanoxatuhu faQsotan-Axa. (Ṣ.)
See also 8.
maA Oaborakahu [How blessed is he, or it!] is an instance of a verb of wonder with a passive meaning [and irregularly derived]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tbr-k bihi i. q. tayam-ana bihi [He had a blessing; and he was, or became, blest; by means of him, or it: so accord. to explanations of tabar-uko in the KL: but very often signifying he looked for a blessing by means of him, or it; he regarded him, or it, as a means of obtaining a blessing; he augured good from him, or it; tym-n bh being opposed to taXaO-ama bh; as in the Ḳ in art. Tyr, and in Bḍ in xvii. 14, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and tbArk↓ biAlX-ayoCi He augured good from the thing. (Lth, Ḳ.) One says so of a man. (Ḳ in art. msH.) And one says, tbr-k biQsomi Qll-ehi [He looked for a blessing by means of uttering the name of God, or saying bisomi Qll-ehi]. (Ksh, on the bsmlp;, &c.)

6. tbArk, accord. to Zj, is an instance of tafaAEala [as quasi-pass. of faAEala, i. e., of baAraka, like as tabaAEada is of baAEada,] from Albarakapu; and so say the lexicologists [in general]. (TA.) [Hence,] tbArk Qll-ehu means [Blessed is, or be, God; or] hallowed is, or be, God; or far removed is, or be, He from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; (Ḳ) or highly to be exalted, or extolled, is God; or highly exalted, or extolled, be He; (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA;) greatly to be magnified is God; or greatly magnified be He: (TA:) or i. q. baAraka↓, like qaAtala and taqAatala, except that faAEala is trans. and tafaAaEala is intrans.: (Ṣ:) accord. to IAmb, it means [that] one looks for a blessing by means of [uttering] his name (yutabar-aku biQsomihi) in every affair, or case: accord. to Lth, it is a phrase of glorification and magnification: (TA:) or tbArk signifies He is abundant in good; from Albarakapu, which is “abundance of good:” or He exceeds everything, and is exalted above it, in his attributes and his operations; because Albarakapu implies the meaning of increase, accession, or redundance: or He is everlasting; syn. daAma; from buruwku AlT-ayori EalaI AlmaMCi [“the continuing of the birds at the water”]; whence Albirokapu, because of the continuance of the water therein: the verb is invariable [when thus used, being considered as divested of all signification of time, or used in an optative sense]; and is not employed [in any of the senses above] otherwise than in relation to God: (Bḍ in xxv. 1:) it is an attributive peculiar to God. (Ḳ.)
tbArk biAlX-aIoCi: see 5.

hom.sense: 8. Abtrk He (a man) threw his barok [i. e. breast upon the ground (as the camel does in lying down), or upon some other thing]. (Ṣ.)
He (a sword-polisher) leaned upon the polishing-instrument, (Ḳ,) on one side. (TA.) And He (a horse) inclined on one side in his running. (TA: [accord. to which, this is from what next follows.])

He hastened, or sped, and strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in running: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and baraka↓, inf. n. buruwkN, (Ḳ,) or, as some say, this is a subst. from the former verb, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or exerted himself. (Ḳ.)

† It (a cloud) rained continually, or incessantly: (TA:) and Abtrkt Als-amaMCu † the sky rained continually; as also barakat↓, (Ḳ,) and Abrkt↓; but Ṣgh says that the first of these three is the most correct. (TA.) And Abtrkt Als-aHaAbapu ‡ The cloud rained vehemently. (Ḳ, TA.)

Abtrk fiI EiroDihi, and Ealayohi, ‡ He detracted from his reputation, censured him, or impugned his character, and reviled him, (Ḳ, TA,) and laboured in vituperating him. (TA.) AbtrkwA fiI AlHarobi ‡ They fell upon their knees in battle, and so fought one another. (Ḳ, TA. [See barakaMCu, below.])
Aibotarakotuhu I prostrated him, or threw him down prostrate, and put him beneath my barok [i. e. breast]. (Ṣ.)

barokN Many camels: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a herd of camels lying down upon their breasts: (Ḳ:) or any camels, males and females, lying down upon their breasts by the water or in the desert by reason of the heat of the sun or by reason of satiety: (TA:)
or all the camels of the people of an encampment, that return to them from pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to whatever number they may amount, even if they be thousands: (Ḳ:) one thereof is termed baArikN↓; (Ḳ;) the two words being like tajorN and taAjirN; (TA;) fem. baArikapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. buruwkN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., pl. of barokN. (Ṣ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and birokapN↓, which is with kesr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The breast (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a camel: (Mṣb, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) as some say, the former signifies the breast of the camel with which he crushes a thing beneath it: (TA:) and (Ḳ) accord. to Lth, (TA,) the latter is the part next to the ground of the skin of the breast of the camel; (or, as in the ʼEyn, of the skin of the belly of the camel and of the portion of the breast next to it; TA;) as also the former: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, the former is the middle of the breast, where [the two prominences of flesh called] the fahodataAni conjoin at their upper parts: (Ḥam p. 66:) or the latter is pl. of the former, like as HiloyapN is of HaloIN: or the former is of man; and the latter, of others: or the former is the interior of the breast; (or, as Yaạḳoob says, the middle of the breast; TA;) and the latter, the exterior thereof: (Ḳ:) or the former is the breast, primarily of the camel, because camels lie down (taboruku) upon the breast; and metaphorically of others. (Ḥam p. 145.)
Hence, barok AlX-itaMCi ‡ The first part of winter; (L, TA;*) and the main part thereof. (L.)

And hence, (TA,) Alburuwku is an appellation applied to ‡ The stars composing the constellation of the Scorpion, of which are Alz-ubaAnaI and AlUikoliylu and Alqalobu and AlX-awolapu [the 16th and 17th and 18th and 19th of the Mansions of the Moon], which rise [aurorally] in the time of intense cold; as is also Aljuvuwmu: (L, TA:*) or, accord. to IF, to a nawoC of the OanowaMC of AljawozaMC; because the AnwAC thereof do not set [aurorally] without there being during their period a day and a night in which the camels lie upon their breasts (taboruku) by reason of the vehemence of the cold and rain. (TA.)

entry.sense: burokN: see burakN.
birokN: see birokapN.

hom.sense: burakN Remaining fixed (baArikN↓) at, or by, a thing. (IAạr, Ḳ.) So in the phrase buraku EalaI janob AlUinaMCi [Remaining fixed at, or by, the side of the vessel], in a verse describing a [gluttonous] man, who swallows closely-consecutive mouthfuls. (IAạr.)
† Incubus, or nightmare; as also baAruwkN↓. (Ḳ.)
‡ A coward; and so ↓the latter word. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also, [and by contraction burokN↓, as in a verse cited in the M and TA in art. wbS,] A name of the month cuw AlHij-ap; (AA, Ḳ;) one of the ancient names of the months. (AA.)

entry.sense: burokapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or burakapN↓, (Mṣb,) A certain aquatic bird, white, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and small: (Ḳ:) [the former applied in Barbary, in the present day, to a duck:] pl. burakN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and burokaAnN and birokaAnN and [pl. of pauc.] OaboraAkN; (Ḳ;) or, in the opinion of ISd, AbrAk and brkAn are pls. of the pl. [burakN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: birokapN A mode, or manner, of buruwk [i. e. of a camel's kneeling and lying down upon the breast]; (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ;) a noun like rikobapN and jilosapN. (Ṣ, O.) One says, maA OaHosana birokapa hecihi Aln-aAqapi [How good is this she-camel's manner of lying down on the breast!]. (Ṣ.)
See also barokN.

A HawoD [i. e. watering-trough or tank]: (Ḳ:) or the like thereof, (Ṣ, TA,) dug in the ground, not having raised sides constructed for it above the surface of the ground; (TA;) and birokN↓ signifies the same: (Lth, Ḳ:) said to be so called because of the continuance of the water therein: (Ṣ:) pl. birakN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which Az found to be applied by the Arabs to the tanks, or cisterns, that are constructed with baked bricks, and plastered with lime, in the road to Mekkeh, and at its wateringplaces; sing. birokapN; and sometimes a brkp is a thousand cubits [in length], and less, and more: but the watering-troughs, or tanks, that are made for the rain-water, and not cased with baked bricks, are called OaSonaAEN, sing. SinoEN: (TA:) [birokapN often signifies a basin; a pool; a pond; and a lake: and in the present day, also a bay of the sea: and a reach of a river:] also a place where water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates, or remains long and becomes altered. (ISd, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: barakapN [A blessing; any good that is bestowed by God; and particularly such as continues and increases and abounds:] good, (Jel in xi. 50,) or prosperity, or good fortune, (Fr, Ḳ,) that proceeds from God: (Fr, in explanation of the pl. as used in the Ḳur xi. 76:) increase; accession; redundance; abundance, or plenty; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, Kull;) whether sensible or intellectual: and the continuance of divinely-bestowed good, such as is perceived by the intellect, in, or upon, a thing: (Kull:) or firmness, stability, or continuance, coupled with increase: (Ḥam p. 587:) or increasing good: (Bḍ in xi. 50:) and abundance of good; implying the meaning of increase, accession, or redundance: (Bḍ in xxv. 1:) or abundant and continual good: (so in an Expos. of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer, cited in the margin of a copy of the MṢ:) and, accord. to Az, God's superiority over everything. (TA.)
burakapN: see burokapN.
baraAki baraAki, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) like qaTaAmi, (Ḳ,) said in war, or battle, (Ṣ,) means OuborukuwA [Be ye firm, steady, or steadfast: in the CK, erroneously, AaborikuwA]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
baruwkN A woman that marries having a big son (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the age of puberty. (Ṣ.)

buruwkN A hasting, speeding, striving, labouring, or exerting oneself, in running; a subst. from Abtrk: and inf. n. of baraka in a sense in which it is explained above with the former verb. (Ḳ: but see 8.)
bariykN: see mubaAraka.

baraAkaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and buraAkaMCu (TA) Firmness, steadiness, or steadfastness, in war, or battle; (IDrd, Ṣ;) and a striving, labouring, or exerting oneself [therein]; from Alburuwku [inf. n. of baraka]: (Ṣ:) or a falling upon the knees in battle, and so fighting; as also baruwkaMCu↓. (Ḳ.)
Also The field of battle: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, brMkACu AlHarobi and baruwkaAWuhaA↓ signify the place to which the men of valour cleave. (TA.)
baruwkaMCu: see what next precedes, in two places.

br-akaAnN and bar-akaAniI-N (Fr, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baronakaAnN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the form commonly obtaining, (Mṣb,) and mentioned by El-Ghooree as well as J, (Mgh,) but disallowed by Fr, (Mgh, TA,) and baronakaAniI-N↓, (Ḳ,) but this also is disallowed by Fr, (Mgh, TA,) or, accord. to IDrd, baronakaMCu↓ and kisaMCN baronakAniI-N↓, but he says that it is not Arabic, (TA,) A kind of [garment such as is called] kisaMC, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) [similar to a burodap,] well-known; (Mṣb;) the black ksMC; (Fr, Mgh, Ḳ;) a woollen ksMC having two ornamental borders: (Fr, TA. in art. brnk:) [in Spanish barangane: (Golius:)] pl. [of all except the first two] baraAniku. (IDrd, Ḳ.) barakaAnN, without teshdeed, is not mentioned by any one. (Mgh.)
baronakaMCu and baronakaAnN and bronakaAniI-N: see bar-akaAnN, in four places.
baArikN and its fem. with p {baArikapN}: see barokN, in two places:
and see burakN.
buwrakN i. q. buwraqN; (Ḳ;) that is put into flour, (TA,) or into dough. (JK and Mgh and TA in explanation of the latter word.)
buwrik, as a noun: see 3.
baAruwkN: see burakN, in two places.

maborakN A place where camels lie upon their breasts: pl. mabaArikN. (Mṣb.) You say, fulaAnN layosa lahu miborakN jamalK [Such a one has not a place in which a camel lies; meaning he does not possess a single camel]. (Ṣ.)

mubaArakN is originally mubaArakN fiyhi [or lahu or Ealayohi, accord. to those who know not, or disallow, baAraka as trans. without a preposition; and signifies Blessed, beatified, felicitated, or prospered; gifted with, or made to possess, barakp, i. e. a blessing, any good that is bestowed by God, prosperity or good fortune, increase,, &c.]; (Mṣb;) abounding in good; (Ksh and Bḍ in iii. 90;) abounding in advantage or utility: (Bḍ in vi. 92 and 156, and xxxviii. 28, and 1. 9:) the pl. applied to irrational things is mubaArakaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say also bariykN↓ as meaning mubaAraka fiyhi: (Ḳ:) or TaEaAmN bariykN is as though meaning mubaArakN [i. e. Blessed food; or food in which is a blessing,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
mubotarikN, [in the CK mutabar-ikN,] applied to a man, ‡ Leaning, or bearing, upon a thing; applying himself [thereto] perseveringly, assiduously, or constantly. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also, applied to a cloud, ‡ Bearing down [upon the earth], and paring off the surface of the ground [by its vehement rain: see 8]. (TA.)
mutabaArikN [app. applied to God (see its verb)] High, or exalted. (Th, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baramahu: see 4, in two places.

barima, aor. _a {yaboramu}; and tbr-m↓; He was, or became, affected with disgust, loathing, or aversion; (M,* Ḳ;) he was vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind. (M.) You say, barima bihi, inf. n. baramN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tbr-m↓ bihi; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He was, or became, disgusted by it, or by reason of it; he loathed it; (T,*, M,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) he was vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind, by it, or by reason of it. (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

barima biHuj-atihi, aor. _a {yaboramu}, ‡ [He was unable to adduce, as he had intended, his argument, allegation, or evidence,] is said when one has intended to adduce an argument, allegation, or evidence, and it did not present itself to him. (A, Ḳ, TA.)

4. Abrmhu, (inf. n. UiboraAmN, T,) He made it (a rope, AḤn, M, Ḳ, or a thread, or string, T) of two strands, or distinct yarns or twists, and then twisted it; (AḤn, T, M, Ḳ;) as also baramahu↓ [aor. _u {yaborumu}, inf. n. baromN]: (T:) or he twisted it well; namely, a rope. (M.)

And hence, (T, TA,) ‡ He made it (a thing, Ṣ, or an affair, T, M, Ḳ, or a compact, Mṣb) firm, strong, solid, or sound; he established it, settled it, or arranged it, firmly, strongly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also baramahu↓, (M, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaborumu},] inf. n. baromN. (Ḳ.)
† He thought, or meditated, upon it; (namely, a thing;) or did so looking to its end, issue, or result; or he did it, performed it, or executed it, with thought, or consideration. (Mṣb.)

He affected him with disgust, loathing, or aversion; (T,* Ṣ, M,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) caused him to be vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb.) You say, laA tuborimoniI bikavorapi fuDuwlika [Disgust me not, or vex me not, by the abundance of thy meddling, or impertinent, speech.]. (T, TA.)
Abrm It (a vine) put forth grapes in the state in which they are termed barama, q. v. (Th, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
7. Anbrm [It (a rope, or a thread, or string,) was made of two strands, or distinct twists, and then twisted: or was twisted well: see 4, of which it is quasi-pass.]

[And hence,] ‡ It ([a thg, or an affair, or] compact, Mṣb) was, or became, firm, strong, solid, or sound; it was, or became, established, settled, or arranged, firmly, strongly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly. (Mṣb, KL.)

hom.sense: barama The fruit of the [trees called] EiDaAh: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {baramapN}: (Ṣ, M:) in its first stage it is termed fatolapN; then, bal-apN; then, baramapN: AḤn has erred in saying that the ftlp is above the brmp [in degree]: (M:) that of every kind of EDAh is yellow, except that of the EurofuT, which is white, (Ṣ, M,) as though its filaments, or fringe-like appertenances, were cotton, and it is like the button of a shirt, or somewhat larger: (M:) that of the salam is the sweetest in odour, (Ṣ, M,) and this is yellow, and is eaten, being sweet, or pleasant: (M:) accord. to AA, the fruit of the TaloH [or acacia gummifera, which is of the trees called EDAh]: n. un. with p {baramapN}: (T:) sometimes, also, baramapN is applied to a fruit of the OaraAk (M,* Ḳ,* TA) before it has become ripe and black; for when ripe, it is called marodN; and when black, kabaAvN: (TA:) and the pl. is biraAmN (M, Ḳ) and buramN, (M,) or baramN. (Ḳ: [but the last is a coll. gen. n.])
Also Grapes when they are above, (M,) or when they are like, (Ḳ,) the heads of young ants. (M, Ḳ.)

‡ One who does not take part with others in the game called Almayosir [q. v.], (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) nor contribute with them anything, (TA,) by reason of his avarice, (Ḥar p. 382,) though he eats with them of the flesh-meat thereof; (Aṣ, TA;) but sometimes he shuffles, or deals forth, (yufiyDu,) the gaming-arrows for the players: (Ṣ in art. jmd:) likened to the barama of the OaraAk, because he is of no use: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) and baramapN↓ occurs in the same sense; [the man so termed being likened to a baramap of the ArAk; or] the p being added to give intensiveness to the meaning: (M:) the pl. is OaboraAmN. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And hence, ‡ Avaricious, or niggardly; mean, or sordid: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) or heavy, or sluggish; (Ḳ, TA;) destitute of good. (TA.) It is said in a prov., OaboramFA qaruwnFA ‡ [Art thou (takuwnu being understood after) one taking no part with others in the game of Almysr, as is implied in the Ṣ, or art thou] heavy, or sluggish, (Ḳ, TA,) destitute of good, (TA,) yet eating two dates at once each time? (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: barimN part. n. of barima [and therefore meaning Affected with disgust, loathing, or aversion; or vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind]. (M, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: buromapN A cooking-pot (T, M, &c.) of stone, (T, Mgh, Mṣb,) or of stones: [see muborimN:] (M, Ḳ:) or [simply] a cooking-pot, (Ṣ, TA,) as some say, in a general sense, so that it may be of copper, and of iron, &c.: (TA:) pl. biraAmN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buramN (T, M, &c.) and [coll. gen. n.] buromN. (T, M, Ḳ.)
Also A certain thing which women wear upon their arms, like the bracelet. (TA.)

entry.sense: baramapN [originally n. un. of baramN]: see baramN.

bariymN A rope composed of two twists twisted together into one; as also muboramN↓: (Ṣ:) or a thread, or string, twisted of two distinct yarns or twists: (T:) or a thread, or string, twisted of white and black yarns: (Ḥam p. 704:) or a twisted rope in which are two colours, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) or two threads, or strings, of different colours, (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,) red and yellow, (M,) or red and white, (Ḳ,) sometimes (AʼObeyd, Ṣ) bound by a woman upon her waist, and upon her upper arm: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) a rope of two colours, adorned with jewels, so bound by a woman: (M, Ḳ:) or a thread, or string, (Lth, AʼObeyd, T,) with beads strung upon it, (Lth, T,) or of different colours, (AʼObeyd, T,) which a woman binds upon her waist: (Lth, AʼObeyd, T: [see also HawoTN]:) or a string of cowries, which is bound upon the waist of a female slave. (Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee in art. bzm of the TA.)
Anything in which are two colours (T, M, Ḳ) mixed together: (M, Ḳ:) and any two things mixed together and combined. (M.)
An amulet (M, Ḳ, TA) that is hung upon a boy; because of the colours therein. (TA.)
A garment, or piece of cloth, in which are silk (qaz-) and flax. (T.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or the dual thereof, (AO, T, Ṣ,) which latter is the right, (TA,) The liver and hump [of a camel], (AO, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) cut lengthwise, and tied round with a string or thread, or some other thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in some copies of the Ṣ, or with a gut; (TA;) said to be thus called because of the whiteness of the hump and the blackness of the liver. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the phrase, AiXowi lanaA mino bariyamayohaA [Roast thou for us some of her liver and hump, cut lengthwise,, &c.]. (AO, T, Ṣ: [in copies of the Ḳ, bariymihaA: and in the CK, bariymatihaA.])
Also, the sing., Water mixed with other [water, &c.]. (TA.)
Tears mixed with [the collyrium termed] Uivomid; (M, Ḳ;) because having two colours. (TA.)
A mixed company of people. (M, Ḳ.)

An army; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because comprising a mixed multitude of men; (Ḳ;) or because of the colours of the banners of the tribes therein: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or an army in which is a mixed multitude of men: (M:) or an army having two colours: (T:) and the dual, two armies, Arabs and foreigners. (IAạr, T.)
A number of sheep and goats together. (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ.)

The light of the sun with the remains of the blackness of night: (IAạr, T:) or the dawn; (M, Ḳ;) because of its combining the blackness of night and the whiteness of day: or, as some say, bariymN AlS-uboHi means the tint (xayoT [q. v.]) of the dawn that is mixed with two colours. (M.)
† Inducing suspicion, or evil opinion; [as though of two colours;] (IAạr, T;) suspected. (IAạr, T, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

bar-iymapN, with fet-ḥ, and with teshdeed to the r which is meksoorah, A daAYirap [or feather, or portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled, in a spiral manner, or otherwise,] upon a horse, whereby one judges of its goodness or badness: pl. baraAriymu. (TA: [and used in this sense in the present day.])
See also bayoramN.

bayoramN The [implement called] Eatalap: or particularly the Etlp of the carpenter: (M, Ḳ:) [i. e.,] an auger, a wimble, or a gimlet; [called in the present day bar-iymap↓; accord. to Mirḳát el-Loghah, cited by Golius, who writes the latter word without teshdeed, the former signifies such an implement (“terebra”) of a large size;] that with which the carpenter perforates: and also said to signify that with which the saddler perforates leather: (KL:) also a well-known kind of [implement such as is called in Persian] tiyXaho [i. e., a hatchet, or the like]: (PṢ:) AO said, the bayoramo is the Eatalap of the carpenter: or he said, the Etlp is the byrm of the carpenter: (T:) this word, (M,) the byrm of the carpenter, (Ṣ,) is Persian, (Ṣ, M,) arabicized. (Ṣ.)
muboramN: see bariymN.
Also A garment, or piece of cloth, of which the thread is twisted of two yarns, or distinct twists. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hence, (Ṣ,) A certain kind of garments, or cloths. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[† A thing, or an affair, or a compact, made firm, strong, solid, or sound; established, settled, or arranged, firmly, strongly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly. See its verb, 4.]
[And hence, qaDaMCN muboramN † Ratified destiny; such as is rendered inevitable.]

hom.sense: muboramN [act. part. n. of 4.]
[And also] A gatherer of baram [q. v.]: (M:) or, of the baram of the EiDaAh: (Ḳ:) or, specially, a gatherer of the baram of the OaraAk. (M.)
A maker of biraAm [or stone cookingpots]: (Ḳ:) or one who wrenches out the stones of which they are made from the mountain, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and fashions them, and hews them out. (TA.)

And hence, (M,) † A heavy, or sluggish, man; as though [in the CK lAan-ahu is erroneously put for kaOan-ahu] he cut off for himself something from the persons sitting with him: (M, Ḳ:*) or, as some say, [so in the M; but in the Ḳ, “and”] bad, or corrupt, in discourse; (M, Ḳ;) who discourses to others of that in which is no profit nor meaning; (TA;) from the same word as signifying “a gatherer of the fruit of the ArAk,” (M, TA,) which has no taste nor sweetness nor sourness nor virtue, or efficacy: (AO, TA:) or one who is a burden upon his companion, without profit and without good; like the baram who takes no part with others in the game of Almayosir, though he eats of the flesh-meat thereof. (Aṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: miboramN sing. of mabaArimu, (TA,) which signifies The spindles with which the twisting termed UiboraAm is performed. (M, Ḳ, TA.) [See 4.]

baroniI-N A sort of dates, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) the best of dates, (M,) or of the best of dates, (Mṣb,) red, intermixed, or tinged, with yellow, having much liHaMC [i. e. flesh, or pulp], and very sweet, (T,) or yellow, and round: (M:) n. un. with p {baroniy-apN}: (M:) it is an arabicized word, originally baroniyko, i. e. good, or excellent, fruit: (Ḳ:) accord. to AḤn, of Persian origin, i. e., baAroniIo; bAr meaning fruit, and nI denoting egregiousness: (M:) accord. to Suh, a foreign, or Persian, word, meaning blessed [or good or excellent] fruit; barN meaning fruit; and hiniI, good or excellent [or wholesome]: the Arabs introduced it into their language: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to the Moajam of El-Bekree, it is from baronN, the name of a town, or village. (TA.) It is converted by a rájiz into baronij-; the double I being changed into [double] j. (Ṣ, M.)
