You say also naxolN baroniI-N and naxolapN baroniy-apN [Palm-trees, and a palm-tree, of which the dates are of the sort described above]. (T.)

hom.sense: baroniy-apN n. un. of baroniI-N.

Also A kind of vessel, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Mṣb,) of baked clay: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or, as some say, of those that are termed qawaAriyr [i. e. flasks, or bottles, generally of glass]; such as are used by the seller of perfumes: (Mgh:) or a thing like a vessel of baked clay, big, or bulky, and green: and sometimes of the kind termed qwAryr: (M:) or a thing like vessels of baked clay, big, or bulky, and green; of the kind termed qwAryr that are thick, with wide mouths: (Lth, T:) pl. baraAniI-N. (Mgh.)
And A cock: (IAạr, T:) or a young cock, (M, Ḳ,) when it attains to maturity, (M,) or when it begins to do so: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-'Irák: (M:) pl. as above. (T, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. 2. tabaronasa He wore, or clad himself with, a buronus. (Ṣ.)

buronusN A long qalanosuwap, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which the devotees used to wear in the first age of El-Islám: (Ṣ:) or any garment of which the head forms a part, (M, Ḳ,) being joined to it, (M,) whether it be a dur-aAEap or a mimoTar or a jub-ap; (M, Ḳ;) and this is said to be the correct explanation: (TA:) [agreeably with the latter explanation, it is applied in the present day to a hooded cloak, mostly of white woollen stuff; but often, of cloth of any colour:] pl. baraAnisu: (Mṣb:) [some say] it is from Albirosu, meaning “cotton,” and the n is augmentative: or, accord. to some, it is not Arabic. (TA.)
buronusu AlHusoni † Comely, or goodly, hair. (TA in art. mlO.)
baronakaMCu and baronakaAnN and baronakaAniI-N: see bar-akaAnN, in art. brk.

1. bariha, aor. _a {yaborahu}, inf. n. barahN, or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, barahaAnN, (TA, [and so I find in an excellent copy of the Ḳ, but in the CK burohaAn,]) His body returned to a healthy state, or his health of body returned to him, or his bodily condition became good, after having been altered by disease. (IAạr, Ḳ.*) [The h is perhaps a substitute for C: see bariYa.]
And He was, or became, white in person, or body and members. (Ḳ.)
See also barahN, below.

4. Abrh He adduced the evidence or proof: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) but as to barohana↓, meaning he manifested the evidence or proof, it is said, on the authority of IAạr, to be post-classical; the former being the correct word: (AA, T, Z, Mṣb, TA:) or the former signifies he adduced, or uttered, or did, wonderful things, and overcame men. (Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 1. Q. Q., or, as some say, Q., 1. barohana: see 4; and see art. brhn.
barahN [perhaps an inf. n., of which the verb is bariha↓,] Softness, thinness of skin, and plumpness, (Ḳ, TA,) of a woman; as also barahorahapN↓. (TA.)
barohapN: see what next follows.

burohapN and barohapN↓ A long space or period of time: (JK, Ṣ:) or a long time: (ISk, Ḳ:) or they have a more general sense; (Ḳ;) i. e. a space, or period, of time: pl. of the former burahN and burohaAtN and burahaAtN and burahaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say, Oatato Ealayohi burohapN mina Ald-ahori and barohapN [A long space or period of time, or merely a space or period of time, passed over him]. (Ṣ.)
burohaAnN: see art. brhn.

hom.sense:
barahorahapN A white (IAạr, JK, Mṣb) girl (IAạr, Mṣb) or female: (JK:) or a woman (Ṣ, Ḳ,) white and youthful: or soft, or tender: (Ḳ:) or that quivers, (Ḳ,) or almost quivers, (Ṣ,) from sappiness, softness, or tenderness: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or that shines, or glistens, by reason of her clearness [of complexion]: or thin-skinned; appearing as though water were running upon her, by reason of her softness, or tenderness: (TA:) of the measure faEaloEalapN, (Ṣ, TA,) from barahN: (TA:) dim. burayohapN↓ (JK, TA) and burayorihapN↓, (JK,) or burayoriyhapN↓; but burayohirahapN↓ is bad, and seldom used. (TA.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
barahorahapN ruWadapF raxoSapN
kaxuroEuwyapi AlbaAnapi AlmunofaTiro
[White, or white and youthful,, &c., soft, or beautiful, tender, like the shoot of the ben-tree breaking forth with leaves: the last word being made masc. by poetic license, for the sake of the metre.]. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, app.,] it is said to signify also A white knife, of clear, pure, or bright, iron. (TA.)
See also barahN.

entry.sense: burayohapN and burayohirahapN: see barahorahapN.
burayorihapN, or burayoriyhapN: see barahorahapN.

Oaborahu [app.] Having the body in a healthy state, or in good condition, after disease: and white in person, or body and members: [but whether it have both these significations, or only the latter of them, is not clear:] fem. barohaMCu. (Ḳ.)

Q. 1. Q., or, as some say, Q. Q., 1. barohana He adduced, (T, Z, Mṣb,) or established, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 7,) the burohaAn, (T, Z, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. the evidence or proof [&c.]; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.;) or he adduced his evidence or proof [&c.]; (T, Mṣb;) Ealayohi [against him, or it, or (as in Aisotadal-a Ealayohi) of it], (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 7,) and lahu [to him, or for him]: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) but this verb is said by Az and Z, on the authority of IAạr, to be post-classical; the correct word, they say, being Oaboraha: (Mṣb:) this they assert on the ground of the opinion that burohaAnN [q. v.] is of the measure fuEolaAnN; but J holds the n to be a radical. (TA.)

burohaAnN An evidence, or a proof: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 7:) and a demonstration; i. e. the manifestation of an evidence or proof: (Mṣb:) or a decisive and manifest evidence or proof: (TA:) or the firmest, strongest, or most valid, evidence or proof; which is such as ever necessarily implies truth, or veracity, as its consequence, or concomitant; for evidences, or proofs, are of five sorts; whereof this is one; another is that which ever necessarily implies falsity, or falsehood, as its consequence, or concomitant; another, that which is nearer to truth, or veracity; another, that which is nearer to falsity, or falsehood; and another, that which is intermediate between these two: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [pl. baraAhiynu:] some say that the n in this word is augmentative; (Mṣb, and Ḥam p. 7;) that it is of the measure fuEolaAnN, from Albrh [app. Albarohu] signifying the “act of cutting:” (Ḥam ubi suprà:) others, that it is radical: Az mentions both of these opinions:
J confines himself to the latter opinion: Z, to the former, saying, on the authority of IAạr, that the word is derived from barahorahapN, meaning “white,” [or “fair in complexion,”] applied to a girl: (Mṣb:) Abu-l-Fet-ḥ [i. e. IJ] says that he holds it to be of the measure fuEolaAlN, like quroTaAsN and quronaAsN, the n not being augmentative, as is shown by the verb above mentioned: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) but [it has been stated above that] this verb is said, on the authority of IAạr, to be post-classical. (Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. barawotuhaA, i. e. Aln-aAqapa: see 4.

barawotuhu, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboruwu}, (Lth, T,) inf. n. barowN, (M,) I formed it, or fashioned it, by cutting; shaped it out; or pared it; (Ḳ;) namely, a reed for writing, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a stick, or piece of wood, (M, Ḳ,) and an arrow, (Ḳ,) [&c.;] a dial. var. of barayotuhu, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb,) used by some, (Lth, T,) but the latter is the more approved: (M, TA:) mentioned by AZ. (TA.)

[Hence, perhaps,] baraAhu, aor. _u {yaboruwu}, inf. n. barowN, He (i. e. God) created him, or it: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but] they affirm that it is originally baraOahu, with hemz: (MF:) so says IAth: (TA:) or it is from barFA or barFI, signifying “dust,” or “earth.” (Fr, Ṣ.)
baraA, aor. _u {yaboruwu}, is also a bad dial. var. of baraOa [signifying He, or it, recovered from disease, or became convalescent,, &c.], aor. yaboruWu. (TA.)

4. OaborayotuhaA, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) i. e. Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, M,) I put a [ring such as is termed] burap in her (a camel's) nose; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also barawotuhaA↓: (IJ, M, Ḳ:) and Abrythu, namely, a camel, I put him a burap. (Mṣb.)
AbrI Dust, or earth, came, or lighted, upon it. (Ḳ,* TA, in art. brI.)

entry.sense: burapN (in which the final radical letter is elided, [and replaced by p,] Msb) A ring (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) of brass, (Lth, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, [in a copy of the Mṣb, mn Swf is erroneously put for mino SuforK,]) or of silver, (Lth, T,) or of some other material, (Lḥ, M,) slender, and bent at the two ends [lest it should open at the place where the two ends meet], that is put in the nose of a she-camel, (Lth, T,) or put in the nose of the camel, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or in the flesh of the nose of the camel, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or, as Aṣ says, in one of the two sides of the two nostrils, (Ṣ,) app. either for the purpose of ornament or to render the animal obedient; (MF;) [generally for the latter purpose, to attach the rein thereto:] when the ring is of hair, it is termed xizaAmapN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) and when of wood, xiXaAXN: (Mṣb:) Aboo-ʼAlee mentions, and explains in like manner, barowapN↓ and burFI; [the latter as pl. of the former;] but this is extr.: (M:) J says, [in the Ṣ,] Aboo-ʼAlee says that burapN is originally barowapN, because it has burFI for a pl., like as qaroyap has qurFI; but Aboo-ʼAlee does not say this; he only desires to show that the final radical letter of burapN is w by the fact that barowapN is a dial. var. thereof: (IB, TA:) some, however, remarking upon J's saying that the original of barapN is barowapN, assert that it is correctly burowapN↓: (TA:) burapN also signifies an anklet: (M, Ḳ:) or any ring; such as a bracelet and an earring and an anklet and the like of these: (Ṣ:) the pl. (in the former and the latter senses, M, TA) is buraAtN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written buraApN, (TA,) and burFI, (T, Ṣ, M,) and buruwna, contr. to analogy, (Mṣb,) or buriyna (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in all of which, except the last, this is in the accus. or the gen. case, but, as it is the nom. case in the Ḳ, it may be that buruwna and buriyna are dial. vars., like sinuwna and siniyna,]) and buriyna. (M, Ḳ: [in a copy of the former of which, accord. to the TT, buriI-N and biriI-N are put in the place of the last two of these pls.])

barFA, or barFI, Dust, or earth: (Fr, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, mentioned in the M and Ḳ in art. brI:) whence baraAhu, [if not originally baraOahu,] meaning “He (i. e. God) created him.” (Fr, Ṣ.) Hence the saying, bifiyhi AlbaraA, or AlbaraI, [In his mouth be dust, or earth], (Ṣ, M,) a form of imprecation against a man. (M.)

hom.sense: barowapN Cuttings, chips, parings, or the like, of a reed for writing, and of a stick, or piece of wood, and of soap, and the like. (TA.)
See also burapN.

entry.sense: burowapN: see burapN.

Albariy-apN The creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created; or, particularly, mankind; syn. Alxaloqu: originally with C: (Ṣ:) but not pronounced with C: (IAth, TA in art. brI:) or, accord. to Fr, if from barFA, or barFI, i. e. “dust,” or “earth,” it is originally without C: pl. baraAyaA and bariy-aAtN. (Ṣ.)
muboraApN A she-camel (T, Ṣ) having a [ring such as is termed] burap put in her nose: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. muborayaAtN. (TA in art. Erf.)
burapN maboruw-apN (T, M, Ḳ) A burap made, or manufactured. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baraI, (T, M, Ḳ,) first pers. barayotu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaboriIu}, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. baroIN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He formed, or fashioned, by cutting; shaped out; or pared; (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ;) a reed for writing, (Lth, Aṣ, ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and a stick, or piece of wood, (Lth, T, M,) and an arrow, (M, Ḳ,), &c.; (M;) as also AbtrI↓: (M, Ḳ:) and barawotu, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaboruIu}, (Lth, T,) is a dial. var., (Mṣb,) used by some, who say, huma yaqoluw Albur-a [instead of yaqoliI]. (Lth, T.)

And hence, (Aṣ, T,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ,) † He (a man) fatigued, or jaded, and made to lose flesh, (Aṣ,* T,* Ṣ,) a she-camel, (Aṣ, T,) or a camel: (Ṣ:) or it (journeying) rendered him lean, or emaciated: (M, Ḳ:) and in like manner one says of a year of dearth or drought. (TA.) And barayotu sanaAmahaA bisayoriI EalayohaA † [I wasted her hump by my journeying upon her]: occurring in a poem of El-Aạshà. (M.)
See also 3:
and see 5, in two places.

3. bArAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAraApN, (T, TA,) He vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with him; emulated, or rivalled, him; or imitated him; i. q. EaAraDahu; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., (TA,) he did the like of what he (the latter) did, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA, and EM p. 64,) striving to overcome him or surpass him; (EM ubi suprà;) as also baraI↓ lahu, aor. _i {yaboriIu}, inf. n. baroIN; and AnbrI↓ lh: (Aṣ, T:) and he vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in glory, or excellence, or in beauty, or goodliness; he emulated, or rivalled, him therein; syn. baAhaAhu: (TA in art. bhj:) and he vied, competed, or contended, with him in running; and strove with him to outstrip him, to be before him, to get before him, or to precede him. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yubaAriI Alr-iyHa saxaMCF [Such a one vies with the wind in bounty]: (T, Ṣ:) [for] the bountiful man whose gifts are common is likened by the Arabs to the wind because it blows upon all in common, not only upon particular persons. (Ḥam p. 445.)
bArI QmoraOatahu He compounded, or made a compromise, with his wife for their mutual separation; (Ḳ;) as also baAraOahaA [which is the original]. (TA.)
4. AbrI: see art. brw
Also He found, or met with, sugar-canes. (Ḳ.)
See also OaboraOa, in art. brO, last signification.

entry.sense: 5. Alt-abar-iI signifies The coming before or forward, presenting oneself, advancing, confronting, encountering, meeting, or opposing; (KL;) and so AlAinobiraMCu↓. (KL, PṢ.) You say, tbr-I lahu He presented, addressed, applied, or betook, himself to him, i. e., one man to another man; advanced, came forward, or went forward, to him; or opposed himself to him; syn. taEar-aDa; as also tbr-Ahu; and baraI↓ lahu, aor. _i {yaboriIu}: (T:) and AnbrI↓ lh signifies AiEotaraDa lahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 558,) meaning [as above; or] he betook himself, and advanced, or went forward, to it, namely, an action; (Ḥar ubi suprà;) and it presented itself to it, as a thought to the heart, or mind, syn. tEr-D: (Ḥam p. 541:) baraI↓ lahu, inf. n. baroIN, is syn. with EaraDa lahu [meaning as above, for it is syn. with taEar-aDa and AiEotaraDa; or it happened to him, befell him, or occurred to him]: (M:) and AnbrI↓ is also syn. with EaraDa [meaning it happened, befell, or occurred]. (Ḥar p. 56.) You say also, tbr-I limaEoruwfihi, i. e. taEar-aDa lahu (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) or AiEotaraDa lahu (M) [both of which explanations mean He presented, addressed, applied, or betook, himself, or he advanced, came forward, went forward, or attempted, to obtain his favour, or bounty; or he sought it, or demanded it]; as also tbr-I maEoruwfahu. (M, TA.) And tabar-ayotu wud-ahumo [I addressed, applied, or betook, myself to obtain their love, or affection]. (Ṣ, M.) And AnbrI↓ liTaI-i bisaATihi, i. q. AiEotaraDa, meaning, in this instance, He hastened to cut short his speech. (Ḥar p. 280.) And AnbrI↓ yunoXidu XiEorFA, i. e. taEar-aDa liUinoXaMYihi [or liUinoXaAdihi, meaning He addressed himself to reciting poetry, or verses]. (Ḥar p. 34.) And AnbrI↓ mina AljamaAEapi, i. q. AiEotaraDa [He presented himself, or advanced, or came forward, from the company]. (Ḥar p. 647.)

6. tabaArayaA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, each with the other; emulated, or rivalled, each other; imitated each other; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) they did each like as the other did. (T, Ṣ, TA.) [See the part. n., below.]

hom.sense: 7. AnbrI, (Ḳ, TA,) or AbtrI↓, (so in a copy of the M,) It was, or became, formed, or fashioned, by cutting; shaped out; or pared: (M, Ḳ:) said of a reed for writing, and of a stick, or piece of wood, (M,) and of an arrow, (M, Ḳ,), &c. (M.)
See also 3:
and see 5, in six places.
8: see 1:
and see also 7.

entry.sense: barFI, or barFA: see art. brw.

hom.sense: baraApN: see miboraApN.
See also baraMCapN, in art. brO.

entry.sense: baraMCN: see miboraApN.
buraMCN: see buraAyapN.

hom.sense: bariI-N, applied to an arrow, i. q. maboriI-N↓ [i. e. Formed, or fashioned, by cutting; shaped out; or pared]; (T, M, Ḳ;) or (M, Ḳ) completely; (T, M, Ḳ;) but not feathered, nor headed: for an arrow when first cut is termed qiToEN; then it is formed, or fashioned, by cutting, or shaped out, or pared, and is termed bariI-N; and when straightened, and fit to be feathered and headed, it is a qidoH; and when feathered and headed, it becomes a sahom. (T.)
It is also sometimes used for bariIoCN. (Ḳz, TA in art. brO.)

entry.sense: Albariy-apN: see art. brw.

buraAyapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and buraMCN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which latter the C is originally I, (IJ, M,) Cuttings, chips, parings, or the like; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) what falls from a thing that is formed, or fashioned, by cutting. (T, Ṣ.*)
[Hence,] maTarN cuw buraAyapK † Rain that pares and peels the ground. (TA.)
And huwa mino buraAyatihimo † He is of the refuse, or lowest or meanest sort, of them. (M, TA.)

But cuw buraAyapK, applied to a camel, means † En-during travel: (T, Ṣ, M:) or having fat and flesh: (Ṣ:) and caAtu buraAyapK, applied to a she-camel, has the latter meaning: or the former: (M, Ḳ:) or strong when fatigued and emaciated by travel: (TA:) or, as some say, brAyp in both cases means the remains of fatness and compactness, or of fat, and of strength. (M, TA.) Hat-u AlburaAyapi is said to mean † Fleet, or swift, when emaciated by travel; for the subst. brAyp is said to be here put for the inf. n. baroI. (L in art. Ht, q. v.)

biraAyapN a quasi-inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: as when it is said that a reed for writing is not called a qalam except after the brAyp [i. e. the shaping, or paring]. (Mṣb.)

bar-aMCN A maker of arrows, who forms, or fashions, them by cutting; who shapes them out, or pares them: or who does so completely: (Ḳ:) and a maker of spindles, who forms, or fashions, them by cutting: and a cutter, or parer, of aloes-wood, that is used for fumigation: (TA:) [and in like manner, baAriI↓ qisiIK a fashioner, or shaper, of bows: whence the saying,] OaEoTi Alqawosa baAriyahaA [Give thou the bow to its fashioner]; meaning † commit thou thine affair to him who will execute it well: a prov. (Ḥar p. 68. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 98.])
bar-aMCapN: see miboraApN.
baAriI qisiI-: see bar-aMCN.
baAriI-N and baAriy-apN and baAriyaMCu: see in art. bwr.
maboraI Alqalami [The place where the paring is commenced of the reed for writing]. (Ḳ in art. jlf.)

miboraApN The iron implement, (Ṣ,) or knife, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) with which one forms, fashions, shapes out, or pares, (AḤn, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a bow; (AḤn, M, Ḳ;) as also bar-aMCapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) with teshdeed and medd, (TA,) or baraMCN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or baraApN↓. (CK, and so in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.)
maboriI-N: see bariI-N.

mutabaAri part. n. of 6. It is said in a trad., AlmutabaAriyaAni laA yujaAbaAni walaA yuWokalu TaEaAmuhumaA [The two persons who vie with each other in the expensiveness of their entertainments shall not have their invitations accepted, nor shall their food be eaten]. (El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer of Es-Suyootee.) The mtbAryAn whose food is forbidden, in a trad., to be eaten, are They who vie with each other in order that each may render the other unable to equal him in respect of the repast prepared by him for his guests: and the doing of this is disliked because of the rivalry and ostentation that are involved in it. (TA.)
AlmutabaAriyaAni is also an appellation of The night and the day. (Ḥar p. 377.)

1. baz-ahu, aor. _u {yabozuzu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. baz-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He took it away; or seized it, or carried it away, by force; (Ṣ, TA;) as also Abtz-hu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bazobazahu↓: (Ḳ:) he took it away unjustly, injuriously, and forcibly; as also Abtz-hu↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) he gained the mastery over it: (Ḳ,* TA:) he pulled it up or out or off; removed it from its place; displaced it; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also Abtz-hu↓, and bazobazahu↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., mano Eaz-a baz-a He who overcomes takes the spoil. (Ṣ, A.) And you say, baz-ahu vawobahu, and Abtz-hu↓, He took away from him, or seized or carried away from him by force, his garment. (A.) It is said in a trad., fayabotaz-u↓ viyaAbiI wamataAEiI And he strips me, or despoils me, of my clothes and my goods; takes them from me by superior force. (TA.) You say also, baz-ahu viyaAbahu He pulled off from him his clothes. (TA.) And Abtz-↓ Alr-ajulu jaAriyatahu mXno viyaAbihaA The man stripped his slave-girl of her clothes. (Mgh,* TA.)

Also baz-avawobahu, aor. as above, He pulled his garment towards him, or to him: so in a verse of Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr El-Hudhalee [cited in art. ryb, but with this difference, that yajur-u is there put in the place of yabuz-u]. (Ṣ, TA.)
[baz-ahu is also explained in the TA by Habasahu; but without any ex.; and I think it probable that Habasahu is a mistake for jacabahu].

hom.sense: 8: see 1, in six places.
Abtz-t mino viyaAbihaA She stripped herself of her clothes. (A.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. bazobazahu: see 1, in two places.
bazobazapN [the inf. n.] also signifies The being quick and active in wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, conduct: and the rel. n. is bazobaziI-N↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: baz-N inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, &c.)

[Hence, app.,] jiIoCa bihi Eaz-aA baz-FA He was brought without any means of avoiding it; (A, TA;) willingly or against his will: (TA in art. Ez:) [as though originally signifying by being overcome and despoiled.]

Cloths, or stuffs, or garments; syn. viyaAb: (IAmb, Mgh, Ḳ:) [see also biz-apN:] or a kind thereof: (Lth, Mgh, Mṣb:) or such as are the goods of the baz-aAz, (Ṣ, A,) or of the merchant: (Mṣb:) or the furniture of a house or tent, consisting of cloths or stuffs (viyaAb, IDrd, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and the like: (Ḳ:) in the dial. of the people of El-Koofeh, cloths, or stuffs, or garments, (vyAb,) of linen and of cotton; not of wool nor of xaz-: (Mgh:) pl. buzuwzN; (A;) meaning, in conjunction with xuzuwzN, (i. e., xuzuwzN wabuzuwzN,) good cloths or stuffs or garments. (A.) [Golius explains it as “Chald. בוּץ, Byssus, seu potius pannus lineus, bombacinus, etiam sericus:” as on the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ (though he omits the explanations in both those lexicons) and Meyd and Ibn-Maạroof (who explains it only by the Persian word jaAmaho, meaning cotton or linen cloth, or a garment,) and the Mirḳát el-Loghah. He seems to have judged from its resemblance in sound to the Chaldee and Latin words with which he identifies it. The things which it signifies, however, may perhaps be so called because they are usual spoils: and hence also, perhaps, the application here next following.]

Weapons, or arms; or a weapon; syn. silaAHN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also biz-apN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bazazN↓, (Ḳ,) and biz-iyzaI↓: (TA:) the first of these four words including in its application coats of mail and the migofar and the sword: (TA:) or it signifies a sword: (IDrd, A, TA:) and bazazN↓, accord. to AA, complete arms. (TA.) You say, taqal-ada baz-aA HasanFA He hung upon himself a goodly sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck. (A.) And gazaA fiI biz-apK↓ kaAmilapK He went to war in complete arms. (A.)
biz-apN Constraint, or force: as in the saying, lano yaOoxucahu OabadFA biz-apF min-iI He will never take it by constraint, or force, from me. (Ks, TA.)

Outward appearance; state with regard to apparel and the like; syn. hayoYapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and XaArapN: (TA:) garb; mode, manner, or fashion, of dress: (TA:) apparel. (A, Mgh.) You say, rajulN Hasanu Albiz-api A man of goodly outward appearance, or state of apparel and the like: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or as some say, clothes and arms. (Mgh.) And Uin-ahu lacuw biz-apK HasanapK Verily he has a goodly outward appearance and dress. (A, TA.)
See also baz-N, latter part, in two places.

entry.sense: bazazN: see baz-N, latter part, in two places.
bizaAzapN The trade of the baz-aAz. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
bizaAzapN The seller of the cloths or stuffs or the like called baz-. (Ṣ,* A,* Mgh,* Ḳ.)

hom.sense: biz-iyzaI a subst. from baz-a in the first of the senses explained above; The act of taking away; or spoliation; or the act of seizing, or carrying away, by force: (Ṣ, TA:) the act of taking, or obtaining, by superior power or force. (Ḳ,* TA.) It is said in a trad., vum-a yakuwnu biz-iyzaI waOaxoca OamowaAlK bigayori Haq-K Then it shall be by spoliation, and the taking of possessions without right: or, as some relate this trad., bazobaziy-FA↓; but accord. to Az, this is naught. (TA.) You say also, rajaEati AlxlaAfapu biz-iyzaI [The office of Khaleefeh became reduced to be a thing taken by superior power or force]; was not taken by desert. (A, TA.)
See also baz-N, latter part.

entry.sense: bazobaziI-N: see R. Q. 1, and biz-iyzaI.

1. bazixa, aor. _a {yabozaxu}, (L,) inf. n. bazaxN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He had a prominent breast and hollow back: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or he had the lower part of his belly prominent, and the part between the hips, or haunches, [behind,] hollow, or depressed: or he had the middle of his back hollow, or depressed, and the lower part of his belly prominent: or he had his back retiring from his belly: or he had his belly depressed, and the vn-ap [here app. meaning the pubes], and the part next thereto, prominent: (L:) bazaxN is similar to qaEasN: [see qaEisa:] (A:) and Anbzx↓ signifies the same as bazixa. (IAạr, TA.) The epithet applied to a man is Oabozaxu↓; and to a woman, bazoxaMCu. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
Also, inf. n. as above, He (a horse) [was saddle-backed; i. e.,] had a hollow back, and prominent croup and withers. (ISd, L.)

6. tbAzx He walked, or sat, in the manner of him who is termed Oabozax. (L.) And tbAzxt She (a woman) made her posteriors to stick out: (Ṣ:) or she had prominent posteriors: (Ḳ:) or she (an old woman, in walking,) erected her backbone, and made the part between her shoulders to recede, and bent the part above it, next her neck: (L:) or she had her posteriors prominent, and the upper part of her back, next the neck, bent. (TA.)
He (a horse) bent his hoof towards his belly, because of the shortness of his neck, at the time of drinking. (TA.)
tbAzx Eani AlOamori ‡ He drew back, held back, or hung back, from the thing, or affair; would not go forward in it. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
7: see 1.
Oabozaxu A man having a prominent breast and hollow back:, &c.: (see 1:) fem. bazoxaMCu. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)

A horse having a depressed croup and backbone: (Ṣ:) or [saddle-backed; i. e.] having a hollow back, and prominent croup and withers. (ISd, L.) It is applied to a horse such as is termed birocawonN. (L.)
And the fem., A she-camel having a plain, or even, croup, or rump. (L.)

maXaI mutabaAzixFA He (a man) walked like an old woman affecting, or constraining herself, to erect her backbone, so that the part between her shoulders recedes: (A:) or, like an old woman having her posteriors prominent, and the upper part of her back, next the neck, bent. (TA.)

1. bazara Alqidora, (Mṣb,) [aor. _u {yabozuru} or _i, accord. to the rule of the Ḳ,] inf. n. bazorN; (Ḳ;) and bz-rhA↓, (A,) inf. n. taboziyrN; (TA;) He threw, or put, OabozaAr, (A,) or UibozaAr, (Mṣb,) or OabaAziyr, (A, Ḳ,) [i. e. seeds for seasoning the food,] into the cooking-pot. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] bz-r↓ kalaAmahu ‡ He seasoned (tawobala [meaning he embel-lished]) his speech, or language. (A.)
bazara, (TḲ,) inf. n. bazorN, (Ḳ,) also signifies He sowed (Ḳ, TḲ) seeds; (TḲ;) i. q. bacara. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
bazorN: see what next follows, in five places.

bizorN and bazorN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former the more chaste, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or the only form used by persons of chaste speech, (ISk, T, Mṣb,) The seed of herbs or leguminous plants, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and of other plants: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or small seed or grain, such as that of herbs or leguminous plants and the like: (TA:) or any seed, or grain, that is sown (Kh, Mṣb, Ḳ) for vegetation; (Ḳ;) as also bacorN [q. v.]: (Kh, Mṣb:) pl. buzuwrN. (Ḳ.)

And Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; syn. taAbalN: pl. OabozaArN↓ and OabaAziyrN; (Ḳ;) the latter of which is pl. of OabozaArN; (TA;) or of this word and of UibozaArN↓; both of which are sings.; arabicized [from the Persian OafozaAro]; the former of them anomalous, being of a pl. form: (Mṣb:) OabozaArN and OabaAziyru are syn. with tawaAbilu: (Ṣ:) or AbzAr and twAbl both signify that with which food is seasoned; but the former of these is applied to what is moist and what is dry; and the latter, to what is dry only: this distinction, however, appears to be conventional [and modern]; for the [classical] language of the Arabs does not indicate it. (MF.)
Hence, OabaAziyru↓ also signifies ‡ Additions [or embellishments] in speech. (A.)
bizorN and bazorN↓ signify also Oil of bazor [i. e. of seeds]. (Ṣ.) bizoru Alkat-aAni [commonly meaning Linseed] signifies linseed-oil in the dial. of the people of Baghdád. (Ḳ.)
Also bazorN↓, (Mgh,) or bazoru Alqaz-i, (Mṣb,) ‡ The eggs of the silk-worm. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
And ↓the former of these, † Offspring. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, maA Oakovara bazorahu↓ † How numerous is his offspring! (TA.)
bazoraMCu: see mabozuwrN.
bazoriI-N One who expresses the oil of bizor. (TA.)
baz-aArN One who sells bizor Alkat-aAn, i. e., linseed-oil, in the dial. of the people of Baghdád. (Ḳ.)
baAzuwrN ‡ A man who induces in one, or throws one into, doubt or suspicion; from the phrase baz-ara kalaAmahu. (A.)
OabozaArN and UibozaArN: pl. OabaAziyru: see bizorN, in three places.
OabozaAriI-N [One who sells OabozaAr or UibozaAr]. (Ḳ.)
mubaz-arN Seasoned with OabaAziyr, i. e. tawaAbil. (Mgh.) [See bizorN.]
mabozuwrN † Having many children; applied to a man: and so bazoraMCu↓ applied to a woman. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. buzuwgN [inf. n. of bazaga] signifies The beginning to rise, or come forth: this is the primary meaning: mentioned by Zj. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) bazaga, said of a tush, or tusk, or canine tooth, (A,) or of the tush of a camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yabozugu},] inf. n. buzuwgN, (Mṣb,) It came forth; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it clave the flesh, and came forth. (A.)

And hence, (A, TA,) bazagati AlX-amosu, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabozugu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and bazogN, (Ḳ,) The sun began to rise; (JK, TA;) as though it clave the darkness with its light: (A, TA:) or rose, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with spreading light: (TA:) or buzuwgN has the meaning first explained above; the beginning to rise, or come forth. (Ḳ.) And in like manner one says, bazaga Alqamaru [The moon began to rise: or rose]. (A, TA.)

bazaga, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabozugu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bazogN, (JK, Mṣb,) He (a cupper, and a farrier,) scarified, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and made the blood to flow: (Mṣb:) he (a farrier) scarified a beast (JK, Mgh, TA) in its OaXoEar [or part next the hoof (in the TA, erroneously, XEr)], (JK,) with a mibozaE (JK, Mgh, TA) of iron; (JK;) as also bz-g↓, inf. n. taboziygN: (JK,* TA:) Aboo-ʼAdnán says that taboziygN and taEoriybN signify the same, namely, the making a slight incision, or stab, such as does not reach the sinews, or tendons. (TA.)
And He made his blood to flow. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
7. Anbzg Alr-abiyEu, (Ṣ, and so in a copy of the Ḳ,) or Abtzg↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) The first, or beginning, of the [season, or rain, or herbage, called] rbyE came. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8: see 7.
qamarN baAzigN, (TA,) and XamosN baAzigapN, (Mṣb,) and nujuwmN bawaAzigu, (JK, A,) [A moon, and a sun, and stars,] beginning to rise: (JK, TA:) or rising. (Mṣb, TA.)
mibozagN A lancet (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) of a cupper and of a farrier. (JK, Mgh, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. bazaqa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabozuqu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. bazoqN, (Ṣ, TA,) or buzaAqN, (Mṣb,) [but see the latter below,] i. q. baSaqa (Ṣ,* Mṣb) or basaqa (Ḳ) [He spat: see also 5]: but it is of weak authority, or rare; the most chaste being bSq. (TA in art. bsq.)
bazaqa AlOaroDa He sowed the land: (Az, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

bazaqati AlX-amosu i. q. bazagat; (Az, Ḳ;) so in a trad., meaning The sun rose: the latter is that which is [commonly] known; but the former may be a dial. var.; though the right reading seems to be bazaqat. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Abzqt She (namely, a ewe, JK, or a camel, Ḳ) excerned the milk [or biestings into her udder before bringing forth]; (Yz, JK, Ḳ, TA;) i. q. Absqt [q. v.]. (TA.)
5. tbz-q He ejected his spittle, as the faster is commanded to do. (Mgh.)
buzaAqN is well known; (Ḳ;) i. q. buSaAqN [Spittle, or saliva, when it has gone forth from the mouth]: (Ṣ:) or saliva that flows. (TA in art. rDb.) [See also 1.]
mibozaqapN A spittoon, or vessel in which to spit; syn. mitofalapN. (TA in art. tfl.)

hom.sense: 1. bazalahu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabozulu}, (TA,) inf. n. bazolN, (Mṣb, TA,) He clave it, split it, or slit it; (Ḳ;) as also bz-lhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboziylN. (TA. [But the latter verb probably has an intensive or a frequentative sense, or applies to many objects.])
He broached it, or pierced it, and drew forth what was in it. (Mṣb.)

He broached, or pierced, the vessel containing it, (IDrd, Ḳ, TA,) and drew it forth; (IDrd, TA;) namely wine, &c.; (IDrd, Ḳ, TA;) as also Abtzlhu↓ and tbz-lhu↓. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, Aibotazalotu↓ AlX-araAba linafosiI [I broached its vessel, and drew forth the wine, or beverage, for myself]. (TA.)

He cleared it, or clarified it; namely, wine, or beverage; (Ḳ;) as also Abtzlhu↓: but Az says, I know not Albazolu as signifying “the act of clearing, or clarifying.” (TA. [bazalotu AlX-araAba is mentioned, but not explained, in the Ṣ. The meaning there intended may be either the third or the last given above.])
‡ He decided it, (Ḳ, TA,) and settled it firmly; (TA;) namely, a case, or an affair; or an opinion: (Ḳ, TA:) and † he decided it; namely, the judicial sentence. (TA.)
† He originated it, or devised it; namely, his opinion. (TA.)
maA Einodahu bulogapN tabozulu HaAjapF † He has not a sufficiency, or a sufficiency of the means of subsistence, that will satisfy a want. (Z, TA.)

bazala, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabozulu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. buzuwlN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bazolN, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK buzol,]) It (the nAb [or tush] of a camel) clave the flesh, and came forth: (Ḳ,* TA:) or his (a camel's) nAb [or tush] clave the flesh, and came forth; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) [or he became such as is termed baAzil; generally] by his entering the ninth year. (Mṣb.)

[And hence, as being likened to a camel that has attained his full strength,] inf. n. bzAlp [written without any indication of the syll. signs, but most probably bazaAlapN, though the verb seems to be bazala, not bazula,] † It (an opinion, or a judgment,) was, or became, right. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 5. tbz-l and Anbzl↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or Abtzl↓, (so the latter is written in the CK,) It clave, split, or slit; intrans.: (Ḳ:) or the former signifies it clave, split, or slit, much, in several places, or often; syn. taXaq-aqa: and ↓the second, said of a TaloE, [app. here meaning a spathe, rather than a spadix, of a palm-tree,] it clave, split, or burst. (Ṣ.)

Also, the first, said of the body, It burst forth, or flowed, with blood: and in like manner one says of a water-skin tbz-l and tbz-l biAlmaMCi [it burst forth, or flowed, with water, or the water]. (TA.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 7: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: 8: see 1, in three places
and see 5.

entry.sense: 10. Astbzlhu He opened it; namely, a dan- [or wine-jar]. (Ḥar p. 140.)
OamorN cuw bazolK A distressing, an afflictive, or a calamitous, affair or event or case. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
siqaMCN fiyhi buzolN A water-skin that bursts forth, or flows, with the water: pl. buzuwlN. (TA.)
bazolaMCu ‡ A great calamity or misfortune or disaster. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)

† Difficulties, distresses, or afflictions. (IDrd, Ḳ.) You say, huwa nah-aADN bibazolaMCi † He is one who manages great affairs; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) who has ability and strength to overcome difficulties. (TA.)
† Good judgment or opinion or counsel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maA lifulaAnK bazolaMCu yaEiyXu bihaA † Such a one has not determination, resolution, or decision, of judgment, whereby to live. (TA.)
huwa cuw bazolaMCa † He has a firm, or well-established, way, or manner, of acting, or conducting himself. (TA.)
xuT-apN bazolaMCu ‡ A great event that distinguishes that which is true and that which is false. (Ḳ,* TA.)
buzaAlN The place that is broached, or pierced, in a vessel containing wine, &c.; (Ḳ;) the place whence issues the thing [or liquid] whereof the containing vessel is broached, or pierced. (IDrd.)
bizaAlN An iron instrument with which the mibozal [or mabozal?] of a wine-jar is opened. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
bazuwlN: see baAzilN in two places.

baziylN, applied to wine or beverage, i. q. mubotazalN↓ [which may mean either That whereof the containing vessel has been broached and which has been drawn forth, or that which is cleared or clarified; but more probably the former]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
Also The tooth that has come forth at the time above mentioned: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. bawaAzilu. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

And ‡ A man perfect in his experience and his intellect: (Ḳ, TA:) or rendered firm, or sound, in judgment by age and experience: so says IDrd: likened to the camel thus termed: (TA:) or old: opposed to jacaEN, q. v. (IAạr in art. jcE of the TA.)
And ‡ A case, or an affair, and an opinion, firmly settled or established. (TA.)

xaTobN baAzilN † A difficult, a distressing, or an afflicting, thing, affair, or business. (TA.) You say also, bulaIa biOaXohaba baAzilK † He was afflicted with a difficult and distressing thing or event. (TA. [See also art. Xhb.])

Xaj-apN baAzilapN A wound in the head from which the blood flows: (Ṣ:) or such as is termed HaAriSapN, (Ḳ,) i. e. mutalaAHimapN, (TA,) [but see these two words, and see Xaj-apN,] that cleaves the skin, but does not penetrate beyond it: (Ḳ:) the mulet for which is said to be three camels. (TA.)

maA baqiyta lahumo baAzilapN is like the saying maA baqiyta lahumo vaAgiyapN walaA raAgiyapN, i. e. ‡ [There remained not to them] one [sheep or goat, or camel]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, maA Einodahu baAzilapN, i. e. † There is not in his possession anything of property, or of camels, &c.: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, a sufficiency, or a sufficiency of the means of subsistence, that will satisfy a want. (Z, TA.) And laA taraka Qll-ehu Einodahu baAzilapF † [May God not leave in his possession] anything. (Ṣ.) And lamo yuEoTihimo baAzilapF † [He did not give them] anything. (Ṣ.)
[mabozalN app. The mouth of a wine-jar: see bizaAlN.]
mibozalN A strainer, or thing with which wine, or beverage, is cleared, or clarified; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also mibozalapN↓. (Ḳ.)
An instrument for broaching, piercing, or perforating. (Mṣb.)
mibozalapN: see mibozalN.
mubotazalN: see baziylN.
UibozaAmN: see what follows.

UiboziymN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, &c.) and UibozaAmN↓ (Ḳ) [A buckle;] the thing that is at the head [or end] of the [zone, or waist-belt, called] minoTaqap (Ṣ, Ḳ) and the like, and that has a tongue, into which [thing] the other extremity [of the mnTqp] enters; (Ḳ;) a ring with a tongue, which is at the head of the mnTqp and the like, and with which it is fastened; (Mgh;) the ring that has a tongue which enters into the hole in the lowest part of the shoulderbelt of the sword, and upon which the ring then bites, or presses; the ring altogether [with the tongue] being termed Abzym; (ISh, TA;) the iron thing that is at the end of the girth of the horse's saddle, which is fastened therewith; and sometimes it is at the end of the mnTqp: (IB, TA:) pl. OabaAziymu. (Ṣ.)
Also A lock; and so UiboziynN. (TA.)
You say, Uin-a fulaAnFA laUiboziymN, meaning † Verily such a one is a niggard. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. bazaA, aor. yabozuw, i. q. taTaAwala [app. as meaning He stretched out his neck, looking at a thing far off];
and taOan-asa [here meaning the same, or he looked, raising his head; said of a hawk, or falcon]: (Az, ISd, Ḳ:) and hence IJ says that baAzN↓ is [originally] of the measure faloEN from this verb: (TA: [and it is said in the Ḳ that baAzK seems to be hence derived:]) for [or tTAwl may here be used in another sense; for, accord. to Fei,] bazaA, aor. as above, signifies he overcame, or subdued; and hence is derived baAzK↓. (Mṣb.) You say also, bazaA Ealayohi, aor. as above, meaning tTAwl [i. e., thus followed by Elyh, He held up his head with an assumption of superiority over him; behaved haughtily towards him; exalted himself above him; or overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him]. (Ṣ.) And buziIa biAlqawomi The people, or company of men, were overcome, or subdued. (TA.) And bazaAhu, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bazowN, (TA,) He overcame, or subdued, him; and laid violent hands upon him, or assaulted him; as also AbzI↓ bihi: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies he overcame him, and subdued him: (Ṣ:) and bazaAhu, he wronged him; or treated him wrongfully, or injuriously: and AbzAhu↓ may signify the same; or this may mean he induced him to become OabozaI, q. v.: (Ḥam p. 502:) and accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, AbzI↓ signifies he pressed heavily upon his adversary, or imposed on him that which he was unable to do, or to bear, in order to treat him wrongfully, or injuriously. (Ḥam pp. 104 and 105.) [It is said that] bazawaAnN [an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one, is bazaA,] signifies the act of Leaping; syn. wavobN. (Ṣ: [but I think it not improbable that this may have been taken from a mistranscription of nazawaAnN, an inf. n. of nazaA.])

baziIa, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabozawu}; (Ḥam p. 502;) and bazaA, aor. _u {yabozuwu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. bazFA (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) and bazowN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) had what is termed bazFA; (Ḳ;) i. e., prominence of the breast and depression of the back: (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà:) or depression of the back and prominence of the belly: or, as some say, prominence of the breast and depression of the lower part of the belly: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) or depression of the breast and prominence of the lower part of the belly: (Ḥam p. 105:) or a bending in the back next the posteriors: (Ḳ, TA:) or a projecting of the middle of the back over the posteriors: or a backward bulging of the posteriors: (Ḳ:) or he was as though his posteriors projected over the hinder part of the thighs: or he had the breast bulging forward and the posteriors backward, so that he appeared unable to straighten his back. (T, TA.) [See also 4.] The epithet is OabozaI: fem. bazowaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. AbzI: see 1, in three places.

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UibozaMCN, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) He (a man, AʼObeyd, Ṣ) elevated his posteriors; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tbAzI↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he acted in such a manner in his walk as to cause it to be imagined that he was OabozaI; (Ḥam p. 105;) or he moved his posteriors in walking, like as does a woman; or he bent, or bowed, himself to others. (TA.) Accord. to IAạr, AlbzAC [probably a mistranscription for AlUibozaMCu] signifies AlSlf [i. e. AlS-alafu, app. meaning An extravagant affecting of elegance of carriage, such as is common with women]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. tbAzI: see 4.
Also He stepped wide. (Ḳ.)
And He made a vain, or false, boast of abundance, or riches; or a boast of more than he possessed; or invested himself with that which did not belong to him. (Ḳ.)
bazowN The equal, equivalent, or like, of a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Oaxacotu minohu bazowa kacaA [I took from him, or of it, the equal, equivalent, or like, of such a thing]. (Ṣ.)

baAzK (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAzN [mentioned in art. bwz] (Mṣb, TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ in this art.) and baAzN [mentioned in art. bOz] and baAziI-N↓ (TA) [A name given to several varieties of the hawk, or falcon;] a species of Saqor, (Ḳ,) that preys, or hunts or catches game; (Ṣ;) the proudest and fiercest of birds of prey, found in the country of the Turks: it is said that this name is only given to the female, and that the male is of another kind, a kite, or a white falcon (XaAhiyn), and hence the varieties of form, &c. in different individuals of the species: that of which the prevailing colour is white is the best, and the fullest in body, and the boldest, and the easiest to train: this variety (the OaXohab) is found only in the country of the Turks, and Armenia, and the country of the Khazar: (Ḳzw:) [see also baAXaqN:] respecting the derivation, see 1, in two places: the pl. (of baAzK, Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb) is buzaApN (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bawaAzK; (ISd, Ḳ;) and (of baAzN, Mṣb) biyzaAnN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and OabowaAzN, (Mṣb,) the former a pl. of mult., and the latter a pl. of pauc., (TA,) or the former is originally buzoyaAnN [and therefore a pl. of baAzK]; (IḲṭṭ, TA in art. myd;) and (of baOozN, Ḳ in art. bOz,) OaboWuzN [a pl. of pauc.] and buWuwzN (Ḳ in this art. and in art. bOz) and biYozaAnN. (Ḳ in the latter art.)
baAziI-N: see baAzK.

OabozaI, applied to a man, (Ṣ, Mgh,) Having what is termed bazFA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., prominence of the breast and depression of the back, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 105,) or of the part between the shoulder-blades: (Ḥam ubi suprà:), &c.: [see 1, latter part:] fem. bazowaMCu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the masc. is sometimes coupled with Oabozaxu; and the fem., with bazoxaMCu, applied to an old woman who, when she walks, is as though she were bowing down her head and body: and the fem. is said by some to signify sticking out her posteriors to be seen of men. (TA.)
huwa mubozK bihecaA AlOamori He is strong, or able, to perform this affair; a prudent, or sound, manager thereof. (Ṣ.)
1. bas-N signifies The act of breaking: or breaking in pieces: syn. HaTomN. (TA.)
[And The act of mixing: see basiysapN. This, or the former, is probably the primary signification.]

[And hence, app.,] bas-ahu, aor. _u {yabosusu}, inf. n. bas-N, (M, Mṣb,) He broke it, crumbled it, or bruised or brayed it; said of wheat, &c.; thus making it what is termed basiysap: (Mṣb:) or he mixed it, namely, sawyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat], and flour, &c., with clarified butter, or with olive-oil; thus making it what is termed bsiysap: (M:) or he moistened it, namely, sawiyq, and flour, with a little water; (ISk, Mṣb;) but making it more moist than one does in the action termed lat-N: (Yaạḳoob, cited in the Ṣ; and ISk, in the Mṣb:) or bas-N signifies the making, or preparing, bsiysap, by stirring about, or moistening, sawiyq, or flour, or ground OaqiT, with clarified butter, or with olive-oil; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) after which it is eaten, without being cooked. (Ṣ.)

[And hence the saying in the Ḳur lvi. 5,] wabus-ati AljibaAlu bas-FA And the mountains shall be crumbled with a vehement crumbling, (Lḥ, M, A, Ḳ,) like flour, and sawiyq, (A,) and become earth: (Fr, Ḳ:) or become dust cleaving to the earth: (AO, M, TA:) or be levelled: (M, TA:) or mixed with the dust: (Zj, M, TA:) or reduced to powder and scattered in the wind. (TA.)

basiysapN Wheat, &c., broken, or crumbled, or bruised: (Mṣb:) or sawiyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat], and flour, &c., mixed with clarified butter, or with olive-oil: (M:) or what is stirred about with olive-oil, or with clarified butter, and not wetted [with water]: (Lḥ, M:) or swyq, or flour, or ground OaqiT, stirred about, or moistened, with clarified butter, or with oliveoil; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) after which it is eaten, without being cooked: (Ṣ:) or swyq, and flour, moistened with a little water, (ISk, Mṣb,) but more moist than such as is prepared in the manner termed lat-N; (Yaạḳoob, cited in the Ṣ; and ISk, in the Mṣb;) and used as travelling-provision: (TA:) and bread dried and pounded, and [mixed with water so that it is] drunk like as swyq is drunk: (M, Ḳ:*) IDrd thinks it to be what is termed fatuwv: also barley mixed with date-stones, for camels: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Aṣ, anything that one mixes with another thing: such as swyq with AqT, which one then moistens with fresh butter: and such as barley with date-stones, which one then moistens, for camels: (Mṣb,* TA:) pl. bususN, (IAạr, TA,) which is explained in the Ḳ as signifying messes of swyq moistened, or stirred about with water, &c. (OasowiqapN malotuwtapN). (TA.)

1. basaOa bihi, and basiYa; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) aor. _a {yabosaOu}; (M, Ḳ;) inf. n. basoCN and busuwoCN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and basaMCN, (M, Ḳ,) all of the former verb; (M;) and basaOo, (M, Ḳ,) of the latter; (M;) He was, or became, sociable, friendly, or familiar, with him; (namely, a man, Ṣ, TA;) or cheered, or gladdened, by his company or converse, or by his presence. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
basaOa biAlOamori, inf. n. basoCN and busuwoCN, He was, or became, accustomed, or habituated, to the affair, or case. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.)
[And hence,] basaOa bihi He despised, or made light of, him, or it. (M, Ḳ.)
4. OabosaOotuhu I made him sociable, friendly, or familiar; or cheered him, or gladdened him, by my company or converse, or by my presence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
basuwoCN A she-camel that offers no opposition to her milker, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) being of a good disposition, and accustomed to him. (TA.)
bst accord. to some: bstAn accord. to others.

busotaAnN [accord. to its etymology (which will be explained below) and to general modern usage, A garden of sweet-scented flowers and trees: but accord. to the Arabic Lexicons,] a [garden such as is termed] jan-ap: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a [garden, or walled garden, such as is termed] Hadiyqap, (M, Ḳ, TA,) of palm-trees; as in a poem of El-Aạshà: (TA:) said by Fr to be an Arabic word; (Mṣb, TA;) but this is denied by IDrd: (TA:) and said by some to be ruwmiI- [or Greek]: (Mṣb:) [but correctly] it is an arabicized word, from [the Persian] buwsotaAnN [bóstán]; (Ḳ, [in which the n is regarded as a radical letter,] Shifá el-Ghaleel, MF,) meaning “taking odour, or fragrance,” or, as some say, “a place where odour, or fragrance, collects, or is collected:” (Shifá el-Ghaleel, MF:) its composition from bw and stAn requires the former meaning to be assigned to it: (TA:) [or rather it signifies “a place of odour, or fragrance:”] afterwards applied to trees: (TA:) pl. basaAtiynu (Mṣb, Ḳ) and basaAtuwna, (Ḳ,) like XayaATiynu and XayaATuwna. (TA.)
busotanobaAnN [an arabicized word from the Persian busotaAnobaAno, i. q. busotaAniI-N↓, which is the more common; A gardener, or] a keeper of a busotaAn. (TA.)
busotaAniI-N: see what next precedes.
bus-acN an arabicized word, [because s and c do not occur in any one Arabic word, (Mṣb, voce OusotaAcN,)] Coral; syn. marojaAnN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. basara He took anything when it was fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid; (TA;) as also Abtsr↓ [which is more commonly used]. (M, Ḳ,* TA.) [Hence,] basarobu Aln-abaAta, aor. _u {yabosuru}, inf. n. basorN, I pastured [beasts] upon the herbage when it was fresh and juicy, I being the first to do so. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (M,) i. q. OaEojala [as meaning † He was quick, or beforehand, or before the proper time, with a person or thing, or in doing, or seeking, a thing]. (M, Ḳ.) [Hence,] basara Aln-aAqapa, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (M;) and AbtsrhA↓, (Ṣ, A,) and tbs-rhA↓; (T;) ‡ He (the stallion) covered the she-camel without her desiring it: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A:) or before she desired it. (M, Ḳ.) And in like manner, basara and tbs-r↓ ‡ He (a stallion) covered a mare when she had only begun to feel the excitement of desire. (TA.) And Abtsr↓ AljaAriyapa ‡ He deflowered the girl before she had attained to puberty. (A, and Mṣb in art. qD.) And basara and Abtsr↓ † He fecundated a palm-tree before the proper time for doing so. (M, Ḳ.) And basara Als-iqaMCa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) † He drank the milk of the skin, (Ḳ,) or gave it to be drunk, (Ṣ,) before it had become thick, and fit for churning. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And basara, (M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M, A,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, M,) ‡ He broke a pustule: (A:) or he squeezed a pustule, or a boil, before it was ripe: (TA:) or he laid it open by peeling off its crust, or scab, before it was ripe; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also Absr↓. (Ḳ.) And, inf. n. as above, † He dug rivers when water was scarce: or sought for, or after, water [when it was scarce]: and so, accord. to Az, tbs-r↓. (L. [But for AcA ErA AlmAC Aw TAbh, as part of the explanation, I read UicaA Eaz-a AlmaACu Oawo Talabahu.]) And basara Aln-ahora † He dug a well in [the bed of] the river, it being dry. (L. [But here, for w hw SAf, I read w hw jaAf-N.]) Also basara, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (M,) and inf. n. as above (Ṣ, M) and bisaArN; (M;) and Abtsr↓ (M, A, Ḳ) and tbs-r↓ and Absr↓; (M, Ḳ;) ‡ He sought, sought for or after, demanded, or desired, a thing that he wanted, or needed, in an improper time: (M, Ḳ:) or in an improper place: (Ṣ, M:) or in an improper manner: (Jm:) or before its time. (A.) And the first of these verbs, ‡ He required a debt to be paid before the time when it was due. (Ḳ, TA.) And ‡ He required his debtor to pay a debt before the time when it was due: from basara Aln-aAqapa, explained above. (Sh, TA.)
Also, inf. n. basorN, † He began a thing; and so Abtsr↓. (Ḳ.) And basara bihi (TḲ) and Abtsr↓ bh (TA, TḲ) † He began with it. (TA, TḲ.)

Also, aor. _u {yabosuru}, inf. n. basorN, He mixed busor [or fullgrown unripe dates] with others, in beverage of the kind called nabiyc: the doing of which is forbidden in a trad.: (Ṣ:) or he mixed busor with fresh ripe dates, or with dry dates, and made with them both together that kind of beverage. (TA.) And basara tamorFA, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; and bs-rhu↓ (M) and Absrhu↓; (Ḳ;) He made, of dry dates, that kind of beverage, and mixed busor with it. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabosuru}, inf. n. basorN and busuwrN, (M,) He frowned; contracted his face; or grinned, or displayed his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; (M, Ḳ;) as also basara wajohahu, inf. n. busuwzN: (Ṣ:) or he did so excessively: (Jel in lxxiv. 22:) or he looked with intense dislike or hatred. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1; last sentence but one.
3. baAsarato, inf. n. mubaAsarapN, † She (a mare) desired the stallion when she had only begun to feel the excitement of lust. (AO.)

hom.sense: 4. Aysr: see 1, in three places.
Also † He dug in ground that had not been dug before. (Ḳ.)
AbsrAln-axolu The palm-trees had dates in the state in which they are called busor: (Ṣ, M:*) or produced dates that did not ripen. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tbs-r: see 1, in four places. It signifies also † He sought for, or after, fresh water recently produced by rain. (Ṣ. [See busorN.]) And † He dug for plants before they came forth: (M, TA:) [or] tbs-r nabaAtFA has this meaning. (TA.) And † He (a [wild] bull) came to the roots of dry plants, and ate them. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8. Abtsr: see 1, in seven places.
Aubotusira lawonuhu ‡ His colour changed, (Ḳ, TA,) and became like that of busor [or full-grown unripe dates]. (TA.)
basorN: see busorN:
and see also baAsirN.

entry.sense: busorN Anything fresh, juicy, moist, not flaccid. (IF, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say nabaAtN busorN A fresh plant: (Mṣb:) or a plant that has risen from the surface of the ground, but not grown tall; because it is then fresh and juicy: (TA:) or such is called busorapN [fem. of busorN]; as also what is fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid, of the plant called buhomaI. (M.) A plant, or herbage, when it first appears in the ground is termed baAriDN; then, jamiymN; then, busorapN; then, SamoEaMCu; and then, [when it is dry,] basorN. (Ṣ.)

Fresh water, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) recently produced by rain; (Ṣ, M;) as also basorN↓: (M:) or this latter signifies cold, or cool, water: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former bisaArN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like as rimaAHN is pl. of rumoHN. (Ṣ.)
‡ A young, or youthful, man, and woman: (Ḳ, TA:) or young, or youthful, and fresh; fem. with p {busorapN}: (M, A:) applied, respectively, to a man and a woman; (M;) or to a boy and a girl. (A.)
And, with p {busorapN}, ‡ The sun when it has just risen, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and is red, and not yet clear. (A,* TA.) [Accord. to the A, this meaning seems to be derived from that next following.]

busorN and busurN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [the former, only, mentioned in the A and Mṣb, &c., as the latter is rare; coll. gen. ns., signifying Fullgrown] unripe dates; dates before they have become ruTab; (M, Ḳ;) dates that have become coloured, but have not become ripe; (TA;) dates that have begun to colour, i. e., to become red or yellow; (Mṣb in art. bulH;) dates beginning to ripen: (IAth, TA in art. blH:) so called because fresh and juicy, and not flaccid: (M:) n. un. busorapN and busurapN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. busoraAtN (Ṣ) [or busorapN] and busuraAtN: (M:) Sb says that busurapN [or busorapN or each of these] has no broken pl.; but he allows busoraAn and tamoraAn, as meaning two sorts of busor and of takor. (M.) [J says,] busorK in their first stage are termed TaloEN; then, xalaAlN; then, balaHN; then, busorN; then, ruTabN; then, tamorN: (Ṣ:) but this saying of J is not good: the original thereof is termed TlE; and when they have become organized and compact (UicaA AnoEaqada), they are termed sayaAbN or say-aAbN [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ]; and when they have become green and round, jadaAlN and saraAdN and xalaAlN; and when they have become somewhat large, bagowN; and when they have become large, [or full-grown,] busorN; then, muxaT-amo; then, muwak-itN; then, tuconuwbN; then, jumosapN [in the CK jamiysapN]; then, vaEodahN and xaAliEN and xaAliEapN; and when completely ripe, ruTabN and maEowN; then, tamorN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] busorapN signifies also ‡ The head, or extremity, of the penis of a dog. (Ḳ, TA.)
And † A kind of bead; syn.xarazapN. (Ḳ.)
busurN: see busorN.
busorapN fem. of busorN as an epithet, and n. un. of the same as a subst.: explained with the latter.
busurapN n. un. of busurN, a dial. var. of busorN, q. v.

baAsirN and basorN↓, the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet, A face frowning; or contracted; or grinning, or displaying the teeth, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look. (M.) [See 1, last sentence.] wawujwhN yawomYicK baAsirapN, in the Ḳur lxxv. 24, means And faces on that day shall be excessively frowning or contracted,, &c.: (Jel:) or expressive of dislike or hatred, and contracted. (Ḳ.) [See also baAsilN.]

baAsuwrN A well-known disease; (Ḳ;) a swelling, or tumour, which nature drives to every part of the body, from a humour that comes from the anus (AlmaqoEadap), and the testicles, and the edges of the labia majora of the pudendum muliebre, and other parts; and when in the anus, attended by a swelling of the veins; (Mṣb;) sing. of; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which signifies a certain disease that arises in the anus (AlmqEdp), [namely, the hemorrhoids, or piles, to which this term generally applies when it is used absolutely,] and also in the inside of the nose; (Ṣ;) what resembles boils in the anus: (Mgh:) sometimes the s is changed into S: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and it is said that the word is not Arabic. (Mṣb.)
mubosirN: see what next follows.
naxolapN mibosaArN, (M, Ḳ,) and mubosirN↓ without p, as though a possessive epithet, (M,) A palm-tree of which the dates do not ripen. (M, Ḳ.) [See also 4.]
mabosuwrN Affected by the disease termed bawaAsiyr, pl. of baAsuwrN. (TA.)
mubaAsirapN † A mare desiring the stallion (AO, Ḳ *) when she has only begun to feel the excitement of lust, (AO,) or before she is fully excited by lust. (Ḳ.) [See also mubaAXirN.]

hom.sense: 1. basaTahu, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabosuTu}, (M, TA,) inf. n. basoTN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) contr. of tabosyiTN; (M, TA;) as also bs-Thu↓, (M,* TA,) inf. n. tabosyiTN. (TA.) [As such,] He spread it; spread it out, or forth; expanded it; extended it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, B;) as also bs-Thu↓: (Ḳ:) and he made it wide, or ample: these are the primary significations; and sometimes both of them may be conceived; and sometimes, one of them: and the verb is also used, metaphorically, as relating to anything which cannot be conceived as composed or constructed: (B:) and baSoTN is the same as basoTN, (Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. bST,) in all its meanings. (Ḳ.) You say, basaTa Alv-awoba [He spread, spread out, expanded, or unfolded, the garment, or piece of cloth]. (Mṣb.) And basaTa rijolahu ‡ [He stretched forth, or extended, his leg]. (TA.) And basaTa ciraAEayohi, and bas-aTahumaA↓, † He spread his fore arms upon the ground; the doing of which [in prostrating oneself] in prayer is forbidden. (TA.) And basaTa yadahu (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) ‡ He stretched forth, or extended, his arm, or hand; (M, Ḳ;) as in the saying basaTa UiliI-a yadahu bimaA OuHib-u waOakorahu ‡ [He stretched forth, or extended, towards me his arm, or hand, with, i. e. to do to me, what I liked and disliked]: (M, TA:*) or he stretched forth his hand opened. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [v. 31], laYino basaTota UilaI-a yadaka litaqotulaniI † [Assuredly if thou stretch forth towards me thy hand to slay me]. (M, TA.) basoTu Alyadi and Alkaf-i is sometimes used to denote assaulting and smiting: [as in the last of the exs. given above; and] as in the words of the Ḳur [lx. 2], wayabusuTuwA Uilayokumo Oayodiyahumo waOalosinatahumo biAls-uwoCi ‡ [And they will stretch forth towards you their hands and their tongues with evil]; (TA;) i. e., by slaying, (Bḍ, Jel,) and smiting, (Jel,) and reviling. (Bḍ, Jel.) And sometimes to denote giving liberally: (TA:) [as in] basaTa yadahu fiI AlUanofaAqi ‡ He [stretched forth his hand, opened, or] was liberal or bountiful or munificent [in expenditure]: (Mṣb:) see basiyTN, below. (TA.) And sometimes to denote taking, or taking possession, or seizing: as in the saying, (TA,) busiTato yaduhu Ealayohi ‡ [His hand was stretched forth against him]; i. e. he was made to have dominion over him by absolute force and power. (Ḳ, TA.) And sometimes to denote seeking, or demanding: [as in basaTa kaf-ayohi fiI Ald-uEaMCi ‡ He expanded his two hands in supplication; a common action, in which the two hands are placed together like an open book upon a desk before the face, in supplicating God:] see baAsiTN, below. (TA.)
[And hence,] basaTotu lahu OamoriI ‡ I displayed, or laid open, to him my state, or case, or affair; syn. faraXotuhu Uiy-aAhu: (A in art. frX:) and Oamorahu [his state,, &c.]. (TA in that art.)
[Hence also,] Aall-ehu yabosuTu AlOarowaAHa fiI AlOajosaAdi Einoda AlHayaApi † [God diffuses the souls in the bodies at the time of their being animated]. (TA.)

[Hence also,] basaTa Qll-ehu Alr-izoqa † God multiplied, or made abundant, and amplified, enlarged, or made ample or plentiful, the means of subsistence. (Mṣb, Ḳ.*) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 246], waQll-ehu yabiDu wayabosuTu (Mṣb and TA in art. qbD, q. v.) And you say, basaTa Ealayohimu AlEadola ‡ [He largely extended to them equity, or justice]; as also bs-Thu↓. (TA.)
[Hence also,] fulaAnN yabosuTu Eabiydahu vum-a yaqobiDuhumo ‡ [Such a one enlarges the liberty of his slaves; then abridges their liberty]. (A in art. qbD.)

[Hence also, basaTa wajohahu † It unwrinkled, as though it dilated, his countenance: see 7. And basaTa qalobahu † It dilated his heart: see remarks on qaboDN and basoTN, as used by certain of the Soofees, near the end of 1 in art. qbD. And] basaTahu, alone, [signifies the same; or] ‡ it rejoiced him; rendered him joyous, or cheerful: (M, Ḳ, TA:) because, when a man is rejoiced, his countenance becomes unwrinkled (yanobasiTu), and he becomes changed [and cheerful] in [its] complexion: it is wrongly said, by MF, to be not tropical: that it is tropical is asserted by Z, in the A: MF also says that it is not post-classical; and in this he is right; for it occurs in a saying of Moḥammad: thus in a trad. respecting Fátimeh, yabosuTuniI maA yabosuTuhaA What rejoices her rejoices me: (TA:) [see also qabaDahu, where this saying is cited according to another relation:] OabosaTaniI↓ [as signifying ‡ it rejoiced me] is a mistake of the vulgar [obtaining in the present day]. (TA.)
[Hence also,] Alxayoru yaqobiDuhu waAlX-ar-u yabosuTuhu ‡ [Wealth makes him closefisted, tenacious, or niggardly; and poverty makes him open-handed, liberal, or generous]. (A in art. qbD.)

[Hence also,] busaTa mino fulaAnK ‡ He rendered such a one free from shyness, or aversion: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) he emboldened him; incited him to [that kind of presumptuous boldness which is termed] daAl-ap. (Ḥar p. 155.) [In the CK, basaTa fulAnAF mn fulAnK is erroneously put for basaTa fulaAnN mino fulaAnS]
[Hence also,] basaTa Qll-ehu fulaAnFA EalaI-a ‡ God made, or judged, such a one to excel me. (Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence also,] basaTa AlmakaAnu Alqawoma ‡ The place was sufficiently wide, or ample, for the people, or company of men. (Ḳ, TA.) And hecaA firaAXN yabosuTuka ‡ This is a bed ample, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or sufficiently wide for thee. (A.) And faraXa liI firaAXAF laA yabosuTuniI He spread for me a bed [not wide enough for me, or] that was [too] narrow [for me], (ISk, Ṣ.)
[Hence also,] basaTa AlEudora, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ He accepted, or admitted, the excuse. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
All these significations of the verb are ramifications of that first mentioned above. (TA.)
basaTa, aor. _u {yabosuTu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. basaATapN, (M,) † He was, or became, free, or unconstrained, (munobasiTN,) with his tongue. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in four places.

3. bAsThu, inf. n. mubaAsaTapN and bisaATN ‡ [He conversed, or acted, with him without shyness, or aversion; boldly; in a free and easy manner; or cheerfully]: (TA:) he met him laughingly, or smilingly, so as to show his teeth. (So accord. to an expl. of the latter of the two inf. ns. in the TA.) [See kaAXarahu.] You say also, bayonahumaA mubaAsaTapN ‡ [Between them two is conversation, or behaviour, free from shyness, or aversion; bold; free and easy; or cheerful]. (TA.)
4: see 1, latter half.
5: see 7.
tbs-T fiI AlbilaAdi † He journeyed far and wide in the countries. (Ṣ, TA.)
xaraja yatabas-aTu † He went forth betaking himself to the gardens and green fields: from basaATN signifying “land having sweet-smelling plants.” (TA.)

7. AnbsT quasi-pass. of basaTahu; as also tbs-T↓ is of bas-aTahu; both signifying It became spread or spread out or forth, or it spread or spread out or forth; it became expanded, or it expanded, or it expanded itself; it became extended, or it extended, or it extended itself: [&c.]. (M, Ḳ, TA.) You say, AnbsT AlX-ayoCu EalaI AlOaroDi [The thing became spread or spread out, &c., upon the ground]. (Ṣ.) And AnbsT Aln-ahaAru The day became advanced, the sun being high: it became long: (M, Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner one uses the verb in relation to other things. (M, TA.)
[And hence, † He expatiated.]

[And] AnbsT wajohuhu † [His countenance became unwrinkled, as though dilated; i. e. it became open, or cheerful; and so AnbsT alone; or he became open, or cheerful, in countenance, as is said in the KL.]. (TA.) [And AnbsT, alone, ‡ He became dilated in heart; or he rejoiced; or became joyous, or cheerful: see basaTahu.]

[Hence also,] AnbsT ‡ He left shyness, or aversion; he became free therefrom: (Ṣ, TA:) he was, or became, bold, forward, presumptuous, or arrogant: (KL, PṢ:) he became emboldened, and incited to [that kind of presumptuous boldness which is termed] daAl-ap. (Ḥar p. 155.) And AnbsT Uilayohi ‡ [He was open, or unreserved, to him in conversation: and he acted towards him, or behaved to him, without shyness or aversion; or with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance: and he applied himself to it (namely, an affair,) with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance.] (TA.)
basoTN, as signifying A certain intoxicating thing, [a preparation of hemp,] is post-classical. (TA.)
busoTN: see basiyTN, in seven places.
bisoTN: see basiyTN, in seven places.
busuTN: see basiyTN, in seven places.

basoTapN Width, or ampleness; syn. saEapN: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Mṣb:) and length, or height: (Ṣgh:) pl. bisaATN: (Ṣgh:) and increase: or redundance, or excess: (TA:) and, (M, Ḳ,) as also busoTapN↓, (Ḳ,) excel-lence; (M, Ḳ;) in science and in body: (M:) or in science, expatiation, or dilatation: (Ḳ:) or profit to oneself and others: (TA:) and in body, height, or tallness; and perfection, or completeness. (Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 24], wazaAdahu basaTapF fiI AlEilomi Aljisomi [And hath increased him in excellence, &c., in respect of science, or knowledge, and body]: (M,TA:) Zeyd Ibn-ʼAlee here read busoTapF↓. (TA.)
[An arm's length.] See baAsiTN
AimoraOapN basoTapN. A woman beautiful and sleek in body: and in like manner, ZaboyapN a gazelle that is so. (M.)
busoTapN: see basoTapN, in two places.
OucunN basoTaMCu ‡ A wide and large ear. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
busoTiI-N A seller of busoT [or carpets,, &c.]: pl. busoTiy-uwna. (TA, but only the pl. is there mentioned and explained.)
basoTaAnu: see basiyTN
busoTaAnN: see basiyTN

basaATN Land (OaroD) expanded and even; as also basiyTapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) and wide, or spacious; (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bisaATN↓, (Fr, Ḳ,) in his explanation of which Fr adds, in which nothing is obtained; (TA;) and basiyTN↓; (Ḳ;) and basiyTapN↓: (AO, Ḳ:) and in like manner, a place; (Ṣ, TA;) as also bisiATN↓; (TA;) and basiyTN↓: (Ṣ, TA;) and land in which are sweet-smelling plants: (TA:) or basiyTpN↓ is a subst., (IDrd, M,) as some say, (M,) and signifies the earth. (IDrd, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, naHonu fiI bisaATK↓ wasaEap ‡ [We are in an ample and a plentiful state]. (TA.) And bayonanaA wabayona AlmaMCi miylN bsATN [the last word thus, without any vowel-sign to the b] † Between us and the water is a long mile. (TA.) [See also baAsiTN.] And maA EalaI AlbasiyTapi↓ mivolu fulaAnK There is not upon the earth the like of such a one. (TA.) And cahaba fiI busayoTapa↓, a dim., imperfectly decl., He (a man, TA) went away in the earth, or land. (A, O, L, Ḳ.)
Also A great cooking-pot. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: bisaATN A thing that is spread or spread out or forth; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, B;) whatever it be; a subst. applied thereto: (B:) [and particularly a carpet; which is meant by its being said to be] a certain thing well known; the word being of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like kitaAbN in the sense of makotuwbN, and firaAXN in the sense of maforuwXN, &c.: (Mṣb:) pl. [of mult.] busuTN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and busoTN and [of pauc.] OabosTapN. (TA.)
See also basiyTN; near the middle of the paragraph.
AinobaraI liTaI-i bisaATihi. is a phrase meaning † He hastened to cut short his speech. (Ḥar p. 280.)
Also The leaves of the tree called samur that fall upon a garment, or piece of cloth, spread for them, the tree being beaten. (M, Ḳ.)
See also basaATN, in three places.

entry.sense: basiyTa and basiyTapN: see basaATN, in six places.
waqaEa Algayovu basiyTFA mutadaArikFA The rain fell spreading widely upon the earth, continuously, or consecutively. (TA.)
fulaAnN basiyTu Aljisomi † [Such a one is tall of body]. (Ṣ, TA.)
basiyTu Alwajohi ‡ A man (M) having the countenance [unwrinkled, or] bright with joy: (M, Ḳ, TA:) pl. busuTN (M, Ḳ.*)

basiyTu Alyadayoni ‡ A man large, or extensive, in beneficence; (M, TA;) liberal, bountiful: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. busuTN: (M, Ḳ:) [and so] basiyTu AlbaAEi (Ṣ,) [and] munobasiTu↓ AlbaAEi. (TA.) And yaduhu bisoTN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like TiHonN in the sense of maToHuwnN, and qiTofN in the sense of maqoTuwfN, (TA,) and busuTN↓ (Z, Ḳ,) like OunufN and sujuHN, (Z,) and (Z, Ḳ) by contraction, (Z,) busoTN↓, (Z, Ḳ,) and mabosuwTapN↓, (TA,) ‡ His hand is liberal; syn. muTolaqapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and TaloqN; (TA;) or he is large in expenditure. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [v. 69], balo yadaAhu mabosuwTataAni↓; (TA;) and accord. to one reading, bisoTaAni↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and accord. to another, with damm, [as though it were busoTaAni↓,] (Z, Ḳ, TA,) [but it is said that] in this case it is used as an inf. n., [and therefore busoTaAnN↓, for an inf. n. is applied as an epithet to a dual and a pl. subst. without alteration,] like guforAnN and ruDowaAnN; or, accord. to some, it is most probably [ basoTaAnu↓,] like raHomaAnu; and Talhah Ibn-Musarrif read bisaTaAni↓: (TA:) the meaning is, ‡ Nay, his hands are liberal, or bountiful; the phrase being a simile; for in this case there is no hand, nor any stretching forth. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., yadaA Qll-ehi busoTaAni↓ limusiIoCi Aln-ahaAri Hat-aI yatuwba biAll-ayoli walimusiIoCi All-ayoli Hat-aI yatuwba biAln-ahaAri, (Ḳ,* TA,) or, accord. to one relation, bisoTaAni↓, (TA,) meaning ‡ God is liberal in forgiveness to the evil-doer of the day-time until he repent [in the night, and to the evil-doer of the night-time until he repent in the day]: for a king is said to be mabosuwTu↓ Alyadi when he is ‡ liberal in his gifts by command and by sign, although he gives nothing thereof with his hand, nor stretches it forth with them at all. (Ṣgh. TA.)
basiyTN also signifies munobasiTu↓ All-saAni, (Lth,) or munobasiTN bilisaAnihi, (M, Ḳ,) † [Free, or unconstrained, in tongue, or with his tongue,] applied to a man: (M:) fem. with p {basiyTapN}. (Ḳ.)

AlbasiyTu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ;) namely, the third; the measure of which consists of musotafoEiluno faAEiluno eight [a mistake for four] times: (Ḳ:) so called because of the extension of its OasobaAb, commencing with a sabab immediately followed by another sabab, as is said by Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ. (M.)
[basiyTN is also used in philosophy as signifying † Simple; uncompounded.]
basiyTapN, as an epithet; and as a subst.: see basaATN, in four places.
[In philosophy, † A simple element: pl. basaAYiTu.]
cahaba fiI busayoTapa: see basaATN.
baAsiTN act. part. n. of basaTa.

It is said in the Ḳur [vi. 93], waAlmalaAYikapu baAsiTuwA Oayodiyhimo, meaning ‡ The angels being made to have dominion over them by absolute force and power (Ḳ,* TA.) And again, in the Ḳur [xiii. 15], kabaAsiTi kaf-ayohi UilaI AlmaMCi liyaboluga ‡ Like the supplicator of water, making a sign to it [with his two hands], in order that it may [reach his mouth, and so] answer his prayer; (Ḳ,* TA;) or, but it will not answer his prayer. (O, TA.)

AlbaAsiTu † God, who amplifies, or enlarges, or makes ample or plentiful, the means of subsistence, to whomsoever He will, (Ḳ, TA,) by his liberality and his mercy: (TA:) or who diffuses (yabosuTu) the souls in the bodies at the time of [their] being animated. (TA.)

maMCN baAsiTN ‡ Water that is distant from the herbage, or pasturage, (M, Ḳ, TA,) but less so than what is termed muTolibN. (M, TA.) And xamosN baAsiTN † A difficult [journey of the kind termed] ximosa [i. e. of five days, whereof the second and third and fourth are without water]; syn. baAYiSN. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) And EuqobapN baAsiTapN (ISK, Ṣ, M, Ḳ [in the CK, erroneously, EaqabapN]) † [A stage of a journey, or march or journey from one halting-place to another,] that is far, or distant, (ISk, Ṣ,) or long: (TA:) or in which are two nights to the water. (M, Ḳ.) You say, sironaA EuqobapF baAsiTapF † [We journeyed a stage,, &c.,] that was far, or distant, or long. (ISk, Ṣ,* TA.)

rakiy-apN qaAmapN baAsiTapN, [in the CK,] and qAmapu bAsiTapN, as a prefixed n. with its complement imperfectly decl., as though they made it determinate, i. q.qaAmapN wabasoTapN↓ [A well measuring, or of the depth of, a man's stature and an arm's length]. (O, Ḳ.) AZ says, Hafara Alr-ajulu qaAmapF baAsiTapF The man dug to the depth of his stature and his arm's length (L, TA.)
mabosaTN Width, or extent; syn. mut-asaEN: (Ḳ:) as in the phrase baladN EariyDu AlmabosaTi [A region wide in extent]. (TA.) [See also basoTapN.]
mabosuwTu Alyadi and yadahu mabosuwTapN, and yadaAhu mabosuwTataAni: see basiyTN.
munobasiTu AlbaAEi and munobasiTu All-isaAni: see basiyTN.

hom.sense: 1. basaqa Aln-axolu, (aor. _u {yabosuqu} Msb,) inf. n. busuwqN, The palm-trees were, or became, tall, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and full-grown: (JK:) or exceedingly tall. (Mṣb.)

basaqa Ealayohimo, (inf. n. as above, TA,) ‡ He overcame them, excelled them, or was superior to them; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, his companions: (Ṣ:) he surpassed them in excellence. (TA.) And basaqahumo He became exalted above them in fame, or renown. (TA, from a trad.)
basaqa fiI Eilomihi He was, or became, skilled in his science, knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it. (Mṣb.)

basaqa, (JK, Ṣ, &c.,) [aor. _u {yabosuqu},] inf. n. basoqN, (Ṣ, TA,) or busaAqN, (Mṣb,) [but see the latter below,] i. q. baSaqa (JK, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ) and bazaqa (TA) [He spat]: but some, as on the authority of Kh, disallow it, saying that it has no other signification than that of excessive tallness, as in the case of a palm-tree: (Mṣb:) or the second of these verbs is the most chaste; the first and last being of weak authority, or rare. (TA.)
basaqati AlX-amosu i. q. bazaqat [and bazagat, i. e. The sun rose]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. laA tubas-iqo EalayonaA, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabosiyqN, (Ḳ,) ‡ Be not thou proliæ, or tedious, to us; syn. laA tuTaw-alo, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) or laA tataTaw-alo, (TA,) both of which signify the same. (TḲ.) [bas-aqa and tbs-q↓ are syn.; or] tabas-uqN signifies † The being proliæ, or tedious, (taTaw-alN,) and heavy, or sluggish. (TA.)

4. Absqt She (a camel) excerned the first milk, or biestings, into her udder, before bringing forth: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or she (a ewe, JK, or a camel, Yz, T) excerned the milk (Yz, JK, T) a month before bringing forth, (JK, T,) so that it oozed, or flowed;; or, as is sometimes the case, when she was not pregnant. (T.) Also She (a girl being a bikor [which means a virgin, and also one that has not yet brought forth, and one that has brought forth but once,]) had milk in her breast: so, says Az, I have heard. (TA.)
She (a ewe) had a long udder. (TA.)
And She (a ewe) was, or became, pregnant. (Bḍ in l. 10.)
5: see 2.
basoqapN A [stony tract such as is termed] Har-ap: [or one that is somewhat elevated; as also baSoqapN:] pl. bisaAqN. (Ḳ.)
busaAqN i. q. buSaAqN [Spittle, or saliva, when it has gone forth from the mouth: or saliva that flows; see buzaAqN: see also 1]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [busaAqapN is app. its n. un. And hence,]
busaAqapN Alqamari Stone of a clear white colour, that glistens; as also with S. (TA.)
basuwqN and mibosaAqN↓, both applied to a ewe, (JK, Ḳ,) and to a she-camel, (TA,) Having a long udder: (JK, Ḳ:) or i. q.↓, applied to a ewe. (JK.)

hom.sense: baAsiqN [act. part. n. of 1]. naxolapN baAsiqapN A tall palm-tree: [or an exceedingly tall palm-tree; see 1:] pl. baAsiqaAtN and bawaAsiqu. (Mṣb.) The former of these pls. occurs in the Ḳur l. 10, meaning tall: (Ṣ, Bḍ, TA:) or bearing fruit; from Oabosaqato said of a ewe, as signifying “she was, or became, pregnant;” so that it is an instance of a part. n. of the measure faAEilN from a verb of the measure OafoEala: accord. to one reading, it is baASiqaAt, because of the q. (Bḍ.) The latter of the pls. also signifies The first portions of clouds: (AḤn, TA:) [app. the portions that first appear above the horizon:] or what are elongated of the heads, or summits, (furuwE,) of a cloud: and hence, of [the plant called] OuqoHuwaAn [or chamomile]. (TA.) And baAsiqapN signifies A cloud of a clear white colour [as being always very high in the sky]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.*)
baAsiqu AlOaxolaAqi † Endowed with elevated, or noble, natural dispositions or mental qualities. (Ḥam p. 369.)
A sweet yellow fruit. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [Golius appears to have found tamorapN in the place of vamarapN.]

entry.sense: mubosiqN A she-camel excerning the first milk, or biestings, into her udder before bringing forth: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ: [see 4:] and see also basuwqN:) pl. mabaAsiyqu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And A girl that is a bikor [see 4] having milk flowing into her breast. (TA.)
mibosaAqN: see basuwqN.

hom.sense: 1. basolN (inf. n. of basala, M) is The act of preventing, hindering, withholding, debarring, forbidding, or prohibiting; syn. manoEN; the primary meaning; (Bḍ in vi. 69;) and UiEojaAlN (M, Ḳ) and HabosN; (AA, Ḳ;) [both syn. with manoEN;] and UibosaAlN↓ [inf. n. of 4, q. v. infrà,] signifies the same. (Bḍ ubi suprà.) You say, basalaniI Eano HaAjatiI, inf. n. as above, He prevented me from accomplishing my want; syn. OaEojalaniI. (M.)
