basala, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabosulu}, (M,) inf. n. busuwlN, He (a man, TA) frowned, contracted his face, or looked sternly or austerely or morosely; or, doing so, grinned, or displayed his teeth; or contracted the part between his eyes; (Eabasa;) by reason of courage, or of anger; as also tbs-l↓: (M, Ḳ:) and [so in the M, but in the Ḳ “or”] tbs-l↓ wajohuhu, (M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or tbs-l↓ [alone], (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) His face, or he, was, or became, odious, and excessively foul or unseemly or hideous, in aspect: (M, Ḳ:) and tbs-l↓ liI He (a man) was displeasing, or odious, in aspect to me. (TA.)

And [hence], (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. busuwlN, (TA,) said of milk, and of nabiyc [or must, &c.], ‡ It was, or became, strong: (Ḳ: [in the CK, bas-ala is here erroneously put for basala; and wabas-alahu, which should next follow, is omitted:]) or, said of the former, it was, or became, displeasing, or odious, in taste, and sour; and, said of the latter, it was, or became, strong, and sour. (M, TA.) Also, said of vinegar, † It, having been left long, became altered, or corrupted, in flavour. (Az in art. Hcq, TA.) And, said of flesh-meat, † It stank, or became stinking. (AḤn, M, TA.)

bisula, [aor. _u {yabosulu},] inf. n. basaAlapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and basaAlN, [respecting which latter see what follows in the next sentence,] (M, Ḳ,) He was, or became, courageous, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) from basolN meaning “forbidden,” or “prohibited;” because he who has this quality defends himself from his antagonist, as though it were forbidden to him [the latter] to do him a displeasing, or an evil, deed. (Ḥam p. 13.) El-Hoteíah says,
waOaHolaI mina Alt-amori AljaniI-i wafiyhimu
basaAlapu nafosK Uino Ouriyda basaAluhaA
[And sweeter than fresh-gathered dates, and in them is courageousness of soul, if courageousness thereof be desired]: but bsAlhA may be here altered by curtailment from basaAlanuhaA. (M.) You say, maA Oaboyana basaAlatahu [How manifest is] his courage! (TA.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2. bs-lhu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabosiylN, (Ḳ,) He made it (a thing) to be an object of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred; syn. kar-ahahu: (M:) or he disliked it, disapproved of it, or hated it; syn. karihahu. (Ḳ.)
3. mubaAsalapN [inf. n. of bAsl] The act of assaulting, or assailing, in war. (Ṣ, PṢ.)

hom.sense: 4. UibosaAlN [inf. n. of Absl] i. q. basolN as explained in the first sentence of this art.; i. e., The act of preventing, hindering, withholding, debarring, (Bḍ in vi. 69,) forbidding, or prohibiting. (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Bḍ ubi suprà.)

Abslhu (inf. n. as above, TA) He pledged, or gave in pledge, him, or it, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) likacaA [and bikacaA, as will be shown below, both meaning for such a thing]: and he gave in exchange, or as an equivalent, him, or it, likacaA [and app. bikacaA also, as above, for such a thing]; syn. Ear-aDahu: (M, Ḳ:) and he gave him up, delivered him, delivered him over, or consigned him, to destruction, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to punishment. (Az, TA.) 'Owf Ibn-El-Ahwas says,
waUibosaAliI baniI-a bigayorijuromK
baEawonaAhu walaA bidamK muraAqi
[And my giving in pledge, or as an equivalent, or giving up to destruction, my sons, not for a crime that we have committed, nor for blood that has been shed by us]: (Ṣ, M, TA:) for he had given his sons in pledge for others, seeking peace, or reconciliation. (Ṣ, TA.) Oano tubosala bimaA kasabato, in the Ḳur [vi. 69], means Lest a soul should be given up, or delivered,, &c., (AO, Ṣ, Bḍ, Jel, TA.) to destruction, (Bḍ, Jel, TA,) or to punishment, (Az, TA,) for that which it hath done, (Az, Bḍ, Jel, TA,) of evil: (Bḍ:) or be given in pledge. (Bḍ, TA.) And OuwleYika Al-aciyna OubosiluwA bimaA kasabuwA, in the same [ubi suprà], means, in like manner, Those who are given up, or delivered,, &c., (to punishment, Bḍ) for their sins: (El-Ḥasan, Bḍ,* TA:) or who are given in pledge: (Mṣb, TA:) or are destroyed: or, as Mujáhid says, are disgraced, or put to shame, by the exposure of their sins: or, as Ḳatádeh says, are imprisoned. (TA.)
Abslhu liEamalihi and biEamalihi He left him to his work, not interfering with him therein. (M, Ḳ.)

Absl nafosahu lilomawoti, (M, Ḳ,) as also Astbsl↓ [alone], (M, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 291), and tbs-l↓, and bsl↓, [which last may be either basala or basula, or perhaps it is a mistranscription for Oabosala,] (Ḥam ibid.,) He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to death, (M, Ḳ, Ḥam,) and felt certain, or sure, of it: (Ḥam, TA:) and in like manner, lilD-arobi [to beating, i. e., to being beaten]: (TA:) and Abtsl↓ lilomawoti He submitted himself to death: (TA:) and Astbsl↓ He threw himself into war, or battle, or fight, desiring to slay or be slain, (Ṣ Ḳ,) inevitably. (Ṣ.)
maA Oabosalahu How courageous, or stronghearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight! (TA.)
5. tbs-l He affected courage, or strength of heart, on the occasion of war, or fight; emboldened himself; or became like a lion in boldness. (TA.)
See 4.
See also 1, in four places.

entry.sense: 8. Abtsl lilomawoti: see 4.
10: see 4, in two places.

hom.sense: basolN [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet;] Forbidden; prohibited; unlawful: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and allowed; permitted; lawful: (AA, IAạr, M, Ḳ:) thus having two contr. significations: (AA, Ḳ:) used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem. [because originally an inf. n.]. (M, Ḳ.) You say, hecaA basolN Ealayoka This is forbidden, prohibited, or unlawful, to thee. (Bḍ in vi. 69.) And damiI lakumo basolN My blood is, or shall be, allowed, permitted, or lawful, to you. (M.)
See also baAsilN, in two places.

entry.sense: basilN: see baAsilN.
basuwlN: see baAsilN, in two places.
basiylN: see baAsilN, in three places.
basaAlapN inf. n. of basula, q. v. (Ṣ, M, &c.)

Also [i. q. busuwlN, inf. n. of basala, q. v.; meaning] A frowning, contracting the face, or looking sternly or austerely or morosely; or doing so with grinning, or displaying the teeth; or contracting the part between the eyes; by reason of courage, or of anger. (Ḥam p. 14.)
And dislike, disapprobation, displeasure, or hatred. (Ḥam ibid.)

baAsilN Courageous, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because he who is so defends himself from his antagonist; (Ḥam p. 13, and Bḍ in vi. 69;) as also basiylN↓ (Mṣb) and basuwlN↓: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) pl. of the first busolN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and busalaMCu. (M, Ḳ.)

Frowning, contracting the face, or looking sternly or austerely or morosely; or doing so with grinning, or displaying the teeth; or contracting the part between the eyes; by reason of courage, or of anger; (M, Ḳ;) as also basolN↓, (M, TA,) in the Ḳ basilN↓, but this is incorrect, (TA,) and basiylN↓: (M, Ḳ:) and baAsirN baAsilN frowning,, &c., much, or vehemently; applied to the face: (TA:) and basolN↓ (IAạr, Ḳ) and basiylN↓ (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ) displeasing, or odious, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in face, (IAạr, Ṣ,) or aspect. (Ḳ.)
The lion; (M, Ḳ;) because of his displeasing, or odious, aspect; (M;) or because his prey does not escape from him; (Bḍ in vi. 69;) as also basuwlN↓ (TA) and mutabas-ilN↓. (Ḳ.)
Applied to a saying, Hard, or severe, and displeasing, or odious. (M, Ḳ.)
Applied to a day, † Distressing, afflictive, or calamitous. (M, TA.)
mubas-alN: see baAsilN.
mutabis-ilN: see baAsilN.

musotabosilN Disposing and subjecting one's mind, or oneself, to death, or to being beaten: (Ṣ: [see also its verb:]) or, as some say, falling into a displeasing, an odious, or an evil, case, from which there is no escape. (TA.)
1. basama: see 5, with which it is syn.
[Hence,] maA basamotu fiI AlX-aIoCi ‡ I did not taste the thing. (Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence,] Abtsm↓ Als-aHaAbu Eani Albaroqi (M,) or tbs-m Eanohu (TA,) i. q. Ainokal-a Enh [i. e. ‡ The clouds displayed a faint flashing of lightning]. (M, TA.)
And tbs-m AlT-aloEu ‡ The extremities of the TlE [i. e. the spadix, or the spathe, of the palm-tree,] burst asunder. (TA.)
8: see 5, in two places.
bas-aAmN (Ṣ M, Ḳ) and mibosaAmN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) epithets from basama, (M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (Ṣ, M,) meaning kaviyru Alt-abas-umi [That smiles much]. (Ṣ.)
baAsimN part. n. of basama [meaning Smiling]. (Ḳ, TA.)

i. q. vagorN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning The front teeth: (TḲ:) [and sometimes, perhaps, the mouth:] so called as being the place of Alt-abas-um [or smiling: pl. mabaAsimu]. (TA.) One says, [of women or girls,] hun-a gur-u AlmabaAsimi [They are white in the front teeth]. (TA.)
mibosaAmN: see bas-aAmN

Q. 1. basomala, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. basomalapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He said, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL,) or wrote, (T, Mṣb,) bisomi Qll-ehi [In, or with, the name of God I recite, or read, or I begin, &c.]: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL:) or bisomi Qll-ehi Alr-aHomaAni Alr-aHiymi [In, or with, the name of God, the Compassionate, the Merciful]: (KL:) a verb of the kind termed manoHuwt i. e. compounded of two [or more] words; like Hamodala and Hawoqala and Hasobala, &c.: (Mṣb, TA:) said by some to be post-classical, not heard from the chaste Arabs; but authorized by many of the leading lexicologists, as ISk and Mṭr; and occurring in the poetry of ʼOmar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah [who is said to have been born in the year of the Flight 23]. (TA.)

mubasomalN Discourse, (TA,) or amorous behaviour, and coquettish boldness, (Mṣb,) accompanied by the saying bisomi Qll-ehi: (Mṣb, TA:) occurring in a verse of ʼOmar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah [referred to above]. (TA.)

4. Absn, said of a man, He was, or became good, or beautiful, in respect of his sajiy-ap [i. e. natural disposition], accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly, as explained by IAạr, his saHonap [i. e. aspect, or colour,, &c.]. (TA.)

basanN an imitative sequent to HasanN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [or it may signify Beautiful in aspect, &c., from the verb above; or the verb may be from this word:] or, in the opinion of Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee, originally bas-N inf. n., used in the sense of the pass. part. n., of bas-a Als-awiyqa, meaning “he moistened, or stirred about, the swyq with clarified butter, or with olive-oil, to complete, or perfect, its goodness;” one of the two s s being suppressed, and n being added; so that it means complete, or perfect. (MF. [But this derivation seems to be extremely far-fetched.])

1. baX-a, first pers. baXiXotu, aor. yabaX-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, accord. to a relation of a verse of Ru-beh, yabiX-u, so that perhaps baXaXotu was also said, (TA.) inf. n. baXaAXapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and baX-N (A, Ḳ) and baXiyXN, (TA,) He was, or became, cheerful in countenance. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, baXiXotu bihi I was, or became, cheerful in countenance [by reason of meeting] with him: (Ṣ:) or baX-a bihi (TḲ,) inf. n. baX-N (Lth, Ḳ) and baXaAXapN, (Ḳ,) signifies he rejoiced in him, or was pleased with him, namely, a friend, (Lth, Ḳ,) at meeting: (Lth:) or he showed joy, or pleasure, at meeting him. (TḲ.)
You say also, laqiytuhu fatabaXobaXa↓ biI [app. meaning I met him and he became cheerful in countenance by reason of meeting with me]; originally tabaX-aXa↓; the middle X being changed into b: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ:) or tabaXobaXa↓ bihi signifies he was, or became, sociable, or companionable, or cheerful, with him; and held loving communion with him: syn. Mnasahu, and waASalahu: (Ḳ:) but when said of God, it means ‡ He regarded him with favour, and honoured him, (IAmb, Ḳ,) and received him graciously, and drew him near to Him. (IAmb.)

Also baX-a lahu, (TḲ,) inf. n. baX-N (IDrd, Ḳ) and baXaAXapN, (Ḳ,) He presented a favourable aspect to him; or met him kindly, namely, his brother; syn. Oaqobala Ealayohi: (Ḳ:) he behaved laughingly towards him; without shyness, or aversion; or boldly; or in a free and easy manner; or cheerfully; syn. DaHika Uilayohi, (IDrd, Ḳ,) and AinobasaTa. (IDrd.)
And baX-a lahu fiI AlmasoOalapi, (TḲ,) inf. n. baX-N (IAạr, A, Ḳ) and baXaAXapN, (A, Ḳ,) He was courteous, or gracious, to him in asking. (IAạr, A, Ḳ.)
And baX-a liI bixayori ‡ He gave me [something good]. (A, TA.)
4. AbX-t AlOaroDu ‡ The land had tangled, or luxuriant, plants, or herbage: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) or produced its first plants, or herbage. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
R. Q. 2: see 1, in two places.
rajulN haX-N baX-N A man [brisk, lively, or sprightly; or joyful; and] cheerful in countenance; pleasant [therein]; (Ṣ, TA;) as also baX-aAXN↓. (TA.) [See also art. hX.]
baXiyXN The face, or countenance. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) You say, fulaAnN muDiIoCu AlbaXiyXi Such a one is bright in countenance. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
baX-aAXN: see baX-N.
OabaX-u [More, and most, cheerful in countenance]. You say, maA raOayotu OabaX-a minohu biAll-aAqiI [I have not seen any one more cheerful in countenance than he to the meeter]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. baXara, aor. _u {yaboXuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. baXorN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AbXr↓, (A,) inf. n. UiboXaArN; (Ḳ;) He pared (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) a hide, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) removing its baXarap, (Ṣ,) or face, or surface, (A, Mṣb,) or the skin upon which the hair grew: (TA:) or, as some say, removing its inner part with a large knife: or, accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, some of the Arabs say, baXarotu AlOadiyma, aor. _i {yaboXiru}, meaning I removed from the hide its baXarap; and OaboXarotuhu↓ as meaning I exposed to view its baXarap that was next to the flesh; and Mdamotuhu I exposed to view its Oadamap upon which the hair grew. (TA.) [But see OadamapN.]

Hence the saying in a trad., mano OaHab-a AlquroMna qaloyaboXuro, accord. to him who recites it thus, with damm to the X; meaning † Whoso loveth the Ḳur-án, let him make himself light of flesh, [by not eating more than will be sufficient, and so prepare himself] for [reading, or reciting,] it, [like as one prepares a horse for running,] because eating much causes one to forget it. (TA.)

Hence also, baXara AlOaroDa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † It (a swarm of locusts) stripped the ground; (TA;) ate what was upon the ground, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., upon its surface; as though the exterior of the ground were its baXarap. (TA.)

And baXara, aor. _u {yaboXuru}, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He clipped his mustache much, so that the baXarap (i. e. the exterior of the skin, TA) became apparent. (Ḳ, TA.) This the Muslim is commanded to do. (TA.)
baXaraniI fulaAnN biwajohK HasanK Such a one met me with a cheerful countenance. (Ṣ.) See also 2, in two places.
And see 3.

baXira, aor. _a {yaboXaru}; (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and baXara, aor. _i {yaboXiru}, (IAạr, Ḳ,) inf. n. baXorN and buXuwrN; (TA;) and AbXr↓, [which is the most common, though extr. in respect of analogy, as being quasi-pass. of baXara, like AHjm and AHnj and AErD and AqXE and Akb- and Anhj, (mentioned by MF in art. Hnj as the only other instances of the kind,) and Axlj, (added in the TA in art. xlj,)] (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiboXaArN; (Ṣ;) and AstbXr↓; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tbX-r↓; (A;) [originally, He became changed in his baXarap (or complexion) by the annunciation of an event: see baX-arahu: and hence,] he rejoiced, or became rejoiced; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) bikacaA [at, or by, such a thing; or at, or by, the annunciation of such a thing]. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.*) You say, OataAniI OamorN baXirotu bihi An affair happened to me whereat I rejoiced, or whereby I became rejoiced. (Ṣ.) And OaboXara↓ bimawoluwdK He rejoiced [at the annunciation of a new-born child]. (Ṣ.) And OaboXiro↓ bixayorK Rejoice thou [at the annunciation of a good event]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And in the same sense OaboXiruwA↓ is used in the Ḳur xli. 30. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2. bX-rhu (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, &c.,) the form used by the Arabs in general, (Mṣb,) inf. n. taboXiyrN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) and baXarahu↓, aor. _u {yaboXuru}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) of the dial. of Tihámeh and the adjacent parts, (Mṣb,) inf. n. baXorN and buXuwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and buXorN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and AbXrhu↓; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) and AstbXrhu↓; (Ḳ, TA;) are syn.; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) originally signifying He announced to him an event which produced a change in his baXarap [or complexion]: and hence, (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee,) he announced to him an event which rejoiced him: (A, El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) so in common acceptation [when not restricted by an adjunct that denotes its having a different meaning: see buXoraI and an ex. below in this paragraph]: (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) or he rejoiced him [by an annunciation]: (Mṣb:) and he announced to him an event which grieved him: [or he grieved him by an annunciation:] both these significations are proper. (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee.) You say, bX-rhu biAlOamori [generally meaning He rejoiced him by the annunciation of the event]; and baXarahu↓ bihi, aor. and inf. ns. as above;, &c. (TA.) And baX-arotuhu bimawoluwdK [I rejoiced him by the annunciation of a new-born child]. (Ṣ.) And it is said in the Ḳur [iii. 20, &c.], baX-irohumo biEacaAbK OaliymK [Grieve thou them by the annunciation, or denunciation, of a painful punishment]. (Ṣ.) You say also, of a she-camel, baX-arato biAll-aqaAHi, meaning † She made it known that she had begun to be pregnant. (TA. [See also 4.])

3. bAXr AlmaroOapa, (Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAXarapN (Ṣ, Mgh, TA) and biXaArN, (TA,) He was, or became, in contact with the woman, skin to skin: (TA:) he enjoyed [contact with] her skin: (Mṣb:) he became in contact with her, skin to skin, both being within one garment or piece of cloth: (Ḳ:) he lay with her, [skin to skin; or in the sense of] inivit eam: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. q. waTiYahaA, both fiI Alfaroji and xaArijFA minohu: (TA:) [and so baXarahaA↓ inf. n. baXorN; for] baXorN and mubaAXarapN are syn. [in the sense of congressus venereus, as is shown by an ex. in the Ṣ.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
bAXrhu Aln-aEiymu ‡ [Enjoyment attended him; as though it clave to his skin]. (A.)
fabaAXaruwA rawoHa Alyaqiyni, or ruwHa Alyqyn, is a metaphorical expression, [app. meaning ‡ And they felt the joy and happiness that arise from certainty,] occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee. (TA.)

bAXr AlOamora, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAXarapN, (Ṣ,) ‡ He superintended, managed, or conducted, the affair himself, or in his own person: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ he was present, himself, at the affair: (A, TA:) or, [properly,] he managed, or conducted, the affair with his baXarap, i. e., his own hand: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) and hence a later application of the verb in the sense of laAHaZa † [He regarded, or attended to, the thing, or affair, &c.]. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 4. AbXr: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

[Hence,] AbXr AlOamoru wajohahu The affair made his countenance beautiful and bright: in the Ḳ we read, OaboXara AlOamora Has-anahu wanaD-arahu; but this is a mistake. (TA.) Agreeably with this explanation, AA renders a reading in the Ḳur [xlii. 22], celika Ql-aciI yuboXiru Qll-ehu EibaAdahu, meaning That is it with which God will make beautiful and bright the face of his servants: so in the L. (TA.)
See also 2.
[Hence,] OaboXarati Aln-aAqapu † The she-camel conceived, or became pregnant: (Ḳ:) as though she rejoiced [her owner] by announcing her conception. (TA. [See 2, last sentence.])
And OaboXarati AlOaroDu ‡ The earth put forth its herbage appearing upon its surface. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, latter part, in four places.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, latter part.

6. tbAXr Alqawomu The people, or company of men, announced, one to another, a joyful event, or joyful events. (Ṣ.) And humo yatabaAXaruwna bicelika AlOamori They rejoice one another by the annunciation of that event. (TA.)

hom.sense: 10. AstbXr: see 1, latter part.
AstbXrhu He demanded of him a reward for an annunciation of joyful tidings. (M.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: buXorN: see buXoraI.
It is also a contraction of buXurN, which is pl. of baXuwrN (TA) or baXiyrN. (TA in art. nXr.)

biXorN Cheerfulness, or openness and pleasantness, of countenance: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) and happiness, joy, or gladness. (Ḥar p. 192.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlbiXori He is cheerful, or open and pleasant, in countenance. (Ṣ.)
baXarN: see baXarapN

[Hence,] AlbaXaru † Mankind: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the human being: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) applied to the male and to the female; and used alike as sing. and pl. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and dual: (TA:) so that you say, huwa baXarN He is a human being, and hiIa baXarN She is a human being, and humo baXarN They (more than two) are human beings, and humaA baXarN They two are human beings: (TA:) but sometimes it has the dual form; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as in the Ḳur xxiii. 49; (Mṣb, TA;) though the Arabs may have used the dual form in the sense of the sing.: (MF:) and sometimes it has a pl., namely, OaboXaArN. (Ḳ.) This is a secondary application of the word: (Mṣb:) i. e., this signification is tropical; or, as some say, the word is so much used in this sense as to be, so used, conventionally regarded as proper; the sense not depending upon its having another word connected with it: but in the Ṣ and Ḳ, and by the generality of authors, this signification is given as proper. (MF.) Some say that a human being is thus called because his baXarap is bare of hair and of wool. (MF.) [Hence,] Oabuw AlbaXari [The father of mankind; meaning] Adam. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baXarapN (Lth, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb) and baXarN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] like qaSabahu and qaSabN, (Mṣb,) and OaboXaArN is pl. of baXarN, (Ḳ,) [The external skin; the cuticle, or scarf-skin; the epidermis;] the exterior of the skin (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a human being; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and, as some say, of other creatures, (Ḳ,) such as the serpent; but this is generally disallowed: (TA:) or baXarapN signifies the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair; as also OadamapN and XawaApN: (Aboo-Safwán:) or the upper skin (Lth, M) of the head (M) and of the face and body of a human being; (Lth, M;) that upon which the hair grows: (M:) or, as some say, that which is next the flesh. (M.) It is said in a prov., Uin-amaA yuEaAtabu AlOadiymu cuw AlbaXarapi: see OadiymN.
baXarapN sometimes means The complexion, or hue: and fineness, or delicacy. (TA.)

baXarapu AlOaroDu ‡ The herbage appearing upon the surface of the earth. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, maA OaHosana baXaratahaA ‡ How goodly is its herbage appearing upon its surface! (Ṣ, A.) And baXarapN [alone] signifies ‡ Leguminous plants; herbs, or herbage. (TA.)
baXarapN is used also as signifying † A man's hand. (Mṣb.) [See 3, last sentence.]

entry.sense: buXoraI (imperfectly decl., because it terminates with a fem. alif which is inseparable from it, Ṣ) and biXaArapN↓ and buXaArapN↓ [but respecting this last see biXaArapN below] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buXorN↓ (Mṣb) are substs. from baX-arahu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [originally signifying An annunciation which produces a change in the baXarap (or complexion) of the person to whom it is made: and hence, a joyful annunciation; joyful, or glad, tidings; good news]: and tabaAXiyru↓ [q. v. infrà] signifies the same as buXoraI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) biXaArapN↓, when used absolutely, relates only to good; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) not to evil unless when expressly restricted thereto by an adjunct: [see 2:] (Ṣ:) its pl. is biXaAraAtN and baXaAYiru. (A.) yaA buXoraAIa, in the Ḳur [xii. 19, accord. to one reading, (otherwise, as Bḍ mentions, buXoraAIo, or buXoraI-a, which is a dial. var. of the same, or buXoraI, which, as some say, was the name of a man,) meaning O my joyful annunciation, or joyful tidings, or good news!], is like EaSaAI: and in the dual you say, yaA buXorayaI-a. (Ṣ.) You say also, tataAbaEati AlbiXaAraAtu↓ and AlbaXaAYiru [The joyful annunciations followed consecutively]. (A.) See another ex. voce baXiyrN.
See also biXaArapN.
[baXariI-N Human; of, or belonging to, or relating to, mankind or a human being.]
buXaArN † The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
baXuwrN: see what next follows, in three places.

hom.sense: baXiyrN i. q. mubaX-irN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) [and so baXuwrN↓, as will be seen by an ex. in what follows,] One who announces to a people [or person] an event, either good or evil; (TA;) but meaning the former oftener than the latter: (Mṣb:) [an announcer of a joyful event, or joyful events: one who rejoices another, or others, by an annunciation:] pl. buXaraMCu (A) and buXurN, (TA in art. nXr,) or this is pl. of baXuwrN↓. (TA in the present art.) It is said in the Ḳur [vii. 55], wahuwa Ql-aciI yurosilu Qlr-iyaAHa buXurFA, and buXorFA, and buXoraI↓, and baXorFA; [accord. to different readings, meaning † And He it is who sendeth the winds announcing coming rain;] in which buXurN is pl. of baXuwrN↓, [syn. with baXiyrN and mubaX-irN, but both masc. and fem.,] (TA,) or of baXiyrN, (Bḍ,) or of baXiyrapN; (TA in art. nXr;) and buXorFA is a contraction of the same; and buXoraI is syn. with biXaArapN; and baXorFA is the inf. n. of baXarahu in the sense of baX-arahu (TA. [But the reading commonly followed in this passage is nuXurFA, with n: another reading is nuXorFA: another, naXorFA: and another, naXarFA.]) And AlmubaX-iraAtu↓, (A,) or mubaX-iraAtu Alr-iyaAHi, (Ṣ,) signifies ‡ Winds that announce [coming] rain: (Ṣ, A:) so in the Ḳur xxx. 45. (TA.)

Also Goodly; beautiful; elegant in form or features; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man, and to a face: (TA:) fem. with p {baXiyrapN}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a woman, and to a she-camel; (Ṣ;) and meaning, when applied to a she-camel, neither emaciated nor fat: or, accord. to Aboo-Hilál, neither of generous nor of ignoble breed: or, as some say, half-fattened: (TA:) pl. of the fem. baXaAYiru: (Ṣ:) and maboXuwrapN↓ signifies beautiful in make and colour; (IAạr, Ḳ;) applied to a girl. (IAạr.)

entry.sense: baXaArapN Goodliness; beauty; elegance of form or features. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: buXaArapN What is pared off from the face of a hide: what is pared off from its back is called tiHoliYN. (Lḥ.)
See also biXaArapN:
and see buXoraI.

entry.sense: Also A gift to him who announces a joyful event; and so buXaArapN↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the latter, which is like the EumaAlap of the EaAmil, has this signification; (IAth;) and so buXoraI↓; (M;) and biXaArapN [has the same meaning accord. to common usage, but, properly,] is a subst. in the sense explained above, voce buXoraI. (IAth.) You say, OaEoTayotuhu vawobiI biXaArapF I gave him my garment as a reward for the joyful annunciation. (TA from a trad.)
huwa OaboXaru minohu He is more goodly or beautiful, more elegant in form or features, and more fat, than he. (Ḳ.)

tubuX-irN, in the hand writing of J tubaX-irN, [and so in my copies of the Ṣ,] a word of which there is not the like except in the instances of tunuw-iTN [or tunaw-iTN], a certain bird, and waAdiI tuhul-ika [or tuhal-ika?] and waAdiI tuDul-ila [or tuDal-ila] and waAdiI tuxuy-iba [or tuxay-iba], (TA,) A certain bird, called the SufaAriy-ap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {tubuX-irapN}. (Ḳ.)

tabaAXiyru, as though it were pl. of taboXiyrN, inf. n. of baX-ara; (A;) a word which has not its like except in the instances of taEaAXiybu and taEaAjiybu and tafaATiyru [and tabaAkiyru and tabaAriyHu, and probably a few others]; (TA;) ‡ [Annunciations; foretokens; foretellers; foreshowers; prognostics; earnests; of what is good:] the beginnings of anything: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the first of blossoms, &c.: (TA:) the beginnings, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or first annunciations, (A,) of daybreak; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also baXaAYiru↓: (TA:) it has no verb: (Ṣ:) and [is said to have] no sing.: but in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, taboXiyrN occurs as meaning † the commencement of rain. (TA.) One says, fiyhi maxaAyilu Alr-uXodi watabaAXiyruhu ‡ [In him are indications of right conduct, or belief, and its earnests]. (A.) See also buXoraI.
† Streaks of the light of daybreak in the night. (TA.)
† Streaks that are seen upon the surface of the ground, caused by the winds. (Lth, Ḳ.*)
† The colours of palm-trees when their fruit begins to ripen; (Ḳ;) as also tabaAkiyru. (TA.)
† Such as bear fruit early, or before others, of palm-trees. (Ḳ.)
† Marks of galls upon the side of a beast. (Ḳ.)

rajulN muWodamN muboXarN ‡ A perfect man; as though he combined the softness of the Oadamap [or inner skin] with the roughness of the baXarap [or outer skin]: (Ṣ:) or a man who combines softness, or gentleness, and strength, with knowledge of affairs: (Aṣ:) and AimoraOapN muWodamapN muboXarapN ‡ a woman perfect in every respect. (TA.) [See also art. Adm.]
mubaX-irN and mubaX-iraAtN: see baXiyrN.
maboXuwrapN: see baXiyrN, last sentence.
HijorN mubaAXirN [so in two copies of the Ṣ: in Golius's Lex. mubaAXirapN:] A mare [so I render Hjr, which Golius renders ‘ vulva, ’] desiring the stallion. (Ṣ.) [See also mubaAsirapN, with s.]

hom.sense: 1. baXiEa, aor. _a {yaboXaEu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. baXaAEapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baXaEN, (Ḳ,) said of a thing, (Ṣ,) or of food, (Ḳ, TA,) It was, or became, disagreeable in taste, and choking: (Ṣ:) or disagreeable, or unpleasant, having in it dryness and bitterness. (Ḳ, TA.)

baXiEa Alr-ajulu, (Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _a {yaboXaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baXaEN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baXaAEapN, (Ḳ,) The man was, or became, disagreeable in the odour of the mouth, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) from eating food disagreeable in taste, and choking; (Ṣ;) not removing the remains of food from between his teeth, nor cleaning them with the tooth-stick. (Ḳ.) You say, baXiEa minohu [He was, or became, disagreeable in the odour of the mouth from it]; meaning, from eating food such as is described above. (Ṣ.) [Or this phrase in the Ṣ may have another meaning, which see in what follows.]
And [hence,] ‡ The man was, or became, evil in his disposition, and in his social intercourse. (Mṣb.) You say also, fiI xuluqihi baXaAEapN ‡ In his disposition is evilness. (TA.)
baXaEN also signifies, in relation to wood, ‡ The abounding in knots. (TA.)

Also The fauces' being straitened, or choked, by coarse, or rough, food.(TA.) [And baXiEa minohu means He experienced a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces from it; namely coarse, or rough, food; or food disagreeable in taste, and choking: see 4: and see another meaning of this phrase above.]

And [hence,] baXiEa [or baXiEa biAlmaMCi,] aor. _a {yaboXaEu}, ‡ It (a valley) was, or became, choked, surcharged, or overfilled, with the water. (Ḳ.) And baXiEa biAln-aAsi ‡ It [a place] was, or became, choked, or overfilled, with men, or the people. (Z, TA.)
[Hence also,] baXiEa biAlOamori, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baXaEN and baXaAEapN, (TA,) ‡ He was unable to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair. (Ḳ, TA.)
baXiEa biAlX-aIoCi, and baXaEa bihi, inf. n.baXoEN, He seized the thing in a violent and an abominable manner. (L,TA.)

entry.sense: 4. OaboXaEaniI AlT-aEaAmu The food caused me to experience a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces, (HamalaniI EalaI AlbaXaEi,) by reason of its coarseness, or roughness. (IAạr.) [See 1.]

hom.sense: 10. AstXEhu i. q. Ead-ahu baXiEFA [He reckoned it disagreeable in taste, and choking; or disagreeable, or unpleasant, as having in it dryness and bitterness]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.)
And [hence,] AstbXE AlmuqaAma fiI maHal-i kacaA He reckoned unpleasant, or uncomfortable, the remaining in such a place of abode; syn.AisotaxoXanahu. (TA.)
AisotiboXaAEN also signifies The being bad, unpleasant, or disapproved. (KL.)

entry.sense: Applied to a man, (Ṣ TA,) as is also baXiyEN↓, in the same sense, (TA, [but in what sense is not there said,]) it signifies, Disagreeable in the odour of the mouth, (Mṣb,ast; Ḳ,) who does not remove the remains of food from between his teeth, nor clean them with the tooth-stick; (Ḳ;) fem. with p {baXiEapN}: (TA:) and one who has eaten a thing such as is thus termed, (Ṣ Ḳ TA,) and not swallowed it easily, (TA,) and has become disagreeable in the odour of the mouth from it, or has experienced a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces from it. (Ṣ, TA: [the last words of the explanation being fabaXiEa minohu])
Also ‡ One whose soul is heavy, or heaving, or agitated by a tendency to vomit. (ISh, Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ Evil in disposition, (Ḳ, TA,) and in social intercourse. (TA.) You say also, huwa baXiEa Alxuluqi ‡ He is evil in disposition. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ, TA,) or baXiEu AlmanoZari, (Mṣb,) ‡ Foul, or ugly, in aspect; (Mṣb; Ḳ) not pleasing to the eyes. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or baXiEu Alwajohi, (ISh, Mṣb,) ‡ Having a frowning, a contracted, a stern, an austere, or a morose, countenance. (ISh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
xaXabapN baXiEapN ‡ A piece of wood abounding in knots. (Ḳ, TA.)
baXiyEN: see baXiEN, in three places.

hom.sense: 1. baXiqa, aor. _a {yaboXaqu}; and baXaqa, aor _i; He struck, smote, or beat, another with a staff or stick. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, Ḳ.)
He looked sharply, or intently: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) inf. n. baXoqN. (JK.)
Also the former verb, He hastened, or was quick; as also baXaka. (IDrd, TA.)
And the former, [but the aor. is not mentioned,] He cut a garment, or piece of cloth, in a light, or prompt, manner; as also baXaka. (TA.)
And baXaqa, inf. n. baXoqN, He took, or seized. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: naZarN baXoqN A sharp, or an intent, look. (JK.)

baAXaqN (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAXiqN, (Mṣb, Es-Suyootee, TA,) the latter being allowable accord. to some for the sake of conformity to the usual Arabic measure, as in xAtm and dAnq and TAbE and the like; (Mṣb;) perhaps derived from baXoqN meaning the “looking sharply,” or “intently;” (JK;) or from baXaqa meaning “he took,” or “seized;” (Mṣb;) or it is arabicized, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) from [the Persian] baAXaho; (Ḳ;) A certain bird; (Ḳ;) [the musket, or sparrow-hawk; falco nisus;] a bird of beautiful form, the smallest of birds of prey, that preys upon sparrows and other birds of their size: (Ḳzw:) it is of the birds called Suquwr, [pl. of SaqorN,] as are also the baAziI and the XaAhiyn and the zur-aq and the yuWoyuW: (AḤát in “the Book of Birds,” TA:) pl. bawaAXiqu. (Mṣb.)

1. baXima, aor. _a {yaboXamu}, inf. n. baXamN, He (a man, Ṣ, TA, or an animal, Mṣb) suffered, or became affected with, indigestion, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in consequence of much eating: (Mṣb:) or he was heavy in consequence of food: (Ḥam p. 363:) or he became distressed, or oppressed, by eating much food. (TA.) You say, baXimotu mina AlT-aEaAmi I suffered indigestion from the food: (Ṣ:) or was heavy in consequence of the food. (Ḥam ubi suprà) And baXima AlfaSiylu mino kavorapi Xurobi All-abani The young camel suffered indigestion from drinking much milk. (Ṣ.) Accord. to IDrd, baXamN specially relates to beasts: accord. to Kh, it specially arises from greasy food. (Ḥar p. 164.)

Also ‡ He became affected with disgust, aversion, loathing, or nausea. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, baXimotu mina AlT-aEaAmi, (Ṣ,) or Eani AlTEAm, (TA,) ‡ I turned away with disgust from the food; was averse from it; loathed it; nauseated it. (Ṣ, TA.) And baXima AlfaSiylu Eani All-abani † [The young camel turned away with disgust from the milk; was averse from it;, &c.]. (Ḳ in art.dqE.)
4. AbXmhu It (food) caused him to suffer, or be affected with, indigestion: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or † loathing, or nausea. (Ḳ.)
baXima part. n. of 1, meaning Suffering, or affected with, indigestion. (Mṣb.)
[And † Affected with disgust, aversion, loathing, or nausea.]

baXaAmN [The tree of the balsam of Mekkeh; amyris opobalsamum; mentioned by Forskål in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. ex. as growing in the middle mountainous region of El-Yemen, and described by him in p. 79 of the same work; in both places as being called in Arabic Abw XAm, which is a mistake for bXAm;] a certain odoriferous kind of tree, (Ṣ Ḳ,) of sweet taste, (TA,) the leaves of which, (AḤn, Ḳ) pounded, and mixed with AlHin-aMC [or the leaves of the Lawsonia inermis], (AḤn,) blacken the hair; (AḤn, Ḳ) it is a kind of tree having a stem and branches, and small leaves, but larger than the leaves of the [species of marjoram called] SaEotar, and having no fruit; [but only, as Forskål states, a blackish seed, which is abortive;] when its leaf or its branch is cut, it pours forth a white milk; (AḤn, TA;) and its twigs are used for cleaning the teeth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {baXaAmapN}. (TA.) In a trad., mention is made of persons having no food but the leaves of the bXAm. (TA.)

baXoniynN, with fet-ḥ, and then sukoon, and then kesr, I. q. nylwfr [i. e. niyluwfarN and nayoluwfarN or nayolawofarN, the nymphæa lotus, or white lotus: and the nymphæa cærulea, or blue lotus: see art. nylwfr]: a word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)
1. baS-a, aor. yabiS-u, inf. n. baSiySN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and baS-N, (TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ, as, for instance, a grain of a pomegranate, TA) shone, or glistened. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
huwa yabuS-u liI, [He looks at me] is an expression used by the vulgar [in the present day], and is from AlbaS-aASapu signifying “the eye.” (TA.) [By rule it should be yabiS-u.]
2. bS-S bisayofihi He made a sign with his sword, waving it, or moving it about [so that it shone, or glistened] (TA.)

hom.sense:
R. Q. 1. baSobaSa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or baSobaSa bicanabihi, (M,) inf. n. baSobaSapN, (TA,) He (a dog, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, and a beast of prey, and a gazelle, and a camel when urged on by the driver's singing, TA) wagged, or moved about, his tail; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which a dog does by reason of cupidity, or fear; (TA;) as also tabaSobaSa↓: (Ṣ:) or he (a dog) struck with his tail. (ISd.) The inf. n. baSobaSapN has a pl., namely, baSaAbiSu; as in the following ex.:
Hat-aI UicaA OaboSaronahu waEalimonahu
Hay-ayonahu bibaSaAbiSi AlOaconaAbi
[Until, when they see him and know him, they greet him with waggings of the tails]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., respecting the flight and submissiveness of the coward,
baSobaSona Uico Hudiyona biAlOaconaAbi
[They wagged the tails when they were urged on by the driver's singing]. (Aṣ.)
baSobaSati AlUibilu qarabahaA The camels performed quickly their nightjourney to water. (Ḳ.) [See baSobaASN.]

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tabaSobaSa: see R. Q. 1.

[baS-N, and baS-u naArK, Live coals; because they shine, or glisten: n. un. with p {baS-apN}: so in the present day; but probably only post-classical: or, accord. to the TA, in art. bSw, the word baS-apN is used by the vulgar, for baSowapN.]
baS-aASN [Shining, or glistening: or rather, shining, or glistening, much].
[Hence,] AlbaS-aASapu The eye: (Ṣ A, Ḳ:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (TA:) said to be so called (TA) because it shines, or glistens. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And hence baS-aASN is applied in the present day to An officer employed as an inspector by a police-magistrate.]

buS-aAnN a name of [The month afterwards called] rabiyEN AlMxiru: the former was its name in the Time of Ignorance: thus it is written accord. to the Jm: [or it was called, or was also called, waboSaAnu, and wuboSaAni: (see art. wbS:) or wabuSaAnN, and wabiSaAnN: (see art. bSn:)] the author of the Ḳ mentions it in art.bSn; [where it is said to be also written buSaAnN, i. e., without teshdeed;] but this is its proper place, for it is from AlbaSiySu [inf. n. of baS-a]. (TA.)

qarabN baSobaASN, (T, Ḳ,) or ximosN baSobaASN, (Ṣ,) A laborious, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) fatiguing, (T,) nightjourney to water, (T, Ḳ,) or journey in which the second and third and fourth days are without water; in which is no flagging: (Ṣ:) [as also SaboSaAbN.]
yawomN baSobaASN A vehemently-hot day. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baSura, [aor. _u {yaboSuru},] (Sb, M, Ḳ,) and baSira, [aor. _a {yaboSaru},] (Lḥ, Ḳ,) inf. n. baSarN and baSaArapN and biSaArapN, (M, Ḳ,) [He saw; i. e.] he became seeing; syn.SaAra muboSirFA; (Sb, M, Ḳ;) with bi prefixed to the noun following. (Ḳ.) But see 4, in four places. baSura is seldom used to signify the sense of sight unless to this meaning is conjoined that of mental perception. (B.)

[Hence,] baSura, [and baSira.], inf. n. baSaArapN [and baSarN], He was, or became, endowed with mental perception; or belief, or firm belief; or knowledge, understanding, intelligence, or skill. (Ṣ,* M, TA.) And baSurabihi, (Ṣ Mṣb, B,) and baSirabihi, and sometimes baSurahu and baSirahu, but more chastely with bi, inf. n. [baSaArapN and] baSarN; (Mṣb;) and * AbSrhu; (B;) He perceived it mentally; (B;) he knew it [or understood it]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) baSurotu bimaA lamo yaboSuruwA bihi, in the Ḳur [xx. 96], means I knew that which they knew not. (Ṣ.)

baSara AlOadiymayoni, aor. _u {yaboSuru}, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. baSorN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He put the two hides together, and sewed them, like as the two edges of a garment, or piece of cloth, are sewed, one being put upon the other; which [mode of sewing] is contrary to, or different from, that in which a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed before it is sewed the second time: (Ṣ:) or he put together the two edges of the two hides, when they were being sewed, (M, Ḳ,) like as a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed. (M.)
2. bS-r He (a whelp) opened his eyes. (M, Ḳ.)

And the former, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made him to know. (Ṣ, Ḳ) You say, baS-arotuhu bihi, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) I made him to know it; acquainted him with it. (A, Mṣb.) And bS-rhu AlOamora, inf. n. as above and taboSirapN, He made him to understand the affair, or case. (M.)
Also He rendered it apparent, or plainly apparent, conspicuous, manifest, or evident. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
buS-irato bidimaAmK, said of the feathers of an arrow, They were besmeared biAlbaSiyrapi, i. e. with blood: (Ṣ:) or were strengthened and fastened with glue. (M.)
Also bS-r, inf. n. taboSiyrN; (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AbSr↓; (Ḳ;) He went, (Ṣ,) or came, (M, Ḳ,) to the city of El-Basrah (AlbaSorap). (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. bASrhu He looked with at a thing, trying which of them two would see it before the other. (M.) And baASaraA They two looked, trying which of them would see first. (Ḳ.)
He elevated himself, or rose up, or stood up, so as to be higher than the surrounding objects, (OaXorafa,) looking at him, or towards him, from afar. (Ṣ.)
See also 4.

hom.sense: 4. AbSrhu, (Lḥ Ṣ M, A, &c.,) inf. n. UiboSaArN, (Mṣb,) He saw him, or it, (Lḥ, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) biruWoyapi AlEayoni by the sight of the eye; (Mṣb;) as also baSura↓ bihi: (A:) or he looked (M, Ḳ) at, or towards, him, or it, (M,) trying whether he could see him, or it; (M, Ḳ;) as also baSura↓ bihi, inf. n.baSarN and baSaArapN and biSaArapN; (M;) and baSira↓ bh; (Lḥ, M;) and tb-Srhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) and bASrhu↓: (M:) or, accord. to Sb, baSura↓ [is used when no object of sight is mentioned, and] signifies he [saw, or] became seeing: and AbSrhu is said when one mentions that upon which his eye has fallen. (M.) You say also, OaboSira UilaI-a Look thou at me: or turn thy face towards me. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)
See also 1.
And see 2.

OaboSiro bihi waOasomiEo, in the Ḳur [xviii. 25], means maA OaboSarahu wamaA OasomaEahu (Jel) ‡ How clear is his sight! and how clear his hearing! the pronoun relating to God; (Bḍ, Jel;) and thus used, the phrase is tropical; i. e., nothing escapes his sight and hearing. (Jel.) And OasomiEo bihimo waOaboSiro, in the same [xix. 39], means maA OasomaEahumo wamaA OaboSarahumo (Ṣ in art. smE, and Jel) How clearly shall they hear! and how clearly shall they see! (Ṣ, Bḍ, Jel:) or the meaning is, do thou make them to hear, and make them to see, the threats of that day which is afterwards mentioned, and what shall befall them therein. (Bḍ.)
OaboSara also signifies He relinquished infidelity, and adopted the true belief. (IAạr.)
See also 10.
He hung upon the door of his dwelling a baSiyrap, i. e. an oblong piece of cotton or other cloth. (TA.)
See also 2, last sentence.

entry.sense: 5. tbS-rhu He looked at it; namely, a thing: or looked long at it: or glanced lightly at it: like ramaqahu: (TA:) or he sought, or endeavoured, to see it: (Mgh:) or i. q. OaboSarahu, in a sense explained above; see 4. (M.) You say also, tabaS-aro liI fulaAnFA [Consider thou, or examine thou, for me, such a one, that thou mayest obtain a clear knowledge of him]. (TA.) And tbS-r fiI XaIoCK He considered a thing, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of it; he looked into it, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, until he knew it: he sought, or sought leisurely, or repeatedly, after the knowledge of it, until he knew it. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) And tbS-r fiI raOoyihi signifies the same as AstbSr↓ fiyhi, i. e. He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or discover, what would happen to him, of good and evil. (M.)
6. tbASrwA They saw one another. (M, Ḳ.)
[tbASr also signifies He feigned himself seeing, either ocularly or mentally; contr. of taEaAmaI.]

hom.sense: 10. AstbSr [He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or to perceive mentally]. You say, AstbSr fiI raOoyihi: see 5, last sentence.

He had, or was endowed with, [mental perception, or] knowledge, (Mṣb,) [or understanding, intelligence, or skill: as in the phrase,] AstbSr fiI XaIoCK [He had a mental perception, or knowledge,, &c., of, or in relation to, a thing]. (Ṣ.) [See musotaboSirN.]
It (a road, TA) was, or became, plain, clear, manifest, or conspicuous; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AbSr↓. (A.)

entry.sense: baSorN: see baSorapN, in four places: and see buSorapN.

hom.sense:
buSorN The thickness of anything; (M;) as of the heaven, (TA,) or of each heaven [of the seven heavens], (Ṣ, A, TA,) and of the earth, [or of each of the seven earths,] and of the skin of a man, (TA,) and of a garment, or piece of cloth. (A.)
You say vawobN jay-idu AlbuSori A thick garment or piece of cloth. (M.) SuborN, formed by transposition, signifies the same. (Ṣ in art. Sbr.)
A side: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the edge of anything: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) formed by transposition from SuborN. (M.)
Cotton: (Ḳ:) whence baSiyrapN signifying “an oblong piece of cotton cloth.” (TA.)
See also baSorapN.

entry.sense: biSorN: see baSorapN, in five places.

baSarN The sense of sight, (Lth, Ṣ,) or of the eye: (M, Ḳ:) or the light whereby the organ [of sight] (AljaAriHap) perceives the things seen (AlmuboSaraAt): (Mṣb:) pl. OaboSaArN. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] SalaApu AlbaSari The prayer of sunset: or, as some say, of daybreak: because performed when the darkness becomes mixed with the light: (TA:) or because performed when the stars are seen: also called SalaApu AlX-aAhidi: (TA in art. Xhd:) or because performed at a time when the eyes see corporeal forms, after the intervention of darkness, or before it. (JM.) And laqiyahu baSarFA He met him when eyes saw one another: or at the beginning of darkness, when there remained enough light for objects to be distinguished thereby: [accord. to some,] the noun is used [in the sense which it here bears] only as an adv. n. [of time]. (M.) And raOayotuhu bayona samoEi AlOaroDi wabaSarihaA ‡ I saw him in a vacant tract of land, or of the earth, where nothing but it heard or saw me. (A.) [See also samoEN, in two places.]
See also baSiyrapN, first sentence, in four places.

Also The eye; [and so baASirapN↓;] syn. EayonN; but of the masc. gender: (TA:) pl. as above: (Ḳur ii. 6, &c.:) but the sing. is also used in a pl. sense [like samoEN]. (TA in art. smE.) See two exs. voce baSiyrpN.

baSorapN Soft stones; (AA, M, Mṣb;) i. q. kac-aAnu; (AA, M;) as also biSorN↓ (M, Mṣb) and baSorN↓; or, accord. to Zj, this last is not allowable: (Mṣb:) or soft stones in which is whiteness: (Ḳ:) or in which is some whiteness: (TA:) or soft stones inclining to white; as also biSorN↓, with kesr if without p: (Ṣ:) [i. e. whitish soft stones:] or soft white stone; as also biSorN↓ (M) and baSorN↓: (TA:) or glistening stones; as also biSorN↓: (Fr:) pl. biSaArN: (M:) and rugged ground: (Ḳ:) or stones of rugged ground; (TA;) as also biSorN↓ and baSorN↓ and buSorN↓: (Ḳz, TA:) or these three words, without p, signify thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (Ḳ:) or the same three, hard, or strong, and thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (Lḥ, M:) and baSorapN signifies, also, land that is as though it were a mountain of gypsum: (ISh, L:) or land of which the stones are gypsum; (M, TA;) as also baSarapN↓ and baSirapN↓; (so in a copy of the M, but accord. to the TA buSorapN↓ and biSorapN↓;) but the last is app. an epithet: (M: [see baSirapN, below; and buSorapN:]) also tough clay in which is gypsum; (TA;) and baSirapN↓ signifies tough clay: (M, TA:) or baSorapN, (M,) or baSorN↓, (TA,) tough and good clay, containing pebbles. (Lḥ, M, TA.)
buSorapN [in the TA, as on the authority of ISd, baSorapN↓,] Good red land. (M, Ḳ.) See also baSorapN.
biSorapN: see baSorapN.
baSarapN: see baSorapN.
OaroDN baSirapN Land in which are stones that cut the hoofs of beasts. (TA.) See also baSorapN, in two places.

hom.sense: baSiyrN Seeing; i. q. muboSirN↓; (M, Ḳ;) contr. of DariyrN: (Ṣ:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN, (M,) or of the measure faAEilN [i. e. baASirN↓]: (TA:) pl. buSaraMCu. (M, Ḳ.) One says, Uin-ahu labaSiyrN biAlEayonayoni Verily he is one who sees with the two eyes. (Lḥ, M.) [Hence,] AlbaSiyru, as a name of God, The All-seeing; He who sees all things, both what are apparent thereof and what are occult, without any organ [of vision]. (TA.) And The dog; (M;) as also Oabuw baSiyrK: (Mṣb:) because it is one of the most sharp-sighted of animals. (M.)

Endowed with mental perception; (B;) knowing; skilful; possessing understanding, intelligence, or skill: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (A.) One says, OanaA baSiyrN bihi I am knowing in it, or respecting it. (Mṣb.) And Uin-ahu labaSiyrN biAlOaXoyaMCi Verily he is knowing, or skilful, in things. (Lḥ, M.) And rajulN baSiyrN biAlEilomi A man knowing, or skilful, in science. (M.) And huwa mina AlbuSaraMCi biAlit-jaArapi He is of those who are knowing, or skilful, in commerce. (A.)

It is also an epithet applied to A blind man; (AʼObeyd, M, B;) and so Oabuw baSiyrK: (TA in art. Ewr:) so applied as meaning endowed with mental perception; (B;) or as meaning a believer; (AʼObeyd, M;) or as an epithet of good omen: (M:) and Oabuw baSiyrK is used as meaning AlOaEoXaI [the weaksighted,, &c.,] for this last reason. (M.)
See also baSiyrapN.

baSiyrapN Mental perception; the perceptive faculty of the mind; as also baSarN↓: (B:) knowledge; (Mṣb;) as also baSarN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) and AisotiboSaArN: (Mṣb:) understanding; intelligence; skill: (M, Ḳ:) AlbaSiyrapu signifies AlAi sotiboSaAru fiI AlX-aIoCi [which implies all the meanings above: see 10]: (Ṣ:) and baSaru↓ Alqalobi [in like manner] signifies mental perception or vision or view; idea, or opinion, occurring to the mind: (M, Ḳ:) the pl. of baSiyrapN is baSaAYru; (M, B;) and the pl. of baSarN↓, as syn. therewith, OaboSaArN. (B.) [Sometimes it is opposed to baSarN, as in the first and second of the following exs.] EamaI AlOaboSaAri↓ Oahuwnu mino EimaI AlbaSaAYiri [Blindness of the eyes is a lighter thing than blindness of the perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.) When Mo'áwiyeh said to Ibn-ʼAbbás, yaA baniI haAXimK tuSaAbuwna fiI OaboSaArikumo↓ [O sons of Háshim, ye are afflicted in your eyes], the latter replied, waOanotumo yaA baniI Oumay-apa tuSaAbuwna fiI baSaAYirikumo [And ye, O sons of Umeiyeh, are afflicted in your perceptive faculties of the mind]. (M.) And the Arabs say, OaEomaI Qll-ehu baSaAYirapu May God blind his faculties of understanding! And one says, lahu firaAsapN caAtu baSiyrapK, and baSaAYira, ‡ He possesses true intuitive perception. (A.) And raOayotu Ealayoka caAta AlbaSaAYiri ‡ [I saw impressed upon thee the signs of perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.)

Also Belief, or firm belief, of the heart, or mind. (M, Ḳ.) And EalaI baSiyrapK According to, or agreeably with, knowledge and assurance: (TA:) and purposely; intentionally. (M, TA.) And EalaI gayori baSiyrapK Without certainty. (M, TA.)
Constancy, or firmness, in religion. (TA.)

[And hence,] Blood, (M,) or somewhat thereof, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) by which one is directed to an animal that has been shot, or to the knowledge thereof: (Aṣ, AA, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or blood upon the ground; (AZ, Ṣ;) what sticks upon the ground, not upon the body: (M:) what adheres to the body is termed jadiy-apN: (AZ, Ṣ:) or a portion of blood of the size of a dirhem: (TA:) or what is of a round form, like a shield: or what is of an oblong form: or what is of the size of the firosin [or foot] of the camel: in all these explanations, blood being meant: or blood not flowing: or what flows thereof at one single time: (M:) or a portion of blood that glistens: (B:) and (as some say, M) the blood of a virgin: (M, Ḳ:) and blood-revenge: and a fine for homicide: (TA:) pl. baSaAYiru, as above: (Ṣ, M:) and baSiyrN↓, which occurs in a verse cited by AḤn, may also be a pl. of baSiyrapN, applied to blood, [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which bSyrp is the n. un.,] like as XaEiyrN is of XaEiyrapN; or it may be for bSyrp, the p being elided by poetic license; or it may be a dial. var. of bSyrp, like as one says bayaADN and bayaADapN. (M.) El-As'ar El-Joafee says,
raAHwA baSaAYiruhumo EalaI OakotaAfihimo
wabaSiyratiI yaEoduw bihaA EatadN waOaI
[They went with their blood upon their shoulderblades; but my blood, a ready and swift and strong horse runs with it]; meaning, they neglected the blood of their father, and left it behind them; i. e., they did not take revenge for it; but I have sought my blood-revenge: (Ṣ, M:*) but see another explanation in what follows. (Ṣ. [See also Ḥam p. 59.])

‡ A witness: (Lḥ, Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Ḳ:) an observer and a witness. (A.) bali AlUinosaAnu EalaI nafosihi baSiyrapN, in the Ḳur [lxxv. 14], means ‡ Nay, the man shall be witness against himself: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or it means that his arms, or hands, and his legs, or feet, and his tongue, shall be witnesses against him on the day of resurrection: (M:) Akh says that it is like the saying to a man, Oanota Huj-apN EalaI nafosika: (Ṣ:) the p is added because the members are meant thereby; (B;) or to give intensiveness to the signification, (Mgh, B,) as in Eal-aAmapN and raAwiyapN; (B;) or because the meaning is EayonN baSiyrapN. (Mgh.) You say also, AijoEaloniI baSiyrapF Ealayohimo ‡ Make thou me an observer of them and a witness against them. (Lḥ,* M,* A.)

An example by which one is admonished: (Ḳ:) pl. baSaAYiru; which is said to be used agreeably with this interpretation in the Ḳur xxviii. 43. (TA.)
You say, OamaA laka baSiyrapN fiyhi ‡ Hast thou not an example whereby thou shouldst be admonished in him? (TA.)

A shield: (AO, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a glistening shield: or an oblong shield: (TA:) and a coat of mail: (AO, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and any defensive armour: (M, TA:) and baSaAYiru Als-ilaAHi any arms that are worn: and biSaArN, as well as baSaAYiru, is a pl. thereof. (TA.) Accord. to AO, the verse of El-Joafee cited above commences thus:
HamaluwA baSaAYirahumo EalaI OakotaAfihimo and the meaning is, [They bore] their shields [upon their shoulder-blades]; or their coats of mail. (Ṣ.)

An oblong piece of cloth (Ḳ, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.) [See buSorN.] Such is hung upon the door of a dwelling. (TA.) And you say, raOayotu Ealayohi baSiyrapF, i. e. Xuq-apF mulaf-aqapF [app. meaning I saw upon him a garment composed of two oblong pieces of cloth joined and sewed together]. (TA.)

What is between the two oblong pieces of cloth [i. e. between any two of such pieces] of a bayot [or tent]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and what is between the two pieces of a mazaAdap and the like; what is sewed, thereof, in the manner termed baSorN [inf. n. of baSara: see 1, last sentence]: (B:) pl. baSaAYiru: (Ṣ:) and baASirN↓ signifies [in like manner] what is joined and sewed together (mulaf-aq) between two oblong pieces of cloth or two pieces of rag. (TA.)
baASirN: see baSiyrN.

lamoHN baASirN ‡ An intent, or a hard, glance: (M, Ḳ:) or a very intent or hard glance. (Ṣ.) You say, Oarayotuhu lamoHFA baASirFA ‡ I showed him a very intent or hard glance: (Ṣ, M:*) bASrA being here used for the augmented epithet [muboSirFA]; (M;) or it is a possessive epithet, (Yaạḳoob, M,) like laAbinN and taAmirN, meaning cuw baSarK, from OaboSarotu, like mawotN maAYitN from Oamat-u; and it means I showed him a severe thing. (Ṣ.) And laqiIa minohu lamoHFA baASirFA ‡ He experienced from him a manifest, or an evident, thing. (M. [See also art. lmH.]) And raOaI fulaAnN lamoHFA baASirFA ‡ Such a one beheld a terrible thing. (Lth, TA.) And OaraAniI Alz-amaAnu lamoHFA baASirFA ‡ Fortune showed me a terrifying thing. (A.)

It is said in a prov., xayoru AlgadaMCi bawaAkiruhu waxayoru AlEaXaMCi bawaASiruhu, [the word bawaASiru being pl. of baASirapN↓,] meaning [The best kinds of morning-meal are those thereof that are early; and the best kinds of evening-meal are those thereof] in which the food is seen, before the invasion of night. (Meyd. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 442.)
baASirapN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]: see baSarN.
See also baSayrapN, last sentence.

entry.sense: baASirapN: see baSarN: and see baASirN.
baASuwrN: see baAsuwrN.
binoSirN: see art. bnSr.
OaboSaru [More, and most, sharp-sighted or clearsighted: see an ex. voce Hay-apN].
maboSarN: see baSayrpN.
muboSarN and its fem. muboSarapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

hom.sense: muboSirN: see baSiyrN.
[Hence,] ‡ A watcher, or guard, set in a garden. (A.)
And AlmuboSiru † The lion, which sees his prey from afar, and pursues it. (Ḳ.)

[Making, or causing, to see, or to have sight: and hence, giving light; shining; illumining: and conspicuous; manifest; evident; apparent: also making, or causing, to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill.] waAln-ahaAra muboSirFA, in the Ḳur [x. 68, &c. (in the CK wAln-hAru muboSarFA↓)], means, And the day [causing to see; or] in which one sees; (Ḳ;) giving light; shining; or illumining. (TA.) And falam-aA jaMCatohumo MyaAtunaA muboSirapF, also in the Ḳur [xxvii. 13], † And when our signs came to them, making them to have sight, or to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill; expl. by tajoEaluhumo buSaraMCa: (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or giving light; shining; or illumining: (Ṣ:) or being conspicuous, manifest, or evident: or we may read muboSarapF↓, meaning having become manifest, or evident. (Zj, M.) And MtayonaA vamuwda Aln-aAqapa muboSirapF, also in the Ḳur [xvii. 61], † And we gave to Thamood the she-camel, by means of which they had sight, or mental perception, or knowledge, or skill: (Akh:) or a sign giving light, shining, or illumining; (Fr, T;) and this is the right explanation: (T:) or a manifest, or an evident, sign: (Zj, L, Ḳ:) and some read muboSarapF↓, meaning having become manifest, so as to be seen. (Zj, L.) And jaEalonaA Myapa Aln-ahaAri muboSirapF, also in the Ḳur [xvii. 13], ‡ We have made the sign of the day manifest, or apparent. (Ḳ, TA.)
One who hangs upon his door a baSiyrap, i. e. an oblong piece of cloth (Ḳ, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.)

entry.sense: maboSarapN: see baSiyrapN.
musotaboSirN One who seeks, or endeavours, to see a thing plainly or clearly [either with the eyes or with the mind]. (TA, from a trad.)

wakaAnuwA musotaboSiriyna, in the Ḳur [xxix. 37], means, And they were endowed with perceptive faculties of the mind, or of knowledge, or of skill: (Jel:) or they clearly perceived, when they did what they did, that the result thereof would be their punishment. (M.) And you say, huwa musotaboSirN fiI diynihi waEamalihi He is endowed with mental perception, or knowledge, or understanding, intelligence, or skill, in his religion and his actions. (TA.)
1. baSoTN, [inf. n. of baSaTa,] i. q. basoTN, in all its meanings: (Ḳ:) the s, with T, is changed into S because of the nearness of the places of utterance. (L.)

1. baSaEa, aor. _a {yaboSaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baSoEN, (Ṣ,) He collected: (Ḳ:) [J says,] I have heard from certain of the grammarians that AlbaSoEu is syn. with AljamoEu, but I know not what is the truth of the matter. (Ṣ.) Hence what here follows. (TA.)

OaboSaEu is a word used as a corroborative, and is pronounced by some with the pointed D, but this is not of high authority: you say, Oaxacotu Haq-iI OajomaEa OaboSaEa [I took my right, or due, altogether]: and [the pl. is OaboSaEuwna:] you say, jaMCa Alqawomu OajomaEuwna OaboSaEuwna [The people, or company of men, came all together]: and the fem. is baSoEaMCu: you say, jamoEaMCa baSoEaMCa: and [the pl. of baSoEaMCu is buSaEu: you say,] raOayotu Aln-isowapa jumaEa buSaEa [I saw the women all together]: it is a corroborative occurring in a particular order, never before AjmE. (Ṣ.) [See OabotaEu.]

hom.sense: 1. baSaqa, (Lth, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaboSuqu},] inf. n. baSoqN, (Ṣ,) i. q. bazaqa (Lth, Ṣ,* Ḳ) or basaqa (JK) [He spat]: it is the most chaste of these three verbs. (TA in art. bsq.) baSaqa fiI wajohihi [lit. He spat in his face,] means † he held him in contempt, or despised him. (TA.)
He milked a ewe when she was with young. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AbSqt She (a ewe) excerned the milk [or biestings into her udder before bringing forth]; (JK, Ḳ;) like Absqt [q. v.]. (TA.)
AbSq is also said of the qaSad, or small juicy branches, in the [species of mimosa termed] EurofuT [app. as meaning They excerned a matter like spittle]. (TA.)

hom.sense: buSaAqN Spittle, or saliva, that has gone forth from the mouth: as long as it is in the mouth, it is termed riyqN: (Ḳ:) [or saliva that flows: see buzaAqN:] i. q. buzaAqN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and busaAqN: (Ḳ:) but it is more chaste than either of these. (TA.) [buSaAqapN is app. its n. un. And hence,]
buSaAqapu Alqamari White glistening stone: (Ṣ:) or stone of a clear white colour. (JK, Ḳ.) [Also written with s.]
A species of palm-tree. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The best of camels: both sing. and pl. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: baSuwqN A ewe having the least quantity of milk. (Ḳ, TA.)

2. taboSiylN The act of stripping, or divesting; [like as when one strips an onion (baSalap) of its coats;] (Ḳ;) as also tabaS-ulN↓. (Fr, Ḳ.) You say, baS-alotu Alr-ajula Eino viyaAbihi [and tabaS-alotuhu↓] I stripped the man of his clothes. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tbS-l It (a thing) was, or became, several fold, or many fold, like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (Z, TA.) See also mutab-S-ilN.
It is also trans.: see 2, in two places.
[Hence,] tabaS-aluwhu † They begged of him so much that all that he had became exhausted. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: baSalN [The onion; allium cepa: or onions, collectively:] what it signifies is well known: n. un. with p {baSalapN}. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the prov., OakosaI mina AlbaSali [Having more coats, or coverings, than the onion]. (TA.)

[Also Any kind of bulb, or bulbous plant.] baSalu Alz-aEofaraAni [The bulb of the saffron], which is buried in the ground, is like the baSal [or onion] commonly known. (Mgh.) baSal AlfaOori is the same as AlUisoqiylu and AlUisoqaAlu and AlEunoSalu, (Ḳ in art. sql,) also written AlEunoSulu, (Ḳ in art. ESl,) or baSalu AlEnSl, (KL voce zyzN, [and so as written by Golius,]) [Scilla, or squill; particularly scilla maritima, or officinal squill; called by all these names, except, perhaps, AlsqAl, in the present day;] also called ziyzN, and AlbaSalu Albar-iI-u [the wild onion; but from what follows, it seems that there is a confusion here]. (KL ubi suprà.) baSalu Alc-iYobi, and bSl Alzyr, (Golius on the authority of Zeyn El-Attár,) or bSl Alrnd, (so in the TA in art. blbs,) i. q. blbws Bulbus esculentus, (Golius, from Zeyn El-Attár,) or Albalobuws, with fet-ḥ, [thus generally written, though it would seem to be correctly bulobuws,] the leaves of which resemble those of the sacaAb [or rue]: (TA in art. blbs:) the balobuws is the wild onion (in Pers. PiyaAzo SaHoraAYiI). (KL voce blbws. [This last assertion suggests that Alzyr and Alrnd may be mistranscriptions for Alz-iyz; the zyz mentioned before.]) [baSalu AlqIoCa Bulbus vomitorius; mentioned by Golius; and by Dioscorides, (l. ii. c. 201,) as being emetic and diuretic.]
Also, (Ḳ,) or baSalapN, (M,) ‡ A helmet (M, Ḳ) of iron, (Ḳ,) pointed in the middle; so called as being likened to what is first mentioned above. (M.) Lebeed likens helmets to baSal. (Ṣ.)
mutabaS-ilN (ISh, Ḳ) and cuw tabaS-ulK↓ (ISh, TA) A covering of any kind (qiXorN) consisting of many coats; thick; (ISh, Ḳ;) like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (ISh, TA.)

buSomN The space that is between the extremity of the little finger and that of the third finger [when they are extended apart]: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:) mentioned on the authority of AO, (Ṣ,) or on that of Aboo-Málik alone. (M.) The Eatab is the space between the third finger and the middle finger; the ratab, that between the middle finger and the first finger; [but see these two words;] the fitor, that between the first finger and the thumb; the Xibor, that between the thumb and the little finger; and the fawot, that between every two fingers, in length. (Ṣ.)

cuw buSomK Thick, or coarse; applied to a man, (M, Ḳ,) or a garment, or piece of cloth: (Ḳ:) or you say vawobN lahu buSomN, meaning a garment, or piece of cloth, that is dense, or compact; close in texture. (M.)

buSaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) so accord. to Ḳṭr, (M,) and buS-aAnN, (Ḳ,) thus in some of the copies of the Jm of IDrd, (TA,) a name of The month rabiyEN AlOxiru, (M, Ḳ,) in the Time of Ignorance: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboSinapN (M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] biSonaAnN; (M, TA;) the latter erroneously written in the copies of the Ḳ buSaAnaAtN: (TA:) so says Ḳṭr; but other lexicologists hold that it is wabuSaAnN, like sabuEaAn, and wabiSaAnN, like XaqiraAn; and this is the correct opinion: Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says that it was so named because of the wabiyS, i. e. gleaming, of the weapons therein: (M:) but it is said in art. wbS of the Ḳ to be waboSaAn and wuboSaAn: and Ṣgh holds buS-aAnN to be correct because baS-a and wabaSa signify the same. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baDaDota, and baDiDota, (Ṣ, TA,) and baDuDota also, (accord. to one copy of the Ṣ,) [third pers., accord. to rule, baD-a, (accord. to Golius and Freytag baDaDa or baDiDa, but these are irregular forms, and not admissible without authority,) aor., accord. to rule, of the first yabiD-u, and of the second yabaD-u, and of the third yabuD-u,] inf. n. baDaADapN and buDawDapN, (Ṣ, TA,) Thou (O man) wast, or becamest, such as is termed baD-N; i. e. thin-shinned and plump;, &c.: (Ṣ:) or very white or fair, with fatness: or delicate and clear in complexion, and such that the least thing made a mark, or an impression, upon thee. (TA.)

baD-a AlmaMCu, aor. yabiD-u, inf. n. baDiyDN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and buDuwDN and baD-N, (Ḳ,) The water flowed by little and little: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or exuded upon a rock or the ground. (TA.) And baD-ati Alr-akiy-apu, and baD-ato bimaAYihaA, The well had, or yielded, little water; or its water became little. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Tabook, waAlEayonu tabiD-u biXaIoCK mina AlmaMCi [The source, or spring, yielding scantily somewhat of water]. (TA.) And you say, baD-ati AlEayonu, aor. as above, inf. n. baD-N and baDiyDN, The eye shed tears. (TA.) And, of a man when you characterise him as patient under affliction, maA tabiD-u Eayonuhu [His eye does not shed tears]. (TA.) And baD-ati AlHalamapu The nipple streamed with milk. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maA tabiD-u bibalaAlK Having no milk dropping from it, or her. (TA.) And in another trad., saqaTa mina Alfarasi faUicaA huwa jaAlisN waEuroDu wajohihi yabiD-u maMCF OaSofara [He fell from the horse, and lo, he was sitting, with the side of his face exuding yellow water]. (TA.) One should not say, baD-a Als-iqaMCu, nor Alqirobapu: but some say so, urging the authority of Ru-beh. (Ṣ.) And you say of a stone, and the like, baD-a, aor. as above, meaning Water flowed from it like sweat; water oozed from it. (TA.)

Hence the saying, maA yabiD-u Hajaruhu † No good is obtained from him; (TA;) i. q. maA tanodaI SafaAtuhu: (Ṣ:) a prov. applied to the niggardly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence also,] baD-a lahu, [aor., accord. to the TA, yabuD-u, but this is evidently a mistake,] † He gave him a little; as also AbD-↓ lh, (Sh, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiboDaADN: (TA:) and baD-a lahu biXaIoCK † He did him a small benefit; as also naD-a. (Aṣ.)

entry.sense: 4. AbD- lahu: see 1, last sentence.
5. tabaD-aDotuhu I took everything belonging to him. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
tabaD-aDotu Haq-iI minohu I took the whole of my right, or due, from him by little and little: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [as also tanaD-aDotuhu minohu.]
10. xuco maA QsotabaD-a Take thou what is easily attainable; what offers itself without difficulty. (AA, TA in art. ndb.)

baD-N A man thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: (Ṣ:) or a man having a thin, or fine, and plump, skin, upon which the least thing makes a mark, or an impression: (Mgh:) or a man (Aṣ) soft, or tender, in body; not particularly implying whiteness: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or soft, or tender, in body, thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {baD-apN}; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) signifying a girl, (Ṣ,) or a woman, thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and soft, or tender, or delicate, (TA,) if tawny or white: (Ṣ, TA:) or soft, or tender, in body; not particularly implying whiteness: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or fleshy and white: (AA:) or thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, in whom the blood appears [through the skin]: (Lḥ:) or soft, or tender, or delicate, compact in flesh, and very white or fair in complexion: (Lth:) and baDiyDapN↓ and baAD-apN↓ and baDobaADapN↓, applied to a girl, signify the same as baD-apN; (Ḳ, TA;) compact in flesh, plump, or soft and thin-skinned and plump, with a very white or fair complexion: (TA:) and baDaADN↓ also is syn. with baD-apN, applied to a woman. (TA.)
baDaDN Little water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
baDaADN: see baD-N, at the end of the paragraph.

biYorN baDuwDN, (Ḳ,) or rakiy-apN baDuwDN, (Ṣ,) A well having little water: (Ṣ:) or of which the water comes forth by little and little: (Ḳ:) pl., in some copies of the Ḳ, biDaADN: in others, baDaAYiDu. (TA.)
maA fiI Als-iqaMCa buDaADapN, (Ḳ,) or buDaADapN mino maACK, (TA,) and baDiyDapN↓, (Ḳ,) There is not in the skin [even so much as] a small quantity of water: (Ḳ, TA:) from Aboo-Saʼeed. (TA.)

hom.sense: baDiyDapN: see baD-N, near the end of the paragraph.
Rain little in quantity. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also buDaADapN.
A thing which the hand possesses. (Ḳ.) You say, Oaxorajotu lahu baDiyDatiI I produced to him what my hand possessed. (TA.)

entry.sense: baDobaADapN: see baD-N, near the end of the paragraph.
baAD-apN: see baD-N, near the end of the paragraph.
maA fiI AlbiYori baADuwDN There is not any moisture in the well. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
huwa OabaD-u Aln-aAsi He is the most delicate, or fine, in complexion, of men, and the most beautiful of them in external skin. (TA.)

1. baDaEahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaboDaEu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. baDoEN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cut it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, flesh, or flesh-meat: (Ṣ, TA:) and it (a sword) cut a piece off from it; namely, a thing: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and he cut it in pieces; namely, flesh, or flesh-meat: (Ḳ, TA:) and bD-Ehu↓, inf. n. taboDiyEN, has the first of these significations: (Ḳ: [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned:]) or this latter signifies he cut it much, or in several pieces, or in many pieces. (Mṣb, TA.*)
He slit it; or cut it lengthwise; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, flesh, or flesh-meat, (Mṣb,) or a wound, (Ṣ, TA,) and a vein, and a hide. (Ṣ.)

[And hence,] baDaEahaA, (Sb, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _a {yaboDaEu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. baDoEN (Ḳ, TA) and buDoEN, like XukorN and XugolN and kuforN, for fuEolN is not rare as a measure of inf. ns., (Sb, TA,) or accord. to some it is an inf. n. of this verb, (Mṣb,) but accord. to others it is a simple subst., (TA,) ‡ Inivit eam; he lay with her, or compressed her; (Sb, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also bADEhA↓, (Mṣb,) inf. n. mubaADaEapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and biDaAEN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) because in the act which it signifies is a kind of slitting. (Mgh.) You say, malaka buDoEahaA, i. e. jimaAEahaA. (Mṣb.) And it is said in a prov., kamuEal-imapi Oum-ahaA AlbiDaAEa↓ ‡ [Like her who teaches her mother AlmujaAmaEap]. (Ṣ.)
baDoEN also signifies ‡ The taking in marriage: (Ḳ, TA:) and buDoEN, as an inf. n., † The making a contract of marriage. (Mṣb.)
2: see 1.
3: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: 4. AbDEhA, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiboDaAEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) ‡ He gave her in marriage. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) tusotaOomaru Aln-isaMCu fiI UiboDaAEihin-a ‡ Women shall be consulted respecting the giving them in marriage: (T, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or, accord. to one relation, OaboDaAEihin-a↓, (Mgh, Mṣb,) which [virtually] means the same; (Mṣb;) but this is a pl., namely, of buDoEN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

AbDE AlX-aIoCa He made the thing to be biDaAEap [i. e. an article of merchandise], (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) whatever it was; (TA;) as also AstbDEhu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or AisotaboDaEotu↓ AlX-aIoCa signifies I made [or took] the thing as bDAEp [an article of merchandise] for myself: and you say, OaboDaEotuhu gayoriI [I made it, or gave it as, an article of merchandise to another than me]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and AbDEhu AlbiDaAEapa he gave him the article of merchandise. (TA.) Hence the phrase, in a trad. relating to El-Medeeneh, accord. to one relation, tuboDiEu TiybahaA, meaning † It gives the good that it possesses to its inhabitants; as explained by Z; but accord. to the relation commonly known, it is tanoSaEu, with n and with the unpointed S; [meaning “it purifies;”; (L in art. nSE;)] and there are two other relations, which are tanoDaxu and tanoDaxu. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnbDE It was, or became, cut, or cut off. (Ḳ, TA.)
8. AbtDE minohu He took, or received, [merchandise] from him. (TA: [in which the word biDaAEapF requires to be supplied in the explanation, and is indicated by the context.])

hom.sense: 10. AisotiboDaAEN denotes a kind of matrimonial connection practised by people in the Time of Ignorance; i. e., A woman's desiring sexual intercourse with a man only to obtain offspring by him: a man of them used to say to his female slave or his wife, OarosiliI UilaI fulaAn faMsotaboDiEiI minohu [Send thou to such a one, and demand of him sexual intercourse to obtain offspring]; and he used to separate himself from her, and not touch her, until her pregnancy by that man became apparent: and this he did from a desire of obtaining generous offspring. (IAth, TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

entry.sense: baDoEN: see biDoEN, first sentence, and near the end: and see also baDoEapN.

buDoEN Initus; sexual intercourse: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a subst., (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) accord. to some; but accord. to others, an inf. n.; (Mṣb;) held by Sb to be the latter: (TA:) [see 1:] and marriage; or the taking in marriage; syn. nikaAHN; (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) [which has also the first of the meanings given above;] as in the phrase malaka fulaAnN buDoEa fulaAnapa [explained above (see 1)]: (ISk, Ṣ:) or, (Ḳ,) in this phrase, (Mgh,) ‡ the pudendum muliebre; the vulva; (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) and so in the saying, in a trad., Eutiqa buDoEuki faQxotaAriI ‡ Thy vulva hath become freed, therefore choose thou whether thou wilt remain with thy husband or separate thyself from him; (TA;) and in the saying, tusotaOomaru Aln-isaMCu fiI OaboDaAEihin-a, accord. to those who thus relate it, others saying UiboDaAEihin-a; (see 1;) OaboDaAEN being pl. of buDoEN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
Also ‡ The marriage-contract. (Ḳ.)

And ‡ A dowry; or gift given to, or for, a bride: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. buDuwEN. (TA.) So in the saying of ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib,
wafiI kaEobK waUixowatihaA kilaAbK
sawaAmiI AlT-arofi gaAliyapu AlbuDuwEi
[And among Kaab, and their brethren Kiláb, are females lofty in look, or] proud, and dear in respect of dowries. (TA.)
Also † Divorce: (Az, Ḳ:) thus having two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
And † The authority possessed over a woman by her guardian who affiances her. (TA.)

And † An equal; particularly as a suitor in a case of marriage: as in the saying, in a trad., hecaA AlbuDoEu laA yuqoraEu Oanofuhu † This equal's marriage shall not be refused, nor shall it be desired, or wished for; he shall not be rejected. (TA.)

biDoEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and baDoEN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) some of the Arabs pronouncing it with kesr, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [A number under ten; and an odd number, meaning] a number between two round, or decimal, numbers; (AZ, Ḳ;) from one to ten [exclusive of the latter]; and from eleven to twenty [exclusive of the latter]; so accord. to Mebremán; (Ḳ;) i. e. Moḥammad Ibn-ʼAlee Ibn-Ismá'eel the Lexicologist, Mebremán being his surname: (TA:) or from three to nine; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ [in the first and last the ns. being in the fem. gender; but in the second, masc.];) so accord. to Ḳatádeh; (Mgh;) from three to less than ten: (Fr [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or not less than three nor more than ten; (Sh [the first n. of number in the fem. gender, and the second masc.];) from three to ten: (Mgh [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to seven: (Mujáhid, Mgh:) or to five: (AO, Ḳ [the n. of number in the fem. gender]:) or from one to four: (AO, O, Ḳ [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to five; an explanation ascribed to AO: (TA:) or from four to nine; (ISd, Ḳ [the ns. of number fem.];) and this is the signification preferred by Th: (TA:) or it signifies five: (Mukátil [this n. of number masc.]:) or seven; (Mukátil, Ḳ [in the Ḳ this n. of number being fem.];) so accord. to some: (AO:) or ten: (Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák [this n. of number masc.]:) or an undefined number; gayoru maHoduwdK; so says Ṣgh; [and the like is said in the Mṣb;] in the Ḳ, erroneously, gayoru maEoduwdK; (TA;) because it means a portion, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) which is undefined: (Ṣgh, TA:) it also signifies, with ten, [in like manner; i. e. ten and a number under ten; or the like: as] from thirteen to nineteen. (Mṣb.) When used as signifying from three to nine, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or to ten, or to seven, (Mgh,) [or to signify some number under ten, without another n. of number,] it is masc. and fem. without variation: (Mgh, Mṣb:) you say biDoEu rijaAlK From three to nine [&c.] men: and biDoEu nisowapK from three to nine [&c.] women: (Mṣb:) and biDoEu siniyna from three to nine [&c.] years: (Ṣ:) and fiI biDoEi siniyna [in from three to nine,, &c., years]: (Ḳur xxx. 3:) and falabiva fiI Als-ijoni biDoEa siniyna [And he remained in the prison from three to nine,, &c., years]. (Ḳur xii. 42.) But when used to denote a number above ten, (Mgh, Mṣb,) with a masc. n. it is with p, (biDoEap↓,) and with a fem. n. it is without p: (ISk, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say biDoEapa EaXara rajulFA From thirteen to nineteen [&c.] men: and biDoEa EaXorapa QmoraOapF from thirteen to nineteen [&c.] women: (Ṣ, Mgh,* TA:) like as you say valaAvapa EaXara rajulFA and valaAva EaXorpa QmoraOapF. (Mgh.) When you have passed the word denoting ten, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e.] to denote a number above twenty, (Mṣb,) it is not used: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you do not say biDoEN waEiXoruwna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but nay-ifN waEiXoruwna; and so in the cases of the remaining numbers: (Ṣ:) or you do say biDoEN waEiXoruwna: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) accord. to AZ, (Mṣb,) you say biDoEapN waEiXoruwna rajulFA (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) meaning Twenty and odd men: (AZ, TA:) and biDoEN waEiXoruwna QmoraOapF (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) meaning twenty and odd women: (AZ, TA:) but not the reverse: (Ḳ:) ISd says, we have not heard this, but there is no objection to it: (TA:) and Fr says, biDoEN is not mentioned save with ten and twenty to ninety; (IB, Ḳ;) not with what exceeds this: (IB:) you do not say biDoEN wamiAYapN nor biDoEN waOalofN, (IB, Ḳ,) but miAYapN wanay-ifN [and OalofN wanay-ifN]: (IB:) it occurs in trads. with EiXoruwna and with valaAvuwna. (TA.)

biDoEN and baDoEN↓ also signify A part, or portion, of the night: (Ḳ:) a time thereof. (Lḥ.) You say, maDaI biDoEN mina All-ayoli [A part, or portion, of the night passed]. (TA.) J mentions it with S [in the place of D]; and explains it by jawoXN, q. v. (TA.)

baDoEapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, other words of like meaning being with kesr, as qiToEapN and filocapN and fidorapN, (Ṣ,) and sometimes with kesr, [biDoEapN↓,] (Ḳ,)
and buDoEapN↓ also is mentioned, (TA,) of which the first is the most chaste, though EshShiháb asserts the second to be more common, (TA,) A piece, or lump, or portion cut off; (TA;) particularly of flesh, or flesh-meat, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a compact, or collective, state: (TA:) pl. baDoEN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which baDoEapN is the n. un.,] and biDaEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as some say, (Ṣ,) but this is disallowed by ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh, (TA,) [or it may be a correct pl. of biDoEapN agreeably with analogy,] and biDaAEN, and baDaEaAtN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and [quasi-pl. n.] baDiyEN, which is extr., like rahiynN and kaliybN and maEiyzN [&c.]. (TA.) Hence the saying [of Moḥammad] in a trad., faATimapu baDoEapN min-aI yariybuniI maA raAbahaA wayuWociyniI maA McaAhaA ‡ Fátimeh is a part of me: [that displeases and disquiets me which has displeased and disquieted her, and that hurts me which has hurt her:] or, accord. to one relation, he said buDayoEapN [a little part].
