(TA.) One says also, Uin-a fulaAnFA laXadiydu AlbaDoEapi HasanuhaA meaning Verily such a one is corpulent and fat. (TA.)
See also baDaEapN.
buDoEapN: see baDoEapN.
biDoEapN: see baDoEapN: and, as a noun of number, see biDoEN, latter half of the paragraph.

baDaEapN The sound of cutting of swords: occurring in the saying, samiEotu lils-iyaATi xaDaEapF walils-uyuwfi baDaEapF I heard a sound of falling of the whips, and a sound of cutting of the swords: (TA:) but in the Ṣ and A in art. xDE, and by IB, xDEp and bDEp are written xaDoEapN and baDoEapN↓; and IB explains the former as signifying the sounds of swords; and the latter, the sounds of whips. (TA in art. xDE.) [See also baADiEN.]
biDaAEN [The giving and receiving merchandise;] a subst. from OaboDaEahu AlbiDaAEapa and AibotaDaEa minohu; [or rather an inf. n. of which the verb, baADaEa, is not used;] similar to qiraADN. (TA.)

baDiyEN Flesh. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) You say, daAb-apN kaviyrapu AlbaDiyEi (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) A beast abounding in what is distinct from the rest of the flesh of the thigh: n. un. with p {baDiyEapN}. (TA.) And rajulN xaAZiI AlbaDiyEi (Aṣ, Ṣ) A fat man. (TA.) And saAEidN xaAZI AlbaDiyEi [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] full of flesh. (IB.) [See also baDoEapN, of which it is a quasi-pl. n.]

biDaAEapN Merchandise; or an article of merchandise; (TA;) a portion of one's property which one sends for traffic; (Ṣ;) a portion of property prepared for traffic, (Mgh,* Mṣb,) or with which one traffics; from baDoEN signifying the act of “cutting,” or “cutting off;” and vulgarly pronounced buDaAEapN: (TA:) pl. baDaAYiEu. (Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: baADiEN A sword that cuts off a piece of a thing that it strikes: (Ṣ, TA:) or a sharp, or cutting, sword: (Ḳ:) or a sword that cuts everything: (TA:) pl. baDaEapN: (Ḳ:) Fr says that baDaEapN signifies swords; and xaDaEapN, whips: but some say the reverse. (TA.) [See also baDaEapN above.]
[See also the next paragraph.]

[A broker who acts as an intermediary between the sellers and buyers of camels;] the same with respect to camels as the dal-aAl with respect to houses: (O, L, Ḳ:) or one who carries the articles of merchandise of the tribe, and conveys those articles from place to place for sale: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) it is said in the A that baADiEu AlHaI-i signifies the person who carries the articles of merchandise of the tribe. (TA.)

baADiEapN A wound by which the head is broken, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which cuts the skin, and cleaves the flesh (Ṣ, Ḳ) in a slight degree, (Ḳ,) and brings blood, but does not make it to flow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or which wounds the skin, and cleaves the flesh: (Mgh:) or which cleaves the flesh, but does not reach to the bone, nor cause the blood to flow: (Mṣb:) that from which the blood flows is termed daAmiyapN [app. a mistake for daAmiEapN]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

A large flock (firoqN [in the CK, erroneously, firaq,]) of sheep or goats: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or a portion separated from the rest of the sheep or goats: (Lth, Ḳ:) pl. bawaADiEu: you say, firaqN bawaADiEu. (Lth.)

entry.sense: OaboDaEu as a corroborative after OajomaEu: see OaboSaEu, with the unpointed S. Az says that it is an evident mistranscription. (TA.)

miboDaEN A lancet; an instrument with which a vein is cut: (Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ, TA:) and [a currier's knife] with which leather is cut: (Ṣ, TA:) [pl. mabaADiEu: accord. to the Mirḳát el-Loghah, as cited by Golius, it signifies a farrier's fleam; differing from miXoraTN, which signifies a surgeon's lancet: but this distinction is probably post-classical; for accord. to the TA, these two words signify the same.]
maboDuwEapN [used as a subst.] A bow: a bow cut from a branch. (TA.)

musotaboDiEN. It is said in a prov., kamusotaboDiEi tamorK UilaI hajarK [Like the taker of dates as merchandise to Hejer]; because Hejer is [famous as] the place of production (maEodin) of dates. (Ṣ.) mstbDE is here made trans. by means of AlI because it has the meaning of HaAmil. (TA.)
1. baT-a, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboTuTu}, inf. n. baT-N, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He slit a wound, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or an ulcer, (Ṣ,) and a purse, (Ḳ,), &c. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
2. biT-T, inf. n. taboTiyTN, He trafficked in the birds called baT-, q. v. (Ḳ.)
4. AbT-, (IAạr, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiboTaATN, (IAạr,) He purchased [or became possessed of] a baT-ap [q. v.] for oil, or of oil. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. Darabahu fabaTobaTahu He struck him and clave his skin, or his head. (TA.) [See 1.]
See also baTobaTapN, below.

entry.sense: baT-N A kind of water-fowl; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) [the duck, or ducks; and the goose, or geese; but generally the former of these birds; agreeably with a statement in the Jm, that baT-N is applied by the Arabs to the small, and Uiwaz-N to the large;] i. q. Uiwaz-N, (Ḳ, TA,) both the small thereof and the large: (TA:) a Persian word (EajamiI-N), arabicized; [originally bato, or baTo, or baT-;] or, accord. to IJ, an imitation of its cries: n. un. baT-apN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is applied to the male and to the female, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like HamaAmapN and dajaAjapN: (Ṣ:) pl. biTaATN. (TA.)

sense.ref: n. un. of baT-N, q. v.

entry.sense: baT-aATN A maker of buTaT, pl. of baT-apN. (TA.)

baTobaTapN [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is baTobaTa↓,] The crying, or cry, of the baT-; (Ḳ;) after which it [the bird] is named, accord. to IJ, as mentioned above: (TA:) or its diving in water. (Ḳ.)
mibaT-apN The miboDaE [or scarifying instrument] (Ḳ, TA) with which a wound is slit. (TA.)

1. baTuWa, aor. _u {yaboTuOu}, inf. n. buToCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baTaMCapN, with fet-ḥ and medd, (Mṣb,) or biTaMCN, like kitaAbN; (Ḳ;) and AbTO↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; contr. of OasoraEa; (Ḳ;) in his going or course, and in his gait [&c.]: (TA:) or the latter is said of a man; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) meaning [as above; or] his coming was late, or backward; (Mṣb;) [and is app. elliptical, for AbTO maXoyahu he made his pace, or going, slow,, &c.; or the like; see AsrE:] and baTuWa [denotes what is as it were an innate quality; see, again, OasoraEa; or] is said of one's coming; [meaning it was, or became, slow,, &c.;] (Ṣ, Mṣb;) buToCN being the contr. of suroEapN. (Ṣ.) One should not say OaboTayota↓ for OaboTaOota. (Ṣ.) [See also 6.]
baTuCa caA xuruwjFA: see buToMna.

2. bT-Obihi [and bT-Ohu, inf. n. as below, It made him slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward;] it kept him, or held him, back; or put him back, or backward. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano baT-aOa bihi Eamaluhu lamo yusoriEo bihi nasabuhu Him whom his evil deeds keep, or hold, back, or put back, or backward, his nobility of lineage will not profit, [or advance, or put forward,] in the life to come, or in the world to come. (TA.) maA OaboTaOa↓ bika and maA baT-aOa signify the same [What made thee, or hath made thee, slow?, &c.]; (Ṣ, TA;) and so maA baT-aOaka. (TA.) And you say, baT-aOa Ealayohi biAlOamori, inf. n. taboTiIoCN;
and AbTO↓ bihi; He delayed to him [the doing of] the thing, or affair. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1 and 2; each in two places.
OaboTaWuwA Their beasts on which they rode were, or became, slow. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maA OaboTaOahu How slow, or tardy, &c., is [he, or] it! (Ṣ.)

6. tbATO [accord. to general analogy, He feigned, or affected, to be slow, tardy,, &c.: or] he was slow, or sluggish; or he made delay; in going, or pace: and he held back from work, or action. (KL.) You say of a man, tbATO fiI masiyrihi [He feigned, or affected, to be slow, &c., in his going, course, or pace]. (Ṣ.)
10. AstbTOhu (Ṣ, TA) He deemed him, or reckoned him, slow, tardy,, &c. (KL.) You say, kataba UilaI-a yasotaboTiYuniI [He wrote to me, deeming me, or reckoning me, slow,, &c.]. (TA.)
buToCN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
One says, in the dial. of Benoo-Yarbooa, (TA,) lamo OafoEalohu buToCFA yaAhecaA, and buToOaI↓, [I never did it, lit.] I did it not ever, O thou! i. e. Ald-ahora. (Ḳ, TA.)
buToOaI: see buToCN.

buToMna caA xuruwjFA, and baToMna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but the latter is extr., (TA,) i. q. baTuWa↓ caA xuruwjFA [Slow, or very slow, or how slow, is this in coming forth!]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the fet-ḥah in [the last syllable of] baTuWa is transferred to the n of buToMn, and the ḍammeh of the T [in the former] to the b [in the latter]; the meaning being one of wonder; i. e. maA OaboTaOahu. (Ṣ, TA.) [bTMn is an enunciative placed before its inchoative: and, being originally baTuWa, it may be a simple enunciative, or an enunciative having an intensive signification; as that verb signifies simply “it was slow,”, &c., and may be used as co-ordinate to ramuwa, meaning “excellent is he in his shooting!”, &c., and qaDuwa “excellent is he in his judging!”, &c.: or it may be equivalent to maA OaboTaOa, as it is said to be in the Ṣ. See also saroEaAna.]
baTiIoCN Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; applied to a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and to a horse or the like: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. baTaMCN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
Also an imitative sequent to HaTiIoCN. (Ṣ in art. HTO.)
OaboTaOu More, and most, slow,, &c. (Meyd, &c.)
AlmaboTaOu for AlmabodaOu is mentioned by AO. (TA on the letter T.)
1. baTaHahu, aor. _a {yaboTaHu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. baToHN, (Mgh, TA,) He spread it; spread it out, or forth; expanded it; extended it. (Mgh,* Mṣb, TA.)
Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or baTaHahu EalaI wajohihi, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He threw him down upon his face. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also 2.

2. bT-H Almasojida, (TA,) inf. n. taboTiyHN; (Ḳ;) and AbTHhu↓; (TA;) He strewed pebbles in the mosque, and made it plain, or level [in its ground, or floor]: (Ḳ, TA:) and baToHuhu, [inf. n. of baTaHahu↓,] occurring in a trad., also signifies the making it plain, or level. (TA.)
4: see 2.

hom.sense: 5. tbT-H: see 7.
Also It (a torrent) flowed widely: (ISd, A:) or spread widely in the baToHaMC. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, [and AnbTH↓,] It (a place, &c.) spread; spread out, or forth; became expanded or extended. (TA.)
And i. q. AinotaSaba [It became set up or upright, erected,, &c.: thus the verb bears two contr. significations]. (TA.)
Also He (a man) took the OaboTaH as a place of abode. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AnbTH It (water) went to the right and left in a place. (AA.)
See also 5.

He became thrown down upon his face: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he lay, or lay as though thrown down or extended, upon his face: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or he stretched himself; or lay, and stretched himself; upon his face, extended upon the ground; as also tbT-H↓. (TA.)
It (a valley) became wide; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AstbH↓. (TA.)
baTiHN: see OaboTaHu, in two places.
baToHapN The stature of a man [app. in a lying posture]: as in the phrase huwa baToHapN rajulK [It is of the stature of a man]. (Ḳ.)
bayonahumaA baToHapN baEiydapN Between them two is a far-extending distance or space or interval. (L.)
See also OaboTaHu.
baToHaMCu: see OaboTaHu, in four places.
biTaAHN buT-aHN [Many wide water-courses in which are fine, or minute, or broken, pebbles: the former word is pl. of OaboTaHu or of baToHaMCu]: a phrase like OaEowaAmN Euw-amN. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)
baTiyHapN: see OaboTaHu.
baATiHN applied to a man, i. q. munobaTiHN↓ [part. n. of 7, q. v.]. (Ḥam p. 244.)

OaboTaHu, originally an epithet [and therefore imperfectly decl.], (M, TA,) that is, an epithet converted into a subst., and not used as an epithet, (Ḥam p. 21,) A wide water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are fine, or minute, or broken, pebbles; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and Ḥam ubi suprà;) so called because the water goes in it to the right and left; [i. e. spreads widely; see 7;] (AA;) as also baToHaMCu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, Ḥam,) fem. of the former, and, like it, an epithet converted into a subst.; (Ḥam ubi suprà;) and baTiyHapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and baTiHN↓: (Ḳ:) or a water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are sand and pebbles; as also baToHaMCu↓: (Mgh:) or a wide place [app. in a water-course]; as also bTHp↓ [app. baToHapN, which is explained by Freytag, but without his stating on what authority, as signifying a depressed place through which water flows, abounding with pebbles; as is also biToHapN; and in like manner Golius explains the former, but mentions the latter as a pl. of bTyHp]: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to AḤn, the bottom of a water-course, or channel of a torrent, producing no plants or herbage: (TA:) or baToHaMCu↓ signifies soft earth of a valley, such as has been drawn along by the torrents: (ISd, TA:) or the soft pebbles in the bottom of the water-course, or channel of a torrent, of a valley; as also OaboTaHu: (IAth, TA:) or the soft earth, such as has been drawn along by the torrents, in the bottom of a taloEap [meaning a water-course, &c.] and of a valley; and the OaboTaH and baToHaMC↓ of a valley are its earth and soft pebbles: (En-Naḍr, TA:) and accord. to AA, baTiHN↓ signifies sand in a baToHaMC: (TA:) the pl. is OabaATiHu and biTaAHN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and baTaAYiHu; (Ḳ;) the first of these, and the second also, contr. to analogy, being pls. of AbTH; (Ṣ;) or both are pls. of bTHMC, contr. to analogy; (Ḥam p. 251;) or the first is pl. of AbTH, formed after the manner of the pl. of a subst. of this measure, though the sing. is originally an epithet; (M, TA;) and the second, as is asserted by more than one, is correctly pl. of bTHMC, as is also baToHaAwaAtN; (TA;) and the third is pl. of bTyHp. (M, TA.)
munobaTiHN [part. n. of 7, q. v.: often applied to anything Spread out, expanded, or flat]: see baATiHN.
4. OaboTaxuwA They had abundance of biT-iyx [or melons, or water-melons]. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
5. tbT-x He ate biT-iyx. (A, TA.)
UibilN baTixapN, and rijaAlN baTixapN, ‡ Large, big, bulky, or corpulent, camels, and men: and rajulN buTaAxiI-N↓ ‡ a large, big, bulky, or corpulent, man. (Ḳ, TA.)
buTaAxiI-N: see what immediately precedes.

baT-iyxN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) vulgarly and incorrectly pronounced baT-iyxN, (ISk, Mṣb,) and in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz called Tib-iyxN, (Mṣb,) A certain well-known fruit; (Mṣb;) [the melon, absolutely, as is shown by many passages in the lexicons, and expressly stated in law-books: and, particularly, the water-melon; cucurbita citrullus: or a plant] of the kind called yaqoTiyn, that does not grow tall, but extends itself upon the surface of the ground: (Ḳ, TA:) and also the xirobiz [or xarobuz, a Persian word, and applied to the water-melon, by the Turks termed by this name, and in their own language qaAroPuwzo]: (CK: [but not found by me in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, nor in the L, nor in the TA:]) or AlbiT-iyxu AlhinodiI-u [the Indian bT-yx] is what is called in Persian the xarobuz: (Mgh:) [the term bT-yx is applied to many varieties of the water-melon, distinguished by different epithets; as AlOaHomaru the red, AlOaSofaru the yellow, AlOaboyaDu the white, AlOajorabu the mangy, Aln-amoXu the speckled, Alburul-uI-u that of El-Burullus,, &c.: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {baT-iyxapN}. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maboTaxapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, &c.) and maboTuxapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) A place where biT-iyx grow: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, &c.:) pl. mabaATixu. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baTira, aor. _a {yaboTaru}, inf. n. baTarN, He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or he exulted by reason of wealth, and behaved with pride and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or he behaved with the utmost exultation,, &c.: or he rejoiced, and rested his mind upon things agreeable with natural desire: syn. of the inf. n. OaXarN, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, TA,) and maraHN; (L, TA;) the former of which signifies Xid-apN AlmaraHi, (Ṣ, A,) and mujaAwazapu AlHad-i fiI maraHK: (A:) he was, or became, stupified, deprived of his reason, confounded, or amazed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, Er-Rághib,) bearing wealth ill, or in an evil manner, performing little of the duty imposed on him by it, and turning it to a wrong purpose: (Er-Rághib, TA,* TḲ:) this is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he was, or became, stupified, or confounded, and knew not what to prefer nor what to postpone: (TA:) he was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, by reason of fright: (Aṣ, Ṣ voce baHira:) he behaved exorbitantly, or insolently, with wealth, (Ḳ, TA,) or on the occasion of having wealth: and this, also, is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he had, or exercised, little of the quality of bearing wealth [in a becoming, or proper, manner]: (Ḳ:) he behaved proudly: (TA:) he regarded a thing with hatred, or dislike, without its deserving to be so regarded: he was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yanoZuru Qll-ehu yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mano jar-a UizaArahu baTarFA [God will not look, on the day of resurrection, upon him who drags along his wrapper of the lower part of the body in exultation and insolence, or pride: meaning one who wears too long a wrapper of the lower part of the body]. (TA.)

baTirota EayoXaka ‡ [Thou exultedst, or exultedst greatly, or excessively, and behavedst insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully,, &c., in thy manner of life,] is a phrase similar to raXidota Oamoraka; (Ṣ, TA;) and in like manner baTirato maEiyXatahaA, in the Ḳur [xxviii. 58]; in which the verb is not trans., but the subst. is put in the accus. case because of fiI understood before it. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ.)
laA OaboTaru AlginaI † I do not, or will not, domineer, or assume superiority, over others when I am rich. (Ḥam p. 517.)
baTira Aln-iEomapa ‡ He held wealth, or the favour, or benefit, in light estimation, and was unthankful, or ungrateful, for it. (A.)
baTira hidaAyapa Oamorihi † He refused the right direction as to the management of his affair, and was ignorant of it. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., that pride is baTaru AlHaq-i, which means ‡ The considering as false, or vain, what God has pronounced to be the truth, or our duty; namely, the confession of his unity, and the obligation of rendering Him religious service: or the being confounded at considering truth, or duty, and not seeing it to be true, or incumbent: (TA:) or the disdaining the truth, or right, and not accepting it or not admitting it. (Ḳ.)
baTarahu, aor. _u {yaboTuru} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yaboTiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baTorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He cut it, or divided it, lengthwise; slit it; split it. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the appellation bayoTaArN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 4. AbTrhu It rendered him such as is termed baTir; it (wealth) caused him to exult, or to exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully:, &c.: [see baTira:] (Ṣ, A:) it stupified him, deprived him of his reason, confounded him, or amazed him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, maA OamoTarato Hat-aI OaboTarato It (the sky) rained not until it caused [men] to exult, or to exult greatly,, &c. (A.)
AbTr Hilomahu ‡ It (the ignorance of a person) caused his (another's) clemency, moderation, or gravity, to become converted into inordinate exultation, and insolence, or the like, and levity. (A.)
AbTrhu Hilomahu ‡ It stupified, confounded, or amazed, him, so as to turn him from his clemency, moderation, or gravity. (TA.)

AbTrhu caroEahu ‡ He imposed upon him more than he was able to do; (Ṣ;) what was above his power: (Ḳ:) crEh is here a substitute for its antecedent to indicate an implication therein: (A:) you say this when a slow-paced camel has endeavoured in vain to keep pace with another camel; and when any man has imposed upon another a difficulty beyond his power: (TA:) or the meaning is, he cut off his means of subsistence, and wasted his body: (IAạr, Ḳ:) crE signifying the “body.” (IAạr.)
Q. Q. 1. bayoTara, inf. n. bayoTarapN, He practised [farriery, the veterinary art, or] the art of the bayoTaAr. (Mṣb.)
huwa yubayoTiru Ald-awaAb-a He treats beasts, or horses and the like, medically, or curatively. (TA.)
cahaba damuhu biTorFA ‡ His blood went unrevenged, (Ks, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) being held in light estimation. (A.)

baTirN part. n. of baTira, (Mṣb, TA,) Exulting, or exulting greatly, or excessively, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or exulting by reason of wealth, and behaving with pride and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or behaving with the utmost exultation,, &c.: see its verb. (A, Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: baTiyrN Cut, or divided, lengthwise; slit; split; (Ḳ;) as also maboTuwrN↓. (TA.)
See also bayoTaArN.

entry.sense: AimoraOapN baTiyrapN A woman who behaves with much baTar, i. e. exultation, and insolence and unthankfulness, or ingratitude,, &c.: [see baTira.] (A.) [See also what next follows.]

biToriyrN Clamorous; long-tongued: and one who perseveres in error: fem. with p {biToriyrapN}: (Ḳ:) but it [the former] is mostly used in relation to women, (TA,) and as signifying a woman who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully, (taboTaru,) and perseveres in error: (ADk:) [it is said in the TA that some say biZoriyrN, and that this is the more approved; but Az says,] Lth cites, from ADk, the phrase AimoraOapN biToriyrN as meaning a clamorous, long-tongued woman; liOan-ahaA qado baTirato wOaXiratN [because of her insolent behaviour]: and says that, accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, it is AmrAp biZoriyrN; her tongue being likened to the baZor: but Lth adds, the saying of ADk is preferable in my opinion, and more correct. (T in art. bZr.)
bayoTarN: see bayoTaArN.
biyaTorN: see bayoTaArN.

[Hence,] A tailor. (Sh, Ṣ,* Ḳ.) A poet says, (calling a tailor a byTr, like as one calls a skilful man an UisokaAf, Sh, TA,)
Xaq-a AlbiyaTori midoraEa AlhumaAmi
[Like as the tailor cuts lengthwise, or slits, the woollen tunic of the valiant chief]. (Sh, Ṣ.)
bayoTarapN [Farriery; the veterinary art;] the art of the bayoTaAr. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See Q. Q. 1.]

bayoTaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and biyaTorN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bayoTarN↓ and baTiyrN↓ (Ḳ) and mubayoTirN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) [A farrier; one who practises the veterinary art;] one who treats beasts, or horses and the like, medically, or curatively: (Ḳ:) from baTarahu, explained above. (Ṣ, Mṣb.*) OaXoharu mino raAyapi AlbayoTaAri [More commonly known than the sign of the farrier, app. meaning a sign which, I suppose, the itinerant farrier carried about with him,] (A, TA) is one of the proverbs of the Arabs. (TA.)
You say, also, huwa bihecaA EaAlimN bayoTaArN ‡ [He is knowing and skilful in this: see also biyaTorN]. (A.)
maboTuwrN: see baTiyrN.
mubayoTirN: see bayoTaArN.

biToriyqN A qaAYid [or leader of an army], in the language of the ruwm [or Greeks of the Lower Empire]; (JK;) one who is to the rwm like the qAYd to the Arabs; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [i. e.] a leader of an army (qAYd) of the rwm; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to Kudámeh, (Mgh,) one who is over ten thousand men: (Mgh, Ḳ:) next to him is the TaroxaAn [in the CK taroxAn], over five thousand: then, the qawomas, over two hundred: (Ḳ:) but in art. Trx in the Ḳ, it is said that TrxAn signifies “a headman, or chief, of high, or noble, rank,” in the language of Khurásán; and in art. qms, that qwms signifies “a commander,” or the like, syn. OamiyrN; and. qamaAmisapN, i. q. baTaAriqapN, (TA,) which is pl. of bTryq, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also baTaAriyqu, for which baTaAriqu is used in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb: (TA:) it is an arabicized word; (Ṣ, TA;) [app. from the Latin “patricius;”] or, as some say, of the language of the rwm and of Syria: or Arabic, agreeing with the foreign word, and of the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz: accord. to El-Jawáleeḳee and others, in the language of the rwm it is btrk: some say that it signifies skilled in war and its affairs, in the language of the rwm; and he who is so has rank, or office, and is sometimes made foremost, among them: (TA:)
and (some say, TA) a proud and self-conceited man; (JK, Ḳ;) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád: (TA:) and fat; applied to a bird (JK, Ḳ), &c.: (JK:) pl. baTaAriqapN. (Ḳ.)
[See also baTorakN, and jaAvaliyqN.]

baTorakN and biTarokN i. q. biToriyqN, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. A leader of the Christians: (TA:) or the chief of the Magians: (Ḳ:) [in the present day, the former is applied to a Patriarch of a Christian church; as also biToriykN↓: (see jaAvaliyqN:) pl. baTaArikapN and baTaAriyku]: adventitious; not Arabic. (Az, TA.)
biToriykN: see baTorakN.
biToriyikI-N: see baTorakiI-N.
biToriyiky-ahu: see baTorakiy-apN.

1. baTaXa bihi, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaboTiXu} and _u {yaboTuXu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of which is that adopted by the seven readers (Mṣb, TA) in chap. xliv. verse 15 of the Ḳur, (TA,) inf. n. baToXN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He seized him violently; laid violent hands upon him: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) assaulted him: (Ṣ:) or he seized him with violence and assault: (A, Ḳ:) or he seized him vehemently, in anger: (Mgh:) and he laid hold upon him (Mgh, TA) vehemently, (TA,) in making an assault: (Mgh, TA:) and OaboTaXahu↓ signifies the same as baTaXa bihi, (Ḳ,) but is rare, occurring in the words [of the Ḳur xliv. 15], yawoma nuboTiXu AlbaToXapa AlkuboraI, accord. to the reading of El-Ḥasan and Ibn-Rejà, [meaning On the day when we make the greatest assault:] or, accord. to AḤát, [and Bḍ says the like,] the meaning is, [on the day when] we give power over them to such as shall assault them [with the great assault; or make to assault with the great assault]. (TA.)

Also He took it, namely, anything, or took hold of it, (Lth, Ḳ,* TA,) or clung to it, (TA,) strongly. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.) In the saying of El-Hulwánee, wamaA laA yaqaEu Ealayohi AlEayonu walaA yaboTiXuhu Alkaf-u, [meaning And that upon which the eye falls not, and of which the hand does not take hold,] the prep. [bi] is understood; or the verb is thus used as implying the meaning of AlOaxocu and Alt-anaAwulu. (Mgh.)
baTaXato bihimo OahowaAlu Ald-unoyaA ‡ [The terrors of the world assaulted them]. (A.)
baTaXati Alyadu The hand worked, wrought, or laboured. (Mṣb.)
fulaAnN yaboTiXu fiI AlEilomi bibaAEK basiyTK ‡ [Such a one labours in science with extensive ability]. (A, TA.)
baTaXa mina AlHum-aI ‡ He recovered from the fever, being still weak. (Aboo-Málik, A,* Ḳ.)

3. bATXhu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. mubaATaXapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and biTaAXN, (TA,) He laboured, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, to prevail, or overcome; syn. of the inf. n. muEaAlajapN. (Ḳ, TA.)
baATaXaA, (TḲ,) inf. n. mubaATaXapN, (Ḳ,) Each of them two stretched forth his hand towards the other to seize him violently (Ḳ, TA) and to assault him quickly. (TA.)
4: see 1, where two meanings are assigned to it.
5. Alr-ikaAbu tabaT-aXu biOaHomaAlihaA, [for tabaT-aXu,] ‡ The travelling-camels walk with slow steps (tazaH-afu [for tatazaH-afu]) with their burdens, hardly moving. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
baToXN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].
Also Might, or strength, in war or fight: or courage; valour, or valiantness; prowess: syn. baOosN. (Ḳ.) You say, rajulN Xadiydu AlbaToXi [A man of great might,, &c.]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And Anger. (Ḥar p. 258.)
baToXapN An assault; a violent seizure. (Ṣ.) AlbaToXapu AlkuboraI [The greatest assault], in the Ḳur xliv. 15, is applied to the day of resurrection, or to the battle of Bedr. (Bḍ.)
baTiyXN i. q. Xadiydu AlbaToXi; (Ḳ;) [see baToXN;] applied to a man; as also baT-aAXN↓. (TA.)
baT-aAXN: see baTiyXN.

biTaAqapN A piece of paper: (IAạr, M, Ṣgh, TA:) in the Ḳ, AlHadaqapu is erroneously put for Alwaraqapu: (TA:) a ticket that is attached to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) bearing the mark, or inscription, of its price; (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) or a ticket marked, or inscribed, with the weight, and the number, of a thing: (TA:) of the dial. of Egypt (T, Ṣ, L) and the neighbouring parts: (T, L:) so called, (Ḳ,) or said (by Sh, TA) to be so called, (Ṣ,) because it is tied by a twist, or thread, (biTaAqapF,) of the unwoven end of the cloth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but this is a mistake: (ISd, TA:) [in Greek, πιττάκιον, as observed by Freytag; and hence probably derived:] accord. to some, it is [niTaAqapF,] with n, because it tells (tanoTiqu) what is marked, or inscribed, thereon; but this is strange. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that a man will be brought on the day of resurrection, and ninety-nine scrolls, or records, inscribed with his sins will be produced; and there will be produced for him a bTAqp bearing the testimony that there is no deity but God, and it will outweigh the others. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baTala, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboTulu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. buTolN and buTuwlN and buTolaAnN, [of which the last seems to be the most common,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL, &c.,) It (a thing) was, or became, baATil, as meaning contr. of Haq-; (Ṣ;) [i. e.,] it was, or became, false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PṢ,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Mṣb;) it went for nothing, as a thing of no account, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (Ḳ.) [It is said of an assertion or allegation and the like, and of a deed, &c.] Hence the saying in the Ḳur [vii. 115], wabaTala maA kaAnuwA yaEomaluwna [And what they were doing became vain, or null; or went for nothing, as a thing of no account]. (TA.) And cahaba damuhu buTolFA His blood went for nothing, [unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulet,] as a thing of no account. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And baTala damuhu [signifies the same; or] He was slain without there being obtained for him either blood-revenge or blood-wit. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also the inf. n. buTuwlN below, voce baT-aAlN.
labaTula Alqawolu [How false, untrue, wrong or incorrect,, &c., is the saying!] is said in wonder at that which is baATil. (TA.)

baTala, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or baTala mina AlEamali, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaboTulu}, (TA,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and biTaAlapN, which is mentioned by one of the expositors of the Moʼallaḳát, and said to be the more chaste, and sometimes one says buTaAlapN, to make it accord with its contr. EumaAlapN, (Mṣb,) He (a hired man, or hireling,) was, or became, idle, unoccupied, or without work. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ, KL. [See also 5.]) [Hence, yawomu baTaAlapK A day of idleness; a holiday.]
biTaAlapN, with kesr, also signifies The being diverted from that which would bring profit in the present life or in the life to come. (TA.)
See also 2.

baTula, aor. _u {yaboTulu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and biTaAlapN (Lth, Mṣb, TA) and buTaAlapN (TA) and buTuwlapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) He (a man) was, or became, courageous, brave, or stronghearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; such as is termed baTalN, q. v.; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL;) as also tbT-l↓: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies he affected courage,, &c.; he made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous,, &c.; syn. taXaj-aEa. (TA.)
labaTula Alr-ajulu [How courageous,, &c., is the man!] is said in wonder at Alt-abaT-ul [i. e. courage, &c., or the affecting of courage, &c.]. (TA.)

2. Alt-aboTiylu [inf. n. of bT-l] signifies fiEolu AlbTAlhi↓, [in which the latter word is written in the TA without any indication of the vowel of the b,] i. e. The pursuit of vain, or frivolous, diversion or sport, and foolish, or ignorant, conduct. (TA.) [See biTaAlapN, above, and the phrase next following it.]
See also 4.

4. AbTl He said, or spoke, what was false, or untrue; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [contr. of OaHaq-a;] he lied: (Mgh:) he made a false, or vain, claim or demand; he claimed, or demanded, for himself that which was not right, or just. (Lth, TA.)
See also 1.

AbTlhu [and vulgarly bT-lhu↓] He made it, or rendered it, [and he proved it to be,] baATil, i. e. false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ, TA,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Mṣb, TA;) he nullified it, annulled it, abolished it, cancelled it; whether it was true or false, right or wrong, authentic or spurious, valid or null; (TA;) he made it to go for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (Ḳ.) Hence, AbTl XahaAdatahu He annulled his testimony. (TA in art. zwr.) And liyuHiq-a AlHaq-a wayuyoTila AlbaATila, in the Ḳur [viii. 8, meaning That He might establish that which is true, and annul that which is false]. (TA.)
5. tbT-lwA bayonahumo They took it by turns to say, or to do, that which was false, wrong, vain, futile, or the like; syn. tadaAluwA AlbaATila. (Az, Ḳ.)
[tbT-l, said in the Mgh to be from AlbaTaAlapu, (see baTala, or baTala mina AlEamali,) app. signifies, as its part. n. (q. v. voce baT-aAlN) indicates, He became unoccupied and lazy.]
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: buTolN [originally an inf. n. of 1, and mentioned therewith, first sentence:] i. q. baATilN, q. v. (Ḥam p. 114.)

baTalN, said to be the only epithet of its measure except HasanN; (TA in art. Hsn;) applied to a man, Courageous, brave, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; [commonly used as a subst., meaning a man of courage or valour, a brave man, a hero;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also baT-aAlN↓; (Ḳ;) one whose wound goes for nothing, so that he does not care for it, (Lth, Ḳ,) and it does not withhold him from the exercise of his courage; (Lth, TA;) or the blood of whose adversaries goes for nothing with him, (Ḳ,) unrevenged: (TA:) or for this reason he is thus called; (TA;) or because life is annulled, or made to go for nothing, on the occasion of encountering him, and severe misfortunes are annulled by him, (Mṣb,) or by his sword, and made to be of no account: (TA:) and so baTalapN↓ applied to a woman; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to one of the expositors of the Ḥamáseh; (Mṣb;) but AZ says that this is not allowable: (IDrd, TA:) the pl. of baTalN is OaboTaAlN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baTalapN: see baATilN:
and see also baTalN.

entry.sense: baTolaAnu One whose powers have become weak: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)
buT-alaAtN ( pl. of buT-alN, TA) False, or vain, things; or unprofitable sayings. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa biAlbuT-alaAti He uttered false, or vain, things;, &c. (El-Moḥeeṭ, TA.)

hom.sense: See also baTalN.

entry.sense: baATilN contr. of Haq-N; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. False, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PṢ,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no effect; (Mṣb;) that proves, when inquired into, or investigated, to be false, wrong, unfounded, unsound, or not established; applying to a saying, and [sometimes] to a deed: (TA:) [going for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that has perished or become lost: (see the verb, 1, first sentence:) often used as a subst., meaning a false, or vain, saying, or assertion, or allegation; a lie; a falsehood: and a false, or vain, deed, or action, or affair, or thing;, &c.:] and buTolN↓ is syn. therewith, (Ḥam p. 114,) and so are OuboTuwlapN↓ and UiboTaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. of baATilN is bawaATilu; (Mṣb;) and buTulN occurs as a pl. of the same; (Ḥam p. 360;) or its pl. is OabaATiylu, contr. to analogy, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as though the sing. were UiboTiylN; (Ṣ;) or, accord. to AḤát, this is pl. of OuboTuwlapN↓, or, as some say, of UiboTaAlapN↓, (Mṣb,) or, accord. to Aṣ and AḤát and IDrd, of both these; (TA;) and signifies false, or vain, sayings and actions or deeds. (Ḳ in art. htr, &c.) You say, qado qulota baATilFA [Thou hast said a false, or vain, saying; a lie; a falsehood]; like as you say, qado qulota Haq-FA. (Ḥam p. 360.) And yaOokuluwna OamowaAla Aln-aAsi biAlbaATili [They devour the possessions of men by false pretence]. (Ḳur ix. 34.) And bayonahumo OuboTuwlapN↓ and UiboTaAlapN↓ [Between them is false, or vain, speech, or discourse,, &c.]; syn. baATilN. (Ḳ.)
The belief in a plurality of Gods: so explained as occurring in the Ḳur xlii. 23. (TA.)
See also baT-aAlN, in two places. [Hence,] baATilFA In play, or sport; acting unprofitably; or aiming at no profit. (Jel in iii. 188 and xxxviii. 26.)

AlbaATilu Iblees: so in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 48], where it is said, maA yubodiYu QlobaATilu wamaA yuEiydu [explained in art. bdO]: (Ḳatádeh, Ḳ:) and again [xli. 42], where it is said, laA yaOotiyhi QlobaATilu mino bayona yadayohi walaA mino xalofihi, [accord. to some,] meaning that Iblees shall not add to the Ḳur-án nor diminish therefrom: (TA:) baTalapN↓ [is its pl., and] signifies devils: (A, TA:) or enchanters. (O, Ḳ.)
UiboTaAlapN: see baATilN; for each in three places.
OuboTuwlapN: see baATilN; for each in three places.

muboTilN One who says a thing in which is no truth, or reality: (Er-Rághib, TA:) one who embellishes speech with lies: (Bḍ in xxx. 58:) one who says, or does, false, or vain, things. (Jel ibid.) [See also its verb, 4.]
mutabaT-ilN: see baT-aAlN.

buTomN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and buTumN, (Ḳ,) the latter allowable accord. to IAạr, (TA,) The Hab-ap xaDoraMC [or fruit of the terebinth-tree, to which this latter appellation is given in the present day, i. e., of the pistacia terebinthus of the botanists]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so accord. to the people of El-ʼÁliyeh; and the like is said on the authority of Aṣ: (TA:) or the tree thereof; (Ḳ;) [which is called buTom in the present day;] so accord. to AḤn; and he says, but no one has told me that it grows in the land of the Arabs; but they assert that the Dirow [meaning the cancamum-tree, also called kamokaAm, but said by IAạr to be the Hb-p xDrAC,] is nearly like it: (TA:) its fruit is heating, diuretic, strengthening to the venereal faculty, good for the cough, and for the [disease of the face called] laqowap, and for the kidney; and the overspreading of the hair with its dry and sifted leaves causes it to grow, and beautifies it. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. baTuna, aor. _u {yaboTunu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baTaAnapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, (Ḳ, TA,) in consequence of much eating. (TA.)

And baTina, aor. _a {yaboTanu}, inf. n. baTanN, He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, in consequence of satiety, (Ṣ, TA,) and disordered therein: (TA:) he was, or became, in a state of repletion, or much filled with food. (TA.)
And [hence,] baTina signifies also ‡ i. q. OaXira and baTira [He exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully:, &c.]. (TA.)
buTina He (a man, Ṣ, TA) had a complaint of, or a disease in, or a pain in, his belly. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

baTanahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboTunu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. baTonN, (TA,) He struck, or beat, his belly; as also baTana lahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to some, or the l is added [only] in verse; (Ṣ;) and bT-nhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboTiynN. (TA.)

It (a disease) entered into him: [as though it penetrated into his belly: see 10:] in this sense it has for its inf. n. buTuwnN. (TA.) And baTanato bihi AlHum-aI The fever produced an effect within him. (TA.)

‡ [He penetrated into it mentally;] he knew it; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) namely, the news or story, or the state or case, of another: (Ḳ, TA:) ‡ he knew the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances thereof; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) i. e., of a case, or an affair; (Ṣ, TA;)
as also AstbTnhu↓: (Ḳ, A, TA:) and tbT-nhu↓ † he entered into it so that he knew its inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances. (Ḥam p. 688.)

baTana bifulaAnK, accord. to the Ṣ and M, but in the Ḳ mino fulaAnK, (TA,) ‡ He became one of his particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) entering into his affair [or affairs]: (TA:) or baTana bihi, aor. _u {yaboTunu}, inf. n. buTuwnN and baTaAnapN, means † he entered into his affair [or affairs]. (TA.)
And baTana, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboTunu}, said of a thing, (Mṣb,) It was, or became, unapparent, hidden, concealed, or covert; (Ḳ, TA;) contr. of Zahara. (Mṣb.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2. bT-nhu, inf. n. taboTiynN: see 1.
See also 4.
He put a biTaAnap, i. e. a lining, to it; namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AbTnhu↓. (Ḳ.)

bT-n liHayatahu, inf. n. as above, He took, or cut off, from that part of his beard which was beneath the chin and lower jaw. (Sh, Nh, TA.) Accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, taboTiynu All-iHoyapi signifies the not doing so: but this is wrong. (TA.)
3. baATanotu SaAHibiI i. q. Xddth [app. a mistranscription for XaAwarotuhu, meaning † I consulted with my companion in order to know what was in his mind]. (TA.)

4. AbTn AlbaEiyra, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiboTaAnN, (Ṣ,) He bound, or made fast, the camel's biTaAn [or belly-girth]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bT-nhu↓, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ; but this is a mistake for baTanahu↓, aor. _u {yaboTunu}, inf. n. baTonN; which last verb, however, though said by Az to be a dial. var., is disallowed by IAạr and by AHeyth. (TA.)

OaboTanotu Als-iyofa kaXoHiI (Ṣ, TA) I put the sword beneath my waist. (TA.) And AbTn kaXoHahu sayofahu † He made his sword to be his biTaAnap↓ [app. meaning his secret companion]. (TA.) [This seems to be from the phrase next following.]

OaboTanotu Alr-ajula † I made the man to be one of my particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates; (Ṣ, TA;*) took him as a biTaAnap. (TA.) One says also, AisotaboTanotu↓ fulaAnFA duwnaka (Ḥam p. 688; [there rendered by xAmSth, app. a mistranscription for xaSaSotuhu; meaning † I took, or chose, such a one particularly, or specially, for my companion, in preference to thee: it is said in explanation of the phrase musotaboTinFA sayofiI, which seems to mean † taking my sword as my special companion, or putting it beneath my waist; so that AstbTn↓ sayofahu is similar to one, or both, of two phrases mentioned above in this paragraph.])
See also 2.
5. tbT-n He filled the [meaning his] belly. (Ḥar p. 176.)
tbT-n jaAriyapF (Sh, Ṣ, TA) He made his baTon to be in contact with that of a girl, skin to skin: (Sh, TA:) or inivit puellam; i. e. OawolaHa cakarahu fiyhaA. (TA.)
tbT-n AlkalaOa He was, or became, in the middle, or midst, of the herbage: (TA:) or he went round about in the herbage. (Ṣ.) See also 1, in two places.
6. tbATn It (a place) was far-extending; one part thereof being remote from another. (TA.)

8. AibotaTanotu Aln-aAqapa EaXarapa OaboTunK I assisted the she-camel in bringing forth, or delivered her of her young, ten times. (Ṣ, TA. [Golius and Freytag render the verb by “ventre enixa fuit:” and the former renders the phrase above (incorrectly printed in his Lex.) by “peperit camela decem vicibus.”])
10. AstbTn Alfarasa He sought to find what young was in the belly of the mare. (TA.)

AstbTn AlfaHolu AlX-uw-ala The stallion covered the she-camels raising their tails, so that they conceived, or received his seed into their wombs; as though [meaning] he deposited his seed in their bellies. (TA.)

AstbTnhu He, or it, entered [or penetrated] into his, or its, belly, or interior; [or was, or became, or lay, within it;] like as the vein enters [or penetrates] into [or lies within] (yasotaboTinu) the flesh. (A, TA.) You say, AisotaboTanotu AlX-aIoCa [I entered, or penetrated, into the thing, whether actually or mentally]. (Ṣ.) See 1, in two places.
See also 4, in two places.

AisotiboTaAnN also signifies The having, or holding, [a thing] concealed within. (PṢ.) [This explanation seems to be given to show that, in the opinion of the author of the PṢ, AisotaboTanotu AlX-aIoCa in the Ṣ means I had, or held, the thing concealed within.]

hom.sense: baTonN The belly, or abdomen; i. e. the part of the body which is separated from the jawof [i. e. chest, or thorax,] by the HijaAb [i. e. midriff, or diaphragm]; containing the liver and the spleen and the stomach and the lower intestines, &c.; (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán;” [in which it is erroneously said to comprise also the lungs;]) contr. of ZahorN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) of a man and of any animal: (TA:) of the masc. gender, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, accord. to AO, fem. also: (AḤát, Ṣ:) pl. OaboTunN and buTuwnN (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buTonaAnN; (Ḳ;) the first a pl. of pauc.; and the second [as also the third] a pl. of mult., applied to more than ten. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] cuw AlbaToni [What is in the belly: but generally meaning] excrement, ordure, or dung. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, OaloqaI caA baTonihi He (a man) ejected his excrement, or ordure. (TA.) And Oaloqato caA baTonihaA She (a woman, TA) brought forth; (Ḳ;) as also waDaEato caAta baTonihaA: (TA in art. cw:) and she (a hen) laid an egg. (Ḳ.) And navarato caA baTonihaA, (T and Mgh in art. nvr,) and [elliptically] navarato baTonahaA, (T and A and Mgh in that art.,) She (a woman) brought forth many children. (T in that art.) And it is said in a prov., (TA,) Alc-iYobu yugobaTu biciI baTonihi [The wolf is envied for what is in his belly]: for one never thinks him to be hungry, but only thinks him to be in a state of repletion, because of his hostility to men and cattle, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) though he is sometimes distressed by hunger. (AʼObeyd. [See various readings of this prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 500 and 501.]) maAtato fiI baTonK, a phrase occurring in a trad., means She (a woman) died in childbirth. (TA.) See also fulaAnN Qbonu baTonihi baTanN. means † Such a one is solicitous for his belly. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnI.) [Many phrases in which the word baTon occurs will be found explained under other words of those phrases; as ZahorN, and Oaxaca, and EuSofuwrN, &c.] baTonu AlHuwti: see Alr-iXaMCu.

Also The inside, or interior, of anything; syn. jawofN: and so baATinN↓; syn. daAxilN: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former as above. (TA.) Thus baTonu waAdK means The interior of a water-course or riverbed [or valley; i. e. its bottom, in which flows, occasionally or constantly, its torrent or river]. (MA.) And baTonu mak-apa means The interior of Mekkeh. (Bḍ in xlviii. 24.) [Hence,] it is said of the Ḳur-án, likul-i MyapK minohaA ZahorN wabaTonN, meaning † To every verse thereof is an apparent sense and a sense requiring development. (TA.) [See ZahorN.] See also baATinN. [And its pl. buTonaAnN is also used as a sing., meaning The middle, or midst, of a thing: and the lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation. Thus,] buTonaAnu Aljan-api means The middle, or midst, of Paradise: (Ṣ, TA:) and buTonaAnu AlEaroXi, The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of the ErX [vulgarly held to be the throne of God]. (TA.) You say also [baTonu Alkaf-i and] baATinu↓ Alkaf-i † The palm of the hand [opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: and [baTonu Alqadami and] baATinu↓ Alqadami † The sole of the foot [likewise opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: (Zj in his “Khalk- el-Insán:”) and baTonu AlHaAfiru (Ṣ in art. nsr) and baATinu↓ AlHaAfiri (M and Ḳ in that art.) † [The sole of the solid hoof;] the part of the solid hoof in which is the nasor, q. v. (Ṣ and M and Ḳ in that art.) baTonu Alr-aAHapi is well known [as another name for baTonu Alkaf-i, explained above; for Alr-aAHap is often used as syn. with Alkaf-]: and baATinu↓ Alxuf-i is [said to be] † The part of the foot of a camel or the like that is next the leg: and one says, baATinu↓ AlUiboTi, [meaning † The armpit, or hollow of the inner side of the shoulder-joint,] but not baTonu AlUiboTi: (TA:) [and baATinu↓ AlEunuqi the throat.] The baTon of a feather is ‡ The long, (Ṣ,) or longer, (Ḳ,) [or wider, i. e. inner,] lateral half: pl. buTonaAnN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) which is explained as signifying the parts beneath the shaft: opposed to ZuhoraAnN, pl. of ZahorN [q. v.]. (TA.)

Also A low, or depressed, tract, or portion, of land, or ground; (Ṣ, TA;) and so baATinN↓: (TA:) [or a bottom, or low land; or a low, soft flat; i. e.] soft, plain, fine, low land or ground; opposed to ZahorN [q. v.]: (TA in art. Zhr:) pl. of the former, (Ṣ,) or of the latter, (Ḳ,) buTonaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. of mult., (TA,) and OaboTinapN, (Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., and anomalous [as pl. of either]: (TA:) the former pl., in relation to land, is also used as a sing., like baTonN: (AḤn, TA:) and accord. to ISh, buTonaAnu AlOaroDi signifies the low, or depressed, tract, or tracts, of land, of the plain, or soft, parts thereof, and of the rugged, and of the meadows, where water rests and stagnates: and such tracts are also called bawaATinu and buTuwnN. (TA.)
baTonu Als-amaMCi and Zahoru Als-amaMCi both signify † The apparent, visible, part of the sky. (Fr, T voce ZahorN [q. v.].)

Also ‡ A tribe below that which is termed qabiylap: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or next below the EimaArap: (Ṣ and TA voce XaEobN, &c.:) or below the faxic and above the EmArp: (Ḳ: [but for this I have found no other authority:]) of the masc. gender: (TA:) or [properly] fem.: but if Hay-N [said by some to signify a tribe, absolutely,] be meant thereby, it is masc.: (Mṣb:) or fem. if used in the sense of qabiylap: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboTunN and [of mult.] buTuwnN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See XaEobN.]

entry.sense: baTinN One whose object of care, or anxiety, is his belly: (Ḳ:) or who has an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; (Ṣ;) whom nothing causes care, or anxiety, but his belly; (Ṣ, TA;) as also miboTaAnN↓: (TA:) or the former, (TA,) or ↓the latter, (Ṣ,) ever large, or big, in the belly in consequence of much eating: (Ṣ, TA:) or ↓both signify voracious; not ceasing from eating. (Ḳ.)
And [hence,] ‡ One who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (TA:) or who does so, being abundant in wealth. (Ḳ, TA.)
biTonapN Repletion; the state of being much filled with food (Ṣ, Ḳ) and drink. (So in a copy of the Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., AlbiTonapu tucohibu AlfiTonapa [Repletion banishes intelligence]. (TA.)
And [hence,] ‡ Exultation, or great or excessive exultation, and insolent and unthankful, or ungrateful, behaviour. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence also,] maAta fulaAnN bibiTonatihi † Such a one died with his wealth complete, not having expended, or dispensed, anything thereof: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, this prov. relates to religion, and means † he went forth from the present world in a state of integrity, without any infringement of his religion. (TA.) [See also tagaDogaDa, in two places.] [Hence also,] naz-ato bihi AlbaTinapu † Richness caused him to exult, or exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TA.)
AlbaTinapu i. q. Ald-uburu [The back, hinder part, posteriors,, &c.]. (TA.)
baTinaAtu AlwaAdiI The roads, or beaten tracks, of the valley. (TA.)

biTaAnN [The belly-girth of a camel: or] the girth of the [kind of saddle called] qatab, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is put beneath the belly of the camel, and is like the taSodiyr to the raHol: (Ṣ:) or the girth of the [saddle called] raHol: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboTinapN and [of mult.] buTonN. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] Ailotaqato HaloqataA AlbiTaAni [The two rings of the belly-girth met]: said of a case, or an affair, that has become severe, strait, or distressing. (Ṣ.) And rajulN EariyDu AlbiTaAni ‡ A man in ample and easy circumstances; or in an easy, or a pleasant, state or condition; or easy, or unstraitened, in mind. (Ḳ, TA. [See also art. ErD.]) And maAta fulaAnN wahuwa EariyDu AlbiTaAni, meaning, accord. to AʼObeyd, † Such a one died broad in the fleshy parts (AlmalaAHim); nothing of him having gone. (TA. [But this seems to be said of a man's dying in a state of opulence: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 601.])

Hence, ‡ Full; applied to a purse [&c.]. (TA.) You say rajulN baTiynu Alkurozi † [lit. A man having the pair of provision-bags full]; meaning † a man who conceals his travel-ling-provision in a journey, and eats that of his companion. (TA.)
† Far; far-extending. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) So in the phrase XaOowN baTiynN † [A farextending heat, or single run to a goal or limit], (Ṣ, TA,) and XawoTN baTiynN [signifying the same]. (TA.)
† Wide, and low, or depressed; applied to a tract of land or ground. (Ḥam p. 506.)
biTaAnapN The lining, or inner covering, of a garment, or piece of cloth [&c.]; contr. of ZihaArapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also baATinapN↓: (JK in art. Zhr:) pl. of the former baTaAYnu. (TA.)

† A secret (Ḳ, TA) that a man conceals. (TA.) One says, huwa cuw biTaAnapK bifulaAnK, i. e. † He is one who possesses knowledge of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of the case, or affair, of such a one. (TA.)

‡ A particular, or special, intimate, friend, or associate; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) one who is particularly distinguished by entering into, and becoming acquainted with, the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of one's case or affair; (TA;) an intimate and familiar friend or associate; (Zj, TA;) a confidential friend, who is consulted respecting one's circumstances: (TA:) it is from the same word in the sense first explained above, relating to a garment, or piece of cloth: (Mgh, Er-Rághib:) and is used in a pl. sense, as meaning intimate and familiar friends or associates, to whom one is open, or unreserved, in conversation, and who know the inward state or circumstances [of one's case or affair]: (Zj, TA:) or one's family; and one's particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates. (Mgh.) You say, huwa biTaAnatiI ‡ [He is my particular, or special, intimate,, &c.]: and humo biTaAnatiI and Oaholu biTaAnatiI ‡ [They are my particular, or special, intimates,, &c.]. (A, TA.) See also 4.
Coupled with EalaAwap, it signifies What is put beneath [the things that compose the main load of a camel], such as a water-skin and the like. (TA.)
See also baATinapN.
baATinN Unapparent; hidden; concealed; covert: (Ḳ, TA:) [and inward; inner; interior; internal; intrinsic; esoteric: in all these senses] contr. of ZaAhirN. (Mṣb, TA.)

baATinu OamorK [The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, of a case or an affair]; (TA, &c.;) [and so baTonu↓ OamorK; whence the phrases,] OaforaXaniI Zahora Oamorihi wabaTonahu † [He displayed, or laid open, to me the outward state or circumstances of his case or affair, and the inward state or circumstances thereof]; and huwa mujar-ibN baTona AlOumuwri † [He is one who possesses experience of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of affairs], as though he hit their bellies by his knowledge of their true, or real, states or circumstances. (TA.)

AlbaATinu [The internal, inward, or intrinsic, state, condition, character, or circumstances, of a man: and the heart, meaning the secret thoughts; the recesses of the mind; the state of mind; the inward, or secret, disposition of the mind: opposed to AlZ-aAhiru.]

[Also,] an epithet applied to God, meaning He who knows the inward, or intrinsic, states or circumstances of things: (Ṣ:) or He who knows the secret and hidden things: or He who is veiled from the eyes and imaginations of created beings. (TA.)
[baATinFA Covertly; secretly.]
See also baATinapN, in eight places.
biTaAnapN also signifies A water-course, or place in which water flows, in rugged ground: pl. buTonaAnN (Ḳ) and buTonN. (TA.)
baATinapN: see biTaAnapN.
Also The middle, and the retired part, of a kuwrap [i. e. province, or district, or city]: in the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written biTaAnap↓, and explained as meaning the “middle of a kwrp.” (TA.)

AlOaboTanu A certain vein in the interior of the arm of the horse; one of two veins which are called AlOaboTanaAni: (Ṣ:) accord. to AO, these are two veins that penetrate into the interior of the arm until they become hidden among the sinews of the shank. (TA.)
mubaT-anN, applied to a man, Lank in the belly: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) fem. with p {mubaT-anapN}. (Ṣ.)
Applied to a horse, White in the back and belly. (Ḳ.)
Lined; having a biTaAnap put to it. (TA.)
miboTaAnN: see baTiynN, in two places: and see baTinN, in three places.
maboTuwnN Having a complaint of, or a disease in, or a pain in, his belly: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one who dies of disease of his belly, as dropsy and the like: such is reckoned a martyr. (TA.)
1. baTaA, aor. yaboTuw, is said by Z and Meyd to signify He, or it, was, or became, wide: and hence baATiyapN, meaning a naAjuwd. (TA.)
4: see what next follows.

biToyapN, with kesr, is a word mentioned by Sb; (Ḳ;) but ISd says, “I know not to what it is applied, unless OaboTayotu↓ be a dial. var. of OaboTaOotu, (Ḳ, TA,) like as AiHobanoTayotu is of AiHobanoTaOotu; in which case it is thence derived as meaning The state [of being slow,, &c.]; and is not to be regarded as formed by substitution [of I for C], because that would be extr.:” so in the M: (TA:) it is asserted, however, in the Ṣ and the Fṣ and the Jámiʼ el-Loghah of Ḳz and in other lexicons, that one should not say, AbTyt, with I, but AbTOt, with C. (MF, TA.)
baATK part. n. of baTaA, mentioned above, accord. to Z and Meyd. (TA.)

baATiyapN A certain vessel; (Ṣ;) a naAjuwd [or vessel into which wine is put]; (AA, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) a large vessel of glass, which is filled with wine, or beverage, and placed amid the drinkers, who ladle out from it [into their cups], (Az, Mgh, TA,) and drink: (Az, TA:) [a wine-vase, of glass or of earthenware; an amphora; an earthen jar; now applied to a vessel of this kind into which wine and oil, &c. are put:] said to be an arabicized word: (TA:) [J says,] “I think it to be arabicized:” (Ṣ:) but accord. to Z and Meyd, it is from 1, as mentioned above. (TA.)
1. baZirato, [aor. _a {yaboZaru}, inf. n. baZarN,] said of a woman, [She had a baZor (q. v.), or a long baZor; or] she was uncircumcised. (Mṣb.) [But see baZarN, below.]
And baZir, inf. n. baZarN, He had what is termed a buZaArap [q. v.] in his upper lip. (Ṣ.)
2. baZ-arato, inf. n. taboZiyrN, She circumcised a female. (Ḳ.)
huwa yumiS-uhu wayubaZ-iruhu (M, Ḳ) He says to him, AumoSuSo baZora fulaAnapa: (Ḳ:) a prov. of the Arabs. (TA.)

baZorN, (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) also pronounced baDorN, (T,) and buZaArapN↓ [which see below] (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and baZaArapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and bayoZarN↓ (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ) and bunoZurN↓, (Ḳ,) A certain thing, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or piece of flesh, (A,) between the two sides of the vulva (AlUisokataAni, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, or AlX-uforaAni, A, or XuforaA Alfaroji, Mgh) of a woman, (M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) which is cut off in circumcision, (A,) not yet cut off; (Ṣ;) a piece of flesh between the two sides of the vulva (AlX-uforaAni) of a woman; i. e. the prepuce (quloqap) that is cut off in circumcision; (Mṣb;) also called kayonN and raforafN and nawofN (Lḥ, T) and qunobN [which last properly signifies the “prepuce,” or “sheath,” of a beast or horse or the like]; (A and Ḳ in art. qnb;) and likened to a cock's comb: (Mṣb in art. Erf:) [the last of these explanations plainly shows that what is meant thereby is the prepuce of the clitoris; which, it seems, in the Arabian and Egyptian races, and others throughout Eastern Africa, and still more so in the Hottentot race, grows to an extraordinary size; and this may be the reason why the bZr is described by some travellers as a caruncle for which we have no name: or it may, perhaps, be a distinct excrescence from the prepuce of the clitoris: it has been described to me as a caruncle a little in front of the meatus urinarius: many of the Egyptians assert that it is the clitoris itself that is amputated, (as Ludolph also does in his Comment. to his Ethiop. Hist. p. 273, finding fault with those who say otherwise;) and they affirm that this is done for the purpose of lessening the libidinous passion: such, indeed, appears to be the case in some instances, but not generally; and it may have led to a misapplication of the term bZr in post-classical times: an analogous practice, one still more barbarous, is said to have obtained among an African race hence called the Colobi: see barobaru: Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zahráwee speaks of the amputation of the redundance of the bZr when preternaturally large, and also of an excrescence in the vulva: the former he describes in such a manner as plainly shows that he means thereby the clitoris: the latter, in terms apparently indicating a preternatural elongation of the lower part of the prepuce of the clitoris; as “an excrescence of flesh at, or in, the mouth of the vulva, such as fills it up, and sometimes protrudes externally, like a tail, wherefore the ancients term it the caudal disease AlmrD AlcnbI; and this,” he says, “should be amputated, like as the bZr is amputated” when preternaturally large: (Albucasis de Chirurgia, pp. 314 and 316:) in some of our medical books, the term “caudatio” is defined as “an elongation of the clitoris;” inconsistently with the foregoing description of “the caudal disease:”] the pl. [of mult.] of baZorN is buZuwrN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and [pl. of pauc.] OaboZurN. (Mṣb.) yaA Qbona muqaT-iEapi AlbuZuwri [O son of her who amputates bZwr!] is an expression of contumely employed by the Arabs whether the mother of the person addressed be really a circumciser of females or not. (TA.)

baZarN The having a baZor: (T, Ṣ:) or the having a long baZor: (Ḳ:) a subst., (Ḳ,) or an inf. n., (T,) having no verb, (T, M,*) because it denotes an inherent quality, not one that is accidental. (T.) [But see baZirato.]
buZorapN, or baZarapN: see buZaArapN.
baZaArapN: see baZorN.

buZaArapN The lower extremity, (M,) or a thing in the extremity, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a protuberant, or prominent, thing in the lower part, (Lḥ, T, M,) of the vulva (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M) of a ewe or goat, (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or camel, (Lḥ, T,) and any animal. (M.) It is metaphorically used by Jereer in relation to a woman. (M.) See baZorN.

Also, (Lḥ, Ṣ, T, M, &c.,) and buZorapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) or baZarapN↓, (IAạr, T,) The thing (M, Ḳ) protuberant, (M,) or a protuberant thing, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) in the upper lip, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) in the middle thereof, (M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) when it is somewhat long, (Ṣ,) or somewhat large: (M:) or a pro- tuberance in the lip: (IAạr, T:) when not long, it is called HivorimapN: (Ṣ:) it is not every one that has it: (Mgh:) dim. buZayorapN↓. (T.)
buZayorapN: see what next precedes.
biZoriyrN † A long-tongued, (M,) clamorous woman: (M, Ḳ: [in the CK, erroneously, with p:]) but some say biToriyrN [q. v.]. (M.) [See OaboZaru.]
bunoZurN: see baZorN.
bayoZarN: see baZorN.
yaA bayoZaru is an expression of contumely addressed to a female slave. (Ḳ.)

OaboZaru A man uncircumcised. (M, Ḳ.) And the fem., baZoraMCu, A woman, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or a female slave, (M, Ḳ,) having a baZor; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) or having a long baZor: (M, Ḳ:) or a woman uncircumcised: (Mgh:) pl. buZorN. (T.) yaA Qbona AlbaZoraMCi O son of the uncircumcised woman! is an expression of contumely. (Mgh.)

A man having what is termed a buZaArap in his upper lip; (Ṣ, A, Mgh;) [i. e.] having a Hivorimap somewhat long; (Ṣ in art. Hvrm;) having a long (T, M) and projecting (M) upper lip, with a protuberance in the middle of it. (T, M.)
Accord. to some, † Clamorous; long-tongued. (Mgh.) [See biZoriyrN.]
mubaZ-irN A circumciser: (M, L:) and mubaZ-irapN a woman who circumcises females. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. baEovN signifies The removing of that which restrains one from free action. (TA.) [And hence,]

baEavahu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _a {yaboEavu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. baEavN (Mgh, L, Mṣb, TA) and baEavN, (L, TA,) He sent him; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a messenger; (Mṣb;) and, when said of God, an apostle; (A;) [and when said of a man, a letter, &c.;] as also AbtEvh↓: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or] the former is said of anything that goes, or is sent, by itself; and of anything that will not go, or be sent, by itself, as a letter, and a present, one says, baEava bihi: (Mṣb:) [thus,] baEavahu signifies he sent him, or it, alone, by himself, or by itself; and baEava bihi, he sent him, or it, by, or with, another, or others: (L:) but El-Fárábee says that the former of these two has another signification, which will be found below; and that the latter signifies he sent him, or it. (Mṣb.) Hence, Duriba Ealayohimu AlbaEovu The being sent to the war was appointed them and imposed upon them as an obligation. (Mṣb.) You say, baEavahu likacaA [He sent him for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) [And baEava Uilayohi bikacaA He sent to him such a thing; lit., he sent to him a messenger with such a thing.] And baEava Aljunoda UilaI Algazowi [He sent the army to the war]. (TA.) And baEava Ealayohimu AlbalaMCa [He sent upon them trial, or affliction;] he caused trial, or affliction, to befall them. (TA.)

Also, (A, L, TA,) inf. baEovN (Mgh, L, TA) and baEavN (L) and taboEaAvN [an intensive form], (TA,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action; (A, L, Mgh, TA;) namely, anything; (TA;) [i. e. any person or animal; and particularly,] an animal lying down, or a person sitting. (L, TA.)
You say, baEava Aln-aAqapa He roused, or put in motion or action, the she-camel; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., loosed the cord that bound her shank to her arm, and dismissed her; or he roused her, or made her to rise, she being lying down. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting ʼÁïsheh, fabaEavonaA AlbaEiyra fUicaA AlEiqodu taHotahu [And we made the camel to rise, and to, the necklace was beneath him]. (TA.) You say also, baEavahu EalaI AlOamori, (A,) or AlX-aIoCi, (L,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action, to do the affair, or thing: (A:) or he incited him, urged him, or instigated him, to do the thing. (L.)

Also, accord. to El-Fárábee, (Mṣb,) or baEavahu mino manaAmihi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. baEavN and baEavN, (TA,) He roused him, or awoke him, from his sleep; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AbtEvhu↓. (TA, from a trad.)

baEovN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and baEavN (TA) also signify The quickening, vivifying, or revivifying, of the dead; the raising of the dead to life; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) by God, (TA,) on the day called yawomu AlbaEovi (Ṣ, TA) the day [of resurrection,] when those who are in the graves shall be raised. (A, Mgh.) You say, baEava Qll-ehu Alxaloqa, and AlmawotaI, God quickened, vivified, revivified, or raised to life, mankind, and the dead. (TA.)
baEiva, aor. _a {yaboEavu}, (inf. n. baEavN, TḲ,) He (a man, TA) was sleepless, or wakeful. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See baEivN.]

entry.sense: 5: see 7, in two places.

6. tabaAEavuwA [They roused, excited, incited, urged, or instigated, one another; or put one another in motion or action; to do a thing]. One says, tawaASawoA biAlxayori watabaAEavuwA Ealayohi [Enjoin ye, or charge ye, one another to do good, and rouse ye, or excite ye,, &c., one another to do it]. (A.)

7. AnbEv He became sent; [i. e. he went, being sent;] quasi-pass. of baEavahu, as signifying “he sent him:” (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he rose, and went away: (TA:) he rose to go forth. (Bḍ in ix. 46.) You say, AnbEv likacaA [He went, being sent, or he rose, and went away. or he rose to go forth, for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) And AnbEv fulaAnN liXaOonihi Such a one rose, and went away, to perform his affair. (TA.) And AnbEv fiI Als-ayori He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick or swift, in going, journeying, or pace. (Ṣ.) And AnbEv AlX-ayoCu, i. e. AinodafaEa [The thing became impelled, or propelled; or went quickly, or swiftly, as though impelled or propelled;, &c.]; as also tbE-v↓. (TA.) [Thus] you say, AnbEv AlmaMCu [The water poured out, or forth, as though impelled or propelled]. (TA in art. fjr;, &c.) And [hence,] tbE-v↓ min-iIa AlX-iEoru, i. e. AnbEv [The poetry issued quickly from me], as though it flowed (kaOan-ahu saAla): so in the Ṣ and Ḳ: but in some of the copies of the Ṣ, in the place of saAla, we find saAra. (TA.) And AnbEv biXar-K [He broke forth with evil, or mischief]. (JK in art. bwq.)

[He became roused, excited, incited, urged, instigated, or put in motion or action.] You say, AnbEvt Aln-aAqapu The she-camel became roused, or put in motion or action, and rose: (L, Mgh, TA:*) quasi-pass. of baEava Aln-aAqapa [q. v.]. (Mgh, TA.) And fulaAnN kasolaAnN laA banobaEivu [Such a one is sluggish, lazy, or indolent: he will not become roused,, &c.]. (A.)
He became roused, or awakened, from his sleep; or he awoke from his sleep. (TA.)
8: see 1, in two places.

And [used as a subst., signifying] A person sent; a messenger: pl. baEovaAnN. (L.) You say also, muHam-adN xayoru maboEuwvK↓ and mubotaEavK↓ [Moḥammad is the best person that has been sent]. (A.) And baEayvuka↓ niEomapF, i. e. maboEuwvuka↓ [He whom Thou (O God) hast sent (namely Moḥammad) as a boon, or benefit, or favour]. (L, from a trad. [The latter word (nEmp) is written in the L without any syll. signs; but the context shows that it is in the accus. case as a specificative.])

A people sent from one place to another; as also baEavN↓: (L, TA:) a people sent in any direction; a word similar to saforN and rakobN. (TA.) baEovu Aln-aAri, occurring in a trad., means The people sent to the fire [of Hell]. (L.)

An army; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because sent; (Mgh;) as also baEavN↓ (Ḳ) and baEiyvN↓: (TA:) pl. of the first buEuwvN; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of the last buEuvN: (TA:) the first, [as also the second,] an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mṣb.) You say, kunotu fiI baEovi fulaAnK I was in the army of such a one, that was sent with him. (Ṣ.) And xaraja fiI AlbuEuwvi He went forth among the forces that were sent to the frontiers. (A.)
See also baEivN.
buEovN: see baEovN.
baEavN: see baEovN, in two places:
and see what next follows.

baEivN (A, L, Ḳ) and baEovN↓ (L, TA) and buEovN↓, (L,) or baEavN↓, (TA,) Sleepless, or wakeful: (Ḳ:) a man incessantly, (A,) or often, (TA,) awaking from his sleep: (A, TA:) a man whose anxieties, or griefs, incessantly render him sleepless, or wakeful, and awake him from his sleep: pl. OaboEAvN. (TA.)

baEovapN [inf. n. of un. of 1; and particularly signifying] An occasion, or occurrence, of raising, rousing, exciting, stirring up, or provoking, of sedition, or the like: pl. baEavaAtN. (TA, from a trad.)
baEiyvN: see baEovN, in three places.
baAEivN [act. part. n. of 1; Sending:, &c.]
[And hence, Occasioning, or causing: an occasion, or a cause; and a motive].
AlbaAEivu one of the names [or epithets] of God; The Quickener of mankind after death, on the day of resurrection. (TA.)

AlbaAEuwvu, (L, Ḳ,) or, accord. to some, AlbaAguwtu, q. v., with the pointed g and the double-pointed t, (TA,) [The Christian festival of Easter;] the AisotisoqaMC of the Christians; (Ḳ;) or [rather] what is to the Christians as the AstsqMC is to the Muslims: a Syriac word. (L.)

maboEavN [a noun of place and of time from 1; A place, and a time, of sending:, &c. Hence, AlmaboEavu is particularly applied to The time of the mission of Moḥammad: and it is also applied to the mission itself]. (A, TA.)
maboEuwvN: see baEovN, in three places.
mubotaEavN: see baEovN.

Q. 1. baEovara, [inf. n. baEovarapN,] He took, drew, or pulled, a thing out, or forth, and uncovered it, laid it open, or exposed it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also baHovara: (Ṣ:) he raised what was in a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and caused it to come forth. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [c. 9], UicaA buEovira maA fiI Qloqubuwri When that which is in the graves is raised, and caused to come forth: (AO, Ṣ:) [see also baHovara:] or the meaning is, when the dust, or earth, in the graves is turned over, and the dead in them are raised: (Zj:) or when what is in the graves, of gold and silver, comes forth; after which the dead are to come forth. (Fr.)
Also He examined; he searched. (Ḳ.)
He searched for, or after, or into, news, or tidings. (TA.)

He scattered, or dispersed, a thing, and turned it over, one part upon another: (Ḳ:) he scattered, or dispersed, his household goods, or his commodities, (Fr, Ṣ,) and turned them over, one upon another; (Fr, Zj, Ṣ;) as also baHovara, (Fr, Ṣ,) and bagovara. (Yaạḳoob.)
He demolished a watering-trough or tank, and turned it upside-down. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. baEajahu, aor. _a {yaboEaju}, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. baEojN, (T, Ṣ,) He slit, ripped, or rent, it, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) namely, a belly, with a knife, (T, Ṣ, A, TA,) and moved about the knife in it, (T,) so that what was in it became displaced and apparent, hanging down; (TA;) as also bE-jhu↓. (Ḳ.)
baEajato baToyahaA lizawojihaA † [She brought forth many children to her husband; i. q. navarato: see baEiyjN]. (Ḳ.)
baEajotu lahu baToniI ‡ I disclosed, or revealed, to him my secret [or my whole mind]. (A.) Esh-Shemmákh uses the phrase baEajotu Uilayohi AlbaTona [meaning the same]. (TA.)
baEaja baToyahu laka signifies [also] ‡ He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual bounds, in giving thee sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel. (Ḳ, TA.)
baEaja OaroDahu ‡ He clave, or furrowed, or trenched, his land. (A.)
baEaja AlOaroDa MbaArFA ‡ He dug many wells in the ground. (A.)
baEaja AlOaroDa wabajaEahaA ‡ He clave the earth, or land, and subdued it: said of ʼOmar, in a trad., alluding to his conquests. (TA.)
baEajato lahu Ald-anoyaA miEaAhaA ‡ The world disclosed to him what it contained, of treasures, and other possessions, and spoil: also said of ʼOmar, in another trad. (TA.)
baEajato hecihi AlOaroDa EacaApN Tay-ibapu AlOaroDi † A tract of good land intervened in the middle of this land [as though cleaving it]. (L.)

baEajahu AlHub-u ‡ Love threw him into mourning, or sorrow; brought grief to him: (Ḳ, TA:) [or occasioned him intense grief: for] you say, baEajahu Hub-u fulaAnK meaning ‡ the love of such a one occasioned him intense grief, and he mourned for him: Az says that laEajahu AlHub-u is more correct than baEajahu: but he afterwards mentions baEajahu AlOamoru as meaning † the affair caused him to mourn, or sorrow. (L, TA.)
2: see 1.
bE-j AlmaTaru AlOaroDa, (Ṣ,) or fiI AlOaroDi, (L, TA,) inf. n. taboEiyjN, † The rain dug up the stones of the earth by its vehemence. (Ṣ, L, TA.)
5. tbE-j Als-aH-Abu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and AnbEj↓, (Ḳ,) biAlmaTari, (TA,) ‡ The clouds clave asunder, with, or by reason of, rain, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) and vehement rain. (TA.)
7. AnbEj It [a belly] became slit, ripped, or rent. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
He had his belly slit, or ripped, or rent, with a knife, so that what was in it became displaced and apparent, hanging down. (TA.)
See also 5.

† It (anything, as, for instance, a valley,) became wide, or ample. (TA.) AinobaEajato dufoEapN mina AlmaTari ‡ [A fall of rain burst forth]. (A.) And AnbEj Als-ayolu ‡ [The torrent burst forth]. (A.)
baEijN: see baEiyjN.
Also † A man who walks weakly, as though his belly were slit, or ripped, or rent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

baEiyjN A belly (Ṣ) slit, ripped, or rent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a knife, (Ṣ,) so that what was in it is displaced and apparent, hanging down; (TA;) as also baEijN↓, thought to be after manner of a rel. n.; (L, TA;) and maboEuwjN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Hence, baToniI lilokiraAmi baEiyjN, an expression used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, meaning ‡ My sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel, is liberally, or freely, given to the generous. (TA. [In a reading given in the Ṣ, bAlkrAm is substituted for llkrAm]) [Or it may mean ‡ My secret is disclosed, or revealed, to the generous: or my whole mind.]

baEiyjN is also applied to a man, and, without p, to a woman, as signifying Having the belly slit, ripped, or rent, with a knife, so that what was in it is displaced and apparent, hanging down: pl., masc. and fem., baEojaI. (TA.)
And [hence,] † A woman who has brought forth many children (baEajato baTonahaA, and navarato, [see 1, and see art. nvr,]) to her husband. (Ḳ.)
baAEijapN † The wide part of a valley; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the place where it becomes wide. (TA.)

Also † Plain, or soft, land, that produces [the plant called] naSiI-: or the extremity of a tract of sand, and of plain, or soft, land, [extending] to what is termed quf- [or high, or high and rugged, ground]: and [the pl.] bawaAYiju signifies places, in sand, which are of little depth [of sand], and which, if naSiI- grow therein, are of least depth, and best. (TA.)
maboEuwjN: see baEiyjN.

hom.sense: 1. baEuda, aor. _u {yaboEudu}, inf. n. buEodN; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and baEida, aor. _a {yaboEadu}, inf. n. baEadN; (L, Ḳ;) and AbEd↓, inf. n. UiboEaAdN, which is also trans.; (Mṣb;) and tbAEd↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AstbEd↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) He, or it, was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof: he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off: he alienated, or estranged, himself: he stood, or kept, aloof: contr. of qaruba: (Ṣ, L:) [but baEuda generally has the first of these significations; and AbEd↓, the others, as also tbAEd↓ and AstbEd↓:] it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that baEida, as well as baEuda, is thus used; but some deny this; and some assert that they may be employed alike, but that baEuda is more chaste than baEida thus used. (TA.) [You say also, of a desert, and a tract of country, and the like, baEuda, meaning It extended far.] And AbEd↓ zayodN Eani Almanozili, meaning tbAEd↓ [i. e. Zeyd went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from the place of alighting or abode]. (IḲt, Mṣb.) And tbAEd↓ min-iI, and AbtEd↓, and tbE-d↓, [He went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from me; he alienated, or estranged, himself from me; he shunned, or avoided, me;] (A;) and tbAEd↓ Ean-iI [and baEuda En-I signify the same]. (Mṣb in art. kXH.) And UicaA OaraAca OaHadukumo AlHaAjapi OaboEada↓, (L, Mṣb,) a trad., (Mṣb,) meaning When one of you desires to accomplish that which is needful, (i. e. to ease nature,) he goes far, or to a great distance. (L.) And OaboEadotu↓ fiI Almacohabi, meaning tabaAEadotu↓, (Mṣb,) I went far, or to a great distance, to the place of ease, i. e., to ease nature. (L.)

[baEuda referring to a saying or the like, and an event, means It was far from being probable or correct; it was improbable, extraordinary, or strange: (see baEiydN, and see also 10:) often occurring in these senses.] And AbEd↓ fiI nawoEihi It reached the utmost point, or degree, in its kind, or species. (IAth.) And AbEd fiI Als-awomi He exceeded the due bounds in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing. (A.)
Oaxacahu maA qaruba wamaA baEuda Recent and old griefs took hold upon him: a saying similar to Oaxacahu maA qaduma wamaA Haduva. (Mgh in art. qdm.)

[baEuda is often used, agreeably with a general rule, in the manner of a verb of praise or dispraise; and in this case is commonly contracted into buEoda, like Husona; as in the phrase, in a verse of Imrael-Keys, buEoda maA mutaOam-alI (in which mA is redundant) Distant, or far distant, was the object of my contemplation! or (as explained in the EM p. 52) how distant,, &c.!]

baEida, aor. _a {yaboEadu}, inf. n. baEadN; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and baEoda, aor. _u {yaboEudu}, inf. n. buEodN; (L, Ḳ;) also signify He, or it, perished: (Ṣ L, Mṣb:) he died: (Ḳ:) it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that both these verbs are used as signifying “he perished,” and both occur in different readings of v. 98 of ch. xi. of the Ḳur: the former is said to be used in this sense by some of the Arabs; and the latter, by others; but some disallow the latter in this sense; and some say that the former is more chaste than the latter thus used: (TA:) or both signify he became far distant from his home or native country; became a stranger, or estranged, therefrom: (L, TA:) or the Arabs say, baEida Alr-ajulu and baEuda in the sense of tbAEd, when not reviling; but when reviling, they say, baEida, only. (Yoo, TA.) You say, laA taboEadN waUino baEudota Ean-aI [Mayest thou not perish though thou be distant from me!] (A.) [And as an imprecation against a man, you say, baEidota, meaning Mayest thou perish! (See the printed edition of the Ḥam, pp. 89 and 90, where baEidotaAIa hlkt is an evident mistake for aEidota OaI halakota.)] And buEodFA lahu May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him! (A,* Ḳ, TA;) i. e. may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! like suHoqFA lahu: the most approved way being to put bEd thus in the accus. case as an inf. n.; but the tribe of Temeem say, buEodN↓ lahu, and suHoqN, like gulaAmN lahu. (TA.)
baEuda is made trans. by means of [the preposition] b: see 4. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in four places.
[You say also, bE-dhu Eani Als-uwoCi He declared him, or pronounced him, to be far removed from evil.]
3. bAEdhu He was, or became, [distant, remote, far off, or aloof, from him; or] in a part, quarter, or tract, different from that in which he (the other) was. (TA in art. jnb.)
See also 4, in seven places.

hom.sense: 4. AbEd, inf. n. UiboEaAdN: see 1, in seven places.
