AbEdhu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and bAEdhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAEadapN and biEaAdN; (Ḳ;) and bE-dhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboEiydN; (Ṣ;) and baEuda↓ bihi; (Mṣb;) He made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof; or to go, remove, retire, or withdraw himself, to a distance, far away, or far off; he placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, or he removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, baAEido↓ nafosaka Eano zayodK [Remove thyself far from; or avoid thou, Zeyd]: and baAEido↓ zayodFA Eanoka [Remove thou Zeyd far from thee]. (TA, voce Uiy-aA.) And baE-adotu↓ bayonahumaA, inf. n. taboEiydN, [I made a wide separation between them two]; as also baAEadotu↓, inf. n. mubaAEadapN. (Mṣb.) And baAEada↓ Qll-ehu maA bayonahumaA [May God make the space between them two far extending! may He make a wide separation between them two!]; as also baE-ada↓. (TA.) And rab-anaA baAEido↓ bayona OasofaArinaA, or baE-ido↓, [O our Lord, make to be far-extending the spaces between our journeys! or, put wide distances between our journeys!] accord. to different readings [in the Ḳur xxxiv. 18]: the former of these is the common reading: Yaạḳoob El-Hadramee read rab-unaA baAEada↓ Alx [Our Lord, He hath made to be far extending, &c.]. (TA.)

OaboEadahu Qll-ehu means May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him! (Ḳ;) i. e., may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! (TA.) [You say also, OaboEada Qll-ehu AlOaxira: see OaxirN.]
See also 10.
maA OaboEadahu mina AlS-awaAbi [How far is it (namely the saying) from what is right, or correct!]. (A.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
6. tbAEd: see 1, in six places.
[It also signifies He became alienated, or estranged, from his family or friends.]

[And tbAEdwA They became distant, or remote, one from another; they went, removed, retired, or withdrew themselves, to a distance, far away, or far off, one from another; they removed themselves far, or kept aloof, one from another.] You say, kaAnuwA mutaqaAribiyna fatabaAEaduwA [They were near, one to another, and they became distant, or remote, one from another]. (A.)
8: see 1.

hom.sense: 10. AstbEdhu He reckoned it, or esteemed it, (namely, a thing, Ḳ, or a saying, A,) baEiyd [i. e. distant, or remote; or if a saying or the like, far from being probable or correct, improbable, extraordinary, or strange]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also AbEdhu↓. (A.)
See also 1, first sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: baEodu an adv. n. of time, signifying After, or afterwards: and allowable also, accord. to some of the grammarians, as an adv. n. of place, signifying after, or behind: (TA:) contr. of qabolu: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) it is a vague adv. n., of which the meaning is not understood without its being prefixed to another noun [expressed or implied]; denoting after-time. (Mṣb.) When it occurs without any complement, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a noun or the like which should be its complement being intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter, (Ṣ,* TA,) it is indecl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) because it resembles a particle, (TA,) and has damm for its termination to show that it is indecl., since it cannot have damm by any rule of desinential syntax because it cannot occur as an agent nor as an inchoative or enunciative. (Ṣ.) Sb, however, mentions [as exceptions to this rule] the phrases mino baEodK [Afterwards] and OafoEalu hecaA baEodFA [I will do this afterwards], as having been used by the Arabs. (Ḳ,* TA.) [The latter of these phrases is common in the present day. Another exception to the rule above-mentioned will be found in what follows.] Accord. to the primary rule, it is used as a prefixed n. governing its complement in the gen. case; (Ṣ;) [i. e., it is used in the manner of a preposition;] and when thus used, it is decl., (Ḳ,) because it does not in this case [always] resemble a particle. (TA.) You say, jaMCa zayodN baEoda EamorKw Zeyd came after ʼAmr. (Mṣb.) And raOayotuhu baEodaka and mino baEodika [I saw him after thee]. (L.) The words of the Ḳur [xxx. 3], Qll-ehi QloOamoru mino qabolu wamino baEodu, meaning To God belonged the command before that the Greeks were overcome and after that they had been overcome, [thus read when the complements of qbl and bEd are intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter,] are also read mino qaboli wamino baEodi, when each complement is intended to be understood as to the meaning and the letter, and also mino qabolK wamino baEodK, meaning To God belongeth the command first and last, [when neither complement is intended to be understood either as to the letter or as to the meaning,] but the first of these readings is the best. (L.) [You say also, baEoda celika and mino baEodi celika After that: and baEoda Oano faEalotu and mino baEodi Oano faEalotu and baEoda maA faEalotu and mino baEodi maA faEalotu After I did, or after my doing, such a thing:, &c.] Also jiYotu baEodayokumaA, meaning baEoda kumaA, I came after you two. (Ḳ.) And hecaA mim-aA layosa baEodahu gaAyapN fiI Aljawodapi, and fiI Alr-adaMCap, This is of the things after, or beyond, which there is not any extreme degree in respect of goodness, and in respect of badness: and, by way of abridgement, layosa baEodahu [with nothing following this]: and hence, app., the saying of Moḥammad, waUino kaAna layosa biAl-aciI laA baEoda lahu, meaning [And though] it be not in the utmost degree in respect of goodness: bEd being thus used as a decl. noun. (Mgh.) [baEodiI and the like are also frequently used as meaning baEoda EahodiI and the like; as in the phrase, qado tagay-arota baEodI Thou hast become altered since I knew thee, or saw thee, or met thee, or was with thee. And similar to this are many phrases in the Ḳur; as, for instance, in ii. 48,] vum-a Qt-axacotumu QlEijola mino baEodihi Then ye took to yourselves the calf as a god, or an object of worship, after him, namely Moses, i. e., after his having gone away. (Bḍ.) Oam-aA baEodu (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) is [an expression denoting transition;] an expression by which an address or a discourse is divided; (Ṣ;) used without any complement to bEd, which in this case signifies the contr. of qabolu: (TA:) you say, Oam-aA baEodu faqado kaAna kacaA, meaning [Now, after these preliminary words, (Abu-l- ʼAbbás in TA voce xiTaAbN,) I proceed to say, that such a thing has happened: or] after my prayer for thee: (Ḳ:) or after praising God: (TA:) the first who used this formula was David; (Ḳ;) or Jacob; (TA;) or Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; (Ḳ;) or Kuss Ibn-Sá'ideh; or Yaarub Ibn-Kahtán. (TA.)

You also use the dim. form, saying buEayodahu↓ [A little after him, or it], when you mean by it to denote a time near to the preceding time. (Mṣb.) You say also, raOayotuhu buEayodaAti↓ bayonK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and baEiydaAtihi↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK buEayodaAtih,]) I saw him a little after a separation: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, after intervals of separation: (Ṣ, L:) or, after a while. (AʼObeyd, A.) And Uin-ahaA lataDoHaku buEayocaAti↓ bayonK Verily she laughs after intervals. (L.) [See also art. byn.] buEayodaAt↓ is used only as an adv. n. of time. (Ṣ, L.)

baEodu also sometimes means Now; yet; as yet. (TA.) [It is used in this sense mostly in negative phrases; as, for instance, in lamo yamuto baEodu He has not died yet. The following is one of the instances of its having this meaning in affirmative phrases: sum-iya AlHawoliI-u mino OawolaAdi Albaqari tabiyEFA liOan-ahu yanobaEu Oum-ahu baEodu The yearling of the offspring of cows is called tbyE because he yet follows his mother: occurring in the Mgh, &c., in art. tbE.]

It occurs also in the sense of maEa; as in the words of the Ḳur [ii. 174 and v. 95], famani QEotadaI baEoda celika, i. e., (as some say, MF,) maEa clk [And whoso transgresseth notwithstanding that; lit., with that]. (Mṣb.)

It has been said that it also means Before, in time; thus bearing two contr. significations: that it has this meaning in two instances; in the Ḳur [lxxix. 30], where it is said, waQloOaroDa baEoda celika daHaAhaA [as though signifying And the earth, before that, He spread it forth]; and [xxi. 105] where it is said, walaqado katabonaA fiI Qlz-abuwri mino baEodi Qlc-ikori [as though meaning And verily we wrote in the Psalms before the Ḳur-án]: (MF, TA:) but Az says that this is a mistake; that God created the earth not spread forth; then created the heaven; and then spread forth the earth: (L, TA:) and Alckr in the latter of these instances means the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (Bḍ:) or Alzbwr means the revealed Scriptures; (Bḍ, Jel;) and Alckr, the Preserved Tablet, (Bḍ,) [i. e.] the Original of the Scriptures, which is with God. (Jel.)

[buEodN as an inf. n. used in the manner of a subst. signifies] Distance, or remoteness; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;*) and so baEadN↓, (L, Ḳ,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, (TA, [see baEoda,]) [and buEodapN↓, for] you say, bayonanaA buEodapN, meaning [Between us two is a distance] of land or country, or of relationship. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Remoteness from probability or correctness; improbability, or strangeness: see baEuda. Hence the phrase, hecaA mina AlbuEodi bimakaAnK This is improbable, or extraordinary, or strange: often occurring in the TA, &c.]

Also i. q. buEodN↓: (L, Ḳ:) this latter (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buEodN, (L, Ḳ,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, as, for instance, in the Ḳur xi. 98, (TA, [see baEida,]) signifying Perdition; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) or death. (Ḳ.)

Judgment and prudence; as also buEodapN↓: so in the phrase, Uin-ahu lacuw buEodK, and buEodapK, Verily he is possessed of judgment and prudence: (Ḳ:) or penetrating, or effective, judgment; depth, or profundity; far-reaching judgment. (TA.) [See also OaboEadu.] cuw AlbuEodapi↓ also signifies A man who goes to a great length, or far, in hostility. (L.)
A cursing; execration; malediction; as also biEaAdN↓. (Ḳ.) You say, buEodN lahu, as well as buEodFA lahu: see 1, last sentence but one. (TA.)

hom.sense: baEadN: see buEodN, in two places:
and baEiydN, in five places.

entry.sense: buEodN: see OaboEadu, in two places.
buEodapN: see buEodN, in three places.
buEaAdN: see baEiydN:
and see also baAEidN.
biEaAdN: see buEodN.

baEiydN Distant; remote; far; far off; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;*) as also buEaAdN↓, and baAEidN↓: (L, Ḳ:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, L) buEodaAnN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and (of the first also, L, TA) buEudN (L, Ḳ) and biEaAdN (TA) and (of the first and second, L) buEadaMCu (L, Ḳ) and of the third, baEadN↓, [but this (which is also used as a sing. epithet, as will be shown in what follows,) is properly a quasi-pl. n.,] like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (Ṣ.) As signifying Distant with respect to place, it is correctly used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; (L, and TA in this art. and in art. qrb, in which latter see the authorities;) but not necessarily; like its contr. qariybN: (L:) you say, hiIa baEiydN minoka [She is distant from thee; or it is] as though you said, makaAnuhaA baEiydN: (L:)
also maA Oanota min-aA bibaEiydK [Thou art not distant from us ], and maA Oanotumo min-aA bibaEiydK [Ye are not distant from us]: and in like manner, maA Oanota min-aA bibaEadK↓, and maA Oanotumu min-aA bibaEadK↓. (Ṣ, TA.) [But it receives, sometimes, the fem. form when used in this sense; for] jalasotu baEiydFA minoka and baEiydapN minoka are phrases mentioned as signifying I sat distant, or remote in place, or at a distance, or aloof, from thee; makaAnFA [and naAHiyapF or the like] being understood. (L.) You say also, manozilN baEadN↓ A distant, or remote, place of alighting or abode. (Ḳ.) And tanaH-a gayora baEiydK (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gayora baAEidK↓ and gayora baEadK↓ (Ḳ) [Retire thou not far;] meaning be thou near: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or] the second and third of these phrases mean retire thou not in an abject, or a mean, or contemptible, or despicable, state. (Ṣ, A.) And AinoTaliqo yaA fulaAnu gayora baAEidK↓ [Depart thou, O such a one, not far;] meaning mayest thou not go away! (L.) [And raOayotuhu mino baEiydK I saw him, or it, from afar: and jaMCa mino baEiydK He came from afar: and the like. And baEiydN as applied to a desert and the like, meaning Far extending.] And buEodN baAEidN↓ A far distance. (Ḳ.) [And niy-apN baEiydapN A distant, far-reaching, or far-aiming, intention, purpose, or design. See also niy-apN.] And fulaAnN baEiydu Alhim-api [Such a one is far-aiming, or faraspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]. (A.) And hiIa baEiydapu AlEahodi [She was known, or seen, or met, a long time ago]: in this case, the fem. form, with p {baEiydapN}, must be used. (L.) And qawolN baEiydN [A saying far from being probable or correct; improbable; far-fetched; extraordinary, or strange]. (A.) And OamorN baEiydN An extraordinary thing or affair or case, of which the like does not happen or occur. (L.)

Also Distant with respect to kindred or relationship: in which sense, the word receives the fem. form, [as well as the dual form, and pl. forms, like its contr. qariybN,] by universal consent. (TA.) [Its pl.] buEadaMCu signifies Strangers, that are not relations. (IAth.) You say also, fulaAnN mino buEodaAni AlOamiyri [meaning Such a one is of the distant dependents, or subjects, of the governor, or prince]. (Ṣ.) And UicaA lamo takuno mino qurobaAni AlOamiyri fakuno mino buEodaAnihi [If thou be not of the particular companions, or familiars, of the governor, or prince, then be of his distant dependents, or subjects]; i. e., be distant from him, that his evil may not affect thee. (AZ, A.)
raOayotuhu baEiydaAti bayonK: see baEodN in the latter half of the paragraph.
See also baAEidN.
buEayod and buEayodaAt: see baEodu in four places.
baAEidu: see baEiydN in four places.
Also Perishing: (Ṣ, L: [in the Ḳ it is implied that it signifies dying; and so baEiydN↓ and buEaAdN↓:]) or far distant from his home, or native country; in a state of estrangement therefrom. (L.)

OaboEadu More, and most, distant or remote; further, and furthest: by poetic licence written OaboEad-u: (L:) [pl. OabaAEidu; as in the saying,] fulaAnN yasotajir-u AlHadiyva mino OabaAEidi OaToraAfihi [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A.)

More, and most, extreme, excessive, egregious, or extraordinary, in its kind. (IAth.) [Hence, perhaps,] Uin-ahu lagayoru OaboEada [in the CK OaboEadK] and buEadK↓ Verily there is no good in him: (Ḳ:) or, no depth in him in anything: (IAạr:) [or, he is not extraordinary in his kind: see also buEodN:] said in dispraising one. (TA.) And maA Einodahu OaboEadu and buEadN↓ [He has not what is extraordinary in its kind: or] he possesses not excellence, or power, or riches: or he possesses not anything profitable: (L, Ḳ:) said only in dispraising one: (AZ:) or it may mean he possesses not anything which one would go far to seek; or, anything of value: or what he possesses, of things or qualities that are desirable, is more extraordinary than what others possess. (MF.)

Remote from good: [which is the meaning generally intended in the present day when it is used absolutely as an epithet applied to a man; but meaning also remote from him or those in whose presence this epithet is used, both as to place and as to moral condition:] and, from continence: (L:) and stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; syn. HaAYinN: (so in a copy of the Ṣ and in the L and TA:) or treacherous, or unfaithful; syn. xaAYinN (So in two copies of the Ṣ and in a copy of the A.) It is used as an allusion to the name of a person whom one would mention with dispraise; as when one says, halaka AlOaboEadu [May such a one, the remote from good,, &c., perish!]: with respect to a woman, one says, halakati AlbuEodaI. (En-Naḍr, Az.) One says also, kab-a Qll-ehu AlOaboEada lifiyhi, meaning [May God cast down prostrate such a one, the remote from good,, &c., upon his mouth! or,] cast him down upon his face! (Ṣ.) [It is a rule observed in decent society, by the Arabs, to avoid, as much as possible, the mention of opprobrious epithets, lest any person present should imagine an epithet of this kind to be slily applied to himself: therefore, when any malediction or vituperation is uttered, it is usual to allude to the object by the term AlOaboEad, or AlbaEiyd, as meaning the remote from good, &c., and also the remote from the person or persons present. See also AlOaxiru, which is used in a similar manner.]

A more distant, or most distant, or very distant, relation; (Lth;) contr. of Oaqorabu: (Mṣb:) pl. OabaAEidu (Lth, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaboEaduwna; (Lth;) contr. of OaqaAribu (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oaqorabuwna. (Lth.)
miboEadN A man who makes far journeys. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. baEara, aor. _a {yaboEaru}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baEorN (Ṣ, Mṣb,) said of an animal having the kind of foot called xuf-, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [i. e.,] of a camel, and also of a sheep and goat, (Ṣ,) and of a cloven-hoofed animal (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the wild kind of bull or cow, but not of the domestic kind, and of the gazelle-kind, beside the other two cloven-hoofed kinds mentioned before, and of the hare or rabbit, (TA,) He voided dung. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
baEarahu He threw at him a piece of baEor. (A.)

baEarato, said of a widow, She threw the piece of baEor; i. q. ramato biAlbaEorap↓; meaning she ended the number of days during which she had to wait after the death of her husband before she could marry again. (A.) [It seems to have been customary for the widow to collect a number of pieces of baEor, as many as the days she had to wait before she could marry again, and to throw away one each day: so that the saying means She threw the last piece of bEr.]
baEira, aor. _a {yaboEaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baEarN, (TA,) He (a camel) became a baEiyr. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

hom.sense: 3. baAEarato HaAlibahaA, [inf. n., app., biEaArN, q. v.,] said of a ewe or she-goat, (Ḳ,) and of a she-camel, (TA,) She befouled her milker with her dung. (TA voce biEaArN.)
baAEarato UilaI HaAlibihaA She (a ewe or goat, and a camel,) hastened to her milker. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AbEr He cleansed an intestine, or a gut, of its baEor; as also bE-r↓, inf. n. taboEiyrN. (Ḳ.)

baEorN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and baEarN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) [coll. gen. ns. signifying Camels', and sheeps', and goats', and similar, dung;] dung (Mṣb, Ḳ) of animals having the kind of foot called xuf-, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) [i. e.,] of the camel, and also of the sheep and goat, (Ṣ,) and of cloven-hoofed animals (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the wild kind of bull and cow, but not of the domestic kind, and of the gazelle-kind, beside the two other cloven-hoofed kinds, and of the hare or rabbit: (TA:) n. un. with p {baEorapN}: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) and pl. OaboEaArN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) One says, huwa Oahowanu EalaI-a mino baEorapK yuromaI bihaA kalobN [He is a lighter thing to me than a piece of bEr that is thrown at a dog]. (A.) And it is said in a prov., Oanota kaSaAHibi AlbaEorapi [Thou art like the owner of the piece of bEr, or Oanota fiI mivoli SaAHibi AlbaEorapi Thou art in a condition like that of the owner of the piece of bEr; (meaning the person for whom it was intended;) applied to him who reveals a thing relating to himself; (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 85;)] originating from the fact that a man had a suspicion respecting some one among his people; so he collected them to search out from them the truth of the case, and took a piece of bEr, and said, “I am about to throw this my piece of bEr at the person whom I suspect;” whereupon one of them withdrew himself quickly, and said, “Throw it not at me;” and confessed. (TA.) See also baEarato, above.
baEarN: see baEorN.

biEaArN, a subst., [or inf. n. of 3,] The befouling of her milker with her dung, by a ewe or she-goat, (Ḳ,) or a camel: (TA:) it is reckoned a fault, because the animal that does so sometimes casts her dung into the milking-vessel. (TA.)

baEiyrN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) sometimes pronounced baEiyrN, (Ḳ,) which latter is of the dial. of BenooTemeem, but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) A camel, male or female; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as applied to a camel, like UinosaAnN applied to a human being; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) whereas jamalN is applied only to a male camel, and naAqapN to a she-camel;
bakorN and bakorapN are respectively terms like fatnFI and fataApN; and qaluwSN is like the term jaAriyapN; so say, among others, ISk and Az and IJ; and it is added in the Mutahffidh, that the terms jml and nAqp are applied only when the animal has entered the seventh year: (Mṣb:) but bEyr is more commonly applied to the male camel; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and only to one that has entered its fifth year; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or that has entered its ninth year: (Ḳ:) the pl. is OaboEirapN [a pl. of pauc.] and buEoraAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and biEoraAnN (Ḳ) and buEurN (TA) and ( pl. of OaboEirapN TA) OabaAEiru (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OabaAEiyru (Ḳ.) If one say, OaEoTuwniI baEiyrFA [Give ye to me a bEyr], the persons so addressed, accord. to EshSháfi'ee, are not to give a she-camel: (Mṣb:) but the following phrases are transmitted from the Arabs: SaraEatoniI baEiyriI My she-camel threw me down prostrate: (Ṣ, A:) and Halabotu baEiyriI I milked my camel: (A, Mṣb:) and Xaribotu mino labani baEiyriI I drank of the milk of my camel: (Ṣ:) and kilaA heciyoni AlbiEorayoni naAqapN Each of these two camels is a she-camel. (A.) layolapu AlbaEiyri [The night of the camel], mentioned in a trad. of Jábir, means the night in which the Prophet purchased of him his camel. (TA.)
Also An ass: (IKh, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur xii. 72; but this signification is of rare occurrence: (IKh:) and anything that carries: (IKh, Ḳ:) so in the Hebrew language [בְעִיר (see Gen. xlv. 17)]. (TA.)

baAEirN A widow throwing the piece of baEor; meaning ending the number of days during which she has had to wait after the death of her husband previously to her being allowed to marry again. (A.) [See 1.]

maboEarN and miboEarN↓ [and maboEarapN↓ (occurring in the Ḳ in art. xwr)] The place [or passage (as is shown in the Lexicons in many places)] of the baEor; [i. e. the rectum; the intestine, or gut, containing the baEor;] of any quadruped: (Ḳ:) pl. mabaAEiru. (TA.) It is said in a prov., Uin-a hecaA Ald-aAEira maA zaAla yanoHaru AlOabaAEira wayanovilu AlmabaAEira [Verily this bad man has not ceased to slaughter camels and to cleanse the intestines containing the dung]. (A, TA.)
miboEarN: see maboEarN
maboEarapN: see maboEarN
miboEaArN A ewe or she-goat, (Ḳ,) or a she-camel, (TA,) that befouls with her dung (tubaAEiru) her milker. (Ḳ, TA.) [See biEaArN.]

1. baEaDahu AlbaEuwDu, [aor. _a {yaboEaDu},] inf. n. baEoDN, The baEuwD [or gnats, or musquitoes,] bit him; and annoyed, or molested, him. (TA.) And buEiDuwA They were bitten by the baEuwD: (A:) or were annoyed, or molested, thereby. (Ḳ.) baEaDahu is not used in relation to anything but baEuwD. (TA.) A poet says, praising a man who passed the night within a kil-ap [or thin curtain used for protection from gnats, or musquitoes], which is also called Oabuw divaArK,
laniEoma Albayotu bayotu OabiI divaArK
UicaA maA xaAfa baEoDu Alqawomi baEoDaA
[Excellent indeed is the tent, the tent of Aboo-Dithár, when some of the people fear biting, and annoyance, or molestation, from gnats, or musquitoes]: by bEDA meaning EaD-FA. (TA.)

2. bEDhu, inf. n. taboEiyDN, He divided it into parts, or portions, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) distinct, or separate, one from another. (Mṣb) You say, OaxacuwA maAlahu fabaE-aDuwhu They took his property and divided it into parts, or portions. (A, TA.) And EaD-aI AlX-aApa wabaE-aDahaA [He limbed, or dismembered, the sheep, or goat, and divided it into parts, or portions]. (A, TA.) [Hence,] mino in certain cases, and bi in the like cases, as in the saying Xaribotu bimaMCi kacaA [“I drank of,” i. e. “some of, such water”], are said to be lilt-aboEiyDi [For the purpose of dividing into parts, or portions]. (Mṣb.)
4. AbEDwA They had baEuwD [or gnats, or musquitoes], (Ḳ,) or abundance thereof, (A,) in their land. (A, Ḳ.)
5. tbE-D It was, or became, divided into parts, or portions. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

baEoDN Some, or somewhat or some one, (lit. a thing,) of things, or of a thing: Th says that it signifies thus accord. to all the grammarians; (Mṣb, TA;) except Hishám, as will be seen hereafter: (TA:) or a part, or portion, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Mṣb,) or of anything; (A, Ḳ;) whether little or much: (TA:) accord. to both these explanations, it may denote the greater part; as eight of ten: (Mṣb:) [thus it signifies some one or more; and it relates to persons and to other things:] pl. OaboEaADN; (Ṣ, IJ, Ḳ;) but ISd doubts whether IJ had an authority for this. (TA.) You say, baEoDu AlX-ar-i Oahowanu mino baEoDK [Some kinds of evil are easier to be borne than some]. (A.) And jaAriyapN Hus-aAnapN yuXobihu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA [A very beautiful girl, parts of whom resemble other parts]. (A.) [And Daraba baEoDuhumo baEoDFA Some of them beat some; i. e. they beat one another.] And labivonaA yawomFA Oawo baEoDa yawomK [We have tarried a day or part of a day]. (Ḳur xviii. 18.) And one says to a man of a company of men, “Who did this?” and he answers, OaHadunaA or baEoDunaA [Some one of us]; meaning himself. (A.) The article Al should not be prefixed to it, (Ḳ,* TA,) because it is originally a prefixed n., and as such determinate either literally or virtually, so that it does not admit another cause of being determinate; (TA;) contr. to what is said by IDrst (Ḳ, TA) and Ez-Zejjájee; for they said AlbaEoDu and Alkul-u; which, properly, as ISd says, is not allowable; and it is said in the O that IDrst, in this matter, was at variance with all the people of his age: (TA:) AḤát says that the Arabs did not say Alkul-u nor AlbaEoDu, but that people used these expressions, even Sb and Akh in their two books, by reason of their little knowledge in this way: (Ḳ,* TA:) a remark, says MF, which is extr., and needs no comment: (TA:) [for who surpassed Sb and Akh in knowledge respecting matters of this kind?] AḤát also relates his having told Aṣ that he had seen in the book of [that celebrated and chaste author] Ibn-El-Mukaffa', AlEilomu AlkaviyrN walekin-a Oaxoca AlbaEoDi xayorN mino taroki Alkul-i [Science is large; but the acquiring of part is better than the neglecting of the whole]; and that Aṣ disapproved of it most strongly, saying that the article Al is not prefixed to baEoDN and kul-N because they are determinate without it: (TA:) Az, however, says that the grammarians allow its being prefixed to these two words, (Mṣb, TA,) though Aṣ disallows it, (TA,) because they are meant to be understood as prefixed ns.; (Mṣb;) or because the article is meant to be a substitute for the noun to which they should be prefixed; or, in the case of baEoDN, because this word is equivalent to juzoCN, which receives the article Al. (MF.) It is related of AO, that he assigned also to baEoDN the contr. meaning of All; or the whole: adducing as a proof thereof the words of the Ḳur [xl. 29], yuSibokumo baEoDu Ql-aciI yaEidukumo as meaning All of that with which he threateneth you will befall you: and the saying of Lebeed.
Oawo yaEotaliqo baEoDa Aln-ufuwsi HimaAmuhaA
[as meaning Or their death shall cling to all living creatures: or, accord. to another relation, Aw yarotabiTo, which means the same as Aw yEtlq]: thus also AHeyth explains the above-cited verse of the Ḳur; and thus Hishám explains the saying of Lebeed, erroneously asserting that bED is here a pl.: (TA:) but with respect to the former instance, the Prophet had threatened them with two things, the punishment of the present world and that of the world to come; so he says, “This punishment will befall you in the present world;” which is part (bED) of the two threats; without denying the punishment of the world to come: or, as Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says, he mentions the part to indicate the necessary consequence of the whole: and as to the saying of Lebeed, by bED Alnfws he means himself. (TA [app. from ISd].)

OaroDN baEiDapN A land abounding with baEuwD [or gnats, or musquitoes]; (Ḳ;) as also maboEaDapN↓, like as you say mabaq-apN. (TA.) And layolapN baEiDapN A night in which are many baEuwD; as also maboEuwDapN↓ (A, Ḳ.)

baEuwDN [Gnats, or musquitoes;] i. q. baq-a [which signifies both gnats, or musquitoes, (called in Egypt naAmuws,) and also bugs]: n. un. with p {baEuwDapN}: (Ṣ:) or pl. of baEuwDapN, (Ḳ,) which signifies i. q. baq-apN. (A, Ḳ.) A poet speaks of the humming of the bEwD of the water. (TA.) The author of the Ḳ says, in the B, that the word is taken from baEoDN, because of the smallness of the body of the bEwDp in comparison with other living things. (TA.) You say, kal-afaniI mux-a AlbaEuwDi ‡ He imposed upon me a difficult thing: (A:) or an impossible thing. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
maboEaDapN: see baEiDapN
layolapN maboEuwDapN: see baEiDapN

hom.sense: 1. baEaqa, (TA,) [aor. _a {yaboEaqu},] inf. n. buEaAqN, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) said of a man, and a camel, &c., (TA,) He uttered a vehement sound, or cry. (Lth,* Ḳ,* TA.)
Also, inf. n. as above, said of a vehement rain, descending in large drops, It clave, or furrowed, the ground, and made it to flow. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And, inf. n. baEoqN, He stabbed, or stuck, a camel in the naHor, or throat, or uppermost part of the breast, (Ḳ, TA,) making the blood to flow; (TA;) and (TA) so bE-q↓. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, TA, all of which, except the last, mention only the latter verb in this sense.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baEoqN, (TA,) He dug a well. (Z, Ḳ.)

baEoqN also signifies The act of slitting, ripping, or rending; like baEojN: (TA:) and taboEiyqN↓ the same; (Ṣ;) or the doing so much. (Ḳ.) You say, baE-aqotu↓ ziq-a Alxamori, inf. n. taboEiyqN, I slit, or ripped, or rent, the wine-skin. (Ṣ.)
baEaqapu Eano kacaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baEoqN, (TA,) He removed it, took it off, or stripped it off, from over, or before, such a thing, which it covered, or concealed. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.
5: see 7, in two places.
7. AnbEq It came upon one suddenly, unexpectedly, without his knowledge. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

AnbEq Almuzonu ‡ [The clouds, or white clouds, or clouds containing water,] clave asunder, with, or by reason of, rain, or violent rain; syn. AinobaEaja biAlmaTari; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) or opened vehemently with rain; (Z, TA;) and tbE-q↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ.)
AnbEq fulaAnN biAljuwdi waAlkarami ‡ [Such a one was profuse in bounty and generosity]. (TA.)
AnbEq fiI AlkalaAmi (Ṣ, Ḳ) † He was profuse in speech; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also tbE-q↓ (Ḳ) and AbtEq↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
8: see 7.
baEaAqN: see what next follows, in two places.
buEaAqN † Clouds (saHaAbN) pouring forth [rain] with vehemence. (Ṣ.)

Also, and baEaAqN↓ and biEaAqN↓ and baAEiqN↓, ‡ Rain coming suddenly, or unexpectedly, with vehemence, in large drops. (Ḳ, TA.) jam-u AlbuEaAqi, in a trad. respecting prayer for rain, means † Copious, abundant, extensive rain. (TA.)
And ↓all these four words, † A torrent vehemently driving; (Ḳ, TA;) that carries away everything. (AḤn, TA.)
biEaAqN: see buEaAqN, in two places.
baAEiqN: see buEaAqN, in two places.
OaroDN maboEuwqapN Land upon which what is termed buEaAq [i. e. either the rain or torrent so termed] has fallen, or descended. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baEala, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaboEalu}, (Ḳ,) or _u [contr. to rule]; (Mṣb;) or the pret. is baEula; (so in the Ḥam p. 337;) inf. n. buEuwlapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and baEaAlapN also (Ḥam ubi suprà) [and app. baEolN, for it is said in the Ḥam p. 359 that the primary signification of AlbaEolu is Aln-ikaAHu]; He (a man, Ṣ) became a husband; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AstbEl↓: (Ḳ:) he married, or took a wife. (Mṣb.) And in like manner, baEalato, inf. n. buEuwlapN, She became a wife: (TA:) [and it seems to be indicated in the Ḥam p. 359 that AbtElt↓ and tbE-lt↓ signify the same:] and bAElt↓ she took to herself a husband. (Ḳ.)

baEala Ealayohi [as though originally signifying He became a baEol, or lord, over him:] he was incompliant, or unyielding, to him; he resisted him, or withstood him. (Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., famano baEala Ealayokumo Oamorakumo faQqotuluwhu And whoso resisteth and disobeyeth your command, slay ye him. (TA.)

baEila, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) biOamorihi, aor. _a {yaboEalu}, (Ḳ,) † He became confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by his affair, or case, and feared, and was disgusted, (Ḳ,) and remained fixed in his place like as do the palm-trees termed baEol, (TA,) not knowing what to do. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. bAElt: see 1.

bAEl Alqawomu qawomFA The people intermarried with a people. (Ḳ.) You say also, banuw fulaAnK laA yubaAEaluwna The sons of such a one, none is married to them, nor are they married [to any but persons of their own tribe]. (Ḥam p. 337.)

[The inf. n.] biEaAlN signifies also The playing, or toying, together, of a man with his wife; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so mubaAEalapN [also an inf. n. of the same verb], (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tabaAEulN↓ [inf. n. of 6]. (Ḳ.) You say, bAEl QmoraOatahu He played, or toyed, with his wife. (Mṣb.) And tubaAEilu zawojahaA She plays, or toys, with her husband. (Ṣ.) And bayonahumaA mubaAEalapF Between them two is playing, or toying. (TA.) And humaA yatabaAEalaAni↓ They two play, or toy, together, each with the other. (TA.)
And metonymically, (TA,) biEaAlN signifies also ‡ I. q. jimaAEN; (Az, Ḳ, TA;) and so mubaAEalapN. (TḲ.) You say, baAEalahaA, meaning ‡ He lay with her. (TḲ.)
And bAEl fulaAnN fulaAnFA ‡ Such a one sat with such a one: (Ḳ, TA:) the idea of playing, or toying, being imagined to be implied. (TA.)
5. tbE-lt: see 1.

Also She was obedient to her husband; (Ḳ;) [so too AbtElt↓, as will be seen from what follows;] and so tbE-lt zawojahaA: (TA:) or she adorned herself for her husband. (Ḳ.) You say AimoraOapN HasanapN AlAibotiEaAli↓ A woman who is good in obedience to her husband. (TA.)
6: see 3, in two places.
8: see 1:
and see also 5, in two places.
10. AstbEl: see 1.
Also, said of palm-trees (naxol), They became what are termed baEol, q. v., (Ṣ, TA,) and great. (TA.)
And, said of a place, It became what is termed baEol: (Ḳ:) or it became elevated. (TA.)
baEolN A husband: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. buEuwlapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buEuwlN and biEaAlN. (Ḳ.) And A wife; as also baEolapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like zawojN and zawojapN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.*)
A lord, a master, an owner, or a possessor, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ḳ,) such as a house, and a beast, (TA,) or a she-camel: (Ṣ:) a head, chief, ruler, or person of authority. (El-Khaṭṭábee, TA.)

[And hence,] A certain idol, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of gold, (TA,) belonging to the people of Ilyás, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who is said to be the same as Idrees, the grandfather, or an ancestor, of Noah, or to have been a grandson of Aaron, (Bḍ in vi. 85,) or the son of the brother of Aaron: (Jel ibid.:) it is mentioned in the Ḳur xxxvii. 123: accord. to one copy of the Ḳ, it belonged to the people of Jonas; and so in the Kitáb el-Mujarrad of Kr: accord. to Mujáhid, it means a deity that is not God: (TA:) or a certain king: (IAạr, Ḳ:) but [SM says,] the correct explanation is the first: (TA:) or a certain idol belonging to the people of Bekk, in Syria; i. e., of the town now called Baala-Bekk: so in the Ḳur: (Bḍ, Jel:*) or it means in the dial. of El-Yemen a lord; and so in the Ḳur. (Bḍ.)
Also One whom it is a necessary duty to obey; as a father, and a mother, and the like. (TA.)
And A family, or household, whose maintenance is incumbent on a man. (TA.)
And it may be a contraction of baEilN, as meaning Lacking strength, or power, or ability; unable to find the right way to accomplish his affair. (TA.)
Also ‡ A weight, or burden. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, OaSobaHa fulaAnN baEolFA EalaI Oaholihi ‡ Such a one became a weight, or burden, upon his family; because of his ascendency over them. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

† Elevated land, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) upon which comes neither running water nor torrent, (Ṣ,) or that is not rained upon more than once in the year: (Ḳ:) or ‡ land elevated above other land; as being likened to the man who is thus termed. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

† Any palm-trees, and other trees, and seed-produce, not watered: or such as are watered by the rain: (Ḳ:) or ‡ palm-trees (naxol) that imbibe with their roots, and so need not to be watered: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) metaphorically so applied: (Mgh:) AA says that it is syn. with EicoIN, meaning what is watered by the rain: but Aṣ says that this latter word has the meaning just given, whereas bEl signifies what imbibes with its roots, without irrigation or rain: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or palm-trees growing in land whereof the supply of water is near [to the surface], so that it suffices without their having irrigation or rain: (TA:) or large, so as to imbibe with the roots: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ‡ a male palm-tree; (Ḳ, TA;) likened to the man who is thus termed: (TA:) and Az says that it is used as meaning † [dates such as are termed] qasob. (TA.)
And † The tax, or impost, that is given for the watering of palm-trees. (Ḳ.)
baEilN part. n. of baEila, Confounded, or perplexed,, &c. (Ḳ.) And Lacking strength, or power, or ability; unable to find the right way to accomplish his affair. (TA.)
With p, applied as an epithet to a woman, (Ṣ,) and meaning One who does not dress, or wear clothes, well, (Ḳ, TA,) nor well adjust her personal state or condition. (TA.)

1. bagatahu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _a {yabogatu}, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bagotN and bagotapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bagatN (MF) and bagatapN (Ḳ) and bagat-apN, with teshdeed to the t, of the same measure as jarab-apN,
accord. to AA's reading of the Ḳur in a passage which will be found below, without a parallel among inf. ns., (Z,) [and said by some to have an intensive signification,] He, or it, came upon him, or happened to him, suddenly, unexpectedly, without his being aware of it, or without any previous cause; surprised him; took him by surprise, or unawares; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also bAgthu↓, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. mubaAgatapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bigaAtN. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur vi. 31, accord. to the reading mentioned above, UicaA jaMCatohumu Qls-aAEapu bagat-apF [When the hour of the resurrection shall come upon them suddenly, unexpectedly,, &c.]. (Z.) And you say, jaMCahu bagotapF He, or it, came to him suddenly,, &c. (A, Mṣb.) And laqiyahu bagotapF He met, or found, him, or it, suddenly,, &c. (Ṣ.) And lasotu Mmanu bagataAti AlEaduw-i I am not secure from, or free from fear of, the enemy's comings [upon me] unawares. (Ṣ.)
3: see 1.

AlbaAguwtu The festival, (A,) or a certain festival, (IAth, Ḳ,) of the Christians; (A, IAth, Ḳ;) [namely, Easter;] thus called accord. to some; but accord. to others, AlbAEwv [q. v.], with the unpointed E and the three-pointed v. (IAth.)
maboguwtN i. q. mabohuwtN [Confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course]: so in the saying, laA raOoIa limaboguwtK [There is no judgment to one who is confounded,, &c.]. (A.)

1. bagiva, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabogavu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bugovapN, (Mṣb,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is bagavN, (TA,) He (a bird) was, or became, of a colour resembling that of ashes: (Mṣb:) or he (a sheep or goat) was of the mixed colours of those to which the epithet bagovaMCu is applied. (Ḳ, TA.) [See Oabogavu, and bugovapN, and bagavN.]
bagavN Dust-colour. (A.) [But see bugovapN. Accord. to the TA, the former is the inf. n. of 1, q. v.]

bugovapN Whiteness inclining to xuDorap [which here app. means a dark, or ashy, dust-colour]: (T:) [or, in a bird, a colour resembling that of ashes: (see 1:)] or the colour of sheep or goats to which the epithet bagovaMCu is applied. (Ḳ, TA.) [See Oabogavu.]
bagovaMCu: see Oabogavu, of which it is the fem.

bagaAvN (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bugaAvN and bigaAvN; (A, Mgh, Ḳ;) only the second of these three mentioned by Sb; (TA;) but the second and third asserted to be correct by Yoo; (AZ, TA;) and the last heard by Az; (TA;) or neither of these two is allowable; (Mṣb;) A bird that does not prey, and such as one does not desire to make an object of prey because it is not eaten: (T, Mṣb:) or small birds that do not prey, such as sparrows and the like; [a coll. gen. n.;] n. un. with p {bagaAvapN}: (Mgh:) or [accord. to Lth,] a certain dust-coloured bird, (T, A, Ḳ,) of the birds of the water, ash-coloured, and long-necked; as also Oabogavu↓; pl. [of the latter] bugovN and OabaAgivu: (T:) [but this appears to be wrong; for AM says, in the T,] Lth makes the bgAv and the Abgv to be one, asserting them to be of aquatic birds; but in my opinion, the former is different from the latter: as to the latter, it is a well-known kind of aquatic bird, so called because it is of the colour termed bugovap, i. e. white inclining to xuDorap [explained above, voce bugovapN]: but as to the bgAv, it is any bird that is not one of prey: and the word is said to be a coll. gen. n., signifying the class of birds that are objects of prey: (TA:) ISk says that the bagaAv is a bird of a colour inclining to that of dust, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) a little less than the raxamap [or vultur percnopterus], (Ṣ,) or less than the rxmp, (Mṣb,) slow in flight: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) but IB says that this is a mistake in two points of view; first, because bgAv is a [coll.] gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, like as is that of HamaAmN; and secondly, because it applies to the class of birds that do not prey; but the Oabogav↓ is a bird of the colour of dust, and this may be a bird of prey, and it may be not a bird of prey: (TA:) AZ says that bgAv signifies the [species of vulture called] raxam; and the n. un. is with p {bagaAvapN} others, the young ones of the rxm and birds of the crowkind: or [birds] like the [hawks called] sawaAdiq [pl. of sawodaqN], not predaceous: in the T, it is said to be [a kind of bird] like the [hawk called] baAXaq, that does not prey upon any other bird: (TA:) or bigaAvN and bugaAvN (ISd, Ḳ) and bagaAvN (Ḳ) signify the worst [or most ignoble] of birds, (ISd, Ḳ, [the latter giving this as a second and distinct signification,]) and such as do not prey: (ISd, TA:) Fr says, bagaAvu AlT-ayori signifies the worst of birds, and such as do not prey; and bugaAvN and bigaAvN are dial. vars.: (Ṣ:) the pl. is bigovaAnN, (Sb, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to those who make bgAv a sing., (Yoo, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) or accord. to those who make the sing. to be with p; (T, TA;) or those who apply bagaAvapN [as a n. un.] to the male and the female make bagaAvN to be pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.]; (Yoo, Ṣ, Mṣb;) as is done in the case of naEaAmapN and naEaAmN: (Yoo, Ṣ:) ISd says that bagaAvapN, with fet-ḥ, is the n. un., applied alike to the male and the female: (TA:) [and Fei says,] it is not allowable to pronounce this with damm or with kesr to the first letter: (Mṣb:) but Yoo asserts both of these forms to be used: (AZ, TA:) and bgAvp is said to signify a weak bird. (TA.) It is said in a prov., Uin-a AlbagaAva biOaroDinaA yasotanosiru (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ *) Verily the bgAv in our land becomes [like] a vulture, or become [like] vultures: (Mṣb:) applied to the low person who becomes of high rank: (A:) meaning ‡ the weak in our land becomes strong: (Mṣb:) or he who makes himself our neighbour becomes mighty, strong, or of high rank, by our means, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) acquiring the might, or strength, of the vulture, after having been low, or mean, in condition. (TA.)

bagiyvN Wheat (HinoTapN and TaEaAmN [both of which signify the same, though the latter, q. v., has a a larger application,]) adulterated by being mixed with barley; (Th, Ḳ;) as also galiyvN and lagiyvN. (Th, TA.)
bugayovaMCu [dim. of bagovaMCu fem. of Oabogavu, q. v.,] The place of the Haqiybap [q. v.] in a camel. (Ḳ.) [So called because of its colour, produced by chafing.]

Oabogavu Of a white colour inclining to xuDorap [which here app. means a dark, or ashy, dustcolour]: (T:) [or of a colour resembling that of ashes: (see 1:)] or dust-coloured: (A:) or of a colour near to that of dust: (Ṣ:) an epithet, like OaHomaru: [fem. bagovaMCu: and] pl. bugovN: and sometimes, when used as a subst., it has for pl. OabaAgivu. (IB, TA.) You say TaAYirN Oabogavu A bird of the colour above described: (T, Ṣ:) whether it be a bird of prey or not: see bagaAvN in two places: (IB, TA:) and SaqorN Oabogavu [a hawk of that colour.]; (ISh, A;) as well as OaHowaI and OaboyaDu; i. e., that wherewith men take game. (ISh, TA.) bagovaMCu applied to sheep or goats, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as in some lexicons, to sheep, (TA,) is like raqoTaMCu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [Black speckled with white; or the reverse;] or in which are blackness and whiteness, with predominance of the latter colour: (TA:) or XaApN bagovaMCu and ganamN bugovN signify a sheep or goat, and sheep or goats, in which are blackness and whiteness. (A.)

Also, [as a subst.,] A certain bird, (Ḳ, TA,) dustcoloured, in truth different from the bagaAv, as shown above: see the latter word: (TA:) pl. bugovN and OabaAgivu. (T, TA.) You say, huwa mino OabaAgivi AlT-ayori [He is of the birds thus called]. (A.)
And AlOabogavu signifies The lion; (TṢ, Ḳ;) because he is of the colour termed bugovapN. (TA.)

And AlbagovaMCu ‡ The medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff, thereof; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the commonalty, or vulgar, and collective body, of the people. (Ṣ.) One says, xaraja falaAnN fiI AlbagovaMCi and AlgavoraMCi ‡ Such a one went forth among the medley,, &c., of the people. (A.) And daxalonaA fiI AlbagovaMCi ‡ We entered among the commonalty, or vulgar, and the collective body, of the people. (Ṣ.)
1. bagaXati Als-amaMCu, aor. _a {yabogaXu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. bagoXN, (Ṣ,) The sky rained a rain such as is termed bagoXapN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
bugiXatu AlOaroDu The land was watered by a rain such as is termed bagoXapN, (Ṣ,) or bagoXN. (TA.)
bagoXN: see what next follows.

bagoXapN A weak shower of rain; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) above what is called TaX-ap: (Ṣ:) or weak rain, small in its drops; as also bagoXN↓ [originally an inf. n.]: or both signify a cloud that pours forth its rain in one shower: Aṣ says that the lightest and weakest of rain is that called Tal-; then, the racaAc; then, the bagoX: the dim. of the last is bugayoXN. (TA.)
maTarN baAgiXN Weak rain. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OaroDN maboguwXapN Land watered by a rain such as is termed bagoXapN, (Ṣ,) or bagoXN. (TA.)

hom.sense: baguDa jad-uhu ‡ His fortune, or good fortune, fell; syn. Eavara. (A.) And baguDa jad-uka, (L, Ḳ, TA,) or bagaDa, (as in one copy of the Ḳ,) or bagiDa, (as in the CK,) ‡ May thy fortune, or good fortune, fall: syn. taEasa, (Ḳ, TA,) and Eavara: (TA:) a phrase ascribed by IB to the people of El-Yemen. (TA.)
See also 4, in three places.

entry.sense: 2. bg-Dhu Qll-ehu UilaI Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ, TA,) or liln-aAsi, (Mṣb,) [but this I think doubtful, from what is said in explanation of the verb of wonder, (see 4,)] inf. n. tabogiyDN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) God rendered him hateful, odious, or an object of hatred, to men; (Ṣ, Mṣb;*) tabogiyDN being the contr. of taHobiybN: (Ḳ:) or very hateful or odious. (TA.) You say also, Hub-iba UilaI-a zayodN wabug-iDa UilaI-a EamorNw [Zeyd was rendered an object of love to me, and ʼAmr was rendered an object of hatred, or of much hatred, to me]. (A, TA.)

3. baAgaDotuhu, inf. n. mubaAgaDapN, I rendered him [hatred, or] vehement hatred, reciprocally. (A,* TA.) You say also, bayonahumaA mubaAgaDapN [Between them two is reciprocal hatred, or vehement hatred]. (A.)

hom.sense: 4. AbgDhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UibogaADN, (Mṣb,) He hated him. (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ.) It is said that bagaDahu↓ is not allowable: (Mṣb:) or yaboguDuniI is a bad form; (AḤát, Ḳ;) used by the lower class; and sanctioned by Th only; for he explains qaAliyna, as occurring in the Ḳur [xxvi. 168], by baAgiDiyna, which shows that he held bagaDa to be a dial. var.; for otherwise he would have said mubogiDiyna: (AḤát:) but the epithet baguwDN affords a strong evidence in favour of the opinion of Th here mentioned; for faEuwlN is mostly from faAEilN, not from mufoEilN. (TA.)

maA OabogaDahu UilaI-a, (Ṣ,) or liI, (Ḳ,) is [said to be] anomalous; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because the verb of wonder is not regularly formed from a verb of the measure OafoEala; but this is not anomalous; for it is from bagaDa fulaAnN UilaI-a [“such a one was, or became, hateful, or odious, to me:” mA AbgDh AlI- signifying How hateful, or odious, is he to me! but mA AbgDh liI, How he hates me! for] the lexicologists and grammarians relate that maA OabogaDaniI lahu is said when thou hatest him; and mA AbgDnI Uilayohi, when he hates thee: (IB:) ISd says, on the authority of Sb, that mA AbgDnI lh means that thou art an object of hatred (mubogaDN [so in the TA, but this is evidently a mistake for mubogiDN, a hater,]) to him; and mA AbgDh AlI-, that he is an object of hatred with thee, or in thine estimation. (TA.)

OanoEama Qll-ehu bika EayonFA waOabogaDa biEaduw-ika EayonFA, (so in the A, and the latter verb thus in the JK and in the L,) or the former verb is naEima, (L, Ḳ,) and the latter bagaDa↓, (Ḳ, TA,) like naSara, (TA,) or bagiDa↓, (CK,) is a form of imprecation (TA) ‡ [app. meaning May God make thine eye to be refreshed by the sight of him whom thou lovest, and make the eye of thine enemy to be pained by the sight of him whom he hateth: or may God make an eye to be refreshed by the sight of thee, and make an eye to be affected with hatred by the sight of thine enemy].

entry.sense: 5. tbg-D He manifested, or showed, hatred; or he became, or made himself, an object of hatred; contr. of taHab-aba. (Ḳ.) You say, taHab-aba liI fulaAnN watabag-aDa liI Oaxuwhu [Such a one manifested love to me, or made himself an object of love to me, and his brother manifested hatred to me, or made himself an object of hatred to me]. (A, TA.)

6. tbAgD Alqawomu The company of men hated one another: (Mṣb:) tabaAguDN is the contr. of taHaAbubN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, maA raOayotu OaXad-a tabaAguDFA minohumaA [I have not seen any more vehement in mutual hatred than they two]. (A, TA.)
bugoDN Hatred; contr. of Hub-u: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) a subst. from OabogaDahu. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: bigoDapN Vehement hatred; as also bagoDaMCu↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bagaADapN↓ [but see 1]. (TA.)
See also bagiyDN.

entry.sense: bagoDaMCu: see what next precedes.
baguwDN: see what next follows.
bagiyDN Hateful; odious; and object of hatred: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) hated; as also baguwDN↓ (TA) and mubogaDN↓: (Mṣb,* TA:) pl. of the first, bugaDaMCu. (A, TA.)
Some say that it has also the contr. signification of Hating; i. q. mubogiDN↓: (TA:) and Skr explains bigoDapN↓ as signifying people hating thee. (L, TA.*)
bagaADapN: see bigoDapN.
mubogaDN: see bagiyDN.
mubogiDN: see bagiyDN.
mabogaDapN [A cause of hatred: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. bagula, aor. _u {yabogulu}, inf. n. buguwlapN, said of a man, i. q. tabal-ada [i. e. † He affected stupidity, dulness, or want of intelligence; or he became submissive, and humble;, &c.]. (TA.) [See also 2.]
bagalahumo: see 2.
2. tabogiylN, the inf. n., signifies † The being big, thick, or rude, and hard, strong, or sturdy, in body; or said of the body: and hence, accord. to some, is derived bagolN↓. (TA.)
bg-l, inf. n. as above, ‡ He was impotent and weak, or languid, and fatigued, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) in going, or pace. (TA.)

bg-lt AlUibilu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ The camels went a pace between that termed hamojalap and that termed Eanaq: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) and hence bagolN↓ is derived accord. to IDrd: (TA:) or they went in a certain manner, with wide step: (JK:) [see also 5:] or the inf. n. signifies the going in a gentle manner: and one says, OaEoyaA fabag-ala, i. e. [he was fatigued, so] he went an easy, but a quick, pace; syn. hamolaja. (TA.)

bag-alahumo, (inf. n. as above, TA,) ‡ He made their children to be base-born, or ignoble, (Ḳ, TA,) by marrying among them; (IDrd, TA;) as also bagalahumo↓, aor. _a {yabogalu}: (Ḳ:) from bagolN; because the bgl [or mule] is unable to equal the heat, or course, of the horse. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tbg-l He (a camel) became like the bagol [or mule] in the width of his step. (TA.) [See also 2.]

bagolN The mule; i. e. the animal generated between the he-ass and the mare [or sometimes between the horse and the she-ass]; (TA;) also called bag-aAlN↓; so in a verse of Jereer: (Ṣ, Ṣgh:) pl. OabogalN [a pl. of pauc.] (JK) and OabogaAlN, [also] a pl. of pauc., (Mṣb,) and bigaAlN, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of mult.; (Mṣb;) and quasi-pl. n. maboguwlaMCu↓, (Ḳ,) meaning a number of mules (bigaAl) together: (JK,* Ṣ:) the female is termed bagolapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) pl. bagalaAtN and bigaAlN. (Mṣb.) See 2, in two places. You say TariyqN fiyhi OabowaAlu AlbigaAli [A road in which is the urine of mules]; meaning † a difficult road. (TA.) And fulaAnapu OaEoqaru mino bagolapK [Such a woman is more barren than a she-mule]. (TA.) And Albagolu nagolN wahuwa lahu OaholN [The mule is a bastard, and he is a relation to him]; meaning † he is a bastard. (TA.) And as the mule suggests the idea of evil disposition, or perverseness, and roughness, you say, in describing him who is low, or ignoble, huwa bagolN nagolN † [he is a mule, a bastard]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) The people of Egypt say, AiXotaraI fulaAnN bagolapF HasonaMCa, meaning ‡ [Such a one bought a beautiful] female slave: and fiI bayoti baniI fulaAnK bigaAlN [‡ In the house of the sons of such a one are slaves, or female slaves]: and AiXotarayotu mino bigaAli Alyamano walekino bigaAliI Alv-amano [‡ I bought of the slaves, or female slaves, of El-Yemen, but for a high price]. (TA.)

hom.sense: bag-aAlN [n. un. of bag-aAlapN↓, which is a coll. gen. n., like Ham-aArapN and jam-aAlapN, but explained by Freytag as meaning “he who possesses many mules;”] An owner, or attendant, (Sb, Ṣ,) of mules, (Sb, TA,) or of the mule. (Ṣ.)
See also bagolN, with which it is syn.

entry.sense: bag-aAlapN: see what next precedes.
huwa mina Alv-awori Oabogalu wamina AlHimaAri Oavoqalu † [He is more mulish than the bull, and more heavy, or sluggish, than the ass]. (TA.)
maboguwlaMCu: see bagolN.

1. bagamato, aor. _i {yabogimu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _a {yabogamu} and _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bugaAmN (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and buguwmN; (JK, Ḳ;) and tbg-mt↓; (Ḳ;) She (a gazelle) uttered a cry: (Ṣ:) or uttered her softest, or gentlest, cry (JK, Ḳ) to her young one: (Ḳ:) and sometimes it is said of a [wild] cow: (TA:) so too bagama said of a male gazelle: and the verb is also used transitively, said of a female gazelle uttering this cry to her young one. (JK.) Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ↓both verbs, (Ḳ,) She (a camel) uttered a cry without clearness: (Ṣ:) or uttered a broken, or an interrupted, not a prolonged, yearning cry, to, or for, her young one: (Ḳ:) or uttered a weak cry, below that [grumbling cry] which is termed rugaMC. (Ḥam p. 233.) [See an ex. in a verse of Dhu-rRummeh cited voce Uil-aA.]
And bagama and tbg-m↓ said of the vayotal and Uiy-al and waEil, [all of which words are said to signify the mountain goat,] He uttered a cry. (Ḳ.)

bagamahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bagama lahu, (TA,) † He spoke to him obscurely, not expressing clearly to him the meaning of his speech to him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) taken from the bugaAm of the she-camel; because it is a cry not uttered clearly. (TA.)

3. bAgmhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAgamapN, (Ṣ,) ‡ He talked with him with a soft, or gentle, voice: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or AlmubaAgamapN is like AlmunaAgamapu, and means the speaking [with another] faintly; taken from the bugaAm [see 1] of the gazelle and the she-camel: (Ḥam p. 233:) or the holding amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with another, with a soft, or gentle, voice. (TA.)
5: see 1, in three places.

6. tabaAgamato [They (gazelles) uttered cries, or their softest or gentlest cries, one to another.] One says, mararotu birawoDapK tatabaAgamu fiyhaA AlZ-ibaMCu [I passed by a meadow in which the gazelles were uttering cries,, &c., one to another]: and bigizolaAnK yatabaAgamona [by gazelles uttering cries,, &c., one to another]. (TA.)

bugomapN A thing like the qilaAdap, [a necklace,] with which women ornament themselves. (TA.) [But this is apparently post-classical, from the Turkish buwgomaqo. In the present day, it is applied to A necklace of pearls.]
bugaAmN The crying, or cry, of the female gazelle, and of the she-camel, as explained above: see 1. (Ṣ.)
baguwmN A female gazelle uttering, or that utters, the cry termed bugaAm. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† A woman having a soft, or gentle, voice. (JK, TA.)
maboguwmN A young gazelle, and a young camel, to which the cry termed bugaAm is addressed by its mother. (JK.)
One says, also, bugaAmN maboguwmN [A cry, &c. uttered]; like as one says, qawolN maquwlN. (TA.)
1. bagaA AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. bagowN, He looked at the thing [to see] how it was; (Ḳ;) as also bagaI, (Ḳ in art. bgI,) inf. n. bagoIN. (TA in that art.)

1. bagaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _i {yabogiIu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bugaMCN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, &c.,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is bagoIN, (Mṣb,) [but, if this be correct, the former is generally used for the latter,] and bugFI, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) but the first is better known, and is the chaste form, and some say, bigFI, (TA,) and bugoyapN and bigoyapN, (Ḳ,) accord. to Th, but others hold these two to be simple substs., and some mention also bagoyapN, with fet-ḥ, (TA,) and bugaAyapN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) He sought; sought for, or after; sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find, and take, or get; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) a stray-beast, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) or any other thing, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA,) good or evil; (Lḥ, TA;) as also AbtgI↓ and tbg-I↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and AstbgI↓: (Ḳ:) or AbtgI↓ signifies he sought,, &c., diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and bagaI signifies also he loved, or affected, a thing: (MF, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the seeking to exceed the just bounds in respect of that which one aims at, or endeavours after, whether one actually exceed or do not; and sometimes it is considered in relation to quantity; and sometimes, in relation to quality. (TA.) You say, bagaAhu biXar-K [He sought him with an evil purpose; or sought to do him evil]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Eqb.)

And bagaAhu He sought,, &c., a thing for him; like bagaI lahu. (Lḥ, Mgh,* Ḳ.*) You say, bagaAhu AlX-aIoCa He sought,, &c., the thing for him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AbgAhu↓ AlX-aIoCa: (Ḳ:) thus you say, AiboginiI kacaA or OaboginiI↓ kcA and Aiboga liI kcA Seek thou for me such a thing; (TA;) and OaboginiI↓ DaAl-atiI Seek thou for me my stray-beast: (Mgh:) or AbgAhu↓ AlX-aIoCa signifies He aided, or assisted, him to seek the thing: (Ks, Ḳ:) or OaboginiI↓ kacaA signifies Seek thou for me such a thing; and also Aid thou me to seek such a thing. (JK.) It is said in the Ḳur [ix. 47], yaboguwnakumu Alfitonapa They seek, or desire, for you discord, or dissension; or they seeking,, &c.: and in the same [iii. 94], taboguwnahaA EiwajFA Ye seek, or desire, for it, namely, the way [of God], crookedness; or ye seeking,, &c.: the first objective complement of the verb being in the accus. case because of the suppression of the preposition l. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] bagaAniI daMCF It procured to me disease; it caused disease to befall me. (Ḥam p. 794.) And Uin-ahu lacuw bugaAyapK Verily he is one who makes much gain: (JK, Ḳ:) but in the M, cuw bugaAyapK lilokasobi, meaning a seeker of gain. (TA.) And maAbugiIa lahu Good was not appointed to betide him. (TA.)

bagaI EalaI Oaxiyhi, inf. n. bagoIN, He envied his brother; he wished that a blessing, or cause of happiness, or an excellence, might become transferred from his brother to himself: so says Lḥ, who holds this to be the primary signification of the verb. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlbagoIu EiqaAlu Aln-aSori [Envy is the shackle of aid from God against an enemy or a wrongdoer]. (TA.)

Hence, (Lḥ, TA,) bagoIN signifies The acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (Lḥ, Ṣ, TA;) because the envier so acts towards the envied; his endeavour being to cause, by guile, the blessing of God upon him to depart from him: (Lḥ, TA:) or the seeking, or endeavouring, to act corruptly, wrongly, or unjustly: (Az, TA:) or the exceeding the due bounds, or just limits, in any way: (Ṣ:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of two kinds: one of these is approved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of equity to exercise beneficence, and beyond the bounds of obligatory duties to do what is not obligatory: the other is disapproved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of that which is true, or right, to do that which is false, or wrong, or to do acts of a doubtful nature: but in most instances it is that which is disapprove. (TA.) You say, bagaI Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bgI EalaI Aln-aAsi, (Az, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yabogiIu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bagoIN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He exalted himself against him, or above him; overpowered, or oppressed, him; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards him; and deviated from the right way: (Ḳ:) and he acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards men, or the people, (Az, Mṣb,) and sought to annoy them, or hurt them. (Az, TA.) Lḥ mentions, on the authority of Ks, the saying, maA liI walilobagi baEoDikumo EalaI baEoDK [What have I to do with wrongful conduct, the wrongful conduct of one of you towards another?], for walilobagoIi; ISd thinks, because of the difficulty found in pronouncing the kesreh after the I. (TA.) bagaI also signifies He occupied himself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct: [accord. to Fei,] from the same verb [in a sense to be mentioned below,] said of a wound. (Mṣb.) Also, aor. _i {yabogiIu}, (TA,) inf. n. bagoIN, (Az, TA,) He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently: (Az, TA:) because he who does so passes beyond the bounds of his proper station to a station that does not belong to him. (TA.)

And [hence,] bagaI fiI miXyatihi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) He [app. a horse, and perhaps a man also,] was proud, or self-conceited, and quick, in his gait: (Ḳ:) or bagoIN in a horse, (Ṣ, TA,) or in the running of a horse, (JK, TA,) is the being proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness. (JK, Ṣ, TA.)

And bagati Als-amaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) The sky rained vehemently: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or exceeded, in rain, the limit of what was wanted. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And bagaI AlwaAdiI The valley flowed with water reaching to a place to which it had not reached before. (Ṣ, TA.)

bagato, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a woman, (Th, IKh, Ṣ, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or of a female slave, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) but it is not restricted to the latter, (TA,) aor. _i {yabogiIu}, (JK, Mṣb,) inf. n. bigaMCN, (IKh, JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or bagoIN, (ISd, Ḳ,) [but the former, only, is commonly known,] She committed fornication, or adultery; she prostituted herself; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because she who does so transgresses her proper bounds; (TA;) as also baAgato↓, (IKh, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bigaMCN (IKh, Ḳ) and mubaAgaApN, (Ḳ,) said of a female slave: (Mṣb:) or mbAgAp signifies the committing fornication, or adultery, with another. (KL.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxiv. 33], walaA tukorihuw fatayaAtikumo EalaI AlbigaMCi [And compel not ye your young women to prostitute themselves]. (Mgh.) And you say, xarajati AlmaroOapu tubaAgiI↓ [The woman went forth for prostituting herself]. (Ṣ.) Accord. to the Jema et-Tefáreek, bigaMCN signifies The knowing of a woman's committing fornication or adultery, or prostituting herself, and approving, or being content: but this, if correct, is an amplification in speech. (Mgh.)

bagaI AljuroHu, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yabogaIu}, inf. n. bagoIN, (JK,) The wound swelled, (Ṣ,) and became in a corrupt state, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and produced thick purulent matter. (JK.)
And baraOa juroHuhu EalaI bagoIK His wound healed having somewhat of corruption in it. (Ṣ.)

bagaI, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yabogiIu}, inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) also signifies He lied; said what was untrue. (Ḳ.) maA nabogiI, in the Ḳur [xii. 65], is said to mean We do not lie: and we do not act wrongfully: or it may mean what do we seek, or desire? (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) He looked at a thing [to see] how it was; (Ḳ;) and so bagaA, inf. n. bagowN: mentioned by Kr. (TA.)
And, (Ḳ,) with the same inf. n., (TA,) He looked, watched, or waited, for a person or thing. (Kr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 3: see 1, latter part, in two places.

Lh mentions the saying, addressed to a pretty woman, Uin-aki lajamiylapN walaA tubaAgiI, as meaning Verily thou art pretty, and mayest thou not be smitten by the [evil] eye: (TA in this art.:) but accord. to some, the verb in this instance belongs to art. bwg or art. byg. (TA in art. bwg.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in five places.
AbgAhu AlX-aIoCa also signifies He made him, or caused him, to seek the thing; to seek for it, or after it; to seek, or desire, or endeavour, to find, and take, or get, it. (Ṣ.)
5: see 1, first sentence.
6. tabaAgawoA They acted wrong fully, injuriously, or tyrannically, one towards another; exalted themselves, one against, or above, another; overpowered, or oppressed, one another. (Ṣ, TA.)

7. AnbgI is said in the Ṣ to be quasi-pass. of bagayotuhu, like as Ainokasara is of kasarotuhu; and Esh-Shiháb says of the aor. that it is quasi-pass. of bagaAhu, aor. yabogiyhi, in the sense of Talabahu: (TA:) [Fei says,] it has been asserted that AnbgI is quasi-pass. of bagaI; but a verb of the measure AnfEl is not used as a quasi-pass. unless it implies effort, and the consequence of an action, as in the case of kasarotuhu, of which the quasi-pass. is Ainokasara; which AnbgI does not: some, however, allow its being thus used: (Mṣb:) accord. to Zj, it is as though it were syn. with AinoTalaba, as quasi-pass. of Talaba, and means It was, or became, suitable, fit, meet, or proper; (Zj, TA;) [or right, and allowable; and good: or very requisite: (see explanations of exs. following:) or it behooved: and] it was, or became, facilitated, or easy; (Er-Rághib, Ḳ;) and practicable, or manageable. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Accord. to some, this verb is not used in the pret. tense, but only in the aor.: it is reckoned among verbs imperfectly inflected: (Mṣb, TA:) but the pret. is mentioned by AZ and Sb and Zj, and by El-Khattábee on the authority of Ks; and was often used by Esh-Sháfiʼee: it is, however, very rare. (TA.) You say, yanobagiI laka Oano tafoEala kacaA [It is suitable to thee, or is fit, meet, or proper,, &c., for thee, or it behooveth thee, that thou shouldst do such a thing]. (Ṣ, TA.) And, accord. to Zj, AinobagaI lifulaAnK Oano yafoEala, as meaning It was, or became, suitable to such a one, or fit, meet, or proper, for him, that he should do, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) And maA yanobagiI laka Oano tafoEala hecaA, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and mA yubotagaI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ to the g, (TA,) and mA QnobagaI, and mA QbotugiIa↓; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) of which four phrases, the first is given by Lḥ as explanatory of the third and fourth, and means, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, It is not right, proper, fit, or meet, nor allowable, for thee that thou shouldst do this, or to do this; and it is not good for thee, &c.; but he adds that only the aor. has been heard from the Arabs in this sense. (TA.) And yanobagiI Oano yakuwna kacaA It is very requisite that it should be so, or that such a thing ought be; [or it ought to be so, or such a thing ought to be; it behooves that it should be so, or such a thing behooves;] it is not well that such a thing should be neglected, or left undone. (Mṣb.) And Ks is related to have heard, from the Arabs, the phrase, maA yanobagiI Oano yakuwna kacaA, meaning It is not right that it should be so, or that such a thing should be: or it is not good, &c. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxvi. 69], wamaA Eal-amonaAhu AlX-iEora wamaA yanobagiI lahu, i. e. [And we have not taught him poetry, or versification], nor is it right, proper, fit, or meet, for him: (Bḍ:) or nor is it easy to him, (Bḍ, Jel, Er-Rághib,) or practicable to him. (Bḍ, Er-Rághib.)
8: see 1, first sentence, in two places:
and see also 7, in two places.
10: see 1, first sentence.
You say also, AstbgI Alqawoma fabagawohu and bagawoA lahu [He asked the people, or company of men, to seek a thing for him, and they sought it for him]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

bagoIN [originally an inf. n. (see 1)] Much of rain; or much rain: in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, AlbTr is erroneously put for AlmTr: (TA:) [and in some, AlbagiI-u for AlbagoIu: in a MṢ. copy, I find AlbagiI-u Alkaviyru mina AlmaTari: and in the CK, AlbagiI-u Alkaviyoru mn Aln-aZari:] or bagoIu Als-amaMCi signifies the main portion, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) or the vehemence, and the main portion, (Lḥ, JK, TA,) of the rain of the sky. (Aṣ, Lḥ, JK, Ṣ, TA.) Hence the saying, dafaEonaA bagoIa Als-amaMCi xalofanaA (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) or Ean-aA (Lḥ, TA) [lit. We drove away the main portion, or the vehemence, and the main portion, of the rain of the sky behind us or from us; meaning it was driven away behind us or from us, or it departed; as is shown in art. dfE].
bugoyapN: see what next follows.

bigoyapN and bugoyapN↓ (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bagiy-apN↓ (Ḳ) A thing sought; (JK, Ḳ;) as also bagaAyapN↓ [originally an inf. n. (see 1)]: (JK:) or a thing wanted, needed, or required; an object of want or need; a want, or needful or requisite thing or affair: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) as in the saying, liI fiIbaniI fulaAnK bagoyapN and bugoyapN [I have among the sons of such a one an object of want]: (Ṣ:) or the first signifies a state that one seeks; and the second, a thing itself that one wants: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb:*) and the first, (JK,) or third, (Ḳ,) signifies also a stray beast that is sought: (JK, Ḳ:) the pl. of the second is bugFI. (JK.) Airotad-ato EalaI fulaAnK bigoyatuhu [The thing that he sought was refused to such a one] is said of one who finds not what he seeks. (TA.).
baguw-N: see what next follows.

bagiI-N, accord. to some, of the measure faEiylN; accord. to others, of the measure faEuwlN, originally baguwIN; [if of the former, originally meaning “sought;” and if of the latter, originally meaning “seeking;”] and therefore [in either case] not admitting the affix p: (TA:) A fornicatress, an adulteress, or a prostitute; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also baguw-N↓ [of the measure faEuwlN, and therefore anomalous, like nahuw-N]: (M, Ḳ:) bagiI-N is not applied to a man, (Lḥ, Mṣb,) nor bagiy-apN to a woman: (Lḥ, TA:) pl. bagaAyaA. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) [See an ex. voce mahorN.]

Also A female slave, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) whether she be a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute or not; (TA;) not meant to imply revilement, though originally applied to female slaves because of their prostitution of themselves: (Ṣ:) or a free woman who is a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute: so in the Ḳ: but correctly, or a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute, whether free or a slave: (TA:) and a female singer, though chaste; because of fornication's being originally attributable to such a person: (Mṣb:) pl. as above. (JK, Ṣ, TA.) One says, qaAmato EalaI ruWusihimu AlbagaAyaA [The female slaves stood over their heads]. (Ṣ.)
bagaAyaA also signifies The scouts, or companies of scouts, that precede an army: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) but the sing. of this is bagiy-apN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: bagiy-apN: see bigoyapN.
Also, pl. bagaAyaA: see bagiI-N, last sentence.

entry.sense: bugaAyapN: see bigoyapN.

hom.sense: baAgK Seeking; seeking for, or after; seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find, and take, or get: pl. bugaApN and bugoyaAnN (Ḳ) and bug-aMCN. (TA: [there mentioned as a pl., but not said to be of baAgK, nor explained.]) baAgK wahaAdK, lit. A seeker of [stray] camels and a guide of the way, mentioned in a trad. respecting the Hijreh (as said by A booBekr to a man who asked him “Who are ye?”), alludes to the seeking of religion and the guiding from error. (TA.) One says, far-iquwA lihecihi AlUibili bugoyaAnFA yuDib-uwna lahaA, i. e. [Disperse ye, for these camels, seekers] to scatter themselves in search thereof. (Ṣ.)

Acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, [&c.,] towards others: pl. bugaApN. (Mṣb. [See 1.]) gayora baAgK, in the Ḳur ii. 168, [&c.,] means Not being a revolter from the Muslims, (Jel,) or, against the Imám: (TA:) or it means not desiring to eat for the sake of enjoyment: or not seeking to exceed the limit of his want: (Az, TA:) or not seeking what he should not seek. (Er-Rághib, TA.) fiYapN baAgiyahN A company of men revolting from the just Imám. (Ḳ.) firoqapN baAgiyapN A party occupying itself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct. (Mṣb.)
A camel that does not impregnate, or get with young. (Kr, Ḳ.)
A horse that is proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness: (JK, Ḥam p. 210:) [but] Kh disallows its being thus used. (Ṣ.)
[The pl.] bugoyaAnN also signifies What the sportsman, or hunter, seeks, of game, or objects of the chase. (JK.)

entry.sense: mabogFI [A place where a thing is sought: and hence, a way, or manner, in which a thing is, or should be, sought]: this is meant in the saying, bagayotu AlmaAla mino mabogaAtihi↓ [I sought wealth by the way, or manner, whereby it should be sought]; like as maOotFI is meant in the saying, Oatayotu AlOamora mino maOotaAtihi. (Ṣ.)
mabogaApN: see what next precedes.
AlmubotagiI, (Ḳ,) or, as in the Tekmileh, Almutabag-iI, (TA,) The lion: (Ḳ:) because he is always seeking prey. (TA.)
Almutabag-iI: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. baq-a, (JK, M,) aor. yabiq-u; and baq-a, [first pers. baqiqotu,] aor. yabaq-u [in the TA yabuq-u, which, being anomalous, is probably a mistake,] inf. n. baq-N and baqaqN [which is of the latter verb accord. to analogy] and baqiyqN; (M;) He spoke, or talked, much; was, or became, loquacious; (JK, M, TA;) as also Abq-↓ (JK, Ṣ, M, TA) and baqobaqa↓. (M, TA.) And baq-a kalaAmFA [in which case the aor., accord. to rule, unless the noun be a specificative, is yabuq-u,] and baq-a bikalaAmK [He was, or became, profuse in speech]. (M.) And baq-a EalaI Alqawomi, (Zj, Ḳ,) or baq-a kalaAmahu, (M,) inf. n. baq-N and baqaAqN, (Ḳ,) He spoke, or talked, much against the people, or company of men; (Zj, M,* Ḳ;) as also Abq-↓. (Ḳ.) Hence, (TA,) qado malaOota AlOaroDa baqaAqFA [Thou hast filled the earth, or land, with much discoursing], said, in dispraise, to a voluminous writer. (M, TA.)
baq-ato and Abq-t↓, said of a woman, She had many children: (JK, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or, as Sb says, baq-ato waladFA she brought forth many children. (M, TA.)
baq-ati Als-amaMCu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and Abq-t↓, (M, TA,) The sky rained much, and consecutively, or uninterruptedly: (M, TA:*) or rained vehemently. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

baq-a, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yayaq-u, (M,) or yabiq-u, (TA,) inf. n. baq-N, (M, TA,) He gave largely, or amply: (IF, M, Ḳ,* TA:) in some of the copies of the Ḳ, AlEaZamap is erroneously put for AlEaTiy-ap. (TA.) And baq-a lanaA AlEaTaMCa He made the gift large, or ample, to us. (M.)
baq-a maAlahu He distributed, or dispersed, or scattered, his property; (Ḳ;) as also bq-qhu↓. (JK,* Ḳ.)
baq-a Alxabara, inf. n. baq-N, He spread, and sent forth, the news, or information. (M.)

baq-a AlX-aIoCa, aor. yabuq-u, He put forth, or took forth, what was in the thing. (M, TA.) Hence, (M,) baq-a EiyaAbahu, (M, L, TA,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, EiyaAlahu, (TA,) He spread out (Ḳ, TA) his [receptacles of skin, or leather, termed] EyAb, and put forth, or took forth, what was in them. (TA.)

He clave, slit, ripped, or rent, the thing. (JK.) So in the phrase baq-a AljiraAba [He slit, ripped, or rent, and opened, (see maboquwqN,) the bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
baq-a, (IF, Ḳ,) inf. n. buquwqN, (TA,) said of a plant, [app. from its cleaving the earth,] It came forth. (IF, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
4: see 1, in five places.
Abq- waladu fulaAnK, inf. n. UiboqaAqN, The children of such a one multiplied; became many, or numerous. (TA.)

Oabaq-ati Alganamu fiI Aljadobi, accord. to the Ḳ, (TA,) or Ainobaq-ati↓ Alganamu fiI EaAmi jadobK, (JK, and thus in the O, TA,) The ewes, or she-goats, being lean, or meagre, brought forth [in drought, or scarcity, or in a year of drought or scarcity]. (JK, O, Ḳ, TA.)
Abq- AlwaAdiI The valley put forth its plants, or herbage. (O, L, TA.) In the Ḳ, xaraja baqaAqupu is erroneously put for xaraja nabaAtuhu. (TA.)
Oabaq-ahumo xayorFA, or Xar-FA, He did to him much, or ample, good, or evil. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ.)
7: see 4.

R. Q. 1. baqobaqa Alkuwzu, (Ṣ, M,) biAlmaMCi, (M,) [inf. n. baqobaqapN, q. v. infrà,] The mug made a [guggling or gurgling] sound with the water [on being dipped into it or on one's pouring out from it]. (Ṣ,* M.) And baqobaqati Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled [so as to make a sound of bubbling]. (M.)
See also 1.
baqobaqa EalayonaA AlkalaAma i. q. far-aqahu [lit. He scattered speech (app. meaning he jabbered) at us, or against us: compare baq-a EalaI Alqawomi, or baq-a kalaAmahu, above]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: baq-N: see baqaAqN.
baq-apN A woman having many children: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ:) and mibaq-apN↓ a woman that brings forth many children. (M, TA.)
OavarN baq-N [A trace, mark, track, impression, or the like,] that is plainly apparent, or conspicuous. (JK, TA.)

Also, a pl. n.; (Ṣ, TA;) [or rather a coll. gen. n.;] sing., (Ṣ, TA,) or n. un., (JK, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) baq-apN; (JK, Ṣ, M, &c.;) Gnats, or musquitoes; syn. baEuwDN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) or large baEuwD: (JK, M, Mṣb:) the poet 'Abder-Raḥmán Ibn-El-Hakam, cited by IB, speaks of their singing [or humming]. (TA.) yaA Eayona baq-apK [O eye of a gnat or musquito] denotes smallness of the person of him to whom it is said; or of the eye, as being likened to the eye of the gnat or musquito. (Ḥar p. 619. [See an ex. voce Huzuq-N.])

Also, [in the M is here added “it is said,” but this implies uncertainty where none exists,] A kind of insect, [namely, bugs,] (M, Ḳ,) resembling the louse, (M, TA,) [but larger,] wide, (Ḳ,) red, and stinking, (M, Ḳ,) [and hence termed baq-N munotinN,] found in bed-frames, or couch-frames, and in walls, [and therefore termed baq-u AlxaXabi and baq-u AlHiyTaAni,] (M, TA,) called also banaAtu AlHaSiyri [from being found in mats]; (TA;) when one kills them, he smells [what resembles] the odour of bitter almonds proceeding from them. (M, TA.)
XajarapN Albaq-i [The elmtree]: see darodaArN.

entry.sense: baqaqapN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: baqaAqN A man who speaks, or talks, much; loquacious; talkative; garrulous; a great talker; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) whether incorrectly or correctly; (M;) or such is termed baq-aAqN↓; (so written in a copy of the M;) as also baqaAqapN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but this has a more intensive signification, (Ṣ, TA,) and mibaq-N↓, (M, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and baqobaAqN↓, (JK, Ṣ, M,) or laqolaAqN baqobaAqN↓, (Ḳ,) and laq-N baq-N↓, (Ḳ,) which last occurs in a trad., but accord. to one recital it is laqFI baqFI, in which the former word signifies “cast away,” and the latter is an imitative sequent thereto: (TA:) baqaqapN↓, also, [app. pl. of baAq-N,] is syn. with varovaAruwna [great talkers,, &c.]: (IAạr, TA:) and baqaAqN [thus written without teshdeed] signifies a babbler; nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk; one who speaks confusedly and improperly; or who speaks, or talks, much and badly, or erroneously. (M.) [See also 1, of which it is an inf. n.]
Also, (Ḳ,) n. un. with p {baqaAqapN}, (JK, Ḳ,) A kind of clamorous bird: (JK, Ḳ:) but Ṣgh writes it [baq-aAqN↓,] with teshdeed. (TA.)
Also The worthless, or mean, or vile, articles of the furniture or utensils of a house or tent, or of household-goods. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: baqaAqapN: see baqaAqN.
baq-aAqN: see baqaAqN, in two places.
baqobaqapN a word imitative of The [guggling or gurgling] sound of a mug (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) [when dipped] in water, (JK, Ḳ,) and the like: (Ḳ:) and of a cooking-pot in its boiling. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
baqobaAqN: see baqaAqN, in two places.
Also The mouth. (Ḳ.)
mibaq-N: see baqaAqN.
mibaq-apN [its fem.]: see baq-N.
OaroDN mabaq-apN A land abounding with baq- [i. e. gnats, or musquitoes; or bugs]; (M, TA;) like as you say maboEaDapN. (TA in art. bED.)
jiraAbN maboquwqN [A bag, or receptacle, for travel-ling-provisions, &c.] opened: (JK:) or slit, ripped, or rent, and opened. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
