hom.sense: 1. baqara, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaboquru}, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or _a, (Ḳ,) [but this seems to be a mistake,] inf. n. baqorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He slit; ripped; split; cut, or divided, lengthwise. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) He slit, or ripped open, an animal's belly. (A, Mgh.) One says, AuboqurohaA Eano janiynihaA Rip thou open her [a camel's] belly so as to disclose her fœtus. (Ṣ.) [See baqiyrN.]
He opened, or laid open. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
He widened; made wide, or ample. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He opened, and widened, or made wide, a house, or tent. (TA, from a trad.)
He opened and revealed to a person a story. (TA, from a trad.)

baqara AlOaroDa said of a hudohud [or hoopoe], It looked for the place of water and saw it: (Ḳ:) [or it clave the ground and discovered water:] occurring in a trad. respecting the hdhd of Solomon [mentioned in the Ḳur ch. xxvii.] (T.)
baqara fiI baniI fulaAnK He knew the state, condition, case, or affair, of the sons of such a one, and examined, or inspected, them. (Ḳ.)
baqara Eani AlEuluwmi He inquired, and searched to the utmost, after sciences. (A.)
baqara AlEiloma: see 5.

baqira, aor. _a {yaboqaru}, He (a dog) became confounded, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and stupified, (TA,) with joy, (Ḳ,) at seeing baqar, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., baqar AlwaHoX [wild oxen, or wild bulls or cows]; (TA;) like as one says gazila meaning “he sported,” or “playedbecame diverted,” “at seeing a gazelle,” or “a young gazelle;” as also bayoqara↓: (Ṣ:) or the former, he feared, so that he was astonished, amazed, or stupified, at seeing many baqar: (TA voce baHiza:) and ↓the latter signifies also [simply] he became confounded, or perplexed: (IAạr, TA:) and he doubted respecting a thing. (Ḳ.)

Also, aor. as above, inf. n. baqarN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baqorN; (Ḳ;) but Az says, El-Mundhiree has informed me that AHeyth disallowed baqorN, saying that it is accord. to analogy baqarN, as the verb is intrans.; (TA;) He (a man) became tired, or fatigued, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so that he could hardly see; (Ḳ;) and he became weary, or jaded; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bayoqara↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 2. bq-r Alqawomu maA Hawolahumo The people dug the tract around them, and made wells. (Aṣ.)
5. tbq-r It (a she-camel's belly) became ripped open; as also Abtqr↓ and Anbqr↓. (TA.)
It became open. (Aṣ.)

And i. q. tws-E; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) as also tabayoqara↓. (Ḳ.) So in the phrase tbq-r fiI AlEilomi [He enlarged himself, or took a wide range, in science, or knowledge]; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) and baqara↓ AlEiloma, inf. n. baqorN, signifies the same. (TA.) And so in the phrase tbq-r fiI AlmaAli, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and fI AlOaholi, (TA,) i. e., He enlarged himself, or he became, or made himself, large, or abundant, in wealth, or camels or the like, and in family; as explained by Aṣ. (AʼObeyd.) You say also, tbq-r AlkalaAma, [meaning fiI AlkalaAmi,] i. e., He was diffuse, or profuse, in speech; syn. tafat-aqa bihi. (A.)
7: see 5.
8: see 5.
Q. Q. 1: see 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 2: see 5.

baqarN a gen. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) a word of well-known meaning, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [The bovine genus; the ox, or bull, and cow; and oxen, or bulls, and cows; neat; black cattle;] applied to the domestic and the wild: (TA:) [but the wild have also distinctive appellations, as will be seen below:] n. un. baqarapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [but in the Ḳ it is said that baqarN is pl. of baqarapN,]) which is applied to the male and the female; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the p being added only to restrict it to unity: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the pl. of baqarN is OaboqurN [a pl. of pauc.]; (M,) and OaboqaArN, meaning herds of oxen, or bulls, or cows: (Mṣb and TA in art. Abl:) and the pl. of baqarapN is baqaraAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buqurN and buq-aArN (Ḳ) and bawaAqiru (Aṣ, T, Ḳ) and OuboquwrN↓; (Ḳ;) [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.;] and the following [also] are quasi-pl. ns., namely, bayoquwrN↓, (Ḳ,) which is syn. with baqarN, (Ṣ,) and baqiyrN↓, (Ḳ,) or this signifies a collection, or herd, of baqar, (Ṣ,) and baAqirN↓, (Ḳ,) or this signifies a collection, or herd, of baqar with their pastors, (Lth, Ṣ,) and baAquwrN↓, and baAquwrapN↓, (Ḳ,) or this last is syn. with baqarapN in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen: (Ṣ:) or baAquwrN↓ and yaboquwrN↓ and OuboquwrN↓ are all syn. with baqarN; and so, accord. to Ḳṭr, is baAquwrapN↓. (Mgh.)

baqaru AlwaHoXi [and Albaqaru AlwaHoXiI-u signify The wild ox, or bull, and cow; and wild oxen, or bulls, and cows, collectively: n. un. baqarapu AlwaHoXi and Albaqarapu AlwaHoXiy-apu; masc. and fem.: in Egypt, these appellations are applied to the antilope defassa of modern zoologists: so says Sir Gardner Wilkinson; and to this, I believe, they generally apply in the poems, &c. of the early Arabs: it is a species of bovine antelope: in Barbary, it seems that the animal thus called is another species of bovine antelope, or perhaps a variety of the former; it is said to be what is termed by Pallas antilope bubalis; by others, alcephalus bubalis, or acronotus bubalis; and this is said to come occasionally to the Nile: but the Arabic appellations given above are employed with much laxity: thus we find baqaru AlwaHoXi explained as meaning] a kind of animal of which there are four different species: the first called mihiA [i. e. mahFA, a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is mahaApN]; the second, Ayl [i. e. Uiy-alN]; the third yHmwr [i. e. yaHomuwrN], or yAmwr [i. e. yaOomuwrN]; the fourth, vyvl [or vayotalN], and also wEl [i. e. waEolN]: (Ed-Demeeree, cited by De Sacy, erroneously written by him “Domaïri,” in his Chrest. Ar. sec. ed. ii. 435 et seq.:) or what is called in Persian kwzn [or Gawazono (see also Uiy-alN in art. Awl)]; it has a great horn, with branches; an additional branch growing upon its horn every year; and its horn is solid, thus differing from the horns of other animals, for their horns are hollow: when it hears singing, and the sounds of musical instruments, it listens thereto, and then it takes no care to guard itself from the arrows, by reason of its intense delight therein: when it raises its ear, it hears sounds; and when it relaxes it, it hears not anything. (Ḳzw: also cited by De Sacy, ubi suprà.) The Arabs regard baqar [meaning bqr AlwHX] as ominous of evil, because of the sharpness of their horns. (Ḥam p. 285.)
miloCu masoki Albaqarapi [The quantity that fills the hide of the bull, or cow,] means ‡ a large quantity. (A.)
AlZ-ibaMCa EalaI Albaqari [or AlZ-ibaMCu] and AlkiraAba EalaI Albaqari [or AlkiraAbu, and AlkilaAba or AlkilaAbu,] are provs. of the Arabs. (TA.) [See arts. ZbI and krb and klb.]
Eayonu Albaqari † [The buphthalmum, or ox-eye;] i. q. bahaArN, q. v. (Ṣ in art. bhr.)
Euyuwnu Albaqari ‡ A species of grape, black, large, round, and not very sweet. (Ḳ, TA.) In Palestine, applied to ‡ A species of Uij-aAS [or plum]. (Ḳ, TA.)

baqarN is also applied to ‡ A family, or household; those who dwell with a man, and whose maintenance is incumbent on him. (TA.) You say, jaACa fulaAnN yajur-u baqarahu ‡ Such a one came dragging along his family, or household. (A,* TA.) And EalaI fulaAnK baqarapN mino EiyaAlK wamaAlK ‡ Upon such a one is dependent a troop, or large number, of his family, and of camels or the like; (A,* TA;) and in like manner you say, kariXN mino EiyaAlK. (A.) And fulaAnN fiI baqarK mina Aln-aAsi ‡ Such a one is among a large company of men. (A.)

hom.sense: A she-camel having her belly ripped open so as to disclose her fœtus. (Ṣ.)
A mare's colt or foal that is born in a [membrane such as is called] maAsikapN or salFI: (Ḳ:) so termed because this is ripped open over it. (TA.)

Also, and baqiyrapN↓, A garment of the kind called burod, which is slit [in the middle], and worn (Aṣ, Ḳ) by a woman, who throws it upon her neck, [putting her head through the slit,] (Aṣ,) without sleeves, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) and without a jayobK [or an opening at the bosom]; (Aṣ;) i. q. UitobN [q. v.], which is a kind of shirt without sleeves, worn by women. (Ṣ.)
See also baqarN.

entry.sense: baqiyrapN: see baqiyrN.

hom.sense: baq-aArN A grave-digger; syn. Haf-aArN. (TA.)
A worker in iron; a blacksmith. (Ḳ.)
An owner, or a possessor, [or an attendant,] of baqar [or oxen, or bulls, or cows]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: EaSFA baq-aAriy-apN A strong staff or stick [such, app., as is used for driving oxen or bulls or cows]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: AlbaAqiru The lion: (Ḳ:) because, when he catches his prey, he rips open his belly. (TA.)

baAqirN and baAqrapN↓, [the latter an intensive epithet,] A man who inquires, and searches to the utmost, after sciences. (A.) And baAqiru EilomK One who enlarges himself, or takes a wide range, in science, or knowledge. (Mṣb.)

fitonapN baAqirapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) occurring in a trad., (TA,) † A sedition, discord, dissension, or the like, that severs society; (Ḳ;) that corrupts religion, and separates men: or that is wide-spreading and great: (TA:) it is likened to the disease of the belly; meaning the yellow water or fluid: (Ṣ:) or to pain of the belly; because its exciting cause and its cure are unknown. (TA.)
See also baqarN.

entry.sense: baAqirapN: see baAqirN.
bayoqarapN Abundance of wealth, or of camels or the like, and of commodities, or household goods or utensils and furniture. (Ḳ.)
baAquwrN: see baqarN; in two places.
bayoquwrN: see baqarN; in two places.
baAquwrapN: see baqarN; in two places.
OuboquwrN: see baqarN; each in two places.
maboquwrN: see baqiyrN.

baqosN and baqosiysN↓, (Ḳ,) the latter written, in some copies of the Ḳ, bqbys, (TA,) [The boxtree; Greek πυξος;] a certain kind of tree, resembling the Ms [or myrtle] in leaves and berries: or i. q. XamoXaAd [a Persian word, also applied to the box-tree]: (Ḳ:) it grows in the country of the Greeks; and spoons and doors are made of it, because of its hardness:
and it may be with X [baqoXN, which is explained by Ṣgh and in the Ḳ as a kind of tree called in Persion xuwXo saAIo; and this, also, is a name of the box-tree]: (TA:) it is astringent, having the property of drying up the moisture of the intestines; and its saw-dust, kneaded with honey, strengthens the hair, and makes it abundant, and is good for (or prevents, as in the CK,) the headache, and with the white of the egg is good for what is termed wavoIN, (Ḳ,) i. e., a fracture [of the flesh]. (TA.)
baqosiysN: see baqosN, above.

baqoXN A certain kind of tree, called in Persian xuwXo saAIo, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) which means “good in shade;” [and also is applied to the box-tree;] as has been said before, voce baqosN, which may be the same: IDrd says that baqoXN is a post-classical word. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baqiEa, aor. _a {yaboqaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baqaEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a bird, and a dog,) was black and white; syn. baliqa; (Ḳ;) [or rather] baqaEN in birds and dogs is like balaqN in beasts that are ridden, or horses and the like: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it (a crow, &c.,) was partycoloured or pied. (Mṣb.)
He (a drawer of water, L, Ḳ, from a well, by means of a pulley and rope and bucket, L) had his body sprinkled with the water, so that some parts of it became wetted. (L. Ḳ.)
maA OadoriI Oayona baqaEa I know not whither he went; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as though one said, to what buqoEap of the biqaAE of the earth he went; (Ṣ;) not used except negatively; (TA;) as also baq-aEa↓. (Fr, Ḳ.)
baqaEatohumu Ald-aAhiyapu The calamity, or misfortune, befell them. (TA.)

buqiEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EuniIa, (Ḳ,) He was assailed with bad, or foul, speech, or language: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or with calumny, slander, or false accusation. (Ṣ.) And buqiEa biqabiyHK He was assailed with foul, evil, or abominable, speech, or language. (L.)
2. bq-E Alv-awoba He (a dyer) left spots, or portions, of the garment, or piece of cloth, undyed. (Mgh, TA.)
bq-E vawobahu He (a waterer) sprinkled the water upon his garment, so that spots, or portions, of it became wetted. (Mgh.)
bq-E AlmaTaru fiI mawaADiEa mina AlOaroDi, inf. n. taboqiyEN, The rain fell in places of the land, not universally. (TA.)
maA OadoriI Oayona baq-aEa: see 1.

entry.sense: 7. AnbqE He went away quickly; (Ḳ;) and ran. (TA.)

8. AubotuqiEa lawonuhu, with damm, i. q. AunotuqiEa, and AumotuqiEa; (the former in some copies of the Ḳ; the latter in others; and both in the TA;) i. e. His colour changed, (TA,) by reason of grief, or sorrow. (Ḥar p. 244.) The last of these three verbs is the best. (Ḥar ubi suprà.)

baqoEapN A place in which water remains and stagnates; (Ḳ;) [and which is not a usual place of watering: (see baAqiEapN:) this is what is meant, app., by its being said that] biqaAEN, which is its pl., signifies the contr. of maXaAriEu [or watering-places to which men and beasts are accustomed to come]. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

buqoEapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baqoEapN↓, (AZ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the former is the more common, (Mṣb,) and more chaste, (TA,) A piece, part, portion, or plot, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of land, or ground, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) differing [in any manner,] in colour, (Mgh,) or in appearance, or external state or condition, (Ḳ,) from that which adjoins it, or is next to it: (Mgh, Ḳ:) this is the primary signification: (Mgh:) [a patch of ground:] pl. biqaAEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or this is pl. of baqoEapN, (Mṣb, TA,) and the pl. of buqoEapN is buqaEN. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) You say OaroDN fiyhaA buqaEN mina AljaraAdi [meaning Land in which are bare places occasioned by the locusts]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) And fiI AlOaroDi mino nabotK In the land are small portions of herbage. (AḤn.) And buqoEapN mino kalaO A patch of herbage. (TA in art. bqTF.)

[The former also signifies A spot; or small portion of any surface, distinct from what surrounds it.] And the pl. buqaEN Places in a garment, or piece of cloth, which has been dyed, remaining undyed. (Mgh.) And buqaEu AlmaMCi Places in a garment, or piece of cloth, which has been washed, in which the water remains, undried. (Mgh.)
huwa Hasanu AlbuqoEapi Einoda AlOamiyri ‡ He has a good station with the prince, or commander. (TA.) [See also julobapN.]
OaroDN baqiEapN Land in which are buqaEN mina AljaraAdi [meaning bare place occasioned by the locusts]: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) and land of which the herbage is unconnected [or in patches]. (TA.)

OaSaAbahu xuroCu baqaAEi, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] and decl., (Ḳ,) and imperfectly decl., so that you say also baqaAEK, and baqaAEa, (AZ, TA,) Dust and sweat came upon him, and discolorations produced thereby remained upon his body: (AZ, Ḳ:) by bqAE is [lit.] meant land, or a land: so says AZ: and Ealayohi xuroCu baqaAE is said to mean upon him is sweat which has become white upon his skin, like what are termed lumaEN. (TA.)

baqiyEN A place in which are roots of trees of various kinds: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a wide, or spacious, place: or a place in which are trees: (Mṣb:) or a wide, or spacious, piece of land; but not so called unless containing trees; (TA;) though baqyEu Algaroqadi continued to the name of a burialground of El-Medeeneh after the trees therein had ceased to be. (Mṣb,* TA.)

baAqiEapN A bird (Ḳ, TA) that is cautious, or wary, and cunning, or wily, that looks to the right and left when drinking, (TA,) that does not come to drink to the maXaAriE [or watering-places to which men and beats are accustomed to come], (Ḳ, TA, [but in the CK, for mXArE is put maXArib,]) and the frequented waters, (TA,) from fear of being caught, but only drinks from the baqoEap, i. e., the place in which water remains and stagnates. (Ḳ, TA.)

Hence, as being likened thereto, ‡ Any one that is cautious, or wary, cunning, or wily, and skilful: (TA:) ‡ a man possessing much cunning: (Ḳ, TA:) [accord. to some] so called because he alights and abides in [various] parts (biqaAE) of the earth, and often traverses countries, and possesses much knowledge thereof: to such, therefore, is likened ‡ a man knowing, or skilful, in affairs, who investigates them much, and is experienced therein; the p being added to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) and ‡ sharp, or quick, in intellect; knowing; whom nothing escapes, and who is not to be deceived, beguiled, or circumvented: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. bawaAqiEu. (TA.) You say, maA fulaAnN Uil-aA baAqiEapN mina AlbawaAqiEi ‡ Such a one is none other than a very cunning man of the very cunning. (TA.)
Also † A calamity, or misfortune, (Ṣ, TA,) that befalls a man. (TA.)

OaboqaEu, applied to a guraAb [or bird of the crowkind], In which is blackness and whiteness; (Ṣ, TA;) and so applied to a dog: (Lḥ, TA voce Oaboraqu, q. v.:) or, applied to the former, having whiteness in the breast; and this is the worst [or most ill-omened] of the crow-kind: (TA:) [it is this species, accord. to some, which is called guraAbu Albayoni: (see art. byn:)] or, applied to a grAb, &c., party-coloured, or pied: (Mṣb:) or the whitewinged grAb: (ISh, TA in art. Hcf:) pl., when thus applied, buqoEaAnN, (TA,) or biqoEaAnN, with kesr; the quality of a subst. being predominant in it; but when it is regarded as an epithet, [in which case the fem. is baqoEaMCu,] its pl. is buqoEN. (Mṣb.)
Hence, as being likened to such a bird, ‡ Anything bad, evil, wicked, mischievous, [ill-omened,] or the like. (TA.)
And † Leprous. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

buqoEaAnu AlX-aOomi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) mentioned in a trad., (Ṣ,) † The servants and slaves of Syria; because of their whiteness and redness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or blackness; (Ṣ;) or because of their whiteness and redness and blackness likened to a thing such as is termed OaboqaEu; (TA;) or (Ḳ) because they are of the Greeks and the Negroes: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so called because of the mixture of their colours; their predominant colours being white and yellow: AʼObeyd says that what is meant is whiteness and yellowness, and they are thus called because of their difference of colours and their being begotten of two races: but Ḳṭ says, AlbuqoEaAnu signifies † those in whom is blackness and whiteness; and one who is white without any admixture of blackness is not called AbqE: how then should the Greeks be called bqEAn when they are purely white? and he adds that he thinks the meaning to be, the offspring of Arabs, who are black, [which is not to be understood literally, but rather in the sense of swarthy,] by female slaves of the Greeks, who are white. (TA.)
buqoEN is also applied to Waterers (suqaApN); because their bodies become sprinkled with the water, so that some parts thereof are wetted. (Ḳ.)
raOayotu qawomFA buqoEFA ‡ I saw a people wearing patched garments; said by El-Hajjáj; (Ḳ, TA;) and thus explained by him; i. e., by reason of their evil condition. (TA.)
cawodN buqoEu Alc-uraI A herd of camels having white humps. (TA.)
AlOaboqaEu The mirage; because of its varying, or assuming different hues. (TA.)
OaroDN baqoEaMCu Land containing [or diversified with] small pebbles. (TA.)

sanapN baqoEaMCu ‡ A barren, or an unfruitful, year: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a year in which is fruitfulness and barrenness. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And EaAmN OaboqaEu ‡ A year in which the rain falls in places of the land, not universally. (TA.) And EaAmN OubayoqiEu↓, (Ḳ,) the dim. form being used to denote terribleness, (TA,) ‡ A year of little rain. (Ḳ, TA.)
OubayoqiEu, dim. of OaboqaEu, which see, last sentence.
huwa mubaq-aEu Alr-ijolayoni He has his legs wetted by water in some places, so that their [general] colour is different from the colour of those places. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baqala: see 4, in two places.

[Hence,] said of a boy's face, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboqulu}, inf. n. buquwlN, (Ṣ,) ‡ It put forth its beard, (Ṣ, TA,) or hair; (Ḳ;) as also Abql↓ and bq-l↓; (Ḳ;) or this last is not allowable: (Ṣ:) similar to AixoDar-a said of a boy's mustache. (Mgh.)
And said of a camel's tush, ‡ It cut, or came forth. (ISk, Ṣ, TA.)
† It (a thing, TA) appeared: (Ḳ, TA:) derived from baqolN, q. v. (TA.)
He collected [plants, or herbs, of the kind termed] baqol for his camel. (Fr, Ḳ.)
baqala Albaqola He cut the bql: so in the “Mufradát. “(TA.)
2. bq-l, inf. n. taboqiyilN, He (a pastor) left camels to pasture upon baqol (TA.)
And, [hence, app.,] inf. n. as above, i. q. saAsa (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) You say, bq-l Ald-aAy-apa, i. e. saAsahaA, meaning He tended, or took care of, the beast well. (TḲ.)
See also 1.

4. Abqlt AlOaroDu The land produced [plants, or herbs, of the kind termed] baqol: (Mṣb:) or produced its bql: (Ṣ:) or produced plants, or herbage: (Ḳ:) or became green with plants, or herbage: (Mgh:) and baqalat↓ signifies the same: (IDrd, Ḳ:) both are chaste words. (IDrd, TA.) In like manner one says also of a place, Abql, (JK, Mṣb,) from baqolN. (Mṣb.)

Abql Alr-imovu The [tree, or shrub, called] rmv became green; as also baqala↓: (Ḳ:) or it put forth what resembled young wingless locusts, and the greenness of its leaves became apparent. (Ṣ. [See also HanaTa.]) And Abql AlX-ajaru The trees put forth their baAqil [q. v., app. buds,] in the days of the rabiyE [or spring], before their leaves became apparent: (JK:) or they put forth, in the time of the rbyE in their sides, what resembled the necks of locusts. (TA.)
See also 1.
Abql Alqawomu The people, or company of men, found [plants, or herbs, such as are termed] baqol. (Mṣb.)
See also 8.
Abql wajohahu ‡ He (God) made his (a boy's) face to put forth its hair, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning, its beard. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tbq-l He went forth seeking [plants, or herbs, of the kind called] baqol. (Ḳ.)
See also 8, in three places.

8. Abtql AlHimaAru and tbq-l↓; (Ṣ;) or Abtqlt AlmaAXiyapu, (Ḳ,) or AlUibilu, (JK,) and tbq-lt↓; (JK, Ḳ;) The ass, or the beasts, or camels, pastured upon [plants, or herbs, of the kind called] baqol: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or became fat from pasturing upon bql. (JK.)

baqolN a word of which the meaning is well known; (Ṣ;) [Leguminous, or tender, plants; such as we term herbs; i. e. plants, or vegetables, that may be gathered, with the hand, or depastured down to the ground, and that are only annuals;] plants which are neither shrubs nor trees; (Lth, JK,* Mgh;) such as, when depastured, have no stem remaining; thus differing from trees and shrubs, which have stems remaining [when they have been depastured]: (Lth, Mgh:) or the herbs, or herbage, produced by [the rain, or the season, called] the rabiyE: (Mgh:) or whatever herbs, or plants, grow from seed, (AḤn, Mgh, Ḳ,*) not upon a permanent Oaruwmap [i. e. root-stock, or root]: (AḤn, Ḳ:) and accord. to this definition may be explained the saying that the cucumber is of the things termed buquwlN [pl. of baqolN, meaning sorts, or species, of baqol], not of those termed fawaAkihu: (Mgh:) or the kind of which the root and branch do not last in the winter: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, it is said, (Ṣ, Mgh,) any plants, or herbs, whereby the earth becomes green: (Ṣ, IF, Mgh, Mṣb:) [pl. of pauc. OaboqaAlN: the pl. of mult. has been mentioned above:] the n. un. is with p, i. e. baqolapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the prov., laA tunobitu Albaqolapa Uil-aA AlHaqolapu [Nothing produces the leguminous, or tender, plant, or herb, but the clear and open piece of good land]: (TA:) [i. e., only a good parent produces good offspring: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 516:)] it is said to be applied to the case of a vile saying proceeding from a vile man. (TA in art. Hql.) The saying baAEa Alz-aroEa wahuwa baqolN means [He sold the seedproduce] when it was green, not yet ripe. (Mgh.)

Albaqolapu, also, and Albaqolapu AlHamoqaMCu, (Ṣ,) or baqolapu AlHamoqaMCi, (Ḳ,) or all these, (TA,) signify the same as Alr-ijolapu [i. e. Purslane; called by these names in the present day]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so Albaqolapu All-ay-inpu and Albaqolapu AlmubaArakapu: or this last, i. q. AlhinodabaMCu [i. e. wild and garden succory, or endive]. (Ḳ.)
baqolapu AlOanoSaAri i. q. Alkuronubu [or Alkuronabu, q. v., the name now given to Cabbage: in the CK Alkuronabu]. (Ḳ.)
baqolapu AlxaTaATiyfi [Chelidonium, or celandine; thus called in the present day;] i. q. AlEuruwqu AlS-uforu. (Ḳ.)
baqolapu Almaliki i. q. AlX-aAhotaraju [Fumaria officinalis, or common fumitory]. (Ḳ.)

Albaqolapu AlbaAridapu i. q. All-abolaAbu [now commonly applied to the Dolichos lablab of of Linnæus; but Golius explains the former appellation by hedera, i. e. ivy, though only as on the authority of the Ḳ]. (Ḳ.)

Albaqolapu Alc-ahabiy-apu i. q. AlqiTofu [or AlqaTafu, a name now given to Atriplex, or orache: Golius explains the former appellation by spinachium seu atriplex; and the latter, in its proper art., by atriplex herba, and androsœnum]. (Ḳ.)
Albaqolapu Alyahuwdiy-apu [Sonchus, or sow-thistle; thus called in the present day]. (TA voce xub-aAzN, q. v.)
Albaqolapu AlyamaAniy-apu [Blitum, or blite; and particularly the species called strawberry blite;] a certain herb. (Ḳ.)
AlbaqolapN AlOutorujiy-apu [Citrago, or balmgentle;] a certain herb. (Ḳ.)

baqolapu AlD-ab-i and baqolapu Alr-umaApi and baqolapu Alr-amoli and [in the CK “or”] baqolapu AlbaraAriI and Albaqolapu AlHamoDaMCu, (Ḳ, TA,) or baqolapu AlHaAmiDapu, (CK,) are also Certain herbs. (Ḳ.)
buquwlu AlOarojaAEi A certain plant proved by experience to remove pains from the belly. (Ḳ, TA.)

baladN baqilN and muboqilN↓ [A country, or region, or district, producing plants, or herbs, of the kind termed baqol]. (JK.) And OaroDN baqilapN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in the CK baqolapN, but it is] like fariHapN, (TA,) and baqiylapN↓ and muboqilapN↓, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Land producing baqol: (Mṣb:) or producing plants, or herbage: (Ḳ:) and the first and ↓second of these, (Ḳ,) and baq-aAlpN↓, erroneously written in the copies of the Ḳ baq-aAlapN, without teshdeed, (TA,) and maboqalapN↓ and maboqulapN↓, (Ḳ,) land having, or containing, baqol (Ḳ,* TA) of [the rain, or season, called] the rabiyE: (Ḳ:) or maboqalapN↓ [used alone, as a subst.,] signifies a land having, or containing, baqol; (JK;) or a place of baqol: (Ṣ:) and baAqilN↓ [app. as meaning producing baqol] is applied as an epithet to a place; (JK, Mṣb;) but not muboqilN↓; (JK;) or this last sometimes occurs, thus applied. (IJ, IB.)
buqolapN The [plants, or herbs, termed] baqol of [the rain, or season, called] the rabiyE. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)
OaroDN baqiylapN: see baqilN, in two places.
[buquwliI-N Of, or relating to, the plants, or herbs, termed baqol: from the pl. buquwlN.]

baq-aAlN [properly A green-grocer; i. e.] a seller of taraho [Persian for baqol]: and [by extension of its application] a shop-keeper: (KL:) or a seller of dry fruits: (Ibn-Es-Sem'ánee, TA:) vulgarly, a seller of eatables [of various kinds, and particularly of dried and salted provisions, cheese, &c.; a grocer]; correctly, bad-aAlN. (AHeyth, T in art. bdl, Ḳ.)
OaroDN baq-aAlpN: see baqilN.
baAqlN: see baqilN.

Also, as an epithet applied to the [tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Becoming green: (Ḳ:) or putting forth what resemble young wingless locusts, and showing the greenness of its leaves: they did not say muboqilN↓ [in this sense], in like manner as [it is commonly asserted that] they did not say muwrisN, from Oaworasa, but waAirsN. (Ṣ.)
Also What comes forth, or come forth, in the sides of trees, in the days of the rabiyE [or spring], before their leaves become apparent. (JK.) [See 4.]

dictScrap.title: baAqil-FI / baAqil-aApN / baAqilaMCN / baAqilaMCapN / baAqilFI / baAqilaApN

entry.sense:
baAqil-FI and baAqilaMCN, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former with teshdeed and the latter without teshdeed, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and baAqilFI, (Ḳ,) [every one with tenween when it has not the article Al, for]
the n. un. is with p, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. baAqil-aApN and baAqilaMCapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) [and baAqilaApN] or the sing. and pl. are alike, (El-Aḥmar, Ḳ,) [and if so, the word may be fem., as Ibn-Buzurj, cited in the TA voce hinodabN, asserts baqilaMC to be, and therefore in every case without tenween,] i. q. fuwlN [Beans; or the bean; faba sativa of Jussieu; vicia faba of Linnæus]; (JK, Ḳ;) a name of the dial. of the Sawád [of El-'Irák]; its produce is called Aljirojiru; (TA; [but see jarojiyrN; and see turomusN;]) [or it is applied to the plant and to its produce;] a certain well-known Hab- [or grain]: (Mgh:) the eating of it produces exhalations (Ḳ) of a gross kind, (TA,) and bad dreams, and sadar, (Ḳ,) i. e. vertigo, (TA,) and anxiety, and gross humours; but it is good for the cough, and for rendering the body fruitful (taxoSiyb Albadan); when properly qualified [app. by seasoning or by some admixture] (UicaA OuSoliHa), it preserves the health; and in its green state, together with ginger, it has the utmost effect in strengthening the venereal faculty: (Ḳ:) the pl. is bawaAqilu: and the dim. of bAq-lI is buwayoqilapN↓ and buwayoqiloyapN↓, the latter with the l quiescent because kesreh is disapproved in so long a word; [both forms indicating that bAql-I is held to be fem.;] and that of bAqlMC is buwayoqilaMC [with or without tenween accord. as it is held to be masc. or fem.], or, if one will, he [who holds bAqlMC to be fem.] may say buwayoqlapN↓, suppressing the augmentative meddeh, and adding p to indicate the fem. gender; and that of bAql-Ap is buwayoqilaApN↓. (TA.)

AlbaAqil-aI AlqboTiI-u [app. the same as AlbAq-lI AlmiSoriI-u mentioned in the Ḳ voce turomusN, &c., i. e. The Egyptian bean; an appellation said to be applied by some in the present day to the colocasia; but what it properly denotes is doubtful;] a certain plant, the grain of which is smaller than the fuwl [or bean]: (Ḳ:) the people of Egypt know it by the name of AljaAmisap, with jym, and with the unpointed syn: he who says that it is the turomus is in error. (Ibn-Beytár, cited by De Sacy in his “Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif,” q. v., p. 97.)
baAqil-iI-N and baAqilaAYiI-N rel. ns. of baAqil-I and baAqilaMC, respectively. (Mgh.)

baAquwlN, (JK, A, O,) or buwqaAlN↓, (Ḳ,) A mug (kuwzN) having no Eurowap [or handle]; (JK, O, Ḳ;) i. q. kuwbN: (A, TA:) [in Spanish bokal, (Golius,) which favours the form in the Ḳ; but the Spanish word may be from buwqaAlapN, if from the Arabic:] pl. bawaAqiylu. (JK, A, TA.)
buwqaAlN: see what next precedes.
buwqaAlapN A kind of drinking-vessel, like a TaAs, or like a kaOosi; syn. TarojahaArapN. (IAạr, TA.) [See also baAquwlN.]
buwayoqilapN: see baAqil-KI, in four places.
buwayoqilaApF: see baAqil-KI, in four places.
buwayoqilaApN: see baAqil-KI, in four places.
muboqilN: see baqilN, in three places:
and see baAqilN.
maboqalapN: see baqilN, in three places.
maboqulapN: see baqilN, in three places.

baq-amN [Brazil-wood; the wood of the Braziltree, a species of Cæsalpinia;] a well-known dye; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. q. EanodamN; (Ṣ;) [or rather the wood from which a well-known dye is prepared;] the wood of a certain great tree, the leaves of which are like those of the almond, and having a red stem, the decoction of which is used as a dye: it consolidates wounds, stops a flow of blood from any member, and dries up ulcers; and its root, or lowest part, is an instantaneous poison: (Ḳ:) the word is said by some to be Arabic; (Mṣb;) others say that it is arabicized; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) [perhaps from the Persian baqamo, or bakamo;] and that the only other words of the same measure in the Arabic language are proper names, and four in number, (Ṣ TA,) or seven: (TA:) if used as a proper name, it is imperfectly decl., because determinate and of the measure of a verb. (Ṣ.)

1. baqaAhu biEayonihi, [aor. _u {yaboquwu},] inf. n. baqaAwapN [and baqowapN, as will be seen from what follows, like raHomapN], He looked, (Lḥ, JK, ISd, Ḳ,) or looked long, or glanced lightly, (JK,) at him, or it; (Lḥ, JK, ISd, Ḳ;) and so with I for the last radical: (JK:) and baqaAhu [alone], with w and with I for the last radical, (Ḳ in art. bqI,) first pers. baqawotuhu and baqayotuhu, (Lḥ, TA,) he looked at him, or it: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or he watched, or observed, him, or it: (Ḳ in art. bqI:) and bqwth I looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it: (Ḳ:) a dial. var. of baqayotuhu, which is the more approved. (TA.) [Hence,] Auboquhu baqowataka maAlaka and baqaAwataka maAlaka Guard thou, or preserve thou, him, or it, as thou guardest, or preservest, thy property. (M, Tekmileh, Ḳ.)
baqowaI and buqowaI: see art. bqI.

hom.sense: 1. baqiya aor. yaboqaI, inf. n. baqaMCN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAqiyapN; (Mṣb; [but see this latter below;]) [and accord. to the CK, baqFI and baqoIN; but this is a mistake; wabaqaI w baqoyFA being there erroneously put for baqaI baqoyFA, explained by what here follows;] and baqaI, [by some written baqaA,] (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (JK,) inf. n. baqoIN, (Ḳ,) of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, (TA,) or of that of Teiyi, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) who in like manner say baqato instead of baqayato, (Ṣ, TA,) and the like is done in other verbs of the same class, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) whether the kesreh and the I be original, as in baqiIa and nasiIa and faniIa, or accidental, as in the pass. verbs hudiIa and buniIa; (Mṣb;) [He, or] it, namely, a thing, remained, continued, lasted, endured: and was, or became, permanent, or perpetual; or continued, lasted, or existed, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever: syn. daAma, and vabata; (Mṣb;) contr. of faniIa: (Ḳ:) baqaMCN signifies a thing's remaining, continuing, lasting, or enduring, in its first state, to a period determined by the will of God, either with respect to its corporeal substance, as in the case of a heavenly orb, or with respect to its kind only, as in the case of the human and other animal races; and the continuing, lasting, or existing, for ever, either by self, as in the instance of God alone, or otherwise, and thus either with respect to the corporeal substance, as in the case of an inhabitant of Paradise, or with respect to kind only, as in the case of the fruits of the inhabitants of Paradise. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Hence,] daAru AlbaqaMCi [The abode of everlasting existence;] the world to come. (T in art. dwr.) The verb is said of a thing; and in like manner of a man, as in baqiIa zamaAnFA TawiylFA, i. e. He lived [or continued in life] a long time. (Ṣ.) [You say also, baqiIa EalaI HaAlihi He, or it, remained, or continued, in his, or its, state, or condition; i. e., as he, or it, was. And baqiIa EalaI AlX-id-api He endured, or bore up against, difficulty, distress, or adversity.] And baqiI mina AlX-aIoCi baqiy-apN [A remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue, of the thing remained.] (Ṣ.) And baqiIa minohu kacaA Such a thing remained, over and above, and behind, thereof; as also tbq-I↓. (Mṣb.)

baqaAhu, with I and with w for the last radical, (Ḳ,) first pers. baqayotuhu (Lḥ, Ṣ) and baqawotuhu, (Lḥ, TA,) aor. of the former _i, (Ṣ,) inf. n. baqoIN, [of the former verb,] (Ḳ,) He looked at him, or it: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [so in the Ḳ, but in the Ṣ “and,”] he watched, or observed, him, or it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and baqayotuhu I looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it; (TA in art. bqw;) as also baqawotuhu; (Ḳ in that art.;) but the former is the more approved. (TA in that art.) [See also art. bqw.] You say also, fulaAnN yaboqiI AlX-aIoCa bibaSarihi Such a one looks at the thing, and watches, or observes, it. (JK.) And it is said in a trad., baqayonaA rasuwla Qll-ehi We looked, watched, or waited, for the Apostle of God. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in two places.

4. AbqAhu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bq-Ahu↓ and tbq-Ahu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) all signify the same, (Ṣ,) and AstbqAhu↓ likewise, (Ḳ,) He made, or caused, [and he suffered,] him, or it, to remain, continue, last; to be, or become, permanent, or perpetual; to continue, last, or exist, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; he continued it; he perpetuated it. (Mṣb, Ḳ *) You say, AbqAhu Qll-ehu [God preserved him, or prolonged his life; or may God preserve him, or prolong his life; or] God made him, or caused him, or may God make him, or cause him, to continue in life. (Ṣ.) And OaboqaI OaSola AlX-aIoCi wajaEala vamarahu fiI sabiyli Qll-ehi He made the thing itself to remain unalienable, not to be inherited nor sold nor given away, and assigned the profit arising from it to be employed in the cause of God, or of religion. (TA in art. Hbs.) And Oaboqayotu maA bayonanaA I was sparing of marring, i. e., forbore from marring much, or exceedingly, that [state of union or amity] which subsisted between us. (Ḳ.) And baq-i↓ naEolayoka waQboculo qadamayoka [Preserve thou, or spare thou, thy sandals, and use freely, or unsparingly, thy feet]: a prov. (Meyd. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 149.)
And tabaq-aho↓ watawaq-aho Preserve thou the soul (Aisotaboqi↓ Aln-afosa), expose it not to destruction, [meaning preserve thyself,] and guard against evils, or calamities: a trad.: the h in each verb is that of pausation. (TA.) [And AbqI mina AlX-aIoCi baqiy-apF He left, or reserved, of the thing, a remain, remainder, remnant,, &c.:] and AstbqI↓ mina AlX-aIoCi He left a portion of the thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tbq-I↓; whence the prov., used to incite to liberality, laA yanofaEuka mino zaAdK tabaq-K↓ Leaving a portion of travel-ling-provision will not profit thee. (JK.) [And AbqI AlX-aIoCi and AstbqAhu↓ He reserved the thing for a future time or use, &c.] And AstbqAhu↓ as meaning [He spared him; he let him live;] he left him alive; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [as also AbqAhu; for] men say to their enemies when the latter have overcome, OaboquwnaA walaA tasotaOoSiluwnaA [Spare ye us, and destroy us not entirely]: (TA:) [or AbqAhu, in a case of this kind,] and AbqI Ealayohi and AstbqAhu↓ signify He pardoned him, [and forbore to slay him,] when slaughter was his due: (TA:) and AstbqAhu↓ signifies also He pardoned, or forgave, his fault, wrong action, or lapse into sin, and preserved his love, or affection. (JK, TA.*) And [hence,] Oaboqayotu EalaI fulaAnK signifies also I showed mercy to such a one [by sparing him, or letting him live, or by pardoning him, or otherwise]; had mercy on him; pitied, or compassionated, him; syn. OaroEayotu Ealayohi and raHimotuhu. (Ṣ.) One says, laA OaboqaI Qll-ehu Ealayoka Uino Oaboqayota EalaI-a [May God not show mercy to thee if thou show mercy to me: a prov., said in derision to one who affects to show mercy when unable to take revenge]. (Ṣ, Meyd.) And laA tuboqi Uil-aA EalaI nafosika [Show not mercy save to thyself: another prov., similar to the former]. (Meyd.) And it is said, in a trad., of the fire [of Hell], laA tuboqiI EalaI mano taDar-aEa UilayohaA, i. e. It will not pity [him who abases himself to it: or rather it will not spare, &c.: and in like manner, laA tuboqiI walaA tacaru, in the Ḳur lxxiv. 28, is generally understood as meaning It (namely, Hell,) will not spare, nor leave unburned]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5: see 1:
and see also 4, in four places.

entry.sense: 6. tabaAqK The remaining together. (KL.) [You say, app., tabaAqawoA, and tabaAqayaA, They, and they two, remained together.]
10: see 4, in seven places. [See also a usage of this verb in art. HI, conj. 10, second sentence.]
laqKI baqFI: see baqaAqN.
baqoyapN: see baqiy-apN.
baqowaI: see buqoyaA, in five places.
buqwaI: see buqoyaA, in two places.
baqoyaA: see what next follows.

buqoyaA (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and baqoyaA↓ (TA) and baqowaI↓ (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and buqowaI↓ (Th, Ḳ) and baqiy-apN↓ (JK, Ḳ,) the ↓third and ↓fourth with I changed into w, like as w is changed into I in dunoyaA and EuloyaA and quSoyaA, (ISd, TA,) [substs. in the sense of UiboqaMCN, inf. n. of 4, signifying The making, or causing, and suffering, to remain, continue, last,, &c.; preservation of a person in life, and of a thing in being; and the sparing, letting live, or leaving alive;] substs. from OaboqaAhu: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or [the showing mercy by sparing or letting live, or by pardoning, or otherwise; having mercy; pitying, or compassionating;] substs. from Oaboqayotu EalaI fulaAnK. (Ṣ.) Thus one says of a pilgrim, that he put gum, or something glutinous, upon his head, and so caused his hair to become compacted, buqoyaA Ealayohi to preserve it in the state in which it was (expl. by UiboqaMCF Elyh), lest it should become shaggy, or dishevelled, &c. (L in art. lbd.) And one says, naXadotuka Qll-eha waAlbuqoyaA and AlbaqowaI↓ [I conjure, or beg, or beseech, thee by God and by the preservation of thy life]. (JK.) And maA liI Ealayoh raEowaI walaA baqowaI↓ [I have no mercy nor pity to bestow upon him]. (JK. [There expl. by the words OaIo OaroEayotu Ealayohi waOaboqayotu; but OaIo is evidently a mistranscription for mino, i. e. from.]) A poet (El-La'een El-Minkaree, TA) says,
famaA buqoyaA EalaI-a tarakotumaAniI
walekino xifotumaA Sarada Aln-ibaAli
[And it was not to show mercy by sparing me that ye two left me; but ye feared the transpiercing of the arrows]. (Ṣ.) And another says, on his having refused to accept an offer of seven bloodwits,
Oucak-aru biAlbuqoyaA EalaI mano OaSaAbaniI
wabuqoyaAIa Oan-iI jaAhidN gayoru muWotaliI
i. e. Am I required [or exhorted or reminded] to show mercy to him who slew my relation, when the mercy that I show to him is that I am labouring to slay him, and not falling short, or being remiss: by bqyAI is meant UiboqaAYiI Ealayohi; though AlUiboqaMC is not Aljahod: the meaning is, that this is done by me in lieu of that: AlbuqoyaA is a subst. from AlUiboqaMC, syn. therewith; and the w prefixed to it is a denotative of state. (Ḥam p. 119. [This verse is also cited in the TA, but with the substitution of biAlbaqowaI↓ and wabaqowaAI for the corresponding words above.]) Albaqiy-apa↓ is said by men to their enemies when the latter have overcome; meaning [We ask, or beg, the being spared, or mercy, or quarter; a verb, whereby it is governed, being understood: or] OaboquwnaA walaA tasotaOoSiluwnaA [spare ye us, and destroy us not entirely]. (TA.)

baqiy-apN A remain, remainder, remaining portion, remnant, relic, residue, or the remains, or rest, of a thing; (KL, PṢ, &c.;) a subst. from baqiIa as signifying “it remained over and above,” and “it remained behind:” pl. baqaAyaA and baqiy-aAtN: (Mṣb:) baAqiyapN↓, also, [pl. bawaAqK and baAqiyaAtN,] has the same meaning as baqiy-apN; (TA;) [i. e., as explained above; and so has baAqK↓, for XaIoCK baAqK, &c.] You say, baqiIa mina AlX-aIoCi baqiy-apN [explained before: see 1]. (Ṣ.) [And humo baqiy-apu Als-ayofi, and baqaAyaA Als-ayofi, They are those who have been spared by the sword].

[Hence,] fulaAnN mino baqiy-api Alqawomi Such a one is of the best of the people, or company of men: because a man reserves the most excellent of the things that he produces. (Bḍ in xi. 118.) And fulaAnN mino baqiy-api Oaholihi Such a one is of the most excellent of his people, or family. (Ḥam p. 78.) And fulaAnN baqiy-apu Alqawomi Such a one is the best of the people, or company of men: pl. baqaAyaA. (Kull p. 96.)

Ouwluw baqiy-apK, in the Ḳur xi. 118, hence means Persons possessed of excellence: [see a phrase mentioned voce balalN:] or possessing a relic of judgment and intelligence: (Bḍ:) or persons of religion and excellence: (Jel:) or persons of understanding (Ḳ, TA) and discrimination: (TA:) or persons of obedience: (TA:) or having the quality of preserving themselves (Az, Bḍ, Ḳ,*) from punishment, (Bḍ,) by their holding the approved religion: (Az, TA:) and this last explanation is confirmed by another reading, which is AwlwA baqoyapK↓ [possessing a quality of watching, or observing, and hence, of guarding, or preserving]; baqoyap being the inf. n. of un. of baqaAhu, aor. yaboqiyhi, signifying “he watched,” or “observed,”, &c., “him,” or “it.” (Bḍ.) See also buqayaA, in two places. baqiy-apN is also a subst. from Oaboqayotu maA bayonanaA [explained before: see 4: app. meaning Forbearance from marring much, or exceedingly, the state of unity, or of amity, subsisting between two persons, or parties: and such may be its meaning in the phrase above-mentioned (AwlwA bqy-p)]. (Ḳ.)

baqiy-apu Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur xi. 87, [after the command, in the next preceding verse, to give full measure and weight,] means God's sustenance that remains for you after your giving full measure [and weight]: (Jel:) or that which God has preserved for you, of what is lawful, (Fr, Bḍ,) after [your] keeping aloof from that which he has forbidden you: (Bḍ:) or the good state, or condition, remaining for you: (Zj, Ḳ:) or the fear (muraAqabap) of God; accord. to some: (Fr, TA:) or the obedience of God, and (as Aboo-ʼAlee says, TA) the looking for his recompense: (Ḳ, TA:) or baqiy-apN and baAqiyapN↓ signify any religious service whereby one seeks to obtain the recompense of God; and such is the meaning of the former in this instance. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also baAqiyapN.

baAqK part. n. of baqiIa [in all its senses; Remaining, continuing, lasting, or enduring: and permanent, or perpetual; or continuing, lasting, or existing, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever:, &c.: see 1]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) AlbaAqiI, a name of God, [as also, pleonastically, AlbaAqiI AlOabadiI-u, means The Everlasting, or] He whose existence will have no end. (TA.) See also baqiy-apN.
AlbaAqiI also signifies The HaASil [or net produce, or perhaps simply the produce,] of the [tax termed] xaraAj, and the like. (Lth, JK, TA.)
baAqiyapN: see baqiy-apN, first sentence.

AlbaAqiyaAtu AlS-aAliHaAtu [in the Ḳur xviii. 44, and xix. 79,] means Any righteous, or good, work, (Ḳ, TA,) of which the recompense remains: (TA:)
or acts of obedience, (Bḍ and Jel in xix. 79,) or good works, (Bḍ in xviii. 44,) of which the fruit remains for ever: (Bḍ in both those places, and Jel * in the former:) and, as included therein, [so Bḍ, but in the Ḳ “or,”] the five prayers; (Bḍ, Ḳ;) and the performance of the pilgrimage; and the keeping the fast of Ramadán; (Bḍ in xviii. 44;) and [so Bḍ, but in the Ḳ “or,”] the saying, suboHaAna Qll-ehi waAlHamodulil-ehi walaA Uil-aA Qll-ehu waQll-ehu Oakobaru; (Bḍ and Jel in xviii. 44, and Ḳ;) to which some add, walaA Hawola walaA quw-apa Uil-aA biQll-ehi: (Jel ibid.:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the correct meaning is any religious service whereby one seeks to obtain the recompense of God: see also baqiy-apN, last explanation. (TA.)

baAqiyapN is sometimes put in the place of an inf. n.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or it is an inf. n.; (Mṣb;) syn. with baqaMCN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) with which baqiy-apN↓, also, is syn. (TA in art. srE.) So in the Ḳur [lxix. 8], fahalo taraI lahumo mino baAqiyapK [And dost thou see them to have any continuance?]; (Ṣ, TA;) so says Fr: (TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, baqiy-apK [i. e. a remnant]: (TA:) or jamaAEapK baAqiyapK [a company remaining]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or nafosK baAqiyapK [a soul, or person, remaining]: (Bḍ, Jel:) or the p is an intensive affix; (Jel;) [or a restrictive to unity;] i. e. one remaining; (Jel, TA;) and this is also allowable and good: one says, likewise, maA baqiyato baAqiyapN walaA waqaAhumo mina Qll-ehi waAqiyapN [One remaining remained not, nor did one preserver preserve them from God]. (TA.)
OaboqaI Longer continuing. (Bḍ and Jel in xx. 74, &c.)
huwa OaboqaI Alr-ajulayoni means Oakovaru UiboqaMCF EalaI qawomihi [He is the more merciful, or pitiful, or compassionate, of the two men, towards his people]. (TA.)
naAqapN muboqiyapN A she-camel [that retains some milk;] that does not exhaust her copious supply of milk. (JK.)

muboqiyaAtu Alxayoli, (Ḳ,) or rather AlmuboqiyaAtu mina Alxayoli, (TA,) The horses whose running continues after the running of other horses has ceased: (M, Ḳ:) or, that reserve somewhat of their running. (T, TA.)
And AlmuboqiyaAtu The places that retain some of the pools in which water has collected, and do not drink it up. (TA.)

1. bakaOato, aor. _a {yabokaOu}; and bakuWato, aor. _u {yabokuOu}, inf. n. bakoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bukoCN (AZ, TA) and bakaOapN, or bakoOapN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) or bakaMCapN, (as in the O and CK,) and bukuwoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is inf. n. of bakuWa, (Ṣ, TA,) as is also that next preceding it, (TA,) and bukaMCN, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ bukoCN, (TA,) She (a camel, Ṣ, Ḳ, or a ewe or goat, Ṣ) had little milk; her milk became little: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, her milk ceased, or stopped. (TA.)
And [hence,] bakaOato EayoniI † My eye had few tears. (TA.)
And bakuWa, inf. n. bakaMCapN, [app. † He became poor; had little wealth; being] said of a man. (TA.) [See also 4.]
And bakiY † He failed of attaining the object of his want. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. qado OabokaOa Ald-ar-a, occurring in a verse, [see Ḥam p. 758,] is asserted by Aboo-Riyásh to mean He (the milker) has found the milk to be little in quantity; like as OaHomadahu signifies “he found him to be such as is praised:” ISd holds that it may signify he has made the milk to be little in quantity [app. by his niggardness]; but he confesses his not having heard the verb used in this sense by any one. (TA.)
AbkO also signifies † He (a man) became poor; or in the condition of having little, or no, wealth. (TA.) [See also bakuWa.]

entry.sense: bakoCN [originally inf. n. of 1, q. v.: and hence,] † Poverty; or paucity of wealth. (TA.)
And † Paucity of speech, except as to things requiring speech. (TA.)

bakiIoCN and bakiyoYapN A she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a ewe or she-goat, (Ṣ,) having little milk; whose milk has become little: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, whose milk has ceased, or stopped: (TA:) pl. bikaMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bakaAyaA (Ḳ.)
And [hence,] dar-N bakiIoCN † [Milk, or a flow of milk, little in quantity]. (TA.)
And rakiy-apN bakiy-apN † A well of which the water has sunk into the earth; or become low: the latter word having its C changed into I to assimilate it to the former. (TA.)
And EuyuwnN bikaMCN † Eyes having few tears. (TA.)

And OayodK bikaMCN † Hands of which the gifts are few. (TA.) And rajulN bakiIpCN † [app. A poor man; a man having little wealth: or of few words: or unable to speak: see bakoCN; and see bakiI-N, in art. bkI]: pl. bikaMCN. (TA.)
1: see 2, in four places.

2. bk-thu, inf. n. tabokiytN, He reprehended, reproved, blamed, chid, or reproached, him, for an affair, or for a crime or the like; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to some, with justice; (TA;) or he did so severely; (Ṣ,* TA;) and threatened him; (TA;) and declared his deed to be evil; (Mṣb;) as when one says, “O wicked man! wast thou not ashamed? didst thou not fear God?” (TA:) and sometimes this is done by using an enunciative phrase, such as the saying of Abraham, [mentioned in the Ḳur xxi. 64,] “Nay, the chief of them, this, did it;” for thus he said to reprove their worship of idols; (Mṣb;) and it may be by means of the hand, and a staff or stick, and the like. (Hr, TA.)
He accused him, to his face, (Aisotaqobalahu, q. v.,) of that which he disliked, or hated; (Aṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also bakatahu↓, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabokutu}, inf. n. bakotN. (TA.)

He overcame him, biAlHuj-api [with the argument, allegation, or plea]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also bakatahu↓; (A, TA;) and both, he obliged him to be silent by reason of his inability to reply. (A,* TA.) You say, bk-thu Hat-aI Oasokatahu, and bakatahu↓, He overcame him [by an argument, &c.,] so that he silenced him. (A, TA.)
Also, (Lth, TA,) and bakatahu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, him (Ḳ, TA) with a staff or stick, and a sword, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) and the like. (Lth, TA.)

mubak-itN A woman who usually brings forth a male child after a female. (Ḳ, TA.) [Such a woman is app. thus called because supposed to reproach her husband for his having been displeased with her on her bringing forth a female.]

1. bakara and gadaA both [properly] relate to the beginning of the day: (AZ, Mṣb:) the former of these verbs, (T, Ṣ, A,) aor. _u {yabokuru}, inf. n. bukuwrN; (T, Ṣ;) and bk-r↓, (T, Ṣ, A,) inf. n. tabokiyrN; (T, Ṣ;) and Abkr↓, and Abtkr↓, (Ṣ, A,) and bAkr↓; (Ṣ;) all signify the same; (Ṣ;) He (a traveller, A) went forth early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; syn. xaraja fiI Albukorapi: (T, A:) or Abkr↓, inf. n. UibokaArN, signifies he entered upon that time: (T:) one should not say bakura nor bakira in the sense of bk-r [&c.]. (Ṣ.)

And [hence,] bakara Uilayohi, [and Ealayohi,] aor. and inf. n. as above; (Mṣb;) and bakira Alyh, aor. _a {yabokaru} (ISd, Ḳ;* [but see a remark respecting this verb above;]) and bkr↓ Alyh, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and Elyh; (TA;) and Abkr↓ Alyh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Elyh; [and Abkrhu↓;] and bAkrhu↓; (TA;) signify also † He hastened [or betook himself early] to it, or to do it, at any time, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) morning or evening. (TA.) You say, bakarotu EalaI AlHaAjapi † [I hastened to do, or accomplish, or attain, the thing needed], inf. n. as above: and in like manner, Oabokarotu↓ EalaI Alwirodi † [I hastened to come to water]: (AZ, Ṣ:) and Abkr↓ Alwiroda, (TA,) and AlgadaMCa, (AZ, Ṣ, TA,) † He hastened to come to water, and to take the morning-meal. (TA.) Lebeed says,
baAkarotu jaAjatahaA Ald-ajaAja bisuHorapK
meaning † I hastened to be before the crowing of the cock, at the close of night, in obtaining what was wanted [of it, namely, of wine,] by me: (TA:) HAjthA being for HaAjatiI UilayohaA, i. e., UilaI Alxamori. (EM p. 170: but the first word is there written baAdarotu.) [See also 2, below.]

[It is also said that] bkr [app. bakira,] inf. n. bkr, [app. bakarN,] signifies † He possessed the quality of applying himself early, or of hastening; expl. by kaAna SaAHiba bukuwrK. (Mṣb.) [But see bakurN.]

hom.sense:
2. bk-r, inf. n. tabokiyrN: see 1, in three places: and see 1. You say also, bk-r UilaI AljumoEapi ‡ He went forth to the [prayers of] Friday at the commencement of the time thereof. (A.) And bk-r [alone], inf. n. as above, ‡ He came to prayer at the commencement of its time. (Ḳ, TA.) And bk-r biAlS-alaApi ‡ He performed the prayer at the commencement of its time: (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) he was regardful of it, and performed it early. (TA.)
And bak-iruwA biSalaApi Almagoribi ‡ Perform ye the prayer of sunset at the setting of the [sun's] disc. (Ṣ.) And bak-arati Aln-axolapu biHamolihaA ‡ [The palmtree was early with its fruit]. (A.)

Also ‡ He was, or became, or went, before; preceded; had, or took, precedence; syn. taqad-ama; and so Abkr↓ and tbk-r↓. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, bak-arotu fiI kacaA ‡ I was, or became, or went, before,, &c., in such a thing; syn. taqad-amotu. (IJ, IB, TA.) And bk-r EalaI OaSoHaAbihi † [He was, or became, or went, before his companions; preceded them; or had, or took, precedence of them]. (M, Ḳ.)
See also 4.
bk-r AlfaAkihapa: see 8.

entry.sense: 3: see 1, in four places.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in seven places: and see 1 as meaning taqad-ama.
Abkr also signifies He had camels coming to water early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

It is also trans. of bakara: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Mṣb:) you say, Oabokarotu gayoriI [I made another to go forth early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise: and I made another to go to a person, &c. at that time; and to betake himself to an action at that time: and † to hasten, or betake himself early, to a thing at any time, morning or evening: and bak-arotu↓ gayoriI app. signifies the same]. (Ṣ.)
You say also, Abkrhu EalaI OaSoHaAbihi: see 2.

entry.sense: 5: see 2.

hom.sense: 8. Abtkr: see 1, in two places.

Also ‡ He arrived [at the mosque on the occasion of the Friday-prayers] in time to hear the first portion of the xuTobap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he heard the first portion of the xuTobap; (A, Mṣb;) [and] Abtkr AlxuTobapa has this meaning. (Mgh.) mano bak-ara↓ waQbotakara, occurring in a trad., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) respecting [the prayers of] Friday, (Ṣ,) means ‡ Whoso hasteneth, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and arriveth in time to hear the first portion of the xuTobap, (Ṣ,) or heareth the first portion thereof: (Mṣb:) or whoso hasteneth, going forth to the mosque early, and performeth the prayer at the first of its time: or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, whoso hasteneth to the Fridayprayers, before the call to prayer, and arriveth at the commencement of their time: or both the verbs signify the same, and the [virtual] repetition is to give intensiveness and strength to the meaning. (TA. [See 2.])

You say also, Abtkrhu, meaning ‡ He took, (A, Mṣb,) or obtained possession of, (Ṣ, TA,) its baAkuwrap, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e., (TA,) the first of it: (A, Mṣb, TA:) which is the primary signification [of the trans. verb]. (TA.)
And Abtkr, (Ḳ,) or Abtkr AlfaAkihapa, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and bak-arahaA↓, (TA,) ‡ He ate the first that had come to maturity of fruit, or of the fruit. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And hence, (Mgh,) Abtkr AljaAriyapa ‡ He took the girl's virginity: (A, Mgh:) or he did so before she had attained to puberty. (Mṣb in art. qD, and TA in art. xDr.)
And Abtkr EajiynFA † [He took, or made use of, fresh dough for preparing bread]. (Ḳ in art. grD.)

And Aibotakarato, (Abu-l-Beydà,) or Abtkrt biwaladihaA, (AHeyth,) She brought forth her first offspring: (AHeyth, Abu-l-Beydà:) or the former signifies she (a woman) brought forth a male at her first birth. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: bakorN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and bukorN↓, (Ḳ,) but this latter is hardly to be found in any of the lexicons, (MF,) and bikorN↓, (ISd, TA,) A youthful he-camel; one in a state of youthful vigour: fem. with p {bakorapN}; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and also bakorN, without p: (TA:) the term bakorN, applied to a camel, corresponds to fatFI, applied to a human being; and bakorapN, to fataApN; and qaluwSN, to jaAriyapN; and baEiyrN, to UinosaAnN; and jamalN, to rajulN; and naAqapN, to maroOapN: (AO, Ṣ:) or the offspring, or young one, of a she-camel; (Ḳ;) thus indefinitely explained: (TA:) or a camel in his sixth year (vaniI-N) [and] until he becomes a jacaE: [but it seems that the reverse must be meant; for a jcE, of camels, is one in his fifth year:] or a camel in his second year [and] until he enters his sixth year: or a camel in his second year, or that has entered his third year, or that has completed his second year and entered his third year; syn. Aibonu labuwnK: (Ḳ:) and a camel that has just entered upon his fourth year: and a camel in his fifth year: (IAạr, Az:) or a camel that has not entered his ninth year: (Ḳ:) and sometimes it is metaphorically applied to a human being; [meaning ‡ a young man;] and bakorapN to ‡ a young woman: (TA:) the pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) is OabokurN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Oubayokiruwna↓ occurs as pl. of the dim. of OabokurN; (Ṣ, TA;) and (pl. of mult., Ṣ, TA) bikaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like as firaAxN is pl. of faroxN; (Ṣ;) or this is pl. of bakorapN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and there are other pls. of bakorN, namely, bukoraAnN (Ḳ) and bikaArapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and [quasi-pl. n.] bakaArapN↓. (Ḳ.) Hence the well-known prov., (TA,) SadaqaniI sin-a bakorihi, and sin-u bakorihi, meaning He hath told me what is in his mind, and what his ribs infold: a saying originating from the following fact: a man bargained with another for a youthful camel (bakor), and said, “What is his age (sin-uhu)?” the other answered, “He is in his ninth year:” then the young camel took fright and ran away: whereupon his owner said to him, hidaEo hidaEo; and this is an expression by which are quieted young ones, (Ḳ,) of the camel; (TA;) so when the purchaser heard it, he said, SdqnI sn- bkrh [He hath told me truly the age, or as to the age, of his youthful camel: or the age of his youthful camel has spoken truly to me]: if sn- is in the accus. case, the meaning [of the verb] is Ear-afaniI, (Ḳ,) and sn- is in the accus. case as a second objective complement; (TA;) or xabara sin-i is meant; [in the CK, erroneously, xabara;] or fiI sin-i; the prefixed noun [xabara] or the proposition [fiI] being suppressed [and sn- being therefore in the accus. case]: but if sn- is in the nom. case, veracity is attributed to the [animal's] age, by an amplification: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, the buyer said to the owner of the camel, “How many years has he?” and he told him; and he looked at the teeth of the camel, and found him to be as he had said; whereupon he said, SdqnI sin-u bkrh. (Ḥar p. 95.)
bukorN: see bakorN.
bikorN A virgin; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and a man who has not yet drawn near to a woman; (TA;) contr. of vay-ibN, applied to a man as well as to a female: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. OabokaArN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And [hence,] † A pearl unpierced. (MF.) And † A bow when one first shoots with it. (TA.) And ‡ A cloud abounding with water: (Ḳ, TA:) likened to a virgin, because her blood is more than that of her who is not a virgin: and the phrase saHaAbN bikorN is sometimes used. (TA.) And naArN bikorN ‡ Fire not lighted from another fire. (Aṣ, A.)

Also She that has not yet brought forth offspring: (AHeyth:) and a cow that has not yet conceived: (Ḳ:) or a heifer (Ḳ, TA) that has not yet conceived: (TA:) and a woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a she-camel, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) that has brought forth but once: pl. OabokaArN and bikaArN: (TA:) or a she-camel in her first state or condition. (Ḥam p. 340.)
And [hence,] ‡ A grape-vine that has produced fruit but once: (A, Ḳ:) pl. OabokaArN. (A.)

Also i. q. bakorN, q. v. (ISd, TA.) And [hence,] OabokaAru AlOawolaAdi † Young children. (TA, from a trad.) And OabokaAru Aln-aHoli † Young bees. (TA.) Whence, Easalu OabokaArK ‡ Honey produced by young bees: or this means honey of which the preparation has been superintended by virgin-girls. (A,* TA.)

Also ‡ The first-born of his, or her, mother (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and father; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied alike to the male and the female: (Ṣ:) and sometimes to that which is not the offspring of human beings; (TA;) the first-born of camels; (Ṣ;) and of a serpent: (TA:) pl. OabokaArN. (TA.) You say, hecaA bikoru Oabawayohi ‡ This is the first-born of his parents. (TA.) And OaXad-u Aln-aAsi bikorN Qbonu bikorayoni (A) or bikoru bikorayoni (M, TA) ‡ [The strongest of men is the first-born of a man and woman each a first-born].

† The first of anything; (Ḳ;) as also baAkuwrapN↓: (TA:) and † an action that has not been preceded by its like. (Ḳ.) You say, maA hecaA AlOamoru minoka bikorFA walaA vaniyFA ‡ This thing, or affair, is not thy first nor thy second. (A, TA.)
HaAjapN bikorN ‡ A want, or needful thing, recently sought to be accomplished or attained: (TA:) or that is the first in being referred to him of whom its accomplishment is sought. (A, TA.)

DarobapN bikorN ‡ A cutting blow or stroke, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that kills (Ḳ) at once, (TA,) not requiring to be struck a second time: (Ṣ, A:) pl. DarabaAtN OabokaArN; occurring in a trad., in which it is said that such were the blows of ʼAlee; (Ṣ, TA;) but in that trad., as some recite it, the latter word is mubotakiraAtN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: bakarN: see bukorapN, in three places:
and see also bakorapN.

entry.sense: rajulN bakurN fiI HaAjatihi, [in the CK, erroneously, bakorN,] and bakirN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) like HacurN and HacirN, (Ṣ,) and bakiyrN↓, (TA,) † A man possessing the quality of applying himself early, or of hastening, or having strength to apply himself early, or to hasten, (SaAHibu bukuwrN, Ṣ, or qawiI-N EalaI Albukuwri, Ḳ,) to do, or accomplish, the thing that he needs, or wants: (Ṣ:) bakurN and bakirN [and bakiyrN] are [said to be] possessive epithets; for they have no simple triliteral verb. (TA.) [But see 1, last sentence.]
bakirN: see what next precedes.

bakorapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bakarapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) The thing upon which [passes the rope wherewith] one draws water (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) from a well [or the like]; (Ṣ;) [i. e. the sheave of a pulley;] a round piece of wood, in the middle [of the circumference] whereof is a groove (Ḳ, TA) for the rope, and in the interior [or centre] whereof is an axis upon which it turns: (TA:) or a quick maHaAlap [or large sheave of a pulley]: (M, Ḳ:) [but MF disapproves of this last explanation: sometimes, by a synecdoche, it is used to signify a pulley complete:] the pl. is bakarN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of the former, anomalous, like HalaqN pl. of HaloqapN, and HamaON pl. of HamoOapN, (Ṣ,) or of the latter; (Mṣb;) or a coll. gen. n., of which bakarapN is the n. un.; (MF;) and bakaraAt, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of the former [as well as of the latter]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Hence, app., the former signifies also † A small ring, like a bead, in the ornamental part of a sword: (Mgh:) [and the pl.] bakaraAtN signifies † the rings that are attached to the ornamental part [of the scabbard] of a sword, (Ḳ,) resembling the [rings called] qatax [which are worn upon the fingers or toes] of women. (TA.)
[And hence, perhaps,] † An assembly, a company, or a congregated body. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

jaAWuwA EalaI bakorapi Oabiyhimo is a prov., (TA,) meaning ‡ They came together, not one remaining behind, (Ṣ, TA;) they came all of them, (AA, IJ, A, TA,) without exception: (TA:) or they came in a multitude, and all together, none remaining behind: (TA:) or they came in succession, one after, or at the heels of, another: (AO:) or they came in one way, or manner: (Aṣ:) [accord. to some, from bkrp as explained in the next preceding sentence; and, if so, ElI is used in the sense of maEa, or muXotamiliyna is understood before it: or it is from bkrp signifying “a youthful she-camel;” and thus implies that they were few: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 312:) or] from bak-arotu fiI kacaA meaning “I was,” or “became,” or “went,” “before in such a thing;” so that it signifies that they came from first to last: (IJ:) or from bkrp in the first of the senses explained in this paragraph; though in this case there is no bkrp in reality. (AO, Ṣ.*)

bukorapN and bakarN↓ The early morning, or first part of the day; (Bḍ and Jel in xix. 12 and xxxiii. 41 and xlviii. 9, as relating to the former word; and Ḳ;*) between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; syn. gudowapN; and UibokaArN↓ is a subst. in the same sense, (Ḳ,) accord. to the lexicologists, as Sb says; but he adds that he holds it to be [only] the inf. n. of Oabokara: (TA: [and the like is said in the Ṣ with reference to its occurrence in the Ḳur iii. 36 and xl. 57:]) pl. [of pauc.] of the first, OabokaArN, and [of mult.] bukarN. (T, Mṣb.) You say, Oatayotuhu bukorapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and bakarFA↓, (A,) meaning baAkirKA↓ [I came to him early in the morning,, &c.]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) But if you mean the bukorapN of a particular day, you say, Oatayotuhu bukorapa, making the noun imperfectly decl.; [meaning I came to him early in the morning,, &c., of this day;] and in this case it is not to be used otherwise than as an adv. n. of time. (Ṣ.) If you say baAkirFA↓, using this word as an epithet, you use baAkirap for the fem. (TA.) You say also, siro EalaI farasika bukorapF and bakarFA↓ [Go thou on thy horse early in the morning,, &c.]; like as you say, saHarFA. (Ṣ, TA. [But in two copies of the Ṣ, for sro, I find siyra.])
bakarapN: see bakorapN.

bakuwrN (A, Ḳ) and baAkuwrN↓ (Ḳ) and baAkirN↓ (A) and mubokirN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ Rain that falls in the first of its season: (A:) or that comes (TA) in the commencement of [the season of] the wasomiI- [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:) and that comes in the end of the night, or the beginning of the day. (TA.) You say also saHaAbapN midolaAjN bakuwrN ‡ [A cloud that comes in the latter part of the night, in the first of its season, bringing rain]: (A:) and saHaAbapN mibokaArN↓ a cloud that comes in the end of the night. (TA.)

Also bakuwrN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bakiyrapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baAkuwrapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and baAkirN↓ (A) and mibokaArN↓ (A in art. Axr and Ḳ) ‡ A palm-tree (naxolapN, A) that comes to maturity first, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) before the other palm-trees: (Ṣ:) or that produces its fruit early; (A;) contr. of miYoxaArN (A in art. Axr:) pl. (of the first, Mṣb, Ḳ) bukurN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ; [in the CK bukorN;]) and [pl. of baAkirN↓ or baAkirapN] bawaAkiru (Ḳ voce tabaAXiyru) baAkuwrapN↓ is fem. of baAkuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) which signifies † Anything that hastens its coming (TA) and its attaining to maturity. (Ḳ, TA.) You say also OaroDN mibokaArN↓ † Land that produces plants, or herbage, quickly. (Ḳ.)
bakiyrN, and its fem. with p {bakiyrapN}: see bakurN and bakuwrN

hom.sense: bakaArapN Virginity: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the virginity, or maidenhead, of a woman. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
baAkirN [part. n. of bakara]: see bukorapN, in two places:
and see bakuwrN, in three places:
and see an ex. of the pl. of its fem. baAkirapN, i. e. bawaAkiru, voce baASirN
Also † Fruit when first ripe: pl. bikaArN, like as SiHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN. (TA.)

entry.sense: baAkuwrN, and its fem. baAkuwrapN: see bakuwrN, in three places.
baAkuwrapN [as a subst.]: see bikorN.

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or baAkuwrapN AlfaA kihapi, (A, Mṣb,) ‡ The first of fruit: (Ṣ:) or the first that comes to maturity, of fruit: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or fruit that hastens to come forth: (AḤát, Mṣb:) pl. bawaAkiyru and baAkuwraAtN. (Mṣb.)
The pl. bawaAkiyru also signifies † Winds that announce [coming] rain. (A in art. bXr)
UibokaArN: see bukorapN.
OubayokirN dim. of OabokirN, pl. of pauc. of bakorN: see its pl. Oubayokiruwna voce bakorN.
tabaAkiyru † The colours of palm-trees when the fruit begins to ripen. (TA voce tabaAXiyru.)
mubokirN: see bakuwrN.
mibokaArN: see bakuwrN, in three places.
DrabaAtN mubotakiraAtN: see bikorN. last sentence.

1. bakima aor. _a {yabokamu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bakamN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was OaxorasN [meaning dumb, either by natural conformation or from inability to find words to express what he would say]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) bakamN being syn. with xarasN, as is also bakaAmapN [accord. to rule an inf. n. of bakuma, which may also have the same signification as bakima, as well as another to be explained below]: (Ḳ:) or he had not understanding to reply, (T, Mṣb, TA,) nor ability to frame speech well, (T, TA,) though possessing the faculty of speech: [see Oabokamu:] (T, Mṣb, TA:) or he was dumb, and moreover unable to find words to express what he would say, and weak in understanding, silly, or stupid: (Ḳ:) or he was dumb and deaf and blind by birth. (Th, Ḳ.)
bakuma, aor. _u {yabokumu}, (inf. n. bakaAmapN, TḲ,) He refrained, (Lth, Ḳ) or, as some say, broke off, or ceased, (TA,) from speaking, intentionally, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) or from ignorance. (Lth, TA.)
‡ He cut himself off, or desisted, from marriage, or sexual intercourse, either from ignorance or intentionally. (Ḳ, TA.)
5. tbk-m Ealayohi AlkalaAmu His speech was, or became, impeded; he was unable to speak freely. (A, Ḳ.)
bakiymN: see what follows, in two places.

OabokamN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and bakiymN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) i. q. Oaxorasu [meaning Dumb, either by natural conformation or from inability to find words to express what he would say]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or not having understanding to reply, (IAạr, T, Mṣb, TA,) nor ability to frame speech well, (T, TA,) though possessing the faculty of speech; whereas Axrs signifies speechless, or destitute of the faculty of speech, by natural conformation, (T, Mṣb, TA,) like the beast that lacks the faculty of articulation; (T, TA;) unable to find words to express what he would say; unable to reply: (AZ, TA:) or dumb by natural conformation: (IAth, TA:) fem. bakomaMCu: (TA:) pl. bukomN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and bukomaAnN, (Ḳ,) both pls. of Oabokamu, like as Sum-N and Sum-aAnN are pls. of OaSam-u; and the pl. of bakiymN↓ is OabokaAmN. (TA.) In the Ḳur ii. 166, bukomN means persons in the condition of him who has been born dumb: or, as some say, deprived of their intellects: (Zj, TA:) or ignorant and ignoble; because not profiting much by the faculty of speech, so that they are as though they had been deprived of it. (IAth, TA.)
The phrase fitonapN Sam-aMCu bakomaMCu EamoyaMCu, occurring in a trad., [lit.] meaning [A sedition, or the like,] deaf, dumb, blind, applies to a ftnp that does not withdraw, or become removed: or, as some say, to one which, by reason of the confusion attending it, and the perishing of the sound and the sick therein, is likened to the deaf and dumb and blind who does not pursue the right course to a thing, but goes at random like the weak-sighted she-camel. (TA.)

1. bakaI, aor. _i {yabokiIu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bukaMCN and bukFA (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mabokFI, (Ḥar p. 11,) He wept; i. e. he lamented, or grieved, shedding tears at the same time; and he lamented, or grieved, alone; and he shed tears alone: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to some, the preferable opinion is, that there is no difference between bukaMCu and bukFA: (TA:) or the former means the crying, or uttering of the voice [of lamentation], (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA, &c.,) that accompanies AlbukaMC [so in copies of the Ṣ and in the TA, but correctly AlbukaA]; (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, TA;) and the latter (bukFA), the shedding of tears: (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA, &c.:) or the former, i. e. with medd, means the shedding of tears by reason of lamentation, or grief, and raising of the voice, or crying, [at the same time,] when the voice is predominant, being like rugaMCN, and vugaMCN and other words of the same form applied to denote the uttering of a cry or of the voice; and the latter, [the shedding of tears, &c.] when lamentation, or grief, is predominant: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or by the former is meant the crying, or uttering of the voice [of lamentation]; and by the latter, the lamenting, or grieving. (Kh, TA.) tabokaMCN and tibokaMCN [may be inf. ns. of bakaI or of bak-aI↓, and] signify the same as bukaMCN: or much bukaAC [or weeping,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) MF asserts that tibokaMCN (with kesr) and the former of these explanations are unknown; but both the word and the explanation are mentioned by Lḥ, as used in a form of words uttered by Arab women of the desert to fascinate men: ISd, however, says that it should be tabokaMC, because it is an inf. n. of a class formed to denote muchness [of the attribute signified by the verb], like tahocaArN and taloEaAbN, &c.; and IAạr says that tabokaACN, with fet-ḥ, has the latter of the two significations assigned to it above. (TA.) [See what is said of the measure tifoEaAlN voce bay-ana.] You say, bakaI lahu (MF, TA) and bakaI Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, MF,) meaning [He wept] for, or over, him, or it: and only bakaI bihi [or thus and also bakaIminohu as appears from what follows] when meaning [He wept] because, or in consequence, of it: ('Ináyeh, MF, TA:) and bakaAhu and bak-aAhu↓, (Aṣ, AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former bukaMCN (Ḳ) [and bukFA], and of the latter tabokiyapN, (TA,) signify the same as bakaI Ealayohi; (Aṣ, AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) the object being a man: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and (or as some say, TA) he wept for, or over, him, i. e., one dead; or did so, and enumerated his good qualities or actions; syn. ravaAhu: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, bakaAhu means [he wept because, or in consequence, of it, i. e.,] on account of being pained: and bakaI Ealayohi, [he wept for, or over, him,] by reason of tenderness of heart, or compassion: and [hence] it is said that bakayotuhu is originally bakayotu minohu: (TA:) [and bak-aAhu↓ may have an intensive, or a frequentative, meaning; for it is said that] bak-iI, addressed to the eye, signifies weep thou much, and repeatedly. (Ḥam p. 461.)
[Hence,] bakat Als-aHaAbapu † The cloud rained. (Mṣb.)

bakaI also means He sang: [in the CK, wbakaI Ean-iI is erroneously put for wbakaI gan-aI:] thus it has two contr. significations: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to MF, it has this meaning only in relation to the pigeon and the like; but it is also used in this sense when said of a man, as in a verse cited voce janaAzapN, q. v.: and he observes that the assertion of its having two contr significations requires consideration, seeing that it is also said to signify ravaI; [for in the performance of rivaMC, it is a common practice to sing;] but rivaMC is generally accompanied by lamentation, and ginaMC by rejoicing. (TA.)
baAkayotuhu fabakayotuhu: see 3.

hom.sense: 2: see 1, in three places:
and see also 4.

entry.sense: 3. baAkayotuhu fabakayotuhu, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. of the latter Oabokuwhu, (TA,) or Oabokiyhi, retaining its original form, accord. to a rule observed in the case of a verb having an infirm letter [for its second or third radical] lest a verb with a radical I should be confounded with one having a radical w, (Ḥam p. 670,) i. e. [I vied with him, or strove to exceed him, in weeping, and I exceeded him therein, or] I was a greater weeper (OabokaI) than he. (Ṣ, TA.)

4. AbkAhu [He made him, or caused him, to weep; or] he did to him what made him to weep; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AstbkAhu↓. (Ṣ.) And bk-Ahu↓ Ealayohi, inf. n. tabokiyapN, He excited him to weep for him, or it; (Ḳ, TA;) namely, a person dead, (Ḳ,) or a thing lost. (TA.)

6. tbAkI signifies takal-afa AlbukaMCa [i. e. He affected weeping; or endeavoured, or constrained himself, to weep]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., faUino lamo tajiduwA bukaMCF fatabaAkawoA [And if ye experience not weeping, endeavour to weep]: (TA:) [or the words of the trad. are] AutoluwA AlquroMna waQbokuwA faUino lamo tabokuwA fatabaAkawoA [Peruse ye the Ḳur-án, and weep; or, if ye weep not, endeavour to do so]. (Bḍ in xix. 59.)
And He feigned, or made a show of, weeping. (Ḥar p. 602.)
10. AstbkAhu: see 4.
Also He desired, or required, of him weeping. (TA.)

hom.sense: bakiI-N One who weeps much; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bak-aMCN↓. (Ḳ, but omitted in some copies and in the TA.)
rajulN Eayiy-N bakiI-N, A man unable to speak. (Mbr, TA.) [But perhaps this should be bakiIoCN: see art. bkO.]

entry.sense: bak-aMCN: see bakiI-N.

baAkK part. n. of bakaI [i. e. Weeping,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) pl. bukiI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure fuEuwlN, with the w changed into I [and the second ḍammeh consequently into a kesreh, wherefore it is also, sometimes, pronounced bikiI-N], (Ṣ,) and bukaApN, (Ḳ,) which is agreeable with analogy and usage, though said by Es-Semeen to have not been heard. (TA.) [The pl. of the fem., i. e. of baAkiyapN, is baAkiyaAtN and bawaAkK.]
OabokaI [A greater weeper, or one who weeps more, than another: see 3]. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. bal-ahu (Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yabolulu}, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. bal-N (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bil-apN, (M, Ḳ,) He moistened it (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with water (M, Mṣb, Ḳ), &c.; (M;) and in like manner, bl-lhu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) but signifying he moistened it much. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence,] bal-ati AlUibilu OagomaArahaA [The camels damped their thirst;] i. e., drank a little. (TA in art. gmr.)

[Hence also,] bal-a raHimahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yabolulu}, (T, M,) inf. n. bal-N (with fet-ḥ, TA [in the CK it has kesr]) and bilaAlN, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ He made close [or he refreshed] his ties of relationship by behaving with goodness and affection and gentleness to his kindred; syn. waSalahaA, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and nad-aAhaA: (T:) for, as some things are conjoined and commixed by moisture, and become disunited by dryness, bal-N is metaphorically used to denote conjunction, as above, and yubosN to denote the contrary. (TA.) A poet says,
waAlr-iHoma fQbolulohaA bixayori Albul-aAno
faUinahaAQXotuq-ato mini Qsomi Alr-aHomeno
[‡ And the ties of relationship, make thou them close, &c. by the best mode, or modes, of doing so; for the name thereof is derived from the name of the Compassionate]: here Albul-aAn↓ may be a noun in the sing. number, like guforaAnN, or it may be pl. of balalN, which may be either a subst. or an inf. n., for some inf. ns. have pls., as XugolN and EaqolN and maraDN. (M.) And it is said in a trad., bul-uwA OaroHaAmakumo walawo biAls-alaAmi ‡ Make ye close [or refresh ye] your ties of relationship, &c., though but, or if only, by salutation; syn. SiluwhaA, (M,) or nad-uwhaA biAlS-ilapi. (Ṣ.) And hence the saying in another trad., Uica QsotaXan-a maA bayonaka wabayona Qll-ehi faQbolulohu biAlUiHosaAni UilaI EibaAdahi ‡ [When the tie between thee and God wears out, repair thou it, or refresh thou it, by beneficence to his servants]. (TA.) [See also bilaAlN.]

bal-aka Qll-ehu biQbonK, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and QbonFA, (M, Ḳ,) † May God give thee a son. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA.) Hence, perhaps, the phrase, bul-ato yadaAka bihi as meaning † Thou was given it. (Ḥar p. 479.) You say also, balalotuhu, meaning † I gave to him. (T.) And laA taboluka EinodiI baAl-apN↓, and balaAlN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [but in the Ḳ EinodanaA, and “or” for “and,” and in the CK lA tabal-uka,]) ‡ No bounty, (Ṣ,) no good, or no benefit, shall betide thee from me, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) nor will I profit thee, nor believe thee. (T.)
bal-uwA They sowed land. (ISh, T, Ḳ.)
[And hence,] bal-ati Alr-iyHu, aor. _i {yabolilu}, inf. n. buluwlN, The wind was cold and moist. (M, Ḳ.) [See baliylN.]

[And hence, probably, as though originally said of one who had had a fever,] bal-a mino maraDihi, aor. _i {yabolilu}, inf. n. bal-N (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and balalN and buluwlN; (M, Ḳ) and Abl-↓, and Astbl-↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) He recovered from his disease: (Ṣ, M:) and Abtl-↓ and tbl-l↓ he became in a good condition after leanness, or meagerness: (M,Z:) or all have this latter signification: and the second (Abl-) has the former also. (Ḳ.)
