bal-a fiI AlOaroD, (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _i {yabolilu}, inf. n. bal-N; (Mṣb;) and Abl-↓; (M, Ḳ;) He (a man, M) went away in, or into, the land, or country. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And bal-ato naAqatuhu His she-camel went away. (TA.) And bal-ato maTiy-atuhu EalaI wajohihaA, (Fr, T, TA,) and Abl-t↓ ElI wjhA, (Ḳ,) His camel, or riding-camel, ran away, or went away, at random, to pasture, straying; syn. hamato DaAl-apF. (Fr, T, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, hmt, which, as is said in the TA, is without teshdeed, is written ham-ato.])

balilotu minohu, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. balalN, (M,) I got him; got possession of him; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) got him in my hand. (Ṣ.) One says, laYino bal-ato bika yadiI laA tufaAriquniI Oawo tuWad-iIa Haq-iI [Assuredly if my hand get hold of thee, thou shalt not quit me unless thou give up, or pay, my right, or due]. (Ṣ.) And hence the prov., maA balalotu mino fulaAnK biOafowaqa naASilK [I did not get, in such a one, a man like an arrow with a broken notch and without a head]; meaning I got a perfect man; one sufficient. (Sh, T.)

Also, (T,) or balilotuhu, (M, Ḳ,) I kept, or clave, to him, (T, M, Ḳ,) namely, a man, (T, Ḳ,) and constantly associated with him. (T.) And bal-a biAlX-ayoCi, inf. n. bal-N, He became devoted, or attached, to the thing, and kept to it constantly. (TA.)

And balilotu minohu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabolalu}, (TA,) inf. n. balalN and balaAlapN and buluwlN, I was tried by him (muniytu bihi [app. meaning biHub-ihi by love of him]), and loved him (Ealiqotuhu [in the CK Ealaqotuhu]); as also balalotu bh, (AA, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yabolilu}, inf. n. buluwlN (AA, TA.) And balilotu bihi I was tried by him, as though by fire, (Saliytu bh, [in the CK Salayotu,]) and suffered distress, or misery, or fatigue (Xaqiytu, for which Xufiytu is erroneously put in the copies of the Ḳ: TA). (M, Ḳ.*)
maA balalotu bihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabolalu}, inf. n. balalN, (TA,) I did not light on, or meet with, or find, nor know, him, or it; expl. by maA OaSabotuhu walaA Ealimotuhu. (Ḳ.)
bal-a, (Th, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. balalN, (Th, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed Oabal- [which epithet see below]. (Th, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: 4. Abl- It (wood, or a branch or twig,) had the sap, (AlmaMC, Ḳ,) or the produce of the rain, (O,) flowing in it. (O, Ḳ.)
See also bal-a, in four places.
He (a man) resisted, or withstood, and overcame. (Aṣ, T, Ṣ. [See also Oabala.]) And Abl- Ealayohi He overcame him. (M, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse of Sá'ideh, cited voce xasofN.]
He wearied by badness, or wickedness: (M, Ḳ:) or he wearied another in aiding him to accomplish his desire. (TA. [See mubil-N.])
Oabolalotuhu I made him to go away. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 5: see 8:
and see also bal-a.
8. Abtl- It became moist or moistened (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ) with water (M, Mṣb, Ḳ), &c.; (M;) and in like manner, [but signifying it became much moistened, being quasi-pass. of bl-lhu,] tbl-l↓. (M, Ḳ.)
See also bal-a.
10: see bal-a.
R. Q. 1. balobala, inf. n. balobalapN and bilobaAlN, (M, Ḳ,) the latter with kesr, (TA,) [but written in the CK with fet-ḥ,] He put people in motion; and roused, or excited, them. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, (T,) inf. n. balobalapN, (Ḳ,) He scattered, dispersed, or put asunder, his goods, commodities, or householdutensils and furniture. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.* [In the CK, wAlmatAEu is erroneously put for waAlmataAEi.])
And He divided, or disunited, opinions. (Fr, T, Ḳ; but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned.)
And He (God) [mixed or confounded or] made discordant the tongues, or languages, of a people. (T.)
[See also balobalapN below.]

hom.sense: R. Q. 2. tabalobala He (a man) was moved by grief [or anxiety: see balobalapN, below]. (Ḥar p. 94.)
tabalobalati AlOalosunu The tongues, or languages, became mixed, or confounded. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tabalobalati AlUibilu AlkalaOa The camels went on seeking the herbage, or pasture, and left not of it aught. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
balo is a particle of digression: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Mbr, it denotes emendation, wherever it occurs, in the case of a negation or an affirmation: (T, TA:) or it is a word of emendation, and denoting digression from that which precedes; as also bano, in which the n is a substitute for the l, because bl is of frequent occurrence, and bn is rare; or, as IJ says, the latter may be an independent dial. var. (M.) When it is followed by a proposition, the meaning of the digression is either the cancelling of what precedes, as in waqaAluwA Qt-axaca Qlr-aHomenu waladFA suboHaAnahu balo EibaAdN mukoramuwna [And they said, “The Compassionate hath gotten offspring:” extolled be his freedom from that which is derogatory from his glory! nay, or nay rather, or nay but, they are honoured servants (Ḳur xxi. 26)], or transition from one object of discourse to another, as in qado OafolaHa mano tazak-aI wacakara Qsoma rab-ihi faSal-aI balo tuWoviruwna QloHayaApa Qld-unoyaA [He hath attained felicity who hath purified himself, and celebrated the name of his Lord, and prayed: but ye prefer the present life (Ḳur lxxxvii. 14-16)]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) and in all such cases it is an inceptive particle; not a conjunctive. (Mughnee.) When it is followed by a single word, it is a conjunction, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Mughnee, Ḳ,) and requires that word to be in the same case as the word before it: (Ṣ:) and if preceded by a command or an affirmation, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as in AiDorabo zayodFA balo EamorFA [Beat thou Zeyd: no, ʼAmr], (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and qaAma zayodN balo EamorNw [Zeyd stood: no, ʼAmr], (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) or jaMCaniI Oaxuwka balo Oabuwka [Thy brother came to me: no, thy father], (Ṣ,) it makes what precedes it to be as though nothing were said respecting it, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Mughnee, Ḳ,) making the command or affirmation to relate to what follows it: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Mughnee:) [and similar to these cases is the case in which it is preceded by an interrogation: see Oamo as syn. with this particle:] but when it is preceded by a negation or a prohibition, it is used to confirm the meaning of what precedes it and to assign the contrary of that meaning to what follows it, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as in maA qaAma zayodN EamorNw [Zeyd stood not, but ʼAmr stood], (Mughnee,) or maA raOayotu zayodFA balo EamorFA, [I saw not Zeyd, but I saw ʼAmr], (Ṣ,) and laA yaqumo zayodN balo EamorNw [Let not Zeyd stand, but let ʼAmr stand]. (Mughnee.) Mbr and ʼAbd-El-Wárith allow its being used to transfer the meaning of the negation and the prohibition to what follows it; so that, accord. to them, one may say, maAzayodN qaAYimFA balo qaAEidFA [as meaning Zeyd is not standing: no, is not sitting], and balo qaAEidN [but is sitting]; the meaning being different [in the two cases]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*) The Koofees disallow its being used as a conjunction after anything but a negation [so in the Mughnee, but in the Ḳ a prohibition,] or the like thereof; so that one should not say, Darabotu zayodFA balo Uiy-aAka [I beat Zeyd: no, thee]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) Sometimes laA is added before it, to corroborate the meaning of digression, after an affirmation, as in the saying,
wajohuka Albadoru laA bali AlX-amosu lawo lamo
yuqoDa lilX-amosi kasofapN waOufuwlu
[Thy face is the full moon: no, but it would be the sun, were it not that eclipse and setting are appointed to happen to the sun]: and to corroborate what precedes it, after a negation, as in
wamaA hajarotuka laA balo zaAdaniI XagafFA
hajorN wabaEodN taraAxaI laA UilaI Oajali
[And I did not abandon thee, or have not abandoned thee: no, but abandonment and distance, protracted, not to an appointed period, increased, or have increased, my heart-felt love]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*)

Sometimes it is used to denote the passing from one subject to another without cancelling [what precedes it], and is syn. with wa, as in the saying in the Ḳur [lxxxv. 20 and 21], waQll-ehu mino waraAYihimo muHiyTN balo huwa quroMnN majiydN [And God from behind them is encompassing: and it is a glorious Ḳur-án: or here it may mean Uin-a, as in an ex. below]: and to this meaning it is made to accord in the saying, lahu EalaI-a diynaArN balo dirohamN [I owe him a deenár and a dirhem]. (Mṣb.)

In the following saying in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 1], waQloquroMni ciI Qlc-ikoribali Ql-aciyna kafaruwA fiI Eiz-apK waXiqaAqK, it is said to signify Uin-a; [so that the meaning is, By the Ḳur-án possessed of eminence, verily they who have disbelieved are in a state of pride and opposition;] therefore the oath applies to it. (Akh, Ṣ.)

Sometimes the Arabs use it in breaking off a saying and commencing another; and thus a man commences with it a citation, or recitation, of verse; in which case, it does not form any part of the first verse, but is a sign of the breaking off, or ending, of what precedes. (Akh, Ṣ.)

Sometimes it is put in the place of rub-a, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) as in the saying of the rájiz,
balo mahomahK qaTaEotu baEoda mahomahK
[Many a far-extending desert have I traversed, after a far-extending desert]. (Ṣ: [and a similar ex. is given in the Mughnee.])

What is deficient in this word [supposing it to be originally of three letters] is unknown; and so in the cases of halo and qado: it may be a final w or I or they may be originally bal- and hal- and qad-. (Akh, Ṣ.)

hom.sense: [bal-N Moist, or containing moisture: or rather moistened; being, app., an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; like xaloqN in the sense of maxoluwqN. Hence,] riyHN bal-apN and baliylN↓ and baliylapN↓ A wind in which is moisture: (Ṣ:) or the last, a wind mixed with feeble rain: (T:) and the second, a wind cold with moisture; (M, Ḳ;) or the same, a wind cold with rain; (A, TA;) the north wind, as though it sprinkled water by reason of its coldness: (TA:) and balalN↓ also signifies a cold north wind: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) baliylN is used alike as sing. and pl.: (Ḳ:) it has no pl. (M.)
bal-N biXaIoCK A man (M) devoted, or attached, to a thing, and keeping to it constantly. (M, Ḳ. [In the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, All-ahoju is erroneously put for All-ahiju.])

And bal-N, alone, Much given to the deferring of payment to his creditors, by repeated promises; (T;) withholding, by swearing, what he possesses of things that are the rightful property of others. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) See also Oabal-N, in two places.

entry.sense: bil-N Allowable, or lawful; i. e., to be taken, or let alone, or done, or made use of, or possessed: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so in the dial. of Himyer: (T, Ṣ. M:) or a remedy; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) from the phrase bal-a mino maraDihi [q. v.]: (A' Obeyd, T, Ṣ, M:) or it is an imitative sequent to Hil-N, (M, Ḳ,) as some say: (M:) so Aṣ thought until he heard that it was said to be of the dial. of Himyer in the first of the senses explained above: (Ṣ, M:) AʼObeyd and ISk say that it may not be so because it is conjoined with Hil-N by wa: (T:) and AʼObeyd says, We have seldom found an imitative sequent conjoined by w. (TA.) Hence the phrase, huwa laka Hil-N wabil-N It is to thee lawful and allowable: or lawful and a remedy. (M, Ḳ.*) And hence the saying of El-ʼAbbás the son of ʼAbd-El-Muttalib, respecting [the well of] Zemzem, hiIa liXaAribK Hil-N wabil-N It is to a drinker lawful, &c. (T, Ṣ, M.)
bal-apN [A single act of moistening.]

[And hence,] The least sprinkling (OadonaI balalK lit. the least moisture) of good. (TA in art. hl.) You say, jaMCanaA fulaAnN falamo yaOotinaA bihal-apK walaA bal-apK [Such a one came to us and did not bring us anything to rejoice us nor the least sprinkling of good]: hl-p, accord. to ISK, being from AlfaraHu and AlAisotiholaAlu, and bl-p from Albalolu and Alxayoru. (Ṣ.) And maA OaSaAba hal-apF walaA bal-apF He did not obtain, or has not obtained, anything. (Ṣ.)
Wealth, or competence: (Fr, TA:) or wealth, or competence, after poverty; (Fr, T, Ḳ, TA;) as also bul-aI↓. (Ḳ.)
Remains of herbage or pasture; (Ḳ;) as also bul-apN↓. (Fr, T, Ḳ.)
The freshness of youth; as also bul-apN↓; (M, Ḳ;*) but the former word is the more approved. (M.)
See also an ex. voce balalN.
bul-apN: see balalN, in two places:
and see also bal-apN, in two places.
Also A state of moisture. (M.)

The moisture of fresh pasture. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) The rájiz (Iháb Ibn-ʼOmeyr, TA) says, describing [wild] asses,
Hat-aI UicaA OahoraOona biAlOaSaAYili
wafaAraqatohaA bul-apu AlOawaAbili
meaning that they went in the cool of the evening to the water after that the herbage had dried up: AlAwAbl means the wild animals that are satisfied with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water. (Ṣ.)
bil-apN: see balalN, in two places.
Also Good, good fortune, prosperity, or wealth: and sustenance, or means of subsistence. (M, Ḳ.)
Health; soundness; or freedom from disease. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
A repast prepared on the occasion of a wedding, or on any occasion. (Fr, Ḳ.)

‡ The tongue's fluency, and chasteness of speech: (Ḳ, TA:) or its readiness of diction or expression, and facility; (M;) and [so in the M, but in the Ḳ “or,”] its falling upon the [right] places of utterance of the letters, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) and its regular and uniform continuance of speech, (T, M, Ḳ,) and its facility. (Ḳ.) You say, maA OaHosanN bil-apa lisaAnihi ‡ [How good is the fluency, &c., of his tongue!]. (T, M, TA.)

balalN Moisture; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also bil-apN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and bilaAlN↓ and bulaAlapN↓ (M, Ḳ) [and several other dial. vars. occurring in phrases in this paragraph]: or bil-apN↓ signifies an inferior, or inconsiderable, degree of moisture; (Lth, T, Ḳ; [an ambiguity in the Ḳ in this place has occasioned several mistakes in Freytag's Lex. voce balalN;]) and bilaAlN↓ is an anomalous pl. of this word; (M, TA;) and is pl. also of bul-apN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) and bul-aAnN, occurring in a verse cited above (see 1) may be pl. of balalN. (M.) [Using syns. of balalN in the sense explained above,] you say, Tawayotu Als-iqaMCa EalaI bululatihi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bulalatihi↓, (Ḳ,) or balalatihi↓, (T, M,) I folded the skin while it was moist, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) before it should break in pieces, (T,) or lest it should break in pieces. (M.) And [hence,] Tawayotu fulaAnFA EalaI bululatihi↓, (T,*S, M,*K,*) and bulalatihi↓, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and balalatihi↓, and bulaAlatihi↓, and balaAlatihi↓, (Ḳ,) and bul-atihi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bal-atihi↓, (M, Ḳ,) and bulaAtihi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and balaAtihi↓, (Ḳ) and buluwlatihi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) and buluwlihi↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ I bore with, suffered, or tolerated, such a one, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) notwithstanding his vice, or fault, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and evil conduct: (Ṣ:) or [so in the M and Ḳ, but in the Ṣ “and,”] I treated him with gentleness, or blandishment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) while some love, or affection, remained in him; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and this is the true meaning; (M;) and in like manner, EalaI bilaAlN↓ nafosihi. (Ṣ, TA.) And TawaAhu EalaI bilaAlihi↓, and buluwlihi↓, ‡ He feigned himself heedless of, or inattentive to, his vice, or fault; like as one folds a skin upon its fault [to conceal that fault]. (T.) And AinoSarafa Alqawoma bibalalatihimo↓, and bibululatihimo↓, and bibuluwlatihimo↓, † The people, or company of men, turned away, or back, having some good, or somewhat good, remaining, in them, or among them; expl. by wafiyhimo baqiy-apN [in which the last word generally implies something good; as, for instance, in the Ḳur xi. 118]: (M, Ḳ:) or, in a good state, or condition: (Ḳ:) or this latter is meant when one says, bibululatihimo. (T.)
Abundance of herbage; or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA.)
See also bal-N.

maA OaHosana balalahu How good is his adornment of himself! or his manner of undertaking a task, or taking upon himself a responsibility! (Ḳ: expl. in some copies by tajam-ulahu; and so in the TA: in others by taHam-ulahu.)
bulalN, like SuradN, (Ḳ,) or bululN, (so in a copy of the T, accord. to the TT,) Seed; grain for sowing. (ISh, T, Ḳ.)
balalapN and its pl.: see four exs. voce balalN.
bulalapN and its pl.: see three exs. voce balalN

The sing. also signifies Garb, guise, aspect or appearance, external state or condition. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) You say, Uin-ahu laHasanu Albulalapi Verily he is goodly, or beautiful, in garb, &c. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
You say also, kayofa bulalatuka, and buluwlatuka↓, meaning How is thy state, or condition? (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
bululapN: see three exs. voce balalN.

balaAli a subst. signifying The making close the ties of relationship by behaving with goodness and affection and gentleness to one's kindred: (Ḳ:) changed in form from baAlapN; q. v. (TA.) [See also bilaAlN.]
balaAlN: see what next follows.
bulaAlN: see what next follows.
bilaAlN: see balalN, in four places.

Also Water; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and so bulaAlN↓ and balaAlN↓. (Ḳ.) You say, maA fiI siqaAYihi bilaAlN There is not in his skin any water: (T, Ṣ:) or anything whatever: (so in a copy of the Ṣ:) and in like manner one says of a well. (T.)
And maA fiI AlbiYori baAluwlN↓ There is not any water in the well. (Ḳ.)
And Anything with which one moistens the fauces, of water or of milk: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) such is said to be its meaning. (Mṣb.)
buluwlN: see two exs. voce balalN.
baliylN: see bal-N.
balaAlapN: see an ex. voce balalN.
bulaAlapN: see balalN, in two places.
Also The quantity with which a thing is moistened. (Ḥar p. 107.)
And A remain, or remainder; (T, and Ḥar ubi suprá;) as also EuluAlapN. (Ḥar ubi suprá.) You say, maA fiyhi bulaAlapN walaA EulaAlapN There is not in it anything remaining. (T, and Ḥar ubi suprá.)
buluwlapN: see two exs. voce balalN:
and see an ex. voce bulalapN.

hom.sense: baliylapN: see bal-N.
Also Wheat boiled in water, [in the present day, with clarified butter, and honey,] and eaten. (TA.)
And i. q. SiH-apN [Health, or soundness, &c.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: bul-aI: see bal-apN.

bal-aAnN A hot bath: (Ḳ:) the A and n are augmentative: for the hot bath is thus called because he who enters it is moistened by its water or by his sweat: (TA:) pl. bal-aAnaAtN, (Ḳ,) occurring in a trad., and said by IAth to be originally bal-aAlaAtN. (TA in art. bln; in which, as well as in the present art., it is mentioned in the Ḳ.)
It is now applied to A man who serves [the bathers, by washing them, &c.,] in the hot bath: [fem. with p:] but this is a vulgar application of the word. (TA.)
bul-aAnN: see 1.

hom.sense: bulobulN [The nightingale: and a certain melodious bird resembling the nightingale: both, in the present day, vulgarly called bilobil:] the Eanodaliyb [q. v.]: and the kuEayot [q. v.]: (T:) a certain bird, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) of beautiful voice, that frequents the Haram [or Sacred Territory of Mekkeh], and is called by the people of El-Ḥijáz the nugar [q. v.]. (M.)

A man light, or active: (Ṣ:) or clever, well-mannered, or elegant, and light, or active: (T:) or a man (M) light, or active, in journeying, and very helpful; (M, Ḳ;) and so bulaAbilN↓, (M,) or bulobuliI-u↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Th, a boy light, or active, in journeying: (M:) and a man light, or active in that which he sets about; (TA;) as also bulaAbilN↓; (Ḳ;) or this last signifies a man active in intellect, to whom nothing is unapparent: (T:) pl. of the first, (Ṣ,) and of the last, (Ḳ,) balaAbilu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A certain fish, of the size of the hand. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
The spout (qanaAp) of a mug (kuwz), that pours forth the water. (M, Ḳ.)
balobalapN inf. n. of balobala [q. v.]. (M, Ḳ.)
A state of confusion, or mixture, of tongues, or languages. (M, Ḳ.*) In the copies of the Ḳ, AlOasin-ap is here erroneously put for AlOalosinap. (TA.)

Also, and balobaAlN↓, The vain, or unprofitable, or evil, suggestion of anxieties in the bosom: (T:) or anxiety, and vain, or unprofitable, or evil, suggestion of the mind: (Ṣ:) or intense anxiety, and vain, or unprofitable, or evil, suggestions or thoughts; (M, Ḳ;) as also bulaAbilN↓, (so in the M, accord. to the TT,) or balaAbilu↓: (so in copies of the Ḳ:) this last [however] is pl. of balobaAlN↓; (T;) which also signifies vehement distress in the bosom; (M, Ḳ;) and so does balobaAlapN↓: (IJ, M:) or balobaAlN↓ signifies anxiety and grief: and, as also balobalapN, a motion, or commotion, in the heart, arising from grief or love. (Ḥar p. 94.)

entry.sense: bulobulapN A mug (kuwz) having a spout (bulobul) by the side of its head, (M, Ḳ, TA,) from which the water pours forth: (TA:) or a ewer, as long as it contains wine. (Kull p. 102.)
bulobuliy-N: see bulobulN.

hom.sense: balobaAlN: see balobalapN, in three places.
Also A putting people in motion; and rousing, or exciting, them: a subst. from R. Q. 1. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: balobaAlapN: see balobalapN.
balaAbilN: see balobalapN.

hom.sense: bulaAbilN: see bulobilN, in two places:
and see balobalapN.

entry.sense: baAl-apN [properly A thing that moistens.]
baAluwlN: see bilaAlN.
[Oabal-N More, and most, moist: fem. bal-aMCu: and pl. bul-N. Hence,] Aljanuwbu Oabal-u Alr-iyaAHi The south is the most moist of the winds. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, also,] maA XaIoCN Oabal-a lilojisomi mXna All-ahowi Nothing is more healthful and suitable to the body than sport. (TA.)
And SafaApN bal-aMCN A smooth stone or rock. (Ṣ.)

And Oabal-u, applied to a man, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) Violent, or vehement, in contention, altercation, or dispute; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also bal-N↓: (Ḳ:) or (M) one who has no sense of shame: (M, Ḳ:) or (TA) one who resists, or withstands, (Ḳ, TA,) and overcomes: (TA:) or (M) very mean, (M, Ḳ,) from whom that which he possesses cannot be obtained, (Ks, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by reason of his meanness; (Ks, T, Ṣ;) and so bal-aMCu applied to a woman: (Ks, Ṣ:) or mean, (TA,) much given to the deferring of payment to his creditors, (IAạr, M, Ḳ,) much given to swearing (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and to wronging, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) withholding the rightful property of others; (TA;) as also bal-N↓ [q. v.]: (IAạr, M, [but referring only to what is given above on the authority of the former,] K, [referring to the same and to what follows except the addition in the TA,] and TA:) or, (Ṣ, M,) accord. to AO, (Ṣ,) i. q. faAjiru [i. e. vicious, immoral, unrighteous,, &c.]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) fem. bal-aMCu: (M, Ḳ:) and pl. bul-u: (Ḳ:) or it signifies one who pursues his course at random, not caring for what he meets. (Ḥam p. 383.)

mubil-N One whose aiding thee to accomplish thy desire wearies thee. (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, for mano yaEoyiyka Oano yutaAbiEaka EalaI maA turiydu, we find mano yuEiynuka AaI yutaAbiEuka ElI mA turiydu.])
xaSomN mibal-N A constant, firm, or steady, adversary in a contention, dispute, or litigation. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. balija, aor. _a {yabolaju}, (ISh, TA,) inf. n. balajN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He (a man) had a clear, a conspicuous, or a white, space between the eyes, not having the eyebrows joined; (ISh, TA;) he had a clear space between the eyebrows; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) he had a wide space, or a space clear of hair, between the eyebrows. (TA.)

[Hence, He (a man) was, or became, bright in countenance: or fair, beautiful, and wide in countenance: or † open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance: or † liberal with acts of beneficence: or ‡ generous, beneficent, and open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance: see the part. n. Oabolaju, below.]

And [hence,] aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) ‡ He (a man, TA) was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, balija biAlX-ayoCi ‡ He rejoiced at the thing; or was rejoiced by it; as also valija. (Aṣ, TA.) And balija bihi AlS-adoru faraHFA ‡ The bosom became dilated with joy thereat. (A.) And balija baEoda maA Harija ‡ [It (the bosom) became dilated with joy after it had been contracted with grief]. (TA.)

[And hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above; (Mṣb;) and balaja, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboluju}, inf. n. buluwjN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and Anblj↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Abtlj↓; (so in copies of the A and Mṣb;) and tbl-j↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Ablj↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) † It (the dawn, or daybreak,) shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Oabolajati↓ AlX-amosu † The sun shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (TA.) And AblAj-↓ AlX-aIoCu † The thing shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (TA.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) balaja AlHaq-u, and balija; (Mṣb;) or Ablj↓; (A, TA;) ‡ The truth became apparent, (A, Mṣb, TA,) manifest, evident, or clear. (A, Mṣb.) And AblAj-↓, inf. n. AiboliyjaAjN, (Ṣ, and so the inf. n. is written in a copy of the Ḳ: in another copy of the Ḳ it is written AibolijaAjN [inf. n. of Ablj-↓], and the verb is written Ablj- in a copy of the Ṣ: accord. to the CK, the inf. n. is AiboliylaAjN [of which the verb is Ablwlj↓]:) said of anything, (Ṣ, TA,) signifies ‡ It was, or became, apparent, manifest, evident, or clear. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
balaja, aor. _i {yaboliju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. balojN, (TA,) He opened; syn. fataHa. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1, in three places.
Abljhu † He made it apparent, manifest, evident, or clear. (Ḳ.)

And † He made him joyful, glad, or happy; syn. far-aHahu: (Ḳ accord. to the TA [and so in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ in my hands]:) or † he removed it, or cleared it away; syn. far-ajahu. (So accord. to the CK.)

entry.sense: 5. tbl-j † He laughed, and was cheerful, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Ṣ.)
See also 1.
7: see 1.
8: see 1.
9: see 1.
11: see 1, in two places.
baloju: see OabolajN, in four places.
balajN: see bulojapN.
balijN ‡ Joyful, glad, or happy. (TA.) [See also OabolajN.]
bulujN, with two dammehs, Men clear of hair in the [parts of the face called the] qasamaAt. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
balojapN: see what next follows.

buljapN Clearness of the space between the eyebrows: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or width of the space between the eyebrows; or [of] the space between the eyebrows when clear of hair; as also balajN↓ [which is the inf. n. of balija]. (TA.) One says, maA OaHosana bulojatahu How beautiful is the clearness of the space between his eyebrows! (A.)
The part behind the EaAriD [or side of the cheek or face], to the ear, when there is no hair upon it. (TA.)

Also, and balojapN↓, † The light (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) of the dawn, or daybreak, (Ṣ, L,) in the last part of the night, (Ṣ, TA,) at the breaking of the dawn. (TA.) You say, raOayotu bulojapN AlS-uboHi † I saw the light of the dawn. (Ṣ.) And laqiytuhu Einoda Albulojapi † [I met, or found, him, or it, at the break of the dawn]. (A.) And sarayotu Ald-ulojapa waAlbalojapa Hat-aI waSolatu † [I journeyed during the whole night, or from the beginning of the night, or during the latter part of the night, and the breaking of the dawn, until I arrived]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., layolapu Alqadori bulojapi † The night of Alqdr is bright [like the dawn]. (TA.)
baliyjN: see Oabolaju, in two places.

biliylajN, with kesr to the b and to the first l, and with fet-ḥ to the second l; (Mṣb;) or baliylajN; (so written in some copies of the Ḳ, in other copies of which it is omitted;) [Myrobalana Bellerica: (Golius and Freytag:) Terminaria Chebula: Sprengel. hist. rei herb. p. 262: (Freytag:)] a certain well-known Indian medicine; (Mṣb;) very beneficial to the stomach and to the intestinum rectum. (Ḳ.) [For other properties, &c. assigned to it, see Ibn-Seenà (Avicenna), book ii. p. 144. See also AiholiylajN, in art. hlj.]

Oabolaju A man having a clear, a conspicuous, or a white, space between the eyes, not having the eyebrows joined: (ISh, TA:) or having such a space between the eyebrows, (Ḳ,* TA,) not having the eyebrows joined: (Ṣ, TA:) or having a wide space, or a space clear of hair, between the eyebrows: fem. balojaMCu. (TA.)

[Hence,] Bright of countenance; the Prophet being said by UmmMaabad to have been Oabolaju Alwajohi; by which she did not mean the balaj of the eyebrows, for she described him as having joined eyebrows: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA:) or fair, beautiful, and wide in countenance, whether long or short: or [alone, or] followed by balojN↓, † open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance; (TA;) and so ↓the latter alone: (Ḳ:) or ↓the latter, ‡ open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance, with beneficence: (TA:) or the former, and ↓the latter, and baliyjN↓, † liberal with acts of beneficence: (TA:) or the first, ‡ generous, beneficent, and open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance; although having joined eyebrows. (A, TA.)

Also † Shining, bright, or shining brightly; applied to the dawn, or daybreak; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) and so baliyjN↓, applied to a thing [of any kind]: (TA:) and the former, anything † apparent, manifest, evident, or clear; (Ḳ;) thus applied to a face, and to the dawn, (TA,) and to the truth, (Mṣb, TA,) and to an affair or event, or a case, &c. (TA.) It is an act. part. n. of balija. (Mṣb.) You say, AlHaq-u Oabolaju waAlbaATilu lajolajN ‡ The truth is apparent, manifest, evident, or clear; [and falsity is a cause of embarrassment, or hesitation, to the speaker;] (Ṣ, A;*) i. e., the latter is agitated to and fro, without having utterance: (Ṣ in art. lj:) or the truth is lucid and direct; and falsity is confused and indirect. (TA in that art.) And Huj-apN balojaMCu † A manifest, an evident, or a clear, proof or argument. (Mṣb.)

Ouboluwju Als-uk-ari, with damm, [meaning Sugar-candy, and loaf-sugar, thus applied in the present day,] is an arabicized term [from the Persian Mboluwjo]: (Ḳ, TA:) in one copy of the Ḳ, it is said that OuboluwjN, with damm, is [syn. with] Als-uk-arN [sugar]: by the people [who are makers] of AlHasaA and AlqaTiyf, [see these words, the latter of which is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, pl. qaTaAYifN,] it is called OumoluwjN. (TA.)
4. AblH It (a palm-tree) bore, or had, dates in the state in which they are termed balaH. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

balaH Dates, or the fruit of the palm-tree, while continuing green (Mṣb, TA) and small; (TA;) a term like HiSorimN applied to grapes; (Mṣb, TA;) called by the people of El-Basrah xalaAlN: when they have begun to colour, i. e., to become red or yellow, they are termed busorN: (Mṣb:) or dates in the state between that in which they are called xlAl and that in which they are called bsr; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) for dates in their incipient state are termed TaloEN; then, xlAl; then, blH; then, bsr; then, ruTabN; and then, tamorN: (Ṣ, IAth:) or i. q. suy-aAbN: (Aṣ, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. syb:) [by many of the Arabs in the present day, it is applied to fresh ripe dates, and to dried dates: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. balada, aor. _i {yabolidu}, [inf. n. buluwdN,] He (a man) remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the balad [i. e. country, or town,, &c.]: (Mṣb:) or balada biAlmakaAna, (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaboludu}, (M, L,) inf. n. buluwdN, (T, M, L, Ḳ,) he remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place, (AZ, T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and kept to it: (Ḳ:) or he took it as his balad [or country, or town,, &c.], (M, L, Ḳ,) and kept to it. (M, L.)

And baliduwA, aor. _a {yaboladu}; (M, Ḳ;) and baladuwA, aor. _u {yaboludu}; (Ḳ;) or the latter is correctly bl-dwA↓; (M,* TA;) They kept to the ground, fighting upon it: (M, Ḳ:) said to be derived from bilaAdu AlOaroDi. (TA.)
balida, aor. _a {yaboladu}, His skin had OabolaAd, or marks, [pl. of baladN,] remaining upon it. (M, L.)
Also, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. baladN, (Ṣ, M,) He (a man, M) had a space clear from hair between his eyebrows: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or had eyebrows not joined. (M.)

baluda, aor. _u {yaboludu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. balaAdapN, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) inert; wanting in vigour; not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performance of affairs; (T, M, Ḳ,* TA;) [or soft, weak, feeble, wanting in endurance, or patience; (see baliydN;)] as also balida, aor. _a {yaboladu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. baladN. (TA.)
Also, inf. n. as above, said of a horse, meaning He lagged behind those that outstripped in running. (T, TA.) [See also 2.]
balada Als-aHaAbu: see 2.

2. bl-d, inf. n. taboliydN, He remained, stayed, or abode; [like balada;] or cast, or laid, himself down upon the ground; syn. Daraba binafosihi AlOaroDa: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he did so by reason of fatigue. (TA. [See 5.]) See also baliduwA.
He became languid, and affected laziness, after being brisk, lively, or sprightly. (A.)
He (a man) was impotent in work, and was weak; (T, L;) and so even in bounty, or liberality, (T,) or in running. (T,* L.)
He (a horse) failed to outstrip in running. (M, Ḳ.) [See also baluda.]

He was niggardly, or avaricious; was not liberal, nor generous. (M, Ḳ.) [And hence,] bal-adati Als-aHaAbapu, (Ḳ,) or balada↓ Als-aHaAbu, (M,) [but the latter is probably imperfectly transcribed,] The cloud, or clouds, gave no rain. (M, Ḳ.)
He did not apply himself rightly to anything. (M, Ḳ.)

bal-adati AljibaAli ‡ The mountains appeared low to the eye by reason of the darkness of the night: so in the L, confirmed by a citation from a poet: in the A, tabal-adati↓ AlbilaAdu ‡ The countries, or regions, appeared short [in extent] to the eye by reason of the darkness of the night. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. mubaAladapN [inf. n. of baAlada] The contending with another, or others, in fight, (i. q. mubaAlaTapN, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with swords and staves. (T, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Abld He clave to the ground, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in submissiveness. (TA.) [Perhaps formed by transposition from Oalobada: see mubolidN.]
See also 5.
His beast became dull; not to be rendered brisk, lively, or sprightly, by being put in motion. (AZ, Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
Abldhu makaAnFA He made him to keep to a place. (Ḳ.)
Abld, inf. n. UibolaAdN, It (a water-ing-trough or tank) was, or became, abandoned, and no longer used, so that it threatened to fall to ruin. (T.)
[And] Abldhu Ald-ahoru Time caused it (a watering-trough or tank) to become abandoned, and worn, and no longer used, so that it threatened to fall to ruin. (TA.) [See mubolidN.]
5. tbl-d He obtained, or exercised, dominion over a balad [i. e. country, or town,, &c.,] belonging to others. (Ḳ.)
He alighted, or sojourned, in a balad [or country,, &c.,] wherein was no one, (L, Ḳ,) saying within himself, O my grief, or sorrow, or regret! (L.)

He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (M, Ḳ;) he went backwards and forwards in confusion or perplexity, unable to see his right course: (T,* Ṣ:) because he who is in this state is like one in a balodap, meaning a desert in which he cannot find his way: (T, L:) he was overtaken by confusion, or perplexity, such that he was unable to see his right course; as also Oabolada↓. (TA.)
He fell to the ground, (Ḳ,) by reason of weakness. (TA.) [See also 2.]
He became submissive, and humble; (T, TA;) contr. of tajal-ada. (T, M, Ḳ.)
He affected balaAdap [i. e. stupidity, dulness, want of intelligence,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

† He turned his hands over, or upside-down: (Ḳ:) [thus one does in sorrow, or regret, or in perplexity: see Ḳur xviii. 40:] or the meaning is that which here next follows: (TA:) † he clapped his hands; or smote palm upon palm; syn. Saf-aqa (M, Ḳ) biAlkaf-i. (TA.) [See balodapN.]
[And hence, app.,] ‡ He felt, or expressed, grief, sorrow, or regret. (M, A, L, Ḳ.)
tabal-adati AlbilaAdu: see 2.
Accord. to AAF, tbl-d also signifies It (the dawn, or daybreak,) shone, was bright, or shone brightly; i. q. tbl-j. (M.)

entry.sense: baladN (which is masc. and fem., Mṣb) and balodapN↓ both signify the same; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, [A country, land, region, province, district, or territory: and a city, town, or village: or] any portion of the earth, or of land, comprehended within certain limits, [thus I render musotaHiyzap, and in like manner it is rendered in the TḲ,] cultivated, or inhabited, or uncultivated, or uninhabited: (M, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or the former signifies any place of this description; and the latter, a portion thereof: (T:) or the former is a generic name of a place [or country or region or province] such as El-'Irák and Syria; and the latter signifies a particular portion thereof such as [the city or town of] El-Basrah and Damascus; (M, Ḳ;) or these are post-classical applications: (TA:) or the former, a tract of land, or district, which is an abode, or a place of resort, of animals, or genii, even if containing no building: (Nh:) or a land, or country, absolutely: and also a town, or village, syn. qaroyapN: but this latter is a conventional adventitious application: ('Ináyeh, TA:) and the latter, a land, country, or territory, [belonging to, or inhabited by, a people,] syn. OaroDN: (Ṣ, TA: [a meaning assigned in the Ḳ to baladN; but this appears to be a mistake occasioned by the accidental omission of the word AlbalodapN:]) you say, hecihi balodatunaA [This is our land,, &c.] like as you say, hecihi baHoratunaA: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. (of the former, Ṣ, Mṣb) is bulodaAnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and (of the same, Ṣ, or of the latter, Mṣb) bilaAdN: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) [which latter, regarded as pl. of balodapN in a more limited sense than baladN, is often used as meaning provinces collectively; i. e. a country:] bulodaAnN is syn. with kuwarN [which signifies districts, or tracts of country; quarters, or regions; and also, cities, towns, or villages]. (T.) Albaladu and Albalodapu↓ are names applied to Mekkeh; (M, Ḳ;) in like manner as Aln-ajomu is a name applied to the Pleiades. (M.) [So too Albaladu AlOamiynu and Albaladu AlHaraAmu, &c.] baladN may-itN means A tract of land without herbage, or pasture: (Mṣb:) and baladN alone, a [desert, a waterless desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzapK. (TA voce tA; under which see an ex.)
baladN also signifies Land which has not been dug, and upon which fire has not been kindled. (M, Ḳ.)

A [house, or dwelling, such as is termed] dAr: (M, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.) Sb mentions the saying, hecihi Ald-aAru niEomati Albaladu [This house, excellent, or most excel-lent, is the dwelling!]; in which Albld is made fem. because it is syn. with AldAr. (M.)
A burial-ground: (M, Ḳ:) or, as some say, (M, but in the Ḳ “and,”) a grave, or sepulchre: (M, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (M.)
Dust, or earth; and so yalodapN↓. (T, M, Ḳ.)

The place in which an ostrich lays its egg, in sand. (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.) And hence, bayoDapu Albaladi The egg of the ostrich, which it abandons in the place where it lays it, in the sand, or in a desert: (M, L:) also called Albaladiy-api↓ and caAtu Albaladi. (M.) You say, fulaAnN bayoDapu Albaladi [‡ Such a one is like the egg of the ostrich,, &c.], meaning such a one is unequalled, or unparalleled: said in dispraise and in praise: (M,* L:) allowed by AʼObeyd to be used in praise: and said by El-Bekree to be applied to him who is separated from his family and near relations. (TA.) [See also art. byD.] You also say, huwa Oacal-u mino bayoDapi Albaladi (Ṣ, M, A) ‡ He is more object, or vile, than the egg of the ostrich, which it abandons (Ṣ, TA) in the desert, and to which it does not return. (TA.) [See again art. byD.] Also huwa OaEaz-a mino bayoDapi Albaladi ‡ [He is more highly esteemed than the egg of the ostrich, which it lays in the sand]; because the ostrich spreads its wings over it and sits upon it. (A in art. frx.) [See more in art. byD]

A trace, mark, or vestige, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in the Ḳ mentioned in two places, but in the latter of these omitted in the CK,]) of a house, or dwelling: (TA:) and a mark remaining upon the body: (AʼObeyd, T:) pl. OabolaAdN. (Ṣ, AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ.)
The origin, or an element, (EunoSur,) of a thing. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph, in three places:
and see bulodapN.

hom.sense: balodapN: see baladN, in three places. You say, Uino lamo tafoEalo kacaA fahiIa balodapN bayoniI wabayonika ‡ If thou do not thus, it will be [a cause of] separation between me and thee; (M,* A, TA;) i. e., I will alienate thee from me so that a country, or region, shall separate us, each from the other. (A, TA.)

Also A desert, or waterless desert, in which one cannot find his way: and any extensive tract of land. (T, L.) [Hence,] laqiytuhu bibalodapi UiSomati I found him, or met him, in a desert, or desolate, place, in which there was no one beside. (M.) [See also art. Smt.]

And [hence, app.,] Albalodapu One of the Mansions of the Moon, (M, Ḳ,) [namely, the Twenty-first Mansion,] a patch of the sky, (Ḳ,) containing no stars, (M, Ḳ,) or containing only small stars, (T,* M,) between the naEaAYim and saEod Alc-aAbiH: (M, Ḳ:) sometimes the moon declines from it, and takes as its mansion the qilaAdap: it [app. AlqlAdp, accord. to the Ḳ, but accord. to the TA Albldp,] consists of six stars resembling a bow, (Ḳ,) in the sign of Sagittarius (Alqawos): (T:) or Albldp is one of the Mansions of the Moon, consisting of six stars of Sagittarius (Alqws), which the sun enters on the shortest day of the year: (Ṣ:) [see manaAzilu Alqamar, in art. nzl: in the Ḳ it is also said that Albaladu↓ is a Mansion of the Moon; but this appears to be a mistake, occasioned by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu; though Albaladu would seem to be an appropriate name for the mansion next after the nEAYm:] IF says that Albalodapu is a star, or an asterism, (najomN,) said to be the balodap, i. e. breast, of the Lion; not meaning the mansion thus called in the sign of Sagittarius: El-Ḥareeree finds fault with him for using this expression, [the bldp of the Lion,] but Ibn-Dhafr replies that it occurs in the language. (TA.)
balodapN also signifies The earth, or ground. (Ṣ.)

Also (Ṣ, M, L, TA, [in the Ḳ balad↓, by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu,]) the pit between the two collar-bones, with the part around it: or the middle thereof, i. e., of that pit: (M, Ḳ:) or the third of the falak (which are six in number) of that part of a horse's breast which is called the zawur: or the part called raHaI Alz-awori: (M:) or [so accord. to the M, but accord. to the Ḳ “and,”] the breast, syn. Sador, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) of a camel, (M, A,) or of that which has a foot like the camel's, and of a solid-hoofed animal, (M,) and of a man: (A:) and the part immediately beneath the two prominent portions of flesh of the breast of a horse, extending to the arms. (M, L.) Dhu-rRummeh says,
Ouniyxato faOaloqato balodapF fawoqa balodapK
She (the camel) was made to lie down, and threw her breast upon [a tract of] ground. (Ṣ, M.) And you say, fulaAnN waAsiEu Albalodapi Such a one is wide in the breast. (Ṣ.)

Also ‡ The palm of the hand. (M, A, TA. [In the Ḳ, by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu, this meaning is assigned to baladN↓.]) You say, Daraba balodatahu EalaI balodatihi ‡ He smote the palm of his hand upon his breast. (A.)
See also bulodapN, in two places:
and see balaAdapN.

bulodapN (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and balodapN↓ (Ṣ, M, L) and baladN↓ [which is an inf. n. of balida] (Ṣ, Ḳ) Clearness, from hair, of the space between the eyebrows: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) i. q. bulojapN: or more than bulojapN: or the having the eyebrows not joined: (M:) or ↓the second signifies the space between the eyebrows. (M.)
And the first, The form, aspect, appearance, or lineaments, of the face. (Ḳ.)
See also balaAdapN.

entry.sense: Albaladiy-apu: see baladN.

baliydN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OaboladN↓ (M, Ḳ) Stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) inert; wanting in vigour; not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs: (T, M, Ḳ:*) [soft, weak, feeble; wanting in endurance, or patience:] contr. of jaliydN. (Ḳ.)
Also the former, A horse that lags behind those that outstrip in running: (T, TA:) and a camel (TA) not to be rendered brisk, lively, or sprightly, by being put in motion. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
See also maboluwdN.

balAdapN [an inf. n. (of baluda) used as a subst.] (Ṣ, M, A) and bulodapN↓ and balodapN↓ (M, TA) Stupidity, dulness, want of intelligence, (Ṣ, A,) or of penetration, sharpness, vigour, or effectiveness, in the performing of affairs. (M, TA.)
baAlidN Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) in a balad [i. e. country, or town,, &c.], (Mṣb,) or in a place. (Ṣ.)
taAlidN baAlidN Lasting; that does not cease, or fail, or pass away: the former word signifies old; and the latter is [said to be] an imitative sequent. (TA.)

hom.sense: OaboladN A man having a space clear from hair between his eyebrows: or having eyebrows not joined: i. q. Oabolaju. (Ṣ, M.)

[More, and most, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence, or in penetration, sharpness, vigour, or effectiveness, in the performing of affairs: see baluda.] You say, Oaboladu mino vaworK [More stupid,, &c., than a bull]. (A.)
See also baliydN.
A man (Ṣ) of large, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) big, gross, rude, or coarse, (M,) make. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
mubolidN, (Ḳ,) or muboladN, (T,) Old; applied to a watering-trough or tank. (T, Ḳ.) So in the words of a poet, describing a watering-trough or tank,
wamuboladK bayona mawomaApK bimaholakapK
formed by transposition from mulobida, which [properly] means cleaving to the ground: (IAạr, T, TA:) or it is mubolad, (TA,) or mubolid, (T,) which means abandoned, and worn, and no longer used, so that it threatens to fall to ruin. (T, TA.)

maboluwdN Confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: [a pass. part. n., but] it has no verb answering to it: (M, TA:) or idiotic; deficient, or wanting, in intellect; or bereft thereof: (Esh-Sheybánee, M, Ḳ:) or unable to proceed in, or prosecute, his journey, his means having failed him, or his camel that bore him stopping with him from fatigue or breaking down or perishing, or an event befalling him so that he cannot move: (Aṣ, M:) all of these significations refer to confusion or perplexity: (M, L:) or one whose modesty, or shame, or whose intellect, has quitted him; as also baliydN↓. (TA.)

Tiynu QloUiboliyzi The mud of Egypt; (Ḳ;) what the Nile leaves behind it after retiring from the surface of the ground: (TA:) a foreign word [arabicized, perhaps from the Greek πηλὸς, as suggested by De Sacy; who also remarks that it might be derived from the Greek ἰλὺς with the Egyptian masc. art. πι, were it not that ἰλὺς is fem.: (see his “Abd-allatif,” p. 8:) if we might suppose Ablyz to be an old mistranscription for Aylyz, we might with good reason derive it from ἰλὺς, which, as pronounced by the modern Greeks, very nearly resembles Uiyliyz in sound]: (Ḳ:) [some of] the vulgar pronounce it with s. (TA.)
[Also applied to Clay; plastic clay; or potters' earth.]

hom.sense: 4. Abls, (inf. n. UibolaAsN, Ṣ, &c.,) He despaired, (A boo-Bekr, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or gave up hope, (A boo-Bekr, TA,) mino raHomapi Qll-ehi of the mercy of God. (A boo-Bekr, Ṣ, TA.)
He became broken [in spirit], and mournful. (Ṣ, TA.)
He was, or became, silent, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) returning no reply, or answer, (TA,) by reason of grief, (Ṣ,) or of despair. (A.)
He was, or became, confounded or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ.)
He was, or became, cut short, or stopped, (Ḳ, TA,) fiI Huj-atihi [in his argument, or plea]. (TA.)
He became unable to prosecute his journey: or was prevented from attaining his wish: syn. quTiEa bihi. (Th, M, TA.)
He repented; or grieved for what he had done. (M.)
He caused a person to despair. (Ḥar p. 138.)

entry.sense: balisN Despairing, (mubolisN,) and silent respecting what is in his mind, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of grief or fear. (TA.)

balaAsN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like salaAmN, (Mṣb,) and saHaAbN, (Ḳ,) [in a copy of the M written bilaAsN,] A [garment, or piece of stuff, of the kind called] misoH [i. e. of hair-cloth]: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) used in this sense by the people of El-Medeeneh: (Ṣ:) a Persian word; (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb;) originally balaAsN, without Al: (TA:) arabicized: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) also called by the Arabs PalaAs, with the b termed muXab-aE: (TA:) pl. bulusN. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [The pl.] bulusN is also applied to Large sacks of musuwH [i. e. hair-cloths], in which figs are put, [or, more probably, in which straw is put, for Alt-iyn, which I find in two copies of the Ṣ and in the TA, can hardly be doubted to be a mistranscription of Alt-ibon], and upon which is paraded he who is made a public example that others may take warning from him, and the subject of a proclamation [acquainting the spectators with his offence]: whence the imprecation, OaraAniyka Qll-ehu EalaI Albulusi [May God show me thee upon the large haircloth-sacks]. (Ṣ, TA.)

balasaAnN [The balsam-tree; or the species that produces the balsam of Mekkeh; i. e., the amyris opobalsamum;] a certain kind of tree, (M,) or shrub, resembling the Hin-aMC, (Ḳ,) having many leaves, inclining to white, in odour resembling the sacaAb [or rue], (TA,) the berry of which has an unguent, (Lth, M, TA,) which is hot, (Lth, TA,) and its unguent is in great request: (Lth, Ḳ, TA:) its unguent [opobalsamum] is more potent than its berry [carpobalsamum], and its berry is more so than its wood [xylobalsamum] : the best of its wood is the smooth, tawny-coloured, pungent and sweet in odour: it is hot and dry in the second degree; and its berry is a little hotter than it: its wood opens stoppages of the nose, and is good for the sciatica and vertigo and headache, and clears cloudiness of the eye, and is good for asthma and oppression of the breath, and for flaccidity of the womb, used by fumigation; it is also beneficial in cases of barrenness, and counteracts poisons and the bite of vipers: (the Minháj, TA:) it is said in the Ḳ and in the Minháj, and by most of the physicians and those who treat of drugs, that it grows only at ʼEyn-Shems, in the neighbourhood of El-Káhireh, the place called El-Matareeyeh; but MF observes that this is strange, as it is well known that it is mostly found in the district of El-Ḥijáz, between the Harameyn and El-Yembo', whence it is conveyed to all countries: the truth, however, is, that it ceased to grow at ʼEyn-Shems in the latter part of the eighth century [of the Flight], and it was endeavoured [successfully] to be made to grow in El-Ḥijáz. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's “Abd-allatif,” p. 89.]
bal-aAsN One who sells what is termed balaAs. (Ḳ.)

Uiboliysu [A name of Satan]; from Oabolasa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the first of the senses assigned to it above, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) accord. to some; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) his former name being EazaAziylu: (Ṣ, TA:) or it is a foreign word, (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and for this reason, (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, Mṣb, TA,) and its being also determinate, (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, TA,) or a proper name, (Mṣb,) it is imperfectly decl.; (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, &c.;) for if it were an Arabic word, it would be perfectly decl., like UijofiylN and UixoriyTN. (Mṣb.)
balasaAnN: see art. bls.

hom.sense:
1. balaTa, (IDrd, Ḳ,) [aor., accord. to a rule observed in the Ḳ, _u,] inf. n. baloTN, (IDrd, TA,) He spread, or paved, (Ḳ, TA,) a house, (Ḳ,) and the ground, (TA,) with balaAT [or flag-stones], (Ḳ, TA,) or with baked bricks; (TA;) as also bl-T↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboliyTN; (TA;) and AblT↓: (Ḳ:)
or, as also ↓the second, he made [or constructed] a wall with balaAT: (IDrd, TA:) or ↓the second, he made a house plain, or even. (TA.)
He struck him, or it, with the baloT [q. v.]. (TA.)
2: see 1, in three places.

The vulgar phrase bal-iTi Als-afiynapa signifies Make thou fast the ship; as though it were an order to make it cleave to the ground. (TA.) [You say, bal-aTa Als-afiynapa fiI Alr-amoli, meaning He ran the ship aground upon the sand.]

entry.sense: 3. bAlT Alqawomu baniI fulaAnK The people, or company of men, alighted with the sons of such a one, each party to oppose the other, upon the ground: (Ḳ,* TA:) from balaATN signifying the “earth,” or “ground;” or “even, smooth ground.” (TA.) bAlT Alqawomu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAlaTapN, (Ṣ,) The people, or company of men, contended, one with another, in fight with swords, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA,) upon their feet; (TA;) as also tbAlTwA↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mbAlTp is only upon the ground; (Z, TA;) and you do not say tbAlTwA when the people are riders. (TA.)
baAlaTaniI He fled from me, (AḤn, Ḳ,) and went away in the land: (AḤn, TA:) or he left me; quitted me. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. OabolaTa He clave to the [balaAT, i. e.] earth, or ground; (Ḳ;) said of a man: (TA:) he became bankrupt, or insolvent, or reduced to a state of difficulty or poverty, or without any property, and clave to the balaAT: (AHeyth:) he became poor, and his property went away; as also OuboliTa: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says Ks; and AZ says the like: (Ṣ:) or he became poor; or had little property. (TA.)
OabolaTa All-iS-u Alqawoma The robber left the people, or company of men, upon the surface of the ground, and left them not anything: (Lḥ, TA:) or simply, left them not anything. (Ḳ.)
AblT AlmaTaru AlOaroDa The rain fell upon the balaAT [or surface] of the earth, (Ḳ, TA,) so that no dust was seen upon it. (TA.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 6: see 3.

baloTN and buloTN↓ [An axe;] i. q. mixoraTN; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. the iron instrument with which the xar-aAT barks and planes (yaxoriTu) [a branch of a tree]: an Arabic word: the vulgar call it baloTapN↓ [now mostly applied to a battle-axe; in Turkish baAlotaho]. (TA.) AḤn says, An Arab of the desert quoted to me,
faQlobaloTu yaboriI Hiyada AlfarofaAri
[And the axe pares off the knobs, or knots, of the tree called farfár]: HayodapN [the sing. of HiyadN] signifying a knob (siloEap) in a tree; or a knot; which is cut off, and whereof vessels are shaped out, so that they are variegated and beautiful. (TA.)
buloTN: see baloTN.
baloTapN: see baloTN.

buloTiI-N [The labrus Niloticus;] a kind of fish that is found in the Nile, said to eat of the leaves of Paradise: it is the best of fish: and they liken to it him who is rising out of childhood, in a state of youthfulness and tenderness or delicateness. (TA.)
balaATN The earth, or ground: (TA:) or even, smooth ground. (Ḳ, TA.)
The face, or surface, of the earth, or ground: (Ḳ:) or the part where what is hard, thereof, i. e. of the earth or ground, ends: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or the hard part of the exterior thereof. (A, TA.)
Any ground, or floor, paved with such stones, or with baked bricks; (Ḳ;) [a pavement.]
You say with respect to a niggardly and mean man, maA caA yaOoxucu Alr-iyHu mina AlbalaATi [What will the wind take from the pavement?]. (TA.)
And rajulN balaATN † A man poor, or in want. (TA.)
And Uin-ahaA Hasanapu AlbalaATi UicaA jur-idato ‡ Verily she is goodly, or beautiful, in skin when she is stripped. (TA.)

bal-uwTo [The acorn;] a certain thing well known; (Ṣ;) the fruit, or produce, of a kind of tree, [namely, the oak,] which is eaten, (Mgh, Mṣb,) sometimes, (Mṣb,) and with the bark of which one tans, (Mgh, Mṣb,) sometimes: (Mṣb:) or [the oak; or this kind of tree is properly called Xajaru Albal-uwTi;] a kind of tree; the fruit, or produce, whereof they used as food, in ancient times; cold and dry (Ḳ, TA) in the second degree, or, as some say, in the first; or its dryness is in the third degree; or it is hot in the first degree; (TA;) heavy, coarse, (Ḳ, TA,) slow of digestion, bad for the stomach, occasioning headache, injurious to the bladder, but rendered good by its being roasted and having sugar added to it; (TA;) suppressing the urine, (Ḳ, TA,) and rendering it difficult; preventing exhaustion by loss of blood, and the emission of blood [from a wound]; good for hardnesses, with the fat of a kid; preventing the progress of [the disease in the mouth called] qulaAE, and frwE [app. a mistake for quruwH, or wounds], when it is burnt; preventing also excoriation, and poisons, and looseness of the bowels; and very nutritious when easily digested. (TA.) [See also EafoSN.]
[Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt., p. lvi., mentions this name as applied to The common ash-tree; fraxinus excelsior.]

bal-uwTu Almaliki, according to some, The walnut: accord. to others, the XaAhobal-uwT [a Persian word, and also used by Arabs in the present day, applied to the chestnut]: as is said in the Minháj. (TA.)

bal-uwT AlOaroDi [applied in the present day to The herb germander, or chamædrys;] a certain plant, the leaves of which resemble the hinodi baMC [or endive]: it is diuretic; aperient; and wasting to the spleen. (Ḳ.)
balaAliyTN Level, or even, lands, or tracts of ground: (Ḳ:) no sing. to it is known. (Seer.) [See also balaATN.]
[muboliTN and mubolaTN, as epithets applied to a man, part. ns. of OabolaTa and OuboliTa, which see above.]

1. baliEahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabolaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. baloEN, (TA, [and the same is indicated in the Ḳ,]) or balaEN when the object is food, but baloEN when it is water or spittle; (Mṣb;) and balaEahu, aor. _a {yabolaEu}, inf. n. baloEN; (Mṣb;) and AbtlEhu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tbl-Ehu↓; (IAạr;) and baloEamahu↓, inf. n. baloEamapN; (Ṣ * and TA in art. blEm;) He swallowed it. (IAạr, TA.) It is said in a proverb, laA yaSoluHu rafiyqFA mino lmo yabotaliEo↓ riyqFA [He is not suitable, or fit, for being a companion who does not swallow his spittle; meaning, † who does not restrain his anger]. (TA.) You say also, baloEama↓ All-uqomapa meaning He ate the morsel. (TA in art. blEm.) And balaEa AlT-aEaAma and AbtlEhu↓ also signify [He swallowed the food without chewing it;] he did not chew the food. (TA.)

2. bl-E AlX-ayobu fiyhi, (Ḳ,) or fiI raOosihi, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. taboliyEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Hoariness began to appear (Ṣ, Ḳ) upon him, (Ḳ,) or upon his head: (Ṣ:) or rose: (A, TA:) or spread much. (TA.) [See also bal-aga.] Hassán says,
qado bal-aEato biI curoOapN faOaloHafato
[Hoariness, or grayness, or the like, had begun to appear,, &c., upon me, and marred me]; making the verb trans. by bi because it has the meaning of qado Mlamato [it had given pain, and this verb is thus made trans.]; or substituting biI for fiI-a on account of the measure, which would not be right if he said fiI-a. (TA.) You say also, tbl-E↓ fiyhi AlX-ayobu Hoariness appeared upon him. (IAạr.)

4. AblEhu AlX-aIoCa (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA) He made him to swallow the thing: (Ṣ, TA:) or he enabled him to swallow the thing. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, OaboliEoniI riyqiI [Suffer thou me to swallow my spittle;] give thou me time to swallow my spittle. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 5: see 1:
and 2.

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 1. baloEama: see 1, in two places. [The m in this word is generally held to be augmentative: see baloEamN.]

hom.sense: bulaEN, applied to a man, Voracious; a great eater; as also bulaEapN↓ and mibolaEN↓ (Ḳ) and bawolaEN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) [bal-aAEo↓ signifies the same:] and hibolaEN↓, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. hblE,) in which the h is said by some to be augmentative, (TA,) and habal-aEN↓ (Lth, Ḳ) and hibolaAEN↓, (IDrd, Ḳ,) also signify the same; (Ṣ in art. hblE;) or voracious, or a great eater, who takes large mouthfuls, and is wide in the Hunojuwr [app. here meaning the fauces]: (Lth, and Ḳ in art. mblE:) and bulaEapN↓, applied to a woman, one who swallows everything. (Fr.) yaA bal-aAEa↓ AlOayori [app. meaning yaA maOobuwnu] is an expression of vituperation used by the people of Syria. (TA.)

saEodu bulaEa, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) determinate, (Lth, Ḳ,) [the latter word imperfectly decl.,] One of the Mansions of the Moon; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [namely, the Twenty-third;] which rose [aurorally], (Ṣ, Ḳ,)
as they assert, (Ṣ,) when God said, yaA OaroDu QbolDEiI maMCaki [Ḳur xi. 46]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) consisting of two stars near together; (Ṣ;) or two stars, straight (musotawiyaAni) in course, (IḲt, Ḳ,) or near together and oblique; (TA;) one of them dim, and the other bright, and called baAliEN↓, as though it swallowed the former, (IḲt, Ḳ, TA,) namely, the dim one, and took its light: (TA:) it rises [aurorally] in the last night but one [lit. one night remaining] of kaAnuwn AlMxir [Jan., O. Ṣ.], and sets [aurorally] when one night has passed of Mb [Aug., O. Ṣ.]. (IḲt, Ḳ.) [Accord. to my calculation, it thus rose in Arabia about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 29th of Jan., O. Ṣ., and set aurorally on the 30th of July. See manaAzili Alqamari, in art. nzl: and see also saEodN.] The rhyming-proser of the Arabs says, UicaA TalaEa saEodu bulaEo AiqotaHama Alr-ubaEo walaHiqa AlhubaEo waSiyada AlmuraEo waSaAra fiI AlOaroDi lumaEo [When Saad-Bula' rises aurorally,] the rubaE [or young camel brought forth in the season called rabiyE, which is the beginning of the breeding-time,] becomes strong in his walk, and quick, but not strong to labour, and the hubaE [or young camel brought forth in the end of the breeding-time] acquires some strength, and attains to him, and the muraE, a kind of bird, is then, it seems, caught, or snared, [and parts differing in colour from the rest become apparent in the earth.] (TA.)

Also The hole, or perforation, of the bakorap [or sheave of a pulley]: n. un. with p: (Ḳ:) or the hole, or perforation, in the qaAmap of the bakorap [which here means the pulley, or sheave with its apparatus]: (Ṣ:) or bulaEapu↓ has this latter signification; and bulaEN is its pl.; [or is a coll. gen. n.;] so explained by Az; and this is the correct explanation. (Marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ.)

entry.sense: buloEapN A gulp, or as much as one swallows at once, of beverage; like juroEapN. (TA.)

hom.sense: bulaEapN, as an epithet: see bulaEN, in two places:
and as a subst.: see the same, last sentence.

entry.sense: baloEamN, applied to a man, (Ṣ,) That eats much, and swallows food vehemently. (Ṣ, Ḳ *) The m is augmentative, (Ṣ,) accord. to most authorities. (TA.)
buloEumN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: buloEuwmN and buloEumN↓; (Mṣb, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. blEm;) the latter a contraction of the former; the m augmentative; (Mṣb;) The place of passage of the food in the Haloq; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) the gullet, or œsophagus; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also mabolaEN↓: (TA:) or this last, i. q. HaloqN [which is properly the fauces; but by a synecdoche, the throat, or gullet]. (Ḳ.) [See an ex. voce suromN.]
Also, the first, A torrent, in ground such as is termed quf-, entering into the earth. (AḤn, and Ḳ in art. blEm.)
And The whiteness that is upon the lip of the ass, (Ḳ in art. blEm,) at the extremity of the mouth- (TA in that art.)
baluwEN a subst- signifying A medicine which is swallowed. (TA.)
Beverage: or wine: syn. XaraAbN. (TA.)
qidorN baluwEN ‡ A wide cooking-pot, (A, Ḳ, TA,) that swallows what is thrown into it. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: bal-aAEN: see bulaEN, in two places.
bal-aAEapN: see baAluwEapN.
bal-uwEapN: see baAluwEapN.
bul-ayoEapN: see baAluwEapN.
baAliEN: see bulaEN.
bawolaEN: see bulaEN.

baAluwEapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of El-Basrah, (TA,) and bal-uwEapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bal-aAEapN↓, (Ḳ,) and bul-ayoEapN↓, (TA,) A hole, or perforation, in the midst of a house; (Ṣ;) a sink-hole; a hole, or perforation, into which water descends: (Mṣb:) or a well that is dug (Ḳ, TA) in the midst of a house, (TA,) narrow at the head, into which run the rain-water and the like: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. [of the first] bawaAliyEu (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and [of the others] balaAliyEu. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mabolaEN: see buloEuwmN.
mibolaEN: see bulaEN.
mubolaEapN A well (rakiy-apN) cased with stones, or with baked bricks, from the bottom to the brink: (O, TṢ, Ḳ:) from Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
hibolaEN: see bulaEN.
habal-aEN: see bulaEN.
hibolaAEN: see bulaEN.
baloEama: see blE.
balEEamN: see blE.
buloEumN: see blE.
buloEuwmN: see blE.

hom.sense:
1. [buluwgN inf. n. of balaga] and UibolaAgN [inf. n. of Ablg↓, but it seems that AblAg is here a mistranscription for balaAgN, which is, like buluwgN, an inf. n. of balaga, and this observation will be found to be confirmed by a statement immediately following this sentence,] signify The reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, the utmost point of that to which, or towards which, one tends or repairs or betakes himself, to which one directs his course, or which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, intends, or purposes; whether it be a place, or a time, or any affair or state or event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed: and sometimes, the being at the point thereof: so says Abu-1-Kásim in the Mufradát. (TA: [in which it is said, in the supplement to the present art., that balaAgN signifies The reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, a thing.]) You say, balaga AlmakaAna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Almanozila, (Mṣb,) [aor. _u {yabolugu},] inf. n. buluwgN (Ṣ, Ḳ) [and balaAgN, as shown above], He reached, attained, arrived at, or came to, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the place, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the place of abode: (Mṣb:) and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or,”) he was, or became, at the point of reaching it, attaining it,, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) fabalagona Oajalahuna, in the Ḳur [ii. 232], means And they have fully attained, or ended, their term. (Mṣb.) But faUicaA balagona Oajalahun-a, in the same [lxv. 2], means And when they are near to attaining, or ending, their term: (Ṣ, TA:) or are at the point of accomplishing their term. (Mṣb, TA.) It has the first of the meanings explained above in the phrase, balaga OaXud-ahu [Ḳur xii. 22, &c., He attained his manly vigour, or full maturity,, &c.]. (TA.) And in balagaOarobaEiyna sanapF [Ḳur xlvii. 14, He attained the age of forty years]. (TA.) And in balaga maEahu Als-aEoIa [Ḳur xxxvii. 100, He attained to working with him]. (TA.) In the Ḳur [iii. 35], occurs the phrase, waqado balaganiIa Alkibaru [When old age hath come to me, or overtaken me]: and in another place [xix. 9], waqado balagotu mina Alkibari Eutiy-FA [And I have reached the extreme degree of old age: so explained in the Expos. of the Jel]: phrases like OadorakaniIa Aljahodu and Oadorakotuhu. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say also, lazimahu celika baAligFA↓ maA balaga with the accus. case as a denotative of state; meaning [That clave to him, or adhered to him,, &c.,] rising to its highest degree or point; from balaga Almanozila, explained above. (Mṣb.) [But baAligFA↓ maA balaga more frequently means Whatever point, degree, amount, sum, quantity, number, or the like, it may reach, attain, arrive at, come to, or amount to.] And balaga fulaAnN mabolagahu↓ and mabolagatuhu↓ [Such a one reached, or attained, his utmost point or scope or degree]. (TA.) And balaga fiI AlEilomi AlmabaAliga↓ [He attained, in knowledge, or science, the utmost degrees of proficiency]. (TA.) And balaga fiI Aljawodapi mabolagFA↓ [It reached a consummate degree in goodness]. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) And balaga mina Aljawodapi mabolagFA↓ [He attained a consummate degree of goodliness]: said of a boy that has attained to puberty. (O, TA.) And balaga gaAyatahu fiI AlT-alabi [He did his utmost, or used his utmost power or ability, in seeking to attain an object]. (Mṣb in art. jhd.) And balaga OaqoSaI majohuwdi baEiyrihi fiI Als-ayori [He exerted the utmost endeavour, or effort, or power, or strength, of his camel, in journeying]. (Ṣ in art. nkv.) And balaga jahoda daAb-atihi i. q. jahadahaA [He jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied, his beast]: (Ḳ in art. jhd:) and in like manner, balaga maXaq-atahu and balaga minohu AlmaXaq-apa i. q. jahadahu [and Xaq-a Ealayohi, i. e. He, or it, jaded him, harassed him,, &c.; ditressed him, afflicted him, oppressed him, overpowered him: thus in each of these instances, as in many similar cases, the verb with the inf. n. that follows is equivalent to the verb of that inf. n.]. (Mṣb in art. jhd.) [And, elliptically, balaga minohu i. q. balaga minohu AlmXaq-apa, explained above: and often meaning It took, or had, an effect upon him; it affected him: frequently said of wine and the like: and of a saying; as in the Ksh and Bḍ in iv. 66, where yabolugu minohumo is followed by wayuWaviru fiyhi as an explicative: see also baliygN.]
And balagota min-aA Albulagiyna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Albilagiyna, and kul-a mabolagK: (Ḳ:) see Albulagiyna below. And balagotu mina AlOamori AlmaXaq-apa [I experienced distress from the affair, or event]. (TA in art. mD.) [See also an ex. voce UibidN. balaganiI also signifies It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told me; or it came to my knowledge,, &c.: and in this case it is generally followed by Oan-a, or by Oano as a contraction of Oan-a: for exs., see these two particles. And in like manner, balaganiI Eanohu Information has come to me, or information came to me, from him, or concerning him, that such a thing has happened, or had happened.] And balaga said of a letter or writing, inf. n. balaAgN and buluwgN, It reached, arrived, or came. (Mṣb.) And said of a plant, or of herbage, It attained its full growth: (TA:) and of a tree, such as a palm-tree, &c., its fruit became ripe: (AḤn, TA:) and of fruit, it became ripe. (Mṣb.) Also, said of a boy, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yabolugu}, inf. n. buluwgN, or, as IḲooṭ says, balaAgN, (Mṣb,) He attained to puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity; syn. Oadoraka, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AiHotalama; (M, Mṣb;) and attained a consummate degree of goodliness (balaga mina Aljawodapi mabolagFA): (O, TA:) as though he attained the time of the writing of his marriage-contract, and of his having duties or obligations imposed upon him: (TA:) and in like manner one says of a girl, balaga, (T, TA,) or balagato. (TA.)

balaga Qll-ehu bihi [God caused him to reach, attain, arrive at, or come to, his appointed end, or term of life; Oajalahu, or the like, being understood]. (TA.) You say, balaga Qll-ehu bika OakolaOa AlEumuri, i. e. [May God cause thee to reach, or attain,] the extreme, or most distant, period of life! (Ṣ and TA in art. klO.) And faEalotu bihi maA balaga bihi AlOacaI waAlmakoruwho [I did with him that which caused him to come to what was annoying, or hurtful, and evil]. (TA.) And balaga bihi Albilagiyna: see the last word of this phrase below.
buliga, like EuniIa, He (a man) was, or became, jaded, harasssed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied. (Ḳ.)

baluga, [aor. _u {yabolugu},] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. balaAgapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He was, or became baliyg, i. e. faSiyH [more properly signifying chaste, or perspicuous, in speech, but here meaning eloquent]; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and sharp, or penetrating, or effective, in tongue; (Mṣb;) attaining, by his speech, or diction, the utmost scope of his mind and desire. (Ḳ,* TA.) The difference between balaAgapN and faSaAHapN is this: that the latter is an attribute of a single word and of speech and of the speaker; but the former is an attribute only of speech and the speaker: (Kull:) blAgp in the speaker is A faculty whereby one is enabled to compose language suitable to the exigency of the case, i. e., to the occasion of speaking [or writing], with chasteness, or perspicuity, or eloquence, thereof: in language, it is suitableness to the exigency of the case, i. e., to the occasion of speaking [or writing], with chasteness or perspicuity, or eloquence, thereof. (KT.)

2. taboliygN and UibolaAgN↓ [inf. ns. of bl-g and Ablg] signify The causing to reach, attain, arrive, or come; bringing, conveying, or delivering: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) the former is the more common. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [You say, bl-ghu AlmakaAna He caused him, or it, to reach, attain, arrive at, or come to, the place. And bl-ghu maqoSuwdahu He caused him to attain his object of aim or endeavour, &c.] And bal-agotu Alr-isaAlapa [I brought, conveyed, or delivered, the message]. (Ṣ.) And bl-ghu Als-alaAma, (Mṣb,) and Alxabara, (TA,) as also Ablghu↓, (Mṣb, TA,) He brought, conveyed, delivered, or communicated, to him the salutation, (Mṣb,) and he brought,, &c., or told, to him the news, or information. (TA.) [And bal-aganiI Eano fulaAnK He told me from such a one, or on the part of such a one, some piece of information, or that some event had happened, &c.]

bl-g AlfaArisu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboliygN, (Ḳ,) The horseman stretched forth, or extended, his hand, or arm, with the rein of his horse, [or gave the rein to his horse,] in order that he might increase in his running. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

bl-g AlX-ayobu fiI raOosihi Hoariness began to appear on his head; accord. to IAạr; as also bl-E, with the unpointed E: the Basrees assert that the former is a mistranscription; but it is related as heard from Th, by Aboo-Bekr Eṣ-Ṣoolee. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. bAlg, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAlagapN (JK, Ḳ, &c.) and bilaAgN, (Ḳ.) He exceeded the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds, or degree, in a thing; acted egregiously, or immoderately, or extravagantly, therein: (KL:) he strove, or laboured; exerted himself, or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, sedulously, earnestly, with energy or effectiveness; took pains, or extraordinary pains: (Ḳ, TA:) he did not fall short of doing what was requisite, or what he ought; did not flag, or was not remiss: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he exerted unsparingly his power or ability, or effort or endeavour, or the utmost thereof: (Mṣb:) he accomplished, or did, or attained, the utmost of his power or ability, or effort or endeavour; he did his utmost: (JK:) fiI OamorK [in an affair]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or fiI kacaA, meaning in the pursuit of such a thing. (Mṣb.) [bAlg fiI kacaA may be rendered as above, or He did such a thing much, exceedingly, egregiously, extraordinarily, immoderately, extravagantly, excessively, vehemently, energetically, superlatively, excellently, consummately, thoroughly. Hence mubaAlagapN in explanations of words; meaning Intensiveness; muchness; extraordinariness; excessiveness; vehemence; energy; emphasis; hyperbole;, &c.; and sometimes, frequentative signification. Thus, Uisomu mubaAlagapK means A noun of intensiveness; or an intensive epithet: as XakuwrN “very thankful,” or “very grateful;” and Ham-aAdN “a great praiser,” or “a frequent praiser.”]

hom.sense: 4. Ablg, inf. n. UibolaAgN: see 2, in two places. [Hence,] Ablg AlOamora jahodahu [He brought his utmost power or ability, or effort or endeavour, to the performance, or accomplishment, of the affair]. (TA.) And Oabolagotu Uilayohi i. e. faEalotu bihi maA balaga bihi AlOacaI waAlmakoruwha [I did with him that which caused him to come to what was annoying, or hurtful, and evil]. (TA.)
See also 1, first sentence; where it is said that UibolaAgN is syn. with buluwgN; but this is app. a mistake.
[maA Oabolagahu, and Oaboligo bihi, How eloquent is he!].

entry.sense: 5. tbl-g Almanozila He constrained himself to reach, or attain, the place of abode, until, or so that, he did reach [it], or attain [it]. (Ḳ.)
tbl-g bihi He was satisfied, or content, with it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and attained his desire [thereby]. (TA.)
tabal-agato bihi AlEil-apu The disease, or malady, distressed him; afflicted him; became vehement, or severe, in him. (Ṣ, Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 6. tbAlg Ald-ibaAgu fiI Aljilodi The tan attained its utmost effect in the skin. (AḤn.) And tbAlg fiyhi Alh-amu, and AlmaraDa, Anxiety, or disquietude of mind, or grief, attained its utmost degree in him, and so disease, or the disease. (TA.) [This verb seems properly to signify It reached, or attained, by degrees.]

tbAlg fiI kalaAmihi He affected eloquence (balaAgap) in his speech, not being of those characterized thereby: [whence] one says, maA huwa bibaliygK walekino yatabaAligu [He is not eloquent, but he affects eloquence]. (TA.)
balogN: see what next follows, in three places:
and see baAligN, in two places:
and baliygN, in two places.

Qll-ehuma simoEN laA bilogN, and samoEN laA balogN↓, (Ks, Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and samoEFA laA balogFA↓, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and simoEFA laA bilogFA, (Ḳ,) O God, may we hear of it (or may it be heard of, IB) but may it not be fulfilled; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or, may it not reach us, or come to us: said on hearing of a displeasing, or hateful, or an evil, event: (L:) or on hearing tidings not pleasing to one: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or on the coming of tidings not held to be true. (TA.) [See also art. smE.]

OaHomaqu bilogN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and balogN↓, and balogapN↓, (Ḳ,) Stupid, or foolish, but, notwithstanding his stupidity, or foolishness, attaining his desire: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or stupid, or foolish, in the utmost degree: (Ḳ, TA:) fem. HamoqaMCu bilogapN. (TA.)
rajulN bilogN milogN (Ṣ,* Ḳ) A man who is bad, evil, or wicked, (Fr, Ḳ,) in the utmost degree. (Fr, TA.)
See also baliygN.

entry.sense: bilagN: see baliygN.
balogapN: see bilogN.

bulogapN A sufficiency of the means of subsistence, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) such that nothing remains over and above it: (T, Mṣb:) and simply a sufficiency; enough; (JK, Mṣb, TA;) as also balaAgN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning a thing that suffices, or contents, and enables one to attain what he seeks; (TA;) and tabal-ugN↓. (JK, Mṣb, TA.) You say, fiI hecaA bulogapN, and balaAgN↓, and tabal-ugN↓, In this is a sufficiency, or enough. (Mṣb, TA.)
And it is said in the Ḳur [xxi. 106], Uin-a fiI hecaA labalaAgFA↓ liqawomK EaAbidiyna Verily in this is a sufficiency [for a people serving God]: (Bḍ, TA:) or a means of attaining the object sought after, or desired. (Bḍ.)

hom.sense: bilagonN: see balaAgapN.
Also A calumniator, or slanderer: (Kr, TA:) or one who conveys people's discourse to others. (TA.)

entry.sense: Albulagiyna, (Ṣ,) or Albilagiyna, (JK,) or both, (Ḳ,) Calamity, misfortune, or disaster: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or distress, or affliction. (JK.) Hence the saying of ʼÁïsheh to ʼAlee, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) when she was taken prisoner [by him], (Ṣ,) balagota min-aA Albulagiyna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Albilagiyna, (Ḳ,) i. e., Ald-aAhiyapa; meaning balagota min-aA kul-a mabolagK↓ [Thou hast distressed us, or afflicted us, in the utmost degree]: (Ḳ:) it is said to mean that the war harassed her, and distressed her in the utmost degree. (TA.) It is like AlburaHiyna [and AlbiraHiyna] and AlOaTowariyna; all meaning calamities, misfortunes, or disasters: (AʼObeyd, TA:) and is as though they said xaTobN bilagN [and bulagN], meaning baliygN, and then formed the pl. thus because they considered calamities [as personified, i. e.,] as rational beings having purpose, or design. (IAth, TA.) It is invariably thus, terminating with I and n: or one may say in the nom. case Albulaguwna, and in the accus. and gen. Albulagiyna. (O, Ḳ.*) You say also, balaga bihi Albilagiyna [lit. He caused him to come, i. e. he brought him, to calamity, misfortune, or disaster, or to distress, or affliction]; meaning he went to the utmost point in reviling him, and annoying him, or molesting him. (IAạr, TA.)

balaAgN is a subst. from taboliygN and UibolaAgN, meaning The bringing, conveyance, delivery, or communication, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) of a message [&c.]. (Jel in iii. 19, &c.) [It often occurs in the Ḳur as meaning The communication, or announcement, of what is revealed.]

In a trad., in which it is said, kul-u raAfiEapK rafaEato UilayonaA mina AlbalaAgi, [in the CK rufiEato ElynA,] it means What is communicated, or announced, (maA balaga,) of the Ḳur-án and of the [statutes, or ordinances,, &c., termed] sunan: or the meaning is, mino cawiI AlbalaAgi, i. e., Alt-aboliygi, [of those who have the office of communicating, or announcing,] the simple subst. being put in the place of the inf. n.: (Ḳ, TA:) but some relate it differently, saying mina Albul-aAgi↓ [of the communicators, or announcers,] like Hud-aAv in the sense of muHad-ivuwn: (TA:) and some say, mina AlbilaAgi↓, meaning mina AlmubaAligiyna fiI Alt-aboliygi, i. e. of those who do their utmost in communicating, or announcing. (Hr, Ḳ.) [See this trad. cited and explained more fully in the first paragraph {1} of art. rfE.]
hecaA balaAgN liln-aAsi, in the Ḳur [xiv. last verse], means This Ḳur-án contains a sufficient exposition, or demonstration, for men. (TA.)
See also bulogapN, in three places.
bilaAgN: see balaAgN.

baliygN i. q. faSiyHN [properly signifying Chaste in speech, but here meaning eloquent]; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) sharp, or penetrating, or effective, in tongue; (Mṣb;) one who attains, by his speech, or diction, the utmost scope of his mind and desire; (Ḳ,* TA;) [possessing the faculty of balaAgap; (see baluga;)] as also balogN↓, and bilogN↓, and bilagN↓, and balDAgaI↓, like sakaAraI, [in the CK like sukaAraI,] and bulaAgay↓, like HubaAraI: (Ḳ:) or balogN↓ signifies a man who does not commit mistakes often in his speech: (JK:) the pl. of baliygN is bulagaMCu. (TA.) Applied to a saying, [&c.,] it also signifies Effectual, or producing an effect. (Ksh and Bḍ and Jel in iv. 66.)
[Also Surpassing in any quality: and superlative.] It is also applied to a calamity or the like [as meaning Great, severe, distressing, or afflictive]. (IAth.)
balaAgapN i. q. faSaAHapN, [as meaning Eloquence; (see baluga, of which it is the inf. n.;)] (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) as also bilagonN↓. (Seer, TA.)
And [the pl.] balaAgaAtN Slanders, or calumnies. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
balaAgaI and bulaAgaI: see baliygN.
bul-aAgN: see balaAgN.
