baAligN Reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, a place [or time, or an affair or a state or an event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed; reaching,, &c., to the utmost point or degree: and sometimes, being at the point of reaching, &c.: see 1, first sentence]. (TA.) You say also, jayoXN balogN↓, meaning baAligN [An army reaching, or arriving at, its appointed place]. (Ḳ, TA.) And Oamoru Qll-ehi balogN↓, i. e. baAligN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning [The decree of God] reacheth, or attaineth, its intended object: (Ḳ:) from the saying in the Ḳur [lxv. 3], Uin-a Qll-eha baAligN Oamorahu (Ṣ) Verily God attaineth his purpose. (Bḍ, Jel.) And baAligN fiI AlHumoqi Reaching the utmost point, or degree, in stupidity, or foolishness. (TA.) And lazimahu celika baAligFA maA balaga: see 1: and see the sentence there next following it. (Mṣb.) OayomaAnN baAligapN, in the Ḳur lxviii. 39, means Firm covenants: (Jel:) or covenants confirmed by oaths in the utmost degree: (Bḍ:) or rendered obligatory for ever; sworn to, that they shall be constantly observed: or that have reached their utmost point: (Th, TA:) or yamiynN baAligapN means [an oath, or a covenant,] confirmed. (TA.)

Attaining, or having attained, to puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity; applied to a boy: (T, IḲooṭ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb:) and in like manner, without p, applied to a girl; (T, IAmb, Mṣb, Ḳ;) thus applied, with the mention of the noun qualified by it, by Esh-Sháfiʼee (T, Mṣb) and other chaste persons, of the Arabs; (T, TA;) or baAligapN; (IḲooṭ, Mṣb;) or the latter is also thus applied, with the mention of the noun which it qualifies, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) not being wrong because it is the original form; (T, TA;) and seems to be necessarily used when the noun which it qualifies is not mentioned, to prevent ambiguity. (Mṣb.)
A good, a goodly, or an excellent, thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Oabolagu [More, and most, effectual or efficacious: see baliygN].

vanaMCN Oabolagu i. q. mubaAlagN↓ fiyhi [Praise, or eulogy, or commendation, in which the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds are exceeded; such as is egregious, or immoderate, or extravagant;, &c.: see 3]. (Ḳ.)

taboligapN A rope, or cord, with which the main well-rope (Alr-iXaMC) is joined to [that which is called] the karab: (Ḳ:) or a rope, or cord, that is joined to the riXaMC so that it may reach the water: (Z, TA:) pl. tabaAligu. (Ḳ.)
Also A thong that is wound upon the curved extremity of a bow, where the bow-string ends, three times, or four, in order that the bow-string may become firm, or fast. (AḤn, TA.)
tabal-ugN [an inf. n. (of 5, q. v.,) used as a subst.]: see bulogapN, in two places.

mabolagN [The place, and the time, which a person, or thing, reaches, attains, arrives at, or comes to: the utmost point to which, or towards which, one tends, or repairs, or betakes himself; to which one directs his course; or which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, intends, or purposes; whether it be a place, or a time, or any affair or state or event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed: (see 1, first sentence:)] the utmost point, or scope, or degree, of knowledge [and of any attainment]: (Bḍ and Jel in liii. 31:) [the utmost degree of proficiency: a consummate degree of goodness and of any other quality: the age of puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity: the sum, amount, or product, resulting from addition or multiplication: a sum of money: and particularly a considerable sum thereof: and] cash, or ready money, consisting of dirhems and of deenárs: in this sense, post-classical: pl. mabaAligu. (TA.) You say, balaga fulaAnN mabolagahu and mabolagatahu: and balaga fiI AlEilomi AlmabaAliga: and balaga fiI Aljawodapi mabolagFA, and mina Aljawodapi: for explanations of all which, see 1. And balagota min-aA kul-a mabolagK: see Albulagiyna.
balaga fulaAnN mabolagatahu: see 1.
[mubal-igN One whose office it is, with other persons each of whom is thus called, to chant certain words, as the UiqaAmap &c., in a mosque. (See my “Modern Egyptians, “ch. iii.)]

huwa maboluwgN bihi [He is caused to reach, attain, arrive at, or come to, his appointed end, or term of life, (Oajalahu, or the like, being understood,)] is said of the object of the phrase balaga Qll-ehu bihi [which see, and the phrase next following it]. (TA.)
vanaMCN mubaAlagN fiyhi: see Oabolagu.
balogamN [Phlegm;] one of the four [natural constituents termed] TabaAYiE; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] one of the humours (OaxolaAT) of the body. (Ḳ.)
And hence, ‡ A heavy, or sluggish, person, who is a great talker, or babbler. (TA.)
[balogamiI-N Of, or relating to, phlegm; phlegmatic.]

hom.sense: 1. baliqa and baluqa: see 9.
balaqa, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaboluqu}, (MSb, TA,) inf. n. baloqN, (TA,) He opened a door wholly: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or opened it vehemently: (Ḳ:) and Ablq↓ signifies the same. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] He devirginated, or defloured, a girl. (AA, Ḳ.)
Also He shut, or closed, a door. (IF, Ḳ.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
4. Ablq He (a stallion) begot offspring such as are termed buloq [pl. of Oabolaqu, q. v.]. (Zj, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 7. Anblq It (a door) became opened wholly: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or became opened with vehemence. (Ḳ.)

9. Ablq-, inf. n. AiboliqaAqN; (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AblAq-↓, (IDrd, Ḳ,) inf. n. AiboliyqaAqN; (IDrd, TA;) and Ablwlq↓, inf. n. AiboliylaAqN; (TA;) and baliqa↓, aor. _a {yabolaqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. balqN; (Ḳ,* TA; [accord. to the CK balqN, but this is a mistake;]) and baluqa↓, aor. _u {yaboluqu}; (Ḳ;) but IDrd asserts only the first and second of these verbs to be known; (TA;) He (a horse) was, or became, Ablq, i. e., black and white: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or white in the kind legs as high as the thighs. (Ḳ.)

balaqN and buloqapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former an inf. n. of baliqa, (Ḳ,* TA,) Blackness and whiteness [together, generally in horses]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the extension of whiteness in the hind legs of a horse as high as the thighs: (ISd, Ḳ:) and the latter, any colour with which white is mixed. (Golius on the authority of Meyd.)
buloqapN: see what next precedes.
bulayqN a contracted dim. of Oabolaqu. (TA.)
bal-uwqN: see what next follows.

bal-uwqapN, (JK, Ṣ, &c.,) [said to be] like EajuwzapN, (Ḳ,) [but this is wrong, and is probably a mistranscription, for Eaj-uwrap, with teshdeed and the unpointed r, n. un. of Eaj-uwr,] and with damm, [bul-uwqapN↓,] (IDrd, Ḳ,) both mentioned by AA, (TA,) but more commonly with fet-ḥ [to the bi], (IDrd, TA,) A [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a tract of sand that gives growth to nothing except the [plant or tree called] ruxaAmaI, (Aṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) of which the [wild] bulls are fond, and the roots of which they dig up and eat: (TA:) or a wide tract of fertile land in which no one shares with thee: (Fr, TA:) or a hard place among sands, as though it were swept, asserted by the Arabs of the desert to be of the dwellingplaces of the Jinn: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) or a desert land, destitute of vegetable produce and of water, or of human beings, inhabited by none but Jinn: (TA:) or a level, soft land: (Ḳ:) or a place in which no trees grow: (JK:) or white places in sand, which give growth to nothing: (ISh, TA in art. brS:) or a piece of ground differing in colour or appearance from that which is next to it, that produces nothing whatever: as also bal-uwqN↓, like tan-uwrN: and, with the art. Al, particularly applied to a place in the district of El-Bahreyn, asserted (as IDrd says, TA) to be of the dwelling-places of the Jinn: (Ḳ:) pl. balaAliyqu; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is syn. with mawaAmK (AʼObeyd, Ṣ) and sabaAriytN, meaning lands wherein is nothing: (AʼObeyd, TA:) in poetry, balaAliqu occurs as its pl. (Ḳ, TA.)
bul-uwqapN: see what next precedes.

Oabolaqu, applied to a horse, fem. baloqaMCu, Black and white: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or white in the hind legs as high as the thighs: (ISd, Ḳ:) pl. buloqN: which is applied by Ru-beh to mountains: but the Arabs apply the epithet Ablq to a beast of the equine kind, and Oaboraqu to a mountain (TA) and to a sheep or goat: (Lḥ, TA in art. brq:) the former is also applied to a rope. (JK.) Talaba AlOabolaqa AlEaquwqa (which is a prov., TA) means He sought an impossible thing; because Ablq is applied to a male, and Eqwq means pregnant: or AlAblq AlEqwq means the dawn; because it breaks, (lit., cleaves,) from Eaq-ahu signifying Xaq-ahu. (Ḳ.)
Q. 1. baloqaEa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. baloqaEapN, (TA,) It (a country, or region,) was, or became, vacant, or void; destitute of herbage or pasturage, and of human beings, &c. (Ḳ.)
Q. 3. AibolanoqaEa It (sorrow, grief, or anxiety, such as is termed karob,) became removed, or cleared away. (Ḳ.)
It (the dawn) shone, or shone brightly. (Ḳ.)
It (a thing) appeared, and came forth. (TA.)

baloqaEN and baloqaEapN↓ A land that is vacant, or void; destitute of herbage or pasturage, and of human beings, &c.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in which is nothing: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies a vacant, or void, place: (Mgh:) [or instead of using the former alone, you say OaroDN baloqaEN; for] you say manozilN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, place of alighting or abiding], (Ṣ, TA,) and daArN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, house, &c.], without p, when it is an epithet, (Ṣ, TA,) applied to a masc. subst. and to a fem.; (TA;) but if it be a subst., you say, AinotahayonaA UilaI baloqaEapK↓ malosaMCa [we came at last to a smooth, vacant, or void, land]: (Ṣ, TA:) and baloqaEapN↓ also signifies a land in which are no trees, either in sands or in plain or level tracts: (TA:) or a vacant land, in which is no one, whether there be in it herbage or not, and whether plain or not: (Ḥam p. 445:) pl. balaAqiEu. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Alyamiynu AlfaAjirapu tacaru (Ṣ, Mgh, TA; but in the second and third of these, in the place of tacaru, we find tadaEu;) The false oath causes the places of abode to become void, or vacant; i. e., by reason of its evil influence, the possessions and their possessors perish; (Mgh;) or the [false] swearer becomes poor, and the property that was in his house goes away; (Sh;) or God renders him in a state of disunion, and changes the blessings which He had conferred upon him: (TA:) accord. to another relation, the words of the trad. are Alyamiynu Algamuwsu Alx. (Mgh.) You say also, diyaArN baloqaEN [Vacant, or void, places of abode]; as though the places were one place: (TA:) and Ru-beh says,
faOaSobaHato daArahumu balaAqiEaA
[And their abode became vacant]: (TA:) and it is said in a trad., OaSobaHati AlOaroDu balaAqiEa [as though meaning the land became altogether vacant]; the pl. being used to render the meaning intensive, as in the phrases OaroDN sabaAsibu and vawobN OaxolaAqN; (IAth, TA;) or because every portion thereof is considered as being blqE. (TA.)
IF says that the l in baloqaEN is augmentative. (TA.)
baloqaEapN: see baloqaEN, in four places.
baloqaEiI-N An arrow, or a spear-head, bright, or free from rust, in the point. (Ḳ.)
SalanoqaEN balanoqaEN is an expression applied to A road [as though meaning made bare by the feet of men and beasts]. (I'Abbád, Ḳ.)
bal-aAnN: see art. bl.

1. baliha, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yabolahu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. balahN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) [and irregularly balaAhapN and bulahoniyapN, (see balahN, below,)] He was, or became, Oabolah [q. v.]; as also tbl-h↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Abtlh↓: (TA:) or he was, or became, weak in intellect. (Mṣb.)
Also He was unable to adduce his argument, proof, or evidence, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of his heedlessness, and his smallness, or lack, of discrimination. (TA.)

3. mubaAlahapN The showing stupidity [in an action or in one's actions, i. e. the acting stupidly,] with any one. (KL.) [You say, bAlhhu He acted stupidly, or in the manner of him who is termed Oabolah, with him.]
4. Ablhhu He found him, or knew him by experience, to be Oabolah [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
5. tbl-h: see 1.
And see 6.

Also ‡ He journeyed, or proceeded, or pursued his way, without any sign of the road, or any track, to guide him, (Az, Ḳ, TA,) without following the right course, (Az, TA,) and without asking [to be directed]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And † He prosecuted a search after a stray, or lost, beast. (JK, Ḳ.)
6. tbAlh He feigned balah, or the attribute denoted by the term Oabolah: (Ṣ:) or he made use of that attribute [as a mask]; i. q. AisotaEomala Albalaha; as also tbl-h↓. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.

baloha is an indecl. word with fet-ḥ for its termination, like kayofa, and means daEo [Let alone, or say nothing of]; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] it is a noun for daEo; indecl.; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) a verbal noun, meaning daEo and Outoruko; (IAth, TA;)
and the noun that follows it, when it is thus used, is in the accus. case; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) i. e. it is indecl., with fet-ḥ for its termination, when the noun following it is in the accus. case; so that you say, baloha zayodFA [Let alone Zeyd, or say nothing of Zeyd]; like as you say, ruwayoda zayodFA: (IB, TA:) and it is also an inf. n. in the sense of Alt-aroku; likewise with fet-ḥ for its termination, but decl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the gen. case; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) or it is put in the place of an inf. n., meaning taroka [which is virtually the same as Autoruko and daEo], and is prefixed to a noun in the gen. case; so that you say, baloha zayodK, i. e. taroka zayodK [which is virtually the same as baloha zayodFA explained above; for taroka zayodK is originally Autoruko zayodFA tarokFA, like as faDaroba Alr-iqaAbi in the Ḳur xlvii. 4 is originally fQDoribuwA Alr-iqaAba DarobFA]; (IAth, TA;) for in this case it cannot be regarded as a verbal noun, since verbal nouns are not prefixed to other nouns, governed by them in the gen. case: (IB, TA:) and it is also a noun syn. with kayofa [How?]; likewise with fet-ḥ for its termination, indecl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the nom. case. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) A poet says, describing swords, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) namely, Kaab Ibn-Málik, (Ṣ,)
tacaru AljamaAjima DaAHiyFA haAmatuhaA
baloha AlOakuf-a kaOan-ahaA lamo tuxolaqi
[They leave the skulls with their crowns lying open to the sun (let alone, or say nothing of, the hands) as though they had not been created]: (Ṣ, Mughnee:) he says, when they cut, or cut off, the crowns, then let alone, or say nothing of, the hands (fadaEi AlOakuf-a): i. e., they are more fit for cutting off the hands: (TA:) Akh says that blh is here in the place of an inf. n.; that it is as when you say, Daroba zayodK: but AlAkf- may be in the accus. case; so that the meaning may be daEi AlOakuf-a: (Ṣ:) the verse is thus recited in two different ways: and also baloha AlOakuf-u [how then must be the case of the hands?]. (Mughnee.) And hence the prov., tuHoriquka Aln-aAru Uino taraAhaA baloha Oano taSolaAhaA, i. e. The fire will burn thee if thou see it from a distance: then let alone, or say nothing of, (fadaEo,) thy entering into it. (TA.) A strange instance occurs in the Saheeh of El-Bukháree, in the explanation of the MlLmL of the chapter of Als-ajodap [the 32nd ch. of the Ḳur]: he says, God says [by these three letters], OaEodadotu liEibaAdiI AlS-aAliHiyna maA laA EayonN raOato walaA OucunN samiEato walaA xaTari EalaI qalobi baXarK cuxorFA mino balohi maA QT-alaEotumo Ealayohi: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) or mA OaTalaEotuhumo Ealayohi: (so in some copies of the Ḳ:) thus blh is used as a decl. word, governed in the gen. case by mn, and deviating from the three meanings [explained above]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) but the reading commonly known is, ElI qlb bXr baloha ma OaTolaEotuhumo Elyh; and this is the reading in the work of J, [the Ṣ,] and in the Nh, and other lexicological works: (TA:) it has been explained by gayor; [so that the meaning of the sentence as first related above is, I have prepared for my righteous servants what eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it occurred to the mind of man, as a treasure for the future, (obviously taken from Isaiah lxiv. 4, quoted by St. Paul in 1 Cor. ii. 9,) save, or except, that with which ye have become acquainted, or that with which I have acquainted them; and the same, with the omission of “as a treasure for the future, “is the meaning of the sentence as related in the Ṣ and Nh, &c.;] (Mughnee, Ḳ;) i. e. siwaI, as in the Ṣ; (TA;) and this corroborates, (Mughnee,) or is agreeable with, (Ḳ,) the opinion of those who reckon blh as an exceptive word: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and as meaning Oajalo [app. a mistranscription for Oajol; i. e., it has been explained also as meaning I have done all this because of my promise to them; (mino Oajoli maA OaTolaEotuhumo Ealayohi because of that with which I have acquainted them;) and thus it may have been read by SM, for he has written Ajl without any syll. signs; and has given no other ex. of blh in the sense here intended except one commencing with the words, baloha An-iI lamo Oaxuno EahodFA, which may mean because I have not broken a covenant, or yea, verily I have not, &c., accord. as we read Oan-iI or Uin-iI]: or as meaning kuf-a [or rather kuf-a Eano] and daEo [let alone, or say nothing of; but this explanation must relate to the sentence as given in the Ṣ and Nh]: (Ḳ, but omitted in an excellent copy of that work:) or, accord. to El-Aḥmar, it means, in this trad. [as commonly known], kayufa [how? which seems to be the least suitable of all these explanations]. (TA.) IAmb relates, on the authority of others, that baloha is also syn. with EalaI: [but I think that this is a mistake, arising from a misunderstanding of what here follows:] Fr says that he who makes it to govern a gen. case regards it as used in the manner of EalaI, and similar particles governing the gen. case. (TA.)
maA balohaka means maA baAluka [What is thy state, or condition, or case?]: (Ḳ, TA:) or maA laka [which often has this meaning: see the letter l]. (So in some copies of the Ḳ.)

balahN and balaAhapN↓ [both properly inf. ns.; see 1;] The attribute, or quality, denoted by the epithet OabolahN [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. heedlessness: (Ḳ:) or heedlessness of evil; (JK in explanation of the former, and Ḳ;), &c.; (Ḳ;) and bulahoniyapN↓ signifies the same; and stupidity and languor. (JK.)
balahaMCu: see Oabolahu.

bulahoniyapN, (Ḳ,) or balahoniyapu AlEayoXi, (JK,) or mina AlEayoXi, (Ṣ,) ‡ An easy and a plentiful, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or a pleasant and heedless, (JK, TA,*) state, or condition, of life: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) from EayoXN Oabolahu [q. v.]: (Ḥar p. 216:) the word blhnyp is rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class by A at the end, which is changed into I because of the kesreh before it: (Ṣ in art. blhn:) it is like rufagoniyapN and rufahoniyapN: IB says that it should be mentioned in art. blh, and means EayoXN Oabolahu; the n and I being augmentative, to render it quasicoordinate to xubaEovinapN: it is mentioned in the Ḳ [and Ṣ] in arts. blhn and blh: (TA in art. blhn:) the n is augmentative accord. to Sb. (Ṣ in the present art.) One says, laA zilota mulaq-FI bitahoniYapK mubaq-FI fiIbulahoniyapK ‡ [Mayest thou not cease to be greeted with congratulation, and made to continue in an easy and a plentiful state of life]. (A, Ḳ.)
See also balahN.
balaAhapN: see balahN.

Oabolahu Heedless: (Ḳ:) or heedless of evil (Ḳ, TA) by reason of his goodness: (TA:) or simple, foolish, or of little sense, without discrimination: (Ḳ:) or weak in intellect: (Mṣb:) accord. to En-Naḍr, (TA,) one whose evilness is dead, (Ḳ, TA,) so that he is not cognizant of it: (TA:) good in disposition; having little cognizance, or understanding, of subtilties; or having little skill therein: (Ḳ:) or one whose predominant quality is freedom of the bosom, or heart, or mind, from evil affections; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and good opinion of men: (TA:) simple-hearted: (TḲ:) naturally disposed to goodness, and therefore heedless of evil, not knowing it: (T, TA:) or heedless with respect to the present world and its people and their corruptness and malevolence, but intelligent and skilled in the law with respect to that which is commanded and that which is forbidden: (Ah- mad Ibn-Hambal, TA:) fem. balohaMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) pl. bulohN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and bulahaMCu↓, a pl., [as though the sing. were baliyhN,] signifies dull, stupid, or wanting in intelligence: but this is post-classical. (TA.) Hence, XaAb-N Oabolahu [A youth, or young man, who is heedless,, &c.], because of his inexperience in affairs: the epithet is applied to a youth in like manner as freedom from care, or thought, and like as insanity, are attributed to him. (Ṣ.) And xayoru OawolaAdinaA AlOabolahu AlEaquwlu ‡ [The best of our children is the heedless,, &c., that has much intelligence]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) a saying of Ez-Zibrikán Ibn-Bedr; (Ṣ;) meaning such as, by reason of his bashfulness, is like the Ablh, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) so that he feigns heedlessness, and passes over things, (Mṣb,) though he has much intelligence; (Ṣ;) or such as is thought to be stupid, but, when examined, is found to be [very] intelligent. (IAth, TA in art. Eql.) And Oakovaru Oaholi Aljan-api Albulohu, a trad., meaning Most of the people of Paradise are the buloh [or heedless,, &c.,] with respect to the present world, because of their being little concerned thereby, while they are intelligent with respect to the world to come; (Ṣ;) or they are thus termed because they are heedless of their affairs in the present world, and unskilful in the management thereof, and busy themselves with their affairs relating to the world to come. (TA.)

balohaMCu, applied to a woman, Generous, strong-hearted, (maziyrapN, for Almariyrapu in the copies of the Ḳ is a mistake for Almaziyrapu, with zAI, TA, [app. here meaning bold,]) inexperienced in affairs, and simple, or unintelligent. (Ḳ,* TA.) ISh cites a poet as applying this epithet to a young girl with whom he had sported, and who acquainted him with her secrets, by reason of her inexperience, and want of cunning, not knowing what that implied against her. (TA.)

Also, applied to a she-camel, ‡ That does not take fright, and flee from a thing, (ISh, A, Ḳ,) by reason of staidness, (ISh, Ḳ,) or heaviness, (A,) as though she were stupid. (ISh, A, Ḳ.)
One does not say jamalN Oabolahu. (ISh, TA.)
XabaAbN Oabolahu ‡ Soft, or delicate, youth; (T, A, Ḳ;) as though he who enjoys it were heedless of nocturnal accidents or calamities. (A, Ḳ.)

And EayoXN Oabolahu ‡ A soft, or delicate, or pleasant, or plentiful and easy, life: (Ḳ, TA:) or a life in which are few anxieties: (CK:) or a life in which are few griefs, or sorrows. (Ṣ.) [See also bulahoniyapN.]

hom.sense: 1. balaAhu, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaboluwu}, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. balaMCN, (Ṣ,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is balowN, (T, Mṣb,) He (God) tried, proved, or tested, him, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) bixayorK [by, or with, good], or biX-arK [by, or with, evil]; (Mṣb;) for God tries his servant (yaboluwhu) by, or with, a benefit, to test his thankfulness; and by, or with, a calamity, to test his patience; (T;) [wherefore it often means He afflicted him;] as also AblAhu↓, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. UibolaMCN; (T, Ṣ; [in both restrieted to good; but in the Mṣb it seems to be common to good and evil;]) and AbtlAh↓: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) and balawotuhu, inf. n. balowN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and balaMCN, (M, Ḳ,) [but from what has been said above, it seems that the latter is used only when the agent is God, and that it is properly a simple subst.,] I tried, proved, or tested, him; (Ṣ, M, Mgh,* Ḳ;) as also Aibotalayotuhu↓: (M, Ḳ:) each of these verbs implying two things; one of which is the learning the state, or condition, of the object, and becoming acquainted with what was unknown of the case thereof; and the other, the manifesting of the goodness or badness thereof; both of these things being sometimes meant, and sometimes only one of them, as when God is the agent, in which case only the latter is meant: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and Alt-abaAliI↓, also, signifies the act of trying, proving, or testing. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxi. 36], wanaboluwkumo biQlX-ari waQlxayori fitonapF [And we try you by, or with, evil and good, by way of probation]. (TA.) And in the same [ii. 118], waUica QbotalaI↓ UiboraAhiyma rab-uhu bikalamaAtK [And when his Lord tried Abraham by certain words, meaning commands and prohibitions]. (TA.) And you say, laA tubolinaA↓ Uil-aA biQl-atiI hiIa OaHosanu [Try Thou not us save by those things that are best]; (T;) from a trad. (TA.) [See also 4 and 8 below.]
[Hence,] balawotuhu also signifies ‡ I smelt it. (T in art. bwl, and A and TA.)
[And balaAhu He knew it, or became acquainted with it. (See baAlK.)]
See also 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.

baliI, aor. _a {yabolawu}, inf. n. bilFA, or bilFI, [in the CK, erroneously, balFI,] and balaMCN, [in the CK, erroneously, bilAC,] (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former with kesr and the latter with fet-ḥ, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) said of a garment, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) It was, or became, old, and worn out: (Mṣb:) belonging to the present art. and to art. blI. (M.) [The inf. n., used as a subst., signifies Wear; attrition; wear and tear: see an ex. in a hemistich cited near the end of the first paragraph {1} of art. AlA, where a dwelling is likened to a garment.]
Also said of a plant [as meaning It became old and withered, or wasted]. (Ḳ in art. Env, &c.)
And of a corpse, meaning It became consumed by the earth. (Mṣb.)
And of a bone, meaning It became old, and decayed; syn. ram-a. (Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. rm.)
And of a man's reputation, meaning † It became worn out of regard or notice. (TA in art. dvr.)

And [hence,] baliyato, (M,) or buliyato, (Ḳ,) She (a camel, M, Ḳ, or a mare, or beast of the equine kind, M) was, or became, a balay-ip; i. e., was tied at her dead master's grave (M, Ḳ) without food or water (M) until she died (M, Ḳ) and wasted away. (M in art. blI.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in six places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

3. laA OabaAliyhi is from AlblMC, [inf. n. of balaAhu,] so that it signifies [properly] I shall not, or I do not, care for him, mind him, heed him, or regard him, so as to share with him my trial and his trial: (Ḥam p. 94:) [and hence,] one says thus, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or maA OabaAliyhi, (M, Ḳ,) and laA OabaAliIbihi, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or maA OubaAliI bihi, (MF, TA,) but the verb is more chastely made trans. without the preposition bi, (A, TA,) inf. n. mubaAlaApN (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bilaMCN (M, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, erroneously, balAC]) and baAlapN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said by some to be a quasi-inf. n. and by others to be an inf. n., (MF, TA,) [in the T it is said to be a subst., from AlmubaAlaApu,] originally baAliyapN, like EaAfiyapN from EaAfaAhu, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and baAlN, [which is more strange,] (M, Ḳ,) meaning [merely] I shall not, or I do not, care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) I shall not be, or I am not, disquieted by him, or it: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or, as some say, laA OubaAliyhi is formed by transposition from laA OubaAwiluhu, from AlbaAlu, i. e. I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind; nor give, or pay, any attention to him, or it: (Z, TA: [and the like is said in the T:]) or the proper [or literal] meaning is, I will not, or I do not, contend with him for superiority in goodness, or excellence, by reason of my little care, or regard, for him: (Mgh:) or it was employed to denote the contending with another for superiority in glory, or excellence, as will be shown by the citation of a verse in the latter portion of this paragraph; and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, came to denote contempt, or mean estimation: (Ḥam p. 31:) or its original meaning is, I will not, or I do not, strive with him to be first; neglecting him, or leaving him to himself; from tabaAlaI Alqawomu as explained below; see 6. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., laA yubaAliyhimu Qll-ehu baAlapF, or, accord. to one reading, laA yubaAliI bihimo baAlapF, meaning God will not hold them to be of any value or weight. (TA.) And in another, heWulMCi fiI Aljan-api walaA OubaAliI waheWulaMCi fiI Aln-aAri walaA OubaAliI, said to mean [These will be in Paradise, and] I shall not disapprove; [and these will be in the fire of Hell,] and I shall not disapprove. (Az, TA.) And one says, laA OubaAliI maA SanaEota [I shall not, or I do not, care for what thou didst, or hast done]. (IDrd, TA.) And maA OubaAliI Oaqumota Oamo qaEadota [I care not whether thou stand or sit]: and maA OubaAliI biqiyaAmika waEadamihi [I care not for thy standing and thy not doing so]. (Mughnee in art. A.) And maA baAlayotu bihi (AZ, Mṣb, TA) I did not care for, mind, or regard, him, or it. (TA.) And baAlaI biAlX-aIoCi [He cared for the thing; or] he was disquieted by the thing. (T.) The verb is sometimes thus used, in an affirmative manner; (Ḥam p. 94; [and the like is said in the TA;]) though some say that it is not; (Mṣb;) but it is not unless it occurs with a negative in the former part of the sentence or in the latter part thereof; as when one says, maA baAlaI bika Sadiyquka walekino baAlaI Eaboduka [Thy friend cared not for thee, but thy slave cared]; and as in the saying of Zuheyr,
laqado baAlayotu maZoEana Oum-i OawofaI
walekino Oum-u OawofaI laA tubaAliI
[Verily I cared for the departure of Umm-Owfà, but Umm-Owfà cares not]. (Ḥam p. 94.) One says also, lamo OubaAli and lamo Oubalo [I did not care,, &c.]: (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ: [but in the CK the latter of these is omitted:]) in the latter the A [of prolongation] is suppressed for the purpose of alleviating the utterance, like as I is suppressed in the inf. n. [or quasi-inf. n.] baAlapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) originally baAliyapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and in laA Oadori: (Ṣ:) or the A is suppressed in this case to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; (Kh, Sb, M, IB;) not for the purpose of alleviating the utterance; (IB, TA;) for this is done because the l is made quiescent. (Kh, Sb, M.) And, accord. to Kh, (Sb, M,) some of the Arabs say, lamo Oubalihi [I did not care for him, or it], (Sb, M,) or lamo Oubali, [in the CK, erroneously, lm Aaboli,] with kesr to the l; (Ḳ, TA;) [for lm OubaAlihi, or lm OubaAli;] only suppressing the A, as they do in EulabiTN [for EulaAbiTN]. (Sb, Ṣ, M.)

IAar says that baAlaI, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, is like OabolaI↓ meaning He exerted himself in a description of a war, or battle, or of generous conduct; as when one says, OabolaI celika Alyawoma balaMCF HasanFA [He exerted himself well, that day, in a description of war,, &c.]: and he cites the following verse [to which reference has been made above]:
maA liI OaraAka qaAYimFA tubaAliI
waOanota qado mat-a mina AlhuzaAli
[What hath happened to me that I see thee standing exerting thyself in a description of generous qualities, when thou hast become like one dead by reason of leanness?]: he says that he [the poet] heard him [whom he thus addresses] saying, “We have eaten and we have drunk [with guests], and we have done [such and such things];” enumerating, or recounting, generous qualities or actions, and lying in doing so: (T, TA:) in another place he says that tubaAliI means looking to see which of them [or of thee and others] is best in bAl [i. e. state, or condition], while thou art dying: (TA:) he says, also, that baAlaAhu, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, signifies he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence; (T, TA;*)
and [it is said that] tbAlI in the verse here cited means thus contending; syn. tufaAxiru: (Ḥam p. 31:) and accord. to IAạr, baAlaAhu also signifies he contended with him in contradiction. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AblAhu, inf. n. UibolaMCN: see 1, in two places.

[Hence,] AblAhu Qll-ehu UibolaMCF HasanFA, (T,) or balaMCa HasanFA, (Ṣ,) God did to him a good deed. (T.) [And hence,] it is said in the Ḳur [viii. 17], waliyuboliIa AlmuWominiyna minohu balaMCF HasanuA (TA) And that He might confer upon the believers a great benefit, or favour, or blessing: (Bḍ:) or a good gift; meaning spoil. (Jel.) And Oabolayotuhu maEoruwfFA [I conferred upon him a favour, or benefit]. (Ṣ.) Zuheyr says,
jazaI Qll-ehu biA lUiHosaAni maA faEalaA bikumo
waOabolaAhumaA xayora AlbalaMCi Al-aciI yaboluw , (T,* Ṣ,) meaning, AlcI yaboluw bihi EibaAdahu, (T,) or AlcI yaxotabiru bihi EibaAda, (Ṣ,) i. e. [May God recompense with beneficence what they two have done to you,] and do to them two the best of the deeds wherewith He tries [the thankfulness of] his servants. (T.)
And He swore to him: (M, Ḳ:) or this, (TA,) or AblAhu yamiynFA, [as above,] (T, Ṣ,) he swore [or swore an oath] to him, and thereby soothed, or placated, his mind. (T, Ṣ,* TA.)
And hence, (TA,) He informed him, acquainted him, or told him. (IAạr, M, Ḳ, TA.)

[And hence, He manifested it; revealed it; made it manifest, apparent, evident, clear, or plain; whence a phrase in a verse cited voce muDomarN; and the phrase] maA lamo yuboli AlEucora, i. e. As long as he does not manifest, show, or make apparent, the excuse: but the verb [in this sense] is originally doubly trans.: one says, Oabolayotu fulaAnFA EucorFA, meaning I manifested to such a one an excuse so that I was not to be blamed after it; properly signifying I made such a one to be acquainted with my excuse, and to know the manner thereof; (Mgh;) and thus it is explained in the A: (TA: [in like manner, also, it is explained in the T:]) [or] AblAhu EucorFA signifies He gave him an excuse which he accepted: (M, Ḳ:) and in like manner, AblAhu juhodahu [He gave him his endeavour, or energy, in an acceptable manner]; and naAYilahu [his gift]. (M.) Hence, AblI Eucorahu signifies also He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, [and thus manifested his excuse,] in work. (Mgh.) And hence, AblI fiI AlHarobi He manifested, or showed, his might, valour, or prowess, in war, or fight, [and he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, therein, (Eucorahu being understood,)] so that men proved him and knew him. (Mgh.) See also 3, where another explanation of AblI is given, in the latter portion of the paragraph.

AblI Alv-awoba [He wore out the garment;] trans. of baliIa; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also bal-aAhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) belonging to the present art. and to art. blI. (M.) One says to the mujid- [i. e. him who makes, or puts on, a new garment], Oaboli wayuxolifu Qll-ehu [Wear out thy garment, and God will replace it with another; or, may God replace, &c.]. (Ṣ.) And Oaboli waOajid-a waQHomida AlkaAsiI Wear out, and make new, [or put on new,] and praise the Clother [meaning God]. (Ṣ in art. jd.)

[Hence,] bal-aAhu↓ Als-afaru [Journeying, or travel, wore him, or wasted him]; namely, a man; (M, Ḳ; but in the copies of the latter, balaAhu↓ [which I think an evident mistranscription];) as also bl-I↓ Ealayohi; and AblAhu: (M:) and so Alham-u [anxiety], (M, Ḳ,) and the like, (M,) and Alt-ajaAribu [tryings, or trying events]: (Ḳ:) and AblAhA Als-afaru (T, Ṣ) or bl-AhA↓ (thus in a copy of the Ṣ) [journeying, or travel, wore her, or wasted her]; namely, a she-camel. (T, Ṣ.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
waAlmaroCu yuboliyhi balaMCa Als-irobaAlo
kar-uAll-ayAliI waQxotilaAfu AlOaHowaAlu
[And man, the returning of the nights time after time, and the alternation of states of being, wear him out as the wearing out of the shirt]: (Ṣ, M:*) he means, UibolaMCa AlsirobaAl, or fabaliIa balaMCa Als-irobaAl. (M.) And Ibn-Aḥmar says,
labisotu OabiI Hat-aI tamal-ayotu Eumorahu
wabal-ayotu OaEomaAmiI wabal-ayotu xaAliyaA
he means I lived the period that my father lived [so that I had long enjoyment of his life, and I outwore my paternal uncles, and I outwore my maternal uncle]: or, as some say, I lived with my father for the length of his life, &c. (M, TA.* [In the latter, tabal-ayotu↓ is put in the place of tamal-ayotu; and hence it is there said that tabal-aAhu is like bal-aAhu: but I think that tbl-yt is a mistranscription.])

Oabolayotu and bal-ayotu↓ also signify I bound the foreshank of a she-camel to her arm at the grave of her [dead] master, and left her without food or water until she died; or I dug for her a pit, and left her in it until she died. (Ṣ, TA. [See baliy-apN, and mubal-FI.])

entry.sense: 5: see 4, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 6. Alt-abaAliI [inf. n. of tabaAlaI]: see 1.
tbAlI Alqawomu The people, or company of men, vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening to a little water, and drew from it. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 8. AbtlAhu: see 1, in three places. [Hence, AubotiliIa bikacaA (vulg. AibotalaI) He was tried, proved, or tested, by, or with, such a thing; generally meaning he was afflicted thereby, or therewith; as, for instance, by, or with, a disease.]

Also He asked, or sought, or desired, of him information, or news, or tidings. (M, Ḳ.) And AbtlI signifies also He conjured, or adjured, and asked if any had knowledge; syn. AisotaHolafa and AisotaEorafa [explained by what here follows]. (M, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, both the verb and the explanation are here wrong: the former is written AuboliIa; and the latter, AsotuHolifa w AsotuEorifa.]) A poet says,
tabag-aI OabaAhaA fiI Alr-ifaAqi watabotaliI
waOawodaI bihi fiI luj-api AlbaHori tamosaHu
[She seeks for her father among the travellingcompanions, and conjures, or adjures, and asks. if any have knowledge, when a crocodile has destroyed him in the depth of the great river: tabag-aI is for tatabag-aI]: he means that she says to them, “I conjure you, or adjure you, by God, (naAXadotukumo Qll-eha,) [tell me,] do ye know any tidings of my father?” (M, TA.) But Aboo-Saʼeed says that ttblI here means tries, proves, or tests; and that AlAibotilaMCu signifies the trying, proving, or testing, whether by an oath or otherwise. (TA.)

[Also He desired it; he sought it.] It is said in a trad., Aln-acoru maA QbotuliIa bihi wajohu Qll-ehu, i. e. [The vow that a man makes to be binding, or obligatory, on himself is that whereby the recompense of God] is desired, or sought. (TA.)
And He chose him, made choice of him, or elected him. (Sh and T, from a trad.)
12. AibolawolaI It (herbage) became tall, so that the camels were able to avail themselves of it. (Ḳ.)

bilowu safarK, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) with kesr to the b, (Ṣ,) and biloIu safarK, (Ṣ, A,) Worn, or wasted, by journeying, or travel; applied to a she-camel, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) and in like manner to a man, and to a he-camel: (M:) and biloIu OasofaArK (M, Ḳ) and bilowu OasofaArK, (Ḳ, TA,) with kesr to the b in both, (TA, [in the CK written with fet-ḥ,]) a man worn, or wasted, by journeyings, or travels, and anxiety, (M, Ḳ,*) and the like, (M,) and tryings, or trying events: (Ḳ:) pl. OabolaMCN. (Ṣ, M.) And bilowN Xar-K and biloIu Xar-K [both written in the CK with fet-ḥ to the b] A man having strength, or power, to endure evil; tried, proved, or tested, thereby: (M, Ḳ:) and in like manner, bilowu xayorK and biloIu xayorK [tried,, &c., by good, or prosperity]. (TA.) And Uin-ahu libalowN mino OabolaMCi AlmaAli and biloIN [both written in the CK with fet-ḥ to the b as before] Verily he is one of those who manage, or tend, camels, or the like, well. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.) The I in biloI, in all these instances, is originally w, changed into I because of the kesreh, and the weakness of the intervening letter, l; as is the case in EiloyapN: so says IJ. (M.)
balaI: see art. blI.
bilowapN: see what next follows.
biloyapN: see what next follows.
balowaI: see what next follows.

balaMCN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb) and balowaI↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and baliy-apN↓ (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bilowapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with kesr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and biloyapN↓, (so in a copy of the Ṣ, beside the third,) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, in the place of the third, (TA,) substs. (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) from balaAhu Qll-ehu, (T, Mṣb,) or from AibotalaAhu Qll-ehu, [which is the same in meaning,] (M,) or from balawotuhu, (Ḳ,) are one [in their signification; which is A trial, as meaning a probation, or a test; and as meaning particularly a trouble or an affliction of any kind by which one's patience or any other grace or virtue is tried, proved, or tested]; (Ṣ;) and the pl. (Ṣ, TA) of baliy-apN↓ (TA) is balaAyaA, of the measure faEaAYilu changed to faEaAlaI: (Ṣ, TA:)
[or] balaMCN is [properly, or originally,] an inf. n., (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and signifies the act of trying, proving, or testing, by, or with, good, and by, or with, evil: (Ṣ, M:) it is evil and good: (T, M:*) a trial, or an affliction, (T, Ḳ,) which is its original meaning; (T;) and a [probationary] benefit, favour, or blessing, (T,) or a [probationary] gift; (Ḳ;) the former of these requiring patience, and the latter being the greater of the two [as being commonly the more dangerous to the soul]; (TA;) [but the latter meaning is generally indicated only by the addition of an epithet: thus] balaMCN HasanN means a great benefit, or favour, or blessing, of God; (Bḍ in viii. 17;) or a good gift of God: (Jel ibid.:) balaMCN also means grief; as though it tried the body: (Er-Rághib, Ḳ:) and the imposition of a difficult, or troublesome, thing; a requirement; an exaction; because it is difficult, or distressing, to the body; or because it is trying. (Ḳ.) balaMCi (like qaTaAmi, Ṣ, Ḳ) is syn. with AlbalaMCu: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) occurring in the saying, nazalato balaMCi EalaI Alkuf-aAri [Trial, or affliction, befell the unbelievers]: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) mentioned by El-Aḥmar, as heard by him from the Arabs. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: bilaMCN, like kitaAbN in form, [is an inf. n. of 3, q. v.:]
[and also signifies] Anxiety respecting which one talks to himself, or soliloquizes. (Mṣb. [Compare a meaning of balaMCN, above.])

entry.sense: baliI-N: see the paragraph next following; last sentence.

hom.sense: baliy-apN: see balaMCN, in two places.

Also A she-camel that has her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and is left without food until she dies: (T:) or a she-camel, (M in arts. blw and blI, and Ḳ,) or a mare, or beast of the equine kind, (M in art. blw,) that is bound at the grave of her master, (M, Ḳ,) he being dead, and is left without food or water (M) until she dies (M, Ḳ) and wastes away; for they used to say that her master would be raised from the dead upon her: (M:) or a she-camel which, in the Time of Ignorance, had her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and was left without food or water until she died: or for which was dug a pit, wherein she was left until she died: for they used to assert that men would be raised from the dead riding upon the balaAyaA, [pl. of baliy-apN in the sense above explained, (T, TA,)] or walking if their beasts whereon they rode were not bound, with the head turned backwards, at their graves: (Ṣ:) or a cow, or she-camel, or sheep, or goat, which, in the Time of Ignorance, they used to hamstring, or slaughter, at the grave: so in a trad. (TA.) Suh says that this custom proves that, in the Time of Ignorance, they held the doctrine of the resurrection of the body: but they who held it were the fewer number. (TA.) It is said that baliy-apN is originally mubolaApN↓ or mubal-aApN↓. (TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
manaAzilu laA taraI AlOanoSaAba fiyhaA
walaA Hufara Almubal-aI lilomanuwni
[Places of abode in which thou wilt not see the stones, or other things, that have been set up to be worshipped, nor the pits of the beast left by the grave of the master to die]; meaning places of abode of the people of El-Islám, exclusively of the pagans. (Ṣ.) IAạr says that baliI-N↓ and baliy-apN signify Such as is wearied, or jaded, and emaciated, and dying. (TA.)
baAlK [act. part. n. of balaAhu; Trying, proving, or testing.]
[And hence,] Knowing, or being acquainted [with a thing]; as in the phrase, jaEalotuhu baAliyFA biEucoriI I made him to be acquainted with my excuse, and to know the manner thereof. (Mgh.)
Also Old, and wearing out [or worn out]; applied to a garment. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] baAliyaAtN is used as meaning The places of tents. (Ḥam p. 492.)

entry.sense: mubolaApN, fem. of mubalFI: see baliy-apN.
mubol-FI, and its fem. mubal-aApN: see baliy-apN.

mubal-iyaAtu Women that stand around a man's riding-camel [which they bind, or place in a pit, by his grave, to die of hunger and thirst,] when he has died or been slain, wailing for him. (T, Ṣ.*) You say, qaAmato mubal-iyaAtu fulaAnK yanuHona Ealayohi [The women that bound, or placed, the baliy-ap by the grave of such a one stood around it wailing for him]. (T, Ṣ.)

bil-aworN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bal-uwrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and bilaworN, (Ḳ,) or the last only, (IAạr, T,) [a coll. gen. n., signifying Crystal;] the kind of stone called mahFA, (M,) which shines by reason of its whiteness and clearness; (TA in art. mhw;) a well-known kind of stone, the best of which is brought from the islands of the Zinj (Alz-inoj); (Mṣb;) a well-known kind of precious stone, (Ḳ, TA,) white and transparent: (TA:) [Golius says, but I know not on what authority, if on any better ground than the resemblance of the name, “Græc. Βήρυλλος, beryllus, lapidis genus: de quo vide Plin. xxxvii. 5: aut potius, quo illum lapidem adulterari idem scribit, crystallum:”] n. un. with p: (M:) some say that it is a kind of glass [or factitious crystal; what we term crystal-glass; and to this the word is commonly applied in the present day; though still also applied to rock-crystal]. (TA.)
1. baliIa: see art. blw.
4. AblI Alv-awoba: see art. blw.
biloIN and biloIu safarK:, &c.: see art. blw.

balaI is a particle; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee;) contr. of laA: (Ṣ:) not a noun: (Sb, Ṣ:) it is a replicative; (Ṣ, Mughnee;) an affirmative of what is said [in that to which it is a reply]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) [with very few exceptions] relating only to a negation, which it annuls: (Mṣb, Mughnee:) the final letter is a radical: or, accord. to some, the word is originally balo, [after which an affirmation is to be understood,] and the final letter is augmentative: and some of these say that this letter is a denotative of the fem. gender, because it is [often] pronounced with imáleh. (Mughnee.) It is a reply to an interrogation in which is a negative, (T, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and affirms what is said to thee [in that interrogation]; (M, Ḳ;) whether it be an interrogation in the proper sense, (Mughnee,) as when you say to another, Oalamo tafoEalo kacaA [Didst thou not such a thing?], and he replies, balaI [meaning Yes, or yea, or ay, I did], (T,) or as when one says, Oalayosa zayodN biqaAYimK [Is not Zeyd standing?], and you reply, balaI [Yes, he is]; or be meant to convey reproof, (Mughnee,) as in the Ḳur [lxxv. 3 and 4], OayaHosabu AlUinosaAnu Oano lano najomaEa EiZaAmahu balaI [Doth man think that we will not collect his bones? Yes], (Mṣb, Mughnee,) i. e., we will collect them; (Mṣb;) or be meant to make a person confess, or acknowledge, a thing, (Mughnee,) as in the Ḳur [vii. 171], Oalasotu birab-ikumo qaAluwA balaI [Am I not your Lord? They said, Yea]. (M, Mughnee.) It is also a reply to a simple negation, (Mṣb, Mughnee,) as when I say, maA qaAma zayodN [Zeyd did not stand, or has not stood], and you reply, balaI as an affirmative [meaning Yes, he did, or he has]. (Mṣb.) It occurs in the Ḳur [xxxix. 60], where it is said, balaI qado jaMCatoka MyaAtiI [Yea, my signs have come to thee], preceded by that which is not literally a negation, but which has the force of a negation; for the preceding saying, lawo Oan-a Qll-eha hadaAniI [If God had directed me aright, or would that God, &c.], is like the saying, maA hudiytu [I was not directed aright]. (M.) It also occurs in the books of traditions, in some instances, as a reply to an interrogation without a negative; but these instances are rare, and not to be followed in rendering revelation. (Mughnee.) Az says that when a man says to another, OalaA taquwmu [Wilt thou not stand?], and the latter replies, balaI, he means balo Oaquwmu [Nay, I will stand], adding the alif [written I] to make the pause good; for if he said, balo, the other would expect something more to be said after it. (TA.) It is said that the pronunciation termed imáleh is allowable in the case of balaI; and if so, its final radical letter is I: and some of the grammarians say that this pronunciation of blI is because, by reason of its completeness and independence of meaning, so that it requires nothing after it, it resembles independent nouns, in the cases of which this pronunciation is allowable. (M.)
biloyapN and baliI-N and baliy-apN: see art. blw.

bam-N [The bass in music; used in this sense in the present day: or particularly the bass notes of the lute: in this sense F seems to have understood the saying of ISd that] the bam- of the lute is well known: (M, Ḳ: [in the CK, Albam-a mina AlEuwodi Aw Alwatari Alx is erroneously put for Albam-u mina AlEuwdi mL Oawi Alwataru Alx:]) or (so in the Ḳ) it is the thick [or bass] chord of the lute: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
the word is foreign: (M:) [in Persian bamo:] Az says that it is not Arabic. (TA.)
bum-N i. q. buwmN, q. v. (Ḳ.)
1: see 4.
2. bn-n, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taboniynN, (TA,) He tied a sheep, or goat, in order to fatten it: (Ḳ:) from ban-a biAlomakaAni. (TA.)

4. Abn- biAlomakaAni, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UibonaAnN; (Lth, T;) and ban-a↓ bihi, aor. yabin-u, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. ban-N; (M, TA;) but Aṣ allows only the former verb; (M, TA;) He remained, continued, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he kept, or clave, to the place. (Lth, T, TA.) Accord. to Z, it is a tropical meaning, from the ban-ap [i. e. odour] of the camels or cattle [of a stationary people]. (TA.)
And Oaban-ati Als-aHaAbapu † The cloud remained, or continued raining, (M, TA,) some days, (TA,) and kept its place. (M.)

5. tbn-n He acted, or proceeded, deliberately, not hastily. (T, TA.) An Arab of the desert said to Shureyh, on his desiring to pronounce judgment against him hastily, taban-ano, meaning Act thou deliberately, not hastily. (T.)

hom.sense: bano is a dial. var. of balo, (M, Ḳ,) and so is laA bano of laA balo; or, as some say, formed by substitution [of n for l; not peculiar to any dialect]. (M.) One says, bano waQll-ehi laA Mtiyka [Nay, by God, I will not come to thee]: Fr says that it is of the dial. of Benoo-Saạd and Kelb; and that he had heard the Báhilees say, laA bano, meaning balo [or laA balo]: but IJ says, I do not trace up bano [to any authority] as being an independent word of a particular dialect. (TA.)
[bonu and boni and bona, for Qbonu, &c.: see art. bnI.]

entry.sense: bun-N [Coffee-berries, whether green or roasted, whole or reduced to powder by pounding or grinding;] expl. in the Ḳ as XaIoCN yut-axacu kaAlmur-iI-i [a certain thing that is taken like the condiment termed mur-iy-, which is used to give relish to food or to quicken the appetite]; Ibn-Es-Sim'ánee says, huwaXaIoCN fiI AlkawaAmiyxi [app. meaning it is a thing reckoned among what are termed kwAmyx, pl. of kaAmaxN, which signifies the same as mur-iI-N, for it seems that fI is here used in the sense of mino, or it may be a mistranscription for mino]; the physician Dáwood says, it is the produce of certain trees in El-Yemen; the berries thereof are put into the earth in McaAr [the Syrian month corresponding to March, O. Ṣ.], and it increases, and is gathered in Oabiyb [the Coptic month commencing on the 25th of June, O. Ṣ.; the 7th of July, N. Ṣ.]; it grows to the height of about three cubits, on a stem of the thickness of the thumb, and has a white flower, which is succeeded by a berry like the hazel-nut; sometimes it is cut like beans; and sometimes, when it is divested of its covering, it divides into two halves: it has been proved to be good for alleviating humidities, and cough, and phlegm, and defluxions, and for opening obstructions, and causing a flow of the urine: when roasted, [and pounded or ground,] and well cooked, [i. e. boiled in water,] it is now commonly known by the name of qahowap. (TA.) [Golius, I think, has misunderstood the explanation of this word in the Ḳ: after having given that explanation, and rendered it by “res quæ sumitur instar AlmrI Múrriji,” he adds, “Pers. AbkAmh Abcâma dictæ: hæc sorbitio est rei ex hordeo et frumento paratæ multa cura et arte, quam Malajesa et Halimæus describunt.” He then mentions the signification of coffee-berries as a second and distinct meaning.]

hom.sense: A place having a fetid odour. (Fr, T, Ḳ.)

It also signifies TiroqN mina AlX-aHomi (T, Ḳ) and Als-imani (Ḳ, TA: in the CK Als-amoni:) [said in the TA to mean quw-apN minohumaA, i. e. Strength arising from fat and from fatness: but I think that waAls-imani has been added in the Ḳ in consequence of a misunderstanding, and that the meaning is a layer of fat; this meaning seeming to be indicated by the ex. here following, and corroborated by significations of several conjugates of TiroqN, as TariyqapN and TaraqN and TiraAqN, &c.] One says (T, Ḳ) of a beast (daAb-ap) when it has become fat, (T,) rakibahaA bin-N EalaIbinK (T, Ḳ *) and TiroqN EalaI TiroqK (T) [clearly I think, meaning Layer upon layer, of fat, has accumulated upon it.]

entry.sense: ban-apN A sweet, or pleasant, odour; (Aṣ, AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) such as that of the apple (T, M) and the like, (M,) or the quince: (T:) Sb says that it is a name for a sweet, or pleasant, odour, like xamoTapN: (M,* TA:) and an unpleasant odour; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ;) a fetid odour; (M, Ḳ;) whence ban-apN Algazoli [the odour of the yarn] occurring in a saying of ʼAlee, respecting a weaver; (M;) which shows that AʼObeyd erred in asserting it to have only the first of the foregoing significations; (IB, TA;) which Suh, in the R, assigns also to bunaAnapN↓: (TA:) the odour of sheep, or goats, (Ṣ, M,) or of camels or cattle; (Z, TA;) and of the dung of gazelles; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of the lodging-places of sheep or goats and of oxen or bulls or cows and of gazelles: (T, M:) and sometimes the lodgingplaces themselves, of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) pl. (in all the senses, M) binaAnN. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: bun-iI-N A seller of bun- [or coffee-berries]. (TA.)

Also, [vulgarly pronounced bin-iI,] A species of fish; (Ḳ;) [the cyprinus Bynni of Forskål; described by him in his Descr. Anim. p. 71;] it is white, and is the best kind [of fish], and abundant in the Nile. (TA.)

entry.sense:
banaAnN The fingers; syn. OaSaAbiEu: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but whether it means peculiarly the ASAbE of the hand, or those of the foot also, [i. e. the toes,] is disputed: (TA:) or the ends, or extremities, thereof: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) said to be so called because by their means are ordered those circumstances whereby man continues in existence; from Oaban-a biAlomakaAni: (Mṣb:) mentioned in the Ḳur viii. 12 because therewith one fights, and defends himself: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there signifies all the limbs, or members, of the body: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M:) or the fingers, or toes, and any other parts of all the limbs, or members: (Zj, TA:) or it means in the Ḳur the XawaI; (Lth, T, TA;) so in lxxv. 4; (M;) i. e. the arms or hands and the legs or feet: (Lth, T, TA:) accord. to El-Fárisee the meaning of the words in the Ḳur lxxv. 4 is, we are able to make their extremities like those of the camel, so that they should not profit by them in handicraft: (M, TA:) the n. un. is with p; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) meaning, accord. to Lth, a single UiSobaE [i. e. finger, or toe]; or, accord. to AHeyth, the whole ASbE; or, as some say, the highest Euqodap [or joint] of the ASbE: (T:) the pl. of pauc. is banaAnaAtN; but a pl. of mult. is sometimes used as one of pauc.; and hence the saying of the rájiz,
xamosa banaAnK qaAniYi AlOaZofaAri
[Five fingers, or ends of fingers, intensely red from the dye of hinnà in the nails], meaning xamosFA mina AlbanaAni: and one says, banaAnN muxaD-abN [Fingers, or ends of fingers, dyed, or much dyed, with hinnà]; for every pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] between which and its sing., or n. un., there is no difference but p [added in the latter] may be treated as sing. and masc. (Ṣ.) Lth cites as an ex. of the n. un.,
laAhum-a Oakoramota baniI kinaAnah
layosa liHaI-K fawoqahumo banaAnaho
meaning [O God, Thou hast honoured the sons of Kináneh: there belongs not to any tribe] excel-lence of the measure of a finger above them. (T, TA.)
baniyinN Deliberate and intelligent: (AA, T, Ḳ:) from ban-a biAlomakaAni. (TA.)

hom.sense: banaAnapN n. un. of banaAnN. (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: bunaAnapN: see ban-apN.
Also A meadow, or verdant tract of land somewhat watery, (AA, T, M, Ḳ,) producing herbage, (M, Ḳ,) and adorned with flowers; (TA;) and so banaAnapN↓. (M.)

mubin-N Remaining, continuing, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. (T, TA.) Applied to a mixture of urine and dung (Eabas) upon the tail [of a camel, &c.], it may mean Cleaving, and sticking: or it may be from ban-apN signifying “a fetid odour” [so as to mean having a fetid odour]: thus, in this case, it may be either a part. n. or a possessive epithet. (M, TA.) It signifies also Having the odour of the dung of gazelles; applied to a covert, or hiding-place, of those animals, among trees. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
2. bn-jhu, inf. n. taboniyjN, [He dosed him, or stupified him, with banoj, q. v.;] he gave him banoj to eat. (Ḳ.) [See the act. part. n. below.]

banojN [Hyoscyamus, or henbane;] an arabicized word, [said to be] from [the Persian] banoko; [but see a quotation from Hammer-Purgstall, near the close of this paragraph;]
a certain plant, (Mgh, and Ḥar p. 365,) having an intoxicating kind of grain, or, as some say, (Mgh,) of which the leaves and peel and seeds torpify: (Mgh, Ḥar:) it is said, in the Kánoon, (Mgh,) by Aboo-ʼAlee [Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna], (Ḥar,) that it is a poison which confuses the intellect, and annuls the memory, and occasions insanity and [the disorder termed] xunaAq [or quinsy]; (Mgh, Ḥar;) and it is red, and white: (Ḥar:) a certain plant having a kind of grain that confuses the intellect, and occasions alienation of the mind, or insanity; and sometimes it intoxicates, when a man drinks it after it has been dissolved; and it is said to occasion forgetfulness: (Mṣb:) a certain torpifying plant, well known; different from HaXiyXu AlHaraAfiyXi; disordering the intellect (muxab-iTN liloEaqoli), rendering insane, allaying the pains of humours and pustules, and the earache, (Ḳ, TA,) applied as a liniment or as a poultice; (TA;) the worst kind (Ḳ, TA) for use (TA) is the black; then, the red; and the safest kind is the white. (Ḳ, TA.) [Ḳzw says that the leaves of the garden-hemp (qin-ab busotaAniI-, or XahodaAnaji, the latter of which properly signifies hemp-seed,) are the banoj which, when eaten, disorders the intellect. And El-Idreesee applies the appellation HaXiyXiy-ap to the “Assassins.” This establishes the correctness of De Sacy's opinion, that the appellation “Assassins” is derived from the vulgar pl. HaX-aAXiyn, (hemp-eaters, or persons who intoxicate themselves with hemp,) for HaX-aAXiyn is syn. with HaXiyX-ap, and the sect called by us the “Assassins” are expressly said by the Arabs to have made frequent use of banoj. Baron Hammer-Purgstall, correctly regarding banoj as hyoscyamus (or henbane), makes the following important observations, “‘ Bendj, ’ the pl. of which in Coptic is ‘ nibendj, ’ is without doubt the same plant as the ‘ nepenthe, ’ which has hitherto so much perplexed the commentators of Homer. Helen evidently brought the nepenthe from Egypt, and bendj is there still reputed to possess all the wonderful qualities which Homer attributes to it.” (Trébutien, “Contes Inédits des Mille et une Nuits,” tome i. p. 12, note.)] The phrase Xariba Albanoja is used by El-Karkhee [as meaning He drank the bnj] because it is mixed with water; or [as meaning he took, or swallowed, the bnj,] according to the conventional language of the physicians. (Mgh.)
muban-ijN One who employs a stratagem by means of food containing banoj [in order to obtain some advantage over another, by stupifying him therewith; as the “Assassins” used to do]. (Mgh.)
banodN is a Persian word arabicized, originally signifying A knot, or tie. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) ‡ [Any of] the stops that are put between the beads of the suboHap to mark the place where the performer of tasobiyH pauses on the occasion of a thing's diverting his attention: so in the Comm. on the Tohfeh by the seyyid ʼOmar El-Basree: (MF, TA:) app. post-classical and recent. (TA.)
A dam; a thing that stops, or dams, [water, or] from water (Al-aciI yusokiru mina AlmaMCi). (Ḳ. [In the CK, yusokaru is put in the place of yusokiru. In this sense, also, it is of Persian origin.])

A stratagem, a trick, or an expedient, of which one makes use: (T, Ḳ:) a snare by which one snares men: (TA in art. qmT:) pl. bunuwdN. (T.) You say, fulaAnN kaviyrN Albunuwdi Such a one abounds in, or practises much, stratagems, tricks, or expedients, (Lth, T, A,) and mischievous, or calamitous, acts. (A.) In this sense, also, it is an arabicized Persian word. (TA.)
An enigma. (TA.)
A pawn that is tied (munoEaqidN, in the CK mutaEaq-idN,) by a queen in the game of chess: as though it confined and tied itself. (TA.)

Also a Persian word, arabicized, (Ṣ, A,) signifying A large banner, standard, or ensign: (En-Naḍr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of a general, or leader, (T, M,) of the Greeks, (M,) under which are ten thousand men, (T, M,) or less, or more: (T:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of horsemen: (El-Hujeymee, T:) [in barbarous Latin bandum; and in Spanish, bandera; as mentioned by Golius; and in modern Arabic banodiyrN:] pl. as above: (Ṣ, M:) it has no pl. of pauc. (M.)
[The pl.] bunuwdN also signifies, in Greece, [Provinces, or districts;] what are called OajonaAdN in Syria, and OaEoraADN in El-Ḥijáz, and kuwarN in El-'Irak, and maxaAliyfN in El-Yemen. (Yákoot.)
banodarN [app. from the Persian banodaro,] A place where ships or boats anchor or moor; a port [or port-town: pl. banaAdiru]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. banodaqa He made a thing into banaAdiq [meaning bullets, or little balls], (Mgh, Ḳ,) or like bnAdq (TA.)
[In post-classical Arabic, He shot a bullet, or bullets, from a cross-bow or other weapon.]
bndq Uilayohi † He looked sharply, or intently, at him, or it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: bunoduqN [The hazel-nut; or hazel-nuts; so in the present day;] a certain thing that is eaten; (Mṣb;) i. q. jil-awoz: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or, as some say, like jl-wz; brought from an island; the best whereof is the fresh, heavy, white, and sweet in taste; the old being bad: it is beneficial as a remedy for palpitation, parched with anise-seed; and for poisons, and wasting of the kidneys, and burning of the urine; and with pepper, it excites the venereal faculty; with sugar, it removes cough; and the shell thereof, burnt, and applied as a collyrium, sharpens the sight: (TA:) they assert that the suspending it upon the upper arm preserves from scorpions, (Ḳ,) i. e., from their stinging: (TA:) the moistening of the top of the head of a child with the powder of it when burnt, together with oil, removes the blueness of its eyes and the redness of its hair: and the Indian kind thereof is an antidote very beneficial to the eyes: (Ḳ, TA:) but in some copies of the Ḳ, [and so in the CK,] instead of liloEayonayoni, we here find liloEin-iyni [for the impotent in respect of the venereal faculty]: (TA:) [it is said in the Mṣb that most hold the n to be augmentative: but this is not the case; for] the word is Persian [arabicized, from funoduqo]: (Ḳ:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {bunoduqapN}: pl. banaAdiqu. (Mṣb.)

[Hence, Bullets, i. e.] certain things that one shoots, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) made of clay: (Mṣb:) n. un. with p {bunoduqapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the latter signifies a piece of clay, made round, which one shoots, or casts; or i. q. julaAhiqN: (Mgh:) it is said in the Shifá el-Ghaleel to be an arabicized word: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [See a prov. voce HidaOapN. Hence qawosu Albunoduqi The crossbow. In modern Arabic, bunoduq is also applied to Balls of any kind of the size of hazel-nuts: n. un. with p {bunoduqapN}.]

bunoduqiI-N A garment, or piece of cloth, of fine, delicate, or thin, linen. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [SM says,] It is most probably, in my opinion, so called in relation to the l and of Albunoduqiy-ap [or Venice]. (TA.) [In modern Arabic, A Venetian sequin: pl. banaAdiqapN.]
bunodaqaAniI-N [app. a post-classical word,] A maker of cross-bows (qisiI- Albunoduq). (El-Makreezee's Khitat, art. xT- AlbndqAny-yn.)

binoSirN The finger that is next to the little finger; (Ṣ in art. bSr;) [the third finger;] that which is between the little and middle fingers: (Mṣb in art. bSr, and Ḳ:) of the fem. gender: (Ḳ:) pl. banaASiru, (Ṣ,) or banaASirapN. (Mṣb.) Accord. to the author of the Ḳ, the n is a radical letter, and therefore the mention of this word in art. bSr is wrong. (TA.)

banafosajN, of the measure qaEal-alN, like safarojalN, (Mṣb,) [an arabicized word, from the Persian banafoXa; The violet; viola odorata of Linn: and accord. to Forskål (Flora AEgypt. Arab. p. ciii.) applied in El-Yemen to the “iris:” and (p. cxx.) “tagetes dubia?”] what is thus called is well known: the smelling it in its fresh state is beneficial to those who are heated by wrath (AlmaHoruwriyn), and the continual smelling of it induces good sleep: the conserve made of it is beneficial for the pleurisy (caAtu Aljanobi), and for inflammation of the lungs (caAtu Alr-iYapi), and for cough, and for headache. (Ḳ.)
1. banaqa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yabonuqu}, inf. n. banoqN, (TḲ,) He joined [a thing to another thing, like as the baniyqap of a shirt is joined: see the pass. part. n., below]; syn. waSala. (Ḳ.)
2. bn-q AlqamiySa, inf. n. taboniyqN, He put a baniyqap to the shirt. (Ḳ.)

bn-q AljaEobapa ‡ He made the upper part of the quiver wide [by adding to it the like of a baniyqap (see the pass. part. n., below,)], and the lower part narrow: (Ḳ, TA:) or he widened its upper part, the lower part being [or remaining] narrow. (JK.)
binaqN: see what next follows.
binaqapN: see what next follows.
binayqN: see what next follows.

binayqapN The libonap, (AZ, Abu-l-Hajjáj El-Aạlam, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or dixoriSap, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás El-Ahwal, TA,) [both of which signify the gore,] of a shirt, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a garment; (JK;) or the dxrSp is longer than the lbnp: (Seer, TA:) and any piece that is added in a garment or a leathern bucket to widen it: (Abu-l-Hajjáj El-Aalam, TA:) or, accord. to IDrd, the dxAryS of a shirt: (TA: [but this is app. a mistranscription for its sing. dixoriyS, q. v., a dial. var. of dixoriSap:]) or the jurub-aAn [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt: (Ḳ:) jrb-An is prefixed to Albnyqp in a verse of Jereer, governing the latter in the gen. case, to show that both these words have the same meaning: (TA:) binaqapN↓, also, signifies the same as bnyqp; (JK, Ḳ; [in the latter of which it is mentioned in such a manner as perhaps to denote that it has only the last of the significations above; but I think that this restriction is not meant;]) and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is binaqN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) Th mentions banaAYiqN and binaqN, and says that the latter is a pl. pl.; [i. e., pl. of the former;] but this is unintelligible: (TA:) banaAYiqN is pl. of baniyqapN, (JK, Ṣ, &c.,) and syn. with daxaAriySN. (JK.) AZ cites, from Mejnoon,
kamaA Dam-a OazoraAra AlqamiySi AlbanaAYiqN , (Ṣ, IB,) which is an inverted phrase; the meaning being,
kamaA Dam-a OazoraAru AlqamiySi AlbanaAYiqaA
[Like as the buttons of the shirt draw together the gores: if the last word mean the gores]: or, if the bnyqp of the shirt be really its jrb-An, the meaning is intelligible [without inversion]; for its jrb-An is the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons; and when one desires to draw it together, he puts its buttons into the loops, and so draws together the bosom [of the shirt, with its buttons,] to the uppermost part of the chest. (IB, TA.) Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee explains AlbnAYq, here, as meaning the loops into which the buttons are inserted; and accord. to this explanation the meaning is plain, not requiring the supposition of inversion nor of deviation from the usual way: but the first explanation is that which is generally given. (TA.) In the saying,
qado OagotadiI waAld-ahoru cuw baniyqi↓
[in the last word of which, p is elided; lit., Sometimes I go forth early in the morning, when the time has a baniyqap;] Lth says that the whiteness of the dawn is likened to the whiteness of the bnyqp; citing another verse, in which a shirt is described as having white bnAYq. (TA.)
jaEobapN mubn-aqapN ‡ A quiver that is widened: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) or in the upper part of which is added what resembles a baniyqap, to enlarge it. (A, TA.)
TariyqN muban-aqN ‡ A wide road. (TA.)

OaroDN mabonuwqapN † Land joined (mawoSuwlap) to other land, like as the baniyqap of a shirt is joined. (ISd, TA.) And mafaAzapN mabonuwqapN, (JK,) or mabonuwqapN biOuxoraI, (TA,) ‡ [A desert, or a desert in which is no water,, &c.,] joined to another. (JK, TA.)
AibonumN or AibonamN, and QbonumN or QbonamN; and QboniymaA for QbonimaA: see AibonN, in art. bnI.
1. banaA, aor. _u {yabonuwu}: see art. bnI.
AibonN, held by some to be originally banawN: see art. bnI.
bunuw-apN: see art. bnI.
banawiy-N: see art. bnI.

hom.sense: 1. banaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _i {yaboniIu}, (M, Mṣb,) and _u, but the former is the more common, (M,) [or rather the only form commonly known,] inf. n. binaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and binFA (T, and TA as from the M [but it is not in the transcript of the M in the TT]) and banoIN and bunoyaAnN and binoyapN and bnaAyapN, (M, Ḳ,) He built it; framed it; constructed it; contr. of hadamahu; (M, Ḳ;) namely, a house, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or tent, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,), &c.; (Mṣb;) as also AbtnAh↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bn-Ahu↓; (M, Ḳ;) or the last has teshdeed given to it to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects; and hence you say, bn-I quSuwrFA [He built palaces, or pavilions: or he raised them high: see the pass. part. n. below]. (Ṣ, TA.) AḤn speaks of a kind of plank as being used fiI binaMCi Als-ufuni [in the construction of ships]: but binaMCN is originally used only in relation to that which does not grow; as stone, and clay, and the like. (M.) You say also, banaI OaroDFA, for banaI fiI OaroDK [He built in, or upon, land]. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] banaI EalaI Oaholihi, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or EalaI QmoraOatihi, (Mgh,) and banaI bihaA also, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to IDrd (Mgh, Mṣb) and IJ, (M,) and occurring in traditions and elsewhere, though said in the Ṣ to be vulgar, (IAth, MF,) and said to be so by ISk, (T, Mṣb,) and by some said to be not allowable, (M,) but the former is the more chaste, (Mṣb,) inf. n. binaMCN; (Ṣ, TA;) as also AbtnI↓, (Ḳ,) i. e. AbtnI ElyhA, (ISk, Mṣb,) or AbtnI bihaA, (IJ, M,) He had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of the marriage: (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he went in to his wife [for the first time]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) originating from the fact that the bridegroom used, on that occasion, to pitch a tent for her, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) a new tent, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and furnish it with what was requisite, (Mṣb,) or a new tent was set up for him, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in honour of him. (Mṣb.) [See also bayotN.]

binaAyapN is sometimes used in relation to nobility: (M, Ḳ:) and the verb thus used is banaI, as above, (T, M,) having [also] binFI for its inf. n., (IAạr, T,) and binaMCN; held by many to be tropical, but by some to be proper. (MF.) Lebeed says,
fabanaI lanaA rafiyEFA samokuhu
fasamaA Uilayohi kaholuhaA wagulaAmuhaA , (M) And He (namely, God,) hath built for us a house of nobility of lofty pitch, and its (the tribe's) middle-aged and its youth have risen to it: i. e., all of them have attained to high degrees. (EM, p. 180.)

banaI badanahu It (food) fattened his body, (Ḳ,) and made it large: (TA:) and banaI laHomahu, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaboniIu}, (TA,) inf. n. binaMCN, (M,) or banoIN, (TA,) It (food) made his flesh to grow, (T, M, Ḳ,) and to become large. (T, TA.)
banaI Alr-ajula He reared, brought up, or educated, the man; (M, Ḳ;) as also AbtnAhu↓. (M.)
[banaI kalimapF, inf. n. binaMCN, He formed a word.]

[And He made a word indeclinable, so as to end invariably with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel.] binaMCu kalimapK [when the former word is considered as the inf. n. of the pass. form buniIa, generally] signifies A word's keeping always the same mode of termination, ending with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel, not by reason of any governing word: (M, Ḳ:) as though the word resembled a fixed, immoveable building. (M.) [You say, buniyato EalaI Als-ukuwni It was made indeclinable, with a quiescent letter for its termination; and EalaI AlfatoHi with fet-ḥ for its termination;, &c.]
[And in like manner you say, banaI AlqaSiydapa EalaI AlbaMCi, &c., He made the qSydp to have b, &c., for its rhyme-letter, or its chief rhyme-letter.]
banati Alqawosu EalaI watarihaA The bow clave to its string (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) so that it (the latter) almost broke. (T, Ṣ.) [See the part. n. below.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

[Hence,] He introduced him to his wife [on the occasion of his marriage]: whence the saying of ʼAlee, mataI tubonyiniI, accord. to IAth properly meaning mataI tajoEaluniI OaboniI bizawojatiI [When wilt thou make me to have my wife conducted to me? or, to go in to my wife?]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. taban-ato, said of a woman sitting, (T, TA,) She became like a tent (T, IAth, Ḳ,* TA) of the kind called mibonaApN, (T, TA,) i. e., a qub-ap of skin; by reason of her fatness, (T, IAth, TA,) and largeness, (T, TA,) or fleshiness: (IAth, TA:) or she parted her legs; as though from mibonaAp, i. e. a qub-ap of skin, which, when pitched, is spread out by the ropes: so this woman, sitting cross-legged, spread apart her legs. (T, TA.) And tbn-I, said of a camel's hump, It became fat. (M.)
tbn-Ahu He adopted him as a son: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he asserted him to be, or claimed him as, a son: (M:) and tbn-I bihi signifies the same. (Zj, TA.)
8. AbtnI: see 1, in three places.
Also It became built, framed, or constructed. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: binotN; pl. banaAtN: fem. of AibonN, which see, in three places.
bunFI: see binaMCN.
binFI: see binaMCN.

banaApu All-aHomi, (IB, TA,) the former of which words is incorrectly written in the Ḳ bnAt, (TA,) A girl whose flesh has been made to grow and become large: (IB, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, maboniy-apN is erroneously put for maboniy-atuhu:]) or, accord. to a learned scholiast, this is a mistake of IB, and the meaning is sweet in odour; i. e. sweet in the odour of the flesh. (TA.)
banaAtN: pl. of binotN; and sometimes of AibonN: see AibonN.
banuwna: pl. of AibonN, which see below.
bunoyapN: see binaMCN.

binoyapN A form, mode, or manner, of building or framing or construction; a word like miXoyapN and rikobapN. (T, TA.) [The form, or mode of formation, of a word.] Natural constitution: as in the phrase, fulaAnN SaHiyHu Albinoyapi [Such a one is sound in natural constitution]. (Ṣ.)
See also binaMCN.
binotiI-N: see what next follows.
Also Of, or relating to, what are termed bunay-aAtu AlT-ariyqi, i. e., the small roads that branch off from the main road. (Ṣ.)
bunoyaAnN and bunoyaAnapN: see what next follows.

binaMCN [originally an inf. n.: (see 1, first sentence:) then applied to A building; a structure; an edifice;] a thing that is built, or constructed; pl. OaboniyapN, and pl. pl. OaboniyaAtN: (M, Ḳ:) and bunoyaAnN↓ [also] has this meaning; (Mṣb;) [and is likewise originally an inf. n.;] or this signifies a wall; syn. HaAYiTN; (Ṣ;) or it may be a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n., meaning buildings, structures, edifices, or walls,] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is bunoyaAnapN↓, and as such may be masc. and fem: (Er-Rághib, TA:) binoyapN↓ and bunoyapN↓ also signify [the same as binaMCN as explained above; or] a thing that one has built, framed, or constructed; (M, Ḳ;) or, accord. to some, the former of these two relates to objects of the senses, and the latter to objects of the mind, to glory or honour or the like; (MF, TA;) and their pls. are binFI↓ and bunFI↓; (Ḳ;) or, accord. to the Ṣ and M, these two appear to be sings.; (TA;) [or they may be pls. or sings.; for J says that] AlbunaI is like AlbinaI; one says, bunoyapN and bunFI, and binoyapN and binFI; (Ṣ;) [and ISd says that] binoyapN and bunoyapN signify as above, and so binFI and bunFI; or, accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, binFI is pl. of binoyapN; or it may be used by poetic licence for binaMCN: (M:) accord. to IAạr, binFI signifies buildings, or structures, of clay: and also [tents] of wool; (T;) and binaMCN likewise signifies a tent (M, TA) in which the Arabs of the desert dwell, in the desert, (TA,) such as is called xibaMC; (M, TA;*) and TiraAfN and qub-apN and miDorabN are names applied to dwellings of the same kind; (TA;) pl. OaboniyapN: (M:) the moveable dwelling, such as the xayomap and miZal-ap and fusoTaAT and suraAdiq and the like, is called binaMCN as being likened to the building of burnt bricks and of clay and of gypsum. (M.) [See also baniy-apN.]

Also The roof, or ceiling, of a house or chamber or the like; as in the Ḳur [ii. 20], Al-aciI jaEala lakumu AlOaroDa firAXFA waAls-amaMCa binaMCF [Who hath made for you the earth as a bed, and the heaven as a roof, or ceiling]: (Ṣ, [but wanting in some copies,] and Jel:) so says AZ: (Ṣ:) or the meaning here is, as a tent (qub-ap) pitched over you. (Bḍ.)
And The body, with the limbs or members. (TA.)

And i. q. niToEN [A thing that is spread on the ground to serve as a table for food, &c., made of leather; like mibonaApN]: occurring in a trad., where it is mentioned as spread on the ground, on a day of rain, for Moḥammad to pray upon: so says Sh. (T.)

bunaI-N, [said to be] originally bunayowN, A little son; [used as a term of endearment;] (Mṣb;) dim. of AibonN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) You say, yaA bunaI-i and yaA bunaI-a [O my little son, or O my child], with kesr to the I and with fet-ḥ also; like as you say, yaA Oabati and yaA Oabata [which see in art. Abw, voce OabN]. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [The fem. is bunay-apN A little daughter; dim. of binotN. And hence,]
bunay-aAtu AlT-ariyqa The small roads that branch off from the main road; (Ṣ;) what are termed Alt-ur-ahaAtu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The Arabs say, Alr-ifoqu bunaI-u AlHilomi, meaning Alrfq is like AlHlm. (IAạr, ISd.)

bunuw-apN Sonship: (Lth, Zj, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [it may be originally bunuwyapN, for Az says, app. on the authority of Zj,] it is not a decisive proof that the last radical is w, since they say futuw-apN, though the dual [of the word from which this is derived] is fatayaAni; (T;) [and ISd says that] bunuw-apN is thus because of the ḍammeh. (M.)

Albaniy-apu [properly The building, like AlbinaMCu, &c.: but particularly applied to] the Kaabeh; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) because of its nobleness. (M, Ḳ.) One says, laA warab-i hecihi Albaniy-api maA kaAna kacaA wakacaA [No, by the Lord of this building (the Kaabeh), such and such thing were not]: (Ṣ, TA:) and this was a common form of oath. (TA.) The Kaabeh is also called baniy-apu UiboraAhiyma [The building of Abraham]; because he built it. (TA.)
ban-aMCN A builder; [meaning one whose business is that of building;] an architect. (M.) [See also what next follows.]

baAnK [Building, framing, or constructing]: accord. to AʼObeyd, its pl. is OabonaMCN; and in like manner, OajonaMCN is pl. of jaAnK: and hence the prov., OabonaAWuhaA OajonaAWuhaA, (M,) or OajonaAWuhaA OabonaAWuhaA, i. e. The injurers thereof, meaning this house (hecihi Ald-aAr), by demolishing it, are the builders thereof. (Ṣ in art. jnI.) ISd says, I am of opinion that these two pls. are not used except in this prov.: and J says, in art. jnI, I think that the prov. is originally junaAtuhaA bunaAtuhaA; but IB affirms that it is not so: and he says that the prov. is applied to him who does, or makes, a thing without consideration, and commits a fault therein, which he repairs by undoing what he has done or made: it originated from the fact that the daughter of a certain king of El-Yemen, during his absence on a military expedition, built, by the advice of others, a house, which he, disliking it, commanded them to demolish. (TA in art. jnI. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 294.])
A bridegroom: from banaI EalaI Oaholihi [q. v.]. (TA.) And hence, Any one going in to his wife. (Ṣ, TA.)
