AiHotamaluwA; this being said by him to be the proper signification of the verb: or, as some say, the meaning is, [they bore the burden of] sin for which they deserved the fire [of Hell] following upon sin for which they deserved the same: or they returned [laden with anger upon anger]: (T:) or they became deserving of anger upon anger. (Ksh.) [See a similar phrase, also from the Ḳur, above.] It is said in a form of prayer, OabuwoCu Uilayoka biniEomatika, meaning I acknowledge, or confess, to Thee thy favour [towards me, as imposing an obligation upon me]. (Mgh.) You say also, baMCN biHaq-ihi; (Ṣ;) and bid-imihi; (M, Ḳ;) He acknowledged, or confessed, [himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for] his right, due, or just claim; (Ṣ;) and so [for] his blood: (M, Ḳ:) the verb expresses acknowledgment, or confession, always of something for which its agent is, as it were, indebted, or answerable; not the contrary. (Ṣ.)

baMCa bikaf-iI, in a poem of Sakhr-el-Gheí, means It [referring to a sword] became in my hand; my hand became to it a mabaMCap, i. e. maOowFI [or place of abode]; it returned, and became in my hand: or, accord. to Ibn-Ḥabeeb, i. q. Aisotaqal-a [app. a mistranscription for Aisotaqar-a it rested, or remained; the verb bMC in this phrase being from bawaMCN signifying luzuwmN, explained above]. (Skr p. 16.)

baMCN also signifies It (a thing, TA) suited, matched, tallied, corresponded, or agreed. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] baMCa fulaAnN bifulaAnK (inf. n. bawaMCN, TA) Such a one was the like, or equal, of such a one, to be slain [in retaliation] for him: (T:) or became his like, or equal, so that he was slain [in retaliation] for him: (Mgh:) and was slain for him, (AZ, T, Ṣ,) and his blood became a compensation for the blood of the other: (T:) or was deserving of being, or fit to be, slain in retaliation for him, (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 58,) because his equal: (Ksh ibid.:) or was slain for him, and so became equal with him; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also OabaMCahu↓, and baAwaOahu↓. (M, Ḳ.) One says, buWobihi, i. e. Be thou of such as are slain [in retaliation] for him. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a prov., baMCato EaraAri bikaHolK 'Arári became slain for Kahl: these were two cows, which smote each other with their horns, and both died: the proverb is applied to any two that become equal. (Ṣ in this art.; and the same and Ḳ in art. Er. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 151.])

baMCa damahu bidamihi, (T,* M, Ḳ,) inf. n. bawoCN and bawaMCN, (M,) He made his blood equal with [or an equivalent for] his [i. e. another's] blood [by shedding the former in retaliation]. (M, Ḳ.) And baMCahu, [or baMCahu bihi,] (M,) or OabaMCahu↓ bh, (T, Ṣ,) and AisotibaMCahu↓ bh, (Ṣ,) He slew him [in retaliation] for him; (T, Ṣ, M;) i. e., the slayer for the slain. (Ṣ.) OabaMCa↓ fulaAnFA bifulaAnK [He slew such a one in retaliation for such a one] is said when the Sultán has retaliated for a man upon another man: and OabaMCahu↓, inf. n. UibaMCapN, signifies he (the Sultán, or another,) slew him in retaliation. (T.)

2. bw-Ohu manozilFA He lodged him in an abode; (Fr, T, M, Ḳ;) as also bw-Ahu fiI manozilK, (M, Ḳ,) and AbMChu↓ manozilFA: (T,* M, Ḳ:) or, as also bw-O lahu manozilFA, (the latter mentioned by Fr, T,) he prepared for him an abode, (Ṣ, Mgh,) and assigned, or gave, him a place therein: (Ṣ:) and baw-aOotuhu dArFA and bw-Atu lahu dArFA I lodged him in a house: (Mṣb:) and baw-aOotuka bayotFA I took for thee a house: and tabaw-aM↓ liqawomikumaA bimiSora buyuwtFA [in the Ḳur x. 87] means take ye two, for your people, in Egypt, houses: (Akh, T:) or tabaw-uWN↓ [or tabaw-uWu makaAnK] signifies a man's putting a mark upon a place, when it pleases him, that he may abide there: (El-'Itreefee, T:) or tbw-Ohu↓ he put it [a place] into a right, or proper, state; and prepared it: (Sh,* T:) or tbw-O↓ bayotFA he took a house as a place of abode, or as a dwelling: (Mṣb:) or tbw-O↓ manozilFA he looked for the best place that could be seen, and the most level, or even, and the best adapted by its firmness, for his passing the night there, and took it as a place of abode; (Fr, T;) or he took for himself a place of abode; (T, Mgh;) or he alighted and sojourned in a place of abode: and AstbMChu↓ he took it as a mabaMCap [or place of abode]: (Ṣ:) and bw-O AlmakaAna and AbMC↓ bihi (Ḳ) and tbw-O↓ [i. e. tbw-O bihi] (Sh, T, Ḳ) he alighted in the place, and stayed, or dwelt, in it: (Sh, T, Ḳ:) or AbMC↓ bh he stayed, or dwelt, in it, i. e., a place: (Akh, T:) and tbw-O↓ AlmakaAna he alighted and abode in the place: (M:) [whence, in the Ḳur lix. 9,] waQl-aciyna tabaw-aWuwA↓ Qld-aArawa QloUiymaAna [and they who have made their abode in the City of the Prophet and in the faith]; the faith being likened to a place of abode; or the meaning may be makaAna AlUiymaAni [the place of the faith]. (M.) baw-aOahumo manozilFA (AZ, M) and OabaMCahumo↓ mnzlFA (AZ, TA) also signify He alighted and abode with them by the face, or front, of a mountain, where it rose from its base, (AZ, M, TA,) or next to a river, or brook. (AZ, TA.)

[Hence, (see baMCapi,)] bw-O (inf. n. tabowiyoCN, Ḳ) † Inivit [feminam]: and he married [a woman]; took [her] in marriage: syn. nakaHa: (M, Ḳ:) and also taz-awaja. (TA. [There mentioned as a distinct signification.]) The verb is trans. in these two senses. (TḲ.)
bw-O AlrumoHa naHowahu He directed the spear towards him; (T, Ṣ;) and (T) confronted him with it; (T, M, Ḳ;) and prepared it, or made it ready [to thrust it towards him]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. baAwaOhu: see baMCa fulaAnN bifulaAnK.

hom.sense: 4. OabaOotuhu: see buWotu bihi Uilayohi, near the beginning of this art.

AbMC AlUibila, (T, Ṣ, O, L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ, in other copies of which we find AbMC biAloUibili,) inf. n. UibaMCapN, (T,) He brought back the camels to the mabaMCap (T, Ṣ, O, L) or maEoTin, (Ḳ,) both of which signify the place where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place. (L.) And AbMC AlUibila, (T, M,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He made the camels to lie down [in the mabaMCap], one beside another. (T, M.) And AbMC Ealayohi maAlahu He drove back, or brought back, to their nightly resting-place, for him, his cattle, (Ṣ, M, TA,) i. e., his camels, or his sheep or goats. (Ṣ, TA.) And [hence,] OabaMCa Qll-ehu Ealayohimo naEamFA laA yasaEuhaA AlmuraAHu [God bestowed upon them cattle (i. e. camels, &c.) which the nightly resting-place thereof would not contain]. (TA.)
See also 2, in four places.
AbMC AlOadiyma He put the skin, or hide, into the tanning liquid. (Ḳ.) In the O, the action is ascribed to a woman. (TA.)
AbMC minohu He fled from him. (M, Ḳ.)
falaApN tubiIoCu fiI falaAopK A desert that extends (lit. goes away) into a desert, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of its amplitude. (TA.)

OabaOotuhu I made him to acknowledge, or confess. (M.) [It seems to be indicated in the M that one says, OabaOotuhu bidami fulaAnK, meaning I made him to acknowledge, or confess, himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for the blood of such a one.]
See also 1, (towards the end of the paragraph,) in four places.

entry.sense: 5: see 2, in eight places.

Alr-ajulu yatabaw-aOu mino Oaholihi kamaA yatabaw-aOu mino daArihi The man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house; syn. yasotamokinu minohaA. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
See also 10.

6. tabaAwaM They two (namely, two slain men, M) became equal [by being slain, one in retaliation for the other]. (M, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Oamarahumo Oano yatabaAwaWuwA; incorrectly related as being yatabMCawoA; (Ṣ, Mgh;) meaning He (the Prophet) ordered them that they should be equal in retaliation, in their fighting: (Mgh:) the occasion of the order was this: there was a conflict between two tribes of the Arabs, and one of the two tribes had superior power over the other, so they said, “We will not be content unless we slay, for the slave of our party, the free of their party; and for the woman, the man:” AʼObeyd holds the former reading to be the right. (T.)
10. AstbMChu: see 2.

In the following verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Abee-Sulmà,
falamo Oara maEoXarFA OasaruwA hadiy-FA
walamo OarajaAra bayotK yusotabaMCu
ISk says that the hadiI- is one who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection; and that ystbMC is syn. with yutabaw-aOu↓, meaning whose wife is taken as a wife [by another man]: but Aboo-ʼAmr EshSheybánee says that ystbMC is from AlbawaMCu, meaning “retaliation:” [and accord. to this interpretation, which is the more probable, the verse may be rendered, And I have not seen a company of men who have made captive one entitled to respect, or honour, or protection, nor have I seen one who has begged the protection of the people of a house, or of a tent, slain in retaliation:] for, he says, he came to them desiring to beg their protection, and they took him, and slew him in retaliation for one of themselves. (T.) See 1, near the end of the paragraph.
AisotabaOotu AlHakama, and biAloHakam, I asked the judge to retaliate upon a slayer; to slay the slayer for the slain. (M.)

hom.sense: baMCN: see baMCapN.
A libidinous man. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)

The name of the letter b, q. v.; as also baA: pl. of the former baMCaAtN; and of the latter OabowaMCN. (TA ubi suprà.) The dim. is buyay-apN, meaning A little b: and a b faintly pronounced: [and app. buway-apN also, as the medial radical is generally held to be w:] and in like manner is formed the dim. of every similar name of a letter. (Lth, on the letter HaMC, in TA, bAb AlAlf Allyn-p.)
baMCapN: see mabaMCapN, in three places.

Also, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and baMCN↓, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and baAhapN, with the C changed into h, (TA,) and baAhN, (IAạr, T, Mṣb,) with A and h, but IḲt asserts this last to be a mistranscription, (Mṣb, TA,) [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] and IAmb says that baMCapN is sing., or n. un., of baMCN, and baMCN [or baMCapN] has for pl. baMCaAtN, (TA,) ‡ Coïtus conjugalis: and marriage: syn. jimaAEN (T, Mṣb) and nikaAHN (Aṣ, Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and tazowiyjN: (T:) from baMCapN signifying a place of abode; [see mabaMCapN;] (T, Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb;) because it is generally in a place of abode; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or because the man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb: see 5:) baMCapN is applied [also] to the marriage-contract; because he who takes a woman in marriage lodges her in a place of abode. (T.) [See also baAhN, in art. bwh.] It is said in a trad., mani QsotaTaAEa minokumu AlbaMCa pa faloyataz-awjo He who is able, of you, to marry, let him marry: (T:) or a prefixed noun is here suppressed; the meaning being, he who finds [or is able to procure] the provisions (muWan) of marriage, let him marry. (Mṣb, TA.) And one says, fulaAnN HariySN EalaI AlbaMCapi Such a one is vehemently desirous of marriage. (Aṣ, T.)

entry.sense: biyoYapN a subst. from baw-aOahu manozilFA. (M, Ḳ.) [See 2; and] see also mabaMCapN.

A mode, or manner, of taking for oneself a place of abode: (M:) and [hence,] a state, or condition. (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) You say, Uin-ahu laHasanu AlbiyoYapi Verily he has a good mode, or manner, of taking for himself a place of abode: (M:) or verily he is of good state or condition. (Ṣ.) And baAta bibiyoYapi He passed the night in an evil state or condition (AZ, T, Ṣ,* M.) bawaMCN Equal; equivalent; like; alike; a match; (Akh, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) and particularly, if slain in retaliation for another. (M.) It is applied to one, and to two, and to more: so that you say, fulaAnN bawaMCN fulaAnN Such a one is the equal,, &c., of such a one if slain in retaliation for him: (M:) and huwa bawaMCN He is an equal,, &c.; and so hiIa she: and humo bawaMCN They are equals,, &c.; and so hun-a they, referring to females: (Mgh:) and humo bawaMCN fiI hecaA AlOamori They are equals in this affair. (T.) Hence, in a trad. of ʼAlee, respecting witnesses, Uaca kaAnuwA bawaMCN When they are equals in number and rectitude. (Mgh.) And maA fulaAnN lifulaAnK bibawaMCN Such a one is not an equal,, &c., to such a one. (T.) And damu fulaAnK bawaMCN lidami fulaAnK The blood of such a one is an equivalent for the blood of such a one. (Ṣ.) And AljiraAHaAtu bawaMCN Wounds are to be retaliated equally: a trad. (T, Mgh.) And Alqawomu EalaI bawaMCi The people, or company of men, are in a state of equality. (T.) And qusima AlmaAlu bayonahumo EalaI bawaMCK The property was divided among them equally. (T. [A similar ex. is given in the Mgh, and explained in the same manner; but there I find Eano bawaMCK; perhaps a mistranscription.]) And kal-amonaAhumo faOajaAbuwA Eano bawaMCK waAHidK [in a copy of the M EalaI bwMC wAHd] We spoke to them, and they replied with one reply: (T, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) i. e., their reply was not discordant: Eano being here used in the sense of bi. (TA.)

Also Retaliation. (T.) [See 1, near the end of the paragraph: as well as in other places.] It is related in a trad., that Jaạfar Es-Sádik, being asked the reason of the rage of the scorpion against the sons of Adam, said, turiydu AlbawaMCa [It desires retaliation]; i. e., it hurts like as it is hurt. (TA.)
baAYiI-N and baAwiy-N↓ rel. ns. of baMCN and baA the names of the letter b; (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np;) and bayawiI-N↓ is a rel. n. of the same. (M in art. b.)
baAwiI-N see baAYiI-N.
bayawiI-N see baAYiI-N.

mabaMCapN The nightly resting-place of camels; (T;) the resting-place of camels, where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place; (T, Ṣ,* M,* L, Ḳ;*) and of sheep or goats likewise; also termed mutabaw-aON↓: (L, TA:) or the place to which camels return; (Mgh;) as also baMCapN↓: (Mgh, Mṣb:) this is the primary signification. (Mgh.)

Hence, (Mgh,) A place of abode (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of a people, in any situation; (T, Ṣ;) as also mubaw-aON↓ (Bḍ and Jel in x. 93) and biyoYapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and baMCapN↓; (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) which last is hence applied in another sense, explained before, voce bMCapN: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a place where people alight and abide next to a valley, or to the face, or front, of a mountain, where it rises from its base; [see baw-aOahumo manozilFA;] as also baMCapN↓. (T.) [Hence,] huwa raHiybN AlmabaMCapi † He is largely bountiful. (TA.)
Also The covert of the wild bull. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
A nest of bees in a mountain: (M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the T, the nightly resting-place of bees; not there restricted by mention of the mountain. (TA.)
The part of the womb where the child has its abode; (M;) the part thereof which is the child's mutabaw-aO↓. (Ḳ.)

A well has what are termed mabaMCataAni, which are The place where the water returns to [supply the place of] that which has [before] collected in the well [and been drawn], (M,) or the place where the water collects in the well; (TA voce maMCabapN;) and the place where stands the driver of the saAniyap [q. v.]. (M.) [See also mavaAbapN; and mavaAbN.]
HaAjapN mubiyoYapN A want that is vehement, or pressing, (Ḳ, TA,) and necessary. (TA.)
mubaw-aON see mabaMCapN, in three places.
mutabaw-aON see mabaMCapN, in three places.

1. baAba lahu, aor. yabuwbu, (M, Ḳ,) quasi-inf. n., if there be such a verb, biwaAbapN, with the w not changed into I because it is not an inf. n. properly speaking, but a subst., (Lth, T,) He was, or became, a door-keeper, or gate-keeper, to him; (M, Ḳ;) namely, a Sultán (M) [or other person].

hom.sense: 2. bw-b [app., † He practised what are termed OabowaAbu AlHarobi, meaning the expedients, tricks, or stratagems, of war, battle, or fight.]
[And hence,] † He charged upon, attacked, or assaulted, the enemy. (AA, T.)

baw-abotu AlOaXoyaMCa † I made the things to be divided into distinct OabowaAb [meaning kinds, or sorts; or I disposed, arranged, distributed, or classified, the things under distinct heads]. (Mṣb.) And bw-b AlOabowaAba † [He disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order, the kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like]. (TA voce OaS-ala, q. v.) And bw-b AlmuWal-ifu kitaAbahu † [The author disposed, or divided, his book in, or into, distinct chapters]. (A.) [See baAbN.]

entry.sense: 5. tbw-b, (A,) or tbw-b baw-aAbFA, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He took for himself a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)

baAbN, originally bawabN, (M, Mṣb,) A door; a gate; a place of entrance: and the thing with which a place of entrance, such as a door or gate, is closed; of wood, &c.: (MF, TA:) pl. OabowaAbN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and biybaAnN (M, Ḳ) and OabowibapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [a pl. of pauc., said to be] only used for conformity with another word mentioned therewith, as in the saying (of Ibn-Mukbil, so in a copy of the Ṣ),
hat-aAku OaxobiyapK wal-aAju OabowibapK
[A frequent render of tents, a frequent enterer of doors], (Ṣ, M,) not being allowable when occurring alone; (Ṣ;) but IAạr and Lḥ assert that it is a pl. of bAb without its being used for conformity with another word; (M;) and this is extr.; (M, Ḳ;) for bAb is of the measure faEalN, and a word of this measure has not a pl. of the measure OafoEilapN [by rule]. (M.) You say, baAbN Ald-aAri [The door of the house]; and baAbu Albayoti [the door of the house, and of the chamber, and of the tent]; (Mṣb;) and baAbu Albaladi [the gate of the town or city]. (The Lexicons, &c. passim.) And Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim assigns a bAb to a grave; calling the latter a bayot. (M.) It is also applied to an opening, or a channel, made for water, to irrigate seed-produce: pl. OabowaAbN. (Mgh.) [And in Egypt, it is applied also to A sepulchral chamber, grotto, or cave, hewn in a mountain; from the Coptic βηβ: pl. biybaAnN only.]

Hence, i. e. in a secondary application, the primary signification being “a place of entrance,” it is used as meaning ‡ A means of access, or of attainment, to a thing: (B, Kull, TḲ:) as in the saying, hecaA AlEilomu baAbN UilaI Eilomi kacaA ‡ This science is a means of attainment to such a science. (B, TḲ.)

[Also † A mode, kind, sort, class, or category.] Suweyd Ibn-Kuráạ uses metaphorically the pl. OabowaAb in relation to rhymes; saying,
Oatayotu biOabowaAbi AlqawaAfiI kaOan-amaA
Oacuwdu bihaA sirobFA mina AlwaHoXi nuz-aEaA
‡ [I gave utterance to the various kinds of rhymes as though I were driving with them a herd of wild animals desirous of the males, or of their wonted places of pasture]. (M, L.) [You say also, huwa mino hecaA AlbaAbi † It is of this mode, kind, sort, class, or category: a phrase of frequent occurrence in lexicons, &c. See also baAbapN.]

[Also † A chapter; and sometimes a section, or subdivision, of a chapter; of a book or writing;] conventionally, † a piece consisting of words relating to matters of one kind; and sometimes, to matters of one species: (Kull:) pl. OabowaAbN. (A.) See also baAbapN.

[Also † A head, or class of items or articles, in an account, or a reckoning; as in the saying,] bay-anotu lahu HisaAbahu baAbFA baAbFA † [I explained, or made clear, to him his account, or reckoning, head by head, or each class of items or articles by itself]; a phrase mentioned by Sb: (M:) [or, sometimes,] baAbN (M, Ḳ) and baAbapN↓ (T, M, Ḳ) are used in relation to Huduwd [which here means the punishments so termed], and to an account, or a reckoning, (T, M, Ḳ,) and the like, (T, M,) as signifying the extreme term or limit; syn. gaAyapN; (M, Ḳ;) but IDrd hesitated respecting this, and therefore it is not mentioned in the Ṣ. (TA.)

baAbapN † A mode, or manner; syn. wajohN: (ISk, Ḳ:) pl. baAbaAtN. (Ḳ.) [See also baAbN, which has a similar, and perhaps the same, signification.] Hence, hecaA mino baAbatiI means † This is of the mode, or manner, that I desire; (TA;) this is suitable to me: (IAmb, TA:) and hecaA XaIoCN mino baAbatika, (Ṣ,) or hecaA baAbatuka, (A,) † this is a thing suitable to thee: (Ṣ, A:) and hecaA baAbatuhu † this is suitable to him. (Ḳ.) Accord. to most of the critics, it is tropical. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN Oahowanu baAbaAtihi Alkacibu † Such a one, the lightest of the kinds (OanowaAE) of his wickedness is lying. (A.)
† A habit: a property; a quality; nature; natural disposition: or a practice; or an action: syn. xaSolapN. (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil, TA.) [Hence, perhaps, the last of the exs. cited above from the A.]
† A condition; syn. XaroTN: as in the saying, hcaA baAbapu hecaA † [This is the condition of this]. (M, Ḳ.*)

baAbaAtu AlkitaAbi † The lines of the book or writing: (M, A, Ḳ:) or it may mean its OabowaAb↓ [i. e. chapters, or sections of chapters]: (M:) this has no sing.: (A, Ḳ:) [ISd says,] I have not heard any sing. of it. (M.)
See also baAbN; last signification.

bawobaApN A desert; or a desert in which is no water; syn. falaApN: (T, IJ, M, Ḳ:) as also mawomaApN; (T, MF;) the b being changed into m, as is often the case. (MF.) [It is mentioned in the Ṣ, and again in the Ḳ, in art. bw, as syn. with mafaAzapN.]
biwaAbapN The office, or occupation, of a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (M, Ḳ.) [See 1.]
baw-aAbN A door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)

OabowaAbN mubaw-abapN † [Kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like, disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order,] is a phrase similar to OaSonaAfN muSan-afapN. (Ṣ.) You say also kitaAbN mubaw-abN † [A book disposed in, or divided into, distinct chapters]. (A.)
baAjN; pl. OabowaAjN: see art. bOj. AZ mentions it as without C: ISk, as with C. (ISd, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. baAHa, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yabuwHu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bawoHN, (A, Mṣb,) It (a secret, A, or a thing, Mṣb) became apparent, or manifest. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, baAHa maA katabotu [What I concealed became apparent]. (A.) And OaEuwcu biQll-ehi mXno bawoHi Als-ir-i wakaXofi Als-itori [I seek protection by God from the appearing of the secret, and the removing of the veil, or covering]. (A.)

baAHa bihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [aor. as above,] inf. n. bawoHN and buWuwHN and buWuwHapN, (Ḳ, TA,) He revealed, or disclosed, it; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a secret, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or a thing; (Mṣb;) as also AbAHhu↓. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It (the former) is said to be from AlUibaAHahu↓ [the inf. n. of the latter] signifying The showing a thing to the beholder in order that he who will may take it. (TA.) You say, OabaAHahu↓ sir-FA fabaAHa bihi He revealed to him a secret, and he (the latter) [revealed it, i. e.,] did not conceal it. (TA.) And buHo biQsomika walaA takoni Eanohu [Reveal thou thy name, and make not a mere allusion to it]. (A.)

entry.sense: 4. AbAH, inf. n. UibaAHapN: see 1, in three places.

UibaAHapN and AisotibaAHapN↓ are used as syn.: but it is said that the former signifies The making a thing allowable, or free, to him who desires it, or seeks it: and the latter, the taking a thing as allowed, allowable, free, or lawful. (MF.) You say, AbAH AlX-aIoCa He made the thing allowable, or free. (L.) And AbAH maAlahu He gave permission either to take or let alone his property; made it allowable, or free, either way one might choose to take. (Mṣb.) And OabaHotuka AlX-aIoCa I made, or have made, the thing allowable, free, or lawful, to thee, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA,) to take it, [or let it alone,] or do it, [or make use of it,] or possess it; but not by the law of the religion, for to do this belongs to God and his apostle; except in the language of this law. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is said that] UibaAHapN bears a signification similar to that of nuhobaI [i. e. Spoliation; a taking of spoil; or the taking a thing as spoil; a signification more properly belonging to the inf. n. of 10, q. v.]. (L.)
10. AstbAHhu He deemed it, or esteemed it, to be allowed, allowable, free, or lawful; namely, the property of another: (A:) or he took it as allowed, allowable,, &c. (A,* MF.) See 4.
He took it as spoil, or plunder. (TA.)
He made an attack upon it; namely, the property of another. (Mṣb.)
He took him captive, making him as a lawful possession to him. (TA.)
And AisotabaAHahumo, (Ḳ,) or AisotabaAHuwhumo, (Ṣ,) He, or they, extirpated, or exterminated, them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

buwHN has the following various significations assigned to it in explanations of the saying, Aibonuka Qbonu buwHika yaXorabu mino SabuwHika: (Ṣ, TA:) The penis: (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḥar p. 336:) the faroj [or pudendum, app. meaning, of a woman]: (Ḳ, Ḥar p. 328 on the authority of AO:) the nafos [meaning one's self]: (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Meyd, L:) coitus; syn. waToCN (Ṣ) or jimaAEN: (Ḳ:) and accord. to the last but one of these renderings, [and virtually accord. to the others also,] the saying means Thy son is the son of thyself, [who drinks of thy morningdraught]; (T, TA;) he whom thou hast begotten, not he whom thou hast adopted: (IAạr, and Mṭr in Ḥar p. 328:) or bwH, here, is pl. of baAHapN; (A, TA, Ḥar p. 336;) and the meaning is, he who has been born within the courts of thy house; (A;) or, in the court of thy house, (TA, Ḥar,) not in the house of another: (TA:) or bwH is here a subst. from baAHa AlX-aIoCi; and the meaning is, thy son is he whom thou hast openly acknowledged (buHota bihi), and whom his mother hath also, agreeably with thee: (Ḥar p. 328:) [accord. to some,] it signifies also i. q. OaSolN [i. e. origin; or race, or stock, which it may mean in the saying above: or original, or primary, state, or condition]; (Ḳ, Ḥar p. 328;) [for] one says, rajaEa UilaI buwHihi [He returned, or reverted, to his original, or primary, state, or condition]. (Ḥar p. 328.)

baAHapN The court; or a spacious vacant part, or portion, in which is no building; syn. saAHapN, (Ṣ A, Ḳ,) and EaroSapN; (A, TA;) of a house or dwelling: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. buwHN [q. v.]. (A, TA.) Hence [is said to be derived] buHobuwHapu Ald-aAri [mentioned in art. bH]. (TA.) One says also, naHonu fiI baAHapi Ald-aAri, meaning We are in the middle, or midst, or best part, of the abode, or district, or country; i. e. OawosaTihaA. (TA.) And hence, accord. to Fr, tabaHobaHa [explained in art. bH]. (Az, TA.) It is said in a trad., layosa liln-isaMCi mino baAHapi AlT-ariyqi XaIoCN, meaning [Women have no right] in the middle of the road. (TA.)

Also The main part or body of water: (Ḳ:) applied by most of the lexicologists to the sea. (TA.) [In the present day applied to A deep part of the sea, distant from land; the deep; the main, or main sea.]
And Many palm-trees. (Aboo-Sárim El-Bahdalee, IAạr, Ḳ.)
Oamarahu bimaEoSiyapK bawaAHFA He ordered him to disobey, or rebel, openly. (Ḳ.) The last word occurs in this sense in two trads.; but in one of them, accord. to one recital, it is baraAHFA. (TA.)
huwa baWuwHN bimaA fiI Sadorihi He is one who reveals, or discloses, what is in his bosom; as also bayoHaAnN and bay-aHaAnN; (Ḳ;) the I being originally w. (TA.)
AlmubiyHu The lion. (Ḳ.)

1. baAxati Aln-aAru, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. tabuwxu, inf. n. bawoxN and buWuwxN and bawaxaAnN, (L,) The fire abated; or became allayed: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:*) or became extinguished, or quenched. (A.) And bAx AlHar-u The heat abated, or became allayed. (Ṣ, A, TA.)

[Hence,] baAxati AlHum-aI † The fever abated, or became allayed. (Ṣ.) And bAx Eanohu Alwirodu ‡ His fever abated, or remitted. (A, TA.) And bAx gaDabuhu ‡ His anger abated, or became assuaged. (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ.*) And bayonahumo HarobN maA yabuwxu saEiyruhaA † Between them is war of which the fire does not become extinguished, or quenched. (A.)
[Hence also,] bAx likewise signifies ‡ He became fatigued, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and out of breath. (L) You say, EadaA Hat-aLI baAxa (Ṣ, A, L) ‡ He ran until he became fatigued (Ṣ, L) and out of breath. (L.)
† He (a man) flagged; or became remiss, or languid. (TA.)
Also, inf. n. buWuwxN, † It (flesh-meat) became altered, or changed in odour or otherwise for the worse, (Ḳ, TA,) And corrupted, or tainted. (TA.)
4. AbAx He extinguished, or quenched, fire. (A, Ḳ.) And He (God) abated, or allayed, the heat. (A.)
[Hence,] AbAx Aln-AYirapa bayonahumo ‡ [He extinguished, or assuaged, the discord, or rancour, or enmity, that was between them]. (A, TA.)
And Oabixo Eanoka mina AlZ-ahiyripa † Stay thou until the midday-heat shall have become allayed, and the air be cool. (IAạr, TA in art. fyH and in the present art.)

buwxN A state of confusion, or perplexedness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, humo fiI buwxK mino Oamorihimo They are in a state of confusion, or perplexedness, with respect to their affair, or case. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And it is said in a prov., waqaEuwA fiI duwkapK wabawxK, meaning They fell into evil, or mischief, and altercation. (Meyd, TA.)
1. baAda, inf. n. bawodN and bawaAdN: see art. byd.

hom.sense: 1. baAra, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) aor. yabuwru, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bawaArN (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and baworN, (M, Ḳ,) or buwrN, (Mṣb,) He, (Ṣ,) or it, (Mṣb,) perished. (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, baAduwA wabaAruwA [They became extinct, and perished]. (A.)
[Hence,] baArati AlOaroDu ‡ The land was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state, and uncultivated; (Ḳ,* TA;) was unsown. (A.)
And baAra Eamaluhu † His work was, or proved, vain, or ineffectual: such is the signification of the verb in the Ḳur xxxv. 11. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And baAra, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawaArN, (Mṣb,) ‡ It (a thing, Mṣb, or commodity, T, Ṣ, A, Mgh) was, or became, unsaleable, or difficult of sale, or in little demand: (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) because a thing, when neglected, becomes of no use, and thus resembles that which perishes. (Mṣb.)
And baArati Als-uwqu, (T, M,) inf. n. baworN and bawaArN, (Ḳ,) ‡ The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (T, M, Ḳ.)
And baArati AlOay-imu, (A,) inf. n. bawaArN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ The woman without a husband was not desired, or sought for: (A:) or remained in her house long without being demanded in marriage. (T, Ḳ.)
[baAra is also used as an imitative sequent of HaAra; like as baAYirN is of HaAYirN: see exs. in art. Hwr.]

baAra Aln-aAqapa, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (T, Ṣ, A,) inf. n. baworN, (Ṣ,) He brought the she-camel to the stallion to see if she were pregnant or not: (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) for if she is pregnant, she voids her urine in his face (Ṣ, Ḳ) when he smells her. (Ṣ.)
Also He (the stallion) smelt the she-camel to know if she were pregnant or not; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and so AbtArhA↓. (Ṣ, M.)

Hence the saying, buro liI maA Eanoda fulaAnK ‡ Try thou, or examine, and learn, for me, what is in the mind (nafos Ṣ) of such a one. (Ṣ, A.*) You say, baArahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. baworN; (T, M, Ḳ;) and AbtArhu↓, (M,) inf. n. AibotiyaArN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning ‡ He tried him; assayed him; proved him by experiment or experience; examined him. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) El-Kumeyt says,
qabiyHN bimivoliIa naEotu AlfataApi
Uim-aA QbotihaArFA w Uim-aA QbotiyaAraA↓
(T, Ṣ) ‡ It were foul in the like of me to characterize the damsel either by false accusation or by trying, with speaking truth, to elicit what is in her mind (maA EinodahaA [i. e. maA fiI nafosihaA, agreeably with an explanation given above]): (Ṣ, TA:) or AbtyArA↓, which is without C, here signifies by asserting with truth my having had sexual intercourse with her: (TA:) [for] AbtArhA signifies he asserted with truth that he had had sexual intercourse with her; and AbthrhA “he asserted the same falsely:” (AʼObeyd, T:) and the former signifies also he had sexual intercourse with her (Ḳ, TA) by force; he ravished her: (TA:) or AbtAr signifies he charged, or upbraided, a person with that which was not in him; and Abthr “he charged, or upbraided, with that which was in him.” (TA in art. bhr.)

entry.sense: 4. AbArhu He (God) destroyed him; caused him to perish. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
8: see 1, in four places.

OaroDN baworN, (AʼObeyd, T, &c.,) in which the latter word is an inf. n. [of 1] used as an epithet, (IAth,) ‡ Land not sown; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, IAth;) as also bawaArN↓, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] of which the pl. is buwrN: (A, IAth:) or land before it is prepared for sowing (AḤn, M, Ḳ) or planting: (AḤn, M:) or land that is left to lie fallow one year, that it may be sown the next year: (Ḳ:) and OaroDN baAYirN↓, (Zj, M, Ḳ,) and baAYirapN↓, (Zj, Ḳ,) and buwrN↓, [which is originally an inf. n.,] (Ḳ,) or buwru↓ AlOaroDi, [in which the former word may be pl. of bawaArN, mentioned above,] (M,) ‡ land that is in a bad state, and uncultivated, (Ḳ,* TA,) unsown, (M, TA,) and not planted: (TA:) or left unsown. (Zj, M.) You say also, OaSobaHato manaAziluhumo buwrFA↓ † Their abodes became void, having nothing in them. (Fr, T.)
See also buwrN.

hom.sense: buwrN A bad, or corrupt, man; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and one (M, Ḳ) in a state of perdition; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) in whom is no good; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) originally an inf. n., (Fr, T,) and [therefore, as an epithet,] applied also to a female, (AO, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and to two persons, and more: (AO, T, M, Ḳ:) [but see what here follows:] baAYirN↓, also, signifies bad, or corrupt; destitute of good; (Zj, M;) a man in a state of perdition; (AO, T, Ṣ;) and its pl., (Ḳ,) or rather quasi-pl., (M, TA,) is baworN↓, (M, Ḳ,) like as nawomN is of naAYimN, and SawomN of SaAYimN; (M, TA;) and another pl. of the same is buwrN, (AO, T, Ṣ, M,) like as HuwlN is of HaAYilN, or, accord. to some, as Akh states, this is a dial. var., not a pl., of baAYirN. (Ṣ.)
See also baworN, in three places.

Uin-ahumo lafiI HuwrK wabuwrK (A, TA [but in the latter, jwr is put for Hawr]) Verily they are in a state of deficiency, or detriment. (TA.) See also baAYirN. [And see HaworN.] You say also, cahaba fulaAnN fiI AlHawAri waAlbawaAri↓ Such a one went away in a defective and bad state. (L, TA in art. Hwr.)

entry.sense: baAriI-N and buwriI-N↓ and baAriy-apN↓ (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and buwriy-apN↓ (M, Ḳ) and baAriyaMCu↓ and buwriyaMCu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) all arabicized words, from the Persian, (M,) A woven mat, (M, Ḳ,) made of reeds; (Ṣ;) what is called in Persian buwriyaA: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) or a rough HaSiyr [or mat]. (Mṣb in art. brI [to which the words belong accord. to Fei, and the same is asserted to be the case by some others].) [The pl. is bawaAriI-u.] It is said in a trad., kaAna laA yaraI baOosFA biAlS-alaApi EalaI AlbuwriI-i↓ explained as meaning He did not see any harm in praying upon a mat made of reeds. (TA.)
Accord. to some, (M,) A road; syn. TariyqN: (Ḳ, M:) [so, perhaps, in the trad. cited above:] arabicized. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: buwriI-N: see baAriI-N, in two places.

Also A kind of fish; [a species of mullet, the mugil cephalus of Linnæus, of the roe and milt of which is made what the Italians call botargo, and the Arabs baTaArix, and, accord. to Golius, bwtrgA;] so called from a town in Egypt, named buwrapu, (Ḳ,) between Tinnees and Dimyát, of which there are now no remains. (TA.)

entry.sense: baAriy-apN: see baAriI-N.
buwriy-apN: see baAriI-N.
baAriyaMCu: see baAriI-N.
buwriyaMCu: see baAriI-N.

hom.sense: bawaArN, an inf. n. of 1: see buwrN, last sentence.
[Hence,] bawaAri, like qaTaAmi, [an indecl. noun,] Perdition: (El-Aḥmar, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) as in the saying, nazalato bawaAr EalaI Alkuf-aAr Perdition fell upon the unbelievers. (El-Aḥmar, Ṣ, TA.)
See also baworN.

entry.sense: bawaAriI-N A seller of mats of the kind called baAriI-N, &c. (Ḳ.)
baAYirN: see buwrN.

You say also rajulN HaAYirN baAYirN, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and fiI HuwrK wabuwrK↓, (A,) meaning A man who does not apply himself rightly, (T, Ṣ, TA,) or has not applied himself rightly, (Ḳ,) to anything; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) erring; losing his way; (T;) who will not do right of his own accord, nor obey one directing him aright: (Ḳ:) it may be from the signification of laziness, or sluggishness, and it may be from that of perdition: (M:) [or] bAYr is here an imitative sequent of HAYr. (Ṣ.) [Respecting the latter phrase, see also art. Hwr.]
See also baworN, in two places.
faHolN mibowarN A stallion-camel that knows the state of the female, whether she be pregnant or not. (M, A, Ḳ.)
mubiyrN A destructive man, acting exorbitantly in destroying others. (TA, from a trad.)
1. baAsahu, aor. yabuwsuhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. bawosN, a Persian word, arabicized, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He kissed him. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say also, baAsa lahu AlOaroDa He kissed the ground to him. (A, TA.)
mabuwsN Kissed: you say, Alyawoma bisaATuka mabuwsN wagadFA Oanota maHobuwsN [To-day thy carpet is kissed, and to-morrow thou art imprisoned]. (A.)
1. baAXa, aor. yabuwXu, inf. n. bawoXN, He mixed, or confounded. (Fr.) See also XaAba, in art. Xwb.
He associated with bawoX, meaning, people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort. (IAạr.)

baAXuwA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (A, Ḳ,) They (mixed people, A, Ḳ, of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, TA) cried out, or vociferated; or did so calling for aid or succour; or in distress and impatience; or in fear. (A, Ḳ.)
2. bw-XwA, inf. n. tabowiyXN, They became mixed, or confused: (Ḳ:) or numerous, and mixed or confused: (TA:) and tbw-XwA↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.)
5: see 2.

bawoXN A mixed or confused assembly or company: (A, Ḳ:) or an assembly, or a company, of mixed or confused people: (Ṣ:) or only of different tribes: or a multitude of men: as also buwXN↓, in these several senses: (Ḳ:) and, accord. to the women of Temeem, of beasts also: (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA in art. hwX:) or people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort: (IAạr:) or a family, or household: (ISd:) and [it is said by F that] it also signifies sons of the same father, when assembled together: (Ḳ:) resembling a contr. signification to that mentioned above, which restricts the application to such as are of different tribes: but it is said in the O, that banuw AlAbAC, [app. a mistake for banuw AlOabi, meaning sons of the same father,] when assembled together, are not called by this name: (TA:) OawobaAXN is a pl. of this word, formed by transposition. (Ṣ.) You say, jaAWuwA fiI hawoXK wabawoXK They came in assemblage and multitude. (A.) And jaMCa mina Aln-aAsi AlhawoXu waAlbawoXu The multitude of the people came: (AZ:) or the assembly and family or household. (ISd.) And tarakotuhumo hawoXFA bawoXFA I left them [in great numbers and] in confusion. (Ḳ.) And bawoXN baAYiXN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or buwXN↓ baAYiXN↓, (CK,) [app. A numerous, or large, assembly of mixed or confused people.] And jaMCa biAlbawoXi AlbaAYiXi↓ He came with multitude, or the multitude. (TA.)
buwXN: see bawoXN, in three places.
bawoXiI-N A poor man having a numerous family or household: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having a family or household: (Aboo-Saʼeed:) and one of the baser and common sort of men: as also buwXiI-N↓. (Ḳ.)
buwXiI-N: see what next precedes.
baAYiXN: see bawoXN, in three places.

hom.sense: 1. baAEa, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He extended his arms to their full reach; expl. by basaTa baAEahu; (TA;) and the inf. n. by mad-u AlbaAEi; with a thing; as also tbw-E↓. (Ḳ.)

He (a camel) stretched forth his fore legs to the full (mad-a OabowaAEahu); as also tbw-E↓; and in like manner a gazelle: (TA:) and he (a horse) stepped far, or took long steps, in his running; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner one says [baAEat] of a she-camel. (Ṣ.) You say, mar-a yabuwEu, and yatabaw-aEu↓, He went along stretching forth his fore-legs to the full extent of his step. (L.)

baAEa biAlmaAli, aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (Lth, Ḳ,) He extended his arm, or hand, [liberally, or bountifully,] with the property. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.) You say also, buEo buEo, meaning † Stretch forth thine arms, or hands, (baA Eayoka,) in acts of obedience to God. (IAạr.) And tabaw-aEa↓ lilomasaAEiI ‡ He stretched forth his arms (mad-a baAEahu) [to attain means of honour and elevation]. (TA.) And maA yudoraku tabaw-uEuhu↓ † The point to which he has reached is not to be attained: (Ḳ, TA:) and, as Lḥ says, laA taboluguwna tabaw-uEahu↓ † Ye will not, or shall not, reach the point to which he has attained: originally, his length of step. (TA.)
UicaA baAEa QnobaAEa↓ When he accomplishes his want, he goes away. (Ḥar p. 592.)

baAEa AlHabola, (Mṣb, TA,) first pers. buEotuhu, (Ṣ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) He measured the rope by the bAE [or fathom]; (Mṣb;) he extended his bAE [or arms stretched to the full reach] with the rope; (Ṣ;) or he extended the rope with his bAE; or, which is nearly the same in meaning, he extended his arms with the rope until it became a bAE [or fathom in measure]; (TA;) like as you say, Xabarotuhu from AlX-iboru. (Ṣ, TA.)
[And hence,] yabuwEu AlOaroDa He traverses the ground with wide step and quick motion. (Ḥam p. 720.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in six places:
and see 7.
7. AnbAE and tbw-E↓, said of a rope, signify the same [app. It was measured by the bAE, or fathom]. (Ḳ, TA.)
AnbAEt AlHay-apu The serpent extended itself, after gathering itself together and coiling itself, in order to spring. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

Also AnbAE, said of a man, He leaped, or sprang, after being still: or he made an assault; or leaped, or sprang, and made a violent seizure. (TA.) [Hence,] muxoranobiqN liyanobaAEa Silent in order to leap, or spring, (Ḳ, and Ṣ in art. xrbq,) when he finds an opportunity; (Ṣ in that art.;) on account of a misfortune which he desires [to effect]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, in that art.;) or in order to make an assault: (TA:) or looking, or waiting, for an opportunity to leap, or spring, upon his enemy, or the object of his want, when able to do so; and in like manner, muxoranoTimN liyanobaAEa: (TA in art. xrbq:) a prov., (Ḳ,) applied to a man who is silent respecting a misfortune [which he desires to effect]; (TA;) or applied to a man who is long silent until he thinks his object inadvertent, and who is possessed of cunning: (Aṣ, TA in art. xrbq:) accord. to one relation, liyanobaAqa, i. e. to bring about, or effect, a baAYiqap, meaning a calamity, or misfortune: (Ḳ:) or lynbAE may be for layonabaE, from nabaEa AlmaMCu. (Ḥar p. 62.) [Hence also,] AnbAE AlX-ujaAEu mina AlS-af-i The courageous man went, or came, out, or forth, from the rank. (AAF.)

AnbAE liI fiI siloEatihi He treated me in an easy manner in the sale of his commodity, or article of merchandise, and strained himself (Aimotad-a) to give his consent to it. (Ḳ, TA.) And hence, AinobayaAEN↓, as used by Sakhrel-Ghei in describing the conduct of a man towards a beautiful woman, or, accord. to one relation, AibotiyaAEN↓, The acting, or behaving, towards another, boldly, in a free and easy manner, or without shyness; syn. AinobisaATN; as also bayoEN (TA.)
AnbAE also signifies He ran in a gentle manner, with a bending and a twisting of himself; from baAEa, aor. yabuwEu. (Aḥmad Ibn-ʼObeyd.)
And he went away. (Ḥar p. 592: see 1.)

And It (sweat) flowed: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, as El-Fárábee says, extended. (Mṣb.) 'Antarah says, describing the sweat of a she-camel,
yanobaAEu mino ciforaI gaDuwbK jasorapK
[Flowing, or extending, from the part behind the ear of a she-camel quickly angered, spirited, or tall, or tall and bulky, or strong, and bold to endure travel]:
ynbAE being originally yanobawiEu; or, as most of the lexicologists say, originally yanobaEu, the A being inserted after the fet-ḥah of the b to render its sound full. (TA.)
8. AibotiyaAEN: see 7, in the latter half of the paragraph.

baAEN A fathom; the space that is between [the extremities of] the two hands when they are extended to the right and left; (Mṣb;) the measure of the extension of the two arms (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with what is between them of the body; (TA;) as also bawoEN↓ and buwEN↓; (Ḳ;) the last of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) said by AḤát to be of the masc. gender: (Mṣb:) pl. OabowaAEN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and biyEaAnN. (Ḥam p. 475.)
[Also The arms; and particularly when extended to their full reach; as also the pl.: and in like manner, the fore legs of a beast: see several examples in the first paragraph of this art.]

[And hence, ‡ Reach; power; or ability.] You say, huwa qaSiyru AlbaAEi ‡ He is lacking in power, or ability: a phrase which has also another meaning, to be seen below. (TA.) And qaSura baAEuhu Eano celika ‡ He was unable to attain, or to do, or effect, that: in this case, bwE↓ is not used. (TA.)

And ‡ Reach, power, or ability, in the means, or causes, of attaining honour; or in generous, or honourable, qualities or actions: (TA:) ‡ eminence; nobility; honour; generosity: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) in which senses, bwE↓ is not used. (Lth.) A poet says,
lahu fiI Almajodi saAbiqapN wabaAEu
[He has precedence and eminence in glory, honour, dignity, or nobility]. (Lth.) And rajulN Tawiylu AlbaAEi ‡ A man of large generosity. (TA.) And qaSiyru AlbaAEi ‡ Niggardly: a phrase which has also another meaning, mentioned above. (TA.)

hom.sense: bawoEN and buwEN: see baAEN, in four places.
The former also signifies A place that is broken, or crushed, (makaAnN munohaDimu,) in a small ravine (liSob) of a mountain. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: baAEapN The court (saAHap) of a house: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)
baw-aAEN † A large-bodied camel. (TA.)

baAYiEN A young gazelle that stretches forth its fore legs to the full (yabuwEu) in going along: (Ḳ, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) pl. buwEN (Ḳ) and bawaAYiEu. (TA.) And OabowaAEu↓, a determinate noun, is applied to The ewe, because she does so in going along: and she is called to be milked thereby; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) by saying, OabowaAEu OabowaAEu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.) You say also naAqapN baAYiEapu A she-camel that steps far, or takes long steps: pl. bawaAYiEu. (TA.) And farasN bay-iEN↓, (Ḳ,) originally bayowiEN, (TA,) A horse that steps far, or takes long steps. (Z, Ḳ.)
bay-iEN: see baAYiEN.
OabowaAEu: see baAYiEN.
munobaAEN Anything that flows; or extends: (Mṣb:) anything sweating, or exuding sweat. (TA.)
1. baAqa, (Ḳ,) aor. yabuwqu, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He came with, or brought, or effected, evil, or mischief, and altercations. (Ḳ.)

baAqati Ald-aAhiyapu The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell, betided, or happened. (Mṣb.) And baAqatohumu Ald-ahiyapu, (Ṣ,) or AlbaAYiqapu, (JK, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell them, or smote them; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AnbAqt↓ Ealayohimo: (JK,* Ḳ:) and AnbAqt↓ Ealayohimo baAYiqapu Xar-K A calamity,, &c., burst upon them; syn. Ainofataqato; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) like AnbAjt, (Ṣ,) from which IF thinks it to be changed: (TA:) and AnbAq↓ Ealayohimu Ald-ahoru Fortune assaulted them, or assailed them, with calamity, like as the sound issues from the trumpet (Albuwq): (Ṣ:) and buqotuhumo [I assaulted them, or assailed them, with a calamity,, &c.]. (JK.) And in like manner, one says, baAqatohumo baWuwqN, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. bawoqN and buWuwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster befell them, or smote them. (TA.)

Also baAqa, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He wronged a man; treated him wrongfully, or unjustly: or he came upon a people, or company of men, suddenly, or unawares, without their permission; as also AnbAq↓: (Ḳ:) [or,] as some say, baAquwA Ealayohi they slew him: (TA:) and AnbAq↓ bihi he wronged him. (Ḳ.) And baAqa bika He (a man, JK) came up, or forth, upon thee, from a low, or depressed, place. (JK, Ḳ.) And baAqa bihi He encompassed, or surrounded, him. (JK, Ḳ.) And baAqa Alqawomu Ealayohi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) The people, or company of men, gathered themselves together against him, and slew him wrongfully: (Ḳ,* TA:) but some say that it means, as explained before, they slew him. (TA.) And baAqahumo, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (JK,) inf. n. bawoqN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA,) He stole from them; robbed them. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ.)

7: see 1, in five places. muxoranobiqN liyanobaAqa, a prov., thus related by some, instead of liyanobaAEa, means Silent in order to bring about, or effect, a baAYiqap, i. e., a calamity, or misfortune: (Ḳ in art. bwE, q. v.:) or, to launch forth, and manifest what is in his mind. (TA.) You say also, AnbAq EalayonaA biAlkalaAmi He broke forth upon us with evil speech. (JK.) And AnbAq biAlD-aHika He broke forth with laughter. (JK.) And AnbAqt AlmaTorapu The shower of rain poured forth with vehemence. (TA.) And AnbAq AlmaMCu The water became copious, or much in quantity. (JK.)

hom.sense: See also the next paragraph.

buwqN [A trumpet;] a certain thing in which one blows; (IDrd, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) in which one blows as in a musical pipe: (Kr, Ḳ:) [mostly used in war, but] mentioned by a poet, cited by Aṣ, as used by the Christians: (Ṣ:) IDrd says, The Arabs used this word, but I know not its origin: Esh-Shiháb says, in the 'Ináyeh, that it is arabicized, from [the Persian] buwriI: (TA: [but this is obviously improbable:]) pl. buwqaAtN (Mgh, Mṣb) and biyqaAnN (Mṣb [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, biyaqaAtN]) [and OabowaAqN, a pl. of pauc., commonly used in the present day]. nafaxa fiI Albuwqi [He blew the trumpet, lit., in the trumpet,] means [also] ‡ he spoke that in which was no profit. (TA.)
[Hence,] † One who does not conceal a secret; (Lth, JK, Ḳ;) as also bawoqN↓. (Ḳ.)

Also A certain thing in which the miller blows; (JK, Ḳ;) accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, resembling a minoqaAb; but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is a thing resembling a [shell of the kind called] minoqaAb, the hole of which is twisted; and sometimes the miller blows in it, raising his voice; and what he means thereby is known. (Lth, TA.)
See also bawoqN.

entry.sense: baAqapN A bundle of herbs, or leguminous plants. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And in modern Arabic, A bunch of flowers.]
buwqapN A shower, fall, or storm, of rain, (JK, Ṣ,) that has burst forth with a dash: (Ṣ, TA:) or such as is vehement; or disapproved, disliked, or deemed evil: (Ḳ:) pl. buwaqN. (JK, Ḳ.)
baWuwqN, or daAhiyapN baWuwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster. (TA.)
And the former, applied to a man, Thievish; a great thief. (JK.)

baAYiqapN A calamity, misfortune, or disaster; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a vehement evil or mischief; (Mṣb;) a trail that befalls a people: (TA:) pl. bawaAYiqN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., laA yadoxulu Aljan-apa mano laA yaOomanu jaArahu bawaAYiqahu, meaning, accord. to Ḳatádeh, [He will not enter Paradise whose neighbour is not secure from] his wrongful, or injurious, conduct: or, accord. to Ks, his malevolent, or mischievous, dispositions, and his evil conduct. (Ṣ.) IF says, in the “Makáyees,” that bwq is not an accredited root, and that there is not, in his opinion, any correct word belonging to it. (TA.) [But this is a strange assertion.]

1. baAla, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) aor. yabuwlu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. bawolN (M, Mṣb) and mabaAlN, (Mṣb,) [He urined, discharged his urine, made water, or staled;] said of a man, (M, Mṣb,) and of a beast, (Mṣb,), &c. (M.)
[Hence,] baAla bawolFA XariyfFA faAxirFA ‡ He (a man) begat offspring resembling him (El-Mufaddal, T, TA) in form and natural dispositions. (El-Mufaddal, TA.)

A poet, using the verb metaphorically, says,
baAla suhayolN fiI AlfaDiyxi fafasado
‡ [Canopus made water in the beverage prepared from unripe dates, and it became spoiled, or marred]: (M:)
meaning, that when Canopus rises [aurorally, which it does, in central Arabia, early in August, the making of that beverage is stopped, for] the season of unripe dates has passed, and they have become ripe. (L in art. fDx.) baAla suhayolN is also a prov., said when winter has come. (MF in art. xrt.) [See suhayolN.]
bawolN also signifies † The having vent, so as to flow forth: (Ḳ:) whence baw-aAlN as an epithet applied to a wine-skin: see this word below. (TA.)
And baAla † It melted, or dissolved: (Ḳ:) said of fat. (TA.)
2. bw-l OaSola AlX-ajarapi (Ḳ in art. qzH) [He made water upon the root, or stem, of the tree: or] he put urine at the root of the tree to render its fruit abundant. (TḲ in that art.)
3. laA OubaAwiluhu, from AlbaAlu, I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind. (Z, TA in art. blw. See laA OubaAliyhi in that art.)

4. AbAl Alxayoli, and AstbAlhA↓, [He, or it, made, or caused, the horses to stale: or] he stopped the horses for the purpose of [their] staling. (TA.) One says, (in threatening, PṢ,) lanubiylan-a Alxayola fiI EraSaAtikumo [We will assuredly make the horses to stale in your courts]. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a prov., baAla HimaArN faQsotabaAla↓ OaHomirapN An ass staled, and caused some (other) asses to stale: applied to a case in which people help one another to do what is disagreeable. (Meyd.)
10. AstbAl He desired, or required, to make water. (KL.)
See also 4, in two places.

El-Farezdaḳ says,
waUin-a Al-aciI yasoEaI liyufosida zawojatiI
kasaAEK UilaI Ousodi AlX-araI yasotabiyluhaA
meaning [And verily he who strives to corrupt my wife is like one betaking himself to the lions of Esh-Sharà (a certain road abounding with those animals)] to receive their urine in his hand. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: baAlN A state, condition, or case; syn. HaAlN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaOonN: (T:) or a state, condition, or case, for which one cares; wherefore one says, maA baAlayotu bikacaA, inf. n. baAlapN, meaning “I cared not for such a thing:” (TA:) or a thing [or things] for which one cares: (Ḥar p. 94:) and AlbaAlu signifies also baAlu Aln-afosi, i. e. care, or concern; and hence is [said to be] derived baAlayotu, having for its inf. n. baAlapN. (T.) One says, maA baAluka What is thy state, or condition, or case? (Ṣ.) [See the Ḳur xii. 50 and xx. 53: and see an ex. in a verse cited in this Lex. voce Uiyhi.] When it was said to a man, in former times, “How hast thou entered upon the morning?” he used to reply, bixayorK OaSolaHa Qll-ehu baAlakumo [With good fortune: may God make good your state, or condition]. (Ḥam p. 77.) wayuSoliHu baAlahumo, in the Ḳur [xlvii. 6], means And He will make good their state, or condition, in the present world: (I’Ab, T:) or their means of subsistence in the present world, together with their recompense in the world to come. (M.) One says also, huwa raxiI-u AlbaAli He is in ample and easy circumstances (T, Mṣb) of life; (T;) he is not straitened in circumstances, nor troubled: (T:) or he is in an easy, or a pleasant, state or condition: (TA in art. rxw:) or he is easy, or unstraitened, in mind: (Ṣ:) [for] AlbaAlu, (T, M, Ḳ,) or raxaMCu AlbaAli, (TA,) signifies ampleness and easiness of life: (T, M, Ḳ, TA:) or AlbAl signifies an easy, or unstraitened, state of the mind. (Ṣ.) And huwa kaAsifu AlbaAli He is in an evil state or condition: (TA:) or he is straitened in his hope, or expectation: for AlbAl is said to signify hope, or expectation: (T:) so says El-Hawaázinee. (TA.) And layosa hecaA mino baAliI This is not of the things for which I care. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad., kul-u OamorK ciI baAlK lamo yubodaOo fiyhi biHamodi Qll-ehi fahuwa Oabotaru, i. e., Every honourable affair, for which one cares, and by which one is rendered solicitous, [in which a beginning is not made by praising God, is cut off from good, or prosperity:] or every affair of importance, or moment. (TA in two places in this art.)

Also The heart, or mind; syn. qalobN, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and xaladN, (Ḥam pp. 76 and 77,) and nafosN, (AZ, T,) and xaATirN. (M, Ḳ, Kull p. 179.) You say, xaTara bibaAliI, (Mṣb, Kull ubi suprà,) and EalaI baAliI, (Kull ibid.,) i. e., [It (an affair, or a thing, Kull) occurred to, or bestirred itself in, or moved,] my heart, or mind. (Mṣb, Kull.) And lamo yaxoTuro bibaAliI celika AlOamoru, i. e., [That affair did not occur to, or] did not move me, or distress me. (T.) And maA yaxoTuru fulaAnN bibaAliI, i. e. [Such a one does not occur to, or move,] my heart, or mind. (Ṣ.)

[And hence, Mind, or attention. You say, OaEoTiniI baAlaka Give me thy mind, or attention. And] laA OuloqiI Uilayohi baAlFA [I will not, or I do not, give, or pay, any attention to him, or it]. (Z, TA in art. blw.)

[The whale;] a great fish, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the fish of the baHor [here meaning sea]; (Ṣ;) a certain bulky fish, called jamalu AlbaHoru; (M;) it is a fish fifty cubits long: (MF:) [Ḳzw describes it as being from four hundred to five hundred cubits in length, and says that it sometimes shows the extremity of its fin, like a great sail, and its head also, and blows forth water rising into the air higher than an arrow can be shot: these and other exaggerated particulars he mentions in his account of the Sea of the Zenj: and in a later place he says, that it eats ambergris, and dies in consequence; and a great quantity of oil is procured from its brain, and used for lamps:] the word [in this sense] is not Arabic: (Ṣ:) in the O it is said to be arabicized, from [the Persian] waAlo. (TA.)
The spade (mar- [in the CK erroneously written mur-]) with which one works in land of seed-produce. (M, Ḳ.)
See also baAlapN, in three places.

entry.sense: bawolN, originally an inf. n., (Mṣb,) [Urine; stale:] pl. OabowaAlN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

OabowaAlu AlbigaAli The seminal fluid of mules. (Aṣ, TA.) And hence, as being likened thereto, because it is fruitless, (Aṣ, TA,) † The saraAb [or mirage: in the CK AlX-arAbu]. (Aṣ, Ḳ, TA.) It is also applied to the road of El-Yemen, which is not travelled but by mules: see also art. bgl. (TA.)
bawolu AlEajuwzi † Cow's milk. (TA.)
bawolN signifies also ‡ Offspring. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ A large number. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also Oabowalu.

hom.sense: baAlapN A [flask, or bottle, such as is called] qaAruwrap: (M, Ḳ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (TA.)

A [bag such as is called] jiraAb, (T,M, Ḳ,) small and large, in which mush is put: (T:) or (M [in the Ḳ “and”]) the receptacle of perfume: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) a Persian word, (Ṣ, M,) arabicized; (Ṣ;) in Persian biyolah, (T, Ṣ, M,) or baAlah: (M:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (T.)

It is said to signify also An odour; a smell; (T;) on the authority of Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer; (TA;) from balawotuhu meaning “I smelled it, and tried, proved, or tested, it;” originally balowapN; the w being transposed, and changed into A. (T.)
And A staff with a pointed iron at the end, used by the hunters of El-Basrah, who throw it at the game: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (T, TA.)
And hence it is applied by the vulgar to A small elongated sword. (TA.)
It is also an inf. n. of baAlaI, which see in its proper art. (TḲ.)

entry.sense: bawolapN The origin (manobit [so in copies of the Ḳ accord. to the TA)] or daughter (binot [so in some copies of the Ḳ]) of a man; (Ḳ;) on the authority of El-Mufaddal. (TA.)

biylapN a subst. from baAla, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [meaning A discharging of urine, making water, or staling: or a mode, or manner, thereof; as appears probable from its form, and from J's adding that it is] like jilosapN and rikobapN; (Ṣ;) [and also from the following phrase:] Uin-ahu laHasanu Albiylapi [Verily he is one who has a good mode of discharging his urine]; from Albawolu. (M.)
buwalapN That discharges much urine; syn. kaviyru Albawoli; (M, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (M;) and so baw-aAlN↓ applied to a camel. (TA.)

bawaAlN A disease occasioning much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]: (M, Ḳ:) a disease that attacks sheep, or goats, such that they discharge urine until they die. (Ḥam p. 77.) You say, Oaxacahu buwaAlN He was taken with much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]. (Ṣ.)
baw-aAlN: see buwalapN.
[Hence,] † A wine-skin from which the wine runs out. (TA.)
And XaHomapN baw-aAlapN † A piece of fat that quickly melts or dissolves. (IAạr, TA.)

Oabowalu mino kalobK More frequent in making water than a dog: or it may mean more abundant in offspring. (Meyd. [Freytag adds, in his Arab. Prov. i. 199, on the authority of Sharaf-ed-Deen, that bwl↓ (i. e. bawolN) may signify urine or coitus or offspring.])
mabaAlN [The place of urine, or of the urinary discharge; meaning] the faroj [or pudendum of a man and of a woman]: whence the phrase, mabaAlN fiI mabaAlK, occurring in a trad. (TA,)
mabowalapN [A diuretic; a provocative of urine]. You say, kavorapu AlX-araAbi mabowalapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) i. e., Much beverage occasions a discharging of urine. (TA.)
mibowalapN [A urinal;] a vessel (kuwz) in which one makes water. (Ṣ, Ḳ,*)

buwmN and buwmapN A certain bird; [namely, the owl;] each word applying to the male and the female: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former signifies the male, or males, (so in different copies of the M,) of the haAm [or owl-kind]; and the latter is its n. un.: (M, TA:) said by Az to be genuine Arabic: (TA:) pl. of the former OabowaAmN. (IB, TA.)
buwmN baw-aAmN [An owl, or male owls,] that cries, or that cry, much. (TA.)

1. baAnahu, aor. yabuwnu, (Ṣ in art. byn, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bawonN, (Mṣb, TA,) i. q. baAnahu aor. yabiynu, (Ṣ ubi suprà Ḳ,) inf. n. bayonN, (TA,) meaning He excelled him; (Ṣ* ubi suprà, Mṣb;) he surpassed him in excellence and in manly virtue: so in the Iktitáf. (TA.)

baAnN [a coll. gen. n., The ben-tree; a species of moringa; so in the present day;] a kind of tree, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known: (Mṣb:) n. un. with p {baAnapN}: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) its seed, or grain, [called Hab-u AlbaAni and jawozu AlbaAni and fusotuqu AlbaAni, the glans unguentaria, or nux unguentaria, or ben-nut,] has a good, or pleasant, [fragrant] oil, (Ḳ,) called duhonu AlbaAni [oil of ben], (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and simply baAnN, the prefixed noun being suppressed: (Mgh:) [Az says,] it is the pl. of baAnapN. which is a certain tree having a fruit, or produce, which is perfumed with aromatics, after which its oil is expressed, of a good [or fragrant] quality: (T in art. bnI:) its seed, or grain, is good for [removing] the [affections of the skin termed] baraX and namaX and kalaf and HaSaf and bahaq and saEafap and the mange, or scab, and for the peeling of the skin, applied in the form of a liniment with vinegar; and for hardness of the liver and the spleen, made into a beverage with vinegar; and a mivoqaAl thereof, drunk, is an emetic, which loosens crude phlegm: its seed, or grain, is good for [removing] the [affections of the skin termed] baraX and namaX and kalaf and HaSaf and bahaq and saEafap and the mange, or scab, and for the peeling of the skin, applied in the form of a liniment with vinegar; and for hardness of the liver and the spleen, made into a beverage with vinegar; and a mivoqaAl thereof, drunk, is an emetic, which loosens crude phlegm: (Ḳ:) AḤn says, (TA,) it is a kind of tree that grows tall, in a straight, or an erect, manner, like as grows the [species of tamarisk called] Oavol, and its leaves are [of the kind termed] hadab, like those of the Avl, but its wood has no hardness: the n. un. is with P: Aboo-Ziyád says, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and has long hdb, intensely green; it grows upon [hills, or what are termed] haDob; and its fruit resembles the pods of the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaMC, except that its greenness is intense; and in it is a seed, or grain, from which is extracted the oil of the bAn: on account of the straightness of its growth and of the growth of its braches, and their length and tenderness, the poets liken thereto the tender girl of tall and beautiful, or just, stature; saying kaOan-ahaA baAnapN [As though she were a ben-tree], and kaOan-ahaA guSonu baAnK [As though she were a branch of the ben-tree], &c.: thus does Keys Ibn-El-Kha- teem: (M in art. byn:) and so does Imra-el-Ḳeys. (TA.) [See an ex. voce barahorahapN.]

[It is also applied in the present day to A species of willow, the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus, properly called in Arabic xilaAf: and this is said to be meant by modern Arab poets when they liken an elegant girl to a twig of the bAn; but probably from their erroneously supposing this tree to be meant in the same case by the older poets.]

bawonN Excellence: an excellent quality; (Ṣ in art. byn, Mṣb;) as also bawonapN↓: (IAạr; T:) or the distance, space, or interval, between tow things; as also darr; buwnN. (M, Ḳ.) You say, bayonahumaA bawonN baEiydN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb*) and bayonN baEiydN (T, Ṣ) [Between them two (meaning two men) is a wide distance]; i. e. between their tow degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Mṣb:) the former phrase is the more chaste: (Ṣ:) when corporeal distance is meant, one says, bayonahumaA bayonN, with I; (Mṣb;) or in the case of [literal] distance, one says, Uin-a bayonahumaA labayonFA; not otherwise. (Ṣ.)
buwnN: see bawonN.
bawonapN: see bawonN
Also Mutual separation. (IAạr, T.)

hom.sense: 1. baAhahaA, (JK, Ḳ,) [aor. yabuwhu,] inf. n. bawohN, (TA,) He lay with her; syn. jaAmaEahaA; (Ḳ;) like baAkahaA. (JK.)

baAha lahu, aor. yabuwhu, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. bawohN; (Ḳ;) as also baAha lahu, aor. yabaAhu, (JK,* Ḳ,) inf. n. bayohN; (Ḳ;) His attention became roused to it; (Ḳ;) he knew it, or understood it; or knew, or had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it: (JK, TA:) like baOaha, and Oabaha or Oabiha. (TA.) And maA buhotu lahu; as also maA bihotu lahu; I did not know it, or understand it; or did not know,or had not knowledge, of it; was not cognizant of it: (JK, Ṣ,- Ḳ:) the inf. n. of the former is bawohN; and that of the latter, bayohN. (TA.)

entry.sense: baAhN a dial. var. of baMCapN (IAạr, Ṣ) and of baMCN, (IAạr, TA,) signifying Coitus: (Ṣ Ḳ:*) and marriage: (Ḳ,* TA:) as also baAhapN↓: (TA:) or a share of coitus; (JK, TA;) occurring in this sense in a trad., in which a woman is mentioned as having adorned herself for it: (TA:) also venereal passion: (TA in art. xfX:) [or the venereal faculty; as when one says of a drug or some other thing, yaziydu fiI AlbaAhi It increases the venereal faculty:] IḲt says, of this word, baAhN, [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] that it is a mistranscription [app. meaning for baMCN]. (Mṣb and TA in art. bwO.) [See also baMCapN.]

hom.sense: baAhapN: see baACN.
Also The court of a house; or a spacious part, or portion, of a house, in which is no building; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) where people alight, or lodge: (JK:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)

entry.sense: baAhiI-N That strengthens the venereal [faculty or] appetite. (TA in art. jzr, &c.)

hom.sense: 2. bay-ayotu AlX-aIoCa, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboyiI-N, (Ḳ,) I made the thing apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous. (Aṣ, T, Ḳ*)

Also, (Ḳ, as in the TA,) or tab-ayayotu↓ AlX-aIoCa (M, and so in several copies of the Ḳ,) [both confirmed by what follows,] i. q. taEam-adotuhu [meaning I directed myself, or my course, or aim, to, or towards, the thing; made for it, or towards it; made it my object;, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.)

In the saying, Hay-aAka Qll-ehu wabay-aAka, the phrase HyAk Qll-eh means May God make thee to have dominion: (Ṣ, M:) or may God prolong thy life: (M:) and by-Ak means AiEotamadaka biAlt-aHiy-api [may He bring thee prolongation of life; lit. may He direct himself to thee, or the like, with the gift of prolongation of life]; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) or qaSadaka biAlt-aHiy-api [which is the same]: (IAạr, T:) or AiEotamadaka biAlomuloki [may He bring thee dominion]; (M;) so too says IAạr: (TA:) or may He make thy state, or condition, to be good: (TA:) or may He make thee to laugh: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so some say, accord. to Aṣ: (T:) and it is related that these words were addressed to Adam, in consequence of his having remained a hundred years without laughing after his son had been slain: (T, Ṣ:) so says AʼObeyd, on the authority of Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr: (T:) or it means may He bring thee near [unto Himself]: (Aboo-Málik, Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ:) or may He bring thee: (IAạr, Ṣ, M:) or may He prepare for thee an abode; i. q. baw-aOaka, (Ḳ,) or baw-aOaka manozilFA; the verb being here altered in order to assimilate it to the preceding verb, Hay-aA: (El-Aḥmar, T, Ṣ:) this explanation was approved by Aṣ: (Ṣ:) the meaning intended thereby is, may He lodge thee in an abode in Paradise: (TA:) or, as some say, the verb in this case is an imitative sequent to that preceding it: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ Ḳ:*) but this is naught: (Ḳ:) AʼObeyd says that in his opinion it is not an imitative sequent, because an imitative sequent is scarcely ever coupled with what precedes it by w. (Ṣ.) As an ex. of bay-aA in the sense of qar-aba, Aboo-Málik cites this verse:
bay-aA lahumo Uico nazaluwA AlT-aEaAmaA
Aalokiboda waAlmaloHaMCa waAls-anaAmaA
[He brought near to them, i. e., placed before them, when they alighted, the food, namely, the liver, and the flesh of the back extending from the withers to the rump, and the hump]. (T.) And IAạr, explaining by-Ak as meaning qSdk bAltHy-p, cites the following verse:
lam-aA tab-ayayonaA↓ OabaA tamiymi
OaEoTaI EaTaMCa All-aHizi All-aYiymi . (T.) Accord. to J, the meaning in this instances may be agreeable with the explanation of by-Ak by AEtmdk bAltHy-p [so that the verse may be rendered When we betook ourselves with salutation to the father of Temeem, or, as the verse is cited in the Ṣ, to the brother of Temeem (OaxaA tmym), he gave the gift of the niggardly, the mean]: or it may mean we brought: and the verb admits of the same double rendering in other instances. (TA.)
bay-ayotu baMCF HasanapF and HasanFA [I made, or wrote, a beautiful b]. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)
5. tby-A It was, or became, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous, being near; syn. tabay-ana mino qurobK. (Aṣ, T.)
See also 1, in two places.

entry.sense: AlbaI-N The low, ignoble, mean, or contemptible, man; as also Aibonu bay-aAna↓, (IAạr, T, Ḳ) and Abn hay-aAna, (IAạr, T,) and Abn baI-, (Ḳ,) or haI-u bonu baI-, and hay-aAnu bonu bay-aAna↓: (Lth, T:) or the last two signify he whose stock and branch are unknown: (M:) or the same two, he who is unknown, and whose father also is unknown: (Ḳ in art. hI; and so the latter of them is explained in the Ṣ, both there and in the present art.:) and one says, maA OadoriI OaI-u haI-i boni baI-K huwa, meaning I know not what man he is.. (Ṣ.) Accord. to some, (Lth, T,) haI-u bonu baI-K was one of the sons of Adam, that went away in the earth when the rest of his children dispersed themselves, and no trace of him was afterwards perceived. (Lth, T, Ḳ.)
Aibonu bay-aAna: see AlbaI-u, in two places.
bayawiI-N rel. n. of baMCN or baA: whence qaSiydapN bayawiy-apN [as also baAYiy-apN and baAwiy-apN] A qSydp of which the rawiI- is b. (M in art. b.)
Albiyabo see OabN, in art. Abw.

1. baAta, (T, Ṣ M, &c.,) aor. yabiytu and yabaAtu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bayotuwtapN (Lth, T, Ṣ A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mabiytN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and mabaAtN (Mṣb) and bayotN and bayaAtN, (Ḳ,) has two meanings: in that which more commonly obtains, the action is restricted to the night: (Mṣb:) it is by night, or in night; not in sleep: (M:) you say, baAta yafoEalu kacaA, meaning He did such a thing by night, or at night: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, doing such a thing: and he passed, or spent, the night, or a night, or a part thereof, or, as will be seen below, he entered upon the night, doing such a thing:] like as one says, Zal-a yafoEalu kacaA as meaning “he did such a thing by day,” or “at day-time:” (Ṣ, Mṣb;*) IḲooṭ and Es-Sarakustee and IḲṭṭ say that it has this meaning, and not “he slept:” (Mṣb:) [F adds,] walayosa mina Aln-awomi, (Ḳ,) which is said to mean, “and the action is not one of sleep;” so that when one sleeps by night, or at night, it is not correct to say, baAta yanaAmu: or, accord. to some, “its meaning is not that of sleeping;” so that one may say, baAta zayodN naAYimFA [Zeyd was in the night,, &c., or passed, or spent, the night,, &c., sleeping]: (MF:) [Fei says,] it is only when one remains awake in the night: and hence the saying in the Ḳur [xxv. 65], waQl-aciyna yabiytuwna lir-abihimo suj-adFA waqiyAmFA [And those who pass the night prostrating themselves to their Lord and standing up in prayer]: (Mṣb:) Fr says that baAta Alr-ajulu means The man remained awake all the night, engaged in acts of obedience or of disobedience: (T, Mṣb:) [or it means the man entered upon the night; or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, in any state, or engaged in any action; for] Zj says, (M,) baAta is said of any one whom the night has overtaken, (M, Ḳ,*) whether he have slept or not slept: (M:) and Lth says, Albayotuwtapu signifies the entering upon the night: one says, bit-u OaSonaEu kacaA wakacaA [I entered upon the night doing such and such things]: and he adds, (T,) he who says baAta as meaning he slept commits an error; for you say, bit-u OuraAEiI Aln-ujuwma [I entered upon, or passed, the night] looking at the stars: and how can he be sleeping who is looking at them? (T, Mṣb:) but Mullà ʼAbd-El-Hakeem, in his Commentaries on the Mutowwal, says that baAta sometimes means he remained, continued, stayed, or dwelt, and he alighted and abode, by night, or at night, whether he slept or not: (MF:) and Ibn-Keysán says that it may be used in the same manner as naAma [he slept]; and also, [as will be explained below,] in the same manner as kaAna. (TA.) You say, baAta bayotuwtapF SaAliHapF (T) or Tay-ibapF (A) [He passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, in a good manner]. And bit-u Alqawoma and bit-u bihimo and bit-u Einodahumo [I passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, with, or at the abode of, the people, or company of men: the last of these phrases is the most common]. (AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ.)

Secondly, it is used in the sense of SaAra [He became]; (Mṣb;) or in the same manner as kaAna [he was]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) One says, baAta bimawoDiEi kacaA He became [or was] in such a place; whether in night-time or in day-time. (Mṣb.) And hence the saying of the lawyers, baAta Einoda QmoraOatihi layolapF He became [or was] with his wife one night; [which is the same as he passed a night, &c.; though this, it will be observed, is not in this instance the signification of the verb alone;] whether sleeping or not. (Mṣb.)
[Thus it is used both as a “complete,” i. e. an attributive, verb, and also as an “incomplete,” i. e. a non-attributive, verb.]
baAta, aor. yabiytu, (T, A,) inf. n. bayotN, (T, M, Ḳ,) also signifies ‡ He married, or took a wife: (T, A:) [see bayotN below:] or † he gave in marriage; syn. of the inf. n. tazowiyjN. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. by-t Albayota He constructed, or built, the bayot [i. e. tent, or house,, &c.]. (M.)

by-t AlOamori, [inf. n. as below,] He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, by night, or at night: (M:) and he thought, or meditated, upon it, considering its end, or issue, or result, (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or entered into it, (Zj, T,) by night, or at night. (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, &c.) And one says, buy-ita bilayolK, (T, A,) meaning the same as dub-ira bilayoli [It was thought, or meditated, upon,, &c., by night, or at night]: (T:) [for] buy-ita AlX-aIoCu also signifies [simply] the thing was thought upon, and considered as to its end, issue, or result; syn. qud-ira. (Ṣ.) Accord. to El-Marzookee, they say of a thing that is not done deliberately, and with good consideration of its issue or result, hecaA OamorN qud-ira bilayolK; [in the text from which this is taken, without the syll. signs;] and hence the saying in the Ḳur [iv. 83], bay-ata TaAYifapN minohumo gayori Ql-aciI taquwlu [A part of them meditateth by night upon doing otherwise than that which thou sayest; as is indicated in the M, where this is cited; and in like manner, yubay-ituwna, in the continuation of the same passage of the Ḳur, is explained in the T as meaning yudab-iruwna, and yuqad-iruwna, (i. e. mina Als-uwoCi,) layolFA]: but Aboo-Hilál says that a thing is meditated upon in the night in order that one may apply himself to it with strong purpose, and not be diverted by other things, so that it may be done with more firmness; and he cites the same passage of the Ḳur. (Ḥam p. 130.) And hence, in the Ḳur [iv. 108], Uico yubay-ituwna maA laA yaroDaI mina Alqawoli When they meditate,, &c., (Ṣ, M, Bḍ, Jel,) by night, (Ṣ, M,) [what He will not approve, of speech,] and prepare it [in their minds] (yuzaw-iruwnahu [see art. zwr]). (Bḍ.) It is said in a trad., laA SiyaAma limano lamo yubay-iti AlS-iyaAma There is no fasting to him [meaning his fasting is null] who does not purpose it from the night. (TA. [See another reading, voce bat-a.]) And you say, bay-ata Aln-iy-apa He decided upon the purpose, or intention, by night, or in night-time. (Mṣb.) And bay-ata raOoyahu He thought upon his opinion, and concealed it, or conceived it, in his mind. (TA.)

bay-atahumo, inf. n. taboyiytN, (Mṣb, TA,) He came upon them, (Mgh, but the verb is there pl.,) or made a sudden attack upon them, and engaged with them in conflict, (Mṣb,) or made a great slaughter among them, or engaged with them in vehement conflict, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) namely, the enemy, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or a people, (M,) by night: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he came upon them (the sons of such a one) in the night, and made a sudden attack upon them, while they were heedless: (T:) he attacked them (the people of a house or place of abode) by night: he went to them (the enemy) in the night, without their knowledge, and took them by surprise. (TA.)
kaAna laA yubay-itu maA lAFA walaA yuqay-iluhu He used not to retain property until night, nor to retain it until noon, when it came to him; but used to hasten the dividing of it. (TA, from a trad.)
See also 4.
by-t Aln-axola He trimmed, or pruned, the palm-trees, by cutting off the stumps of the branches, or by cutting off the straggling branches, not in the best part thereof. (Ḳ.)
See also 5.

entry.sense: 4. AbAthu, inf. n. UibaAtapN, He (God) made him, or caused him, to pass, or spend, the night, [or a part thereof,] or to enter upon the night. (T, M, Ḳ.) You say, OabaAtaka Qll-ehu HasanapF [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night with happiness], (Ṣ,) and UibaAtapF HasanapF [in a good manner of doing so]. (T, A.) And [in like manner,] bay-ataka↓ Qll-ehu fiI EaAfiyapK [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night in health and safety]. (A.) And OabaAtahu Qll-ehu OaHosana biytapK God made him to pass, or enter upon, the night in the best manner of doing so. (M, Ḳ.*)
5. tby-thu Eano HaAjatihi [so in the TA and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the CK bay-atahu↓:] He withheld, or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted. (Ḳ.)
10. [AstbAt seems to signify He asked for, or required, biyt, or biytap i. e. food: (see musotabiytN:) and also to have the contr. signification; i. e.]
[He possessed food: for you say,] laA yasotabiytu layolapF He possesses not a night's food. (T, Ḳ.) And laA yasotabiytu He has not food. (A.)

bayotN [signifies A tent; properly, having more than one pole; but often applied without this restriction: and also a house; a chamber; an apartment; a closet; and the like]: a bayot is [a tent] of [goats'] hair (XaEar), (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of wool: (Mgh:) a byt of hair [i. e. hair-cloth] is that kind [of tent] which has more than one pole: the word is masc.: and applies to small and large: (M:) tents of goats' hair are peculiar to people of cold countries and of fertile regions, where the goats have abundant hair; for the goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun: (T in art. bnI:) a xibaMC is a small byt of wool or of hair: a byt is what is larger than a xbMC: next is the miZal-ap, which is larger than the byt; but the term byt is also applied to a mZl-p when it is large and muraw-aq [i. e. furnished with a riwaAq, q. v.]: (T:) Ibn-El-Kelbee says that the Arabs have six kinds of byt; namely, a qub-ap, which is of skins, or tanned hides; a miZal-ap, of hair; a xibaMC, of wool; a bijaAd, of soft hair (wabar); a xayomap, of trees; an Ouqonap, of stone; and a sawoT, of hair; or this is the smallest of them: El-Baghdádee says that the xbAC is a byt made of soft hair (wabar), or of wool, or of hair [commonly so called] (XaEar), upon two poles, or three; and that a byt is [a tent] upon six poles, or more, to the number of nine: in the Towsheeh it is said that the term xbAC is applied to a byt of any kind: (TA:) a byt is also [a structure] of clay, or tough or cohesive clay or earth; (A, Ḳ;) [and of baked bricks; and of stone;] the name being likewise applied to a structure of a kind other than the structures which are called Oaxobiyap [or tents]; (M;) signifying a habitation [of any kind; an abode; a dwelling]: (Mṣb:) a man's house; syn. daArN: (T:) [and particularly a chamber; i. e.] a single roofed structure (Mgh, Kull) having a place of entrance; manozilN being applied to what comprises more than one [such] byt, and a roofed SaHon [or vacant part, and a kitchen, inhabited by a man with his family]; and daArN, that which comprises more than one [such] byt and more than one [such] manozil and a [court, or] SaHon without a roof: (Kull:) the pl. is buyuwtN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) also pronounced biyuwtN, (TA,) and OaboyaAtN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the latter a pl. of pauc.;
