(TA;) and pl. pl. buyuwtaAtN (M, Mgh, Ḳ) and OabaAyiytu (Sb, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OaboyaAwaAtN, (Fr, M, Ḳ,) which last is extr.: (M:) the dim. is buyayotN↓, also pronounced biyayotN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the vulgar say, buwayotN, (Ṣ,) which is not allowable. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa jaAriI bayota bayota, (T, Ṣ, M,) He is my neighbour [tent to tent, or house to house, i. e.,] by contiguity [of our habitations]: byt byt being made indecl. with fet-ḥ for the termination because they are two nouns made one: (Ṣ:) Sb says that some of the Arabs make them [thus] indecl., like xamosapa EaXara, and some make the former a prefixed noun governing the latter in the gen. case, [saying bayota bayotK,] except when used as a denotative of state: (M:) one says also, bayotFA libayotK, and bayotN libayotK; (Fr, T;) which last, or bayotN UilaI bayotK, is the original form. (Ḥar p. 353.) banaI fulaAnN EalaI QmoraOatihi [lit. Such a one constructed a tent over his wife,] means such a one had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of his marriage, and brought her, or had her brought, into a pitched tent, having conveyed thither the utensils and furniture and other things that they required. (T.) And Oaholu bayotu Aln-abiI-i [The people of the house of the Prophet,] means the Prophet's wives and his daughter and ʼAlee: and so Oahola Qlobayoti [i. e. yaxuS-u Oahola Albayoti He means particularly, or peculiarly, the people of the house], in the Ḳur xxxiii. 33: banuw and maEoXar and Oahol and Ml, as prefixed nouns, being, as Sb says, the nouns most frequently occurring in the accus. case [for the reason indicated above, or, as the Arabian grammarians express it,] EalaI AlAixotiSaASi. (M.)

It also signifies A [pavilion, palace, or mansion, such as is called] qaSor: (T, Ḳ:) whence the saying of Gabriel, baX-iro xadiyjapa bibayotK mino qaSabK, i. e. [Rejoice thou Khadeejeh by the announcement of] a pavilion (qSr) of hollow pearls, (T, TA,) or of emerald. (TA. [See also art. qSb.]) buyuwtFA gayora masokuwnapK [Uninhabited houses], in the Ḳur xxiv. 29, means buildings for the reception of travellers, or for merchants and their goods, and the shops of the merchants and places in which things are sold, the entering of which is allowed by their owners: or ruins which a man enters for the purpose of easing nature. (M.) And the buyuwt which God has permitted to be raised, mentioned in the same chapter, verse 36, are Mosques, or places of worship: or, accord. to El-Ḥasan, Jerusalem (bayotu Almaqodisi); the pl. being applied to it as a mark of honour. (Zj, M.) Albayotu [The House] applies particularly to ‡ the Kaabeh [of Mekkeh]; (Ḳ;) as also bayotu Qll-ehi [the House of God]; (AAF, M;) and Albayotu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred House]; (T;) and Albayotu AlEatiyqu [the Ancient House]; (Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. Etq;) and accord. to some, Albayotu AlmaEomuwru, q. v. (Bḍ in lii. 4.) [bayotu AlmaAli signifies The treasury of the state. And bayotu AlmaMCi is a euphemism for The privy; because water is put there for the purpose of ablution: also called bayotu AlfaraAgi, &c.]
Also † The ark of Noah: so in the Ḳur lxxi. last verse. (T.)

‡ A grave; (M, IAth, Ḳ;) app. by way of comparison. (M.) So in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr: kayofa taSonaEu UicaA maAta Aln-aAsu Hat-aI yakuwnu Albayotu biAlwaSiyfi, meaning How will thou do when men shall die so that the grave shall be sold for the [servant-] boy? (IAth.)

† The habitation of the surofap, which it constructs in a beautiful manner, (AʼObeyd, M,) of fragments of sticks; (Yaạḳoob, M;) and of the SayodanaAniI-, which it makes in the interior of the earth, and covers over: (AʼObeyd, M:) and † the burrow, or hole, of the Dab-, &c.: and † the web of the spider: all, app., as being likened to the bayot of a man. (M.)
‡ A man's household. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

‡ The wife (Aṣ, IAạr, T, M, A) of a man. (M, A.) So in the saying,
OakibarN gay-araniI Omo bayotu
[Hath old age altered me, or a wife?]: (Aṣ, T:) or here it means a household. (Ṣ.)

The nobility of the Arabs; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as when one says, bayotu tamiymK fiI baniI HanoZalapa [The nobility of Temeem is in the sons of Handhaleh]: (T, Mṣb:*) or the family that comprises the nobility of a tribe; as Mlu HiSonK of the fazaAriy-uwn, and Mlu Aljud-ayoni of the XayobaAniy-uwn, and Mlu Eabodi AlmadaAni of the HaAriviy-uwn; which three were asserted by Ibn-El-Kelbee to be the highest of the families thus called of the Arabs: (M:) [see a verse of El-Lahabee cited voce OaxoDaru:] pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN, (T, M,) the latter being pl. of the former. (T.) You say, huwa mino Oaholi AlbuyuwtaAti He is of the people of nobility: and mino bayotK kariymK [of a generous, or noble, house, or family]. (A.) [See also banaI.]
A noble person: (M, Mgh, Ḳ:) pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN bayotu qawomihi Such a one is the noble person of his people. (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil El-Aarabee, M.)

‡ The [furniture termed] faroX, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or mataAE, (TA,) of a tent or house, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or that is sufficient for a tent or house. (A.) You say, tazaw-ajotu fulaAnapa EalaI bayotK ‡ I married, or took as a wife, such a woman for [my giving] furniture sufficient for a tent or house, (A,) or furniture of a house or tent. (Mgh.) [See 1, last sentence.]

A bayot of poetry, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) or of the poet, (Ḳ,) is ‡ [A verse; i. e.] what consists of certain known divisions [or feet] called OajozaMCu Alt-afoEiyli; being termed byt metaphorically, because of the conjoining of its component parts, one to another, in a particular manner, like as those of a tent are conjoined in its construction; (Mṣb;) because it consists of words collected together in a regular manner, and so resembles a tent, which is composed of a saqof and kifaMC and riwaAq and Eumud: (T:) it is derived from the same word signifying a xibaMC [or tent], and applies to the small and the great, as the rajaz and the Tawiyl; and is [said to be] thus called because it comprises words like as the tent comprises its inhabitants; wherefore its component parts are termed OasobaAb and OawotaAd, as being likened to the AsbAb and AwtAd of tents: (M:) pl. OaboyaAtN and buyuwtN, (M, A, Mṣb,) the latter mentioned by Sb and IJ, (M,) [but rare,] and [pl. pl.] OabaAyiytu: (A:) Abu-l-Ḥasan says that if the byt of poetry be likened to the byt which is a tent or other kind of structure, there is no reason why it should not have the same pl. forms as the latter has. (L.) By the following words of a poet,
wabayotK EalaI Zahori AlmaTiI-i banayotuhu
biOasomara maXoquwqi AlxayaAXiymi yaroEufu
[Many a byt upon the back of the camel have I constructed with a lawny thing slit in the nose and bleeding], is meant, many a byt of poetry have I written with the reed-pen. (Ṣ.) [Albayota, written after a quotation of a part of a verse of poetry, means AiqoraOi Albayota Read thou the verse.] bayotu AlqaSiydapi [The chief verse of the poem] is a phrase employed when a person composes a poem in praise of any one from whom he would obtain some object of desire and want, being applied to that verse of the poem in which the author's want is mentioned: and is a proverbial expression relating to that which is extraordinary and strange, and used in denoting the superiority of a part of a thing over the whole of it [regarded as a whole]: [hence,] one says, fulaAnN Oaw-alu Aljariydapi wabayotu AlqaSiydapi † [Such a one is the first of the detachment of horsemen, and the chief verse of the poem]. (Ḥar p. 441.)
biytN: see biytapN, in two places.

hom.sense: biytapN a subst. from baAta: and signifying A manner or mode, and state, or condition, of passing, or entering upon, the night. (M.) [See 4; last sentence.]

entry.sense: bayaAtN A coming upon the enemy by night; (Mgh;) a sudden attack upon, and conflict with, the enemy by night; (Mṣb;) a great slaughter (Ṣ, M) among the enemy, (Ṣ,) or a people, (M,) and vehement conflict with them; (Ṣ, M;) a coming upon people in the night, and making a sudden attack upon them, while they are heedless; (T;) an attack upon a people by night; a going to the enemy in the night, without their knowledge, and taking them by surprise: (TA:) a subst. from 2; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb;) like salaAmN from sal-ama. (Mgh.)
OataAhumu AlOamoru bayaAtFA The thing, or event, happened, or came, to them in the latter part of the night. (T.)
buyayotN, also pronounced biyayotN, dim. of bayotN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
bay-uwtN That has remained throughout a night [and so become stale; stale from being a night old]; as also baAYitN↓: both, in this sense, [but the latter more usually,] applied to bread. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Cold, or cool, water, (M, Ḳ,) that has become so from its having remained throughout a night: (M:) or water that remains during the night beneath the sky: (Ḥam p. 553:) or water that has been cooled in the leathern bag by night; and in like manner, milk; for [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say, AisoqiniI mino bay-uwti Als-iqaMCi, meaning Give thou me to drink of the milk that has been milked at night and left in the skin so that it has become cold, or cool, by night. (T.) In the saying,
faSab-aHato HawDa qirFI bay-uwtaA
the meaning seems to be, qiraI HawoDK bay-uwtaA, i. e., [And they (app. camels) came in the morning to] the collected water of a trough, which water had remained throughout the night and so become cold, or cool; the phrase being inverted. (M.)
OamorN bay-uwtN † An affair, or event, for which, or on account of which, one passes the night in anxiety or grief. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
ham-N bay-uwtN † Anxiety, or grief, that has remained during the night in the bosom. (M.)
sin-N bay-uwtapN A tooth that does not fall out, or become shed. (Ḳ.)
baAYitN [Passing, or spending, the night, or a night, or a part thereof; or entering upon the night;, &c.;] act. part. n. of 1. (Mṣb.)
See also bay-uwtN.
mabiytN A place in which one passes, or enters upon, the night. (M, A.)
mutabay-itapN A woman who has obtained a bayot [i. e. tent or house, or the furniture thereof,] and a husband. (M, Ḳ.)
bayoHaAnN and bay-aHaAnN: see baWuwHN, in art. bwH.

1. baAda, aor. yabiydu, inf. n. bayodN (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) and buyuwdN (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bayaAdN (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and bayoduwdapN (Lḥ, M, L, Ḳ) and bawaAdN (L, Ḳ) and bawodN, (CK,) the last but one disapproved by MF, (TA,) [and the last equally doubtful,] He, or it, perished; (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb;) went away; passed away; became cut off, or extinct; came to an end. (M, L, Ḳ.)
baAdati AlX-amosu, inf. n. buyuwdN, The sun set. (Sb, M, Ḳ.)
4. OabaAdahumo He (God) destroyed them; (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh,* Mṣb;) caused them to go away, pass away, become cut off or extinct, or come to an end. (M.*)

bayoda, (T, Ṣ, M, L, Mughnee, Ḳ,) as also baAyada↓, (L, Ḳ,) or baAYida, (so in the Mughnee and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ omitted,) a noun inseparably prefixed to Oan-a with its complement, (Mughnee,) used as syn. with gayor, (Ks, T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) but never otherwise than in the accus. case, nor as an epithet, nor otherwise than as an exceptive in a case in which the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made. (Mughnee.) You say, huwa kaviyru AlmaAli bayoda Oan-ahu baxiylN He is possessed of abundant, or much, wealth, but he is niggardly. (ISk, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Mughnee.)

Also as syn. with EalaI, (M, Ḳ,) as some say; (AʼObeyd, M;) but to render it in the former manner is preferable. (M.) Accord. to some, (L,) it is syn. with EalaI in the following trad.: naHonu AlMxiruwna Als-aAbiquwna yawoma AlqyaAmapi bayoda Oan-ahumo Ouwtuw AlkitaAba mino qabolinaA waOuwtiynaAhu mino baEodihimo [We, the latter people, shall be those who will precede on the day of resurrection, although they were given the Scripture before us, and we were given it after them]: (T, L:) El-Umawee holds it to be so: (T:) but Ks says that it here signifies gayor [as in the former ex.]: (T, L: [and so says IHsh in the Mughnee:]) accord. to one recital, it is bAyad; (L;) or baAYida; so in the Musnad of the Imám Esh-Sháfiʼee: (Mughnee:) IAth says, I have not found this in the classical language in the sense of EalaI: some say that it is biOayodK, i. e. by means of strength, or power; and that the meaning is, we shall be those who will precede to Paradise on the day of resurrection by means of strength, or power, given us by God. (L.)

Also, [accord. to some,] as meaning mino Oajoli: (L, Mughnee, Ḳ:) as in the saying of Moḥammad, OanaA OafoSaHu AlEarabi bayoda Oan-iI mino qurayoXK wanaXaOotu fiI baniI saEodK [I am the most chaste in speech of the Arabs because I am of the tribe of Kureysh and I grew up among the children of Saạd]: (T, L: [in the Mughnee given somewhat differently:]) but Ibn-Málik and others say that it here, also, means gyr, after the manner in which the latter is used in the saying [of a poet],
walaA Eayoba fiyhimo gayora Oan-a suyuwfahumo
bihin-a fuluwlN mino qiraAEi AlkataAYibi
[And there is no blemish in them, save that their swords have in them notches from the conflicting of the troops]. (Mughnee.) This manner of praising is termed by Abu-l-ʼAbbás Moḥammad Ibn-Yezeed AisotivobaAtN. (Ḥam p. 474.)
mayoda is also a dial. var. of the same. (AʼObeyd, T, Mughnee.)

bayodaMCu A desert; or a waterless desert: (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or one that is plain, or level, in which horses are made to run: (M:) or one wherein is nothing: (TA:) so called, accord. to IJ, because it [often] destroys him who alights, or sojourns, in it: (M, Mṣb:*) or a plain tract, slightly elevated, with few trees, and without herbage, extending to the distance of a day's journey, or half a day's journey, or less, rugged and hard, and only in a country of mould, or clay: (ISh:) pl. biyodN: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it has a pl. of a form proper to epithets because it is originally an epithet: (M:) by rule it should be bayodaAwaAtN. (M, Ḳ.)

A she-ass; a subst. applied to that animal: (Ṣ:) or a wild she-ass: (M, Ḳ:) or one that inhabits a desert (bayodaMC); (T, Ḳ;) [an epithet;] not a subst. applied to the animal; J being in error in asserting it to be such: (Ḳ:) the [wild] she-ass is thus called, accord. to most of the lexicologists, because it inhabits the bydAC; and if so, the n is an augmentative letter: or, accord. to some, because it is large in the body (Albadan); and if so, the n is a radical letter: (L:) the pl. is bayodaAnaAtN. (L, Ḳ.)
baAyada, or baAYida: see bayoda.
biyorN; pl. of pauc. OaboyaArN: see biYorN, in art. bOr.
waqaEa fiI HaASi baASi, and HayoSa bayoSa, &c.: see art. HyS
bayoSN Difficulty; straitness; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also biySN↓. (Ḳ.) See above.
biySN: see above.

hom.sense: 1. baADahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) first pers. biDotu, (M,) aor. yabiyDu, for which one should not say yabuwDu, [though it would be agreeable with a general rule respecting verbs denoting surpassingness,] (Ṣ, O,) He surpassed him in whiteness. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)

baADato, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, except that in the M and Mṣb we find the masc. form, baADa, followed by AlT-aAYiru,) aor. tabiyDu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. bayoDN, (M, Mṣb,) said of an ostrich, (M,) or a hen, (Ḳ,) or any bird, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and the like, (Mṣb,) She laid her eggs, (M, Mṣb, TA,) or egg. (Mṣb.)

baADa Als-aHaAbu ‡ The clouds rained. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) A poet says, [using a phrase from which this application of the verb probably originated,]
baADa Aln-aEaAmu bihi fanaf-ara Oaholahu
Uil-aA Almuqiyma EalaI Ald-awaI AlmutaOaf-ini , (IAạr,) i. e. ‡ The nEAm, meaning the naEaAYim, [or Twentieth Mansion of the Moon,] sent down rain upon it, and so put to flight its occupants, except him who remained incurring the risk of dying from disease, wasting away: [the last word being in the gen. case, by poetic license, because the next before it is in that case; like xaribK in the phrase hecaA juHoru Dab-K xaribK:] the poet is describing a valley rained upon and in consequence producing herbage; for the rain of the asterism called AlnEAYm is in the hot season, [when that asterism sets aurorally, (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl,)] whereupon there grows, at the roots of the HaliI-, a plant called naXor, which is poisonous, killing beasts that eat of it: the verse is explained as above by El-Mohellebee: (IB:) or, as IAạr says, the poet means rain that falls at the nawoC [by which we are here to understand the setting aurorally] of AlnEAYm; and that when this rain falls, the wise flees and the stupid remains. (O.)
baADa biAlmakaAni ‡ He remained, stayed, or abode, in the place [like as a bird does in the place where she lays her eggs]. (O, Ḳ.)

baADati AlOaroDu † The earth produced kamoOap [or truffles, which are thus likened to eggs]: (A, TA:) or † the earth produced the plants that it contained: or † it became changed in its greenness to yellowness, and scattered the fruit, or produce, and dried up. (M, TA.)
baADa AlHar-u ‡ The heat became vehement, or intense. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
baADa Alqawoma;, &c.: see 8, in three places.

entry.sense: 2. by-D, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboyiDN, (Ṣ,) He whitened a thing; made it white; (Ṣ, M;) contr. of saw-ada. (Ḳ.) He bleached clothes. (M.) [He whitewashed a wall, &c. He tinned a copper vessel or the like.] You say, bay-aDa Qll-ehu wajohahu [lit., God whitened his face: or may God whiten his face: meaning ‡ God rendered his face expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or rejoiced, or cheered, him: or may God, &c.: and also God cleared his character; or manifested his honesty, or the like: or may God, &c.: see the contr. saw-ada]. (TA.) And by-D lahu [He left a blank space for it; namely, a word or sentence or the like: probably post-classical]. (TA in art. Xms;, &c.)
[He wrote out fairly, after having made a first rough draught: in this sense, also, opposed to saw-ada: probably post-classical.]
‡ He filled a vessel: (M, A, Ḳ:*) or he filled a vessel, and a skin, with water and milk. (Ṣ, O.)
And ‡ He emptied (A, Ḳ) a vessel: (A:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
3. bAyDhu, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. mubaAyaDapN, (TA,) He contended with him for superiority in whiteness. (Ṣ, M.)
4. OaboyaDato and OabaADato She (a woman) brought forth white children: and in like manner one says of a man [OaboyaDa and OabaADa, meaning He begat white children]. (M, TA.)
See also 9, in two places.

hom.sense: 8. AbtAD He (a man, Ṣ) put upon himself a bayoDap [or helmet] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of iron. (TA.)

AbtADhumo He entered into their bayoDap [or territory,, &c.]: (A, TA:) and AbtADwA Alqawoma They exterminated the people, or company of men; they extirpated them; (M, Ḳ;*) as also baADuwhumo↓: (M:) and AubotiyDuwA [originally AubotuyiDuwA; in the CK, incorrectly, AbtayaDuwA;] They were exterminated, or extirpated, (Ḳ, TA,) and their bayoDap [or quarter,, &c.,] was given up to be plundered: (TA:) and AibotaDonaAhumo We smote their byDp [or collective body,, &c.,] and took all that belonged to them by force; as also biDonaAhumo↓: and biyDa↓ AlHaI-u The tribe was so smitten, &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: 9. AbyD-, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and, by poetic license, AiboyaDaD-a, [of which see an ex. voce xafaDa, and see also 9 in art. Hw,] (M, TA,) inf. n. AiboyiDaADN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) It was, or became, white; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) contr. of Aisowad-a; (Ḳ;) as also AbyAD-↓, inf. n. AiboyiyDaADN;. (Ṣ;) contr. of AisowaAd-a; (Ḳ;) and OabaADa↓: which ↓last also signifies it (herbage or pasture) became white, and dried up. (M, TA.) [You say also, AbyD- wajohuhu, lit., His face became white: meaning ‡ his face became expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or he became joyful, or cheerful: and also his character became cleared; or his honesty, or the like, became manifested: see 2.]
bayoDN: see bayoDapN, in three places.

bayoDapN An egg (Mṣb) of an ostrich, (Mgh,) and of any bird, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like, i. e. of anything that is termed SamuwxN [or having merely an ear-hole] as distinguished from such as is termed OacuwnN [or having an ear that is called OucunN]: so called because of its whiteness: (TA:) n. un. of bayoDN↓: (Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. [of the former] bayoDaAtN (M, Ṣgh, Ḳ) and bayaDaAtN, which latter is irreg., (M, Ṣgh,) and only used by poetic license; (Ṣgh;) and (of bayoDN, M) buyuwDN. (M, Ḳ.) You say, Oaforaxati AlbayoDapu The egg had in it a young bird. (ISh.) And Oaforaxa bayoDapu Alqawomi † What was hidden, of the affair, or case, of the people, or company of men, became apparent. (ISh.) [See also art. frx.] bayoDapu Albaladi signifies The egg which the ostrich abandons. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And hence the saying, huwa Oacal-u mino bayoDapi Albaladi ‡ He is more abject, or vile, than the egg of the ostrich which it abandons (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ) in the desert. (TA.) You say also, huwa bayoDapu Albaladi in dispraise and in praise. (IAạr, Aboo-Bekr, M.) When said in dispraise, it means ‡ He is like the egg of the ostrich from which the young bird has come forth, and which the male ostrich has cast away, so that men and camels tread upon it: (IAạr, M:) or he is alone, without any to aid him; like the egg from which the male ostrich has arisen, and which he has abandoned as useless: (TA:) or he is an obscure man, or one of no reputation, whose lineage is unknown. (Ḥam p. 250.) And when said in praise, it means ‡ He is like the ostrich's egg in which is the young bird; because the male ostrich in that case protects it: (IAạr, M:) or he is unequalled in nobility; like the egg that is left alone: (M:) or he is a lord, or chief: (IAạr, M:) or he is the unequalled of the balad [or country or the like], to whom others resort, and whose words they accept: (Ḳ:) or he is a celebrated, or wellknown, person. (Ḥam p. 250.) [See also art. bld. And for another meaning of bayoDapu Albaladi see below.]

‡ A helmet of iron, (AO, Ṣ,* M,* Mgh,* Ḳ,*) which is composed of plates like the bones of the skull, the edges whereof are joined together by nails; and sometimes of one piece: (AO:) so called because resembling in shape the egg of an ostrich: (AO, M, Mgh:*) in this sense, also, n. un. of bayoDN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ: [in the CK, for wAlHadiydu we should read wAlHadiydi.]) This may be meant in a trad. in which it is said that a man's hand is to be cut off for his stealing a bayoDap. (Mgh.)
† A testicle: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. biyDaAnN. (TA.)
‡ The bulb of the saffron-plant [&c.]: as resembling an egg in shape. (Mgh.)
† [A tuber: for the same reason.]
† A kind of grape of Et-Táïf, white and large. (M.)
‡ The core of a boil: as resembling an egg. (M.)
‡ The fat of a camel's hump: for the same reason. (M.)
bayoDapu Albaladi, in addition to its meanings mentioned above, also signifies † The white truffle: (O, Ḳ:) or simply truffles; syn. AlkamoOapu; (TA;) or these are called bayoDu↓ AlOaroDi. (A.)

bayoDapN also signifies ‡ The continent, or container, or receptacle, (Hawozap,) of anything. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And [hence] bayoDapu AlUisolaAmi ‡ The place [or territory] which comprises El-Islám [meaning the Muslims]; like as the egg comprises the young bird: (Mgh:) or this signifies the congregation, or collective body, of the Muslims. (AZ, M.)
And bayoDapu Alqawomi ‡ The quarter, tract, region, or district, of the people, or company of men: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the heart; or midst, or main part, of the abode thereof: (Ṣ, TA:) the principal place of abode (OaSol) thereof; (M, TA;) the place that comprises them; the place of their government, or regal dominion; and the seat of their dEwp [i. e. diEowap or kindred and brotherhood]: (TA:) the midst of them: (M:) or, as some say, their [kinsfolk such as are termed] EaXiyrap: (TA:) but when you say, OataAhumu AlEaduw-u fiI bayoDatihimo, the meaning is [the enemy came to them in] their principal place of abode (OaSol), and the place where they were congregated. (TA.) And bayoDapu Ald-aAri ‡ The midst of the country or place of abode or the like: (AZ, M, TA:) the main part thereof. (TA.) And bayoDapu Almuloki i. q. Hawozatuhu † [The seat of regal power: or the heart, or principal part, of the kingdom]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Hwz.)

bayoDapu Alxidori (M, A, Ḳ) ‡ The damsel (M, Ḳ) of the xdr [or curtain, &c.]: (Ḳ: [in the CK, jaAriyatuhaA is erroneously put for jaAriyatuhu:]) because she is kept concealed within it. (TA.) You say also, hiIa mino bayoDaAti AlHijaAli ‡ [She is of the damsels of the curtained bridal canopies]. (A, TA.) bayoDapN is used by a metonymy to signify ‡ A woman, by way of likening her thereto [i. e. to an egg] in colour, and in respect of her being protected as beneath the wing. (B.) [See Ḳur xxxvii. 47.]

bayoDapN also signifies † White land, in which is no herbage; opposed to sawodapN: (TA:) and biyDapN↓, with kesr, white, smooth land; (Ḳ;) thus accord. to IAạr, with kesr to the b: (Sh:) and OaroDN bayoDaMCu↓ signifies smooth land, in which is no herbage; as though herbage blackened land: or untrodden land: as also bayoDapN. (M.)
bayoDapu Aln-ahaAri The whiteness of day; [daylight;] i. q. bayaADuhu↓; (Ḳ;) i. e. its light. (Ḥar p. 222.) You say, Oatayotuhu fiI bayoDapi Aln-ahaAri I came to him in the whiteness of day. (TA.)

bayoDapu AlHir-i † The vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (M.) And bayoDapu AlqayoZi ‡ The most vehement, or intense, heat of summer, or of the hottest period of summer, from the [auroral] rising of Ald-abaraAn to that of suhayol; [i. e., reckoning for the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, from about the 26th of May to about the 4th of August, O. Ṣ.;] (A,* TA;) as also bayoDaMCu↓ AlqayoZi. (A, TA.) And bayoDapu AlS-ayofi † The main part of the Syf [or summer]: (M, TA:) or the vehement, or intense, heat thereof. (Ḥam p. 250.)
bayDapN: see bayoDapN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

bayaADN Whiteness; contr. of sawaAdN; in an animal, and in a plant, and in other things; and, accord. to IAạr, in water also; (M;) the colour of that which is termed OaboyaDu: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) they said bayaADN and bayaADapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like as they said manozilN and manozilapN: (Ṣ:) bayaADapN being applied to a whiteness in the eye. (M.) You say, hecaA OaXad-u bayaADFA mino kacaA [This is whiter than such a thing]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) but not OaboyaDu mnohu↓: (Ṣ:) the latter is anomalous; (Ḳ;) [like Oasowadu minohu; q. v.;] but it was said by the people of El-Koofeh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who adduced as authority the saying of the rájiz,
jaAriyapN fiI diroEihaA AlfaDofaADi
OaboyaDu mino Ouxoti baniI UibaADi
[A damsel in her ample shift, whiter than the sister of the tribe of Benoo-Ibád]: Mbr, however, says that an anomalous verse is no evidence against a rule commonly approved: and as to the saying of another,
UicaA Alr-ijaAlu XatawoA waQXotad-a Oakoluhumu
faOanota OaboyaDuhumo sirobaAla Tab-aAxi
[When men experience dearth in winter, and their eating becomes vehement, thou art the whitest of them, or rather the white of them, in respect of cook's clothing, having little or nothing to do with entertaining them], the word in question may be considered as an epithet of the measure OafoEalu that is followed by mino to denote excess: but it is only like the instances in the sayings huwa OaHosanuhumo wajohFA and Oakoramuhumo OabFA, meaning Hasanuhumo wajohFA and kariyimuhumo OabFA; so it is as though he said faOanota muboyaD-uhumo sirobaAlFA; and as he has prefixed it to a complement which it governs in the gen. case, what follows is in the accus. case as a specificative. (Ṣ.) This latter verse is by Tarafeh, who satirizes therein ʼAmr Ibn-Hind; and is also differently related in respect of the first hemistich, and the first word of the second. (L, TA.)

bayaADN is also used elliptically for cuw bayaADK; and thus means † White clothing; as in the saying, fulaAnN yalobasu Als-awaAda waAlbayaADa Such a one wears black and white clothing. (Mgh.) [Hence, also, it has other significations, here following.]
† Milk. (Ḳ.) See an ex., voce sawaAdN.
[† The white of an egg.]
bayaADu AlOaroDi † That part of land wherein is no cultivation nor population and the like. (M.)
bayaADu Aljilodi † That part of the skin upon which is no hair. (M.)
‡ bayaADN also signifies ‡ A man's person; like sawaAdN; syn. XaxoSN; as in the saying, laA yuzaAyilu sawaAdiI bayaADaka ‡ My person will not separate itself from thy person. (Aṣ, A, TA.)

bayuwDN A hen that lays many eggs; (Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ;*) as also bay-aADapN↓: (M:) [but in the Mṣb it is evidently used as signifying simply oviparous:] pl. (of the former, Ṣ, M *) buyuDN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and biyDN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the latter in the dial. of those who say rusolN for rusulN, the b being with kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged; (Ṣ, M;) but sometimes they said buwDN. (M.)
bayaADapN: see bayaADN.

baAYiDN A hen, (Az, Ḳ,) or bird, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the like, (Mṣb,) laying an egg or eggs: (Az, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) without p because the cock does not lay eggs: (Az, TA:) or it is applied also to a cock, (M, TA,) and to a crow, (M, A, TA,) [as meaning begetting an egg or eggs,] in like manner as one uses the word waAlidN. (M, TA.)
bay-aADN A bleacher of clothes; as a kind of rel. n.; not as a verbal epithet; for were it this, it would be mubay-iDN. (M.)
A seller of eggs. (M.)
bay-aADapN: see bayuwDN.

hom.sense: OaboyaDu White; contr. of Oasowadu; (A, Ḳ;) having whiteness: (Mṣb:) fem. bayoDaMCu: (Mṣb:) pl. biyDN, originally buyoDN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the damm being converted into kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e.] to suit the I. (Mṣb.) In the phrase OaEoTiniI OaboyaD-aho, mentioned by Sb, as used by some of the Arabs, meaning OaboyaDa, [i. e. Give thou to me a white one,] h is subjoined as it is in hun-aho for hun-a, and the D is doubled because the letter of declinability cannot have h subjoined to it; wherefore the letter of declinability is the first D, and the second is the augmentative, and for this reason it has subjoined to it the h whereof the purpose is to render plainly perceivable the vowel [which is necessarily added after the doubled D]: Aboo-ʼAlee says, [app. of the h,] that it should properly have neither fet-ḥ nor any vowel. (M.)

Applied to a man, &c., it was sometimes used to signify White in complexion: but in this sense they generally used the epithet OaHomaru. (IAth, TA in art. Hmr.) They also said, fulaAnN OaboyaDu Alwajohi and fulaAnapu bayoDaMCu Alwajohi, meaning Such a man, and such a woman, is clear, in face, from freckles or the like, and unseemly blackness. (Az, TA.) And they used biyDaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. of OaboyaDu, (TA,) in the contr. of the sense of suwdaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [i. e. as signifying Whites,] applied to men: (Ṣ:) though they applied the appellation Oabuw AlbayoDaMCi to the Abyssinian: (TA in art. Ewr:) or to the negro: and Oabuw Aljawoni to the white man. (ISk.) But accord. to Th, OaboyaDu applied to a man signifies only ‡ Pure; free from faults: (IAth, TA in art. Hmr:) or, so applied, unsullied in honour, nobility, or estimation; (Az, Ḳ;) free from faults; and generous: and so bayoDaMCu applied to a woman. (Az.) [In the lexicons, however, (see, for ex., among countless other instances, an explanation of baD-apN in the Ṣ,) and in other post-classical works, it is generally used, when thus applied, in its proper sense, of White; or fair in complexion.]
katiybapN bayoDaMCu An army, or a portion thereof, upon which the whiteness of the [arms or armour of] iron is apparent. (M.)
And bayoDaMCu alone, [as a subst.,] A piece of paper [without writing]. (Ḥar p. 311.)
AlOaboyaDu The sword: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) because of its whiteness: (TA:) pl. biyDN. (Ṣ.)
Silver: (A, Ḳ:) because of its whiteness: like as gold is called AlOaHomaru [because of its redness]. (TA.)
The saliva (rDAb) of the mouth. (Ḥam p. 348.)
A certain star in the margin of the milky way. (A, Ḳ.)
AlbayoDaMCu The sun: because of its whiteness. (M.)

Waste, or uncultivated, or uninhabited, land: (Ḳ,* TA: [in the CK AljirAbu is erroneously put for AlxaraAbu:]) opposed to Als-awodaMCu: because dead lands are white; and when planted, become black and green. (TA.) See also bayoDapN, near the end.
Wheat: (Ḳ:) as also Als-amoraMCu. (TA.)
Fresh [grain of the kind called] sulot. (El-Khaṭṭábee, Ḳ.)
A certain kind of wood; that which is called AlHawaru: (Ḳ in art. Hwr:) because of its whiteness. (TA in that art.) [See HawarN.]
The cooking-pot; as also Oum-u bayoDaMCa. (AA, Ḳ.)
The snare with which one catches game. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

AlOaboyaDaAni Milk and water. (ISk, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) A poet says,
wamaA liIa Uil-aA AlOaboyaDayoni XaraAbu
[And I have not any beverage except milk and water]. (ISk, Ṣ, M.)
Bread and water: (Aṣ, M, Ḳ:) or wheat and water: (Fr, Ḳ:) or fat and milk. (AO, Ḳ.)
Fat and youthfulness (AZ, IAạr, M, A, Ḳ.) You say, cahaba OaboyaDaAhu His fat and youthfulness departed. (TA.)
maA raOayotuhu muco OaboyaDaAni I have not seen him for, or during, two days: (Ks, M, A, Ḳ:) or two months. (Ks, M, Ḳ.)

Oay-aAmu AlbiyDi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or simply AlbiyDu, (Mgh,) for Oay-aAmu All-ayaAliI AlbiyDi; [The days of the white nights;] i. e. the days of the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the month; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so called because they are lighted by the moon throughout: (Mṣb:) or of the twelfth and thirteenth and fourteenth nights: (Ḳ:) but this is of weak authority, and extr.: the former is the correct explanation: (MF, TA:) you should not say AlOay-aAmu AlbiyDu: (Ibn-El-Jawá- leekee, IB, Ḳ:) yet thus it is in most relations of a trad. in which it occurs; and some argue for it; and the author of the Ḳ has himself explained AlOawaADiHu by AlOay-aAmu AlbiyDu. (TA.)
sanapN bayoDaMCu † A year [of scarcity of herbage,] such as is a mean between that which is termed XahobaMC and that which is termed HamoraMC. (TA in art. Xhb.)
kalaAmN OaboyaDu ‡ Language expounded or explained. (M.)
kal-amotuhu famaA rad-a EalaI-a sawodaMCa walaA bayoDaMCa ‡ I spoke to him, and he did not return to me a bad word nor a good one. (M.)
yadN bayoDaMCu † A demonstrating, or demonstrated, argument, plea, allegation, or evidence. (M.)
And † A favour, or benefit, for which one is not reproached; and which is conferred without its being asked. (M.) [See also yadN.]

Almawotu AlOaboyaDu † Sudden death; (Ḳ, TA;) such as is not preceded by disease which alters the complexion: or, as some say, death without the repentance, and the prayer for forgiveness, and the accomplishment of necessary duties, usual with him who is not taken unawares; from bay-aDa signifying “he emptied” a vessel: so says Ṣgh: opposed to Almawotu AlOaHomaru, which is slaughter. (TA.)
bayoDaMCu also signifies † A calamity, or misfortune: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) app. as a term of good omen; like saliymN applied to one who is stung by a scorpion or bitten by a serpent. (TA.)
bayoDaMCu AlqayoZi: see bayoDapN, last sentence but one.
hecaA OaboyaDu mino kacaA;, &c.: see bayaADN.

entry.sense: mabiyDN A place for laying eggs. (ISd, TA in art. fHS.)
mubiyDapN A woman who brings forth white children: the contr. is termed musowidapN: (Fr, Ḳ:) but muwDiHapN is more commonly used in the former sense. (O.)
[muboyaD-apN The fair copy, or transcript, made from a first rough draught; which latter is called musowad-apN: probably post-classical.]
mubay-iDN A man wearing white clothing. (TA.)

Hence, Almubay-iDapu A sect of [the class called] the vanawiy-ap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the companions of Almuqan-aE; (Ṣ;) so called because they made their clothes white, in contradistinction to the musaw-idap, the partisans of the dynasty of the 'Abbásees; (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) for the distinction of these was black: they dwelt in Kasr ʼOmeyr. (TA.) [See also AlHaruwriy-apu.]

hom.sense:
1. baAEahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yabiyEu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. bayoEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mabiyEN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter is anomalous, (Ṣ,) the regular form being mabaAEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) has two contr. significacations: He sold it: and he bought it: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and AbAEhu↓ is a dial. var. of the same: (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb:) [but app. only in the former sense:] or this last signifies he offered it for sale; or exposed it to sale: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and AbtAEhu↓, as well as baAEahu, signifies he bought it. (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ.) The primary signification of bayoEN is The exchanging, or exchange, of property; or the making an exchange with property; as in the phrases bayoEN raAbiHN [an exchange of property bringing gain], and bayoEN xaAsirN [an exchange of property occasioning loss]: and this is a proper signification when it relates to real substances: but it is tropically used to signify the making the contract [of sale and purchase]; because this is the means of giving [and obtaining] possession: [though this signification is what is termed HaqiyqapN Eurofiy-apN, i. e., a sense so common as to be conventionally regarded as proper:] the phrase SaH-a AlbayoEu, or baTala, and the like, mean Safoqapu AlbayoEi; [i. e. The contract of sale, or purchase, was valid, or was null;] but the prefixed n. being suppressed, and its complement [alone] used for it, and this being masc., the verb is made masc. (Mṣb.) baAEa [mostly signifies He sold; and] is doubly trans., both by itself and by means of mino prefixed to the second object; (Mgh, Mṣb;) this prep. being thus used as a corroborative: (Mṣb:) you say, baAEahu AlX-aIoCa and baAEahu minohu [He sold to him the thing and He sold it to him]: (Mgh:) and biEotu zayodFA Ald-aAra and biEotu mino zayodK Ald-aAra [I sold to Zeyd the house: (see also an explanation of the phrase AisotabaEotuhu AlX-aIoCa: and see baAEahu mina Als-uloTaAni: to which might be added countless similar instances; for when bAE signifies he sold, mino is generally prefixed to the noun or pronoun denoting the person to whom the thing is sold:)] and sometimes li is put in the place of mino; so that you say, biEotuka AlX-aIoCa and biEotuhu laka [I sold to thee the thing and I sold it to thee]; the l being redundant [when the verb has this meaning, though not when it has the contr. meaning, as will be seen below]. (Mṣb.) Of the contr. signification we have an ex. in the saying of El-Farezdaḳ,
Uin-a AlX-abaAba laraAbiHN mano baAEahaA
waAlX-ayobu layosa libaAYiEiyhi tijaAru
[Verily youthfulness, he who buys it is a gainer; but hoariness, there are no traffickers for its sellers; the part. a. being here from the verb in the former sense]: (Ṣ, TA:) and [often in a case in which the verb is followed by l; as] in baAEa lahu AlX-aIoCa He bought for him the thing; (Mgh;) [the l not being redundant when the verb is used in this sense;] and as in the saying of Tarafeh,
wayaOotiyka bAloOaxobaAri mano lamo tabiEo lahu
bataAtFA walamo taDoribo lahu waqota mawoEidi
[And he will bring thee tidings for whom thou hast not bought travelling-provisions, and for whom thou hast not assigned an appointed time for his bringing them]: (TA:) and in the saying, baAEa dunoyaAhu biMxiratihi ‡ [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]: (Z, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, AbtAE↓ zayodN Ald-aAra, meaning Zeyd bought the house: and AbtAEhA↓ ligayorihi He bought it for another person. (Mṣb.) The verb has this signification, also, in the trad., laA yabiEo baEoDukumo EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi [One of you shall not buy in opposition to the buying of his brother when an agreement has been manifested but the contract has not been concluded]; (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb; [but in the Ṣ and Mṣb and by IAth, the trad. is related thus; laA yaxoTubi Alr-ajulu EalaI xiTobapi Oaxiyhi walaA yabiEo EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi; (see art. xTb;)]) as is shown by the relation of Bkh, laA yabotaAEu↓ Alr-ajulu EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or it may here have the contr. meaning: (IAth:) Az says that the seller and buyer are equal in offence when either of them does thus to another. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying, laA yasuwmu Alr-ajulu EalaI sawomi Oaxiyhi: see art. swm. See also baAEa EalaI bayoEihi below, used in a tropical sense.] You say also, baAEa Ealayohi AlqaADiI, meaning The judge sold against his will; (Mgh;) sold without his consent. (Mṣb.)

The pass. form is biyEa [It was sold: and it was bought]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) optionally either [thus] with kesr to the b, or [buyoEa] with damm to the b, (Ṣ,) [or rather with a sound between that of damm and that of kesr, which pronunciation is termed UiXomaAmN;] and some say buwEa; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) changing the I into w: and thus in the cases of kiyla and qiyla and the like: (Ṣ:) [but Ibn-Málik requires damm or AXmAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is I, and kesr or AXmAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is w, to prevent the mistaking of an active verb for a passive in such cases as biEotu and sumotu: others, however, only prefer what Ibn-Málik absolutely requires in these cases. (See I’Aḳ p. 131.)]
You say also, baAEahu mina Als-uloTaAni, [lit. He sold him to the Sultán,] meaning ‡ he slandered him, or calumniated him, to the Sultán. (Ḳ, TA.)

And baAEa fulaAnN EalaI bayoEihi, [of which the lit. meaning has been shown above,] meaning ‡ Such a one superseded him, or occupied his place, in respect of honourable and elevated station or rank, and gained the mastery over him; (Ḳ,* TA;) and so Hal-a biwaAdiyhi: (TA:) or baAEa fulaAnN EalaI bayoEi fulaAnK means ‡ such a one gained the mastery over such a one, and wrested from him that which he sought to obtain from him; and is an old proverb, applied by the Arabs to a man who contends with another, and seeks to obtain a thing from him by superior power or force, when he has succeeded in doing as above explained; and similar to it is the saying Xaq-a fulaAnN gubaAra fulaAnK. (El-Mufaddal Ed-Ḍabbee, TA.) One also says, maA baAEa EalaI bayoEika OaHadN, meaning † Not any one has equalled thee. (TA.)
bayoEN is also used in the sense of AinobisaATN. (TA in art. bwE. [See AinobaAEa in that art.])

entry.sense: 3. baAyaEotuhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. mubaAyaEapN and biyaAEN, (TA,) is from AlbayoEu; and so is Alt-abaAyuEu↓; (Ṣ, TA;) this being syn. with AlmubaAyaEapu. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, baAyaEaA and tabaAyaEaA↓, meaning They two sold and bought, each with the other: (TḲ:) and tabaAyaEonaA↓ [We sold and bought, one with another]: (Mgh:) and bAyEhu also signifies He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him. (TA.) [See 1; where a citation from the Mṣb indicates that this latter is the primary signification accord. to the author of that work.]

It is also from AlbayoEapu; and so is Alt-abaAyuEu↓: (Ṣ, TA:*) AlmubaAyaEapu and Alt-abaAyuEu↓ from AlbayoEapu signifying The making a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like; as though each of the two parties sold what he had to the other, and gave him his own special property, and his obedience, and all that pertained to his case. (TA.) [Hence,] bAyE AlOamiyra He promised, or swore, allegiance to the prince; making a covenant with him to submit to him the judgment of his own case and of the cases of the Muslims [in general], not to dispute with him in respect of anything thereof, but to obey him in whatever command he might impose upon him, pleasing and displeasing: in doing which, it was usual for the person making this covenant to place his hand in the hand of the prince, in confirmation of the covenant, like as is done by the seller and buyer; wherefore the act was termed bayoEapN, an inf. n. [of un.] of baAEa. (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 256 - 7.) [And hence the phrases, buwyiEa biAlixilaAfapi and buwyiEa lahu biAlxilaAfapi He had the promise, or oath, of allegiance made to him as being Khaleefeh.] You say also, bAyEhu Ealayohi, inf. n. mubaAyaEapN, He made a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like, with him, respecting it, or to do it: and tbAyEwA↓ EalaI AlOamori [they made a covenant,, &c., respecting, or to do, the thing, or affair]; like as you say OaSofaquwA Ealayohi. (TA.)
4: see 1, first sentence.
6: see 3, throughout.

7. AnbAE It was, or became, saleable, or easy of sale; it had an easy, or a ready, sale: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) as though quasi-pass. of baAEahu [and therefore primarily signifying it was, or became, sold, or bought]. (TA.)
8: see 1, in four places.
10. AisotabaEotuhu AlX-aIoCa I asked him to sell the thing to me; expl. by saOalotuhu Oano yabiyEahu min-iI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) for instance, Eabodahu [his slave.] (Mgh.)

hom.sense: bayoEN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].
It also signifies The hire, or hiring, of land. (TA.)

Also A thing sold, or bought: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) a subst. in this sense: (Mgh, TA:) pl. buyuwEN: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) which is also used as a pl. of the inf. n., to signify Kinds of selling and buying. (Mgh.) See also biyaAEapN.

entry.sense: bayoEapN [inf. n. of un. of baAEa.]
[Hence,] A striking together of the hands of two contracting parties in token of the ratification of a sale. (Mṣb, TA.)

And [hence,] The act of mubaAyaEap [or promising, or swearing, allegiance and obedience, as explained above, (see 3,)] and submission, or obedience. (Mṣb, TA.) Whence, OayomaAnu AlbayoEapi [The oaths of allegiance and obedience]; (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 257; and Mṣb;) which the Khaleefehs exacted; (Ibn-Khaldoon;) and which El-Hajjáj appointed, including hard, or difficult, matters, relating to divorce and emancipation and fasting and the like. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: biyEapN A mode, or manner, of selling or buying. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) Hence, SaAHibu biyEapK [A person occupying himself in any kind of selling or buying]: occurring in a trad. of Ibn-ʼOmar. (Mgh, TA.) And Uin-ahu laHasanu AlbiyEapi [Verily he is good in the manner of selling or buying]. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.)

[A Christian church;] a place of worship (Ḳ) pertaining to the Christians: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, as some say, a synagogue of the Jews: (TA:) pl. biyaEN, (Ḳ, TA,) or biyoEN. (Mṣb: [but this I think a mistake: if correct, it is a coll. gen. n.])

entry.sense: bayuwEN: see bay-iEN.
bayaAEapN An article of merchandise; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also bayoEN↓ [q. v. suprà]: (Mgh:) pl. of the former biyaAEaAtN. (Ḳ.)
bay-iEN: see baAYiEN, in five places.
bay-aAEN A man who sells, or buys, much. (TA.)

baAYiEN Selling, or a seller: and buying, or a buyer: (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) as also bay-iEN↓: (Ḳ:) the former signification is the more obvious when bAYE is used without restriction: (Mṣb:) and bay-iEN↓ also signifies [accord. to some] a bargainer, or chafferer; (Ḳ, TA;) not a seller nor a buyer; but Esh-Sháfiʼee and Az deny that this epithet is applied to a man before he has concluded the contract: (L, TA:) the pl. of bAYE is baAEapN: (ISd, Ḳ:) and the pl. of by-E↓ is biyaEaMCu [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and OaboyEaMCu: (Ḳ:) and Kr holds that baAEapN is pl. of by-E. (TA.) Albay-iEaAni↓ signifies The seller and the buyer; (Ṣ, Mgh;) and so AlmutabaAyiEaAni↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Albay-iEaAni↓ biAlxiyaAri maA lamo yatafar-aqaA, and in another, AlmutabaAyiEaAni↓, [The seller and the buyer have the option of cancelling the contract as long as they have not separated.] (TA.)
AimoraOapN baAYiEN ‡ A woman who easily obtains a suitor; or who is much in demand; by reason of her beauty: (Ḳ, TA:) as though she sold herself: like naAqapN taAjirapN. (Z, TA.)

mabiyEN Sold: and bought: as also maboyuwEN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in the latter sense syn. with mubotaAEN↓. (Mṣb.) Kh says that the letter suppressed in mabiyEN is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, because it is augmentative: but Akh says that the letter suppressed is the medial radical; for when they made the I quiescent, they transferred its vowel to the letter before it, so that it became madmoomeh, [the word thus being altered to mabuyowEN,] then they changed the ḍammeh into kesreh because of the I after it, then the I was suppressed, and the w was changed into I, like the w of miyzaAnN, because of the kesreh: accord. to El-Mázinee, each of these sayings is good; but that of Akh is the more agreeable with analogy. (Ṣ.)
maboyuwEN: see mabiyEN.
mubotaAEN: see mabiyEN.
mutabaAyiEN: see baAYiEN, in two places.

bayoluwnN [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] the yellow [or rather yellowish, or yellowish gray, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth known by the name of Tafol. (TA, from Esh-Shiháb El-'Ajamee.)

hom.sense:
1. baAna, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [aor. yabiynu,] inf. n. bayonuwnapN and buyuwnN (M, Mgh, Ḳ) and bayonN, (M, Ḳ,) It (a thing) became separated, severed, disunited, or cut off, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Eani AlX-aIoCi from the thing. (Mgh.) And baAnato, (M, Ḳ,) or baAnato biAlT-alaAqi, (Mṣb,) She (a wife) became separated by divorce, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Eani Alr-ajuli from the man. (M, Ḳ.) And baAnatN said of a girl, [She became separated from her parents by marriage;] she married: (ISh, T:) as though she became at a distance from the house of her father. (ISh, TA.) And baAna, (M,) or baAna bimaAlK, aor. yabiynu, (T,) inf. n. buyuwnN (T, M) and bayonN, (M,) He became separated from his father, or mother, or both, by property [which he received from him, or her, or them,] (AZ, T, M,) to be his alone: (AZ, T:)
and El-Fárisee states, on the authority of AZ, that one says also, baAna Eanohu and baAnahu [the former app. meaning he became separated thus from him, i. e., from his father; and the latter being syn. with OabaAnahu, q. v.]. (M.) And baAna AlxaliyTu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, [The partner, or copartner, or sharer,, &c., became separated from the person, or persons, with whom he had been associated.] (T.) And baAnato yadu Aln-aAqapi Eano janobihaA, inf. n. buyuwnN, [The fore leg of the she-camel became withdrawn, or apart, from her side.] (T.) And baAna, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and baAnuwA, (Ḳ,) aor. yabiynu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He separated himself, or it separated itself; (Ṣ; [in one copy of which it is said of a thing;]) and they separated themselves: (Ḳ:) or it (a tribe, M, Mṣb) went, journeyed, went away, or departed; and went, removed, retired, or withdrew itself, to a distance, or far away, or far off. (Mṣb.)

baAna, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. yabiynu, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. bayaAnN; (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and AbAn↓, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. UibaAnapN; (T, Mṣb;) and by-n↓, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. taboyiynN; (Ṣ;) and tby-n↓; and AstbAn↓; (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) all signify the same; (T, M, Mṣb;) i. e. It (a thing, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Mṣb) was, or became, [distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and it was, or became, known. (Ḳ.) You say, baAna AlHaq-u [The truth became apparent,, &c.; or known]; as also AbAn↓. (T.) And
qado bay-ana↓ AlS-uboHu liciI Eayonayoni
The dawn has become apparent to him who has two eyes: a prov.: (Ṣ, M:) applied to a thing that becomes altogether apparent, or manifest. (Ḥar p. 542.) And it is said in the Ḳur [ii. 257], qado tabay-ana↓ Alr-uXodu mina AlgaI-i [The right belief hath become distinguished from error]. (TA.) And the lawyers, correctly, use the phrase, kaSawotK laA yasotabiynu↓ minohu HuruwfN [Like a sound whereof letters are not distinguishable]. (Mgh.)

[It seems to be indicated in the TA that baAna, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, also signifies It was, or became, united, or connected; thus having two contr. meanings; but I have not found the verb used in this sense, though bayonN signifies both disunion and union.]
baAnahu, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN: see baAnahu, aor. yabuwnu, inf. n. bawonN, in art. bwn.
See also 2, in two places.
2. by-n, intrans., inf. n. taboyiynN: see 1, in two places.
You say also, by-n AlX-ajaru The trees, (Ḳ,) or the leaves of the trees, (TA,) appeared, when beginning to grow forth. (Ḳ, TA.) And by-n Alqaronu ‡ The horn came forth. (Ḳ, TA.)
by-n binotahu: see 4.

by-nhu, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taboyiynN (T, Ṣ) and tiboyaAnN↓ (T, Ṣ,* Ḳ *) and taboyaAnN; (Ḳ;) the second of which three is an anomalous inf. n., (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) for by rule it should be of the measure tafoEaAlN; (T, Ṣ;) but taboyaAnN is not known except accord. to the opinion of those who allow the authority of analogy, which opinion is outweighed by the contrary; (TA;) and tiboyaAnN is the only inf. n. of its measure except tiloqaMCN, (T, Ṣ,) accord. to the generality of the leading authorities; but some add timovaAlN, as inf. n. of mav-ala; and El-Ḥareeree adds to these two, in the Durrah, tinoDaAlN, as inf. n. of naADalahu; and Esh-Shiháb adds, in the Expos. of the Durrah, tiXoraAbN, as inf. n. of Xariba Alxamora; asserting taXoraAbN also to have been heard, agreeably with analogy; [and to these may be added tabokaMCN and timoXaMCN, and perhaps some other instances of the same kind;] but some disallow tifoEaAlN altogether as the measure of an inf. n., saying that the words transmitted as instances thereof are simple substs. used as inf. ns., like TaEaAmN in the place of UiToEaAmN; (MF, TA;) and Sb says that tiboyaAnN is not an inf. n.; for, where it so, it would be taboyaAnN; but it is, from bay-anotu, like gaArapN from Oagarotu; (M, TA;) [He made it distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] he made it (namely, a thing, T, Ṣ, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Mṣb) apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AbAnhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UibaAnapN; (Mṣb;) and tby-nhu↓; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AstbAnhu↓: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [by-nhu is the most common in this sense: and often signifies he explained it: and he proved it:] and ↓all these verbs signify also he made it known; he notified it: (Ḳ:) or Aisotabanotuhu↓ signifies, (Ṣ,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) I knew it, or became acquainted with it, [or distinguished it,] (Ṣ, Mgh,) clearly, or plainly; (Mgh;) and so tabay-anotuhu↓; (Ṣ,* Mgh;) [and bay-anotuhu, as appears from an ex. in what follows, from a verse of En-Nábighah:] binotuhu↓ and Oabanotuhu↓ and Aisotabanotuhu↓ and bay-anotuhu all signify the same as tabay-anotuhu↓ [app. in all the senses of this verb]: (M:) or, of all these verbs, baAna↓ is only intrans.: (Mṣb:) and Aisotabanotuhu↓ signifies I looked at it, or into it, (namely, a thing,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order that it might become apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, to me: (T, TA:) and tby-nhu↓ he looked at it, or into it, (namely, an affair, or a case,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, or deliberately, in order to know its real state by the external signs thereof. (T.) A poet says,
wamaA xifotu Hat-aI bay-ana AlX-irobu waAlOacaI
bqaAniYapK Oan-iI mina AlHaI-i Oaboyanu↓
[And I feared not until the drinking, or the time of drinking, and molestation, made manifest, or plainly showed, by a deep-red (sun), that I was separated from the tribe: see qaAniYN]. (M.) And it is said in the Ḳur [xvi. 91], waOanozalonaA Ealayoka AlkitaAba tiboyaAnFA likul-i XaIoCK [And we have sent down to thee the Scripture to make manifest everything]; meaning, we make manifest to thee in the Scripture everything that thou and thy people require [to know] respecting matters of religion. (T.) See also bayaAnN, in the latter half of the paragraph. En-Nábighah says,
Uil-aA AlOawaAriI-a m-aA Oubay-inuhaA
[Except the places of the confinement of the beasts: with difficulty did I distinguish them]; meaning Oatabay-anuhaA↓. (Ṣ.) You say also, tabay-ana↓ maA yaOotiyhi, meaning He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or discover, what would happen to him, of good and evil. (M in art. bSr.) [See also 5, below.] walitasotabiyna sabiyla Almujorimiyna, in the Ḳur [vi. 55], means And that thou mayest the more consider, or examine, repeatedly, in order that it may become manifest to thee, the way of the sinners, O Moḥammad: (T:) or that thou mayest seek, or endeavour, to see plainly, or clearly,, &c.; syn. walitasotawoDiHa sabiylahumo: (Bḍ:) but most read, waliyasotabiyna syblu Almjrmyn; the verb in this case being intrans. (T.)

entry.sense: 3. bAynhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mubaAyanapN, (Ṣ,) He separated himself from him; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him: (Ṣ, TA:) or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him; or cut him off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him; or cut him, or ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him. (Ḳ.) [And It became separated from it.]

hom.sense: 4. AbAn, intrans., inf. n. UibaAnapN: see 1, in two places.

AbAnhu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He separated it, severed it, disunited it, or cut it off. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) You say, Darabahu faOabaAna raOosahu (Ṣ, Ḳ) He smote him and severed his head, mino jasadihi from his body. (Ṣ, TA.) And AbAn AlmaroOapa He (the husband) separated the woman, or wife, by divorce. (Mṣb.) And AbAn binotahu, and by-nhA↓, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former as above, and of the latter taboyiynN, (TA,) He married, or gave in marriage, his daughter, (T, Ḳ,) and she went to her husband: (T:) from bayonN signifying “distance:” as though he removed her to a distance from the house, or tent, of her mother. (TA.) And AbAn Qbonahu bimaAlK, (M,) or AbAnhu OabawaAhu, (T,) He separated from himself his son, (M,) or his two parents separated him from themselves, (T,) by [giving him] property, (T, M,) to be his alone: (T:) mentioned on the authority of AZ. (T, M.) And AbAn Ald-alowa Eano TiI-i AlbiYori He drew away the bucket from the casing of the well, lest the latter should lacerate the former. (M.)
See also 2, in three places.

[Hence, AbAn signifies also He spoke, or wrote, perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, as to meaning; or, with eloquence: from bayaAnN, q. v.] And AbAn Ealayohi He spoke perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, and gave his testimony, or evidence, or gave decisive information, against him, or respecting it. (TA.) [The verb thus used is for AbAn kalaAmahu, and XahaAdatahu.] One says of a drunken man, maA yubiynu kalaAmFA He does not speak plainly, or distinctly; lit., does not make speech plain, or distinct. (Ks, T in art. bt.)
[maA Oaboyanahu How distinct, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, is it! See an ex. voce basula.]
[And How perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, is he in speech, or writing! how good is his bayaAn!]
5. tby-n, intrans.: see 1, in two places.
As a trans. verb: see 2, in seven places.

[Hence,AlOamora being understood,] He sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge [of the thing], until he knew [it]; he examined, scrutinized, or investigated: (Bḍ in xlix. 6:) he sought, or endeavoured, to make the affair, or case, manifest, and to settle it, or establish it, and was not hasty therein: (Idem in iv. 96:) or he acted, or proceeded, deliberately, or leisurely, in the affair, or case; not hastily: (Ks, TA:) or it has a signification like this: in the Ḳur ch. iv. v. 96 and ch. xlix. v. 6, some read fatabay-anuwA, and others fatavab-atuwA; and the meanings are nearly the same: Alt-abay-unu was said by Moḥammad to be from God, and AlEajalapN [i. e. “haste”] from the devil. (T.)

entry.sense: 6. tbAynA They two (namely, two men, and two copartners,) became separated, each from the other: (M, TA:) or they forsook, or abandoned, each other; or cut each other off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, each other. (Ḳ.) And tbAynwA They, having been together, became separated: (Mṣb:) or they forsook, or abandoned, one another; or cut one another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, one another. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, They two were dissimilar: and they two (namely, words,) were disparate; whether contraries or not: and they two (namely, numbers,) were incommensurable.]

hom.sense: 10. AstbAn, intrans.: see 1.
As a trans. verb: see 2, in six places.

entry.sense: baAnN a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {baAnapN}: see art. bwn.

hom.sense:
bayonN has two contr. significations; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) one of which is Separation, or disunion [of companions or friends or lovers]. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, caAtu Albayoni as meaning Enmity, and vehement hatred: and the saying liUiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni, i. e. For the reforming, or amending, of the bad, or corrupt, state subsisting between the people, or company of men; meaning for the allaying of the discord, enmity, rancour, or vehement hatred: (Mṣb:) [but this has also the contr. meaning, as will be seen below: and it is explained as having a vague import; for it is said that] fiI UiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni means In the reforming, or amending, of the circumstances subsisting between the persons to whom it relates, by frequent attention thereto. (Mgh.) [Hence also,] guraAbu Albayoni [The raven of separation or disunion; i. e., whose appearance, or croak, is ominous of separation: said by some to be] the grAb termed OaboqaEu [i. e. in which is blackness and whiteness; or having whiteness in the breast]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so described by the poet 'Antarah: (Ṣ:) or that which is red in the beak and legs; but the black is called AlHaAtimu, because it makes [or shows] separation to be absolutely unavoidable, (Abu-1-Ghowth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) according to the assertion of the Arabs, i. e., by its croak: (Mṣb in art. Htm:) [or it is any species of the corvus:] Hamzeh says, in his Proverbs, that this name attaches to the grAb because, when the people of an abode go away to seek after herbage, it alights in the place of their tents, searching the sweepings: (Ḥar p. 308:) but accord. to the Kádee of Granada, Aboo-ʼAbd-Allah Esh-Shereef, this appellation, so often occurring in poetry, properly signifies camels that transport people from one district, or country, to another; and he cites the following verses:
galiTa Al-aciyna raOayotuhumo bijahaAlapK
yaloHawona kul-uhumu guraAbFA yanoEaqu
maA Alc-anobu Uil-aA liloOabaAEiri Uin-ahaA
mim-aA yuXat-itu jamoEahumo wayuqar-iqu
Uin-a AlguraAba biyumonihi tadonuw Aln-awaI
watuXat-itu AlX-amola AljamiyEa AlOayonuqu
[Those have erred whom I have seen, with ignorance, all of them blaming a raven croaking: the fault is not imputable save to the camels; for they are of the things that scatter and disperse their congregation: verily the place that is the object of a journey is brought near by the raven's lucky omen; but the she-camels discompose the united state]: and Ibn-ʼAbd-Rabbih says,
zaEaqa AlguraAbu faqulotu Oakocabu TaAYirK
Uin l-amo yuSad-iqohu rugaMCu baEiyri
[The raven cried; and I said, A most lying bird, if the grumbling cry of a camel on the occasion of his being laden do not verify it]. (TA in art. grb.)

Also Distance, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by the space, or interval, between two things. (Mṣb.) You say, bayona Albaladayoni bayonN Between the two countries, or towns,, &c., is a distance, of space, or interval: (Mṣb:) and bayonahumaA bayonN Between them two is a distance, with I when corporeal distance is meant: (Idem in art. bwn:) or Uin-a bayonahumaA labayonN [Verily between them two is a distance], not otherwise, in the case of [literal] distance. (Ṣ.) And you say also, bayonahumaA bayonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, Ṣ, M *) and bawonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, Ṣ, M,* Mṣb * in art. bwn) Between them two [meaning two men] is a [wide] distance; (M;) i. e. between their two degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Mṣb in art. bwn:) in this case, the latter is the more chaste. (Ṣ.) You also say, [using byn to denote An interval of time,] laqiytuhu buEayodaAti bayonK [I met him after, or a little after, an interval, or intervals,] when you have met him after a while, and then withheld yourself from him, and then come to him. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ. [See also baEodu.])

Also Union [of companions or friends or lovers]; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the contr. of the first of the significations mentioned above in this paragraph. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.) [Hence caAtu Albayoni as meaning The state of union or concord or friendship or love subsisting between a people or between two parties; this being likewise the contr. of a signification assigned to the same expression above: whence the phrase, UifosaAdu caAti Albayoni (occurring in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Abr, and often elsewhere,) The marring, or disturbance, of the state of union or concord, &c.: and] hence the saying, saEaI fulaAnN liUiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni mino EaXiyratihi [Such a one laboured for the improving of the state of union or concord, &c. of his kinsfolk; but in this instance, the meaning given in the second sentence of this paragraph seems to be more appropriate]. (Ḥam p. 569.)
caAtu bayonihimo may also be used as meaning The vacant space (saAHap) that is between their houses, or tents. (Ḥam p. 195.)

bayon is also an adverbial noun, [as such written bayona,] (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) capable of being used as a noun absolutely: (M, Ḳ:) it relates only to that which has space, as a country; or to that which has some number, either two or more, as two men, and a company of men; and denotes [intervention in] the interval between two things, or the middle, or midst, of two things, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or the middle of a collective number: (Ṣ:) [thus it signifies Between, and amidst, and among:] its meaning is [therefore] vague, not apparent unless it is prefixed to two or more [words, or to a word signifying two or more], or to what supplies the place of such a complement: (Mṣb:) it must necessarily be prefixed, and may not be otherwise than in the manners just explained: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it may not be prefixed to any noun but such as denotes more than one, or to a noun that has another conjoined to it by w, (M,) not by any other conjunction, (M, Mṣb,) acc0ord. to the usage commonly obtaining. (Mṣb.) You say bayona Alr-ajulayoni [Between the two men]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [The property is between the company of men]: (M, Mṣb, Er-Rághib:*) and AlmaAlu bayona zayodK waEamorKw [The property is between Zeyd and ʼAmr]: and huwa bayoniI wabayonahu [He, or it, is between me and him]: (M:) and jalasotu bayona Alqawomi I sat in the middle of [or amidst or among] the company of men: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and bayonakumaA AlbaEiyra faxucaAhu, with AlbEyr in the accus. case, [See between you two the camel, therefore take him], a saying heard by Ks: (L in art. End:) and fasada maA bayonahumo [The state subsisting among them became bad, or marred, or disturbed]: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. myT:) and bayona AlOay-aAmi (M and Ḳ in art. ndr) and fiymaA bayona AlOay-aAmi (Ṣ and Mṣb in that art.) [In, or during, the space of (several) days]: and EawaAnN bayona celika, in the Ḳur [ii. 63], is an ex. of its being prefixed to a single word supplying the place of more than one; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the meaning being, Of middle age, between that which has been mentioned; namely, the faAriD and the bikor. (Bḍ.) Some allow that two words to the former of which bayona is prefixed may be connected by fa, citing as an evidence the phrase used by Imra-el-Ḳeys, bayona Ald-axuwli faHawomali [as though meaning Between Ed-Dakhool and Howmal]: but to this it has been replied that Aldxwl is a name applying to several places; so that the phrase [means amidst Ed-Dakhool, &c., and] is similar to the saying, AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [mentioned above, or jalasotu bayona Alqawomi, also mentioned above]. (Mṣb.) [You say also, bayona OaZohurihimo, and bayona Zahorayohimo, &c., meaning In the midst of them. (See art. Zhr.) And bayona yadayohi, and bayona yadayohimo, meaning Before him, and before them. bayon is also often used absolutely as a noun: thus it is in the Ḳur lxxxvi. 7, yaxoruju mino bayoni AlS-ulobi waAlt-araAYibi Coming forth from between, or amidst, the spine and the breast-bones: and in xxxvi. 8 of the same, wajaEalonaA mino bayoni Oayodyhimo sad-FA And we have placed before them (lit. between their hands) a barrier.]
It is said in the Ḳur [vi. 94], laqado taqaT-aEa bayonukumo, as some read; or bayonakumo, as others: (T, Ṣ, M:) the former means Verily your union hath become dissevered: (AA, T, Ṣ, M:) the latter, that which was between you; (maA bayonakumo, Ibn-Mesʼood, T, Ṣ, or Ql-aciI kaAna bayonakumo, IAạr, T;) or the state wherein ye were, in respect of partnership among you: (Zj, T:) or the state of circumstances, or the bond, or the love, or affection, [formerly subsisting] among you, or between you; or, accord. to Akh, bayonakumo, though in the accus. case as to the letter, is in the nom. case as to the place, by reason of the verb, and the adverbial termination is retained only because the word is commonly used as an adv. n.: (M:) AḤát disapproved of the latter reading; but wrongly, because what is suppressed accord. to this reading is implied by what precedes in the same verse. (T.)

[It is often used as a partitive, or distributive; as also maA bayona: for ex.,] you say, humo bayona HaAcifK waqaAcifK, (Ṣ and TA in art. qcf,) or humo maA bayona HaAcfK wqAcfK, (TA in art. Hcf,) i. e. [They are partly, or in part,] beating with the staff, or stick, and [partly, or in part,] pelting with stones; [or some beating, &c., and the others pelting, &c.] (Ṣ and TA, both in art. qcf, and the latter in art. Hcf.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce xayoTapN.]

hecaA bayona bayona means This (namely, a thing, Ṣ, or a commodity, Mṣb) is between good and bad: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or of a middling, or middle, sort: (M:) these two words being two nouns made one, and indecl., with fet-ḥ for their terminations, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like xamosapa EaXara. (Mṣb.) Alhamozapu Almuxaf-afapu [i. e. the hemzeh uttered lightly] is called hamozapN bayona bayona, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) i. e. A hemzeh that is between the hemzeh and the soft letter whence is its vowel; (Ṣ, M;) or hamozapu bayoni bayonK, the first byn with kesreh but without tenween, and the second with tenween, (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab,) [i. e. the hemzeh, &c.:] if it is with fet-ḥ, it is between the hemzeh and the alif, as in saAala, (Ṣ, M,) for saOala; (M;) if with kesr, it is between the hemzeh and the yé, as in sayima, (Ṣ, M,) for saYima; (M;) and if with damm, it is between the hemzeh and the wáw, as in lawuma, (Ṣ, M,) for laWuma: (M:) it is never at the beginning of a word, because of its nearness, by reason of feebleness, to the letter that is quiescent, (Ṣ, M,) though, notwithstanding this, it is really movent: (Ṣ:) it is thus called because it is weak, (Sb, Ṣ, M,) not having the power of the hemzeh uttered with its proper sound, nor the clearness of the letter whence is its vowel. (M.) ʼObeyd Ibn-El-Abras says,
taHomiI HaqiyqatanaA wabaEoDu
Alqawomi yasoquTu bayona bayonaA
i. e. [Thou defendest what we ought to defend, or our banner, or standard, while some of the people, or company of men,] fall, one after another, in a state of weakness, not regarded as of any account: (Ṣ:) or it is as though he said, between these and these; like a man who enters between two parties in some affair, and falls, or slips, or commits a mistake, and is not honourably mentioned in relation to it: so says Seer: (IB, TA:) or between entering into fight and holding back from it; as when one says, Such a one puts forward a foot, and puts back another. (TA.)

bayonaA↓ and bayonamaA↓ are of the number of inceptive Huruwf: (M, Ḳ:) this is clear if by Hrwf is meant “words:” that they have become particles, no one says: they are still adv. ns.: (MF, TA:) the former is bayona with its [final] fet-ḥah rendered full in sound; and hence the A; (Mughnee in the section next after that of wA, and Ḳ;) [i. e.,] it is of the measure faEolaI [or faEolaA] from Albayon, the [final] fet-ḥah being rendered full in sound, and so becoming A; and the latter is bayona with maA [restrictive of its government] added to it; and both have the same meaning [of While, or whilst]: (Ṣ:) or the A in the former is the restrictive A; or, as some say, it is a portion of the restrictive mA [in the latter]: (Mughnee ubi suprà:) and these do not exclude bayona from the category of nouns, but only cut it off from being prefixed to another noun: (MF, TA:) they are substitutes for that to which bayona would otherwise be prefixed: (Mgh:) some say that these two words are adv. ns. of time, denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; and they are prefixed to a proposition consisting of a verb and an agent, or an inchoative and enunciative; so that they require a complement to complete the meaning. (TA.) One says, bayonaA naHonu kacelika Uico Hadava kacaA [While we were in such a state as that, lo, or there, or then, such a thing happened, or came to pass]: (M, Mgh,* Ḳ:*) and bayonamaA naHonu kacaA [While we were thus]: (Mgh:) and
bayonaA naHonu naroqubuhu OataAnaA
[While we were looking, or waiting, for him, he came to us]; (Ṣ, M;) a saying of a poet, cited by Sb; (M;) the phrase being elliptical; (Ṣ, M;) meaning bayona OawoqaAti naHonu naroqubuhu, (M,) i. e., bayona OawoqaAti riqobatinaA Uiy-aAhu [between the times of our looking, or waiting, for him]. (Ṣ, M.) As used to put nouns following bayonaA in the gen. case when bayona might properly supply its place; as in the saying (of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, which he thus recited, with kesr, Ṣ),
bayonaA taEan-uqihi AlkumaApa warawogihi
yawomFA OutiyHa lahu jariIoCN salofaEu
[Amid his embracing the courageous armed men, and his guileful eluding, one day a bold, daring man was appointed for him, to slay him]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in [some copies of] the Ḳ, taEan-ufihi; but in the Deewán [of the Hudhalees], tEn-qh: [in the Mughnee, ubi suprà, taEaAnuqihi:] the meaning is bayona taEaAnuqihi; the A being added to give fulness to the sound of the [final] vowel: (TA:) Aṣ used to say that the A is here redundant: (Skr, TA:) others put the nouns following both bayonaA and bayonamaA in the nom. case, as the inchoative and enunciative. (Skr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Mbr says that when the noun following bynA is a real subst., it is put in the nom. case as an inchoative; but when it is an inf. n., or a noun of the inf. kind, it is put in the gen., and bynA in this instance has the meaning of bayona: and Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà says the like, but some persons of chaste speech treat the latter kind of noun like the former: after bynmA, however, each kind of noun must be in the nom. case. (AA, T.) [See an ex. in a verse cited towards the end of art. Ac.]

entry.sense: biynN A separation, or division, (T, M, Ḳ,) between two things, (T,) or between two lands; (M, Ḳ;) as when there is a rugged place, with sands near it, and between the two is a tract neither rugged nor plain: (T:) an elevation in rugged ground: (M, Ḳ:) the extent to which the eye reaches, (T, M, Ḳ,) of a road, (T,) or of land: (M:) a piece of land extending as far as the eye reaches: (T, Ṣ:) and a region, tract, or quarter: (AA, T, M, Ḳ:) pl. buyuwnN. (Ṣ, TA.)

bayaAnN is originally the inf. n. of baAna as syn. with tabay-ana, and so signifies The being [distinct or] apparent, &c.; (Kull;) or it is a subst. in this sense: (Mṣb:) or a subst. from bay-ana, [and so signifies the making distinct or apparent, &c.,] being like salaAmN and kalaAmN from sal-ama and kal-ama. (Kull.)

Hence, conventionally, (Kull,) The means by which one makes a thing [distinct,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (Ṣ, Er-Rághib, TA, Kull:) this is of two kinds: one is [a circumstantial indication or evidence; or] a thing indicating, or giving evidence of, a circumstance, or state, that is a result, or an effect, of a quality or an attribute: the other is a verbal indication or evidence, either spoken or written: [see also bay-inapN:] it is also applied to language that discovers and shows the meaning that is intended: and an explanation of confused and vague language: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the eduction of a thing from a state of dubiousness to a state of clearness: or making the meaning apparent to the mind so that it becomes distinct from other meanings and from what might be confounded with it. (TA.)

Also Perspicuity, clearness, distinctness, chasteness, or eloquence, of speech or language: (T, Ṣ:) or simply perspicuity thereof: (Ḥar p. 2:) or perspicuity of speech with quickness, or sharpness, of intellect: (M, Ḳ:) or perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, speech, declaring, or telling plainly, what is in the mind: (Ksh, TA:) or the showing of the intent, or meaning, with the most eloquent expression: it is an effect of understanding, and of sharpness, or quickness, of mind, with perspicuity, or chasteness, or eloquence, of speech: (Nh, TA:) or a faculty, or principles, [or a science,] whereby one knows how to express [with perspicuity of diction] one meaning in various forms: (Kull:) [some of the Arabs restrict the science of AlbyAn to what concerns comparisons and tropes and metonymies; which last the Arabian rhetoricians distinguish from tropes: and some make it to include rhetoric altogether:] Esh-Shereeshee says, in his Expos. of the Maká- mát [of El-Ḥareeree] that the difference between bayaAnN and tiboyaAnN↓ is this: that the former denotes perspicuity of meaning; and the latter, the making the meaning to be understood;
and the former is to another person, and the latter to oneself; but sometimes the latter is used in the sense of the former: (TA:) or the former is the act of the tongue, and the latter is the act of the mind: (Ḥar p. 2:) or the former concerns the verbal expression, and the latter concerns the meaning. (Kull.) It is said in a trad., Uin-a mina AlbayaAni siHorFA (Ṣ) or lasiHorFA (TA) [Verily there is a kind of eloquence that is enchantment: see this explained in art. sHr]. The saying in the Ḳur [lv. 2 and 3], xalaqa QloUinosaAna Eal-amahu QlobayaAna means He hath created the Prophet: He hath taught him the Ḳur-án wherein is the manifestation of everything [needful to be known]: or He hath created Adam, or man as meaning all mankind: He hath [taught him speech, and so] made him to discriminate, and thus to be distinguished from all [other] animals:(Zj, T:) or He hath taught him that whereby he is distinguished from other animals, namely, the declaration of what is in the mind, and the making others to understand what he has perceived, for the reception of inspiration, and the becoming acquainted with the truth, and the learning of the law. (Bḍ.)

It is also applied to Verbosity, and the going deep, or being extravagant, in speech, and affecting to be perspicuous, or chaste, therein, or eloquent, and pretending to excel others therein; or some byAn is thus termed; and is blamed in a trad., as a kind of hypocrisy; as though it were a sort of self-conceit and pride. (TA.)

biYorN bayuwnN A well of which the rope does not strike against the sides, because its interior is straight: or that is wide in the upper part, and narrow in the lower: or in which the drawer of water makes the rope to be aloof from its sides, because of its crookedness: (T:) or deep and wide; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because the ropes are wide apart from its sides; (Ṣ;) as also baAYinapN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) or that is wide between the two [opposite] sides: (M:) pl. [regularly of the latter epithet] bawaAYinu. (T, Ṣ.)

bay-inN [Distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also baAYinN↓ (T) and mubiynN↓: (T, Ṣ:) pl. [of mult.] OaboyinaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] bayinapN. (Ḳ.) Hence, AlkitaAbu AlmubiynN↓ [as applied to the Ḳur, q. v. in xii. 1, &c.,] The clear, plain, or perspicuous, book or writing or scripture: or, as some say, this means the book, &c. that makes manifest all that is required [to be known]: (T:) or, of which the goodness and the blessing are made manifest: or, that makes manifest the truth as distinguished from falsity, and what is lawful as distinguished from what is unlawful, and that the prophetic office of Moḥammad is true, and so are the narratives relating to the prophets: (Zj, T:) or, that makes manifest the right paths as distinguished from the wrong. (M, TA.) And kalaAmN bay-inN Perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste, or eloquent, language. (T.)
A man, or thing, bearing evidence of a quality, &c. that he, or it, possesses. (Ṣ and Ḳ and other Lexicons passim.)

A man (M) perspicuous, or clear, or distinct, in speech or language; or chaste therein; or eloquent; (ISh, T, M, Ḳ;) fluent, elegant, and elevated, in speech, and having little hesitation therein: (ISh, T:) pl.
